column2: SAIGON, May 9 Anti-Government Buddhist leaders in South Vietnam commented cautiously today on Premier Nguyen Cao Ky's weekend assertion that his junta would remain in power for at least another year.

SOUTH AMBOY, N.J. May 9 (AP) A Jersey Central Railroad train rolled north through here just after 5:30 A.M. today and a Pennsylvania Railroad train followed a few minutes later over the newly repaired Raritan River railroad bridge.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) The General Services Administration moved today to encourage expansion of domestic copper production.

ROME, May 10 (AP) Nicola Pietrangeli of Italy upset top-seeded Roy Emerson of Australia in a three-hour match today, 3-6, 6-1, 3-6, 8-6, 6-1, and went into the final of the Italian international tennis tournament against Tony Roche.
The Royal National Bank of New York announced here yesterday the election of Seymour I. Baum as a director. The board seat was held by Mr. Baum's father, Isidore Baum, who died last April.
A V-shaped apartment building rising in the Riverdale area of the Bronx has been named the Winston Churchill with the authorization of the late statesman's widow, Lady Clementine Spencer-Churchill.

THE hottest ticket in town last weekend was to a showing of Herbert Marshall McLuhan, author, lecturer, philosopher, critic, celebrity, director of the Center for Culture and Technology, at the University of Toronto, and by-now legendary interpreter of new media phenomena to those who would be with it. The event took place at the Kaufmannaudi- torium of the 92nd Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A., famous` for poetry readings, critical symposia and occasional literary scandals.
WASHINGTON, MAY 10 Gov. George Romney of Michigan told Congress today that the automobile industry could be thrown "into a tailspin" by ill-considered traffic safety legislation.
CHICAGO, May 10, (AP) Orlando Cepeda slammed his first home run for St. Louis and Bob Gibson scattered six hits today in pacing the Cards to an 8-0 victory over the Chicago Cubs.
BETHESDA, Md., May 10 Miss Jan Waring Tupper and Terence Cogley plan to marry on June 11 in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York.
A former campaign worker for Mayor Lindsay has received the Republican designation for the City Council seat left vacant by Representative Theodore R. Kupferman.

Thomas S. Lamont, a director of the Texas Gulf Sulphur Company, testified in Federal Court here yesterday that he made a telephone call to an executive vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company after the mining concern had announced a rich copper strike. But he declared that he neither disclosed the contents of the press release concerning the discovery nor advised the official to buy stock.
SOUTHPORT, Conn., May 10--Thomas E. Maytham, a New York advertising executive for many years, died yesterday at his home here. He was 70 years old and lived at 104 Main Street.

A gift with a potential value of $5-million was offered to the National Music Camp and Arts Academy at Interlochen, Mich., last night by W. Clement Stone of Chicago. Mr. Stone is president of the Combined Insurance Company of America, board chairman of Hawthorn Books, Inc., author of two books on the principles of success, and co-producer in 1963 of a shortlived Broadway play.
The London Stock Exchange rallied strongly in afternoon dealings yesterday, wiping out or reducing earlier losses. Sentiment was helped by expectations of a rally on Wall Street.

EAST LONGMEADOW, Mass. May 10--Mr. and Mrs. John L. Johnson have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Ann Johnson, to Robert Dorff Carraway. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Carraway Jr. of Chester.

Operations of Warner Bros. Pictures, Inc., in the six months ended Feb. 26 resulted in sharply higher revenues and earnings than in the corresponding period a year earlier, the semi-annual report disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 10 Senator Clifford P. Case said today that a recent New Jersey poll indicated he would win reelection to a third term over former Democratic Gov. Robert B. Meyner by more than 500,000 votes.

A newly formed Roman Catholic group called the Catholic Committee on Population and Government Policy announced its support yesterday for governmental assistance to family planning programs at home and abroad.
The City University of New York is in the position of a nation that has just recovered from civil war, only to find itself under fire under a jealous neighbor.
UPPER MARLBORO, Md., May 10 (UPI) The wife of a former Kansas Congressman was found guilty today of manslaughter for slaying her son and three daughters.
DETROIT, May 10 (UPI) An explosion in a soap factory rocked a mile-square area today, shattering windows at an elementary school two blocks away and showering nearly 100 children with flying glass.

WASHINGTON, May 10 The American Bankers Association proposed a group of amendments today to the Administration's bill expanding the Government's authority to police unsound practices by banks and savings and loan associations. It said it would support the legislation if its amendments were adopted.
OMAHA, Neb., May 10 Lieut. Gov. Philip C. Sorensen won the Democratic nomination for Governor in Nebraska's primary election tonight.

NORWALK, Conn., May 10 Fred Schwed Jr., author and humorist, died today in Norwalk Hospital. He was 64 years old and had lived in Rowayton for 25 years. Since suffering a stroke in 1960, he had lived in a sanitorium in Stamford.
BOSTON, May 10 (AP) An 18-inch gila monster, which has a tenacious bite that handlers say could kill a child, was the object of a wide search here today.
WILMINGTON, Del., May 10 Former Senator Daniel O. Hastings died last night in a nursing home after an illness of several months. He was 92 years old.
Turin, Italy, May 10 (UPI) Tennis teams of Hungary, Canada, Rhodesia, Sweden and Poland today won their way into the Federation Cup, women's equivalent of the Davis Cup.
THE landlocked salmon is one of the finest game fishes an angler can hope to encounter. And now is the time to encounter him in the deep, cold lakes of the north.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., May 10 Mr. and Mrs. LeRoy Marceau have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sandra Elaine Marceau, to Peter M. Briggs, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Briggs of Plymouth, Mass.
Channel 13 will devote three programs during the week beginning May 22 to a celebration of one of the 20th century's greatest and most difficult novels, James Joyce's "Finnegans Wake."
WASHINGTON, May 10 Governor Rockefeller urged congress today to enact the federal program under which narcotics addicts not charged with any crime could be committed for compulsory treatment.

SAIGON, May 10 Almost all the casualties in the terrorist bombing this morning in downtown Saigon were inflicted by the gunfire of overwrought American military policemen, United States officials acknowledged tonight.
BERLIN, May 10 "We would not think of giving up the security of our republic for a dish of lentils," the tenants of 36 Forsthaus Allee in East Berlin declare in an open letter in Neues Deutschland.
Robert Moses contends that the Lindsay administration's plan for vest-pocket parks is "very expensive and impossible to administer."
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector, May 10 Dr. Konrad Adenauer left Israel today after an eight-day private visit. The former West German Chancellor said his reception had been "much nicer than I had hoped."
Two new publications may be of interest to families who are beginning to make plans for the summer.
The trustees of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine are to resume construction of the unfinished Morningside Heights landmark, which has been left untouched for 25 years.
The American Stock Exchange turned in its best performance in more than a week yesterday. Most stocks bounced back after their recent weakness. Trading, however, was comparatively quiet.
NEW DELHI, May 10 India alleged today that Mizo rebels were being trained at three camps in East Pakistan.
CHICAGO, May 10 Dr. James F. Redmond of Syosset, L.I., was chosen today to become superintendent of Chicago public schools, the highest paid public education job in the country.

WASHINGTON, May 10 The Justice Department, in a turnabout that followed protests by Italian-American leaders, sued today to block the publication of the memoirs of Joseph M. Valachi, the convicted Mafia figure.
The Bank of New York, the city's oldest bank, announced yesterday that its board of trustees had approved a two-for-one stock split.

Councilman Robert A. Low, who headed the air-pollution study that led to passage of a bill tightening the control over fuels used here, declared yesterday the city "should take drastic steps now" for still further antipollution measures.

WASHINGTON, May 10 President Johnson and the highest Administration officials met with Ambassador Henry Cabot Lodge late today for a review of the military, economic and political situation in South Vietnam.
Water in various forms is playing a major, if somewhat tongue-in-cheek, role in a new advertising campaign by Schieffelin Co. for its Teacher's Scotch.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 10 (AP) Stocks representing the 75 per cent interest of Howard R. Hughes in Trans World Air lines, Inc., changed hands today for $546,549,171. Mr. Hughes who has avoided any public appearances for many years, was not present for the transaction one of the largest stock transfers in history.
Mrs. Donald F. Hyde has been elected to the board of trustees of The Pierpont Morgan Library. Henry S. Morgan, president of the Library, made the announcement yesterday. He said:
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 10 Antonio Patricio, Acting Chief Delegate of Portugal, denied today that the Portuguese territory of Mozambique had become the chief source of oil for neighboring Rhodesia.
The Rev. Joseph H. Titus, rector of Grace Episcopal Church, Jamaica, Queens, from 1930 to 1963, died on Monday in his home at 155-01 90th Avenue, Jamaica. He was 72 years old.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 10 Secretary General Thant conferred today with the Chief Delegates of Cyprus and Greece on new efforts to find a way out of the impasse between the Greek and Turkish ethnic communities on Cyprus.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 10 Kenneth A. Cox, Federal Communications Commissioner, said today he was finding that television "has its ups and downs," with the season's new programs "not as interesting as in some past seasons."
David L. Cole, mediator in the newspaper strike, said last night that he was pressing the 10 unions and The World Journal Tribune, Inc., to intensify their efforts to resolve the dispute.
KINGSTON, Jamaica, May 10 (AP) The United States will play the West Indies here in the second round of Davis Cup tennis competition on May 19, 21 and 22, officials said today.

ATLANTA, May 10 (UPI) The Cincinnati Reds swept a double-header from the Atlanta Braves tonight, with Milt Pappas winning, 8-0, on a fourhitter in the second game after Jim Maloney and Don Nottebart combined to pitch a threehit 8-2 triumph in the opener.

NAIROBI, Kenya, May 10 President Jomo Kenyatta disclosed today that Kenya, Uganda and Tanzania had been unable to agree on means of preserving the economic cooperation the three countries began before any of them were independent.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., May 10 J.W. Fulbright, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, warned today that American universities were failing in their "higher purposes" as a result of the "stiflingly close" relationship that they had developed with the Federal Government.
DETROIT, May 10 The Chrysler Corporation said today that two of its seven automobile assembly plants would shut down for four days after the Memorial Day holiday.
Mayor Lindsay's top adviser on water policy said yesterday he would confer tomorrow with officials of the Delaware River Basin Commission on whether to permit the watering of plants and shrubs.

THE HAGUE, May 10 (Reuters) West Germany lost two more supersonic Starfighters today when they collided and plunged into the North Sea during a training exercise by members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
A preliminary investigation has failed to disclose any traffic in LSD at the High School of Music and Art, school officials said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) The House Education and Labor Committee rejected today on party-line votes a string of Republican amendments to the antipoverty bill.

WASHINGTON, May 10 The voluntary balance-of-payments program for corporations will produce an estimated contribution of only $919-million toward reducing the payments deficit this year, far less than the Government had originally expected, a Commerce Department report disclosed today.

The village of Garden City, L.I., long known for its fine homes and shops, has become a center of offices for white-collar service industries that are spreading in the wake of Long Island's population and factory booms.

WASHINGTON, May 10 Representative Adam Clayton Powell denounced today the forthcoming draft deferment tests as "reminiscent of Hitler," the foundation for a "racial aristocracy" and a device that would send a disproportionate number of Negroes to the "Vietnam slaughterhouse."
WASHINGTON, May 10 Robert W. Adams, special assistant to the Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, died yesterday in Fairfax Hospital, Virginia, following surgery. He was 50 years old.
The state rested its case yesterday on the seventh day of the conspiracy and bribery trial of L. Judson Morhouse, former Republican state chairman.
The British pound was firm in light trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. Volume was small. The spot rate closed at $2.7934, down a point from Monday.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 10 The unbeaten Army baseball team registered its l2th victory of the season today, defeating St. John's, 10-0, behind the onehit pitching of Barry de Bolt. The cadets scored six runs in the second inning.

Enormous toy animals on loan from F.A.O. Schwarz will adorn the Tavern-on-the-Green for the Safari Ball on May 19. Other decorations will be monkeys hanging from the rafters, leopard-spotted table cloths and impala, leopard and zebra skins.

Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Manheim of 2 East 88th Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katherine Manheim, to Charles Edward Magowan. He is the son of Edward S. Magowan of New York and Hobe Sound, Fla., and Mrs. David Osborn of New York.
CARACAS, Venezuela, May 10 The United State Secretary of Labor, W. Willard Wirtz, today criticized the lag in social progress among members of the Alliance for Progress.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 10 The California Supreme Court today prohibited racial discrimination in the disposal of property. In a 5-to-2 ruling, the justices held invalid an amendment to the State Constitution that permitted such discrimination. It held that the amendment violated the 14th Amendment to the Federal Constitution.
DOVER, Del., May 10 (UPI)--The Equity Corporation has sold some of its holdings in recent weeks and will sell more, Jacob Isbrandtsen, chairman, told the annual meeting today.

CLEVELAND, May 10 (AP) The Right Rev. Stefan Lastavica, Bishop of the Eastern United States and Canadian Diocese of the Serbian Eastern Orthodox Church, died today of cancer in Parma Community Hospital. He was 58 years old.
Howard Eliot Drake, real estate counselor, died yesterday in Dobbs Ferry (N.Y.) Hospital after a short illness. He was 67 years old and lived at 465 Broadway, Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y.

LONDON, May 10 Responding to pressure from the United States, an international committee recommended today a stiffening of maritime fireprevention regulations that would put potential Yarmouth Castles out of business.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 10 Medicare portends wide changes in the care of mental patients, the American Psychiatric Association was told today.

TEL AVIV, May 10 Justice Minister Yaakov Shapiro told the Knesset (parliament) in Jerusalem today that the American marriage of an Israeli Supreme Court judge to a divorcee was no circumvention of Israeli law.

The International Business Machines Corporation announced yesterday that it filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering its previously announced subscription offering of capital stock.
When the real Fred Pohl stood up yesterday at a luncheon given in his honor by his publishers, it was to shake hands with the real Fred Pohl, guest of honor at a luncheon given by his publishers.
Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner disclosed yesterday that he had taken on a parttime non-paying post as chairman of the board of the Library of Presidential Papers.

Paperboard production rose 11.8 per cent with 469,600 tons in the week ended May 7, from 419,922 tons in the corresponding week, the Paperboard Group of the American Paper Institute reported yesterday.
The Park Slope Civic Council will hold a tour of renovated brownstone houses Sunday from 1 to 4 P.M. on Garfield Place between Seventh and Eighth Avenue in Brooklyn.
Joseph (Joe Bananas) Bonanno, long-missing Mafia leader is alive and hiding somewhere in Europe, a Government source said yesterday.

BRUSSELS, Wednesday, May 11--The elusive agreement on financing the agricultural program of the Common Market--which the six member nations have pursued for more than 13 months--was hammered out this morning as dawn broke.

The turmoil in stock prices on Wall Street has had remarkably little influence on the views of business forecasters. For the most part, they are sticking to their previ- ous predictions that business activity will continue to advance throughout the year.

LONDON, May 10 Authoritative Whitehall sources are talking in terms of 1.2 billion cubic feet a day as the capacity of a natural gas field tapped by the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) and the Royal Dutch-Shell Group in the North Sea.

Registration will begin this morning for the eighth annual American Film Festival at the Biltmore Hotel. The nontheatrical gathering of filmmakers, and educators will also include the competitive screening of more than 600 movies and film strips.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) J. Edgar Hoover quietly observed today his 42d year as director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
The status of merger developments was the theme of several railroad stockholder meetings yesterday.

EVER, since sports was lured into the realm of big business by the irresistible loot available from its new overlord, television, a lot of sentiment has been squeezed out of it. Although not all of this has been too obvious, much of the old-time sports-for-sports-sake approach has yielded to a more mercenary what's-in-it-for-me attitude. Both sides have been to blame, management and labor presuming that athletes can be classified as labor.
WASHINGTON, May 10 Administration forces squeezed out a 4-vote margin in the House tonight to save President Johnson's rent supplement program. The vote was 192 to 188.

Mrs. Gertrude Folks Zimand, one of the country's foremost campaigners against child labor abuses, died yesterday in a fall from her sixth-floor apartment at 242 East 19th Street, near Second Avenue. She was 71 years old.

CAIRO, May 10 Fifty thousand Egyptians gave a cheering welcome today to Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin, who arrived on an official visit aimed at extending Soviet influence in the Middle East and broadening collaboration with President Gamal Abdel Nasser.

A grant of $1.5-million to the National Urban League for a series of three-year demonstration projects to improve housing for minorities in up to eight cities was announced yesterday by the Ford Foundation.
BOSTON, May 10 The first American production of Schoenberg's "Moses and Aron," scheduled for May 22 and 29 by the Opera Company of Boston, has been postponed to Nov. 2 and 6.
The Prudential Insurance Company of America announced yesterday in Newark the election of Frederick E. Rathgeber as executive vice president and Robert A. Beck as senior vice president.
VIENNA, May 10--American and Soviet space findings have revived the idea that the earth may sometimes have a comet-like tail stretching past the orbit of Mars.

MACAO There is wry humor in the fact that the only empire giving any durable appearance in this violently anticolonial age should be Portugal's weakest of all the imperial agglomerations when World War II began.
After the 1:30 P.M. bell yesterday some gravel-voiced traders shouted, "Yea, Yea," at the New York Mercantile Exchange.

CHICAGO, May 10 (AP) Science Research Associates, Inc., the private agency that is administering draft deferment tests to about 800,000 students, said today there had been some errors in assigning students to test centers.
BALTIMORE, May 10 (AP) Johns Hopkins University announced today the appointment of a seven-member advisory board for the publication of the papers and personal letters of Dwight D. Eisenhower.
Apawamis and Somerset Hills became new champions in Westchester and New Jersey districts, respectively, yesterday as the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub team matches were completed.

LONDON, May 10 (UPI) Cassius Clay, the heavyweight champion, boxed three rounds today in preparation for his May 21 fight with Henry Cooper. He had routed the press at a morning news conference, where the exchanges came thick and fast.
WASHINGTON, May 10 Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen broke, his right hip today and will be out of action for several weeks.

MOSCOW, May 10 Leonid I. Brezhnev, leader of the Soviet Communist party, left today on a visit to Rumania, according to qualified diplomats, at a time when talks are going on between Rumania and North Vietnam and just before a planned official visit to Bucharest by Chou En-lai, Premier of Communist China.
WASHINGTON, May 10 Retail sales declined somewhat last month for the first time since August, the Census Bureau reported today.
Auckland, New Zealand Tuna Scanlan, 158 pounds, Samoa, knocked out George Thomas, 162, Calif., 10 rounds.

Emphasizing the international scope of its operations, the Warner-Lambert Pharmaceutical Company plugged its annual stockholders' meeting into London yesterday. With the help of the Early Bird Satellite and a host of technicians on both sides of the Atlantic, 850 shareholders gathered in the Grand Ballroom of the Statler-Hilton Hotel and saw, heard and asked questions of six company executives who had assembled in Broadcast House.

YONKERS, May 10 Inclement weather having curtailed all morning workouts yesterday at Yonkers Raceway, the racing strip there was crowded with trotters and pacers this morning. With several hundred standardbreds being sent through their paces, the horsemen were hard pressed to avoid traffic jams.
SAIGON, Wednesday, May 11 Premier Nguyen Cao Ky confirmed today his statement that he intends to remain in power for another year.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 10 The sound of laughter silly, unrestrained, giggly, but not quite hysterical laughter reverberated through the New York Yankee clubhouse last night. They had just won a tough ball game, 3-2, from the Minnesota Twins, making it three-straight victories since Ralph Houk had replaced Johnny Keane as manager.
NEWARK, Del., May 10 (UPI) Dan Peterson, the 30-year-old Naval Academy freshman basketball coach, was named today head coach at the University of Delaware.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (UPI). Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Auto Mobile Workers Union, urged Congress today to make the auto industry produce safer cars.

Christian A. Herter is gloomy about the prospects for the Kennedy round of tariff-cutting negotiations in Geneva. The former Secretary of State has told a Senate subcommittee the talks are going badly "for much the same reason that American troops have been told to leave France" in short, Gaullist obstructionism.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 10 The Massachusetts Institute of Technology received today a $520,000 contract from the United States Department of Commerce for research in highspeed ground transportation.
PARIS, May 10 Top American and French businessmen ended today two days of private and reasonably frank discussions of their differences.
The outlook appears to be inproving for North Atlantic ship travel.

WASHINGTON, May 10 Communist China's nuclear explosion Sunday was much larger than was at first estimated by the United States and probably exceeded 100 kilotons in yield, Administration sources suggested today.

The nation's leading department-store trade group predicted yesterday that the issue of consumer protection would get hotter and warned that even the reputable retailer was vulnerable "through his own shortcomings."

SAIGON, May 10 United States troops who swept through a densely jungled section near the Cambodian border after a large-scale tear gas attack last week found no evidence of enemy soldiers or installations, a United States spokesman said tonight.

OTTAWA, May 10 (Canadian Press) Prairie members of Parliament asked the St. Lawrence Seaway Authority today to reconsider its proposal to increase tolls 10 per cent on the Montreal-Lake Ontario section of the waterway.
PHILADELPHIA, May 10 (UPI) Sandy Koufax registered his fourth victory of the year tonight as the Los Angeles Dodgers beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 6-1.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 10 Representatives of 30 independent African states called today for an immediate Security Council meeting to consider harsher measures to force Rhodesia to accept rule by the black majority.

BOSTON, May 10 (AP) The Boston Bruins named 33-yearold Harry Sinden as coach to- day in a bid to end seven years of frustration as also-rans in the National Hockey League. Sinden, who directed the Oklahoma Blazers to the Central League playoff championship, was promoted to the post as the N.H.L's youngest coach. Milt Schmidt voluntarily left the bench to move into the front office on a full-time basis.

LONDON, May 10 The House of Lords, donning its reformist clothes, today pushed through major legislative stages bills legalizing abortions and removing the criminal penalty for homosexual practices between consenting adult males in private.
LEXINGTON, Ky., May 10 (AP) "My opinion is that Graustark will not return to racing." Olin Gentry, the manager of Darby Dan Farm, said today. "I just think it would be foolish to race him again."
Charging that Long Island Rail Road executives had been drinking during duty hours, the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen ordered a strike last night that partly disrupted homebound commuter service.

GREAT NECK, L.I., May 10 Gene Borek, natty in a babyblue outfit, kept repeating essentially the same thing as he strode back to the clubhouse after having won his first Long Island Golf Association open championship today.

The United States rowing team that will compete in the world championships at Bled, Yugoslavia, Sept. 8 to 11 will be not only the most complete to represent this country, but also the best accoutered and equipped, and will travel and live in fitting style.

GENEVA, May 10 The Soviet Union dispelled today some of the gloom that has gripped the disarmament conference. It acted as the conference adjourned for five weeks under the shadow of a lack of progress and Communist China's third nuclear test.
Lloyd K. Garrison and Alfred A. Giardino were re-elected president and vice president of the Board of Education yesterday at the board's annual election meeting at 110 Livingston Street.
WASHINGTON, May 10 Senator Robert F. Kennedy urged today that the United States be more discerning in its efforts to organize resistance to Communist subversion in the Western Hemisphere.

Special to The New York Times PHILADELPHIA, May 10 Mrs. Flagler Harris, a granddaughter of Henry M. Flagler, developer of Florida and partner of John D. Rockefeller Sr. in the founding of the Standard Oil Company, died today at Chestnut Hill Hospital. She was 58 years old and lived in Chestnut Hill.
KANSAS CITY, May 10 (AP) Mike Ryan's passed ball on a third strike led to Kansas City's winning run in the 10th inning tonight as the Athletics edged the Boston Red Sox, 3-2.

Stocks advanced yesterday as the market made a jagged recovery from its recent slide. Prices rolled up and down throughout the day but closed well above their final levels of Monday, when the market took its sharpest drop in two and a half years.

RUXTON, Md., May 10 The engagement of Miss Frances Elizabeth Nevill Jackson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Nevill Jackson, to Dr. George Washington Munsick, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Munsick of Morristown, N.J., has been announced by Miss Jackson's parents.
The United States Circuit Court of Appeals upheld yesterday an April 18th District Court ruling calling for the appointment of a receiver for the S P National Corporation and two subsidiaries.
Policemen have been instructed not to lure homosexuals into breaking the law and to "make every effort" to find witnesses whenever an arrest occurs involving homosexual advances to a plainclothesman.
A Government witness, who on Monday told of visits by prostitutes to Hudson County Jail, lapsed into a litany of "I don't recall" under crossexamination by the defense yesterday.

IRVINGTON, N.J., May 10 Frederick Fiducia, a former professional prizefighter, died today in St. Michael's Hospital, Newark, after a heart attack. He was 52 years old and lived here at 78 Berkeley Terrace.
More than 100 boys and girls turned out yesterday at Harlem Houses Playground, Seventh Avenue and 151st Street, for the Eastern Tennis Patrons' first free clinic of the season.

Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio of Newark, running for re-election against five rivals, captured almost half of the total votes cast yesterday but appeared to be forced into a runoff with former Mayor Leo P. Carlin next month.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 10 Sweden proposed today that the financing of peacekeeping operations be based on flexible formulas tailored to each one.
There he stands, ready to serve, a candidate in next month's primary election.
LONDON, May 10 (AP) A New York judge who dabbles in theatricals went into a British high court Tuesday to seek bigger billing for himself in a West End musical. He lost.

The General Telephone Electronics Corporation successfully demonstrated yesterday to some 275 educators and security analysts an electronic "blackboard-by-wire" system aimed at the educational market.

HONG KONG, May 10 Mao Tse-tung, 72-year-old Chairman of the Chinese Communist party, whose name has not been mentioned in reports of public events since Nov. 26, was reported today to have met with leaders of a visiting Albanian delegation.
BONN, May 10 "It was great," Dr. Adenauer declared on his return to Bonn today from his visit to Israel.
Keeping up with Senator Robert Kennedy these days is quite a job. He is running hard a little left of Lyndon and he has clearly transformed and improved his political base here in New York.

W.R. Grace Co. is again holding merger discussions with the Ruberoid Company, in which it now holds a 27 per cent interest. Grace made this disclosure yesterday at its annual shareholder meeting in the New York Hilton Hotel here.

THE fourth of the season's races in the series for the United States Road Racing championship will be run at Bridgehampton, L.I., on Sunday, May 22, with practice and preliminaries on the preceding Saturday. The point score after the first three events at Las Vegas, Nev., Riverside and Monterey, Calif., shows five drivers bunched at the top. Three different drivers have ...

WASHINGTON, May 10 The engagement of Miss Maren Heidelauf, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ulrich Karl Heidelauf of Washington, to Timothy Cobb Robinson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Ripley Robinson of Cape Elizabeth, Me., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents.

LONDON, May 10 Debrett's, that scarlet-and-gold bound authority on peerage, baronetage, knightage and companionage, will make its 164th annual appearance tomorrow weighing in at six pounds and containing more than 42,000 principal names in 3,202 pages.
Investment banking activity was heavy yesterday, but it failed to shed much light on the current state of the money and capital markets.
The ivy in the window boxes at 165 East 64th Street yesterday was a brilliant, unnatural emerald green, the work of Hollywood's technicians rather than of God's little helpers.
Spring was staging a stiff uphill fight to make itself felt in the city and much of the nation yesterday. And although spring officially began March 21, the end of the fight was not quite in sight.

JERUSALEM (Israeli sector), May 10 (UPI) A gun battle broke out between Israeli and Jordan troops on the eastern Negev border today. Four successive truces arranged by the United Nations failed to halt the shooting.

Plans were formulated yesterday for a proposed new professional soccer league involving 11 franchises from coast to coast. Robert R. Herman, the league's president, made the announcement at a meeting in the New York Athletic Club.

If anyone ever doubted it, let there be no more doubts. The Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association has proved it beyond the shadow of a doubt in what "is probably the largest consumer-oriented study ever to come out of the newspaper business."
The stock market went on a roller-coaster ride to recovery yesterday.

WITH many women dressing in styles that seem to shriek, "Look at me!" it was inevitable that some- body would concoct an attention-seeking pearl the size of a cherry tomato. What the fashionables will do with it remains to be seen; the 24-millimeter simulated pearls will cost at least $75 apiece when they enter the market next month.

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, May 10 Play in the World Open Pair Championship and World Women's Pair Championship begin here tomorrow. The United States is on Hudson, N.Y.; George Rapee and Boris Koytchou, both of New York; Robert Jordan and Arthur Robinson, both of Philadelpsia; and James Jacoby and Dr. John Fisher, both of Dallas.
MILTON, Ont., May 10, (Canadian Press) A woman injured in a traffic accident held the car's steering responsible for the mishap, a coroner's inquest was told here today.

Two hundred high school dropouts, working to get the support of New Yorkers for Federal antinarcotics legislation, have asked Senator Robert F. Kennedy to help them get an audience with President Johnson.

Staten Island is linked to the other four boroughs of New York in more ways... than the Verrazano Narrows Bridge and a fivecent ferry ride. More than 20 of the 425 hos- pital, health and welfare agencies affiliated with the Greater New York Fund have their main offices or branches in the Borough of Richmond.
A manuscript nearly 500 years old, lost for centuries and only recently discovered in a pile of presumably worthless paper, may have been written by William Caxton, England's first printer.
CHARLESTON, W. Va., May 10 (AP) John D. Rockefeller 4th led a field of 56 candidates today in winning nomination as a Democratic candidate for the State Legislature.
WASHINGTON, May 10 The Government expects both the pace of the boom and the rate of inflation to "be more moderate" from now to the end of the year, a top Presidential economic adviser said today.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) Spokesmen for the Americanflag ocean liner industry testified today that competitive bidding for military cargoes would scuttle the American merchant marine.
SAIGON, May 10 (AP) Representative Robert P. Griffin, Republican of Michigan, charged today that Unted States commodities shipments to South Vietnam had been "very inadequately handled."
The Gen. Julius Ochs Adler $100 award for superior campus citizenship at New York University was given to Bruce Berger, of Rockville Center, L.I., a senior in the School of Commerce.

HARRISBURG, Pa., May 10 (UPI) State and Federal Aviation agencies began investigation today into the crash of a private plane that killed State attorney general Walter E. Alessandroni, his wife, Ethel, and two other persons on Sunday.

BONN, May 10 Legal experts of West Germany's three major political parties met today to begin drafting a law that would enable East German Communist officials to enter West Germany without being subject to arrest.
An 800,000-share offering of W.T. Grant Company common stock and two smaller corporate stock sales scheduled for yesterday and today have been delayed because of uncertain market conditions.
BALTIMORE, May 10 (AP) The Baltimore Orioles pushed across a run in the 12th inning on two singles, a passed ball and an infield out and beat the Chicago White Sox, 3-2, tonight.
BOSTON, May 10 (AP) Gov. John A. Volpe signed a bill today to ease the 87-yearold Massachusetts law against the dissemination of contraceptives or birth control information.

ALBANY, May 10 Governor Rockefeller today accused Dr. Albert H. Bowker, Chancellor of the City University, of raising "fictitious" issues in barring 2,300 students from admission next fall for the lack of space.

The city Traffic Commissioner, Henry A. Barnes, will return home today from St. Vincent's Hospital where he has been recuperating from a coronary thrombosis since April 15. It was his second heart attack since 1963. He expects to be back at work in his office in mid-June.

The Police Department is embroiled in two quite contradictory legal assaults that seem to us to point a common moral. One is the court action brought by the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association to stop Mayor Lindsay's plan for a police review board with a civilian majority. The other is the joint report by two state legislative committees asserting that existing law bars policemen from membership in the John Birch Society.

IRVING BERLIN is 78 years old today. He does not con- sider this an especially notable achievement. From Toron- to, where he is ministering to the needs of "Annie Get Your Gun," a show he wrote in 1946 with Herbert and Dorothy Fields, Mr. Berlin said yesterday; "I think too much fuss is made over birthdays. Of course I appreciate the well wishes of all, but why should I get credit for ...
ALBANY, May 10 Howard J. Samuels entered the fight for the Democratic nomination for Governor today with an attack on Governor Rockefeller.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 10 The visit of Mr. Brezhnev to Rumania stirred speculation here that there was friction between the Bucharest Government and Moscow.

SANTA ANA, Calif., May 10 (UPI). Mrs. Elizabeth Marvin Corrigan, the wife of the transAtlantic pilot Douglas (Wrong Way) Corrigan, died last night in St. Joseph's hospital in nearby Orange. She was 59 years old.

Buildings Commissioner Charles G. Moerdler requested the police yesterday to take "vigorous steps" to prevent demolition of the old Metropolitan Opera House because no wreckcing permit had been requested or issued.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) Production prospects for the important winter wheat crop declined 2 per cent during April, but the Agriculture Department forecast today that the harvest still would be 7 per cent larger than that of a year earlier and 10 per cent above average.

IN most mases, Annie doesn't live there any more. The maid's room in homes today is a far cry from yesteryear's cell-like interior, which was sparsely furnished with leftover family pieces, had exposed pipes and walls painted a bilious green. And in rare instances where Annie is still in residence, it bears little resemblance to the past, thanks to the talents of some of New York's top decorators.
On an afternoon in which four maiden races were carded on Aqueduct's program, Harry Bartell's favored Hanging Gardens provided a sharp contrast yesterday by sweeping to her third straight triumph.

OTTAWA, May 10 (Canadian Press) Both public lethargy and the indifference of automobile manufacturers are responsible for thousands of traffic deaths each year, the Commons Justice Committee was told today.

Johnny Keane, recently deposed as manager of the Yankees, went to Shea Stadium with his wife last night, possibly to get some solace in watching the New York Mets lose as his erstwhile team so often did under his reign.

The giant of the computer industry, the International Business Machines Corporation, announced yesterday an initial, but not unexpected step, into a new business; the sale of information. The company's first move in this field will be to sell computer-prepared, market-research reports to United States industry. The reports will provide ...

A group of leading Federal and state judges has accused the police and lower courts across the country of aiding organized crime, corruptly or otherwise, by failing to obtain or approve proper search warrants.

LONDON, May 5 The dramatic difference between the soaring aspirations of Africa's independent states and the appalling economic and social conditions that begin where the pavement ends is a basic continuing problem.
Security analysts on both coasts yesterday were treated to some glowing forecasts of 1966 operations by several senior corporate executives.
ALBANY, May 10 By a vote of 61 to 2, the Senate today approved a plan designed to save the historic Metropolitan Opera House "before the wrecking ball starts swinging."
The special mediator in the contract dispute between the city and its registered nurses said yesterday that he hoped to issue recommendations for a settlement by the end of the week.
SYOSSET, L.I., May 10 Dr. Redmond said today that he was "exceedingly pleased" to have been named superintendent of schools in Chicago.
The American Tobacco Company announced here yesterday the election of Robert K. Heimann to the vacant post of executive vice president.

WASHINGTON, May 10 Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall said today that it would probably be a decade before the Administration's drive to clean up the country's water supplies made its full impact.
The Association of the Bar of theh City of New York elected Dr. Russell D. Niles as president for a two-year term, last night.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., May 10 Tufted carpet manufacturers have successfully sold their product wall-to-wall and now are casting a covetous eye on the wall itself as well as the ceiling. Future plans call for covering the nation's patios, golf courses and even the race tracks.

GUATEMALA, May 10 Congress elected Julio Cesar Mendez Montenegro, a law professor, as President in a runoff election today and Clemente Marroquin Rojas, a newspaper publisher, as Vice President. Their four-year term will begin July 1.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Ma. 10 (AP) With their rendezvous and space "float" flight just a week away, the Gemini 9 astronauts participated today in a perfect dual countdown rehearsal that officials termed an excellent omen.
WASHINGTON, May 10--The Communications Satellite Corporation may show its first profit as early as 1967, James McCormack, chairman and chief executive officer, predicted here today.
Juniors and seniors at Queens College will be taking courses under a new marking system next term.

The nation's largest bakery-- the same one whose 250-foot sign aroused the wrath of Robert Moses during the World's Fair--was formally dedicated yesterday by the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company at 131-43 Avery Avenue, Flushing L.I.

With two days to go before the deadline, the future of the Warsaw Convention, which limits the international airlines' liability for accidents to and deaths of passengers, hung in the balance last night.

The decision of the American Bar Association to appoint a blue ribbon commission to study the reform of the Electoral College may lead to fresh progress on this long-standing problem. A similar bar study of Presidential succession and disability helped bring consensus on the constitutional amendment which Congress submitted to the states last year.
A birthday cake will be lighted in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria on Saturday to celebrate the 13th anniversary of the League School for Seriously Disturbed Children.
MADRID, May 10.--The Spanish Government hinted tonight at a compromise with university students.

WASHINGTON, May 10 Representative Emanuel Celler, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, vowed today to "fight to the last inch" to include "Mrs. Murphy's boarding house" in the proposed Federal fair housing bill.

Th City Council's endorsement of major elements in the Lindsay tax program is a constructive and essential first step. But the omissions and reservations in its action make for a mixed victory. Mayor Lindsay declared himself "delighted" and "grateful," which could--unless read in context--give the erroneous conception that he was satisfied. He was not; the fight for fiscal responsibility must go on, to override the mistaken policy that marred the Council action.

The Democratic leaders at City Hall issued a white paper last night on Mayor Lindsay's tax program and budget, accusing the Mayor of perpetrating a hoax in the economies he had promised to make in municipal government.
ELIZABETH, N.J., May 10 Mayor Thomas G. Dunn today ordered the police to examine teen-age youths returning from Staten Island for evidence of drinking.

PITTSBURGH, May 10 (AP) Tom Haller raced home as Len Gabrielson grounded into a force out in the 15th inning tonight and the San Francisco Giants beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 2-1. The victory was the ninth straight for the Giants.

CHERRY HILL, N. J., May 10 (AP)--Don Brumfield, fresh from his triumph in the Kentucky Derby on Kauai King, rode the 6-5 favorite, Meistersinger, to a five-length victory in the feature race at Garden State Park today.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) Vice President Humphrey confided today that he had failed as a cub reporter in college.

Dr. Gosta C. Akerlof, a physical chemist who had been a senior scientist at the Textile Research Institute, Princeton, N.J., since 1965, died Sunday in the Presbyterian Hospital here after a short illness. He was 68 years old and lived at 384 Stockton Road, Princeton.
About half of the nation's 300 living Pulitzer Prize winners spent a glittering and convivial evening at the Plaza Hotel yesterday in honor of the 50th anniversary of the awards.
About half of the nation's 300 living Pulitzer Prize winners spent a glittering and convivial evening at the Plaza Hotel yesterday in honor of the 50th anniversary of the awards.

CANNES, France, May 10 Politics, said somebody, is the tragedy of our times. It can also be a terrible headache for the director of an international film festival. Witness just one of the political tangles that Robert Favre le Bret, the director of the current Cannes exposition, found himself caught in recently and out of which he wiggled, with a little help, last night.

WICHITA, Kan., May 10 (AP) The Lear Jet Corporation said today it had asked owners of the more than 100 Lear model 23 and 24 planes in service to discontinue flights until technicians could inspect each craft's stabilizer hinge.
TOKYO, May 10 (AP) McGeorge Bundy, former Presidential assistant, said today that President Johnson was "in full and final command of the great decisions of the United States in Vietnam."
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 10 Miss Susan Ellen Ancell and Dr. John M. Darley plan to be married on July 2 in the St. Regis Roof.

CEVELAND, May 10 (AP)--A pinch-double by Willie Horton drove in Bill Freehan with what proved to be the decisive run in the ninth inning tonight as the Detroit Tigers edged the Cleveland Indians, 3-2.

Courtesy of Bowdoin College in Brunswick, Me., and with the accomplished help of the Aeolian Chamber Players, New Yorkers were treated to the New York premiere of three ambitious new works last night at Carnegie Recital Hall.

Cornell University will give $300,000 over a 20-year period as rent for the use of the Ithaca Festival Theater. The pledge was made to hasten construction of the theater, to have it ready by the summer of 1968. It is expected to cost $4,660,000.

Long Island Rail Road commuters pluckily set off for home last night by any way they could find. Some were incredulous over reports that the trains had been stopped because the union charged management with drinking on the job.

The 15 per cent increase in wheat acreage allotments announced by President Johnson will help to quell discontent among the nation's farmers. They will not only be receiving bigger incomes; they also are being accorded a more important role in the economy.
TOKYO, Thursday, May 12 Scientists reported today that the major atmospheric contamination from Communist China's nuclear explosion on Sunday may have passed over Japan without harm.

The State Department, under mounting pressure from Government-owned airlines in foreign countries, shows increasing signs of wanting to continue its adherence to the Warsaw Convention limiting an-airline's liability in an international accident. The United States gave the required six-month notice of its intention to abandon the pact last Nov. 15.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 11 Britain formally acGovernment today of directing terrorism in Aden and the British protectorates of South Arabia.

WASHINGTON, May 11 Duncan Phillips, founder of the Phillips Gallery and the owner of one of the most famous art collections in the world, died Monday night of a heart attack at his home at 2101 Foxhall Road, N.W. He was 79 years old.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 11 Ideological conflicts between Arab revolutionaries and Arab conservatives appear to be growing sharper.

Mrs. Gisela Kahn Gresser, the defending United States women's chess champion, and Miss Lisa Lane, a former champion, both of New York, tied for first place in the United States women's championship last night at the Henry Hudson Hotel.

TEANECK, N.J., May 11 Frank Brennan, a junior righthander, pitched his second straight Metropolitan Baseball Conference shutout today as Fairleigh Dickinson downed New York University, 3-0, Brennan, who pitched a threehitter against St. John's in his last outing, tossed a two-hitter at the Violets. He has a 4-2 won-lost record.

SAIGON, May 11 When Ann Schein walked into the National Conservatory of Music last weekend to rehearse, she found the stage occupied by a Vietnamese "soldier," training a machine gun on four motionless figures on the floor.

GLEN RIDGE, N.J., May 11 Miss Mary India Beach and Robert Charles Ellis are planning to be married on May 28. Mr. and Mrs. Robert T. Beach have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mrs. Aarne J. Anderson of Vineyard Haven, Mass., and the late Charles R. Ellis.
BONN, May 11 West German and Israeli negotiators reached agreement today on an economic aid pact providing Israel with about $37.5-million credit for 1966.
WASHINGTON, May 11 The House Rules Committee cleared for floor action today the Administration bill permitting the sale of "participations" in Federal loans to private investors.

Howard J. Samuels declared yesterday that the Democratic party should not give its nomination for Governor to anyone who did not participate in the forums that had been arranged to help choose a candidate.

The chief mining engineer for the Securities and Exchange Commission testified in Federal Court here yesterday that the first hole the Texas Gulf Sulphur Company drilled at its Kidd Creek, Ont., property showed an unprecedented degree of mineralization.

YONKERS, May 11 Seventeen of the 46 eligible horses for the 12th edition of the Cane Pace, the first leg in the triple crown of pacing set for Yonkers Raceway on the night of May 19, will start tomorrow night in the Cane Prep.

CHICAGO, May 11 (UPI) Snowplows and sand trucks were taken out of storage in the storm-swept Midwest today as tornado watches were posted for sections of seven midland states from Texas to Iowa. A third consecutive day of record-breaking low temperatures increased fruit crop losses in the North and East.

Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union, the challenger for the world chess title, had a decided edge over his compatriot Tigran Petrosian at the adjournment of the 13th game of their match last night in Moscow's Variety Theatre.

The Wiltwyck School for Boys was the beneficiary of a folk-song concert at Carnegie Hall last night. The interfaith, interracial residential treatment center for boys has facilities here and in Yorktown, N.Y.

MADRID, May 11 More than 100 Roman Catholic priests, peacefully protesting alleged police brutality toward an imprisoned university student leader, were violently dispersed by the police in Barcelona to- day.

Dollar Land Holdings' Ltd., the giant British concern that deals exclusively in North American real estate, has added to its investments. The company's operating subsidiary, the Dollar Land Corporation, Ltd., has join Collins Tuttle Co., real estate concern here, as a partner in the development of a $5-million office building now under construction in Orlando, Fla.
A Fine Arts Center that includes a 1,400-seat playhouse and adjoining wings for music and art is under construction at Russell Sage College in Troy, N.Y., at a cost of $1.25-million.
CARACAS, Venezuela, May 11--A sharp and ebmarrassing split appeared today in the United States delegation to the Second Inter-American Conference of Ministers of Labor.
ALBANY, May 11 Charity Officials today protested a proposed law requiring their fundraising literature to state what portion of contributions actually goes to the charity.
HONG KONG, May 11 Peking today questioned whether normal diplomatic relations could be maintained between Communist China and Indonesia, in a bitter denunciation of Foreign Minister Adam Malik.
SAIGON, May 11 The United States expressed today its "sympathy and regret" over the shooting yesterday of a number of Vietnamese civilians by apparently panicky United States military policemen.
The nation's electric power production rose 7.8 per cent in the week ended May 7, from the level in the corresponding 1965 week, it was reported by the Ediso Electric Institute yesterday.
Former Republican State Chairman L. Judson Morhouse declined yesterday to take the witness stand in his own defense at his trial for bribery and conspiracy.
WASHINGTON, May 11 The following guide to Vietnamese political campaigning is designed for those who wish to keep abreast of developments in the forthcoming elections in South Vietnam.

AMHERST, Mass., May 11 Jeffrey M. Fine, a slightly built, twitchy Amherst College honor student, pleaded not guilty today to charges that he assaulted an elderly widow and bit two policemen while he was berserk under the influence of the hallucinatory drug LSD.

The Right Rev. James A. Pike has submitted his resig- nation as Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of California to join the resident staff of the Center for the Study of Democratic Institutions in Santa Barbara.
CAPETOWN, May 11 (AP) The Government today curbed a student leader who played a principal role in arranging a projected visit by Senator Robert F. Kennedy to South Africa next month.

The city's top Democratic officials demanded yesterday that the City University admit 2,278 qualified freshman candidates who were recently turned away by university authorities on the ground that both space and funds were lacking.
WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) The Treasury determined today that leather work shoes from Czechoslovakia were being dumped or were likely to be dumped on the American market at less than fair value.
Oswald S. Pick, who told the Federal Bureau of Investigation he planned to assassinate President Johnson, was given a conditional five-year prison term yesterday in Federal Court.
After showing weakness at the opening of trading, prices for grain futures climbed sharply yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.
WASHINGTON, May 11 The State Department asked Congress today to relax restrictions on East-West trade to take political advantage of the "winds of change" in Eastern Europe.
BONN, May 11 The West German Government welcomed today as "a satisfactory and fair compromise" the Common Market agreement on agricultural financing.
City Hall's plan to place public housing in middle-class neighborhoods outside the central city encountered vociferous opposition yesterday from homeowners in the Bronx and Queens.
Union taxi drivers struck the city's fleet cabs yesterday in a move to obtain higher commissions on their fares.
PARIS, May 11 The cheapest prices in the world on California wines of the better grades are right here, or soon will be.
LONDON, May 11 The Attorney General, Sir Elwyn Jones, said today in Parliament that the Government was considering legal changes with regard to contracts between newspapers and trial witnesses.

Yet another voice of caution was raised yesterday to those in the advertising business who, by their failure to engage in more self-regulation and selfpolicing, would encourage the tighter grip of Government control.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 11 Hofstra, paced by Phil Mordente's four goals and two assists, defeated Post in lacrosse today, 10-5.

WAYNE, Pa., May 11 Mr. and Mrs. Henry C. Townsend 3d have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Welsh Townsend, to Marshall Morgan Jeanes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry S. Jeanes Jr. of Devon.
A LADY who is renouncing earth's vanities carries a Picasso in a Harvard book bag. That's the sort of caper that happens only in a story by Hortense Calisher.
BALTIMORE, May 11 The Federal Government's racial peace-keeping team has sent two staff members here for "an indefinite period," it was reported today.
ATHENS, May 11 Ioannis Toumbas, retired vice admiral and World War II hero, was sworn in tonight as Greece's new Foreign Minister.

SYDNEY, Australia, May 11--French aircraft carrying equipment for nuclear tests in the Pacific have been banned from Australian airports. Paul Hasluck, Minister of External Affairs, said in Canberra that the planes could land in Australia and New Guinea only if the French government gave specific assurances that they were not carrying materials for tests.
WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) Mr. Ball predicted today that a proposal would be made next year for an across-the-board increase in Social Security retirement benefits.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) The Federal Communications Commission today announced its approval of the purchase by the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints of a New York City FM radio station, WRFM, for $850,000.
TURIN, Italy, May 11 (AP) The United States scored a 3-0 sweep over Sweden today in the second round of the women's Federation Cup tennis compe- tition.

MILTON, Ontario, May 11 (AP) A coroner's jury held today there was no evidence that a mechanical failure in a 1964 Chevrolet Corvair had contributed to an accident in which a woman driver was fatally injured.
CHARLESTON, W.Va, May 11 An amazed John D. Rockefeller 4th emerged as a major figure on the West Virginia political scene today after scoring a spectacular victory in his first bid for public office.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 110.3 on Tuesday from 110.4 on Monday.

OTTAWA, May 11--Former Prime Minister John Diefenbaker denied today that he had ever met and praised Gerda Munsinger, a German woman who was alleged to have engaged in a liaison with Pierre Sevigny when he was Associate Minister of Defense.
John H. Tompkins, a magazine writer and editor, died yesterday at his home in Babylon, L.I. He was 54 years old.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 11 An editor urged the Catholic Press Association today to eliminate "trivia and ecclesiastical doodling" from its publications in favor of "more deeply theological editorials and columns.
PARIS, May 11 The French Government indicated today that it was bowing to Algeria's decision to nationalize Frenchowned mines, but would bargain for appropriate compensation.

CHICAGO, May 11 (UPI) Howard Pyle, president of the National Safety Council, said today that Congressional investigations into auto safety had created a climate that will make the council's task easier.
ROME, May 11--A Spanish priest-diplomat, kidnapped 12 days ago as a hostage for Spanish political prisoners, was released unharmed today 20 miles north of Rome.
Dr. Zbigniew Brzezinski, director of Columbia University's Research Institute on Communist Affairs, has been named to the State Department's Policy Planning Council, it was announced yesterday.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 11 (AP) The United States Commissioner of Social Security disclosed today a plan to scale Medicare benefits to the cost of living.

John J. Halleran, former Borough Works Commissioner of Queens, who was described yesterday as "a little piece of Queens antiquity," died yesterday in Flushing Hospital. He was 91 years old and lived at 29-01 159th Street, Flushing.

ALBANY, May 11 Republican and Democratic leaders held their first "exploratory" meeting today on New York City's proposed tax program and agreed that it would have to undergo changes in the Legislature. They said they had not yet decided what the changes would be.
LANSING, Mich., May 11 Gov. George W. Romney named Representative Robert P. Griffin today to the Senate vacancy created by the death of Pat McNamara, a Democrat.
POLISH-BORN Zophia de Long is an investment counselor in the Park Avenue office of the brokerage house of Reynolds Co. She speaks 15 languages 16 if you include food.
Harvard is favored to win most of the honors again in the regatta of the Eastern Association of Rowing Colleges, on the basis of the seedings annouced yesterday.

Six thousand pills most of them deadly poison if taken improperly were stolen from a Brooklyn drugstore yesterday, setting off a citywide alert to doctors and hospitals to be on the lookout for persons suffering from violent internal disorders.
WASHINGTON, May 11-- New York City's first narcotics coordinator told Congress today that an "ideal" treatment program for all the city's addicts would cost $90-million a year to operate.

The salary of the New York City Superintendent of Schools was erroneously given as $45,000 a year yesterday in an article in The New York Times on the selection of James F. Redmond of Syosset, L.I., as Superintendent of Schools in Chicago. Bernard E. Donovan, the Superintendent here receives $40,000 a year.
Two home runs by Bob Hickes a second baseman, powered Columbia to a 5-2 victory over Yale in an Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League game yesterday at Baker Field.

TOKYO, May 11 Dr. Shinzo Koizumi, one of Japan's bestknown educators and a former tutor and adviser to Crown Prince Akihito, died of a stricture of the heart at his home here today. He was 78 years old.
The use of containers for handling ocean cargo is leading the trans-Atlantic shipping industry into a revolutionary age, Edmond Lanier, president of the French line, said here yesterday.
The General Electric Company announced here yesterday the election of John R. Casey as vice president in charge of the mid-states region.

STRANGERS grew nervous when they listened in on a verbal exchange between Bing Miller and his boss, Jimmie Dykes. They needled each other outrageously and traded insults of such mounting intensity that fisticuffs invariably seemed imminent. But they were the closest friends since Damon and Pythias operated in the mutualadmiration league.
A broad program for relieving overcrowding in the city's jails was recommended yesterday to Mayor Lindsay.

Henry Fonda will read excerpts from the writings and speeches of the late President Kennedy in part one of the National Broadcasting Company's two-part documentary, "The Age of Kennedy." The network will televise the programs as part of its "N.B.C. White Paper" series on Sunday, May 29, and Sunday, June 5, from 6:30 to 7:30 P.M.
Three new films made by schools typify the increasing amount of movie production, the variety of subject and the professional skill on American campuses in the field of the 16millimeter short.

DR. ARMOUR C. WOOD, the president of the Trenton Kennel Club, said yesterday he was determined that the club's show, which last Sunday became the East's biggest in 25 years, would be the biggest in the country the next time.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., May 11 Philip Marshall Brown, former diplomat and retired professor of international law at Princeton University, died last night at a nursing home here. He was 90 years old.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 11 (AP) Sledge won the $28,200 Premier Handicap and Johnny Longden made a winning debut as a trainer as the Hollywood Park racing meeting opened today.

Lake Chelan, racing as part of the triple entry representing the Meadow Stable, won the 68th running of the Fashion Stakes yesterday at Aqueduct. With Walter Blum guiding, Lake Chelan scored by a head over the Harbor View Farm's Charlo. In third place, by two lengths, came Mrs. Moody Jolley's Betoken.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, May 11--The speech by Nicolae Ceausescu, the Rumanian leader, contained reminiscences of the Soviet-German pact of 1939 and suggested that Moscow was to blame for Rumania's siding with the Axis in 1940.
THE Nassau Fish and Game Association has called to the attention of its members a bill signed by Governor Rockefeller that will benefit New York competitive pistol shooters.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 11 The Security Council was called today to meet Tuesday morning to consider a resolution calling on Britain to blockade Rhodesia by land, air and sea.

ROME, May 11 (AP) Tony Roche of Australia became the giant-killer of the new tennis season today when he defeated Nicola Pietrangeli of Italy, 11-9, 6-1, 6-2, for the title in the Italian international tournament.

Once again the city's transit lifeline is disrupted, this time by a simultaneous strike of taxicabs and of airport buses. The two labor disputes are unrelated, but their effects are not. The sufferers are travelers, businessmen, the handicapped and all others in need of emergency transportation. New York, perhaps more than any city in the world, is crippled by a break in its intricate chain of mass transport.

LOS ANGELES, May 11 The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation holding its 46th annual meeting at the Beverly Hilton Hotel announced the highest first-quarter earning in the company's history.
VIENNA, May 11 Soviet scientists revealed for the first time today the methods they use to sterilize spacecraft they are sending to Mars and Venus.

WHEN he was in college, Harold Joseph Pryor stud- ied for the priesthood. Years later, the man who on Tuesday called a strike against the Long Island Rail Road said, "I have a feeling now I'd have been a pretty tough priest and that the bishop would have had me in his of- fice every other day."
John J. Cassese has been elected to his fifth consecutive term as president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association and has promised to continue to fight plans for a civilian review board.

A rabbi who is an assistant supervisor for the Department of Welfare lost a suit in State Supreme Court yesterday to force the city to reschedule its promotion examinations, which are held on Saturdays.

Communist China's third nuclear explosion confirms Peking's technological progress, the seriousness of its program of weapons development and its strides toward great power status. Although it will be a decade before China has delivery systems capable of reaching the United States, Peking may be able much sooner to threaten American bases in Asia as well as such neighboring states as Japan, Taiwan, India and the countries of Southeast Asia.
A 23-year old father of three who spent eight months in jail accused of a murder of which he was later exonerated sued the city for $1-million in damages yesterday.

A Government witness in the Federal perjury trial here of Warden Henry B. McFarland of Hudson County Jail testified yesterday that he had twice left the jail where he was an inmate to visit with his family and had shared a prostitute with a guard.

STANFORD, Calif., May 11 Dr. J.E. Wallace Sterling, president of Stanford University, and Mrs. Sterling have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Hardy Sterling of Mount View, to Bernard M. Monjauze of San Francisco. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Camille Monjauze of Bogota, Colombia.

Members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee expressed their misgivings yesterday over the proposed new air liability limits under the War saw Convention and urged deferment of action by the United States pending a fuller examination of the complex issues involved.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 11 (AP) The police arrested four men today on warrants charging them with conspiracy to murder Dow Wilson, one of two painters union officials slain recently.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 11 An unusual study of 100 New York City addicts at least 30 of whom had been off narcotics for more than three years has found that supervised parole, new emotional attachments and a "substitute addiction" to such things as alchohol, food or religion are the keys to rehabilitation.

Douglas Dillon, former Secretary of the Treasury, who headed a group of top-level American businessmen that met recently in Paris with French industrialists, said yesterday the talks helped in furthering mutual understanding.
PARIS, May 11 The French Government today praised the Common Market agreement on farm financing and industrial tariffs as a realistic compromise and, by implication, a French success.
"A TIME FOR SINGING," tonight through May 20, at 8:30, at the Broadway Theater. The musical by Gerald Freedman and John Morris opens May 21.

Canada will celebrate its centennial in 1967 with year-long festivities, including some 40 works commissioned from Canadian composers, several Canadian operas and ballets and about 20 new Canadian plays, musicals and literary works.

The Houston Astros, who have maintained a 2-to-1 superiority over the New York Mets since the two expansion clubs joined the National League in 1962, demonstrated again the reasons for that margin last night in Shea Stadium.

WASHINGTON, May 11 The Securities and Exchange Commission denied today an application by the Electric Bond and Share Company and its principal subsidiary, the American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., for an exemption from regulation under the Investment Company Act of 1940.

WASHINGTON, May 11 Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that heavy bombing of enemy communication and supply lines had produced a "noticeably adverse effect on Vietcong morale and expectation of victory."

WESTHAMPTON, L.I., May 11 Exodus defeated Green Monster in a two-of-three jetcar match series tonight for the world's quarter-mile drag racing championship at the Westhampton Drag Strip. Both cars, powered by jet engines, are owned by Walter Arfons of Akron, Ohio.

James H. Meredith, who left Mississippi in 1963 after his graduation from the University of Mississippi, said yesterday that he would lead a homecoming march this summer from Memphis to Jackson, Miss., to bolster voter registration.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 11 Three maritime unions will vote next week on a contract with West Coast shipowners that deals with the problem of automation.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) The Secretary of Commerce, John T. Connor, suggested today seven steps businessmen might take to reduce the flow of dollars overseas as part of the Administration's balance-ofpayments program.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 11 The Iraqi Government has made preliminary moves toward a negotiated settlememt of the fiveyear guerrilla war with the Kurds in the northern part of Iraq, Kurdish sources here reported today.
About 100 union office employes walked out yesterday afternoon on a union-affiliated employer, the National Maritime Union Pension, Welfare and Employment-Security Plans.

Tom Cahill, who has been the Army plebe (freshman) football coach for the last seven seasons, was named yesterday as varsity head coach at the United States Military Academy. The 46-year-old graduate of the University of Niagara succeeds Paul Dietzel, who broke a longterm contract at Army last month to sign another longterm contract as football coach and athletic director at the Uni- versity of South Carolina.

WASHINGTON, May 11 Under Secretary of State George W. Ball is expected to leave the Government by the end of August. His resignation and other personnel changes will compel President Johnson to restaff virtually the entire top echelon of the State Department.

In her debut program last night at Carnegie Recital Hall, Penelope Spurrell did not show that she has what it takes to sustain a career as a pianist. Her technical equipment has been polished to its utmost, probably, but lack of a basic physical affinity to the piano kept her best work from ever really getting off the ground. Trills were slow, accents uneven even and the concepts themselves were literal.

BALTIMORE, May 11 (UPI) Gene Brabender, pitching in his first big-league game, balked home the winning run with two out in the 11th inning tonight to give the Chicago White Sox a 3-2 victory over the first-place Baltimore Orioles.

SHORTLY after the start of the second act of Frank Loesser's "The Most Happy Fella," which was revived last night at the City Center, two subsidiary characters played by Karen Morrow and Jack DeLon take over the stage with one of Mr. Loesser's funniest, most rousing musical comedy numbers, "Big D."
CHARLOTTE, N.C., May 11 (AP) Ford put its powerful and controversial new overhead cam-shaft stock-car racing engine through high-speed tests today.
WASHINGTON, May 11 The Department of Health, Education and Welfare defended today a policy of secrecy in the handling of some information developed in auto safety research projects.
A baby elephant from Thailand found the city's sights, smells and clattering sounds a frightening experience yesterday.
NEW DELHI, May 11 (UPI) The 11-member executive committee of the ruling Congress party called today for India to begin work on nuclear weapons to counter the threat of Communist China.
Champagne and omelettes will be served tomorrow in the St. Regis-Sheraton Roof at a Candlelight supper dance sponsored by the Friends of the Henry Street Settlement.
WASHINGTON, May 11--An "increasingly severe" manpower shortage in the radiological sciences is threatening the quality of medical care, the National Advisory Committee on Radiation warned today.
DETROIT, May 11 The Ford Division of the Ford Motor Company reported today an end to a sales slump with record auto sales for the first 10 days of May.
A miscalculation by Communist China regarding United States motives in Vietnam "could mean all-out war," Lester B. Pearson, Canadian Prime Minister, said in a speech last night.

Special to The New York Times AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, May 11 Five of the seven American pairs were in good positions at the end of the second qualifying session of the World Open Pair Championship here tonight. Highest in the standings, in sixth place, were James Jacoby and Dr. John Fisher, both of Dallas, with 3,322 points. Robert Jordan and Arthur Robinson of Philadelphia stood 13th, with 3,260 points.

Cazzie Russell of Michigan, the outstanding college basketball player of last season, was chosen by the New York Knickerbockers yesterday when they made the first pick in the annual National Basketball Association player draft. Moments later the Detroit Pistons selected Dave Bing of Syracuse, the player some observers consider to be even better than Russell.
ST. LOUIS, May 11 Busch Memorial Stadium, a $26-million edifice that opens for baseball here tomorrow night, intends to curb the home run, but not make it obsolete in a scientific manner.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP)--Representative H. R. Gross says the Johnson Administration's "mink coat set" should cut out its 3 A.M. White House parties and swinging watusis in the Smithsonian Institution.
When James Rorimer accepted the directorship of the Metropolitan Museum, some of his friends thought he might be making a mistake.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles Edward Haydock of New York and De Ruyter, N.Y., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Atwood Kugel, to Edward V. Brookfield, son of Mrs. Henry A. Thoman of Cincinnati and Harbor Point, Mich., and the late E.V. Brookfield.
MINNEAPOLIS, May 11 Gov. Karl F. Rolvaag vetoed today a reapportionment bill passed at a special session of the Minnesota Legislature.

WASHINGTON, May 11 Damocrats on the House Education and Labor Committee decided today, on second thought, not to raise the budget request for the poverty program. Accordingly, they cut their own figures back to $1.75billion, the amount asked by President Johnson.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 11 City College pushed across two runs in the 10th inning, then held off Army to score an 11-10 baseball victory over the cadets here today. The loss was the first for Army in 13 games.

Physicians and their wives will join nurses and other employes of the Long Island College. Hospital in "Cobble Hill Capers," a revue to be presented tomorrow and Saturday evenings at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
Most issues advanced on the London Stock Market yesterday. Trading was moderately active.
The Women's Bar Association will induct Mrs. Fannie J. Klein as president on Saturday at a luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
COLOGNE, Germany, May 11 (AP) Old 007 won today a lifeor-death battle against a fragrant-smelling, but determined opponent 4711.
MASERU, Basutoland, May 11 (AP) The National Assembly approved by a vote of 32-28 today a motion calling for independence from Britain for this tiny territory.
PITTSBURG, May 11 (AP) Willie Mays hit his 514th career homer tonight as the first-place San Francisco Giants scored their 10th straight victory by downing the Pittsburgh Pirates, 6-1.

BELGRADE, May 11 Rumanian officials willing to discuss the current trip of Leonid I. Brezhnev, Soviet Communist party leader, to Rumania maintain that it is a "normal, unofficial visit" to talk about party relations.

LONDON, May 5--Africa's central dilemma is whether its peoples and states can develop peacefully as long as South Africa and Rhodesia are committed to white supremacy and Angola and Mozambique are welded to Portugal.

ATLANTA, May 11 (UPI) Hank Aaron drove in five runs with his 10th and 11th homers of the season tonight and led Atlanta to an 8-1 victory over the Cincinnati Reds. The vic- tory snapped the Braves' fivegame losing streak.
Higher prices are needed on a "substantial" portion of steel shipments if profit margins are to be raised, Thomas F. Patton, chairman of the Republic Steel Company, said yesterday.
Israel Breslow, manager of Dressmakers Local 22 of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, yesterday was elected president of the Workmen's Circle. He had been president from 1958 to 1962.
AUSTIN, Tex., May 11--The Texas Court of Criminal Appeals heard arguments today on whether a judge's $5,000 advance for writing a book had prevented Jack L. Ruby from receiving a fair trial.

SAIGON, May 11 MIG-17 jet fighters fired missiles at United States aircraft over North Vietnam yesterday. It was the first confirmed instance in which such air-to air weapons had been used against American planes in the Vietnamese war.
BERNARDSVILLE, N.J., May 11 Miss Jean Sears Alexander and Robert R. O'Donnell plan to be married next month.

The fight against racial ghettoes has been advanced by the California Supreme Court's invalidation of an amendment to the State Constitution permitting discrimination in the sale or rental of property. Five of the seven justices agreed that the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution guaranteed, among other things, the right to acquire and possess property without discrimination on account of color, race or religion.
