According to Mrs. Ernest L. Byfield, "Feathers are a la mode." And almost as if to prove the point, the stately Grand Ballroom of the Plaza Hotel sprouted an array of ostrich feathers last night for the Feather Ball Just One Break's annual May festival benefit.
Anna Rochester, a Marxist economist and historian of the American scene, died of pneumonia yesterday at the New York Infirmary. She was 86 years old and lived at 85 Bedford Street.

COLONIA, N.J., May 11 The family and friends of a Roman Catholic soldier who was killed in Vietnam Sunday began a campaign today to have his parish church reverse a decision to deny him a funeral service because he was married in a civil ceremony.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) Senate Democratic leader Mike Mansfield of Montana wrote President Johnson and Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach today, pressing his request for a world conference on copper.
BONN, May 11 West Germany has taken a new step toward establishing diplomatic relations with the Communist nations of East Europe by exchanging visa offices with Rumania.
The Appellate Division yesterday affirmed a lower-court ruling holding that Burton B. Turkus was the proper arbitrator for the current waterfront dispute.

WASHINGTON, May 11 The United States will get the famous Hirshhorn art collection worth between $25 million and $50-million, informed sources said tonight. The collection 6,300 paintings, drawings and sculptures is one of the largest privately owned in the world.
Red Beard, an international villain who aspires to be the first liar in space, matched wits with Dr. Whoo, the world's foremost lie detector, in an East Harlem school yesterday.

LONDON, May 11 Col. Alfred Daniel Wintle, whose colorful career included a six-month prison sentence for pulling the pants off a lawyer who had been left $123,000 of the $322,000 estate of Colonel Wintle's cousin, died last night at his home in Wrotham, Kent. He was 68 years old.

LONDON, May 11 The Government, over strenuous protests from the Labor party's left wing, announced today the appointment of a "supersalesman" to promote the purchase of British arms by other countries.
HONG KONG, May 11 Com- munist China and Albania have joined in thinly veiled attacks on the ideological stand taken by the leaders of North Vietnam.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 11 Dick Schofield, an experi- enced infielder who has played for the St. Louis Cardinals, Pittsburgh Pirates and San Francisco Giants, became a New York Yankee today. To make room on the roster after purchasing Schofield from the Giants for about $25,000, the Yankees sent Jack Cullen, a right-handed pitcher, to Toledo on option.
William L. (Sam) Van Alen of Philadelphia was re-elected president of the United States Court Tennis Association yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 11 The State Department confirmed today that the United States had rejected a Chinese Communist proposal that the two nations pledge neither would be the first to use atomic weapons against the other.
No progress was reported yesterday toward settling the 17-day-old strike against the World Journal Tribune, Inc.

MASTER ROBERT DURKIN of Pleasantville, N.J., captured first place in the recent New Jersey Ama- teur at the Walt Whitman Hotel in Camden. Topping a 63-man field in a six-round Swiss system, he scored 5 . Next came K. Nedved and T. Lux, tied with game points at 5 1 each. Nedved, however, took secondplace on a tie-breaking count.

WASHINGTON, May 11 The sources of the rise of Lyndon B. Johnson to the Presidency were identified with remarkable clarity in the N.B.C. tele- vised program which showed him moving about in the Texas hill country that is his homeland. He emerged as another President formed, like Jackson and Lincoln, in the old American tradition that the true measure of the worth of attainment is the triumph over youthful adversity by self-help and hard work.
The British pound was nearly steady in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. Its closing quotation of $2.7932 was 2 points down from Tuesday.
The W.T. Grant Company announced yesterday that it was withdrawing its proposed offering of 800,000 shares of common Stock because of "unfavorable market conditions."
Several municipal hospitals here have asked permission to reduce admissions of patients by as much as 30 per cent, in anticipation of a mass resignation of nurses threatened for May 23.
WASHINGTON, May 11 Another new plan for international monetary reform was made public today.

WHITE PLAINS, May 11 Louis Blumenthal, a lawyer for the Builders Institute of Westchester and Putnam Counties, the Title Guaranty Company, the Westchester Federal Savings and Loan Association and real estate concerns, died last night in his home at 6 Sherill Court. He was 52 years old.
A teen-aged rock 'n' roll group set the tone as a South Brooklyn neighborhood group began raising funds to convert an old church into a community center.
Is the Norfolk Western Railway really free of the domination of its former parent, the Pennsylvania Railroad?
Governor Hughes, President Goheen, trustees, faculty and students, Secretary Gardner and distinguished guests of Princeton:
WASHINGTON, May 11 The State Department said today that the United States was "considering" a request from the United Arab Republic for additional surplus food in the coming fiscal year.
WASHINGTON, May 11 The Administration's minimum wage bill, stalled in the House Rules Committee since March, was cleared today for floor action.
ALBANY, May 11 A bill requiring the New York City Po- lice Department to provide full protection for private housing developments won final passage in the Legislature today.

CANNES, France, May 11 The Cannes Film Festival is changing not abruptly and not noticeably, perhaps, to anyone who has been coming steadily year after year. But to one who has come intermittently to this most popular of international do's and has been watching, at the same time, what is happening in the world of films, a change of phenomenal proportions is perceptible.
It was a beautiful day on the Long Island Rail Road yesterday as train service returned to normal.
The Liberal party designated a Republican, Civil Court Judge George S. Starke, as its candidate for Surrogate of New York County last night.
NEW ORLEANS, May 11 Arnold Palmer today advocated a shorter schedule for the pro golf tour as a solution to postponements such as occurred last week in Houston.

WASHINGTON, May 11 Considering the work and consultation that went into preparing it and the expectations it aroused, Senator Robert F. Kennedy's two-day exposition on the state of the Alliance for Progress reached what has been termed some remarkably unremarkable conclusions.
Administrative Judge John M. Murtagh of Criminal Court said yesterday that he favored removing traffic, housing and air-pollution violation cases from his court to administrative agencies.
The election of Michael J. Esposito as controller, a post vacant since 1961, was announced here yesterday by American Export Isbrandtsen Lines.

OMAHA, May 11 (AP)--The fast-climbing political careers of Norbert T. Tiemann, small-town Republican banker, and Lieut. Gov. Philip C. Sorensen, youthful Democrat, will be tested when they oppose each other in November in the contest for Nebraska's Governorship.
Representative James B. Utt, Republican, of California, lost a $5.25-million libel suit against the Columbia Broadcasting System in Federal Court yesterday.
Dr. Hyman U. Solovay, a Brooklyn internist, died yesterday in New York Hospital after a long illness. He was 64 years old and lived and practiced at 622 Ocean Avenue.

The career of Duncan Phillips resists the usual categories and comparisons. He was an art collector of the greatest distinction, a man of subtle sensibility and taste in whom a devotion to esthetic quality was combined with an exceptional civic vision.

STERN BROTHERS celebrated yesterday the first anniversary of its third-floor Sportique, a department that specializes in avant-garde fashions, by introducing three new names to its roster of designers.

The Metropolitan Opera Company may be stuck with its old opera house even after the company opens at the new Met in Lincoln Center, an official of the opera company said yesterday. This could happen, he said, if a bill passed by the State Senate on Tuesday to save the old Met, becomes law. The bill will reach the Assembly next week.
ROME, May 11--Senator Edward M. Kennedy said tonight that Western efforts to east the plight of American soldiers in the hands of the North Vietnamese and the Vietcong had met with failure.
James J. Rorimer, director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art since 1955, died of a heart attack early yesterday in his home at 1000 Park Avenue. He was 60 years old.
WASHINGTON, May 11 State Department officials hailed as "a major step forward" today the agreement reached early this morning in Brussels among the six nations of the Common Market.
LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., May 11 Mrs. Thorne Dempsey of Piping Rock scored a 42,38 80 to win low-gross honors in the opening tournament of the Women's Long Island Golf Association.
NEWARK, May 11 Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio and former Mayor Leo P. Carlin began planning their strategy today for a run-off mayoral election on June 14.
Yesterday was the day that was supposed to reveal more clearly the outline of the bond market this week as one large new corporate issue and two tax-exempt offerings were sold at competitive bidding.

BRUSSELS, May 11 When ministers of the six Common Market countries reached agreement at 5 A.M. today on agricultural financing, they resolved a knotty problem that had been bedeviling them for 13 months.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP)--Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara said today that the manager of the United States post exchange in Saigon had been removed after more than 142,000 cans of women's hair spray were imported by the exchange.

Senator Robert F. Kennedy called yesterday for a massive building campaign that would rehabilitate slum neighborhoods, provide work for the unemployed and give poor people a stronger voice in the over-all planning of such activities.

WASHINGTON, May 11 John E. Horne, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, said today that commercial banks should be barred from competing for individual savings deposits with highyielding certificates of deposit.
The highest auction price ever bid for a Maillol sculpture was paid at the Parke-Bernet Galleries during a benefit sale for the Whitney Museum of American Art last night.

More than 300 shareholders of the International Paper Company gathered in the Biltmore Hotel yesterday for the first annual meeting of the company ever to be held outside the corporate offices in New York.

Haryou-Act has reinstated its controversial executive director, Livingston L. Wingate, to an active status amid indications that Federal antipoverty officials have softened their position that funds would be withdrawn from the Harlem agency if he remained in charge.
OXFORD, England, May 11 Oxford University was urged today to Slough off some of its medievalism and revamp its outlook and structure to fulfill the needs of 20th-century Britain.

SAIGON, May 11 The young French businessman, a veteran of hard campaigns in the Foreign Legion, was reading an American magazine as he lolled beside the swimming pool of the Cercle Sportif, Saigon's most stylish athletic club.
PHILADELPHIA, May 11 (AP) Don Sutton of the Los Angeles Dodgers shut out the Philadelphia Phils, 5-0, on six singles tonight and collected three himself.
WASHINGTON, May 11-- Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach was accused today of bowing to political pressures from "professional Italians" to suppress Joseph M. Valachi's book about the Mafia.
A new line of furniture with a protecting all-over sur- face called Armorwood may be an answer for some harassed mothers who have despaired of decorating rooms with anything other than orange crates.
A New York cancer specialist proposed yesterday that Pap smears to detect cervical cancer be mandatory for all women over 20 who have borne a child.
While many people associate trust agreements with the wealthy these legal tools can be useful to families of relatively moderate income, as well.

The Unilever group of companies reported yesterday increased sales in the first quarter this year but a $4-million decline in earnings from a year before. The group consists of Unilever, N.V., a Dutch company, and Unilever, Ltd., a British company, makers of detergents and foodstuffs.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 11-- United States State Department representatives are visiting key South American countries in an attempt to clear the way for a meeting of American Presidents.
WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) The House passed today a bill to broaden and increase medical benefits for active and retired military personnel and their dependents. The vote was 356 to 0.

KHADDAS, Yemen, May 1 They talk these days of the "miracle of Khaddas." It came to pass when the tribesmen of this barren and remote sandstone plateau scraped out a primitive airstrip in one day be- cause of their enthusiasm over the offer of American help in digging urgently needed water wells.
ALBANY, May 11--Two ethics bills passed by the Assembly last week but earmarked for a quiet burial in the Senate will get a hearing in the upper house after all.
St. John's won a Metropolitan Conference baseball game yesterday, routing Wagner, 13-0, at the victors' field in Queens.

Gasoline supplies in the United States fell to 213,186,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday from 214,073,000 barrels in the preceding week and 223,111,000 barrels in the comparable week a year ago, the American Petrolium Institute anounced yesterday.

LONDON, May 11 (Reuters) Cassius Clay, in training for his heavywight title defense against Henry Cooper May 21, was knocked down twice by a 19-year-old sparring partner today. But it was only a part of Clay's act.

Texas Gas Transmission Corporation and its subsidiaries achieved the best first quarter in its history, W.M. Elmer, president, told about 60 stockholders at yesterday's annual meeting at 20 Pine Street.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 11 President Johnson appealed today to the nation's scholars and intellectuals for under- standing and support of his policies in Vietnam.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 11 Delegates to the 59th meeting of the American Baptist Convention heard a strong plea tonight for Christian unity.

CAIRO, May 11 President Gamal Abdel Nasser and Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin opened their talks tonight after a new warning from the United Arab Republic to the United States against the dangers of cutting off economic aid.
Three men were convicted in Federal Court yesterday on charges of conspiring to transport and sell 12 pounds of heroin valued at $1.5-million on the illicit market. A fourth defendant was acquitted.
Two significant developments in metal technology were announced yesterday.

ASWAN, United Arab Republic, May 12--Hundreds of Soviet experts sent here to help build the country's biggest prestige project, the Aswan High Dam, have won Egyptian respect for sticking to business and steering clear of politics.
CHICAGO, May 12--About 350 University of Chicago students seized control of the six-floor administration office building today to protest university cooperation with the Selective Service System.
The Visiting Nurse Service of New York gave its annual dinner dance in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza last night.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, May 12 An international conference of Buddhist monks that ended here today decided to set up a world organization with headquarters in Colombo.

TOKYO The United States, as protector, faces a dismal Hobson's choice in South Vietnamese politics. This summer's elections promise to be most vigorously contested between an avowedly religious party and an avowedly military party. Yet it is our preference to appose intrusion of either church or army into affairs of state.

A PRODUCING company called Transcenics, Inc., gives with one hand and takes away with the other. Last night that organization presented the overdue New York premiere of Isaac Babel's "Sunset," a play teeming with vitality; but their production (which I saw at its last preview) is hollow.
The Board of Higher Education appointed Dean Milton G. Bassin as president of New York City Community College of the City University yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (UPI) Daniel P. Moynihan, former Assistant Secretary of Labor, chargedto day that the auto industry's "planned obsolescence" of models might cause accidents.

BUCHAREST, May 12.--The Rumanians maintained their silence today on the whereabouts and activities of Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader, who is believed to have conferred with Nicolae Ceausescu, the Rumanian party leader, in this country.

CULLACAN, Mexico, May 8 This sun-baked provincial capital lies within Mexico's arid zone, a vast area stretching across most of the northern part of the country. Here Mexico's efforts to give her peasantry a better life is being put to one of its most severe tests.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 12 Dr. Anson E. Morse, retired professor of history, died yesterday is the Foothill Acres Nursing Home. He was 86 years old.
A few days ago, the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association began distributing a propaganda booklet titled "Have Fun! Live Dangerously! Own a Jumper!"
WASHINGTON, May 12 A $60-million program for North Atlantic container vessels was announced here today by the Maritime Administration.

NEW HAVEN, May 12 Yale University announced today the establishment of a new graduate degree, the Master of Philosophy, designed to help satisfy the demand for more college teachers as well as to raise the requirements for the master's degree.

Paul R. Screvane, former President of the New York City Council and last year's unsuccessful primary candidate for Mayor, has emerged as a candidate for the board of an apparel company under the sponsorship of an insurgent group of stockholders.
CLEVELAND, May 12 Walter J. Tuohy, chief executive officer of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway and the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, died tonight at St. Vincent's Charity Hospital at the age of 65.
ST. LOUIS, May 12 (AP) Henry S. Caulfield, Republican Governor of Missouri from 1929 to 1933, died last night in a St. Louis convalescent home. He was 92 years old.
Larry Brown, the Cleveland Indian shortstop injured on May 4, was removed from the intensive-care unit yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital.
SAIGON, May 12--United States fighter-bombers attacked a surface-to-air missile site 10 miles northeast of Haiphong yesterday. It was their closest strike to the principal North Vietnamese port city.
Charles A. Buckley, the Bronx Democratic leader, hinted last night that his political career of more than a half-century was drawing to a close.
The world's first commercial model of a nuclear power generator will go on the market today.

LAWRENCE, L.I., May 12 The engagement of Miss Alice Blumberg to Lawrence Oberweger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Oberweger of Flushing, Queens, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Ira Blumberg.

WASHINGTON, May 12 The Senate Foreign Relations Committee urged the State Department today to proceed with its announced plans for renouncing the Warsaw Convention limiting the liability of interna- tional airlines.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 12 Bernard G. Steinetz, former president of Congoleum-Nairn, Inc., a manufacturer of floor coverings, died today in the Harkness Pavilion of ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center, New York. He was 81 years old and lived at 175 Wildwood Avenue, Upper Montclair.
Four new National Geographic Society Specials will be presented in color next season on the Columbia Broadcasting System television network.

DALLAS, May l2 (AP) Peggy Wilson, who never has won a tournament, and Mickey Wright, who has won more than anybody, ignored the wind and misty rain today to shoot one-under-par 70's and tie for the first-round lead in the $15,000 Dallas Civitan women's open golf.
Mayor Lindsay's Negotiating Committee on the World Trade Center is conducting a wideranging review of the city's relationship with the Port of New York Authority.

A total of 237 parcels of surplus city property will be auctioned by the Department of Real Estate next Wednesday, Acting Commissioner John Dobb announced yesterday. The sale will be held at the Roosevelt Hotel beginning at 9:30 A.M.
BONN, May 12 West Germany and Israel today signed an economic assistance agreement providing Israel with a $40-million credit for 1966.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., May 12 Charles T. Ireland Jr., president of the Alleghany Corporation, told his company's annual meeting today that Alleghany's ownership of shares in the New York Central Railway had been reduced from 984,000 to 150,564 shares.
SAIGON, May 12--For the second time in five weeks, the number of American troops killed and wounded in a week has exceeded South Vietnamese losses.

WASHINGTON, May 12, (AP) A Senate Narcotics subcommittee was told today that evidence indicated that use of the hallucinagenic drug LSD was increasing in New York City, but that while the problem was serious, "It is not a cause for hysteria."

The appointment of Dr. Samuel Bieber as dean of Richard L. Conolly College, the undergraduate division of Long Island University's Brooklyn Center, was announced yesterday by Dr. William M. Birenbaum, vice president and provost.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 12 The "banning" of Ian Robertson, the 21-year-old student leader who invited Senator Robert F. Kennedy to visit this country, has set off a wave of protests at English-language universities.
A city patrolman was suspended yesterday when it became known that he had been tried as a cigarette bootlegger in Maryland last month.

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., May l2 Pat Schwab, with a 31, 37 68, and Mrs. Helen Sofferman of Crestmont won a New Jersey pro-woman golf tournament to- day with a net better-ball 30, 36 66 at the Maplewood Country Club.

Miss Borghild Dahl, who is blind and 75 years old, goes on writing books. Yesterday, to celebrate her latest book, her neighbors in the Audubon Apartments, a New York City Housing Authority development at 1909 Amsterdam Avenue, near West 155th Street, gave her a party.

After eight days of testimony, the Government yesterday rested its perjury case against Warden Henry Bernard McFarland of Hudson County Jail, Jersey City. But not before it read into the record what it alleged were lies to the Federal ...
SANTA MONICA, Calif., May 12 (AP) Charles W. Hinman was sentenced today to one to five years in prison for plotting to have a prominent lawyer, Murray Chotiner, killed.
Stephen E. Kelly, publisher of McCall's magazine, returned to New York on Tuesday from what he considered a successful, three-day, three-speech visit to Dallas. Sometime Wednesday he was dismissed.
LONDON, May 12 Britain is preparing for a strike by merchant seamen Monday that could badly disrupt the nation's economy.
As part of its planned reorganization to improve in struction and promote integration, the Board of Education announced yesterday an expansion of pilot schools at the primary and intermediate levels.

WASHINGTON, May 12 President Johnson told more than 6,000 Democrats at a fund raising dinner here tonight to stand firm on the Administration's record in Vietnam in the Congressional elections this fall.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 110.6 on Wednesday from 110.3 on Tuesday.

BUPRANG, South Vietnam, May 2 At least part of the Ho Chi Minh Trail, which serves as the enemy's supply line, is a slippery, narrow cow path of red earth that wanders across the green face of a lovely savannah.
A two-day advance on the American Stock Exchange ended abruptly yesterday as the list retreated along a broad front in quiet trading.

PITTSBURGH, May 12 (UPI) Unbeaten Juan Marichal's sixhit pitching ran his personal winning streak to seven games and the San Francisco Giants' skein to 11 tonight in a 3-0 triumph over Bob Veale and the Pittsburgh Pirates.

NEW ORLEANS, May 12 Play on the pro golf circuit resumed today with the $100,000 Greater New Orleans open. A half-hour delay was forced by rain, but the first round was completed a considerable improvement over last Sunday when rain washed out the Houston tourney.
The police and health officials continued their search yesterday for 6,000 toxic pills stolen Wednesday from a drug store at 4902 16th Avenue in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn.
LONDON, May 12 Recmendations to reform Oxford University have omitted safeguards to preserve its most cherished possession intellectual freedom in the opin- ion of two Oxford professors.
RADNOR, Pa., May 12 Miss Judith Allen and David L. Kniffin plan to marry next month.

Lenox Hill Hospital, one of 69 voluntary hospitals affiliated with The Greater New York Fund, will open a new community health center this year to provide increased services for New Yorkers. The hospital, first a dispensary on Canal Street in 1857, moved uptown in 1868. It holds many medical "firsts," such as the first tuberculosis division in any general hospital in America.
Governor Rockefeller expressed confidence yesterday that the City University would admit the 2,278 qualified freshman candidates it recently rejected in time for the fall semester.
Two men and a woman heard an airline stewardess scream for help in a Queens subway underpass yesterday, went to her rescue and captured her alleged assailant, the police reported.

CLEVELAND, May 12 The merger plans of the Norfolk and Western and the Chesapeake and Ohio railways were approved today by stockholders of both lines despite vigorous opposition of the Pennsylvania Railroad. The Pennsy holds 25 per cent of N. W.'s stock.
A nurserymen's association moved yesterday in Bronx Supreme Court to seek relaxation of the city's water restrictions, which it contends have cut horticultural business as much as 50 per cent.
A $100-million decline in the United States gold stock in the week ended May 11 was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
Dr. Max Maier, an ear, nose and throat specialist, died of a heart attack Wednesday at Mountainside Hospital in Montclair, N.J. He was 81 years old and lived at 216 West 89th Street.

VANCOUVER, B.C., May 12 (AP) Santiago Rosario of the Vancouver Mounties was suspended for the rest of the season and fined $250 tonight for hitting Merritt Ranew of Seattle with a bat in the worst brawl in Pacific Coast League history.
Miss Marianne Glick and Jay Barry Rohrlich plan to marry in June.

VIENNA, May 12--Leading members of 15 West European Communist parties, ending a three-day secret meeting, issued a statement today urging alliances with "antimonopolistic forces," including Socialist parties and Roman Catholic organizations.
ASWAN, United Arab Republic, May 12 Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin, hailed as a "Hero of the High Dam," today made a triumphal tour of the showpiece of Soviet aid projects in the underdeveloped world.
BERGEN, Norway, May 12 Britain promised today to consult fully with her fellow outsiders as she maneuvers for membership in the European Common Market.
High over Brooklyn, on the topmost floor of a hotel looking out upon the Manhattan skyline, a group of teen-age Negroes are dancing.

Haydn's oratorio "The Creation" can be analyzed time and again, with a detailed description of all its manifold virtues, pointing out the composer's genius in finding the perfect musical metaphor for such disparate subjects as the chaos before creation, God's injunction "Let there be light!" or "the lowly worm."

One of the art world's greatest dramas ended Wednesday with the announcement that the United States would receive the Hirshhorn art collection after a two-year international competition that ranged from London to Jerusalem to Beverly Hills, Calif.
The Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation said yesterday it had filed a registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission for its previously announced rights offering.

HUNTINGDON, Pa., May 12 (AP) A searching party of about 200 persons assisted by bloodhounds and a helicopter combed a heavily wooded area near here today for a 17-yearold girl who was abducted yesterday by an armed man wearing a mask.

PORTSMOUTH, England, May 12 Faced with possible dissolution within the next two months, Britain's longest established dance company, Ballet Rambert, tonight backed its claim to survive by giving the premiere of a first ballet by one of the company's youngest dancers.
LONDON, May 12 Foreign exchange continued to drain from Britain last month because of her inability to sell as much as she buys abroad.
WASHINGTON, May 12 Another member of the Federal Reserve Board came out publicly today in favor of a tax increase.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 12 The New York Yankees paid the price of their defensive weaknesses tonight, hit the ball hard but in tough luck, and lost to the Minnesota Twins, 4-3.

WHEN in doubt, wear sari. There are half a dozen reasons why American women are subscribing to this bit of fashion philosophy. The one-of-a-kind patterns, the tempting colors and the classic beauty of Indian saris, not to mention their suitability in almost any kind of environment, have kept these fabrics continuously ...
THE closing date for entries for the Storm Trysail Club's yacht race around Block Island has been changed from next Tuesday to next Friday, John R. Latham, the committee chairman, said yesterday.

Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. announced yesterday that he would seek the Democratic nomination for Governor in an effort to end what he called the "crisis-to-crisis" government of Republican adminstrations in Albany.

"Anything that should be in a hospital today, we got it here." That was the view yesterday of Charles H. Silver, president of the board of trustees of Beth Israel Medical Center, as he described the comforts and equipment of a new 12-story pavilion at First Avenue and 16th Street.

THE luck of the New York Knickerbockers has been uniformly consistent over the years and virtually none of it has been good. As if that unhappy state of affairs has not been embarrassing enough, some bad guesses by the front office have heightened the damage.

A certified public accountant was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury here on charges of obstructing justice by threatening a witness in the Government's year-long investigation of the distribution of stock in Tel-A-Sign, Inc., and its subsidiary, Scopitone, Inc.

COLONIA, N.J., May 12 Mrs. Kathleen Genovese, who was prevented by Roman Catholic priests from having a funeral mass for her husband, Pfc. Carmine V. Genovese, began today to arrange for his burial under Episcopal rites.
The bond market was hit yesterday afternoon first by news that tended to push prices up and later by news that pushed them back down.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 12 John Grenier, former executive director of the Republican National Committee, plans to announce next week his candidacy for the United States Senate seat from Alabama held by John J. Sparkman, a Democrat.

WASHINGTON, May 12 If Cassius Clay is classified as a conscientious objector by the Kentucky Selective Service appeals board, it won't be because he is a Black Muslim, according to draft officials here.

CANNES, France, May 12 A major Anglo-French film production was roundly booed at the 20th Cannes Film Festival today, and it was difficult for an impartial observer to tell which nation's distinguished participants were being rebuked.

A spokesman of the Chinese Ministry of National Defense, in a statement this evening [Thursday], sternly condemned U.S. imperialism for its act of war provocation and expressed the strongest protest in relation to the serious incident in which U.S. fighter planes intruded over the area northeast of Makwan, in China's Yunnan Province, and launched surprise attacks on Chinese aircraft in training flight.

The Society for Mental Health will benefit from a dinner dance at the Tavern-on-the-Green on May 26. About 400 persons are expected at the event, which, weather permitting, will be al fresco, with yellow tablecloths and brilliantly colored Mexican paper flowers against the background of trees sparkling with tiny lights.
The Government filed answering papers yesterday in Federal Court asking that a post-trial motion by Gerardo A. Re and his son, Gerard F. Re, to reverse their stock-fraud convictions be thrown out.
PHILADELPHIA, May 12 (AP) Dick Groat's two-run homer and a bases-loaded single by John Callison carried the Philadelphia Phillies to a 5-1 victory tonight over the Los Angeles Dodgers.
The national president of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen said yesterday that Tuesday's walkout of some employes of the Long Island Rail Road was "absolutely an unauthorized strike."

Prices on the London Stock Exchange recovered most early losses yesterday after traders found Britain's foreign trade figures for April bettter than some had expected. The market closed with a slight decline on average.

WARREN, N.J., May 12 Ernest T. Gardner, director of alumni relations at Rutgers, the State University, since 1958, and Deputy Freeholder Director of Somerset County, died this morning in his physician's office of a heart attack. He was 46 years old.
The chance for enactment this year of Mayor Lindsay's plan for coordinating the city's transportation facilities practically vanished yesterday.
TWO giants of the fashion underworld proved in showings this week that there is as much going on inside fashion as there is outside.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 11--Subtle criticism of President Sukarno has become one of Indonesia's favorite pastimes. Every day the press carries articles that appear to aim at undermining his prestige and authority without attacking him directly.

WASHINGTON, May 12 Representative F. Edward Hebert, chairman of a House Armed Services subcommittee, accused Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara today of continuing to conceal the true views of the Joint Chiefs of Staff on the need for a $6-billion manned-bomber program.

LONDON, May 12 The Astors are leaving Cliveden. The great mansion on the Thames in Buckinghamshire, with its gardens and golf, swimming pool and tennis courts, statues and pavilions, where the "Cliveden set" discussed the fate of Czechoslovakia in 1938, and where John Profumo, then Secretary of State for War, met Christine Keeler in 1961, is to become the province of tourists.
VIENNA, May 12 The monitoring of the sun by an earth satellite has disclosed a steep rise in solar X-ray emissions during recent months.

NAIROBI, Kenya, May 12-- Remnants of the Mau Mau leadership have banded together in a publishing company to improve their image and correct some of the "wrong things" that have been written and said about their 10-year campaign of terrorism to win freedom from the British.

ISLIP, L.I., May 12 Governor Rockefeller and a delegation of more than 60 state legislators and officials attended a funeral service here today for State Senator Elisha T. Barrett. The 63-year-old Republican from Brightwaters died Sunday night in Albany after suffering a heart attack.

WASHINGTON, May 12-- The House Ways and Means Committee is prepared to shelve proposed Federal minimum standards for state benefit payments to the jobless. The action would be organized labor's third major setback of the year.
David L. Cole, chief mediator in the newspaper dispute, said last night that there had been "no appreciable movement" this week toward settling the 18day-old strike.

DETROIT, May 12 Sales of new automobiles dropped by slightly more than 15 per cent during the first 10 days of May, compared with the same period last year, manu facturers' reports showed today. Of the four major manu- facturers, only Ford reported an increase.

Racine County, Wis., sold yesterday $9.4-million of school district bonds to a group led by the First National Bank of Chicago, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company and Halsey, Stuart Co. A bid of 100.0002 for coupons of 5 and 3.60 per cent resulted in an annual net interest cost of 3.673.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (UPI) Representative Theodore R. Kupferman, Republican of New York, and New York Deputy Mayor Robert Price have filed applications with the Federal Communications Commission to divest themselves of their interest in three radio stations.
SANA, Yemen, May 1-- Serious food shortages have brought some parts of central and northern Yemen near the brink of famine, according to Western diplomatic circles here.

YONKERS, May 12 Romeo Hanover and Overcall paced up to their advance billing in capturing the two divisions of the Cane Prep tonight at Yonkers Raceway. Both favorites won their one-mile tune-ups for next week's Cane Pace handily, Romeo Hanover beating Caliburn by three lengths in 2:02 and Overcall turning back Tracer Hanover by three-quarters of a length in 2:04.
Evangelist Billy Graham and the Most Rev. F. Donald Coggan, Archbishop of York, shared the dais yesterday at the Philharmonic Hall of the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.

Kennedy Airport--From downtown or midtown Manhattan take an E or F IND train on the 8th or 6th Avenue lines, respectively, to the Union Turnpike-Kew Gardens Station in Queens, a 26-minute ride from 42d Street, Manhattan.

BALTIMORE, May 12 (UPI) The Chicago White Sox, capitalizing on two Baltimore errors and their own alert base running, handed the Orioles a 5-3 defeat tonight to knock them out of first place in the American League.

TURIN, Italy, May 12 (AP) Mrs. Billie Jean King and Julie Heldman scored singles victories today that carried the United States past France, 2-1, into the semi-finals of the women's Federation Cup tennis tournament.

Governor Rockefeller proposed yesterday the construction of a "coordinated community" of offices, light industry, housing and commercial and recreational facilities on 98 acres of filled-in-land on the Hudson River from the Battery to Chambers Street.

BROOKLINE, Mass., May 12 Dr. and Mrs. Philip H. Walker have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Suzanne Hulet Walker, to Thomas North Gilmore, son of Prof. Myron Piper Gilmore and Mrs. Gilmore of Cambridge.

LIDO BEACH, L.I., May 12 After breaking the course record with a morning round of 66, Gene Borek, numbed by the cold, slumped to a 79 this afternoon and tied for first place in the Metropolitan Professional Golfers' Association sectional qualifying round for the P.G.A. tourney.

WASHINGTON, May 12 A proposal for a new and broadened Senate committee to oversee the Central Intelligence Agency won a surprisingly easy victory today in a test vote in the Foreign Relations Committee.
An even $100-million was the price paid yesterday by the Hess Oil and Chemical Corporation for the 10 per cent interest in the Amerada Petroleum Corporation held by the British Government.

Mrs. Hildegard Halstead Sleeper, widow of Harold Reeve Sleeper, architect, and a founder of the Women's Architectural Auxiliary of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects, died Wednesday in the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. She was 61 years old and lived at 50 Sutton Place South.
Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, presi- dent of City College, argued with hundreds of students yesterday over whether the college should release a student's class standing to his draft board.

Mrs. Edwynna Wilson Davis of New York and Charles David Labouchere of Gstaad, Switzerland, and Marigne, France, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alix Elaine Labouchere of New York, to Marc-Antoine Chessex of Bussigny, Switzerland. His parents are the late Mr. and Mrs. Marc Emile Chessex of Lausanne.
BOSTON, May 12 Mayor John F. Collins of Boston announced today his candidacy for the Senate.
LONDON, May 12 The Kurdish revolutionary Army announced today that the Iraqi Army had started a new offensive, its fourth since 1961, against the Kurds in northern Iraq.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 12 Scores of Nassau County policemen swarmed through affluent North Shore communities at daybreak today to arrest 28 persons allegedly engaged in a bookmaking operation that was said to have taken in $2.5-million a year.

PHILADELPHIA, May 12 (UPI) The Budd Company announced today that it was mak- ing a "very slight" reduction in auto chassis frames production at its plants here. The company said the cutback would not result in any lay-offs.

THE British have established a new beachhead here at 700 Fifth Avenue (between 54th and 55th Streets). That is where Suedes of London, a shop dealing in imported leatherwear and accessories, opened this week.

Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall is under heavy pressure from oil companies to permit development of the oil shale deposits in public lands. The companies own considerable shale lands, but they do not want to start working them until they obtain the rights to exploit the public lands as well.
It was another gray day on Wall Street yesterday, both inside and out.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) The Port of New York Authority would pay Federal taxes on revenue derived from commercial operations at its World Trade Center, under a bill introduced today by Representative Eugene J. Keogh, Democrat of Brooklyn.

BARCELONA, Spain, May 12 Roman Catholic clergymen in Catalonia were reported today to be planning major demonstrations this weekend to protest a refusal by the Archbishop of Barcelona to condemn publicly the beating of 100 priests by the police here yesterday.

As two kilted Scottish pipers lustily played "Scotland the Brave," pretty girls in uniform and a clutch of Canadian dignitaries joined with officials of Macy's yesterday to salute Canada's forthcoming international exhibition, "Expo '67," scheduled to open in Montreal next April 28.
ALBANY, May 12 Mayor Lindsay has invited legislative leaders to a City Hall meeting tomorrow to discuss New York City's tax program, which has run into trouble in the divided Legislature.
WASHINGTON, May 12 The National Safety Council, in a change of policy, testified toeral authority to establish minday in support of stand-by Fedimum safety standards for new passenger automobiles.

Sales of the nation's leading chain stores and mail order houses increased in April over the corresponding month last year. It also was the 59th consecutive monthly increase, a survey made by The New York Times disclosed yesterday.

Parents plan to borrow the public playground at Central Park West and 90th Street from their children tomorrow and Sunday. Barring rain, they will hang paintings and set up sculpture to be sold to raise $5,000 for equipment exciting enough to make more youngsters want to use the playground.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 12--Secretary General Thant undertook to reply today to critics who had accused the United Nations of dragging its feet in Vietnam.

Two major soft coal companies raised their prices yesterday and other concerns indicated they would follow suit soon. The increases are retroactive to April 1 when a new contract set rises in miners' wages, ranging from 2 to 7.5 per cent.
BALTIMORE, May 12 Five civil rights pickets were arrested today in front of an apartment building on charges of violating an injunction limiting such demonstrations to Sunday afternoons.

Benjamin Adelstein, chief mining engineer for the Securities and Exchange Commission, testified in Federal Court here yesterday that the agency did not allow gross assay values the projected worth of an ore body to be included in registration statements on stock of ferings.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 12 The United Nations Relief and Works Agency, which looks after 1.3 million Arab refugees from Israel, has found funds or received pledges of funds sufficient to cover its $4.2-million budgetary deficit for this year.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) The House passed a bill today designed to relieve the freight-car shortage by encouraging construction of new ones and more efficient use of those now on the rails.
Mrs. Celia Guttenberg Eliasberg, the wife of Irving Eliasberg, a retired industrialist, died yesterday after a long illness, in her home at 875 Fifth Avenue. She was 67 years old.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) Senators opposing President Johnson's plan to cut $82-million from the special school milk program in the next year testified today that the program should be expanded and made permanent.

An Institute on Law and Ethics, where "great" men will sit at a table and "think and discuss what is right," will be established by the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, Dr. Louis Finkelstein, the seminary's chancellor said yesterday.

Negotiations were completed yesterday for the Vienna State Opera to appear in Montreal from Sept. 1 to 22, 1967. It will be the first trip to North America for the famous company, which includes the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, May 12 Philip Feldesman of New York and Ira Rubin of Paramus, N.J., moved up with the leaders in the fourth qualifying session of the World Open Pair Championship here last night.

ST. LOUIS, May 12 The St. Louis Cardinals won the first game played in the new $26million Busch Memorial Stadium tonight, defeating the Atlanta Braves, 4-3, in 12 innings. Lou Brock singled home Curt Flood to end a contest that lasted 3 hours 20 minutes.

HOLLYWOOD, May 12 (AP) Eric Pommer, the German film producer who was responsible for such vintage screen classics as "The Blue Angel," "The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari," "Hotel Imperial" and "Congress Dances," died here last Sunday at the age of 76.
LEE, Me. The first hint of things to come was the wet ground around the toll booth of the Maine Turnpike at Augusta.
The British pound was slightly higher in active trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. Sterling for delivery today was quoted at $2.7935, up 3 points from Wednesday.

CHICAGO, May 12 A sharp increase in sales and earnings of the Hilton Hotels Corporation in the first quarter of this year was reported to stockholders at their annual meeting today by Conrad N. Hilton, chairman.

FANTASY is rampant if not dominant at the Henry Street Playhouse, where last night the Alwin Nikolais Dance Company gave Mr. Nikolais's "Vaudeville of the Elements," first performed for the Tyrone Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis at the end of last year.
The Avenue of the Americas Association elected Gustav S. Eyssell, President of Rockefeller Center, Inc., as president at its annual meeting yesterday at the St. Moritz Hotel.

WASHINGTON, May 12 Dr. and Mrs. Karl E. Stromsem have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Julia Dyckman Stromsem, to Edmund Healy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Healy. A wedding on June 18 is planned.
LEXINGTON, Mass., May 12 (AP) The Raytheon Company announced today it had received a $126-million contract from Saudi Arabia for Hawk airdefense missile systems.
CHICAGO, May 12 Montgomery Ward Co. named a new president today, promoted his predecessor to chairman and reported an estimated 33 per cent increase in share earnings.
The taxi strike swept all but 131 of the city's 6,816 fleet- owned cabs off the streets yes- terday, causing hardship for some travelers, but no chaos in the transportation system.
The Board of Elections got a court order yesterday to make available its latest voter lists for Manhattan to Robert B. Blaikie an insurgent Democrat.

SANTO DOMINGO, May 12 Juan Bosch charged in a radio campaign talk yesterday that the election posters of his Dominican Revolutionary party were being tampered with by the Reformist party of Dr. Joaquin Balaguer.
The Bronx Savings Bank announced yesterday the election of Frederick J. Freese as executive vice president. He was formerly senior vice president.

BOSTON, May 12, (AP)-- Two of eight Roman Catholic students expelled last March from St. John's Seminary after a demonstration protesting an alleged lack of academic and personal freedom have enrolled at the Harvard Divinity School.

LONDON, May 12, (UPI) George Smith of Edinburgh, Scotland, will referee the world heavyweight title fight between Cassius Clay, the champion, and Henry Cooper, the British Boxing Board of Control announced today.

Artists from several countries will take part in an International Bach Festival to be given at Philharmonic Hall on six Sunday evenings during the 1966-67 season. This will be the fourth annual Bach festival presented at the hall by Jay K. Hoffman and George F. Schutz.

Mayor Lindsay declared yesterday he would revive what he called the "dormant" Board of Air Pollution Control as a policymaker. He named Robert A. Fox, a 34-year-old chemical engineer, to fill a board post that had been vacant seven years.
WHITE PLAINS, May 12 Mr. and Mrs. Jack Paige have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Karen Joy Paige, to Frederick Kenneth Berdon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon Berdon of Harrison.
PARIS, May 12. Senator Jacob K. Javits urged the members of the North Atlantic alliance today to remove their political headquarters from France.
Dr. Arnon Roy Rojansky, an Israeli lawyer and accountant who was formerly an opera singer, a judge and a United Nations aide, died of a heart ailment Wednesday in Tel Aviv. He was 64 years old.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) A bill to increase parcel post rates by 8.2 per cent and to increase the size and weight of packages that can be mailed between first-class post offices was approved today by the House Post Office Committee.
BAY SHORE, L.I., May 12 Suffolk detectives raided six residences early today and arrested eight persons for allegedly operating a policy ring.

THERE are two types of labor mediators: the pa- tient, team player and the lone wolf with the dazzling insights and creative solutions. Vincent Daniel McDonnell, chairman of the New York State Board of Mediation, the man who is attempting to settle the taxi strike, ...
Viscount Astor of Cliveden, who died March 7 in Nassau, the Bahamas, left more than $2-million in assets in this country, according to his will, filed yesterday in Manhattan Surrogate's Court.
WASHINGTON, May 12-- Arthur J. Goldberg called tonight for the immediate Senate ratification of the human rights treaties on genocide, slavery, forced labor and the political rights of women.

SILVERSTONE, England, May 12 (AP) Denis Hulme of New Zealand became the first driver to exceed 120 miles an hour in a sports car in Britain when his Lola attained a speed of 120.29 m.p.h. today at the Silverstone track.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 12 (AP) J. Allen Sherman, chairman of Cassius Clay's local draft board, said today that the world heavyweight champion had filed two appeals of his 1-A draft status, both of which were rejected by the local board.
HONG KONG, Friday, May 13 Communist China asserted today that five United States fighter planes intruded yesterday into Yunnan Province and shot down one of its military aircraft.
BEFORE his appointment as drama critic of The Times, Stanley Kauffmann served eight shining years as the regular film critic of The New Republic.
The Mets and the Houston Astros conceded last night that New York's spring weather was fit for neither man nor baseball, and postponed the final game of their series in Shea Stadium.
WASHINGTON, May 12 A compromise truth-in-packaging bill has been drafted that could end the long Congressional deadlock over this controversial issue.
WASHINGTON, May 12 Rail freight ton-mileage and intercity truck tonnage in the latest week ended May 7, were both above the volume in the corresponding week of 1965.
MOSCOW, May 12 Seri- ous flooding has struck large areas of northern Russia, isolating many communities and forcing the evacuation of thousands of people.

Five of the 37 Off Broadway playhouses have made arrangements with Shepard Traube to provide them with bookings as their over-all producer. The houses, and their seating capacities, are Renata (162), Provincetown Playhouse (182), Actors Playhouse (150), Gramercy Arts (199) and Theater Four (299).

WASHINGTON, May 12 Robert C. Weaver, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, said today he was opposed to exempting "Mrs. Murphy's Boarding House" from the openhousing section of the Administration's civil rights bill.

WASHINGTON, May 12 The Johnson Administration was surprised tonight by Peking's charge that American jets had shot down a Chinese plane about 15 miles inside Communist China. They said they were unable to comment on Peking's protest.

Alfred G. Vigderman, political counselor of the United States Embassy in Athens, and Mrs. Vigderman have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Auster Vigderman, to James Franklin Goldberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney D. Goldberg of Washington.
WASHINGTON, May 12 The House Education and Labor Committee completed action today on an antipoverty bill authorizing a $1.75-billion program for the year beginning July 1.
GENEVA, May 12 An unusual East-West alliance of major powers failed today to win an economy fight in the World Health Organization's annual Assembly.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 12 Leslie A. Roberts, a 44-year-old labor union organizer, announced his candidacy today for the Democratic nomination for Congress in the 26th District, which covers eastern Westchester County.

What is turning out to be one of the most influential and at the same time tormenting religious utterances of the modern era was written from a Nazi prison on April 30, 1944. The author was Dietrich Bonhoeffer, a sensitive young German Protestant ...

Exuberance seems to have taken Governor Rockefeller captive in his impulsive disclosure yesterday of plans for a miniature metropolis on the Lower West Side. So elated was the Governor that he couldn't hold his announcement for a prearranged joint conference with Mayor Lindsay.
MOSCOW, May 12--Leading Soviet scientists published a new plea yesterday for action to save Lake Baikal, a large body of fresh water in Siberia, from being turned into an industrial cesspool.
The Hershey Chocolate Corporation, the largest domestic producer of chocolate and cocoa products, reported yesterday little change in its first-quarter earnings from a year ago.
ANAHEIM, Calif., May 12 (AP) Don Lock drove in three runs with a homer and a single tonight to lead the Washington Senators to a 4-2 victory over the California Angels.
HARRISBURG, Pa., May 12 Leaders of the Pennsylvania Republican organization opened a drive today to nominate a dead man against a former Goldwater backer in the primary election next Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, May 12. President Johnson today visited soldiers who had been wounded in Vietnam. He was visibly saddened.

THE list of disposable, packable, portable, adjustable and convertible items for in- fants has reached such impressive proportions that Macy's has decided to gather them all together in a center to be called "Have Baby, Will Travel."
SAN FRANCISCO, May 12 Five men have been arrested on charges of conspiracy to commit murder in connection with the killing of a painters' union official here in April.
BONN, May 12 The on-again-off-again effort by Texaco, Inc., to take over Deutsche Erdol, A.G., the big West German oil and coal company, is definitely on again.

The 21 municipal hospitals will begin evacuating convalescent patients early next week and will halt admissions of nonemergency cases on Monday unless substantial progress is made in negotiations with the city's nurses.

LUSAKA Zambia, May 12 President Kenneth Kaunda said at news conference today that China should not be condemned for testing nuclear devices when stronger nations were "raining" bombs in Vietnam near her borders.

WASHINGTON, May 12 The Administration's proposal to liberalize trade with Communist nations of Eastern Europe was dealt an unexpectedly swift and fatal blow in Congress today by Representative Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee.
Cocoa futures and industrial stocks had something in common yesterday some nervous speculators who sold out.
WASHINGTON, May 12 The official "silly season" in this country runs with the dogdays, from the Fourth of July to Labor Day, but this year it has started early.

Frederic S. Berman, City Rent and Rehabilitation Commissioner, said last night that his department would not allow any landlord to increase rent unless the building involved was free of all violations and maintained all essential services.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., May 12 The State Investigation commission today was asked to look into the sale by the state for $1 each of two houses that were to be turned over to a Mount Vernon alderman.

Prize winners at the eighth annual American Film Festival include movies from England, Australia, Canada and Russia, films from American television and a pair of screen offerings by two American newspapers. The winners were named last night at the closing banquet in the Biltmore Hotel.

PHILADELPHIA, May 13 (AP) Dick Farrell allowed only one hit in eight innings Tony Taylor's triple in the fifth as Houston nipped Philadelphia, 1 0, tonight. Jim Wynn's homer off Chris Short in the ninth produced the Astros' run.
The Union Pacific Railroad plans to spend an additional $32,157,000 for more equipment to be delivered this year, Edd H. Bailey, president, said yesterday.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange declined for the second day yesterday in moderate trading.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) Industrial production continued to rise to record levels during April, but the increase was the smallest monthly advance since last September, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
LINCOLN, Neb., May 13 (AP) The Olin Foundation, Inc., of New York gave the Nebraska Wesleyan University of Lincoln $2,347,248 today for construction of an Olin Hall of Science.
AUSTIN, Tex., May 13 President Johnson's old school caught the Great Society aid train just as it was about to pull out of the station.
WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) The Civil Aeronautics Board reaffirmed today its refusal to permit Railway Express Agency, Inc., to raise the rates for air express.
WASHINGTON, May 13 The Job Corps Center for Women in St. Petersburg, Fla., is pulling up stakes and moving to another community because of local hostility.
After taking stock of so many other things in life, television will speculate on "Wall Street: Where the Money Is."
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 13 The marriage of Dr. Micheline M. Mathews to Dr. Robert Steele Roth took place this afternoon in St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church.
DAMASCUS, Syria, May 13 (AP) The Arab League has reported that it has warned the Coca-Cola Company of boycotts and plant closures if the company tries to do business with Israel.

History must present the whole process of the revolutionary struggle in the complexity, base itself on the scientific analysis of social reality, and describe the fact not according to the subjective wishes of people, not according to monetary [and] political requirements and temporary criteria, but as they happened and in accordance with truth.
SAIGON, May 13 Senior United States Air Force officers here have been disheartened by the restrictions placed on their conduct of the air war over North Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, May 13 The Administration refused today to make any direct comment on Peking's charge that United States jet fighters had intruded into Communist China and shot down a Chinese military aircraft.
Mayor Lindsay criticized the Legislature yesterday and by implication the City Council for "irresponsibility" in holding back action on his transportation bills until late in the legislative session.

KANSAS CITY, May 13 An injury of undetermined severity to Whitey Ford cast a small cloud over the 4-2 victory the New York Yankees scored tonight over the Kansas City Athletics in the opener of a four-game series.
Navy's lacrosse team, the most successful in the country, takes its bag of tricks to Baltimore today to face a fine Johns Hopkins ten.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 13 (AP) Mario Andretti set an unofficial record of 167,411 miles an hour for the Indianapolis Motor Speedway today during a practice run on wet pavement.

PORT ARTHUR, Tex., May 13 (AP) A record cloudburst hit Galveston and part of the Conroe area north of Houston received 12 inches of rain today as severe downpours tied up parts of south and southeast Texas.

A MAN dreams, a man loves, a man prays, a man dies. And that is the story or, for that more important matter, the spirit of George Balanchine's moving epic ballet "Don Quixote," revived last night by the New York City Ballet at the State Theater, Lincoln Center.

Otto A. Ritzmann Jr., promotion plans coordinating manager of Lever Brothers Company, 390 Park Avenue, died Thursday of a heart attack at Flower-Fifth Avenue Hospital He was 58 years old and lived at 500 East 77th Street.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 13 (AP) The Rev. Guy Wesley Howard, who gained fame as the "walkin' preacher of the Ozarks," died yesterday at his home. He was 74 years old.

Once again, as so many times in the past, Charles A. Buckley is contemplating retirement. The aging Democratic leader of the Bronx told his dwindling array of organization lieutenants at their annual dinner that this year might be his last on the political scene. Unfortunately, the Bronx boss has given similar hints so many times in the past half-dozen years that it is a bit difficult to take him literally.
LISBON, May 13--More than half a milion pilgrims gathered in Fatima today for the annual pilgrimage to the shrine of the Virgin Mary.

NEW DELHI, May 13 Asoka Mehta, India's Planning Minister, announced today that the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the United States had assured India of "substantially greater assistance than in the past."

BARCELONA, Spain, May 13 Roman Catholic "new church" priests, indignant over police beating of some of the clergy and the subsequent propaganda campaign against them, are taking their case before public opinion.

Senator Robert F. Kennedy and Mayor Lindsay have been elected as trustees of the National Art Museum of Sport. Announcement of their election was made yesterday at the semi-annual meeting of the trustees at the Harvard Club.

City library doors are being closed in the faces of students trying to study for their examinations because of Mayor Lindsay's "job freeze," City Council President Frank D. O'Connor declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 13--The index of primary market prices rose three-tenths of 1 per cent to 105.4 of its 1957-59 base during the week ended May 10, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Prices increased for farm products and processed foods but averaged unchanged for industrial commodities.
Mrs. Anne Roberts resigned yesterday as executive director of the Economic Opportunity Committee, the city's antipoverty agency.

Mrs. Clara Schwartzman Chess of 10 Mitchell Place, a retired public school teacher who worked mainly with pupils who were retarded in reading, died yesterday in Park East Hospital. Her age was 83. She was the widow of Benjamin Chess, a lawyer, and the mother of Dr. Stella Chess, a prominent child psychiatrist.
JACKSON, Miss., May 13--The Mississippi Legislature today approved legislation to legalize the sale of liquor in the state, the last in the nation to have statewide prohibition.

YONKERS, May 13 Harry's Laura, loser in all her seven previous outings this season, accounted for the year's fastest one-mile pace, over a half-mile track, as she captured the feature event in 2:00 1/5 at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

A chanting group of 150 students took over the administration building at City College yesterday as part of a mounting nationwide protest against college participation in the Selective Service process.

PHILADELPHIA, May 13 The Defense Personnel Support Center, the Government agency that buys apparel for the armed forces, answered today charges by certain men's clothing producers that its mandatory orders were being unfairly allocated.

Thomas W. Gleason, president of the International Longshoremen's Association has sent messages to members of the New York State Legislature urging them to defeat a pending measure that would give the Waterfront Commission authority to set mental and physical standards for waterfront workers.

Exaggerated alarms about the future course of business activity have been raised by the decline in automobile sales for the first ten days of May. Henry Ford 2d has warned Congressional critics that if they do "something that is irrational they can upset the economy of this country very quickly ..." And Michigan's Gov. George Romney has solemnly observed that "any time people refuse to buy cars this country is in economic difficulty."

SAIGON, May 13 United States marines, South Vietnamese infantrymen and armed helicopters have killed 267 Vietcong guerrillas in sharp battles in widely separated areas of South Vietnam, military spokesmen said today.

Lou Schneider, president of the corporation bearing his name at 570 Seventh Avenue, died of a heart attack yesterday while on vacation in Rome. He was 73 years old and lived at 1020 Park Avenue. The company, formerly a women's coat and suit manufacturer, is a real estate and mortgage concern.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 13 Prof. Ernst Bergmann, who led Israel's atomic development program from its inception until last month, was awarded the State Security Prize today for contributions to national defense.

Norman Rosten, Brooklyn poet and playwright, will be introduced to guests tomorrow afternoon at a party at the home of Mrs. Albert C. Magee of Brooklyn Heights that was arranged in behalf of the Brooklyn Association for Mental Health.

Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Friezner of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sharon Rona Friezner, to Leslie E. Bloomenthal. Mr. Bloomenthal is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Abraham P. Bloomenthal of Waltham, Mass.
The Salvation Army opened a 38-hour evangelistic crusade yesterday noon near the corner of Eighth Avenue and 42d Street. The nonstop "campaign for souls" will end at 2 A.M. tomorrow.

The Hospitals Department, threatened with a mass resignation of nurses, yesterday directed the 21 municipal hospitals to begin closing outpatient clinics on Monday and postponed vacations of all employes who care for patients.
"VRRRRROOM!" said Mrs. Charles Gaines as she sat in her handsomely appointed apartment on West 15th Street. "VROOM, VROOM, VROOM, VROOM."

BONN, May 13 United States, British and West German diplomats have drawn up a list of the detailed conditions under which France would be allowed to keep her forces in West Germany after they were withdrawn from the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's command July 1.
LONG BEACH, Calif., May 13 Walter P. Reuther today dismissed the current slackening in car production as an "inventory adjustment" of only temporary nature.
WASHINGTON, May 13--An Atlanta physician was granted a patent this week for a calorie meter. A person can calculate the calories he is consuming by measuring ...

TOKYO, May 13 (AP) Jenmin Jih Pao, the Chinese Communist party newspaper, has denounced Mikhail Sholokhov, the Soviet novelist, as a "traitor" and "revisionist writer," the Peking radio reported today in a broadcast monitored here.
BONN, May 13 The West German Government appealed to the Arab nations today to normalize diplomatic relations with Bonn as soon as possible.

CANNES, France, May 13--The decks have been cleared for what is expected to be the biggest, swashiest turnout of stars and rubbernecks of this year's Cannes Film Festival. The occasion will be the gala showing of "Doctor Zhivago" tomorrow night in the Palais des Festivals, and already anticipation is reaching explosive heat.
The Jewish Chronic Disease Hospital in Brooklyn will mark its 41st anniversary with a President's Ball at the WaldorfAstoria tomorrow.
The Johnson Administration should move "right now" to set Congressional machinery in motion to increase taxes, a leading New York City banker said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 13 The United States agreed today to abide by an international treaty governing the liability of airlines after a majority of international carriers had accepted an increase in the liability limits from $8,300 to $75,000 a person.
A campaign to save from demolition the 77-year-old Sterling Opera House of Derby, Conn., has been started by citizens and the Mayor of that community of 12,300 people.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 13 Ronald Reagan has demanded a legislative investigation of alleged Communism and sexual misconduct at the University of California at Berkeley. He insists on public hearings.
Thousands of persons from all parts of the country are expected to converge on Washington this weekend to participate tomorrow in a march urging an end to the war in Vietnam.

A colt that has won all six of his races, the Bwamazon Farm's Creme dela Creme, will seek today to add a stakes victory to his 1966 accomplishments. He will compete in the $50,000 added Withers Mile for 3-year-olds against nine rivals. The race will be run for the 91st time.
ANAHEIM, Calif., May 13 (AP) Rick Reichardt drove in three runs with a single and a homer, and Dean Chance pitched a five-hitter tonight as the California Angels defeated Boston, 4-1.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 13 Delmar Leighton, who retired as dean of Harvard College in 1963 after 40 years of guiding undergraduates, died of a heart attack yesterday at his summer home in St. Andrews, N.B. He was 69 years old.
Dr. Van Zandt Williams, director of the American Institute of Physics, 335 East 45th Street, died yesterday in London. He was 50 years old and lived at Greenwich, Conn.

Richard H. Clayton, a Texas Gulf Sulphur Company engieer, testified in Federal Court here yesterday that he had recommended that the concern purchase land at Kidd Creek, Ont., before beginning a ground geophysical survey of the area. Aerial reconnaissance of the area, he said, had established that the site was a "first-class" possibility.

LONDON, May 13 (UPI) Jubilant Conservative leaders contended today that the party's sweeping victory in yesterday's nationwide municipal elections was the first step toward ending the Labor party's control of Parliament.
BOSTON, July 13 Gov. John A. Volpe and the Massachusetts Senate have ordered separate investigations of student publications at the University of Massachusetts.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 13 The nation's top business leaders rose to the defense of the auto industry today in the controversy over automobile safety standards.
Cardinal Spellman, the 77year-old Archbishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, will mark the 50th anniversary today of his ordination to the priesthood.

The Americana's Imperial Ballroom was the setting last night for the Carnation Ball, held in behalf of the Children's Asthma Research Institute and Hospital in Denver. Robert W. Dowling was chairman of the event. Mrs. Jacob G. Albert and Charles Van Rensselaer were co-chairmen.
It was the day of the critics yesterday at the City Hall hearings on the proposed World Trade Center.

In a decision rare in criminal cases, Federal Judge Marvin E. Frankel granted a defense motion to take a pretrial deposition from the informant in a tax evasion case against Charles E. Hagedorn, a publisher.

PATERSON, N.J., May 13 Elmer E. Rowland, who operated a taxidermy shop in New York from 1937 until 1959, died today in Paterson General Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived here at 446 Park Avenue.
LONDON, May 13 (AP) Czechoslovakia, West Germany and France took 2-0 leads, while favored Spain was idled by rain today in the second round of the European Zone Davis Cup tennis eliminations.

To help meet the problem of seaman and ship officer shortages, graduation exercises of the 1966 class of 198 cadets of the United States Merchant Marine Academy, Kings Point, L. I. will be held on June 1 this year.
Mayor Lindsay's tax program appeared to have run into a political stone wall yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) Corporate profits before taxes rose to a record high during the first three months of this year, reaching a seasonally adjusted annual level of $78.3-billion before taxes, the Commerce Department reported today.

Senator Robert F. Kennedy said yesterday that if Governor Rockefeller had not vetoed the statewide primary bill last year, "he would not be the Republican Gubernatorial candidate Senator Javits would."
WASHINGTON, May 13 President Johnson staged a major White House ceremonial today to celebrate a temporary victory in the hope that Congress would be encouraged to make the victory permanent.
The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation is continuing its acquiring ways.

CLEVELAND, May 13 (AP) Leon Wagner raced home in the 11th inning tonight as Jerry Adair, the Baltimore second baseman, threw the ball into the dirt at home plate, giving the league-leading Cleveland Indians a 4-3 victory over the Orioles.

ALGIERS, May 13 The Al gerian Government has established a special top-level commission to undertake negotiations for a new "formula of cooperation" with American and other non-French oil companies here.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 13 Government economists and major business leaders agreed today that the economy would unquestionably continue to prosper through the end of this year.

THE controversy over the safety of automobiles was summarized last night by the Columbia Broadcasting System in a television report that was forthright and frequently illuminating. Its most worthwhile feature was the innate advantage of using motion pictures to illustrate specific safety problems that necessarily cannot be presented so vividly in printed reports.

WASHINGTON, May 13 Senator Thomas J. Dodd won the right today to exclude the press from the pretrial questioning in his libel and conspiracy suit against Drew Pearson and Jack Anderson, the columnists.
PHILADELPHIA, May 13 Roy J. McCorkle, finance secretary for the American Friends Service Committee, died today at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived in Swarthmore.
PARIS, May 13 (Reuters) Anna Langfus, the fourth woman to win France's top literary award, the Prix Goncourt, died in a hospital here yesterday after a heart attack at the age of 46.

Earnings of the Hilton International Company, which operates hotels outside this country, rose sharply in the first four months of 1966 and are expected to maintain the rise, Conrad N. Hilton, chairman and president, told the annual meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 13 Jim Purcell, a right-hander, halted Army's Eastern League five-game winning streak today as Cornell defeated the Cadets, 4-0, on Hoy Field. Purcell scattered four hits and struck out 13.

Frank Wille, the New York State Superintendent of Banks, proposed a four-point Federal program yesterday to eliminate competitive disparities between state-chartered banks and their national, or Federally-chartered counterparts.

As all know, a lively debate is now on over economic policy and whether in particular to increase taxes. If this debate is to be fully understood, and the associated irony fully savored, the reader should have information which, though part of the public record, needs to be put in more organized form.

HONG KONG, May 13 Peking denounced today Thailand's decision to send a small force to South Vietnam and declared that the Thai Government was setting itself "against the people of Indochinese and Southeast Asian countries."

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 13 The wind blew hard, the temperature was low and scores soared to unpleasant heights today for most of the 130 golfers who teed off in the qualifying round of the 38th annual Walter J. Travis Memorial tournament.

Renewed efforts by Mayor Lindsay to break the impasse in the taxi strike negotiations yielded no progress yesterday. As the weekend travel rush developed, thousands of persons were harassed by the shortage of cabs and by pricegouging.

Supreme Court Justice Arthur G. Klein, designated last week by the Democrats as their candidate for Manhattan Surrogate, was unanimously endorsed for the post last night by the New York County Republican organization.

WASHIGTON, Mon. 13 (UPI) (UPI) Allen S. Whiting, chief of Far East research and analysis in the State Department's Bureau of Intelligence and Research, will become deputy to the United States Consul General in Hong Kong, the State Department announced today.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, May 13 Rhodesia's nine High Court judges have been excluded from playing their traditional role in opening Parliament.

WASHINGTON, May 13--A major research project to determine to what extent Roman Catholic religious materials may promote anti-Jewish prejudice has been started at the Catholic University of Louvain, Belgium, one of Western Europe's oldest academic institutions.

On Thursday evenings, on Fifth Avenue near 47th Street the heart of New York's retail area one is likely to hear a string quartet or a recital of Japanese koto music. Or, if one listens more closely, one might hear a lec- ture on Sex and the TeenAger or the En Garde! of a fencing match.

PITTSBURGH, May 13 (AP) Roberto Clemente tripled in the seventh inning and scored the tie-breaking run on Jim Pagliaroni's sacrifice fly as the Pittsburgh Pirates beat the Los Angeles Dodgers, 4-3, tonight.

HOLLYWOOD, May 13 More musicals will be going before the cameras in the next few months than have been produced here in a generation. After long neglect, the motion picture studios now plan to commit nearly $100-million to the genre.
Edward Everett Cauthorne, Harvard's oldest alumnus, died Thursday night eight days before his 104th birthday in the Neponsit Home for the Aged in Queens.

MOSCOW, May 13 A mild winter and generous rain, ever a farmer's good fortune, have enabled the Soviet Union's important winter wheat crop to recover from the bad weather of the fall, Western agricultural experts said today.

LONDON, May 13 (Reuters) A bronze head of Sir Winston Churchill by Sir Jacob Epstein one of an edition of 10 was bought for 5,040 ($14,112) at Christie's, auctioneers, today on behalf of Lord Thomson, the newspaper publisher.

FREEPORT, L.I., May 13 Alexander E. Frontera, City Collector of New York from 1948 to 1956, died Wednesday at the Pompano Beach (Fla.) Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived here at 85 North Long Beach Avenue.
SYDNEY, Australia, May 13 The Labor party has committed itself to withdrawal of Australian forces from Vietnam if it wins federal elections later this year.

PARIS, May 13 Elieth Roux, a blond Parisian pacesetter who is assistant manager in the couture house of Christian Dior here, is moving to New York Sept. 1 to help Bergdorf Goodman expand the scope of its custom salon.

Although he was billed as the star attraction at last night's "Sanremo Festival," a program of current Italian popular hits at Carnegie Hall, the tenor Giuseppe Di Stefano did not appear until the second half and then only sang a short list of innocuous pop tunes.
A bag containing 18 automatic .45-caliber pistols stolen from Fort Eustis, Va., was fished from the East River at 81st Street yesterday by Police Department scuba divers.

The biennial "let's-raise-steelprices" season seems to have arrived. Charles M. Beeghly, chairman of the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, said yesterday the company might raise some steel prices. He declined to specify which products might be raised or when J. would take the step.
WASHINGTON, May 13-- Dr. Timothy F. Leary, a pioneer experimenter with LSD, acknowledged today that use of the drug was out of control.
