PHILADELPHIA, May 13 Abram L. Spector of Elkins Park, founder and chairman of the board of the Dial Shoe Company, Inc., died Wednesday in the University of Pennsylvania Hospital.

The Public Education Association praised Dr. Albert H. Bowker, the Chancellor of the City University, yesterday for his "courage" in refusing to admit more students without being assured of additional state and city funds.

CAIRO, May 13 The United Arab Republic stepped up its press campaign against the United States today. It said that friendship with Washington was not possible because it "wants agents and not friends" in the underdeveloped world.
Two snipers apparently firing an air gun and a BB gun from a car wove a zigzag pattern of pain and fear through Manhattan on Thursday night.

Chadbourn Gotham, Inc., hosiery and lingerie manufacturer, showed a sharp recovery from last year with net earnings of $1,756,717, or 71 cents a share, for the 36 weeks ended April 9, J.C. Bolles, president and trestreasurer, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 13--At 9 A. M. tomorrow in 1,200 test centers across the nation, some 350,000 college students will take an examination that may determine whether they stay in school or wind up in Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, May 13 A new and far-reaching assertion of independence by Rumania has alerted officials here to the possibility that the Balkan Communist nation may be getting ready to quit the Warsaw Pact.

The owner and the prospective buyer of an apartment in an almost exclusively white Queens neighborhood complained to the city's Human Rights Commission yesterday of an asserted joint action between cooperatives to keep Negroes out.

JERSEY CITY, May 13 Dr. Pinckney J. Harman, head of the department of anatomy at the New Jersey College of Medicine and Dentistry for 10 years, died today at the Jersey City Medical Center. He was 53 years old and resided at 107 Kensington Avenue.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 110.5 on Thursday from 110.6 on Wednesday.
The spot rate of the British pound dropped 10 points to $2.7925 in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday.
The trading volume on commodity exchanges has continued to climb this year, outpacing 1965, which was a record year.
BERGEN, Norway, May 13 The seven countries of the European Free Trade Association pledged today to pursue the integration of Western Europe "by all available means."

FARMINGTON, Conn., May 13 Australis, the 1965 national high-point champion, and Red Shoes, who spent most of the year chasing him for the title, won one open jumper class each today as the Children's Services Horse Show got under way at the Farmington Polo Grounds. They tied for the lead with 5 points each.
CHICAGO, May 13 About 400 University of Chicago students voted tonight to end a sit-in that they had been conducting in the university administration building.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 13 Three thousand students from the University of Witwatersrand marched today from their campus to the city center to protest the Government's restriction on Ian Robertson, president of the National Union of South African Students.

BEHIND the bland, round face, the rimless glasses, the turn-wrath-away smile, the mundane words, the soft, hesitant voice that in 27 New York years still stubbornly shows its Massachusetts origin behind all these outward signs of a most commonplace man, there stands, obviously, ...
WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP)--The Supreme Court was asked today to end state and local tax exemptions for houses and buildings used for public worship.
WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) The Atomic Energy Commission said today that Communist China's atomic explosion Monday was not that of a hydrogen weapon.

Almost everywhere these days the stock market is a subject of conversation. As luck would have it, the Rotary Club of Brooklyn had scheduled Jack L. Bruckner, a vice president of Merrill Lynch, Pierce Fenner and Smith, as its speaker this week. His subject: The Market.
As New York apartment buildings get taller, the city's smokestacks have to get taller too, to stay above them.

LOS ANGELES, May 13 (UPI) The bizarre divorce trial of the silent-film actress Corinne Griffith and Danny Scholl, a dancer and singer, ended today with a divorce awarded to her and alimony denied to him. The decision, was handed down by Judge F. Ray Bennett, of the Superior Court.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) The pilot of a chartered airplane which crashed April 22 near Ardmore, Okla., killing 83 persons, suffered from arteriosclerosis and had been under treatment for a heart ailment, Congressmen were told today.
The London Stock Exchange closed firm yesterday despite the scheduled British seamen's strike.
WORCESTER, Mass., May 13 The Harvard varsity and the Pennsylvania freshman heavyweight crews are strong favorites in tomorrow's sprint championships of the Eastern Association of Rowing Colleges.

NEW ORLEANS, May 13 Fighting off pain for 14 holes, Arnold Palmer completed the second round of the $100,000 Greater New Orleans Open golf tournament with a sub-par score of 71. But even though he posted a 36-hole aggregate of 142 to be assured of a place for the remaining two rounds, it was doubtful whether he would be able to continue.

A charge that Warden Henry B. McFarland of Hudson County Jail lied when he denied ever seeing Mrs. Marilyn Jean Fraser, a convicted prostitute, was dismissed yesterday on a motion by the warden's lawyer.
IT'S a short block between Seventh Avenue and Broadway, and a fashion designer named Robert G. Mackintosh is working both ends of the street.

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, May 13 Five of seven American pairs qualified for the final stages of the World Open Pair Championship this afternoon. Robert Jordan and Arthur Robinson of Philadelphia finished second with a score of 8,453 more than a board behind Bob Slavenburg and Hans Kreyns of The Netherlands, who were first, with 8,589.

NORTH SALEM, N.Y., May 13 Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Charles Mergentime have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dian Maxine Mergentime, to John Andre Fatula, son of Mrs. Andre E. Fatula of Philadelphia and the late Mr. Fatula. A July wedding is planned.
When she learned that her husband, who had suffered from severe depressions sev- eral years, must enter a mental hospital, Mrs. C. was frantic.
WASHINGTON, May 13 (UPI) The Federal Aviation Agency postponed again today a resumption of hearings on the controversy over the distance between North Atlantic flight paths.
DALLAS, May 13, (AP) Clifford Ann Creed sank a 35foot chip for an eagle on the 12th hole, took the lead and held it with 142 for 36 holes in the Dallas Civitan open golf tournament today.

Capt. Edward I. McQuiston, U.S.N. retired, former industrial Security officer of the Third Naval District, comprising the New York area, died yesterday at the United States Naval Hospital in St. Albans, Queens, after a long illness. He was 67 years old and lived at 530 East 23d Street.
LANSING, Mich., May 13 Gov. George Romney announced today that 36 Michigan cities and industries had agreed to join in a $200-million program to help end pollution of Lake Erie and the Detroit River.

John T. Thompson, who had been a drama reporter for The New York Journal-American was asphyxiated Tuesday in an accidental fire at his apartment in the Nassau Hotel, 56 East 59th Street, and was pronounced dead on arrival at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 60 years old.

ST. LOUIS, May 13 (UPI) Al Jackson pitched a six-hitter and drove in three runs with a double and a sacrifice fly tonight as the St. Louis Cardinals defeated the Atlanta Braves, 8-0, for their second straight victory in Busch Memorial Stadium.
David L. Cole, chief mediator in the newspaper dispute, said yesterday that he would push hard for a settlement of the strike next week.
The City College faculty has approved a plan to enable students to have a voice in the granting of tenure and promotion for their teachers.
It was more of the same in the stock market yesterday. Prices continued to slide as volume increased.

Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Lubitz have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss SaraNina Lubitz, to Morton N. Richter. Mr. Richter is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Isadore Richter of Chicago. The wedding is planned for June 20.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 13 Relations between the Communist Governments of Rumania and Hungary have deteriorated during the last two months, mainly over the Transylvania issue.
With one exception, all matches were won by teams that challenged in the women's metropolitan inter-club golf series yesterday.

The financial news wires hummed yesterday with stories of the current dialogue about the economy, inflation and taxes, and the bond market, continuing to try to make sense out of the conflict, changed little.

WASHINGTON, May 13 The Senate Commerce Committee approved today a "truthin-packaging" bill designed to simplify the discriminating housewife's task of choosing the best buys when she goes to the supermarket.

The owners of the 2,300-room New Yorker Hotel, against whom a foreclosure action was brought last month, filed a petition yesterday in Federal Court for an arrangement under Chapter XI of the Bankruptcy Act. The hotel has a staff of 700.

LONDON, May 13 (AP) Britain today barred the entry of race horses from the continent because of the outbreak of a disease believed to be swamp fever and immediately threw betting on the English Derby into confusion.
LONDON, May 13 Britain's merchant seamen turned down an appeal by Prime Minister Wilson today and reaffirmed their decision to go on strike midnight Sunday.

PHILADELPHIA, May 13 Trinity College of Hartford, Conn., scored the best time today in the 28th annual Dad Vail Regatta. It won the opening varsity heat of 1.15-16 miles in 6 minutes 40.3 seconds on the Schuylkill.
The major interest in today's 33d annual Metropolitan Intercollegiate track and field championships is not whether Manhattan College will win but rather by how much it will win.
The need for a fundamental reappraisal of Selective Service procedures is put into sharp focus as several hundred thousand students across the country take the first draft deferment tests today.
CAMDEN, N.J., May 13 (AP) The Rutgers University Board of Trustees refused today to dismiss Associate Professor Eugene Genovese, who has said he would welcome a Vietcong victory in Vietnam.
A platoon of future Army second lieutenants established a linguistic beachhead aboard the West German liner Bremen here yesterday.
NOUMEA, New Caledonia This 250-mile-long cigar- shaped South Sea island is an amalgam of Europe and the Pacific and of modern industrial conditions and backward agrarian society.

BALTIMORE, May 13 The White House has rebuffed an appeal to intercede in the case of Eerik Heine, an Estonian emigre who is suing an agent of the Central Intelligence Agency for slander for calling him a Soviet spy.

WITH the foundations pouring as much money into art as they do these days, you would think that one of them would commission a team of biologists, physicians and phychologists to put Louise Nevelson under observation ...

The 14th game of the world chess championship match between Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, and his compatriot, Boris Spassky, was adjourned last night at Moscow's Variety Theater. At adjournment, Spassky had a tiny positional edge.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 13--Gov. George C. Wallace and Alabama's entire Congressional delegation announced today that they would attempt to mobilize the South for a showdown battle over the Federal Government's guidelines for school desegregation.

PARIS, May 13 Foreign Minister Maurice Couve de Murville expressed optimism today about the future of the European Common Market. He forecast the gradual disappearance of political disagreements among its six partners France, West Germany, Italy, the Netherlands, Belgium and Luxembourg.

ITHACA, N. Y., May 13-- Four Democratic contenders for Governor will speak on the Cornell campus tomorrow in the first of a series of forums suggested by Senator Robert F. Kennedy to help the party pick its candidate.

The San Francisco Giants won their 12th straight game early this cold Saturday morning when Jim Davenport hit a home run in the 17th inning to defeat the New York Mets, 5-4, before what was left of the largest crowd of the major league baseball season.
A man spotted through binoculars as he climbed around a Greenwich Village, apartment house last Saturday was sentenced yesterday to nine months in jail.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 13 (UPI) The American Baptist Convention today elected a layman to succeed a theologian as president of the delegates of the 1.5 million member body, also approved a resolution against extremism.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 13 Canada, the principal supplier of troops for United Nations peace forces, suggested today a fresh approach to peacekeeping activities.
WORCESTER, Mass., May 14 --Harvard oars scored a triumph today of almost the same magnitude as last year's in the 21st regatta of the Eastern Association of Rowing Colleges.

WHITE PLAINS, May 14-- The Westchester Welfare Workers Association announced today that 100 of the 224 workers and supervisorS in the county's division of Family and Child Welfare would picket the county office building here Monday to protest their low wages.

Communist China is well on her way toward--in fact may already have--an operational nuclear capability. The third Chinese nuclear test gave evidence of considerable progress--expected by some, surprising to others--in Peking's attempts to achieve a full-member status in the nuclear club.

SAIGON, May 14--Before the end of May the southern parts of South Vietnam and the central plateau stretching north along the west side of the Annamese mountain range, which bisects most of the country, will begin to feel the effects of the annual southwesterly monsoon.

ON a recent weekend, more German authors, critics and publishers could be found on the campus of Princeton University than in Berlin or Munich. They had came from Germany by ship or airplane to attend the annual meeting of Group 47, an organization of writers that numbers among its members nearly every famous name in contemporary German literature.
HANOVER,, N. H., May 14-- Princeton took a 9-1 half-time lead behind the scoring of Marty Eichelberger and John Lloyd and went on to defeat Dartmouth, 17-6, in an Ivy League lacrosse match today.

CHESAPEAKE, va., May 14 The engagement of Miss Linda Lorraine Hopkins to Lieut. (jg.) Kenneth Arthur Lapin, U.S.N.R., has been an nounced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Weston Hopkins. Lietenant Lapin is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Lapin of New York.

The engagement of Miss Victoria Allen Brown, daughter of Mr, and Mrs. Francis Brown of 468 Riverside Drive and Amherst, Mass., to Erno Robert Bonebakker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Erno Bonebakker of Carpinteria, Calif., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents.
ST. VINCENT, Italy--For the 12th consecutive year, American bridge players and tournament followers are asking: Why didn't we win the world championship?

AMSTERDAM, May 14-- Philip Feldesman of New York and Ira Rubin of Paramus, N.J., increased their lead in the world open pair championship here last night. They followed an afternoon score of 612 points with 544 in the night session, and moved more than a board ahead of the field with three sessions to be played.

During his administration, President Eisenhower declared: "This Government has no and will not, as long as I am here, have a positive political doctrine in Its program that has to do with this problem of birth control. That's not our business."

Aaron E. Koota, the Brooklyn District Attorney, has been assailed by the High School Principals Association of New York City for having asserted that LSD, the hallucinogenic drug, was being manufactured in Brooklyn high schools.

WASHINGTON, May 14--It has frequently been said that, if the Supreme Court did not exist, someone would have to invent it. The same might have been said about the constitutional right of privacy, which Justice William O. Douglas discovered in the Bill of Rights less than a year ago.
THE nickel was born a century ago tomorrow. Although it does not buy much today, the nickel was easily America's most useful coin through most of those first 100 years.

When Lou Celente went to work as manager of Mariners Harbor Marina last July, the Staten Island facility had nine boats.

Some of the East's top dragracing cars and drivers will go to the post in eight elimination classes at the Westhampton L.I.drag strip's 10th anniversary "money day" today. The prizes are $2,500 in bonds.

Actually, the words express a sentiment that seems to have been spreading in theatrical circles ever since the successful revival at the George S. KaufamanMoss Hart comedy, "You Can't Take It With You," at the Lyceum.
WHITE PLAINS, May 14-- Miss Nancy Marie McIntyre became the bride today of Jay James Ryan in the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Sorrows here. The Rev. Henry
COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 14 (UPI)--George Ritenour, first president of the United States Trotting Association and a member of its board until 1952, died yesterday in a hospital. His age was 80.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., May 14--Miss Nancy Almy McCain's engagement to Peter Sherburne Dillingham has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Dwight McCain. Her fianc is the son of Mrs. Sherburne Dillingham of Evanston, Ill., and the late Mr. Dillingham.

Piped-in background music that is to be heard, not listened to--proven over the years to give a psychological lift to office efficiency--is becoming standard equipment in some of the newer Long Island office buildings.

IN matters of craftsmanship Albert Roussel was a surgeon of a composer. For Ages 10 and Up. MOST of us think of Leo Tolstoy as the creator of novels in the great tradition, naturalistic works like "Anna, Karenina" or epics like "War and Peace." GAGNON, Que.--It is hard to believe that there was nothing here six years ago except lots of water and lichen moss, sparsely growing spruce, cedar and tamarack trees,wandering herds of caribou and occasional outcroppings of rock. Now, thanks to discoveries of iron ore, a sort of "Instant Town" has sprung up, with two churches, two banks, three schools, supermarkets, fire and police departments, a mayor and a town manager, and airport and a fine hotel.

THE common sea, or herring, gull is not a bird given to carefully ordered sky formations. I hardly knew where to look, simultaneously seeking out a leader, attempting to determine the number of birds.

BERLIN, May 14 (UPI)-- Nino Benvenuti of Italy scored a 14th-round technical knockout over Jupp Elze of West Germany tonight to retain his European welterweight title.
JUNEAU, Alaska, May 14-- A brisk, blue-eyed, 62-year-old woman who dyes her hair a flaming a red is Alaska's first woman candidate for Governor.

The Soviet flag was recently hoisted on the third and last in a series of 19,000-ton passenger liners built in East Germany for the Soviet Union. The Taras Shevchenko was then handed over to her Soviet master, Capt. S.L. Dondua, by officials of the East German Mathias-Thesen yard in Wismar.

WASHINGTON, May 14-- President Johnson created a committee on mental retardation this week to evaluate pres ent programs in the field and to advise him on what new national efforts were needed to cope with the problem.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 12-- The Brazilian economy, supposedly dulled by inflation, is showing unexpected vitality.
AUGUSTA, Me. -- Crescent Beach State Park, Maine's sixth oceanfront state park, will make its debut in midsummer, with parking for 900 cars and facilities to gladden any swimmer, hiker or picnicker.
BUNNELL, Fla.--A few miles east of here, between the Tomoka and Matanzas Rivers, are the well-preserved ruins of what was once one of the largest and finest antebellum plantations in Florida.

The appointment of Dr. Joseph B. Gittler as dean of Yeshiva University's new Ferkauf Graduate School of Humanites and Social Sciences has been announced by Dr. Samuel Belkin, president of the university.

METUCHEN, N.J., May 14-- Leo Slobodien of Redfield Village, who retired in 1957 as head of Slobodien Shoes, a retail chain in the Perth Amboy-New Brunswick area, died of a heart ailment today at Perth Amboy General Hospital. He was 69 years old.

WESTPORT, Conn., May 14 --Comdr. William C. Casey, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Casey have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Eileen Casey, to Robert Arthur O'Neil, son of Capt. Justin A. O'Neil, U.S.N., and Mrs. O'Neil of Virginia Beach, Va.
ITHACA, N.Y., May 14 (AP)--Maple syrup producers of New York State report their sweetest season in years.

By a contractual arrangement unusual in the world of professional prizefighting, Jos Torres will have already collected his $75,000 guarantee before he steps into the Shea Stadium ring Saturday night.

ALGIERS, May 14--The nationalization of eleven foreignowned mines announced May 7 by Col. Houari Boumediene, Al geria's chief of state, has led unexpectedly to new tensions between Algeria and Morocco.

LEE, Me., May 14--Events and conditions can change abruptly in an angler's life. On Sysladobsis Lake Thursday, wind blew all fishing right out of the world, except for a few who went out anyway. This writer played it cagy because there were two small boys who were intent on fishing.

In 1947, John Sloan Dickey,who had just become president of Dartmouth College, created the Great Issues course. It brought to the campus outstanding speakers to address the entire senior class for an hour on Monday evenings, totally off-the-record. On the following morning, the speaker faced the students in a free-for-all question period. The course became a national prototype, and was imitated by many colleges across the country.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand--During the financial year ended March 31, 1966, receipts for exports exceeded payments for imports by L15.9-million ($44.5-million), a review of overseas transactions issued by the Reserve Bank of New Zealand has disclosed, the New Zealand Newsletter reports. Total export earnings increased from L384.3-million ($1.076-billion) last year to L397.1-million ($1.0838-billion) this year. Payments for imports for the same periods totalled L328.5million ($909.8-million) and L371.2-million ($1.0393-billion) respectively.

BARCELONA, May 14--A delegation of Roman Catholic priests warned Barcelona's Archbishop today that unless he publicly condemned Wednesday's beatings of clergymen by the police, priests and their parishioners could no longer have confidence in ecclesiastic authority.

A giant new community that will provide housing for 1,410 families in apartment buildings, duplex town houses and twofamily semi-detached houses has been started on a 52-acre tract overlooking Little Neck Bay at Bayside, Queens.

LONDON May 14 (UPI)--A titled lady armed with an umbrella and a doughty 79-yearold retired newspaper vender armed With a cudgel led a phalanx of shoppers into battle with a gang of jewel robbers near London's fashionable New Bond Street today.

SHEFFIELD, Ala., May 14-- The marriage of Miss Margaret McDonnell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Francis McDonnell, to John Prime Treadwell 4th, son of Mrs. Richard S. Stark of New York and John P. Treadwell 3d of Rhinebeck, N.Y., took place here this afternoon.

Miss Maureen Patricia Walsh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wililiam P. Walsh of Brooklyn and Smithtown, L.I., was married to Michael Joseph Holian yesterday in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral. The Rev. Bernard Donachie performed the ceremony. Mr. Holian is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas P. Holian of Brooklyn.

FARMINGTON, Conn., May 14--Danny Lopez, a 7-yearold high school senior from Old Brookville, L.I., rode Australis to two viotories today and a solid lead for the open jumper championship in the Children's ervices orse Show at the Farmington Polo Grounds.
Early last week, while stock, prices generally were reeling" only a handful of issues managed to post new 1966 highs on the New York Stock Exchange.

Last week, about 500 advertising people from around the world were taken inside the satellite control as 40 television monitors flashed their pictures during the live global transmission of the Olympic Games in Mexico City-- the 1968 Olympics, that is.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., May 14--The executive committee of the Young Republican National Federation warned its New Jersey affiliate tonight that it faced suspension unless it ended the investigation of alleged racial and religious discrimination in its ranks.

ELIZABETH, N.J. May 14-- A police roadblock, set up last night and early today on the Goethals Bridge intended to catch teenagers who had been drinking on Staten Island produced seven cases involving auto violations, but none involving drunkenness.
Hospitals Commissioner Alonzo S. Yerby has proposed fiscal autonomy for Bellevue and Morrisania Hospitals in a pilot project intended to cut red tape.

COLORADO SPRINGS, May 14--Mr. and Mrs. Archibald Gordon Barron of Colorado Springs, formerly of Harvard, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Constance Barron, to Henry Holton Fuller Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Fulton of Milton, Mass. The couple plan to marry here Aug. 13.

SEVERAL years ago when a local television station in Jackson, Miss., applied for a three-year renewal of its license, two civil-rights leaders and a church group filed objections and sought a hearing on their charges that the station had been anti-Negro and anti-Catholic, and that it had carried disproportionate amounts of commercials and entertainment.
SEATTTLE--This city is rediscovering its early boisterous history, thanks to an ex-newspaperman named William Speidel.

TUTZING, Germany, May 14 (AP)--Mathilde Ludendorff widow of Gen. Erich Ludendorff, chief of staff of the German armies in World War I and an early supporter of Adolf Hitler died here last night. She was 89 years old.
D cor reminding guests that horse racing on Long Island is 301 years old has been chosen for the Belmont Ball, to be held June 1 at the Waldorf-Astoria.

GENEVA, N.Y., May 14-- Miss Christine Maltby Bennett and Stephen Palmer Cook plan to be married here in August. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Hawes Bennett, parents of the bride-to-be.
The annual "Fun Night at Yonkers Raceway" for the benefit of Hamilton-Madison House will take place on Thursday. Mrs. Herbert H. Bachrach is chairman for the event.
Five youngsters, 10 to 12 years old, who have founded a committee to oppose the manufacture and sale of war toys, picketed yesterday to mark their protest.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, May 7--Graft is such an accepted part of Haitian life that workers squirmed knowingly when President Francois Duvalier's Government announced an old-age pension program.

The Republican machine in Manhattan wants no part of a fight to reform the Surrogate's Court. Although the Liberal party and the Reform Democrats are eager to mount a campaign against Supreme Court Justice Arthur G. Klein, the candidate of the Democratic organization, the Republicans have instead joined in making his nomination bipartisan.
BOSTON, May 15 The International Brotherhood of Telephone Workers called a general strike tonight against the New England Telephone Company.
SAIGON, May 15--South Vietnamese soldiers killed more than 200 Vietcong guerrillas in fighting in the mangrove swamps of the Mekong Delta yesterday, a Government military spokesman said tonight.
WASHINGTON, May 15--The possible revocation of the tax-exempt status of two religious magazines that opposed Barry Goldwater's Presidential bid in 1964 is under study by the Internal Revenue Service.
The Mets continued to make money faster than the Beatles yesterday, when they broke their second attendance record in three days against the San Francisco Giants.

PITTSBURGH, May 15 (AP) Don Sutton and Phil Regan combined to limit Pittsburgh to six hits today as the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the Pirates, 3-1. The loss was the eighth in the last 10 games for the Pirates.

Mayor Lindsay's sound program for unifying city transportation policy-making agencies is in grave danger of falling victim to chicanery by its opponents in City Hall and Albany. Unwilling to vote openly against a plan so beneficial to all who use mass transit facilities, they have set up a situation in which the State Legislature can blame the City Council and the Council can blame the Legislature for failing to act.
GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., May 15 (UPI) Los Angeles area teams dominated the National Collegiate volleyball championship tournament yesterday, capturing the titles in all five divisions.

PARIS, May 15 (UPI) Paul Derval, who founded the Folies Bergere and gave their start to such stars as Maurice Chevalier, Mistinguett and Fernandel, died today at his home on the Avenue Foch. He was 85 years old.
CAIRO, May 15 President Gamal Abdel Nasses threatened today to mount an armed struggle, if necessary, to defeat the "reactionary-imperialist alliances" facing Arab nationalism.
Hyman Baden, head of the Baden Manufacturing Corporation, makers of stationery at 475 Broadway, died of a heart attack Saturday night in his home at 573 Grand Street. He was 61 years old.

WASHINGTON, May 15 It is one year, six months and 12 days since William Edward Miller of Lockport, N.Y., assumed the most forgettable role in American public life that of a defeated Vice-Presidential nominee.
An Asphalt Garden Party will be held tomorrow afternoon in the paved courtyard at the clubhouse of the Girls Club of New York, 312 East 30th Street.
Phil Krieger of St. Benedict's Prep in Newark led the favorites into the third round in the annual Fordham interscholastic invitation tennis tournament yesterday.

The seizure of Danang by the Ky Government means a determination to fight it out with the dissident political elements of the Unified Buddhist Church. Unless the struggle is quickly stopped, this would mean an end to the hopes, expectations and promises of an election by Sept. 15 for a constituent assembly and later an elected government.
SAIGON, Monday, May 16 About 50,000 workers did not appear for work this morning as the South Vietnamese Confederation of Labor began an anti-Government strike here.
WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) Barry Goldwater said today that he expects the 1968 Republican national convention to be about as conservative as the 1964 convention that nominated him for President.

Pop, op, even hop art were splashed across a 105-yard canvas in Central Park yesterday afternoon in "A Hoving Happening" that included a pink fish with legs, a blue man, a da Vinci meter maid and Little Red Riding Hood axing the Big Bad Wolf.

WASHINGTON, May 15 An international group of historians, sociologists and psychoanalysts is investigating the problem of "man's peculiar propensity to kill and even enjoy killing on a mass basis when such crimes are sanctioned by his country or society."

SAO PAULO, Brazil A speculative fever in beef cattle production is sweeping through the ranches of central Brazil. In the business clubs of this great industrial center it is fashionable and profitable to talk about feeder lots, the merits of various breeds of zebu cattle, and pasture grasses. A group of ...

CARACAS, Venezuela, May 15 the Philadelphia Orchestra gave its first performance in South America here Friday night and for Conductor Eugene Ormandy, his wife and the guest maestro, Stanislaw Skrowaczewski, the event will not be soon forgotten.

BROOKLINE, Mass., May 15 A group of intellectuals who spent the weekend here discussing religion and American culture agreed that the nation was undergoing a religious crisis. However they could not agree on what the crisis was all about.

General discontent with everincreasing school tax rates and an awareness by the homeowner that his vote on the school budget was the one area in which he could register displeasure with the increase in all taxes was seen as a prime reason for the rejection of 14 school budgets in Nassau County this month.

YONKERS, May 15 Dancing everything from the hora to the hula and playing instruments ranging from bagpipes to bells, amateur performers from national and ethnic groups in Yonkers spent this afternoon celebrating "Peace Through Understanding."
CANNES, France, May 15 Sophia Loren's position as president of the Cannes Film Festival jury this year may cost her some slight diminution of popularity and prestige hereabouts.
BAYONNE, N.J., May 15 F. William Grip, supervisor of the purchasing and sales division of Lee, Higginson Co., an investment house in New York, died here today. He was 58 years old.

DALLAS, May 15 (AP) Clifford Ann Creed battled high winds over the 6,178-yard Glen Lakes County Club course today and struggled in with a three-over-par 74, but still won the $15,000 Dallas Civitan open golf tournament by seven strokes.
The nineteen-sixties seem certain to become the decade in which the arts in this country achieved the broad, democratic base that the prophets had long talked about.

YONKERS, May 15 Bret Hanover arrives at Yonkers Raceway tomorrow, bringing with him a record of 47 victories in 50 career starts and the unshakable belief of his backers that he will put away Cardigan Bay Friday night in the $65,000 Pace of the Century.
TEL AVIV, May 15 A shrine to the vanished "shtetl," the physically bleak but culturally flourishing Jewish town of prewar eastern Europe, was dedicated here today.

KANSAS CITY, May 15 Unperturbed by a flash hailstorm that interrupted the second game for half an hour and tornado-strikes in the surrounding area, the New York Yankees swept a double-header from the Kansas City Athletics today, 5-2 and 3-1.
Suburban School budgets are turned down in alarming number, not so much because the voters resent school spending, but more because they rarely have a chance of voting against any other spending.
WASHINGTON, May 15 Federal financing for legal aid to the poor, denounced a year ago in many legal circles as "socialized law," appears to have won over most of the country's lawyers.
Officially, the theme of National Maritime Day observance this year is a prosaic one: American ships chart America's future.

The ranks of the critics of the draft deferment test for college students gained two supporters yesterday, Senator Robert F. Kennedy and Dr. Albert H. Bowker, chancellor of the City University of New York.

MARSEILLES, France Although Marseilles is one of the largest cities in France, there are many small communities that are far more urbane. There is, nonetheless, a certain soft charm about the seaport, particularly in the vicinity of the old port where hundreds of small, tall-masted boats, most of them painted blue and white, rock casually at anchor.
The nomination of Edward Glassmeyer of Blyth Co., Inc., as president of the Bond Club of New York was announced over the weekend.

WASHINGTON, May 15 The Administration, surprised and deeply concerned over the South Vietnamese junta's move against dissidents in Danang, began an immediate effort today to prevent the action from leading to civil war.
PHILADELPHIA, May 15 (AP) Harvey Kuenn scored the tying run in the sixth inning today, then singied across the lead run in the seventh as the Philadelphia Phillies defeated the Houston Astros, 5-2.

Aqueduct race fans will get a chance today to size up the candidates for the triple crown for fillies. Thirteen 3-year-olds are expected to start in the $25,000 added Comely Handicap, at seven furlongs.

William H. Jenson has been elected vice president of the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association and its companion organization, the College Retirement Equities Fund, it was announced over the weekend by William C. Greenough, chairman and president of both organizations.

BARCELONA, Spain, May 15--Many of Catalonia's liberal priests assailed the Roman Catholic hierarchy and the Government today in a bitter sermon describing the Spanish church's long silence on human liberties as a "great historic sin."
Control of Eichler Homes, Inc., of San Francisco, one of country's largest home builders, has been acquired by a group headed by Charles H. Parr Sr. of Beverly Hills, Calif., from the Eichler family.
The Coburn Credit Company, Inc., announced plans over the weekend to seek shareholder approval to issue three million shares of a new convertible preference stock.
LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., May 15 "Some people say it's one of my best works," Richard Lippold said during a party at his combined studio and home here last night.

WHEN Wayne Thornton was 17 years old, he wandered into Pat DiFuria's gym in Los Angeles and was immediately beguiled by the spectacle of the fighters sparring. It had so much appeal to his combative nature that he soon found himself donning boxing gloves for the first time in his life.

Hyman Epstein, a dairy company executive and a pioneer of the frozen-food industry, died Saturday night after a short illness. He was 54 years old and lived at 1201 Oriental Boulevard in Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn.
The three-day Gemini 9 space mission, scheduled to get under way tomorrow at about 11 A.M., will be carried live on all three television networks.
SYRACUSE, May 15 Leaders of the Iroquois Confederation have directed Indians not to collect state sales taxes on their reservations.
SAIGON, May l5 Militant Buddhist monks tonight denounced Premier Ky's crackdown in Saigon, Danang and elsewhere as an "act of treachery" that would "surely lead to civil war."

Preparing for next week's national interscholastic championships, Jim Dietz stroked his way to four first places yesterday and carried St. Helena's High School of the Bronx to its sixth straight metropolitan scholastic rowing title.

WILLIMANTIC, Conn., May 15 Ch. Foremark Ebony Box of Foxden, a smooth fox terrier owned by Mr. and Mrs. James A. Farrel Jr. of Darien, Conn., and shown by Jane Kamp, was selected as best in show tonight at the Windham County Kennel Club's 23d annual all-breed event.

Three major American oil companies endorsed yesterday a recent recommendation by the chief of United States Army Engineers for joint tanker terminal and pipeline facalities as an alternative to harbor and channel dredging.

The Skelly Oil Company announced over the weekend that it would present for consideration by its board of directors on Aug. 2 a plan to split the company's common stock on a three-for-one basis and to increase the authorized number of shares of common stock.

The Department of Hospitals said yesterday that it was deferring the closing of out-patient clinics in the municipal hospitals, earlier announced to begin today. But this morning it will go over a series of alternate plans to cope with a threatened wholesale loss of nurses.
Activity picks up this week in both the corporate and municipal bond markets and the larger issues are expected to provide good tests of prices.

South Korea is becoming one of the economic bright spots of Asia after a long period of poverty and trouble, according to a foreign information service study just released ... leased by the First National City Bank.
With the admission of Robert H. Arnow as a partner, the realty investment and development firm of Swig Weiler of 711 Third Avenue will now be known as Swig, Weiler Arnow.
BY the autumn of 1935, the years of working on the docks during the day and going to law school at night had taken their toll of George Moskowitz.

Members of Assembly Speaker Anthony J. Travia's staff are preparing a bill to provide construction money and operating assistance to the City University of New York so that 2,278 qualified freshmen will not have to be turned away this fall.

PHILADELPHIA, May 15 Perhaps an understressed aspect of performances by Moscow's Bolshoi Ballet is how simply and purely enjoyable they are. Not only do these Russians seem to take an infinite enjoyment in their own dancing, but that enjoyment also infects the audience almost like a state of euphoria.
DALLAS, May 15 (AP) Texas Democrats, apparently safely past an intraparty squabble, are due to start directing their attack at the Republicans and especially Senator John G. Tower.

CLEVELAND, May 15 (UPI) The Cleveland Indians' physician, Dr. Vic Ippolito, said today that plastic surgery performed on the Indians' shortstop, Larry Brown, yesterday morning was a success. Brown is in "very satisfactory" condition, he said.
If a pretty, sometimes exciting voice were all it took to sustain a whole program, Julie Terrell, the suprano who sang at the Carnegie Recital Hall yesterday afternoon, would have no problems.

BERGEN, Norway, May 14 The new conservative Government has touched off a Scandinavian scandal of sorts by its first significant break with the Socialist past. The Government has decided to award an important air route to a private airline.

S. Sloan Colt, chairman of the Port of New York Authority, announced yesterday that construction would begin immediately on three of the six new berths planned at Port Newark. The piers, on the north side of the Elizabeth Channel, will be available for occupancy in the summer of 1968.
"Flame of Hope" candles, named in memory of the late President Kennedy, will go on sale next Monday in stores around the country.
ARMONK, N.Y., May 15 Kingman Lambert of Bronxville, N.Y., who was seeded No. 6. won the 33d annual Westchester County amateur tennis championship today.

IT may be the chocolate mints by the bedside at nightfall, or the private dining room available to enter- tain out-of-town guests, or someone on duty 24 hours a day, or the free Rolls-Royce service to midtown stores. Whatever it is it induces 10,000 people to go against the trend making their New York homes in hotels.

The latest round of controversy between the state and New York City over the city's jealously guarded free university, focused on the question of expansion to meet pressures for admission, represents a real threat to Governor Rockefeller in his third-term bid.
NEW LONDON, Conn., May 15 Mrs. William E. Thornton has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Marilyn Thornton, to Roger E. Williams, son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Williams of Yonkers.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 15 Syrian authorities have ordered the evacuation of villages close to the southwestern border with Israel.
Federal and state attempts to end employment discrimination are being hampered by inadequate enforcement powers, meager budgets and weak administration, a new 20th Century Fund report asserts.
Barbara Long, violinist, and Gerald Ranck, harpsichordist, chose four Bach sonatas as their entire program last night at Carnegie Recital Hall.
Sir Francis Ibiam, one of the six presidents of the World Council of Churches, took sharp issue yesterday with the controversial "God is dead" school of theology.

WESTPORT, Conn., May 15--In Temple Israel this afternoon, Miss Elizabeth Ann Sarnoff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur T. Sarnoff, became the bride of Bennett Godfrey Galef Jr., son of Mrs. Benjamin Miller of New York and the late Mr. Galef.
The Financial General Corporation had net operating earnings of $1,333,781, or 39 cents a share, for the quarter ended March 31, it was announced by George Olmsted, chairman.
The amazing Mets staged another of their extravaganzas yesterday before another record crowd in Shea Stadium 55,226 persons, who watched them defeat the San Francisco Giants, 6-1.

Miss Deborah Katherine Stuhlmiller Butler, daughter of Mrs. Truman Monroe Dodson 4th of Stonington, Conn., and Positano, Italy, was married yesterday to Joseph Maybin Gore Friedrichs, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Shelby Friedrichs of New Orleans.
BALTIMORE, May 15 Sixteen more members of the Congress of Racial Equality were arrested today for violating a court order restricting picketing at a high-rise apartment house here.

A self-educated engineer-inventor who was responsible for one of the outstanding rotorcraft achievements of the last quarter-century received the American Helicopter Society's highest honor last week.

SELMA, Ala., May 15 (AP) Three shots were fired to night into a house formerly occupied by Wilson Baker, who is opposing the incumbent James G. Clark for the Democratic nomination for sheriff of Dallas County.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 15 Miss Katherine Hoagland Muir and Timothy Moore plan to be married next month.

LANCASTER, Pa., May 15 A 5-year-old Lhasa Apso, Oh. Kham of Nerbulingka, owned and bred by Phyllis Russell Taylor of Middleburg, Va., scored in a field of 1,093 dogs today to gain best-in-show honors at the 21st annual Lancaster Kennel Club event.
Montgomery Ward Co., announced yesterday that it would make an investment in Caribou Department Stores, Inc., in Anchorage, Alaska, thus marking its first entry into that remote state of the union.

New York State yesterday officially honored "the intrepid exploits of Leif Ericson, son of Eric the Red, and his valiant Norsemen, who explored the uncharted seas. It named part of a Brooklyn highway for him.
WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) Representative Leonor K. Sullivan said tonight that some manufacturers were using their customers to test the safety of cosmetics and other products.

Mrs. Lillian Jolliffe, widow and collaborator of Dr. Norman Jolliffe, the nutritionist, died Saturday at the Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases. She was 63 years old and lived at 910 Park Avenue.

Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., bidding for the Governorship, charged yesterday that he was frustrated in his first try for the office in 1954 because he was "double-crossed" by Carmine De Sapio in New York City.
LONDON While American television and radio set manufacturers are establishing new records in production and sales, their British cousins are running into troubles.
SAIGON, May 15 The whine of bullets and the clank of tank treads today probably erased the possibility of harmonious transition from military to civilian government in South Vietnam.

ANAHEIM, Calif., May 15 (AP) Jose Santiago, with ninth-inning relief help from Dick Radatz, ended the Boston Red Sox's six-game losing streak today by pitching a 6-3 victory over the California Angels in the second game of a double-header here.
MEXICO CITY, May 15 Intellectuals from nine LatinAmerican countries issued an appeal here today for an end of Russian discrimination against Jews living in the Soviet Union.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., May 15 Angus McIntyre's Polar Bear of the new California-36 class won the Winged Foot Trophy today by placing first in the New York Athletic Club's overnight contest around Stratford Shoal.

Cardinal Spellman said mass for 1,500 religious sisters yesterday afternoon, telling them that he wanted to celebrate his golden anniversary in the priesthood with them because he admired their sacrifice, good works, and devotion.
Msgr. Henry C. Breen, pastor since 1943 of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Francis of Assisi, 1544 Shakespeare Avenue, the Bronx, died Saturday in St. Elizabeth's Hospital. He was 71 years old.
Mayor Lindsay told negotiators in the five-day-old taxi strike yesterday to continue meeting without break until they reached an agreement to get the cabs back on the street.

The marriage of Miss Jane Wartels, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eli Wartels of Scarsdale, N.Y., to Dr. Arthur Harvey Tiger took place here last evening. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Tiger of New York. Rabbi Lawrence W. Schwartz performed the ceremony at the Sheraton-East.

FRESNO, Calif., May 15 (AP) A seasoned pole vaulter at the age of 19, Bob Seagren sailed over the bar with distance to spare at 17 feet 5 inches in the West Coast Relays last night to add the world's outdoor record to his indoor mark.
PITTSBURGH, May 15 By late last week, steel officials were still trying to assess the impact of reduced purchases by automobile companies.
Cooperative apartments and condominium units are growing steadily in popularity, among families desiring home ownership.

YONKERS, May 15 Outstanding marathon runners are generally associated with slight physical frames. "The ideal size is about 5 feet 7 or 8 inches and around 140 pounds," Jock Semple, the well-known Boston Athletic Association coach, said today.

PITTSBURGH, May 15 The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People plans to demonstrate at the headquarters of the United States Steel Corporation in downtown Pittsburgh to protest alleged discrimination at the company's plant at Birmingham, Ala.
Joseph Verner Reed Jr., an official of the American Shakespeare Festival, will begin a tour of eight cities this week to promote industrial support for the performing arts.
DETROIT, May 15 (UPI) Larry Sherry stopped a Chicago White Sox seventh-inning rally today, then singled in the tiebreaking run as the Detroit Tigers scored an 8-6 victory.
William H. Booth, chairman of the City Commission on Human Rights, announced yesterday the appointment of Ramon E. Rivera as executive director of the commission.

CLEVELAND, May 15 (AP) All activities of the Chesapeake Ohio and Baltimore Ohio Railroads will stop for one minute at 11 A.M. tomorrow in tribute to Walter J. Tuohy, chief executive officer, who will be buried at that time in Des Plaines, Ill.

ARTHUR BISGUIER of the Manhattan Chess Club, as White in a Nimzo-Indian Defense, bypassed a locked center and broke through with simultaneous assaults on the wings to defeat Edmar Mednis of the Marshall Chess Club in their recent game in the Metropolitan Chess League match.
"We're up in the clouds over our new plant in Farmingdale, Long Island ... in more ways than one."
MANILA, Monday, May 16 (AP) A vessel carrying 250 passengers sank in rough seas today off the coast of the central Philippines, the Philippine News Service reported.

The appointment of James R. Bradburn as division vice president and general manager of R.C.A. Data Processing, was announced yesterday by Arthur L. Malcarney, group executive vice president of the Radio Corporation of America.

ROME, May 15 The Fiat Automobile Company, recent winner of a $320-million contract to build an automobile factory in the Soviet Union, is expected to announce this week a similiar but smaller arrange[ment with Poland.

Earnings of the Jewel Tea Company, Inc., in the 12 weeks to April 23 increased 14.6 per cent and sales rose 15.6 per cent from the levels in the first fiscal quarter a year earlier, according to the report issued today.

NEW DELHI, May 15 Thirty-eight years ago a young Cambridge graduate named Donald Falshaw landed in Bombay to take up his first post in the Indian Civil Service. This afternoon Mr. Falshaw left the same docks on his way back to London the last British judge to leave India.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 15 A.J. Foyt of Houston and Dan Gurney of Costa Mesa, Calif., were the top men today as five cars were added to the field for the 500-mile race here Memorial Day. The list now numbers 23, with 18 having qualified in the opening session yesterday. That leaves 10 places to be filled in the final runs next Saturday and Sunday.

THE recent victory of the Conservative party in Austria and the subsequent termination of the coalition that had ruled the country for 20 years was the subject last night of an earnest documentary entitled. "An Austrian Affair." It was shown over the network of the National Broadcasting Company.
MOSCOW, May 15 (Reuters) Premier Souvanna Phouma of Laos arrives here tomorrow for what are expected to be talks with Soviet leaders on Southeast Asia.

The election of Joseph C. Wilson as chairman of the board of the United Nations Association of the United States was announced yesterday. Mr. Wilson is president and chief executive officer of the Xerox Corporation.

WASHINGTON, May 15 New laws and regulations designed to make sure that people get their money's worth when they buy mutual funds are about to be proposed by the Government. The reforms will be recommended in a long-awaited report by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
LONDON, Monday, May 16 The first strike by British merchant seamen in 55 years started at 12:01 A.M. today.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., May 15 The Gemini 9 mission, a difficult three-day space flight with overtones of a trip to the moon, moved smoothly toward a Tuesday launching today.

The Metropolitan Opera will present its second season of outdoor concerts at Lewisohn Stadium of City College from June 28 through Aug. 13. Performances will be on Tuesday, Wednesday, Friday and Saturday nights.
LIVERPOOL, England, May 15 (AP) Scores of persons were hurt tonight when a welcome-home celebration for the Everton soccer team, which won the British championship yesterday, got out of hand.

NEW ORLEANS, May 15 The rain-plagued professional golf tour was stalled again today. A thunder and lightning storm that lasted for an hour and a half forced the postponement of the final round of the $100,000 Greater New Orleans open until tomorrow.
A young woman told the police yesterday that she was probably the 17th victim of two snipers who drove about Manhattan Thursday night, firing an air gun and a BB gun at pedestrians.

The Eurodollar market the $7-million pool of United States currency on deposit at foreign banks has emerged as an important source of funds for major banks in New York, according to a bulletin issued yesterday by the Graduate School of Business Administration at New York University.

BOGOR, Indonesia, May 15 President Sukarno said today that Indonesia would continue her policy of confrontation against Malaysia, but that he would be willing to "have a talk" with the Malaysian Prime Minister, Prince Abdul Rahman.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 15 George H. (Pete) Bostwick Jr. held firm today in the face of an amazing comeback by Charles J. Slicklen Jr. and took the 17th and 18th holes to win the 56th annual Walter J. Travis Memorial golf tournament, 1 up.
Stock prices declined sharply in the last three weeks, carrying leading market indicators to their lowest levels since last summer.

The Concordia Choir gave its annual spring concert Sunday night at Carnegie Hall. The 60-voice ensemble (not to be confused with the similarly named group from Concordia College in Minnesota) is drawn from the student ranks of the Concordia Collegiate Institute in Bronxville, N.Y., a Lutheran high school and junior college.

DANANG, South Vietnam, May 15 The ruling junta appeared tonight to have seized control of most of this city after a day of wild shooting between troops loyal to the Government and rebel military units allied with Buddhist insurgents.

MIA FONSSAGRIVES, the tall half of the Americanborn, Paris-based design team of Fonssagrives and Tiel, is back in New York for a few weeks. Miss Fonsasagrives, who looks less than her 25 years, arrived for lunch at Sardi's wearing a bright orange smock dress ...

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, May 15 A marching band of the Middlesex Regiment, sweltering under the equatorial sun in stiff white uniforms, tried nobly today to play the calypso rhythms of "Archie, Buck Them Up."

NEWARK, May 15--Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., former Presidential adviser and Pulitzer Prize-winning historian, questioned tonight many aspects of United States policy in Vietnam but asserted also that he was "appalled by the character" of some of the protests against that policy.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 15 Judy Dixon's victory on the final day of the three-day tournament today gave Kimberley School the team title in the Kimberley invitation tennis tournament.

WASHINGTON, May 15 Secretary of State Dean Rusk and his senior advisers will begin tomorrow a 24-hour review of the gathering crisis in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. The crisis has been provoked by President de Gaulle's denunciation of the alliance's integrated military command.

SOME months ago a recording of "Music From 'The Baroque Beatles Book, Rediscovered, Edited and Conducted by Joshua Rifkin" began to attract the attention of Beatles fans and Baroque music connoisseurs.
GENEVA, May 15 Paul Klecki, the Polish-born Swiss conductor and composer, is to take charge of the Suisse Romande Orchestra with the retirement next year of its founder, Ernest Ansermet.
MONTLHERY, France, May 15 (UPI) Peter Revson of the United States won the international Formula III auto race at the Grand Prix de Paris auto meet today in a Lotus 41.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) James G. Ray, a World War I Army flyer, a veteran racing and test pilot and a pioneer in the development of helicopter travel in the United States, died today in Doctor's Hospital. He was 69 years old.
NEW HAVEN, May 15 Army, led by the running of Jim Warner and the throwing of Dan Seebart and Larry Hart, won the Heptagonal outdoor track and field championship today for the first time since 1952.
Mrs. Louisa Allen Hazen, widow of William E. Hazen, former industrial editor of The Wall Street Journal, died yesterday in her home, 420 Riverside Drive, after a short illness. She was 86 years old.
Lester Eisner Jr., regional administrator of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, has resigned, effective Friday.
GLADSTONE, N.J., May 15 (UPI) Mrs. John F. Kennedy and her daughter Caroline both won riding ribbons yesterday at the annual St. Bernard's School horse show.
