Bob Seagren and Gerry Lindgren, two young collegians who shook up the record book on Saturday, filed entries yesterday for the Amateur Athletic Union's national outdoor track and field championships. The meet will be held June 25 and 26 at Randalls Island.

WARREN, Ohio, May 17 Mr. and Mrs. Elmer L. McFadden have made known the engagement of their daughter, Mrs. Catherine Dunning of New Concord, widow of Anthony M. Dunning, to Phillip T. Young of New Haven, executive officer of the Yale University School of Music.

Four corporations have each leased a full floor in the building at 330 Madison Avenue, which occupies the westerly blockfront between 42d and 43d Streets. The transactions totaled more than $2.1-million in aggregate rentals.

RICHMOND, May 17 Mrs. Jessie Mewhort Gray, a retired nurse and the widow of Dr. Benjamin H. Gray, New York and Richmond obstetrician and gynecologist, died yesterday in the Westport Nursing Home here after a long illness. She was 87 years old and lived here and, during summers; on Fishers Island, N.Y.

ROSELLE PARK, N.J., May 17 George P. Cron, a former project coordinator in the design section of the Esso Research and Engineering Company, Linden, died yesterday at St. Elizabeth's Hospital, Elizabeth, after a brief illness. He was 75 and lived at 810 Prospect Street.

Stockholders of the Socony Mobil Oil Company approved yesterday the change in the, company's name to the Mobil Oil Corporation at the annual meeting in the Commodore Hotel. They also authorized the doubling of the company's shares and approved an incentive compensation plan for key employes.

Federal Judge Sylvester J. Ryan handed down a ruling here yesterday that substantially reduces the damages that International Railways of Central America can seek in the $507-million antitrust suit it filed against the United Fruit Company a little more than a year ago.

FAIRFIELD, N.J., May 17 Mrs. Julia Munkacsy, who with her husband John bottled "Munkacsy's Original Red Cross Health Water" from 1937 until they sold their interests five years ago, died Sunday in Mountainside Hospital. She was 80 years old and lived here at 84 Lane Road.
DETROIT, May 17 (UPI) Charlie Dressen, manager of the Detroit Tigers, registered some improvement today at Ford Hospital, where he was taken yesterday because of a suspected heart attack.

The relationship in 1961 and 1962 between L. Judson Morhouse and Martin C. Epstein was described to a jury yesterday as that of a political boss and a grafting public official who teamed up to enrich themselves and one another.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) The Government, acting to combat black marketing of the experimental hallucination-producing drug LSD, barred today all distribution of its ingredients, except for use in authorized research.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 17 Dr. Arieh Kubovy, chairman of the Yad Vashem Memorial authority, formerly an Israeli diplomat, died last night at Hadassah Hospital following a long illness. He was 69 years old.
More than a dozen policemen searched the Tompkins Square Park area last night after reports that a sniper had been shooting. They found nine spent .22-caliber cartridges on a roof.

Jim Maloney, who missed most of spring training because of a salary hassle, overpowered the New York Mets on two hits last night and demonstrated two things: He really didn't "miss" spring training that much, and he was probably worth all of the $48,000 he finally got for signing.
John D. Rockefeller 3d proposed yesterday a three-point development program to strengthen Asia's solidarity and correct what he called the United States' "overpresence" in that troubled region.

Rumors were humming yesterday in Frankfurt, the financial capital of West Germany, that the Continental Oil Company may make a counteroffer to a bid by Texaco, Inc., to take over Deutsche Erdol (DEA), the big German oil and coal mining company.

The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company announced yesterday that Raymond C. Firestone, who started work with the company in 1933 as a gas station attendant, was elected board chairman. He continues as chairman of the executive committee and as chief executive officer.

WASHINGTON, May 17-- Allan S. Waldo, senior vice president of the Army Times Publishing Company and manager of its office in Miami, died in Hollywood, Fla., yesterday of a heart attack. He was 67 years old.
MADISON, Wis., May 17 (AP) Student leaders voted tonight to demand that University of Wisconsin officials stop making classroom grades available to draft boards.

JERSEY CITY, May 17 Henry Adlersheim of 117 Kensington Avenue, who recently retired as president of Square Electric Supply and Fixture Company here, died yesterday in Philadelphia of a heart attack. He was 75 years old.
Genesco, Inc., a manufacturer and retailer of footwear and apparel, said here yesterday that its sales and earnings rose to records in the three and nine months ended April 30.

To the stockholders of the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation, the sound of music is the lilting ring of ticket sales for "The Sound of Music." Darryl F. Zanuck, president of the film company, told the annual meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria here yesterday that Fox's net earnings after taxes for the first 1966 quarter, ended March 31,...

For the third time in the past few months a space experiment involving the Atlas-Agena rocket has run into trouble. Late last year a sequence of events similar to yesterday's led to a postponement of the original Gemini rendezvous experiment, while in March of this year Gemini 8 nearly met catastrophe when it was docked with an Agena target vehicle.
The Navy said yesterday the National Steel Shipbuilding Company of San Diego is the apparent low bidder on construction of 17 tank landing vessels.

NEW ORLEANS, May 17 (UPI) Miller Barber, Larry Beck, Dean Refram, Harold Kneece and Wayne Yates qualified at Lakewood Country Club today for berths in the Professional Golfers Association national championship, scheduled for July 21 through 24 at Akron, Ohio.
The New York Giants signed Pete Gogolak to a long-term contract yesterday, dealing the American Football League a blow and endowing themselves with a first-class field goal kicker they needed badly.
WASHINGTON, May 17 The Senate placed itself on record today in overwhelming support of a treaty to prevent the spread of atomic weapons.

"LADY L," a period romantic drama with Sophia Loren, Paul Newman and David Niven, directed by Peter Ustinov, who also adapted the novel by Romain Gary for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, is the new attraction at Loew's State, Broadway and 45th Street, and the Beekman Theater, Second Avenue and 65th Street.

In a flurry of late trading, prices for soybeans rose yesterday. Much of the activity was centered on the soon-to-expire May contract, which climbed 5 cents a bushel, quite a steep rise. It closed at a lifetime high of around $3.08, up from $3.03 a bushel the preceding day.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 17 Jerry Grant, an affable, giant-size driver from Santa Ana, Calif., is on his way from Indianapolis to Bridgehampton, L.I., where he will compete in Sunday's 200-mile United States road racing championship contest.

YONKERS, May 17 It appears now that Friday night's "pace of the century," in which Bret Hanover, Cardigan Bay and three other sidewheelers will meet in a one-mile race at Yonkers Raceway, will be a money-making vehicle for everyone except those bettors who guess wrong on the outcome.

Paperboard production rose 9.6 per cent with 457,100 tons in the week ended May 14, from 4l7,147 tons in the corresponding 1965 week, the Paperboard Group of the American Paper Institue reported yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 17 Secretary General Thant rejected today Rhodesia's request to speak in the Security Council debate on the use of harsher measures, including force, to topple the independent regime of Prime Minister Ian D. Smith.

PROTEST BY UNIONS BLOCKS WAGE BILL ALBANY, May 17 Republicans and Democrats reached agreement today on raising the state's minimum wage to $1.50 an hour, but last-minute objections by labor officials forced Senate leaders to call off their plans to pass the bill tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 17--The head of the House Foreign Operations Subcommittee demanded today that the Agency for International Development completely overhaul its $400-million commodity program for South Vietnam.

YONKERS, May 17 A $3million educational television system that carries live programs into 3,000 classrooms of Roman Catholic schools in 10 counties was dedicated today at its headquarters in St. Joseph Seminary here.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, May 17--The Government continued today its official silence in the face of reports that it had sent notes to the Soviet Union and the other Warsaw Pact nations calling for the withdrawal of Soviet Troops from territory of members of the pact.
SAIGON, May 17 A strike by 50,000 Saigon workmen, which had threatened to deprive the city of electric power and water, ended unexpectedly this morning after one day.
Registered nurses at the 21 city hospitals rejected a new offer of wage increases yesterday as the hospitals stepped up their discharges of patients and sharply curtailed admissions.
WASHINGTON, May 16 In the United States Court of Claims the following proceed ings were had May 13, 1966:

WASHINGTON, May 17 A Federal judge overruled today a request by Senator Thomas J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, that would have kept secret the pretrial statements of witnesses in his $5-million libel and conspiracy suit against Drew Pearson and Jack Anderson. Washington columnists.
The defense rested yesterday in the Federal perjury trial here of Warden Henry B. McFarland of the Hudson County Jail but not before it had called the Government prosecutor to the witness stand.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 17 Juan Bosch warned the Provisional Government today that he and his Dominican Revolutionary party would withdraw from the Presidential elections of June 1 unless what he called repression of his followers ended.
KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y. May 17 "Throw that right hand, don't hold it back! When his back is on the ropes, throw that right into his ribs!"
Hedge buying of gold shares prompted by uncertainties stemming from the British seamen's strike was a factor yesterday in an otherwise quiet London stock market.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 17 (AP) Tony Oliva slammed two 400-foot home runs, driving in four runs and leading the Minnesota Twins to a 8-3 triumph over the Chicago White Sox tonight.
BALTIMORE, May 17 (AP) The Baltimore Orioles rallied for four runs in the sixth inning and defeated the Boston Red Sox, 8-6, tonight.

LEE, Me., May 17 The anglers in this camp have accounted for 23 salmon, one pickerel and a lovely brook trout that Clark Tefft of Alexandria, Va., picked up while trolling. It weighed about 2 pounds, a heavy, fat beautiful fish.
William C. Batchelder and Richard M. Sellers have been elected senior vice presidents of the United States Life Insurance Company.
Bausch Lomb, Inc., a Rochester, N.Y., producer of optical products, announced yesterday the election of Paul Miller as a director.
WASHINGTON, May 17 Representative Emanuel Celler today accused a citizens committee of seeking to save the old Metropolitan Opera House by "throwing the baby out with the bath water."

WASHINGTON, May 17 (UPI)--Senate investigators submitted evidence today to show that an international Dutch cartel increased prices of quinine, which is used for United States troops in Vietnam, despite a plentiful supply of the raw material used to make the antimalaria drug.

The Family Service League of Suffolk County has arranged a tour of six residences and the gardens of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Long, all in or near Oyster Bay Cove, L.I., for today from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M.

Charles Mays of the Grand Street Boys Association will receive the top award at the Metropolitan Association of the Amateur Athletic Union's annual awards dinner to be held tonight at the Downtown Athletic Club.

A profile of the continent of Africa, covering its geography, culture, economy and complex political structure, will be offered for a full television evening by the American Broadcasting Companies. Inc.
HAMILTON, N.Y., May 17 Miss Ann Hoben will be married on Aug. 20 to Richard Bowen Broussard, son of Rear Adm. Clarence Broussard, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Broussard of Upper Montclair, N.J.
A gourmet dinner on Monday at Il Mio, the discotheque at Delmonico's, will benefit Comeback. Mrs. Robert C. Durham and Judge Kenneth Keating of the State Court of Appeals are chairmen for the event.

James J. Saxon, the Controller of the Currency, has received and may well approve applications from at least two national banks to acquire other banks and operate them as subsidiaries, Robert Bloom, chief counsel in Mr. Saxon's office, said yesterday.
GENEVA, May 17 The Government unveiled today a plan to give the Swiss National Bank additional leverage on the economy in an attempt to avoid extreme boom or bust conditions.

CAPE KENNEDY, May 17 An Atlas booster rocket went out of control today as it tried to lift an Agena target rocket into space for the Gemini 9 astronauts to chase. As a result, Gemini 9 never left the ground.

BOSTON, May 17 One of the most distinguished collections of French art of the 18th century, valued at about $4million, has been given to the Boston Museum of Fine Arts. It was the property of Forsyth Wickes of Newport, R.I., and New York.

Coach Bob Swift was in charge of the Tigers, as acting manager, while Charlie Dressen remained in the hospital. Dressen's condition is listed as improved but still serious although no firm diagnosis has been made that he has had a recurrence of the heart attack that struck him 14 months ago. Swift managed the team during Dressen's convalescence and compiled a 24-18 won-lost record at the start of last season. Dressen is 67 years old.
Rumania's current offensive against the stationing of Soviet troops in eastern Europe is one of the most important political developments in that area since the Hungarian Revolution a decade ago.

LONDON, May 17 (Reuters) Cassius Clay has demanded, and will get, a ring bigger than normal British boxing standards for his title fight with Henry Cooper Saturday. That drew a charge from Cooper's manager, Jim Wicks, that Clay planned to run for most of the fight.
"I like people," Roberta Berkel remembers commenting when she was being interviewed by some top officials of the Chemical Bank New York Trust Company for possible appointment as a branch manager.
Continued selling pressure again depressed most issues on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.

The annual balloting by the Board of Higher Education to elect a chairman, usually an uncontested routine, has become a matter of controversy this year. None of the other Board members is advancing himself as a candidate or has openly challenged Gustave G. Rosenberg, who has held the unsalaried position for eight years; yet the Board is deeply divided over whether to re-elect him next Monday.
The Associates of the Jewish Museum will sponsor a bus trip to Philadelphia on Friday with visits to the Barnes Foundation in Merion, Pa., and Beth Shalom Synagogue in Elkins Park, Pa.

DETROIT, May 17 Dennis McLain is a young right-handed pitcher who believes he's just as good as the young lefthander named Sam McDowell over in Cleveland. As far as the New York Yankees are concerned, Denny has a point. The Yanks saw no discernible difference as McLain and the Detroit Tigers beat them tonight, 7-2.
ALBANY, May 17 Everybody talked about New York City taxes today, but nobody did anything about them.
The first breakthrough in the 23-day newspaper strike came yesterday when the printers' union and the World Journal Tribune, Inc., reached full agreement on all issues.
A highly optimistic 1966 picture for the company and for retailing in general was drawn yesterday at the annual meeting of the J.C. Penney Company.

THE Bolshoi Ballet returned to New York last night, opening a season at Madison Square Garden that runs through Sunday afternoon, and opening it marvelously with a young girl's New York debut in the title role of "Giselle."

Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday a "memorandum of understanding" with the Consolidated Edison Company against air pollution, under which the utility promised to submit a plan within six months for shutting three plants here and older units at a fourth.
WASHINGTON, May 17 President Johnson formally accepted the Hirshhorn art collection today "on behalf of the American people" in a ceremony at noon is the Rose Garden of the White House.

BERLIN, N.H., May 17 Mrs. Robert Rich has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Nancy Mason Rich of West Hartford, Conn., to Luke Marbury, son of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Marbury of Baltimore.
"Never on Sunday," a musical treatment of the popular 1960 film, will reach Broadway next March with three of those connected with the picture.
LOS ANGELES, May 17 (AP) Wes Parker raced home in the 13th inning as Ollie Brown threw Maury Wills's single past third base, giving Los Angeles a 2-1 victory over San Francisco tonight.

Gimbel Brothers, Inc., operator of the Gimbel department stores and the Saks Fifth Avenue specialty store chain, registered a 30.7 per cent increase in net income for the first quarter ended April 30.
EVER since dolls moved out of the nursery and into the living room, the variety of designs and materials of these adult decorations has been on the increase in art galleries and shops.

NOROTON, Conn., May 17 Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Hale Johnson have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Griswold Johnson, to Stephen Lane Billard, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jules Benoit Billard of Springfield, Md.

Events today: Vladimir Ussachevsky, presenting music for tape recorder, Baruch School, City College, 17 Lexington Avenue, 11 A.M.; New York Philharmonic, Philharmonic Hall, 8:30; Josef Marais and Miranda, folk songs, Town Hall, 8:30; New York Concert Ensemble, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.
WASHINGTON, May 17 The Government's report on personal income supplied further evidence today that the swift pace of the economy slowed in April.
WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) The Interstate Commerce Commission postponed today for two months the effective date of the merger of the Pennsylvania and New York Central Railroads.
LEWISBURG, Pa., May 17 Bucknell defeated Penn State today, 2-1. It was Bucknell's first victory over Penn State since May 22, 1951.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (UPI) The Civil Aeronautics Board announced today it would hold a public hearing starting May 25 on the crash of an American Flyers Airline plane last month in which 77 servicemen and five crew members were killed.
The Federal Home Loan Banks set the terms yesterday on $956-million of securities in the largest financing undertaken by an agency of the Federal Government.
Mary Scott of 150-26 86th Avenue, Jamaica, Queens, a former English teacher at Jamaica High School, died Monday in the Windsor Park Nursing Home in Hollis, Queens. Her age was 87.

THE potential scientific uses of lysergic acid diethylamide were vividly demonstrated last night in a way that also underscored the hazards of the LSD drug. The extreme precautions exercised by the medical profession in administering LSD to aid two patients constituted a striking warning against mass abuse of the chemical.
Capt. Richard Hubble, a Northeast Air Lines pilot, described yesterday the flight of the unmanned Agena rocket launched from Cape Kennedy, Fla.
ALBANY, May 17 A bill to prevent slumlords from escaping the law by hiding behind corporate facades won final passage in the Legislature today.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., May 117 Seton Hall defeated Long Island University, 5-3, today to win the Metropolitan Conference baseball title.

A total of 285 oarsmen from 34 high schools of the United States and Canada will compete in the 31st annual American scholastic rowing championships on Hunter's Island Lagoon in the Bronx Friday and Saturday.

BURNT CABINS, Pa., May 17 A man who abducted a 17year-old girl six days ago shot a pursuing Federal agent to death from ambush today and then eluded a massive search in a heavily wooded mountain area.
Maybe it was the blinkers, or maybe it was Braulio Baeza. Or maybe, as Moccasin's owner suggested, it was just that Aqueduct in May had fewer buttercups than Kentucky in April.
ANAHEIM, Calif., May 17--What suburb is currently a hotter baseball town than Los Angeles, or--for that matter--New York? Would you believe Anaheim?

With its magnificent scenery and attractive climate, Arizona has a fast-growing population and a worsening water shortage. But there is something that outreaches its need for water. That is the state's breathtaking political audacity in trying to seize hold of national resources to put them to its own use.
MINEOLA, L.I., May 17 The former head of the Nassau County Children's Shelter was cleared today of an indictment charging him with negligence and omission of duty.
TOMS RIVER, N.J., May 17 In the lonely streams and piney woods and gravel pits of Ocean and Monmouth Counties, seven victims of murder have been found in the last 30 months.

HELSINKI, Finland, May 17 (AP) Dennis Ralston, America's top-ranked player from Bakersfield, Calif., and Marty Riessen of Evanston, Ill., advanced to the semi-final of the Helsinki international tennis tournament today.
Stockholders of the Commonwealth Edison Company approved at their annual meeting in Chicago yesterday a proposed merger with the Central Illinois Electric and Gas Company.
Indian Head Mills, Inc., is seeking to expand its textile operations through the proposed acquisition of Roxboro Cotton Mills for stock worth about $7-million, it was announced yesterday.

The board of directors of the Regional Plan Association elected Max Abramovitz, partner in the architectural firm of Harrison Abramovitz, to head the nonprofit civic organization that promotes the efficient development of the metropolitan region.
WASHINGTON, May 17 The basic law under which the $35billion mutual fund industry does business was written to industry specifications in a room in Washington's elegant old Carlton Hotel.
CLEVELAND, May 17 Many of the nation's top prosecutors conceded today that law enforcement had not suffered from a controversial confession ruling made by the United States Supreme Court in 1964.
CHICAGO, May 17 Leaders of the University of Chicago student demonstration against university draft policy today called a rally for tomorrow to consider broadening their goals.
A reception and dinner dance at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Berkey in Scarsdale, N.Y., on Saturday, will benefit the Casita Maria Settlement of East Harlem and East Bronx.

CAIRO, May 17 The Soviet Union has apparently persuaded United Arab Republic and Syrian Socialists to shelve their long-standing rivalry and move toward cooperation against pro-Western countries in the Middle East.

CHICAGO, May 17--Former Senator Barry Goldwater told a conservative rally here tonight than the Johnson Administration programs, "threaten to engulf American freedom" and bring Federal control over every area of personal life.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 17 The Humble Oil and Refining Company gave up today on its controversial plans to build a refinery at Moss Landing in scenic Monterey County on the central California coast.

The decline in stock prices on Wall Street has brought a marked psychological change in expectations about business prospects but its discernible impact will probably be slight. There is no doubt about the shift in psychology. Before the steep drop that has wiped out billions of dollars in paper profits, the outlook had never been sunnier. Forecasts differed only in their estimates of just how fast activity and profits would climb.
SAIGON, May 17 Strenuous American attempts to effect a reconciliation between the regime of Premier Nguyen Cao Ky and the Buddhists have made no progress.

Dr. Murray H. Block was installed yesterday as president of the Borough of Manhattan Community College in rented quarters at 134 West 51st Street and took the opportunity to ask for immedi ate action to provide a new home for the two-year college, a part of the City University.
The long behind-the-scenes careers of a pair of musicians whom Skitch Henderson calls "two of the best trumpet players in the world" has finally come completely out into public view.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, May 17 (AP) Japan defeated England, 4-3, today in the interzone final of the Uber Cup competition for women badminton players and earned the right to meet the United States, the holder of the cup.
S.S. Kresge Company expects a "substantial improvement" in second-quarter results despite an earlier Easter this year, Harry B. Cunningham, president, told the annual meeting in Detroit.

Two civil rights leaders told a meeting commemorating the 12th anniversary of the Supreme Court's school desegregation decision yesterday that the implementation of integration required a deep and extensive attack on urban social problems.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 17 the Boeing Company will be able to sell enough of its new 747 jets to enable it to begin manufacture on the initial order of 25 from Pan American World Airways, Najeeb E. Halaby predicted here today.
A tie for first place in the final event, the four-lap relay, gave Newark Academy the open team title in the annual Fieldston Relays at the Fieldston School field in the Bronx.
The world chess champion, Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, drew the adjourned 15th game of his 24-game match with this compatriot, Boris Spassky, last night in Moscow.
The spot rate on the British pound firmed slightly yesterday in moderate trading on foreign-exchange markets here.

ALBANY, May 17 "I'm trying to be an honest broker," Governor Rockefeller said the other day, "bringing together different points of view in the Legislature in the interests of the people of the state as a whole."
ALBANY, May 17 After years of political bickering, the leaders of the Legislature have reached bipartisan agreement to add 35 justices to the State Supreme Court bench.
Wolcott Blair, a member of the New York Stock Exchange, died yesterday in his home at 1 Sutton Place South. He also maintained residences in Palm Beach, Fla., and in Muttontown, L.I. His age was 72.

MARSHFIELD, Mass., May 17--Miss Penelope Knapp and Henry Byron Garrison, students at the Harvard Medical School, plan to marry here on June 25. Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Hirsch have announced the engagement of Mrs. Hirsch's daughter to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Archie W. Garrison of Coral Gables, Fla.

LONDON, May 17 Girls in mini-skirts scream his name, nannies croon it. Bus drivers abandon their double-deckers in Piccadilly Circus and chase him up through Soho. Muslims hail him, cricketers at Lord's break to get his auto graph.

The United States Golf Association's two-stage qualifying round begins next Monday to whittle the record total of 2,513 entrants to the 151 who will play next month in the United States Open championship.

PHILADELPHIA, Wednesday, May 18 Milton Shapp, who single-handedly took on the entire Pennsylvania Democratic leadership, led the organization candidate for the party's nomination for Governor early today.
The use of containers by various domestic transport media showed a divergent trend in the first nine months of 1965, it was reported yesterday by the Interstate Commerce Commission.
After an hour of noisy debate on the virutes of political district leaders, the City Council elected one to the Board of Elections yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 17 The Department of Housing and Urban Development has approved a community, renewal grant for the Watts section of Los Angeles. It is the fourth Federal grant aimed at solving problems in the racially explosive area to be made in the last few weeks.

DETROIT, May 17 A critic of the automobile industry's safety practices called on Congress today for an investigation of car advertisements that he said deliberately encouraged reckless driving among teenagers.
WALLINGFORD, Pa., May 17 Jack Barron Cowie, who retired in 1962 as an assistant vice president of the Scott Paper Company, died yesterday in his home. He was 69 years old.
LONDON, May 17 Britain's housewives were told today to resist unjustified price increases on food as more ships became immobilized by the first national maritime strike here in 55 years.

Seventy thousand New Jersey commuters who travel to and from their jobs in this city by rail have just been given some hope of replacing their present ancient, creaky, partly bankrupt commuter lines. Governor Richard J. Hughes has offered a plan for developing over the next decade a unified, electrified system with modern equipment.

Dr. Leopold E. Levine, a retired general medical practitioner who, according to a member of his family, delivered over 3,000 babies on the Lower East Side, died on Monday in the Home and Hospital of the Daughters of Israel, 1260 Fifth Avenue, after a long illness. His age was 90.

PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., May 17 (UPI) Doug Sanders, who won $2,600 for 10th-place finish in the Greater New Orleans open yesterday continues to lead the Professional Golfers' Association money winners list.
PARIS, May 17 French' workers staged a 24-hour strike today for higher wages, shorter hours and greater social security.

The directors of the Pet Milk Company voted yesterday in St. Louis to raise the quarterly dividend to 25 cents a common share from 20 cents in preceding quarers. The dividend is payable July 1 to holders of record June 13.
Stocks fell to new 1966 lows again, with television, airline, electronics and many investment-grade issues showing the biggest losses in brisk trading; volume 9.87 million shares.

WASHINGTON, May 17 Secretary of State Dean Rusk suggested today that the recent rash of anti-American statements and threats from Cairo was giving President Johnson's Administration pause in continuing surplus food assistance to the United Arab Republic.
"Why don't you face it?" a teen-age girl challenged a teenage boy yesterday. "Your mother's hung up on alcohol; it's a disease, like diabetes."
ALBANY, May 17 The Legislature's top Republican said today that a bill to increase financial aid to the City University might never reach a vote in the Senate.
An open letter protesting the imprisonment of two Soviet writers will be sent tdoya to Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin by 121 United States intellectuals.
JAKARTA, May 17 Fifteen prominent political prisoners were released today after having spent four years in jail without trial.

MOSCOW, May 17 The 15th congress of Komsomol, the Communist Youth League, opened in the Kremlin today with a demand from the Soviet Communist party for strong measures against "parasitic and undisciplined" youngsters indifferent to Marxist ideals.
Harold Fischer, a checkers master, who established several unusual chess and checkers clubs in the Times Square area, died on Monday in Toronto. His age was 57.
MOSCOW, May 17 The Soviet Union is facing a demand that it relinquish its monopoly of control over the armed forces of Eastern Europe.

FAIRFIELD, Iowa, May 17 (AP) Earle R. Van Vliet, former treasurer of the Olin Mathieson Corporation, died in Jefferson County Hospital here yesterday after apparently suffering a stroke while driving his car. He was 68 years old. Mr. Van Vliet had been found unconscious in his car in a ditch north of Fairfield.
CLEVELAND, May 17 (AP) Max Alvis's two-run homer capped a three-run sixth inning and the Cleveland Indians gained a 3-2 victory over the Washington Senators tonight.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 17 (AP) A grand jury indicted five men last night in the slaying of Dow Wilson and the police said they had linked his death to the killing of another labor leader.

Ignoring the State Constitution once again, and too impatient to await results of a court test now under way, the New York Legislature is preparing to send to Governor Rockefeller a bill that enlarges greatly the provision of free textbooks to children in private and parochial schools, as well as public.

TORONTO, May 17 A sharp debate developed today among spiritual leaders of Conservative Judaism over whether American Conservative Judaism should become more deeply involved in Israel's cultural and religious life.

SAIGON, Wednesday, May 18 United States Air Force jets dropped anti-personnel bombs on American troops during an operation last week in the jungles 40 miles northwest of Saigon, a United States military spokesman reported today.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) The National Football League discussed a central scouting system and voted to extend the goal posts 20 feet above the crossbar during the opening session of its spring meeting yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, May 17 (UPI) Two magazine reporters were beaten tonight shortly after a group of some 25 to 40 Negro youths smashed windows in a south Los Angeles liquor store and made off with liquor and food.

Public hearings to clarify the state's new medical aid program were approved yesterday by the State Board of Social Welfare and a delegation of seven legislators from Albany. The hearings are scheduled to open next week.
Following are excerpts from Secretary of State Dean Rusk's news conference yesterday at the State Department in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of A.B.C. News:
WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) The Senate gave speedy final Congressional approval today to a bill designed to alleviate the shortage of box cars of the nation's railroads.

Seven American artists and one architect will receive cash awards totaling $18,500, it was announced yesterday by George F. Kennan, president of the National Institute of Arts and Letters. The awards will be presented at the joint annual ceremonial of the National Institute and the American Academy of Arts and Letters on May 25 at the Academy auditorium.

Following are excerpts from President Johnson's address to a Democratic party fund-raising dinner in Chicago last night at McCormick Place, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of A.B.C. News:
CHICAGO, May 17 (AP) Six shopcraft unions asked railroads across the nation today for a 20 per cent wage increase, Good Friday off and, in effect, a 37 -hour work week.

TOKYO, May 17 (AP) Communist China declared today it had photographs to prove that United States fighter planes intruded over mainland China and shot down a training plane with missiles last Thursday.
WASHINGTON, May 17 The House Armed Services Committee criticized Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara today for an "almost obsessional" dedication to cost factors.
HOUSTON, May 17 (UPI) Dr. Michael E. DaBakey attached as external heart pump today to a 61-year-old man and reported that the patient was "awake and doing quite well."
Richard Deering Howe, a 22year-old youth who was said by the police to have inherited $8million, was arraigned yesterday in Criminal Court on charges of felonious possession of marijuana.
HUE, South Vietnam, May 17--Shooting broke out here today as Buddhist elements opposed to Premier Nguyen Cao Ky staged demonstrations.
IRVINGTON, N.J., May 17 Frederick Francis, who manufactured artificial limbs in Newark for 30 years, died yesterday at his home, 240 Park Place here. He was 87 years old.

WASHINGTON, May 17 The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today a resolution that would give it an equal role with the Armed Services and Appropriations Committees in supervising the activities of the Central Intelligence Agency. The vote was 14 to 5.

NEAR the center of the walled capital city of Peking stands the walled Forbidden City of the emperors, now a vast museum of imperial China; and in the center of that there is an open courtyard called the Temple of Heaven, where the emperor communed privately with the gods. In the middle of the Temple of Heaven there is a flat, round stone, and this is called the Center of the Earth.
The Colony Club will be the setting on Tuesday for the annual reception and tea dance of the Society of Mayflower Descendants in the State of New York.
The Colony Club will be the setting on Tuesday for the annual reception and tea dance of the Society of Mayflower Descendants in the State of New York.

LONDON, May 17 Randy Turpin, who took the world middleweight boxing title from Sugar Ray Robinson in 1951 and held it for 64 days, was found dead from a gunshot wound at his home at Leamington, today. Beside him was his 2-year-old daughter, Carmen, suffering from gunshot wounds.
Union negotiators and representatives of the city's 80 taxi fleets tried to reach agreement on unresolved contract issues yesterday as 20,000 striking drivers returned to their jobs.
WASHINGTON, May 18 The Senate Banking Committee voted unanimously today to apply the standards of the new 1966 Bank Merger Act to bank holding company acquisitions.
DALLAS, May 18 (AP) The Southern Baptist Convention announced today that it had canceled plans to confer its distinguished Communications Medal on Bill D. Moyers, Presidential assistant.
DENVER, May 18 (AP) The United States Circuit Court of Appeals ruled today that Ralph Neely must play with the Houston Oilers of the American Football League.
Mayor Lindsay said yesterday he had worked quietly behind the scenes trying to block the Republican endorsement of Supreme Court Justice Arthur G. Klein for Surrogate in New York County.
Gen. William D. Eckert, the commissioner of baseball, accepted an invitation yesterday to visit Japan this fall. He said he would be in Japan for about a month.
PHILADELPHIA, May 18 An amateur who could not get the professionals to listen has become the Democratic nominee for Governor of Pennsylvania.
Small pox Outbreak in England

CLEVELAND, May 18 The earnings of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) are expected this year to be better than in 1965, making the fourth successive year that they will have exceeded the billion-dollar mark.

IWO JIMA, May 18 Nine men and a woman, representing survivors of 1,300 people who inhabited this island before World War II, came back today for the first time in 26 years and found practically nothing recognizable.
Two two-time winners of the Academy Award have been signed for leading roles in major network specials for next season.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 18 Britain and the United States joined today in urging the Security Council to forgo further pressure on Rhodesia that might impede present efforts to find "a just and peaceful solution."
A joint Federal and union program to prepare poorly trained high school graduates for decently paying subprofessional and vocational jobs was begun yesterday in Harlem.

OTTAWA, May 18 (AP) A bomber was killed by his own home-made explosive device today in a men's washroom in Parliament near the offices of Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson and Paul Martin, External Affairs Minister.
LONDON, May 18 Spain demanded today that Britain surrender her 262-year-old title to Gibraltar as the foreign ministers of the two countries opened talks on the Rock's future.

MRS. EVELYN MONTE of New York, a field trial expert, and Mrs. Samuel A. Gardner of Ossining, N.Y., a specialist in obedience competition, said yesterday that dogs needed activity to be at their best. The two experts gave talks at the Dog Fanciers Club meeting in Luchow's.
A proposed 20-year, $10-billion program for subway, rail and highway improvements in the metropolitan area was made public yesterday by the Tristate Transportation Commission.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 18 President Hector Garcia Godoy ordered the armed forces to their barracks today until after the June 1 presidential election in a move to prevent them from becoming involved in it.
Mr. and Mrs. Robert Emmett of New York have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathryn Deirdre Emmett, to David N. Rosen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert S. Rosen of New York.

LONG BEACH, Calif., May 18 The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations plans to ask President Johnson to issue an executive order that would withhold Federal contracts from companies violating the National Labor Relations Act.
The nation's electric power production rose 8.1 per cent in the week ended May 14 from the level in the corresponding 1965 week, it was reported by the Edison Electric Institute yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 18 The administrator of the painters union welfare fund was found dead last night, the third official of the union to die by violent means in less than two months. The police said he had committed suicide after admitting the misappropriation of $60,000 from the fund.

Paul Edward Andrepont, an executive who had served with several electronic defense contractors, died of a heart attack on Tuesday. He was stricken during a tennis game at the Riverdale Yacht Club and died almost immediately. His age was 47.
The name of the game today appears to be, "Change your name." And, unlike in marriages and mergers, it takes only one to play one company, that is.
DETROIT, May 18 (AP) Doctors at Henry Ford Hospital confirmed today that the Detroit Tiger manager, Charlie Dressen, had suffered a heart attack Monday.
WOLFEBORO, N.H., May 18 Cutting west from Maine toward Lake Winnipesaukee in New Hampshire, the route takes a traveling fisherman past Lake Sebago, long-famed as a fine spot for landlocked salmon.

DENVILLE, N.J., May 18 Milton (Babe) Lichardus of the Hollywood Golf Club took a five-stroke lead with a sixunder-par 66 in the first round of the $25,000 Dodge open golf tournament today at the Rockaway River Country Club.

ALBANY, May 18 The Legislature sent Governor Rockefeller today a bill to expand a controversial program enacted last year that requires public school boards to supply private and parochial school pupils with textbooks.

ELMSFORD, N.Y., May 18 Mr. and Mrs. Jeremiah J. Mahoney of Elmsford and Pompano Beach Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ellen J. Mahoney, to Bruce McLanahan. He is the son of Mrs. William G. Heaphy of Wilton, Conn., and John D. McLanahan of New York.
CHICAGO, May 18 (AP) Gypsy Ben, who was claimed for $7,000 by Oscar Cox in March, won the $16,275 Education Handicap on the turf course at Arlington Park today.
The election of Samuel H. Desch as executive vice president and a director was announced here yesterday by the Pepsi-Cola Company, a division of Pepsico, Inc.

David L. Cole, Mayor Lindsay's special mediator, has helped effect an initial agreement in the strike that has kept the World Journal Tribune, Inc., from publishing for more than three weeks. The pact with New York Typographical Union No. 6 provides ` displaced printers with separation benefits greater than those provided under their old contracts; it also permits operation of the composing room of the new morning, afternoon and Sunday papers on a pooled basis.
Julio Meade's 20.9 second 220yard dash highlighted Andrew Jackson's 15th consecutive team-title victory in the Queens Public Schools Athletic League track and field meet yesterday at Randalls Island.
A campaign to obtain $1-million to finance the completion of the Tri-Faith Chapels at Kennedy International Airport was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 18 Interwoven in the proposal to include members of the Foreign Relations Committee in the Senate group which checks the operations of the Central Intelligence Agency is the native ...
Ralph E. Kharas, dean of the College of Law at Syracuse University, died yesterday at the Upstate Medical Center in Syracuse. He was 64 years old.

Yves Louis Ploneis, the head chef at the 21 Club for almost 19 years, died yesterday in Boulevard Hospital after a long illness. He was 53 years old and lived at 148-38 Booth Memorial Avenue, Flushing, Queens.
The May Department Stores Company, which operates 72 units across the country, reported yesterday in St. Louis record sales and earnings for the first fiscal quarter ended April 30.

Nelson J. Peabody Dead at 83; Ex-Atlantic Monthly Publisher WELLESLEY HILLS, Mass., May 18 Nelson J. Peabody, former publisher of The Atlantic Monthly, died Saturday in Newton-Wellesley Hospital, Newton, Mr. Peabody, who was 83 years old, had fractured his skull two days earlier in a fall near his home at 18 Maugus Avenue here.

TRENTON, May 18 State Attorney General Arthur J. Sills obtained a court order here today restraining the New Jersey Ku Klux Klan from holding a big cross-burning rally Friday night in the southern part of the state.
In the Caucasus mountain region somewhere between the Black and the Caspian seas, there are shepherds who say they are 120 years old.

'MORGAN' CHARMS CANNES FESTIVAL CANNES, France, May 18 Perhaps the most enthusiastic reception an entry in the 20th Cannes Film Festival has yet received was given the British comedy "Morgan" at its showing last night. Immediately, this third and last contestant from Great Britain leaped to the fore as one of the likeliest contenders for the grand prize.

"Foul," cried Councilman Theodore S. Weiss as he stood on a soapbox in front of 406 West 23d Street. "Fraud and deceit!" Mr. Weiss, who is the designated Reform candidate for the Democratic nomination in the 19th Congressional District, was pointing to the sign above a storefront rented by the Independent Citizens for the Re-election of Representative Leonard Farbstein.

BURNT CABINS, Pa., May 18 A former mental patient, who had killed a Federal agent after abducting a 17year-old schoolgirl, wounded a deputy sheriff today in a daring attempt to escape a police cordon and then was shot dead in farmyard gun battle.

LOS ANGELES, May 18 (AP) San Francisco parlayed eighth inning errors by Ron Fairly and Jim Lefebvre into a four-run rally and a 6-4 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers tonight. The victory snapped a threegame losing streak for the Giants.
The Republic Steel Corporation raised prices yesterday on two types of steel products and reduced them on two others.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 18 (AP) Dr. Nathan M. Pusey, president of Harvard University announced today that the university's Fogg Art Museum had received a $4-million endowment from the estate of Archibald A. Hutchinson.
New York's Republican administration will make for "more efficient performance for the same tax dollar" and will produce "better government and better services," Mayor Lindsay declared yesterday.
Ohio sold yesterday $75-million of highway-improvement bonds in one of the key taxexempt bond sales of the week.

CLEVELAND, May 18 (AP) Don Lock's leaping catch of Duke Sims's line drive in the ninth inning preserved the Washington Senators' 4-3 victory over the Cleveland Indians tonight. The triumph snapped the Senators' three-game losing streak.

SELMA, Ala., May 18 (UPI) Government witnesses testified today that there were no intentional irregularities at polling places May 3 during the Democratic primary in which Wilson Baker outpolled Jim Clark for the Dallas County sheriff's nomination.
WASHINGTON, May 18 The House gave President Johnson a hard-fought victory today by approving his plan to shift more than $4-billion in Government mortgages and loans to private investors.
GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, May 18 Cheddi B. Jagan, whose pro-Marxist Government ended after bloodshed and racial strife here in 1964, will be Leader of the Opposition in the New Guianese Parliament.
A Police Department spokesman said yesterday that surveys had shown only a small fraction of cars parked in midtown Manhattan in violation of traffic laws.
Dr. Albert Gain Black, for many years associated with various government agricultural agencies, died Monday of lung cancer in Berkeley, Calif. He was 68 years old.

Drug Theft Suspect Held; Citywide Alert Is Canceled Fear that children or unsuspecting adults might be poisoned by drugs stolen in Brooklyn last week was dispelled last night when a burglary suspect was arrested and said he had dumped the drugs into a sewer.
Vito J. Giacalone, chief registrar of birth and death records of the Department of Health, died of a heart attack on Sunday in his home at 3075 Xavier Court, Oceanside, L.I. He was 54 years old.
ALBANY, May 18 Governor Rockefeller, defending the state's new medical-care program against growing upstate protests, asserted today: "I'm not prepared to retreat."

Mediators, in the 24-day-old newspaper strike accelerated negotiations in the remaining disputes yesterday after the printers had reported details of their $913,000 settlement with the World Journal Tribune, Inc.
Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc., filed late yesterday a $500,000 damage suit against Philip J. Levin, a dissident stockholder.
CASABLANCA, Morocco, May 18 Communist China blocked today a bid by the Soviet Union to join the Afro-Asian Organization for Economic Cooperation, which is holding a conference here.
HAMBURG, Germany, May 18 (AP) Three companies have agreed to a merger that would form one of the world's largest shipbuilding concerns, it was announced today.
Miss Alice S. Sullivan, a retired school teacher, died Tuesday in Roosevelt Hospital after a short-illness. Her age was 84. She lived at 171 West 71st Street.

The world chess champion, Tigran Petrosian and his challenger, Boris Spassky, both of the Soviet Union, adjourned their 16th game last night after 41 moves. The title match is taking place at Moscow's Variety Theater.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 110.5 on Tuesday from 110.6 Monday.

ROANNE, France The road to Roanne from the west is astonishingly beautiful, with undulating hills and valleys, blossoming fruit trees, grazing sheep and cattle, and fields of yellow, sweetly perfumed genet.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) President Johnson prodded Congress today to provide money to keep work going on Mohole, the project to drill through the earth's crust from a platform on the Pacific Ocean.

BOSTON, May 18 William P. Thompson, retiring Moderator of the 3.3 million-member United Presbyterian Church, called today for closer rapprochement between the "conservative, evangelical" bodies within American Protestantism and the larger, ecumenically minded "mainstream" denominations.
MILWAUKEE, May 18 (UPI) A $60-million nuclear power plant will be built in the town of Two Creeks in Manitowoc County, Wis., about 10 miles north of Two Rivers, it was announced today.
DETROIT, May 18 Although they added Roger Maris to the list of casualties, the New York Yankees completed their most successful Western trip in two years tonight by beating the Detroit Tigers, 7-2.
PHILADELPHIA, May 18 Harry Gold, the diffident hospital biochemist who confessed in 1950 that he had conspired to pass atomic secrets to the Soviet Union, came home today.

Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that he had called upon Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz to abandon the practice of lumping New York City with Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester and Rockland Counties as a major labor area.

FORT WORTH, May 18 Peter Thomson, the British Open champion, joined the pro golf tour today. But he is in a quandary. The 36-year-old Australian from Melbourne is a man with a country but without a Professional Golfers' Association card.

THE Queens Chess Club captured first place in the recent Long Island Chess League 1965-66 Team Tournament, scoring 7 match points out of a possible eight. The Nassau Chess Club was second with 6 and Westbury was third with 5 .

THUS far the supposed war between the National Football League and its junior counterpart, the American Football League, has not amounted to much more than suspicious looks across the frontier by armed border guards. It's true, of course, that there was a swift and bloodless capture of Atlanta by the N.F.L. along with strategic retreats by the badly outgunned A.F.L. in Dallas and Los Angeles.

BUFFALO, May 18 (AP) Dr. Albert H. Sharpe, former football coach at Cornell and Yale Universities and at Washington University in St. Louis, died last night in Buffalo General Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived in East Aurora.
LONDON, May 18 Twelve former Members of Parliament were named life peers in an honors list published today.
Thecaptain and 26 members of the sinking Greek freighter Aurora abandoned ship in the North Atlantic last night and were picked up by two British freighters, the Coast Guard said.
Prices on the London Exchange drifted off along a broad front yesterday on reports that the International Monetary Fund may recommend further deflationary measures to improve Britain's economy.
The chairman of the Michigan Gas and Electric Company urged his stockholders yesterday to turn down a tender offer of $100 a share from the American Electric Power Company.

TORONTO, May 18 (Canadian Press) The Texas Gulf Sulphur Company is being sued by the Royal Trust Company and a Hamilton, Ont., widow for $400-million or the recovery of 159 acres in orerich Kidd Township, near Timmins, in Northern Ontario.
The spot rate on the British pound continued to recover from its recent decline in moderate trading yesterday on foreign-exchange markets here.

Stocks rallied yesterday in one of the market's strongest recoveries since the sharp decline that began almost a month ago. The biggest gains were made by issues that had shown the deepest losses in recent weeks.

PRETORIA, South Africa, May 18 (Reuters) A European woman, imprisoned here for three months, told the Supreme Court today that she had made a statement to police only after relays of security men questioned her continuously for three days.

The Pittsburgh Lake Erie Railroad, the wealthy coal-and steel-carrying affiliate of the New York Central System, announced yesterday it had ordered 50 highly specialized freight cars to serve the steel industry and users of coiled steel.

The Encampment for Citizenship will honor Roger Baldwin and Norman Thomas at a dinner on Tuesday at the Plaza. The two men will receive the Medallion of the City of New York for their persistent work in behalf of democratic ideals.

BALTIMORE, May 18 The National Congress of Parents and Teachers adopted an emergency resolution today advocating the introduction in public schools of courses in venereal disease education "at least by the eighth grade."
GENEVA, May 18 The World Health Organization refused today to assume international leadership in developing family planning as an answer to the population explosion.
136 Typhoon Survivors Found
NORTH SALEM, N.Y., May 18 The cultures and customs of the English in past centuries are dramatically presented in an unusual "London Observ'd" exhibition that opened here today in the Hammond Museum.

KANSAS CITY, May 18 (AP) Mike Hershberger drove in three runs and scored two, leading the Kansas City Athletics to a 7-4 victory over the California Angels tonight and a sweep of their double-header. The A's won the opener, 7-1, behind the four-hit pitching of Jim (Catfish) Hunter.
Stocks rallied strongly in brisk trading yesterday in one of the few sustained recovery moves since a sharp price slide began almost a month ago.

ANDRE COURREGES whose brief career as a Paris couturier has altered the look of fashion, made the rounds of Seventh Avenue yesterday in the manner of the best French detective film tradition. He used the technique of being so obvious that hardly anyone noticed him.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 18 An Evening in Stratford, the biennial benefit of the Smith College Club of Greenwich and Stamford, will take subscribers on Saturday to "Twelfth Night" at the American Shakespeare Festival Theater and to dinner at the Mermaid Tavern in Stratford, where menu and decor are reminiscent of Elizabethan England.
The United States Public Health Service is taking steps to insure that rights and welfare are safeguarded when human beings are used in medical research.

New York University Library has received from Grove Press a complete set of its publications. At a reception yesterday, J.M. Edelstein, the University's librarian for special collections, said that the gift consists of more than 850 works, most in first editions.
Stocks advanced sharply, with airline, television and electronics issues strongest in active trading; volume, 9.31 million shares.

The New York Stock Exchange's board of governors will hold its annual organization meeting today after the close of the market. One item on the agenda, as required by the Big Board's constitution, will be a vote for the presidency of the exchange.

Juan Bosch would be well advised to remain a candidate for President of the Dominican Republic in the June 1 elections. He has threatened to withdraw on the grounds that his followers are being terrorized. Professor Bosch's principal opponent, Joaquin Balaguer, has put forward a similar complaint about intimidation of his Reformist party supporters.
Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange during the month ended last Friday fell to 10,295,241 shares.
"BIG MAN," opens at the Cherry Lane Theater, 38 Commerce Street, at 7. Two plays by Lawrence Weinberg, "Duet for Three" and "Big Man."
STAMFORD, Conn., May 18 Mr. and Mrs. Howard Root Sutherland have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Laurie Ann Sutherland, to Peter Grabon Macy, son of Nelson Macy Jr. of Southport.

Bernard B. Zients, executive head of Gimbels New York, has been elected president of the Metropolitan New York Retail Merchants Association, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Zients succeeds David L. Yunich, president of Macy's New York, who served two terms as president of the association.

Eugene M. Becker, the city's Budget Director, has declared that the $100-million cut that the City Council planned to make in Mayor Lindsay's budget would result in a continuation of "disastrous" deficit financing.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., May 18 Mr. and Mrs. John Joseph Gallagher have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Ellen Gallagher, to Ian Edward Fraser, son of Mrs. Ian H.S. Fraser of Lewiston and the late Mr. Fraser.

The accuracy of United States Weather Bureau reports will be challenged today by a senior commercial pilot who has charged that the weather data being issued to the airlines is both false and a serious threat to air safety.
The Pabst Theater in Milwaukee, the only commercial playhouse in a city of 760,000, will end its career May 28 with the final performance of "Do I Hear a Waltz?"
A nicely balanced program of rarely heard music was given by the New York Concert Ensemble last night at Carnegie Recital Hall.

WASHINGTON, May 18 Rejecting President Johnson's demands for Federal standards of benefit payments to the jobless, the House Ways and Means Committee cleared today a bill calling for relatively moderate changes in the unemployment compensation system.
Stockholders of the General Precision Equipment corporation, meeting yesterday at the Biltmore Hotel, approved a merger with the Controls Company of America.
CAPE KENNEDY, May 18 Gemini 9, grounded yesterday because it had no quarry to pursue in space, will try again to fly on May 31, space officials said today.

WASHINGTON, May 18 Some, called it a "Biennale Bash." Others said it was a "Biennale Bouillabaisse." Dr. Sergio Fenoaltea, the Italian Ambassador to the United States, began it last night by saying, "We Italians are among those Europeans who welcome American presence in Europe in any form."
LONDON, May 18 (Reuters) The British state-run Gas Council and three United States States oil companies announced today that they had struck natural gas with a jointly operated rig in the North Sea.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) The State Department made public tonight five United States-French agreements covering American military facilities in France.
The Transport Workers Union tried yesterday to extricate itself from 43 legal suits that seek more than $100-million in damages as a result of the union's 12-day transit strike last January.
Nurses in the 21 municipal hospitals accepted last night a fact-finder's proposal to end their labor dispute with the city, averting the mass resignation of 1,480 nurses threatened for Monday.
ATHENS, May 18 Greece and Turkey announced today a meeting of their Foreign Ministers to negotiate a "peaceful and agreed settlement" on Cyprus.

Since its creation in 1958 the State Commission of Investigation has done some excellent work. It has used its broad powers of inquiry throughout the state. The need for its impartial scrutiny will never become obsolete.

Waterfront employers in the port sided with the International Longshoremen's Association yesterday in opposing a legislative measure that would expand the power of the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor over the men who work the docks.

LONDON, May 18 At tea today, three dark medical students asked Muhammad Ali to autograph their inorganic chemistry textbooks and then pleaded with the world heavyweight champion to take his time beating Henry Cooper Saturday night, to inflict exquisite suffering before knocking him cold.

ALMOST every day in any one of three all-male bar bershops in Rockefeller Center's arcades, a big blonde woman with eyes like gentians bangs on a teacher's bell as if she were calling a class to order. And, in a way, she is.
CHICAGO, May 18 (UPI) The Houston Astros swept a double-header from the Chicago Cubs today, 5-1 and 4-2, for their 14th and 15th victories in the last 19 games.
The deadline for negotiations between the Taxi Drivers Organizing Committee and the city's fleet cab operators has been extended until midnight Saturday by Mayor Lindsay.
The last member of the top management team of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company trained directly under the Hartford Brothers John and George announced his retirement yesterday.
Millions of people working and living in New York have access to information and re ferral services maintained by Greater New York Fund agencies.

WASHINGTON, May 18 The next big development in labor-saving devices will almost certainly be the automatic tongue. When fully developed, it will take over as much as 95 per cent of all the conversation that now has to be ground out laboriously, syllable by syllable, by man.

A COUNTRY OF STRANGERS. By Conrad Richter, 172 pages, Knopf. $3.95. THE novel about the American Indian rarely reaches its extraordinary potentialities. The Indians remain a minority group, isolated in life and in art.
A goodly number of Bronx and Manhattan residents have been getting their water without fluoridation for a month because the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity lacked technical personnel.
MONTREAL, May 18 (UPI) Eight members of the American Society of Newspaper Editors were elected to the society's board of directors at the group's convention here today.
A top member of the Lindsay administration took sharp issue with Mayor Lindsay yesterday on a budget cut.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, May 18 Malaysia and Indonesia appeared headed today for discussions to end hostilities over formation of the Malaysian federation.
Lyle Mahan, 85, Lawyer, Son of the Naval Historian Lyle Evans Mahan, a lawyer, died Tuesday in his home at 255 East 49th Street. His age was 85.

The board of Filmways, Inc., declared here yesterday a cash dividend of 15 cents a common share plus a 2 per cent stock dividend. Both declarations are payable June 30 to stockholders of record June 10.

YONKERS, May 18 Romeo Hanover, a colt that was purchased for $8,500 as a yearling in 1964 and already has earned $158,965, and Overcall, a homebred with earnings of $84,869, are the favorites in tomorrow night's 12th edition of the Cane Pace at Yonkers Raceway.

MOST bridge problems are double-dummy, which simply means that the solver knows the distribution of all four hands and can take full advantage of that knowledge. More interesting for the practical player is the "sure trick" variety of problem. In this the solver is given two hands and is required to make his contract against any conceivable distribution and defense.

LINDEN, N.J., May 18 Mr. and Mrs. Arthur L. Breakstone have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sheryl Lee Breakstone, to Leslie I. Shapiro, son of Mr. and Mrs. Melville D. Shapiro of Elizabeth.
WASHINGTON, May 18 President Johnson pledged today to give the American Bar Association a prominent role in selecting a large number of Federal judges soon to be chosen.
WASHINGTON, May 18 Senator Herman E. Talmadge tentatively put himself in the Georgia governorship race today. He said that if he ran and won, he would expect to appoint his successor in the Senate.
LAKE FOREST, Ill., May 18 Mr. and Mrs. William Roy Carney have announced the engagement of Mrs. Carney's sister, Miss Florence A. Murphy of New York, to Maurice F. Dunne of Winnetka.

Praise the New York State Council on the Arts and pass the earmuffs. For its adventurousness in sending out a strange avant-garde jazz show to tour a half-dozen upstate campuses last week the council deserves an A for effort. For some of the shell-shocked listeners who sat through this program, some ...

WASHINGTON, May 18 The deficit in the nation's balance of international payments widened to $582-million in the first quarter of this year, but the Government has decided against any major new steps to deal with the problem.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) Representatives of seven cities made bids in the National Football League today for the 16th league franchise, which is to go into operation next year.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (UPI) The Administration strongly opposed today legislation that would impose immediate mandatory auto safety standards.

Mrs. Jeremiah C. Ingersoll of Brooklyn was elected president of the Women's City Club of New York yesterday at the club's annual meeting at its headquarters, 6 West 48th Street. Mrs. Ingersoll, the former Miss Minneola Perry, will succeed Mrs. Herbert Sternau on June 12 for a two-year term.
LONDON, May 18 The Government proposed today a new territorial structure for Provincial Police forces in England and Wales to improve the efficiency and to help fight crime.
NEWARK, May 18 This old colonial city, which is razing its antiquated buildings and replacing them with modern structures, celebrated its 300th birthday today in a spirit of hope and pride.

WASHINGTON, May 18 Chief Justice Earl Warren warned today that "ill-advised" proposals pending in Congress to bar racial discrimination in the selection of juries could, if enacted, encroach on rights of the states.

The case of L. Judson Morhouse, former Republican state chairman, will be turned over to a jury in State Supreme Court this afternoon. Mr. Morhouse is being tried on charges of conspiracy and bribery of Martin C. Epstein, former chairman of the State Liquor Authority.

DANANG, South Vietnam, Thursday, May 19 A number of small gun battles between pro-Government and anti-Government South Vietnamese troops broke out this morning near pagodas in which dissident Buddhists have taken refuge.
As fickle as the weather, wheat futures prices have been moving up and dawn in response to news about rain and frost in the growing areas.
VIENNA, May 18 Leading space scientists from East and West, after nine days of sober scientific discussion, gave free rein to their hopes and imaginations here this afternoon.
JOHN WEITZ, the American sportswear designer, who disclaims any knowledge of the Carnaby look, showed his 1966 resort line at Lord Taylor Tuesday night.
New vice presidents were announced yesterday on both the client and agency sides of the advertising business.
Marais and Miranda, the international balladeers, returned to Town Hall last night. They appeared on the stage where "nearly 20 years ago to the day" they had made their concert debut.

HELSINKI, Finland, May 18 (UPI) Dennis Ralston of Bakersfield, Calif., and Marty Riessen of Evanston, Ill., de feated Ove Bengtsson of Sweden and John Newcome of Australia, 6-4, 6-3, today to win the men's doubles title in the Helsinki tennis tournament.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., May 18 There are some boxing managers and trainers who subscribe to the theory that the best way to prepare for a fight is to fight.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 18 Premier Levi Eshkol said today that the major powers should draw the line between "the permissible and the impermissible" in establishing a balance of arms in the Middle East.
Natalie Wood, wearing a mink coat, a brunette wig and an expectant expression, breezed out of Bergdorf-Goodman, Fifth Avenue at 58th Street, yesterday afternoon and hailed a cab.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (UPI) President and Mrs. Johnson honored seven Vietnam combat heroes tonight and seven members of the Navy's Blue Angels' precision flying team as their special guests at a military reception.
WASHINGTON, May 18 A $615,000 Federal grant to finance half of a major rehabilitation of Prospect Park in Brooklyn was announced today by the Interior Department.

All references to sex at the Hudson County Jail were stricken yesterday from the perjury charges against Warden Henry B. McFarland as the defense counsel continued to chip away at the original fourcount indictment.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, May 18 Rumania denied today any intention of wanting to scuttle or leave the Warsaw Pact, but indicated opposition to Soviet demands for a strengthening of the alliance.
LONDON, May 18 (AP) Sir Daniel Davies, the physician to the British royal family, died today at his home here. He was 66 years old. The cause of death was not announced.
AMARILLO, Tex., May 18 (AP) Five Air Force men died last night when a jet tanker burst into flames while landing at the Amarillo Air Force Base.

The Potomac Electric Company offered yesterday rights to subscribe to 522,940 shares of convertible preferred stock at $50 a share. The offering is being underwritten by a group of investment bankers headed by Dillon, Read Co., Inc., and Johnston, Lemon Co.
The Federal Bureau of Investigation believes that Joseph Bonanno was kidnapped because he had plotted to kill two other Mafia chiefs Thomas (ThreeFinger-Brown) Luchese and Carlo Gambino.
Arthur J. Goldberg took issue last night with those who believed that the United States should discount United Nations procedures in favor of power politics.

Senator Robert F. Kennedy proposed yesterday that a privately financed development corporation be formed to rebuild the physical structure of urban ghettos and regenerate the lives of their inhabitants.
BALTIMORE, May 18 (AP) Earl Wilson scattered seven hits and won the game with a leadoff homer in the 10th inning off Jim Palmer as the Boston Red Sox beat the Baltimore Orioles, 2-1, tonight.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., May 18 (AP) Richard Petty defeated two other drivers today and captured the pole position for Sunday's 600-mile Grand National stock car race.

BALTIMORE, May 18 (AP) Stupendous gave an indication today of what can be expected Saturday when he hooks up with the Kentucky Derby winner, Kauai King, and seven other 3-year-olds in the $150,000 added Preakness.

HOUSTON, May 18 A 61year-old man to whom a heart pump had been attached after heart surgery here yesterday took a turn for the worse today and underwent further surgery, during which the pump was removed.

I ONCE paid the equivalent of $1 for a pair of cot ton gloves and then $7 to get them dyed, that's how hungry I was for color," Gunilla Ponten, one of Sweden's foremost designers of teenage fashions, said here recently.

In a major policy address, Archie K. Davis, president of the American Bankers Association, spelled out yesterday the details of A.B.A.'s long-awaited program of voluntary credit restraint for the nation's banks.

Of President Johnson's earnest desire for peace we have no doubt, nor have we ever had any doubt. But we take strong exception to some of the President's other statements at the Cook County Democratic fundraising dinner, night before last.

OCEANPORT, N.J., May 18 Philip H. Iselin was elected today president and chairman of the board of the Monmouth Park Jockey Club, succeeding Amory Haskell, who died last April 12. The selection was made at a meeting of the board of directors.
City Councilman Woodward Kingman yesterday said he was "shocked by the [Metropolitan Opera] Association's claim that the sum of $15-million is the [old Met's] true value.
The number of converts entering the Roman Catholic church in the United States reached a 12-year low last year, the official Catholic Director for 1966 reported yesterday.

JERSEY CITY, May 18 William H. Donnelly, a standing master of the New Jersey Superior Court, died yesterday at Mercer County Hospital in Trenton at the age of 67. He lived at 106 Kensington Avenue and had an office in Trenton.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) Senator Birch Bayh, Democrat of Indiana, said today that neither President Johnson's limited Electoral College reform nor his own proposal for direct elections of President and Vice President had a chance of approval now by his Senate subcommittee.
ALBANY, May 18 The Legislature bogged down today over a proposed increase in the state's minimum wage and went home until Monday.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) A total of 41 United States servicemen in South Vietnam have been courtmartialed or given lesser punishment in a crackdown on blackmarketeering and currency manipulation, defense officials said tonight.
The Flying Tiger Line placed an order yesterday for 10 Douglas DC-8 63F convertible airfreighters valued at $100 million.
SAIGON, May 18 South Vietnamese troops in the Mekong Delta have killed more than 600 Vietcong in the last week.
LONDON, May 18 The Government was warned today that a general strike would result if the navy was used to reduce the impact of the seamen's strike.
Wheatley Stable's Bold Lad, the toast of the thoroughbred world as a juvenile in 1964, but a surgery case last year, made his first stakes comeback effort a sparkling one at Aqueduct yesterday.

HANOVER, N.H., May 18 Dr. Carleton B. Chapman of Dallas, a former president of the American Heart Association, has been appointed dean of the Dartmouth Medical School, according to an announcement today by John Sloan Dickey, president of Dartmouth College.
WASHINGTON, May 18 Representative Melvin R. Laird, Republican of Wisconsin, said today that 440,000 United States servicemen were in Southeast Asia on duty primarily concerned with the Vietnam war.

TORONTO, May 18 Representatives of American Conservative Judaism approved a broad educational and service program today designed to make their influence felt in Israel. Their action poses a challenge to Orthodoxy, the dominant religious force in that country.
A thin, tall, freckled young man from Gstaad, Switzerland, arrived here yesterday. Like so many foreign visitors, he had immediate and acute need of a friend.

CAIRO, May 18 The United States snubbed today the departure of Premier Aleksel N. Kosygin after an eight-day visit here, marked by Soviet and Egyptian attacks on American policy in Vietnam and moves to form a leftist alliance in the Middle-East.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) A top Pentagon official conceded today that there was a temporary shortage of bombs in South Vietnam early in April. But he said ammunition supplies now were "more than adequate."

WASHINGTON, May 18 With his speech in Montreal today, Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara brought into the open his deep personal conviction that the Administration must adopt some new and urgent priorities in its relations with the rest of the world.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., May 18 Mrs. Sylvia See Schornstein, wife of Harry Schornstein, a retired wholesale food importer, died last Saturday in Venice, Italy, while vacationing with her husband and two sisters. She was 59 years old and lived at 195 Prospect Street.

MOSCOW, May 18 The Soviet Union today challenged West German's sincerity in making European security proposals and reiterated its own program to incorporate East Germany into a stable European peace settlement.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 18 Werner (Jack) Endrikat, who never ran a half-mile until last month, scored the most significant victory of his track career today. It helped Princeton win the New Jersey intercollegiate championship at Palmer Stadium for the third time in the meet's four-year history.

WASHINGTON, May 18 The United States has begun to give more emphasis to its desire to obtain good treatment and, if possible, the release of United States prisoners held by the Vietcong and in North Vietnam.
AUSTIN, Tex., May 18 (UPI) The Texas Court of Criminal Appeals ordered a lower court in Dallas today to "proceed without further delay" in holding a sanity trial for Jack Ruby.
WASHINGTON, May 18 The United States has protested to Cambodia over reported use by the Vietcong of Cambodian territory for undertaking military actions against American forces in Vietnam.

Paul Radenhausen, for 46 years language teacher at Brooklyn Technical High School, died Tuesday at Burlington (N.J.) County Hospital after a short illness. Mr. Radenhausen had lived in Mount Holly, N.J., for the last eight years. He would have been 78 years old on May 30.
ANACONDA, Mont., May 18 (AP) Government interven tion is partly to blame for a chaotic price situation for copper, C. Jay Parkinson, the president of the Anaconda Company, told stockholders today.
LONDON, May 18 "If we were thinking of the coun try first and foremost, naturally we would say there should be no strike. But charity begins at home."
PARIS, May 18 Paris will get a twin city next week: Moscow.
Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz yesterday reversed his department's practice of prohibiting racial identification on employment records.

MADISON, Wis., May 18 An antidraft sit-in that began Monday afternoon continued today on the University of Wisconsin campus. Its end appeared to be near, however, after the protesters were assured that the university faculty would meet Monday, to discuss proposed changes in the university's draft policies.

IN this day and age of exploding cultural conscious ness (or pop art, as it is known in some quarters) what is happening to the audience? Or to be more specific, what is happening to the dance audience? Well, it still isn't eating popcorn (or it wasn't at the last count) and it is still increasing.
FAIRFIELD, Conn. Mr. and Mrs. Albert J. Wieland have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lynda Joan Wieland, to Dr. J. David R. Kramer Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Kramer of Philadelphia.
The Greek Fur Workers Local, believed to be the last labor organization in the country in which membership was restricted to one national group, was dissolved last night.

LOS ANGELES, May 18 The police were put on an alert today after a night of unrest in the all-Negro Watts section during which two newsmen were beaten, a liquor store was looted, shots were fired by snipers and angry crowds of up to 500 persons surged through the streets.
ST. LOUIS, May 18 (UPI) The St. Louis Cardinals sent Alex Johnson, obtained from the Philadelphia Phillies in a winter trade, to their Tulsa farm club tonight.

The chairman of the City Commission on Human Rights charged yesterday that the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association had exploited "basic prejudice and bigotry" in criticizing the civilian-controlled complaint review board planned for the police.
BALTIMORE, May 18 (AP) An anecdote has been revived at Pimlico, where the Preakness will be run Saturday, to illustrate the lack of agreement over the pronunciation of Kauai King.

BERKELEY, Calif., May 18 (AP) Dr. Thomas Harper Goodspeed, University of California botanist who founded and directed the Botanical Gardens here, died Monday at a convalescent home. He was 79 years old.
