Three alleged members of an international syndicate that specialized in mulcting banks and businessmen were indicted yesterday on Federal charges of entering the United States illegally and possessing 16 forged passports.
The City Commission on Human Rights charged a landlord's son yesterday with having interfered with an investigator in a case involving the refusal of a Brooklyn apartment to a Negro applicant.

Year-around attention, in tensified after each snowfall, has reduced the problem of potholes in the city's 6,000 miles of streets and 100 miles of expressways, Highways Commissioner Harry J. Donnelly reported yesterday.
EAST ORANGE, N.J., May 18 Irving A. Harris, a newspaper reporter in the Essex County suburbs for more than 30 years, died yesterday in his home at 179 South Harrison Street. He was 73 years old.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) Paul Hall, president of the Seafarers International Union, said today that the Vietnam war had shown the Americanflag merchant fleet "is certainly inadequate to meet defense and commercial needs at the same time."
MONTREAL, May 18 Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara proposed today that all young Americans give their country two years of service in either a military or a civilian role.

KINGS PARK, L.I., May 18 A highly esteemed schoolteacher, active in the Little League and the Parent-Teacher Association, was being sought today for having allegedly molested a dozen schoolboys in the last three years.
GRAFTON, N.Y., May 18 Harry B. Nugent, the father of Brother Gregory Nugent, F.S.C., president of Manhattan College, died at his home here at the age of 84.
PARIS, May 18 France has called on West Germany to state unequivocally whether it wanted French forces to remain stationed on German soil.
CHATTANOOGA, May 18 The Chattanooga Times and The Chattanooga News-Free Press announced plans today to dissolve their joint publication arrangement, effective "within a few months."
The New York Mets suffered a double setback last night as the Cincinnati Reds swept to their 10th victory in 12 games behind Sammy Ellis's four-hit pitching.

Young musicians, gathered yesterday at a reception here before their participation in the Third International Tchaikovsky Competition in Moscow, agreed with the comment of one singer "I was thrilled at the thought of going to Moscow, and then it dawned on me it meant a lot of hard work."

Professional football war erupted yesterday when an American League team made overtures to three players on the New York Giants of the National League. All three were promised reportedly lucrative contracts if they would play out their options with the Giants and then sign with the rival league.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP)--Plans to dot the nation with self-service post offices, clear the air of pollution from mail trucks and offer every mailer an advanced course in zip-code usage were announced today by Postmaster General Lawrence F. O'Brien.
A 61-year-old woman was slightly wounded by one of eight bullets fired by policemen at two teen-age suspects in a chase on Broadway in the 80's that ended with the arrest of the youths.

They will join Amos Vogel, the festival's director, and Richard Roud, program director, who selected films for the three earlier festivals.
Industrial stocks moved irregularly on the London Stock Exchange yesterday, but British Government bonds met brisk demand and posted gains.

THE Orpheus of this extremely accomplished, horrible-hilarious, derivativeamalgamating, tour-de-farce first novel is a put-upon young man who learns to embrace his fate with a vengeance. His name is Alex Underland, which is appropriate enough.

The threatened resignation of nearly half the nurses in the city's badly understaffed hospitals has been averted by a fact finder's recommendation of higher salary scales. The mass withdrawal of nurses would have created a municipal emergency of drastic dimensions; so disastrous a contingency should not have been required to arouse the community to the inadequacy of the wages that prompted the original threat.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 19 (UPI)--A Criminal Court jury today found Mrs. Gertrude Baniszewski, 38-year-old mother of seven, guilty of first degree murder in the torture slaying of Sylvia Likens, 16. Four teenage defendants were convicted on lesser charges.
ALBANY, May 19--In the March examination for admission to the New York State Bar, 274 candidates passed, the State Board of Law Examiners announced today. The test was taken by 483 applicants.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 19--Cambodia informed the Security Council today of "a series of clear acts of aggression, involving large-scale warlike operations."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 19--Borba, the Yugoslav Communist party newspaper, published a report today from Moscow saying that Rumanian military representatives proposed changes in the Warsaw Pact statutes last February. Borba's report was by its usually well-informed correspondent, Risto Bajalski.
The Port of New York Authority will start today a survey of the origin and destination of steamship passengers arriving at or departing from Hudson River piers in Manhattan.
The British pound rose slightly, in fairly active trading on foreign-exchange mar kets here yesterday. Sterling for delivery today was quoted at $2.7927, up 4 points from Wednesday.

BUENOS AIRES, May 19-- The General Labor Federation voted today, for a countrywide general strike as a protest against the veto by President Arturo U. Illia of a bill expanding severance pay and otherwise favoring workers in their relationship with management.
The Bethlehem Steel Corporation and the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation followed yesterday the price changes on several types of steel products initiated Tuesday by the Republic Steel Corporation.
A memorial service to honor all merchant seamen killed in the service of their country is scheduled at 11 A.M. on Memorial Day aboard the Amer ican Export Isbrandtsen Lines' Independence.

WOODMERE, L.I., May 19-- Mr. and Mrs. Henry Bentley of Woodmere and Spofford, N.H., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gene Beatrice Bentley, to Martin William Cooper, son of Lieut. Col. Denis A. Cooper, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Cooper of Arlington, Va.
An all-male jury found Warden Henry B. McFarland of Hudson County Jail guilty on both counts of perjury early this morning.

ANOTHER foreign expedition by IASTA--the Institute for Advanced Studies in the Theater Arts. This group recently produced "Phedre" at the Off Broadway Greenwich Mews, and last night it opened a Chinese drama at the same theater.

DANANG, South Vietnam, May 19--The United States tried unsuccessfully today to persuade Lieut. Gen. Nguyen Chanh Thi, the former I Army Corps commander, to meet secretly with Premier Ky in an effort to find a settlement of the minor civil war here.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 19-- President Humberto Castelo Branco today removed a defiant general, Justino Alves Bastos, who had hoped to become a state governor, from an army command in the extreme south.
BONN, May 19--The way is still open for an agreement with France on the status of French troops stationed in West Germany, Government sources said today.
YONKERS, May 19--Walter B.J. Mitchell of Glenwood Gardens, a lawyer and former office holder here, died last night in St. Albans Naval Hospital, St. Albans, Queens. He was 74 years old.
LONDON, May 19--Britain's first national maritime strike in 55 years will enter its fifth day tomorrow with no sign of a break in the deadlock between the shipowners and the striking merchant seamen.
The city school system will get a $1-million Federal grant, originally earmarked for Freeport, L.I., as a result of quick action by Mayor Lindsay's office.

NEWARK, May 19--Company officials outnumbered shareholders at the Hazel Bishop, Inc., annual meeting in the Robert Treat Hotel in New ark yesterday, but a few outspoken stockholders made up for the small numbers.
Parks Commissioner Thomas P.F. Hoving has declined, a philanthropist's offer of a $1million children's theater for Central Park, but he is hopeful that it can be built somewhere else.
THE unusual enthusiasm with which owners of cruising yachts are responding to distance races this year was reflected yesterday from two sources. Donald B. King,...

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., May 19--"Follow the lead of Alabama" has become a frequent plea of Gov. Haydon Burns of Florida as he stumps the state in the closing days of the second Democratic primary campaign.
ROME, May 19--The influential Jesuit review Civilta Cattolica took Italy's Parliament to task today for triviality and failure to resist Communist bullying.
Controller Mario A. Procaccino warned Mayor Lindsay yesterday not to use any Federal antipoverty funds in setting up the controversial "Little City Halls" program.
MR. AND. MRS. CHARLES GILMAN JR. had a simple party Wednesday night. Only 500 hours of work went into it.

CHICAGO, May 19 (UPI) --Twenty-two horse players collected the second largest daily double in Arlington Park history when Priscilla Mullen, a 75-1 shot, and Boy U Rite, another outsider, won the first and second races.

BUFFALO, May 19--Irving S. Williams, retired executive art director of the Buffalo office of Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc., died of a heart attack yesterday in his automobile. He was 73 years old and lived at 99 16th Street here.

TOKYO, May 19--Gov. William W. Scranton of Pennsylvania declared today that public confidence in the Johnson Administration's "reliability" had been deeply shaken by "highly overoptimistic statements on Vietnam.
SHADE GAP, Pa., May 19 (UPI)--Larry Rubeck, a 15year-old farmboy whose bullet may have killed Hollenbaugh, stayed home from school today...
Mayor Lindsay is being urged by some of his close advisers to appeal directly to the people in a fireside television chat in an effort to end the impasse over his tax legislation in Albany.
TRENTON, May 19--Dr. Frederick M. Raubinger, the controversial State Commissioner of Education, announced today that he had accepted a professorship beginning this fall at the University of Illinois.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP)--Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower, wife of the former President, was among Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson's guests today at the annual White House luncheon for Senate wives, present and past.
A 40-year-old patrolman who allegedly brandished his service revolver in the face of a motorist was arrested yesterday and charged with felonious assault.
KINGSTON, Jamaica, May 19 (AP)--Arthur Ashe and Cliff Richey swept to straightset victories today that gave the United States a 2-0 lead in its Davis Cup tennis competition against the West Indies.
HYDERABAD, India, May 19 --As the eastbound passenger train pulled into Baivanthal several weeks ago, the engineer blinked with surprise at a large crowd of villagers running down the tracks.
John D. Harper, president of the Aluminum Company of America, assailed the Administration's anti-inflationary guideposts yesterday.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 19--Foreign Minister Adam Malik today confirmed that Indonesian officials had made direct contact with officials of the Malaysian Government in an effort to resolve the dispute between the two countries.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 19--Secretary General Thant, in jesting mood, compared his job today to a "shoe that pinches in many places." But he sidestepped a reply whether he wanted to remain when his current term as Secretary General ends in November.

THE Eastern Regional Championships, which are the high spot of the New York tournament year, will begin this afternoon at the New York Hilton Hotel. The event dates back to 1929, making it one of the oldest tournaments in the world, once having had national prestige.
Five union leaders from the British newspapers and printing industry visiting New York yesterday described Britain's advanced machinery to ease newspaper disputes and improve efficiency.

Although stockholders and management of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad have formally endorsed a merger offer from the Union Pacific Railroad, holders of 1,360,548 shares of the 2,919,811 Rock Island shares outstanding have accepted a rival exchange offer from the Chicago North Western Railway.

CANNES, France, May 19-- All of the motion-picture action in this region is not happening at the Cannes Film Festival. Some of the liveliest location shooting ever took place in nearby Monaco today, when James Garner and other actors in the film "Grand Prix" drove racing cars around the narrow and twisting streets where the 24th Grand Prix Automobile de Monaco will be run on Sunday.

Hopes for a Cyprus settlement have been dashed so often in the last thirty months that no one will celebrate just because Greece and Turkey have agreed to resume high-level talks. This is an encouraging development, nevertheless, and there are reasons why Athens and Ankara might agree at least to the cooling-off period of three to five years suggested by United Nations Secretary General Thant.

TORONTO, May 19--The personal effects of Paul Joseph Chartier, who was killed yesterday while trying to bomb the House of Commons in Ottawa, disclosed today that he planned for a year to kill as many members of Parliament as possible.
North American production of newsprint rose to a record 893,754, tons in April, up 11.1 per cent from output in the 1965 month, the Newsprint Service Bureau reported yesterday.
TOKYO, May 19 (Reuters) --The Japanese Air Self-Defense Force grounded more than 400 American-designed jet fighters for inspection after a crash today brought the total lost this year to six.
WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP)--James R. Hoffa tilted with truck lines and the Interstate Commerce Commission today at a demonstration of truck safety devices sponsored by his union.
Paper handlers last night became the second of 10 newspaper unions to reach agreement on contract terms with the World Journal Tribune, Inc.
David Karp's "The Confession," a dramatic evocation of the conflict between police interrogation and civil rights, will be televised on "ABC Stage '67" next season.

It's not true that Jack J. Valenti, the recently elected president of the Motion Picture Association of America, never remembers having seen a bad movie, an opinion attributed to him last month when he resigned as an assistant to President Johnson.
HONG KONG, May 19--The Chinese Communist party has intensified its nationwide campaign against "anti-party, antisocialist plotters" within its Peking municipal branch.

WASHINGTON, May 19--A vague rustle of doubt and even anxiety is now running through the Administration in Washington, and no wonder. The problems facing the President and his principal aides in Vietnam and elsewhere are boundless, and the strain is beginning to tell.
The old Tribune Building at 150 Nassau Street, a relic of what was New York's "Newspaper Row" at the turn of the century, is to be razed to make way for Pace College's $12million campus center.

The National Broadcasting Company made it unanimous yesterday among the three major TV networks in announcing the elimination of certain discounts for major advertisers who purchase large amounts of prime evening time.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., May 19 (AP)--Former Gov. LeRoy Collins said today that he planned to run for the United States Senate in 1968.
Plans to modernize the Dr. Albert Schweitzer Hospital in Lamberene, Gabon, were announced here yesterday by Mrs. Rhena Eckert-Schweitzer, the daughter of the late Nobel Peace Prize winner.
MONTREAL, May 19--Canada's two foremost political leaders lectured American newspaper editors today on Canada's independence, economic and otherwise, from the United States.

The city's banks are collecting an estimated windfall of about $250,000 a year on interest on real estate taxes owed to the city, a City Councilman declared yesterday. He said "there ought to be a law" and prepared a Council bill designed to correct the situation.
BOSTON, May 19--Richard Cardinal Cushing, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Boston, stood before more than 800 Presbyterians today, raised his arms and declared:

FERNDALE, N. Y., May 19 --The sounds of Arabic, of the West African language of Yoruba and of a Negro spiritual drifted across the rolling, hazeshrouded hills of Ferncliff Cemetery today as 50 mourners paid tribute to Malcolm X at his graveside.
More than $4.5-billion in New York City transit and highway improvements may be involved in the 20-year, $10-billion interim plan put forward by the Tri-State Transportation Commission.

Business in the wool textile industry is good and getting better as a result of strong civilian demand for apparel and military requirements for Vietnam, industry leaders said yesterday. But they warned that the Government must take action to control the influx of goods from abroad to assure the industry's long-term growth.
The Right Rev. John E. Hines, Presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church, announced yesterday that the Bishops of the Church had consented to the resignations of Bishop James A. Pike of the Diocese...
WASHINGTON, May 19-- President Johnson announced today his intention to nominate Eugene M. Locke, formerly Democratic party chairman in Texas as Ambassador to Pakistan.
ALBANY, May 19--Legislation to guarantee patients a free choice of physicians under the state's new medical care program was introduced today by Senate Majority Leader Earl W. Brydges.
ANDRE COURREGES held a press conference yes terday to prove that he wasn't hiding.
Yale University's School of Drama has received a grant of $390,000 from the Rockefeller Foundation. The money will be distributed over a five-year period with matching funds from the university.

MONTROSE, N.Y., May 19-- Thomas N. Fasso, a former city official and Republican chairman of New Rochelle, died of a stroke here today in the Franklin D. Roosevelt Veterans Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived at 17 Oakdale Avenue, New Rochelle.
The jury in the conspiracy and bribery trial of L. Judson Morhouse, former Republican state chairman, failed to reach a verdict last night after sevenand-a-half hours of deliberation.

The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday the appointment of Winsor H. Watson Jr. as a vice president and Robert N. Schilling as secretary of the exchange. Edwin D. Etherington, president, said the appointments were part of a realignment of the exchange's membership and public information services.

SHE has called herself "the old witch," "Crazy Jane" and "Mother Lollipops," but the secret of her achievements, she confided to an interviewer, is her ability to be a "Jimmy, Jimmy, got anything to gimmee." The last charac-...
WASHINGTON, May 19-- Two more key economic indicators made it unanimous today --the hectic upward pace of the economy definitely slowed in April.
The election of Dwight L. Stocker as senior vice president and general manager of the pulp, paper and board manufacturing division of the Brown Company was announced yesterday.
An official of the New York Transit Authority revealed yesterday that a new color-coded subway guide would be ready for public use next September.
WASHINGTON, May 19--One of President Johnson's top aides said today that the historic form of federalism no longer met modern conditions.

CHICAGO, May 19--Lawrence Young's carry-out fried-chicken establishment, started with the help of President Johnson, went out of business today as the Small Business Administration sent a van to cart off the counters and other equipment.
MOSCOW, May 19--The Soviet Union announced today that it had ordered an intensification of paramilitary training of civilians to meet "present-day needs."

The state chairmen of the Democratic and Liberal parties joined yesterday in an appeal to their Republican counterpart for a reversal of his party's opposition to a nonpartisan slate of delegates at large to the 1967 Constitutional Convention.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (UPI)--Senators accused the country's top medical officers today of underestimating the danger of the hallucinatory drug LSD and asked why they did not demand legislation to make its possession illegal.
SYRACUSE, May 19--An odd pocket of rebellion against Governor Rockefeller's sales tax exists in the quiet glades of the Onondaga Valley, five miles south of here.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) --Army doctors arrived at a diagnosis today of the type of arthritis former President Dwight D. Eisenhower has--osteoarthritis. They gave no word of how long he would remain at Walter Reed General Hospital.

The Tri-State Transportation Commission, legally established only last year to be the official planning agency for the transportation and land use problems of the New York metropolitan area, has now made a cautious beginning in its staggering task.

LONDON, May 19--A 12legged American floating rig called Mr. Louie struck another gas field in the North Sea yesterday, which means that six of the 16 companies exploring Britain's share of the North Sea have now found gas.

PURCHASE, N. Y., May 19 Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart announced today that Mother Eleanor M. O'Byrne would retire as its president in July. She will be succeeded by Mother Elizabeth J. McCormack, academic dean of the Roman Catholic institution.
NORWALK, Conn., May 19-- The Norwalk Redevelopment Agency approved plans last night for this city's first tall office building.

Workable artificial hearts could save millions of lives and have profound effects on the nation, but many important problems still remain to be solved before that goal is reached, according to a series...

YONKERS, May 19--Interest in tomorrow night's "pace of the century," in which 4-year-old Bret Hanover and 10-year-old Cardigan Bay will meet for the first time, is so high, the onemile race for a purse of $65,000 may attract the largest crowd of the meeting at Yonkers Raceway.

Textron, Inc., a diversified manufacturing company based in Providence, R. I., reported yesterday it had agreed to acquire Bostitch, Inc., an East Greenwich, Conn., producer of staplers, staples and container machinery.
WASHINGTON, May 19--In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals today the following proceedings were had:

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 19 --Wilson P. Minor, Packson, Miss., correspondent of the Times-Picayune of New Orleans, was named today the 1966 winner of the Louis M. Lyons Award for conscience and integrity in journalistm. He was cited for "sharply perceptive investigative reporting of political and racial affairs."
Stand-by credits of $36.4million are being extended to Ghana by the International Monetary Fund to help the West African nation meet the heavy debts left by the deposed regime of Kwame Nkrumah.

CHICAGO, May 19--Formal action by the Maritime Administration continuing foreign trade routes linking the Great Lakes with Europe, Africa, South America and the Far East was announced here today by Nicholas Johnson, Maritime Administrator.
SAIGON, May 20 (Friday) (AP)--Two South Vietnamese outposts near the border of North Vietnam came under strong enemy attack yesterday.
A city pest-control operator was accused by the police yesterday of having fired a shotgun at four teen-age boys who he said were vandalizing his parked car on the street outside his apartment.
WASHINGTON, May 19-- The Secretary of the Treasury, Henry H. Fowler, suggested some temporary restrictions today on the interest rates banks pay on certain types of small savings deposits.

NEW HYDE PARK, L. I., May 19--Clinton G. Martin, administrator of the Nassau County Board of Elections and former supervisor of North Hempstead, died at his home here today, apparently of a heart attack. He was 54 years...
Senator Jacob K. Javits said last night that if the South Vietnamese could not establish a "stable government" the United States might have no alternative but to withdraw its forces.
NOGALES, Mexico, May 17 --Mexican-American friendship in this border town of 40,000 people has been undergoing severe strain recently because some Mexicans are not making the money they used to.
WASHINGTON, May 19-- Saigon's PX Alley is on the way out, at least as a black market for goods stolen from army post exchanges, Defense Department officials said today.
HOUSTON, May 19--Surgeons operated here today for the third time in as many days on a 61-year-old man whose first operation involved the attachment of an experimental heart pump.

WASHINGTON, May 19-- Two experts on the North Atlantic Treaty took issue today with proposals for United States troop reductions in Europe made recently by the Senate majority leader, Mike Mansfield of Montana.

LONDON, May 19--Britain's senior tax agents are refusing to collect the new capital gains tax unless the Government gives them a bonus of 100 for wrestling with the 7,000 paragraphs of regulations on the tax.
The La Scala Opera of Milan will make its first appearances in North America as part of an arts festival to be held in Montreal during the 1967 World Exposition.
WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) --Judge DeWitt S. Hyde asked today whether charges of contempt of court or obstruction of justice should be filed against Senator Stephen M. Young, Democrat of Ohio.

NEWARK, May 19--The American Civil Liberties Union of New Jersey accused overzealous civil rights groups and their friends in the Legislature today of "undermining a number of constitutional rights in their attempts to promote civil rights."
CLEVELAND, May 19 (UPI) --Mike McCormick held Cleveland to four hits tonight and slammed a home run to pace the Washington Senators to a 7-2 triumph over the Indians.

MONTREAL, May 19 (AP)-- Alex Delvecchio, the Detroit Red Wings' captain and a 15year man with the club, has won the Lady Byng Trophy for the second time in his career, the National Hockey League said today.
CHADDS FORD, Pa., May 19 --Andrew Wyeth, the painter, and other residents here 1ast night won their fight to prevent the building of a factory near the Brandywine Battlefield Park.

Special to The New York Times FREEPORT, L. I., May 19-- "We have lost a great opportunity," a resident here said tonight. "While Freeport had its head in the sand, Mayor Lindsay got the grant for New York City. It's a shame. But if I were the Mayor of New York City, I would have done the same thing."
A young woman receptionist who fired a tear-gas pen at a man she said was anoying her in an East Side restaurant was arrested and charged with three violations yesterday.
A group of faculty members at the City College of New York firmly opposed yesterday the use of class standings as a criterion for granting student draft deferments.
MIAMI, May 19--Cuba and the Soviet Union signed yesterday an agreement to improve the island's meteorological serv ice and hurricane detection system.
Bearish news about auto sales blunted a sharp advance on the American Stock Exchange in the last half-hour of trading yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (UPI)--James E. Webb, head of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, told Congress today that the United States was lagging two years behind the Soviet Union in "certain important aspects of space power."

FOX POINT, Wis., May 19-- Pierce Rosenberg, the president of the Grand Division of Best Co., Inc., which operates 24 women's and children's apparel stores, died of a heart attack today at his home here. He was 57 years old.
Plans for the city's first direct election of the poor to control an area's antipoverty program were announced yesterday on the Lower East Side.
Mrs. John V. Lindsay believes that the corridors of the Municipal Building and other "grim" city structures could be made a lot more attractive by decorating them with children's art work.

A four-alarm fire that sent thick smoke and flames more than 60 feet high swept through six stores and a pool parlor in a two-story brick building on the southwest corner of Broadway and 96th Street last night.

A hearing examiner for the Civil Aeronautics Board completed taking testimony yesterday in the appeal of Capt. William L. Guthrie, an Eastern Airlines pilot, against a 60-day suspension of his pilot's certificate.

Merck, Sharp Dohme, International, a division of Merck Co., pharmaceutical manufacturer, has signed a 25-year lease for 12 of the 16 floors of the office building under construction at 110 Church Street at Park Place.

Eddy Arnold, one of the most durable singing stars in pop and country music, headed a show of singers from Nashville at Carnegie Hall last night. The program will be offered again tonight at the Brooklyn Academy, and Sunday at the Island Garden in West Hempstead, L. I.

AUSTIN, Tex., May 19--After eight months of slowly increasing Texas oil production, the Texas Railroad Commission cut back today the market-demand allowable factor from the 35 per cent of ability to produce, now in effect, to 34.5 per cent for the month of June.
Another case of auto nerves sent stock prices tumbling in the final 30 minutes of trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

SAIGON, May 19--A leading Buddist monk proposed today that Tran Van Don, a leading figure in the coup d'etat that overthrew President Ngo Dinh Diem in 1963, be chosen as the interim successor to Premier Nguyen Cao Ky.
COLUMBIA, S.C., May 18 "Dignity!" snorted the candidate, throwing his chest out and his head far back in exaggerated imitation of his opponent's posture.

HOUSTON, May 20 Capt. J.W. Clark, president of Delta Lines, who is chairman of the Committee of American Steamship Lines, said here today that Nicholas Johnson, "whether wittingly or unwittingly," was making too many public statements that tended "to discredit the American merchant marine."
"Some progress" was reported yesterday in working out a compromise tax package for the city, though the negotiations were described by one of the participants as "long, arduous and difficult."

WASHINGTON, May 20 The index of primary market prices declined one-tenth of 1 per cent to 105.3 of its 1957-59 base during the week ended May 17 the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Prices of farm products declined, while prices of processed foods and industrial commodities averaged unchanged.

An international film production contest open to all students in colleges, universities or film schools has been announced by The World Law Fund, a nonprofit, educational organization established in 1961 by the Institute for International Order.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 20 President Hector Garcia Godoy said last night that all Haitians crossing the border would be sent back to Haiti. He said an army round-up and deportation of Haitians living on the Dominican side of the border was routine.
A man who contends that he was made a female by an operation lost a suit in State Supreme Court yesterday to compel the city to change the sex listing on his birth certificate.
An air pollution control bill described by its supporters as the toughest of its kind in the country was signed into law yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.
City College's faculty received a grade of B-plus yesterday from its students.
Widespread speculation on the ramifications of a KorvetteSpartans Industries merger stirred financial circles yesterday.
DANANG, South Vietnam, Saturday, May 21 Heavy fighting broke out again in Danang this morning and four mortar shells were reported to have fallen on the huge American air base here.
GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, May 20 For the big celebration next Thursday, Prime Minister Forbes Burnham has a lace-trimmed dress shirt in the national colors red, green, yellow, black and white.
LONDON, May 20 (Reuters) Britain's biggest newspaper group, the International Publishing Corporation is starting a training ground.
The money market continued tight yesterday as Federal funds traded at 5 per cent and bankers' acceptances rates were raised.

WASHINGTON, May 20 An eclipse of the sun cast a momentary shadow over the Nimbus 2 today and it was five minutes before nervous scientists realized why the weather satellite thought day had turned into night.

The election of Emma McCain as president of the Savings Bank Women of New York has been announced. Miss McCain is administrative assistant for personnel at the East River Savings Bank. The association consists of nearly 600 female officers and employes of savings banks in the New York area.
"One of these days," said Al Downing of the Yankees before pitching against the Minnesota Twins last night, "it will all come together."
BARCELONA, Spain, May 20 (AP) Clark Graebner of Beachwood, Ohio, upset Roy Emerson of Australia, 6-1, 3-6, 4-6, 6-2, 9-7, today and gained a semi-final berth in an international tennis tournament.
CHICAGO, May 20 About 75 demonstrators resumed a sit-in today at Roosevelt University, where 25 persons were arrested last night during an antidraft protest.

MONTHEY, Switzerland, May 20 Charges that dollar imperialism played a leading role in the collapse of the first Swiss oil-refining venture resounded today at a stockhold- ers' meeting in one of the two movie theaters of this small village in the upper Rhone Valley, near Lake Geneva.
The State Supreme Court began deliberating yesterday on the legality of the city administration's plan to establish a civilian-controlled board to examine complaints against policemen.

CHICAGO, May 20--Raymond M. Hilliard, Cook County Public Aid Director, contended today that a nine-day strike by about 1,000 public aid employes was collapsing. He urged all remaining absentees to return to work.
Robert H. Rapp was sworn in yesterday as chief of the Transit Authority's police force. He succeeded Thomas J. O'Rourke, who had retired.
DETROIT, May 20 (UPI) Car production inched up this week to 194,266 units, Ward's Automotive Reports said today, but still was down 9.3 per cent from the week last year.
The Appellate Division ruled yesterday that the city was liable in the wounding of a Carine Corps honor guard shot in the head by a policeman who was chasing an armed robber.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 20 "A Sunday Afternoon in Old Stamford Towne," a house tour to benefit the Stamford Historical Society, will be held Sunday from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. The tour will include seven 18th and 19th century homes never before opened to the public.

The Legislature has sent to Governor Rockefeller a bill designed to make all directors, officers and major stockholders of a corporation owning a certified "public nuisance" building responsible for penalties and repairs. This is the so-called "WMCA Bill," for which that radio station and its president, R. Peter Straus, have campaigned so vigorously.

Supreme Court Justice Arthur G. Klein, Democratic-Republican designee for Manhattan Surrogate, declared yesterday that if he was elected he would publish the names of all lawyers he appointed to handle cases and the fees they received.

Fog followed rain into the New York metropolitan area Thursday night and closed La Guardia Airport for 14 hours, from 8:30 P.M. to 10:30 yesterday morning. A few planes departed during the period, but inbound flights had to be diverted to Kennedy International and Newark Airports.

SAIGON, Saturday, May 21 (AP) Thousands of Buddhist monks and nuns and their followers jammed the main Bud dhist institute here today to begin a sitdown hunger strike that could bring more street violence. There were rumors that student demonstrators joining the throng would seek to march on Premier Nguyen Cao Ky's office and the United States Embassy.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., May 20 Washington and Lee High School of Arlington, Va., won its qualifying heats for senior eights and fours with coxswain today in the 32d annual championship of the Schoolboy Rowing Association of America.
Joseph L. Wood was appointed yesterday as president of the Penn-Olin Chemical Company, a jointly owned subsidiary of the Pennsalt Chemicals Corporation and the Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (UPI) The Senate Republican leader, Everett McKinley Dirksen, gave his support in absentia today to the fight against enlargement of the Senate's watchdog committee on the Central Intelligence Agency.

A major foreign policy speech by Secretary of State Dean Rusk Tuesday at 10 P.M. will be seen live in 11 East Coast cities on National Education Television. The hour telecast will be seen here on Channel 13.

BALTIMORE, May 20 (AP) Dick McAuliffe and Bill Freehan knocked in three runs each as the Detroit Tigers whipped Baltimore, 9-5, in the second game and gained a split of tonight's double-header, The Orioles won the opener, 8-4, behind a 13-hit attack.
Eastern Airlines, New Haven and its Chamber of Commerce yesterday notified the Civil Aeronautics Board that they had agreed to cooperate in a 19-month study of the city's air-traffic potential.

MILL NECK, L.I., May 20 The home of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Denison Babcock on Horse Shoe Road was the setting this evening for the wedding of their daughter, Miss Katherine Roe Babcock, to Dr. Charles Michael Yates of London. He is a son of Mrs. G. Charles H. Yates, also of London, and the late Mr. Yates.
A $32.7-million interchange between the Long Island Expressway and the BrooklynQueens Expressway was approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate.

WASHINGTON, May 20 The United States substantially increased today its estimate of the size of the third Chinese nuclear test, providing further evidence that Communist China had achieved some form of thermonuclear reaction.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (UPI) New unemployment insurance claims were lower last week than at any time since mid-October, 1952, the Labor DDepartment reported today.

LONG BEACH, Calif., May 20 Walter P. Reuther today strongly supported organized labor's political alliance with the Democrats and dismissed as unwise the idea that labor should chart its own political course.

Federal Judge Thomas F. Croake yesterday set June 22 for sentencing Warden Henry J. McFarland of the Hudson County Jail, who was found guilty on two counts of perjury by a Federal jury just after midnight.
WASHINGTON, May 20 The Consumer Price Index rose substantially again in April, the Labor Department reported today. The index was pushed up this time by services, rather than food.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) Members of the American Law Institute agreed today that the collection of damages for libelous published statements should be made more difficult when the statement is published without knowledge of related harmful facts.

VIENNA, May 20 The Soviet delegation to an international conference on radioactive waste disposal withdrew a paper today that had urged a complete ban on discharging such wastes into the waters of the world.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., May 20. The Apawamis Country Club team of Rye, representing Westchester, defeated Somerest Hills of New Jersey and Piping Rock of Long Island at Sunningdale Country Club today to win the interclub intersectional championship of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association.

"Concerts at the Shea," a series of five weekend programs featuring rock 'n' roll, jazz and television artists, will be presented this summer at Shea Stadium. Harry Bloomfield, Broadway producer, will sponsor the venture.
CAIRO, May 20 The already troubled relations between the United States and the United Arab Republic were further complicated today by the announcement of a new American arms deal with Israel.
In the melting-pot city of Prague, a young lawyer named Franz Kafka sat down in the summer of 1914 to write a novel about a man harassed by established authority.
Some behind-the-scenes maneuvering by Mayor Lindsay has apparently produced crucially needed support for his neighborhood city halls among the five borough presidents.

A track rated sloppy for yesterday's opening race, muddy for the second event and good for the contests that preceded the feature is expected to be fast this afternoon for the 27th running of the Top Flight Handicap at Aqueduct.
Prices on the London stock market advanced moderately yesterday on hopes for an early settlement of the British seamen's strike.

The new Pastoral Care and Human Relations Institute of the New York Board of Rabbis will conduct a pilot program in community mental health education this summer for theological students of all faiths.
The World Journal Tribune, Inc., reached basic agreement yesterday with three more unions the stereotypers, electricians and machinists in the 26-day-old newspaper strike.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, May 20 President Chiang Kai-shek likened himself today to the undiscouraged old soldier who is "indifferent to name and position and oblivious to fame and slander."

LONDON, May 20 Cockney pay packets were thinned by sentiment today as the odds dropped on Cassius Clay's expected victory tomorrow night over Henry Cooper. The scheduled 15-round heavyweight championship bout, Britain's first in 58 years, will be seen live on American home television screens.

CHICAGO, May 20 (AP) Morton Bodfish, a founder of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board in the Herbert Hoover Administration, died yesterday in Wickenburg, Ariz., where he and his second wife had lived since his retirement two years ago. He was 64 years old.

WASHINGTON, May 20 Representative Wiliam F. Ryan said today that Chief Justice Earl Warren had assured him he had not intended in a controversial speech on Wednesday to condemn any pending bil or group of bills on jury selection.

The annual shareholder meeting of the Glen Alden Corporation, held at the Park Sheraton Hotel here yesterday, produced a number of questions from shareowners, a few words of praise for management and some sharp accusations-but little firm news.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 20 It was like old times tonight as the New York Mets opened a nine-game swing through the West. Casey Stengel watched from behind the dugout, the Mets made three errors in one inning, the San Francisco Giants hit three home runsand the Mets still won the game, 7-5.
The spot rate on the British pound eased yesterday in moderate trading on foreign-exchange markets here.
Health Department physicians announced yesterday that they would perform only emergency services if public health nurses resigned on Monday, as they have threatened.

Unless there's an early knockout, Cassius Clay and Henry Cooper may be fighting in London at the same time today that Maryland's big horse race, the Preakness, is being run in Baltimore. If so, there'll be much TV dialturning, for both events will be on television networks.

MOSCOW, May 20 The Soviet Government has intervened to veto the visit of a United States oceanography research ship after an invitation from the Soviet Academy of Sciences, American officials said today.
COLUMBIA, S.C., May 20 The South Carolina General Assembly approved legislation today that would permit women to serve on juries and set literacy requirements for all jurors.
The Max Roach Quintet and Abbey Lincoln, the singer, performed their "Freedom Now Suite" last night as part of a jazz concert at Town Hall to bzenefit the United Community Centers, Inc.
WASHINGTON, May 20 A method of teaching by radio, which is to begin next month in Philadelphia, enables the student to answer questions and find out...

LONDON, May 20 (Reuters) Viscount Amory, governor of the Hudson's Bay Company, reported at the annual meeting today that sales in the first quarter of 1966 were running ahead of the 1965 period, Fur auction sales in the period were strong, he said, although in the last month there has been some softening in demand and a slight decline in prices.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 20 The Special Committee on Ending Colonialism left today for a five-week, five-country investigation in Africa, despite British protests that it will serve no useful purpose.
MEXICO CITY, May 20 (AP) Carlos Arruza, a popular Mexican matador in bullrings here and in Spain for many years, was killed in an automobile accident today. He was 44 years old.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 20 Larchmont Yacht Club's annual overnight race for cruising sailing yachts began off the Larchmont breakwater shortly before sunset this evening with a record fleet in the 12-year history of the event.
K.S. (Bud) Adams, the president of the Houston Oilers of the American Football League, said yesterday an all-out signing war between the American and National Football Leagues was a possibility.
Benny Goodman is back at his old trade of paying for dancers.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 20 (AP) E.W. (Billy) Ingram, the man who parlayed a 5-cent hamburger into a $36-million chain, died today in Columbus Hospital after a short illness. He was 85 years old.

GROSSE POINTE FARMS, Mich., May 20 Mr. and Mrs. J. Otis Wardwell have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Suzanne Taylor Wardwell of New York to Ralph Patterson Moore Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Moore of Old Greenwich, Conn.
The 17th annual observance of Armed Forces Day will be marked throughout the country today with parades and open house at military installations.

DENVILLE, N.J., May 20 Milton (Babe) Lichardus won the $25,000 Dodge open golf tournament at the Rockaway River Country Club today with a birdie 3 on the second extra hole of a playoff with Ron Howell.

Charles Maxwell Bayer, a well-known New York newspaper reporter and a former Borden Company publicity representative who helped to make "Elsie the Cow" an advertising personality, died of a heart attack yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at 40 West 55th Street.

One need not be an unquestioning admirer of Secretary of Defense McNamara or agree with all his judgments to be disturbed by the implications of the attack on him in the recent report of the House Armed Services Committee, which strikes at the entire concept of systematic, rational allocation of resources.
The Civil Aeronautics Board approved yesterday an airlines agreement to charge $2.50 for movies on all International flights. The charge will go into effect Tuesday.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., May 20 Winding up his second campaign for Governor, Miami Mayor Robert King High said Florida voters next Tuesday would disavow Gov. Haydon Burns "and his spoils system."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 20 A plea for restraint by J.G. de Beus of the Netherlands today led the Security Council to postpone further consideration of the draft resolution on Rhodesia presented by the African members.

BEDFORD HILLS, N.Y., May 20 Mrs. Jean Campbell Rabsey, wife of Carl Rabsey, an advertising man associated with Cantor Publications, Inc., New York trade paper publishers, was killed yesterday morning while driving to work on the Saw Mill River Parkway.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 20 Mr. and Mrs. Frank M. Smith Jr.'s 2 -year-old black standard poodle, Ch. Prince Philip of Belle Glenn from Scarsdale, N.Y., gained the best-of-breed award today at the 34th Poodle Club of America specialty.

Amid all the political uncertainties facing Mayor Lindsay's tax program in Albany, one certainty may be discerned: If compromise must be accepted to secure passage, it will surely reduce revenue yield revenue that is badly needed. That prospect directs urgent attention to the intolerable loss the city is suffering from the 15-cent fare.

Harlem antipoverty groups have voted not to accept "one dime" of the $1,960,000 allocated by the city and Federal Government for the area's summer program unless they get the $5,838,082 they originally asked for.
'Birth defects often mar parents' hopes for a happy, healthy life for their children.

THE Eastern Regional Championships continue this afternoon at the New York Hilton Hotel, where the Master Pair Championship will be played in two sessions at 2 P.M. and 8 P.M. Contestants are divided into three flights according to their master-point holdings: Flight A, 200 or more; Flight B, 50-199; Flight C, 0-49.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) Gen. Generoso Campos Marquetti, one of the last surviving generals of Cuba's war of independence, part of the SpanishAmerican War, died of a heart ailment and cancer in the George Washington University Hospital late yesterday. He was 94 years old.
GALVESTON, Texas, May 20 An indifferent public and an "inattentive" government menace the future of the merchant marine, a leading maritime official declared here yesterday.
"Everybody wants to build a cultural center," R. Philip Hanes Jr. observed.

DETROIT, May 29 James M. Roche, president of the General Motors Corporation, told the annual meeting today that adverse publicity stemming from litigation involving the Corvair had hurt that car's sales.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 20 Foreign Minister Adam Malik said today that President Sukarno had forbidden him to go abroad. The Presidential order was apparently intended to prevent him from holding talks with Malaysian officials.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (UPI) Vice President Hubert Humphrey today proposed a national sports festival to help develop the country's best amateur athletes.
LOS ANGELES, May 20, (UPI) The Pittsburgh Pirates batted around for five runs in the first inning off Don Sutton tonight and then coasted to a 7-3 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

LONDON, May 20 Officials of Britain and rebel Rhodesia suspended today the talks held here over the last two weeks in an effort to find some way out of the crisis raised by the Rhodesians' unilateral declaration of independence.

WASHINGTON, May 20 Increasingly discouraging reports from South Vietnam were placed before President Johnson and his principal advisers at a White House meet- ing this evening. The Western alliance was the announced subject of the meeting, but officials indicated that the deterioration in Vietnam had concerned them for part of the time.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 20 (UPI) The police investigated today an unsuccessful attempt on the life of a presidential candidate, Joaquin Balaguer, in which one person was killed and four others were wounded.

RABAT, Morocco, May 20--A reliable source said today that Morocco was calling for an urgent meeting of the Organization of African Unity's commission dealing with the Algerian-Moroccan frontier dispute. The action follows reports that Algerian troops had entered a border no man's land.
ALBANY, May 20 Governor Rockefeller will go on statewide television Sunday to try to calm the furor over the state's controversial new medical aid program.

Adamant Republican opposition to offers by the Democratic and Liberal parties for nonpartisan nomination of a slate of fifteen delegates at large to the state constitutional convention next year appears to insure a straight party fight between slates distinguished only by their party labels. This may have the lamentable effect of excluding from the convention some citizens best qualified to make useful contributions from their experience and public service.
The Bible won a publishing, award yesterday. Doubleday Co. received the Carey-Thomas Award for "creative publishing" for the Anchor Bible, its 38-volume, scholarly, interfaith project.
The Civil Aeronautics Board has predicted that passenger traffic of scheduled domestic trunk airlines will increase 20 per cent to 59 billion revenue passenger miles this year compared with 1965.
HYDERABAD, India, May 20--Michigan State University, which provided "cover" for Central Intelligence Agency operations in Vietnam, is beginning to reap a harvest of distrust here.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) An advisory panel of automotive safety experts was named today to help the General Services Administration tighten safety standards for motor vehicles purchased by the Federal Government.

DANANG, South Vietnam, Saturday, May 21--Government marines today took over one of the pagodas used as a refuge by dissidents here after four hours of bitter fighting in which two Buddhist monks were killed.
The 17th game of the world championship chess match between Tigran Petrosian, the champion, and Boris Spaasky, both of the Soviet Union, ended in a draw last night at Moscow's Variety Theatre.

AN artist's publicity is rarely a reliable guide to the value of his work. Indeed, under certain circumstances, such publicity may even displace the artist's actual accomplishment as the object of interest.
Edward Rice, a retired investment banker and a former partner in August Belmont Co., died yesterday at his home, 8053 Harbor View Terrace, Brooklyn. He was 77 years old.

Paul A. Danielson, for 20 years executive director of the Grand Central Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association, died in St. Agnes Hospital in White Plains Thursday night of a heart ailment. He was 77 years old and lived at 27 Plymouth Road in White Plains.

The panic in many upstate communities over the impact of the new state law for medical aid to the medically indigent" illustrates the dangers implicit in hurried horsetrading at Albany on important legislative innovations. The law was needed to make New Yorkers eligible for protection under Title XIX of the Social Security Act, a little noted companion to Medicare.
WASHINGTON, May 20 Administration officials were hopeful today that the sale of some attack jet bombers to Israel would at least temporarily halt American involvement in the Middle Eastern arms race.
Customers of New York Stock Exchange member firms owed a record $5,862,000,000 to their brokers at the end of April, the Big Board said yesterday.

L. Judson Morhouse, who was described at his trial as the "Mr. Big of the Republican party," was found guilty yesterday on two felony counts in the bribery of Martin C. Epstein, former chairman of the State Liquor Authority, to obtain a liquor license for the Playboy Club.

WASHINGTON, May 20 The Department of the Interior said today that it had asked Congress to authorize a fiveyear, $172-million development program for the scattered Pacific Ocean islands administered by the United States under a United Nations Trusteeship.

JERUSALEM, Israeli Sector, May 20 The Israeli negotiators who recently obtained a $40-million loan from West Germany have returned home far from conquering heroes. They have had to justify the agreement to many unhappy countrymen.

YONKERS, May 20 Cardigan Bay, a gelding who was the champion of New Zealand and Australia before Bret Hanover was born, took possession of the world pacing title tonight by beating the 4-year-old Bret by a length in the $65,000 Pace of the Century at Yonkers Raceway.
Representaives of nine civic, school and religious groups expressed oppositon yesterday to a proposed law that would permit public schools to lend textbooks to private and parochial schools.
WASHINGTON, May 20 The Sixth International Phil atelic Exhibition, the major stamp collectors' show in 1966 will open here tomorrow morning at 10 o'clock at the Shoreham Hotel.

AT the end of the first week of the fall dress, coat and suit showings on, Seventh Avenue, the most start- ling fashion news was the prevalence of pants. Plastic pants, Chiffon pants, Knee pants, Long pants.

FORT WORTH, May 20 Bruce Devlin continued subpar golf today after a thunderstorm forced a brief halt in the second round of the $110,000 Colonial Country Club's national invitation golf tourney. Adding a two-under-par 68 to his 67 of yesterday, the slim Australian increased his lead with an aggregate of 135 that was only one stroke above the 36-hole tournament record.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, May 20 (Reuters) Former Premier Moise Tshombe was without a seat in the Congolese Parliament today and blacklisted for high treason by the Government, which he led until his dismissal last October.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy charged yesterday that "red tape" was snarling immigration into the United States and frustrating the spirit of the Immigration Act of 1965.
WASHINGTON, May 20 Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall today urged Congress to authorize a two-year study aimed at establishing a national recreation area in the Connecticut River valley.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 20--Hopes are rising here that South Africa has at last found oil in commercially viable quantities after a massive search.

NORFOLK, Va., May 20 (UPI) The widow of a retired Marine colonel has sued the Central Intelligence Agency for $800,000, alleging that he committed suicide as a result of drugs she said had been given to him during a C.I.A. employment interview.
HOUSTON, Tex., May 20 (AP) The second heart-surgery patient to be equipped with a heart pump here in less than a month died today of what doctors said was uncontrollable chest bleeding.

Dr. George Zuckerman, an assistant superintendent of public schools here from 1947 to 1960, died yesterday of a heart ailment in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 165 West 66th Street.
Thieves broke into the apartment of Lily Harmon, former wife of art collector Joseph H. Hirshhorn earlier this week, and got away with jewels, furs and paintings worth more than $47,000.
The National Maritime Union is threatening "protest" action against seven major shipping operators over a longstanding dispute involving the manning of automated freighters.
In the harbor's haze yesterday morning the red, blue and white of the Cuban flag added a touch of color to be pedestal of the Statue of Liberty. But only briefly.

WASHINGTON, May 20, (UPI) The State department said today that the United States had refused to issue an export license for "high-performance" computers needed by France in its nuclear weapons program.
The Continental Oil Company does not plan to make an offer for the stock of Deutsche Erdol, the West German petroleum company, L.F. McCollum, Continental's chairman, said yesterday.

WARSAW, May 20 (Reuters) Foreign Minister Maurice Couve de Murville of France signed today two five-year pacts with Poland covering the development of cultural, scientific and technical relations. Foreign Minister Adam Papacki signed for Poland.
About 800 shareholders of the Manhattan Fund crowded into an Americana Hotel ballroom yesterday for a first-hand look at Gerald Tsai Jr., president of the fastest-growing mutual fund in history.

The Grand Ballroom on the 19th floor of the Biltmore Hotel was the setting for several things last night, all of them enjoyable. It was the last of this season's Concert Parties, which are usually held in the hotel's ground-floor Bowman room. Because the St. Paul Chamber Orchestra was making its local debut, the larger upstairs room was used.

BACK in 1928 when movie queens were worshiped, Milton Herman, then a 25-year-old lingerie salesman infatuated with Myrna Loy, started a lingerie business in New York. He called it Movie Star, Inc. Thirty-eight years later, neither film queens nor Movie Star, Inc., are the same. The shot of the star lounging provocatively in a negligee seems to have disappeared from moviemaking. And Movie Star, Inc., has an annual business of millions of dollars.
The trustees of the Metropolitan Museum of Art announced yesterday they have appointed a committee to find a successor to James J. Rorimer, the museum's director, who died on May 11.

The John's Bargain Stores Corporation, which sells lowpriced merchandise in nearly 500 stores in 23 states, an nounced yesterday a net loss of $1,550,700 in the 16 weeks ended April 16. This compares with a deficit of $501,538 in the corresponding 1965 quarter.
IN the great days of Pax Britannica the classic solution to any difficulty was to send a gunboat.

The New School for Social Research is negotiating to acquire the long-term lease of the former Lane store at 14th Street and Fifth Avenue. This was confirmed by Dr. John R. Everett, president of the school, and by Meshulam Riklis, chairman of McCrory, which holds the lease on the old Lane's store.

AS befits his role as an American husband, Rob- ert Allen Low is frequently assigned the job of taking out the garbage. Most men merely wedge the sack into the incinerator door, listen for a moment as the glass shatters on the way down, and then forget about it.
BALTIMORE, May 20 Cramming a jockey's head with do's and don't's before a horse race can be hazardous, most trainers agree.
Charles R. Howell, New Jersey Commissioner of Banking and Insurance, said yesterday he was suspending for one year the consideration by the state of applications for new bank charters.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20 The Middle South Utilities System plans to spend a record $207-million on construction this year, Gerald L. Andrus, president, told about 40 stockholders at the annual meeting here today.
REDWOOD CITY, Calif., May 20 An antiwar group was rebuffed today in its attempt to have a napalm manufacturing plant here closed.

VIENNA, May 20 One of the wildest, strangest ballets of our time, made bearable and sometimes exciting by the dancing of Rudolf Nureyev, had its world premiere at the Vienna Opera House on Wednesday night.
ROME, May 20 The car factory that Fiat will build in the Ukraine represents a total investment by the Soviet Union of $887-million with $96-million to be spent outside Italy.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 20 Mr. and Mrs. John-Robert Ferns have announced the engagement of Mrs. Ferns's daughter, Miss Rebecca Lynn Stoess, to David Lynn Williams, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lindsay Williams of Dousman, Wis.
BAYONNE, N.J., May 20 A French Line freighter rammed the Jersey Central Railroad drawbridge over Newark Bay last night, disrupting service for about 13,000 commuters. Fog was blamed for the accident.
ALBANY, May 20 Rarely has social legislation of the scope and cost of the state's new medical care program been enacted amid such confusion or set in motion with so little sense of direction.
WASHINGTON, May 20 President Johnson, declaring that the nation was probably using no more than half its human potential, called tonight for the development of a new national manpower policy.
Directors of Genesco, Inc., authorized yesterday in Nashville, Tenn., a three-for-two split of the common shares to be followed by an increase in the dividend rate.
SHADE GAP, Pa., May 20 (AP) Seated in a wheel chair and clutching a vase of roses, Peggy Ann Bradnick came out of seclusion today for the first time since her rescue Wednesday from a kidnapperkiller.
The State Supreme Court building in Foley Square is suffering from a minor crime wave, and apparently the judges are the only ones above suspicion.
City Narcotics Bureau agents went out Thursday night with a search warrant and the expectation of finding narcotics in an apartment on East 13th Street.

We like to think of ourselves as "permanent residents." But, to our distress, we are more commonly and starkly known as "resident aliens" or "R.A.'s." At the last head-count there were in the United States some 3,366,000 of us.
LONDON, May 20 (UPI) Millions saw a partial solar eclipse today that was visible from Asia to Wales.
United States colleges and universities have shown a strong partiality to the production of American plays on their campuses in the last five years.

CANNES, France, May 20 Another masterpiece of diplomatic juggling that is how one veteran festival-goer who declined to be identified characterized the list of jury awards for the 20th annual Cannes Film Festival that was announced to the press this afternoon.

The stock market turned upward in light trading yesterday, aided by an optimistic, but rather indefinite, statement by top officials of the General Motors Corporation that the future of the automobile industry was bright.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20, (AP) Ralph Ginzburg, the New York publisher convicted of sending obscene matter through the mails, asked the United States District Court here today to vacate, suspend or reduce his five-year prison sentence.

BALTIMORE, May 20 Cold calculation, forthright frankness and personal popularity are among the qualities that will be aligned against each other with the 91st running of the Preakness at Pimlico tomorrow.
NORMAN, Okla., May 20 (AP) Several hundred University of Oklahoma students conducted a "study-in" today to focus public attention on what they consider to be low faculty salaries and long hours.
OTTAWA, May 20 (Canadian Press) Studies of a proposed new set of locks at the Welland Canal that would cost about $250-million were announced today by Transport Minister John W. Pickersgill.

SAIGON, May 20 Despite the renewed political and military turmoil in the country, South Vietnam is going ahead with its rural pacification program. The first class of pacification workers will be graduated tomorrow and will go into the field after having been trained to begin political action designed to counter Communist ideology.

The best American silver of the 19th century will be on view in the American wing of the Metropolitan Museum of Art until June 19 in an exhibition called, "American Craftsmanship in Silver (1815-1905)."

KINGS POINT, L.I., May 20 Mayor Lindsay got a tourist's-eye view of New York City today, winding up a fog-shrouded circumnavigation of Manhattan and a foggy crossing of Long Island Sound with a luncheon here at the United States Merchant Marine Academy.

ONE of television's most mature and thoughtful examinations of homosexuality was presented on Channel 13 on Thursday night. The program, which happened to conflict with Jack Paar's amusing hour of humor and politics, will be repeated at 10:35 P.M. on Monday. It is well worth seeing.

LOS ANGELES, May 20--A coroner's inquest into the fatal shooting of a 25-year-old Negro by a traffic policeman resumed here today with sharply conflicting testimony. More than 200 helmeted policemen stood by to control a crowd of 400 Negroes in the courtroom and corridors of the Los Angeles County Court House.

ST. JAMES, L.I., May 20 Ch. Hillaway's Padrac of Eagle, owned by Sam E. Ewing 3d of Glen Mills, Pa., won first honors today at the 37th annual national specialty show of the Irish Wolfhound Club of America. The event was held on the Shadow Hill estate of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon F. Graham.
United States business was assured yesterday of a warm welcome and generous concessions on investments by the new government in Ghana.
FAIRTON, N.J., May 20 The New Jersey Ku Klux Klan called off its cross-burning rally here tonight in the face of massive police enforcement of a state court order barring the rally.
PINE POINT, Northwest, Territories Pine Point, a clearing in the woods surrounded by wolves, is becoming one of the most glamorous names in Canadian mining.

ALAMOGORDO, N.M., May 20 (AP) A test version of the Surveyor vehicle designed for an unmanned soft landing on the moon made a smooth 900-foot descent in a successful final test today prior to the scheduled May 30 flight to the moon.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 20 (AP) Critics applauded Eugene Ormandy and the Philadelphia Orchestra after two performances here this week.

Sixteen unions representing 30,000 municipal employes said yesterday that they would demonstrate outside City Hall on June 2 to protest Mayor Lindsay's proposal setting up a city Office of Collective Bargaining.

WASHINGTON, May 20 Judge Alexander Holtzoff of the United States District Court here today rearranged the schedule of pretrial interrogation in Senator Thomas J. Dodd's $5-million conspiracy and libel suit against Drew Pearson and Jack Anderson so that Mr. Dodd, a Democrat from Connecticut, could be questioned by the columnists' lawyers in June.

WALLOPS ISLAND, Va., May 20 (AP) An instrument package designed to pick up the whisper of radio signals from the Milky Way was launched today on a 570-mile-high, 20minute ballistic flight ending in the Atlantic Ocean 620 miles downrange.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (UPI) President Johnson today nominated the United States attorney for Massachusetts to the Federal judgeship post once sought by Francis X. Morrissey, a friend of the Kennedy family.
SAIGON, May 20, (AP) United States troops who have killed about a third of an enemy battalion since Monday battled survivors in the Central Highlands today.

HEWLETT, L.I., May 20 George H. (Pete) Bostwick Jr., shooting his best golf in seven years, took a four-stroke lead today after the opening round of the 19th annual William D. Richardson Memorial tournament with a two-under-par 70 at the Seawane Club.
By July the great soybean mystery probably will be solved whether the carry-over will be a modest 40 million bushels as now generally estimated, or an even lower amount than that.

THE literary province that Joao Guimaraes Rosa has marked out for exploitation in "Sagarana" is the backlands of eastern Brazil a land of heavy vegetation in which jaguars, alligators and snakes are not unknown and neither are malarial mosquitoes, ticks and assorted disease-breeding flies.

Chancellor Albert H. Bowker said yesterday that the City University was prepared to open emergency centers in rented quarters to accommodate almost 2,300 qualified freshman applicants who have been denied admission for next fall.
A rally in the last halfhour of trading managed yesterday to push a slim majority of issues on the American Stock Exchange into the plus column. Volume was the lowest in more than a month.

PARTAN BREE, Cullen Skink and Atholl Brose may sound like a wee bit of a Robert Burns poem, but they are actually the names of traditional recipes taken from a new Scottish cookbook. Partan Bree is a rich cream of crab soup, Cullen Skink a finnan haddie soup and Atholl Brose the oatmeal, honey and whisky beverage traditionally served on hogmanay, the Scottish New Year.
WASHINGTON, May 20--President Johnson invoked Job today to point up the need for the further conservation of natural resources.
Long Island's booming industrial pant construction, producing sprawling buildings with prize-winning facades and sweeping landscaped grounds, has frequently overlooked the small manufacturer.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., May 21 Washington and Lee High School of Arlington, Va., regained the eight-oared championship from LaSalle High School of Philadelphia today and carried off top honors in the 32d annual regatta of the Schoolboy Rowing Association of America.

WASHINGTON, May 21 Antonio A. Micocci, staff adviser to the Cuban-refugee program in the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, died of a heart attack last night, while attending his 40th reunion at the University of Pennsylvania. He was 64 years old.
United Air Force jets in Vietnam recently killed two American servicemen and injured 58 others through a bombing accident.

PHILADELPHIA, May 21 (UPI) Three youths were exonerated today in the "horseplay" death of a friend, Richard Teodoro, 20 years old, whose neck was broken when he was tossed into the Schuylkill River.

FOR some 20 years now, Ernest Ansermet has been pouring his youthful spirit and mature wisdom onto LP's for London Records. A new set of five just released brings the conductor's total to 92 disks for London all with the Orchestre de la Suisse Romande, which he founded in 1918.

BY now it has become unwritten law that the film is a director's medium and the theater is a writer's medium; but all unwritten laws ought to be written down once in a while so that they can be examined. Some recent plays make the second part of the proposition worth challenging.

CROSS RIVER, N.Y. A new arboretum is taking shape here, a stone's throw from New York City, and visitors are welcome to come and watch it grow. It is called the Meyer Arboretum, and it occupies 170 acres of woodland and hillside in Westchester County's largest public park, the Ward Pound Ridge Reservation.
CIUDAD JUAREZ, Mexico, May 18 This city and El Paso just across the Rio Grande in Texas are constantly exchanging populations.

A group of tenants, some of whom have lived in their apartments for more than 30 years, are fighting plans of the Cornell University Medical College to tear down 13 tenements it owns on East 70th Street.
SEA ISLAND, Ga., May 21 (UPI) Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, former Ambassador to South Vietnam, said today the United States should not be distressed by the internal strife in that country.
The economy is in for a breather, but one in which the indicators, with some few exceptions, will stay moderately ahead of year-earlier figures.
TAOS, N.M. The oldest town in the United States, one that is still to be discovered by most Americans, is braced for its annual summer influx of tourists.

ROCHESTER, May 21 (AP) The New Jersey Five of Bayonne fired a 2,760 series today and took fifth place in the booster team division of the American Bowling Congress tournament.
The over-the-counter market took it on the chin last week for the third week in a row as prices dropped in moderate trading.
The Cosmopolitan Young Peoples Symphony Orchestra gave the penultimate concert of its 1965-66 season at Philharmonic Hall in Lincoln Center yesterday afternoon.
LONDON This city's newest landmark, the 620foot-high Post Office Tower, which makes Big Ben look like little benjamin, was officially opened to the public last Thursday, Ascension Day.
SANTIAGO, Chile, May 21 President Eduardo Frei Montalva took the temperature of his "Revolution in Liberty" today and provided some tranquilizers for Chile's distraught private business sector.
The aircraft jet engine is scheduled to make its debut in North America in regularly scheduled rail passenger operations next year.

Whenever the teacher shortage hits the headlines, scores of young people looking for teaching positions complain that the shortage is a myth. Yvonne D. Staples, assistant director in charge of academic placement at Columbia ...
LISBON, May 21 Four Angolans were sent to prison today on charges of plotting to overthrow Portuguese rule in Angola, on West Africa. The sentences ranged from 2 to 8 years.

A NEW member has been added to the evergrowing family of adhesive-backed tapes that can be used for repair jobs around the home. Made of heavy aluminum foil that measures about three mils in thickness, this tape can be used for mending all types of metallic surfaces as well as for many other sealing and decorating jobs around the house.

COLOR is the least expensive way to achieve distinction in a land- scape, and home gardeners should explore the design possibilities of the hardy and long-lived bearded iris. Although some varieties are grown in most gardens, there are others available in almost every tint and hue in the color spectrum, from light-hearted pastels to rich sultry blends. A survey of spring iris gardens will suggest which varieties might be planted this summer.

TUCSON, Ariz., May 21 (AP) J. Carlos McCormick, an official in the Government's domestic peace corps, flew here from Washington today to face a 15-count embezzlement indictment.

COLLECTORS of the country's current coinage have been coping with turmoil for two years and may be in for more of the same. They survived the 1964 date-freeze and the elimination of mint marks. THOMASTON, Me. High on a hill in this quiet coastal town lies one of the most handsome tour1st attractions that Maine has to offer. It is Montpelier, the reconstructed home of Maj. Gen. Henry Knox, this country's first Secretary of War. A striking example of painstaking restoration, and the l3th historic memorial to be taken over by the State Parks and Recreation Department, the mansion will be reopened for the summer on May 30.

VIENNA, May 21 It is typical of science that, when new techniques make possible new experiments, the results are perplexing and call for even further experiments. This is in part because some of nature's greatest truths are hidden in the detail; only when sophisticated observations are made do they come to light. Relativity is probably the most dramatic example.
