THE chances are that more people watched Cassius Clay in action last Saturday than witnessed all the other fights he waged throughout his careers. It was not his most impressive performance. He toyed with Henry Cooper in London, much in the fashion of a matador making passes at a floundering bull.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., May 22 George Hans Lynen, former secretary of the Forstmann Woolen Company in Passaic, died here today at Valley Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived at 580 Overlook Drive, Wyckoff.
SHADE GAP, Pa. May 22 (AP) The state police said today that a kidnap victim was forced to accompany her kidnapper Monday night while he burglarized a residence near here.
The need of the United States to increase sales abroad will be given fresh emphasis this week in widespread observation of World-Trade Week.
RIDGEWOOD, N.J., May 22 Joseph R. Boldt, a former vice president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, died yesterday in the Ridgewood Nursing Home on his 86th birthday.
Arnold M. Denby, a broker and market analyst for the New York stockbrokerage firm of Hirsch Co., died yesterday in his home at 204 Norwood Avenue, Deal, N.J. He was 58 years old.
HEWLETT, L.I., May 22 Dick Siderowf had been driving well and putting poorly as he approached the 13th green. He had just missed putts of 4, 3 and 1 feet.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 22 Miss Ilse Fischer, the 22-year-old daughter of Abram Fischer, a lawyer who was jailed for life this month, has been put on South Africa's "red list" of named Communists. So too has her fiance, John Sholto Cross, a journalist.

MILLBURN, N.J., May 22 Aaron Dorsky, a retired partner of the New York commercial printing concern of R. Ralsen-Grocraft-Andor's Press, died Saturday in his home. He was 56 years old and lived at 11 River Lane.
Most of the nation's once preeminent merchant fleet consists of obsolete "rust buckets," yet its role in the country's defense is vital beyond question.
Mrs. Helen Cohen Rednor, wife of Dr. Daniel Rednor, a physician, died yesterday in her home at 880 Fifth Avenue. She was 57 years old.
WASHINGTON, May 22 President Johnson had decided not to expand the list of bombing targets in North Vietnam, a high official reported today.

MOSCOW, May 22 The Soviet film industry has scored a rare comedy success with a movie about a car thief who is a hero, police detective who is not too bright and an assortment of off-beat characters including swindlers, speculators, bribe-takers and members of the country's fun-loving, jassloving jet set.
ROME, May 22 (AP) A strike by ground personnel today halted many flights of the state-operated Alitalia Airline.
Municipal bond offerings will predominate in the debt market this week as taxexempt volume picks up. Only one large corporate sale is scheduled.
LOS ANGELES, May 22 (AP) Bob Veale pitched a five-hitter today and gained his fifth victory in seven decisions as the Pittsburgh Pirates defeated the Los Angeles Dodgers, 4-0.

The automobile has brought back the bicycle in Europe. For a time it seemed that Europe's headlong rush into the auto age would soon put the old twowheeler in the museum. But the bicycle, even more than some of its motorized relatives--the mopeds, scooters and motorcycles--is gaining new popularity.

ALGIERS, May 22 The official Algerian news agency reported tonight that "serious difficulties" have arisen within Ascop, the joint French-Algerian cooperative association for oil exploitation in the Sahara.

Fourteen miles south of Jerusalem on a Judean hilltop, an imposing memorial to president Kennedy is nearing completion. On July 4, America's Independence Day, the monument will be dedicated by members of the Kennedy family and Chief Justice Earl Warren. Premier Levi Eshkol and President Zalman Shazar of Israel will also participate in the ceremonies.

LONDON, May, 22 Brighteyed and relaxed, with laughter tugging at the corners of his full mouth, Cassius Clay today called Henry Cooper a "real sportsman," thanked the people of Britain for "the royal treatment" and admitted that the "sight of blood really scares me."
ROME, May 22 An Egyptian couple, Youssef Bebawi and his former wife, Claire, were released from prison today following their acquital on charges of having murdered an Egyptian who was her lover.

EDWARD SCHUYLER JACKSON of New York, a former national amateur champion, is an aggressive, imaginative player. He prefers to try for a winning attack by early psychological confrontation rather than by a build-up of small, cumulative positional subtleties.
Thomas J.V. Cullen Sr., Orange County Democratic chairman from 1935 to 1953, died yesterday at the George Washington University Hospital in Washington. He was 73 years old and lived at Chester, N.Y.
Two governmental agencies have joined in the publication of a book to help American businessmen become better exporters.
LISBON, Portugal, May 19 (Reuters)--Portugal is exploiting her position at a major maritime crossroad by building a shipyard to handle 300,000-ton tankers at the mouth of the Tagus River.

A new kind of speculation may begin soon on Wall Street. By the end of this summer, according to some observers in the financial district, both the New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange may be searching for new presidents.
James H. Meredith said yesterday he planned to walk from Memphis to Jackson, Miss., next month in an effort to break "the overriding fear" that Negroes still have of registering to vote.
Raymond V. Winquist has been elected chairman of the board of directors of the General Steamship Corporation, the company announced yesterday.

PAOLI, Pa., May 22 Miss Rosmari Ann Malloy and John Philip Case plan to be married on Aug. 28 at the home of Mr. and Mrs. W. Wilkinson Malloy, parents of the bride-to-be, who have announced the engagement. Mr. Case is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Everett Case of Van Hornesville, N.Y., and New York.
BALTIMORE, May 21 (AP) Don Wert drove in two runs with squeeze bunts today as Detroit beat Baltimore, 3-2.

"This is really a quiet game," said Christy Ring, Ireland's Babe Ruth of hurling, yesterday after leading a County Limerick team made up mostly of Americans to a 21-19 triumph over Galway at Gaelic Park in the Bronx.

NEWINGTON, Conn., May 22 Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Paullin have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Karen Colleen Paullin, to Philip Sinclair Will. Mr. Will is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Will Jr. of Evanston, Ill.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 22 A bookmaking operation that reportedly did a $10-million-ayear business was broken up in Manhattan and New Rochelle today by Nassau County, WestChester and New York City police officials.
Miss Linda Halpern, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Hale Halpern of 1095 Park Avenue, was married yesterday to Freeman Arthur Shore, son of Mr. and Mrs. Josselyn M. Shore of Kings Point, L.I.
Restaurant Waldorf Associates, Inc., has added a new item to its already diversified menu a division specializing in sports marketing.

MOSCOW, May 22 Soviet officials are hopeful that the Government's plan to introduce a guaranteed monthly wage for collective farmers will help to stem a worrisome flight of young people from the land.

Bill Cosby, a co-host for television's Emmy award ceremonies last night, encountered a special pleasure. He was forced to take time out to accept an award for "outstanding continued performance by an actor in a leading role in a dramatic series."
Both sides in the taxi dispute asked Mayor Lindsay yesterday to decide the length of their proposed contract and the vacations to be given to drivers of fleet-owned cabs.
The inland waterways department of the Humble Oil Refining Company has reported the recent completion of the largest shipside bunkering assignment the company ever conducted in or near New Orleans.
In the five months he has been Mayor, John V. Lindsay has discovered an unsuspected dimension to his new job.
National Maritime Day will be observed in ports throughout the nation today with ceremonies, speeches and parades.

PERRY MASON, an institution in broadcasting since 1943, began last night the lucrative process of fading away. The last new story starring Raymond Burr as the world's most celebrated defense attorney was presented on the television network of the Columbia Broadcasting System. It was the 275th show in nine years.

President Johnson has taken the only possible line toward the political civil war in South Vietnam. In his weekend news conference he called on the rival factions to settle their differences at the polls and not in the streets. So long as there is hope of a peaceful settlement, that must be sought.
Ernest Castaldo, a personable, good-looking baritone who gave recitals at Steinway and Judson Halls last year, appeared at Carnegie Recital Hall on Saturday night.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 22 Miss Phoebe Kazdin became the bride of Dr. Haward Joel Schnitzer here this afternoon in the Beth-El Synagogue Center. Rabbi David I. Golovensky performed the ceremony.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) Dr. James L. Goddard, director of the Food and Drug Administration, said today that his agency planned to intensify its efforts to curb the use of LSD, a hallucination-producing drug.

BOSTON, May 22 (AP) The Boston Red Sox, held to one hit by Ralph Terry of the Athletics for six innings today, erupted for three runs with two out in the seventh and defeated Kansas City, 5-1, for their fifth straight victory.

NEW ORLEANS, May 22 (AP) Benjamin Smith of New Orleans, an attorney for a young draftee, facing courtmartial for refusing to kill in Vietnam, said today that the Pentagon had postponed the trial indefinitely.
SNEDEN'S LANDING, N.Y. Here where the Palisades begin, 14 miles north of the George Washington Bridge, a Mohican legend still hovers over this covert, wooded and rarefied community.
Labor leaders, as well as leaders in business and industry, finance and gov ernment, have supported the Greater New York Fund without reservation since its its founding in 1938.

Manager Ralph Houk insists he is not using mirrors, magic wands or potions of any kind on his Yankees, but he has to concede there is little resemblance between the Yanks of a month ago and the team that took two games from the Minnesota Twins yesterday and swept a four-game series.

BALTIMORE, May 22 (UPI) The Congress of Racial Equality announced today that six members of Baltimore's Downtown Apartment House Association, including the owner of the luxury high-rise apartment building Horizon House, had conditionally agreed to a policy of open occupancy.

PARIS There is probably no city on the continent of Europe with a wider array of restaurants than Paris. There are snack bars, food emporiums called drugstores, Russian restaurants, Chinese restaurants, Vietnamese restaurants, couscous places and the usual run of bistros and grand luxe establishments.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., May 22 Tom Allegretti's Amigo took Rhodes-19 honors as a fleet of 37 boats sailed in the Cow Bay area championships of the Long Island Sound Yacht Racing Association today on Manhasset Bay.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) Rick Reichardt and Jim Fregosi combined to throw out Jim King at the plate in the ninth inning, preserving California's 2-1 victory over Washington today and giving the Angels a split of a double-header. The Senators won the opener, 6-2.
WARWICK, N.Y., May 22 John Charles Straton, a lawyer, died today in St. Anthony's Hospital. His age was 59.

A total of 252 ships that have carried cargo to Cuba since Jan. 1, 1963, have been listed by the Department of Commerce. The listed vessels are ineligible to carry United States Government-financed cargoes from the United States.
NAIROBI, Kenya, May 22 Oginga Odinga was accused today of having introduced "reckless thuggery" into the election campaign in Kenya and of an attempt to split the country on tribal lines.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 22 The New York Mets and San Francisco Giants split a doubleheader before 40,496 today on superb pitching performances by Juan Marichal and Jack Hamilton.
DALLAS, May 22 (AP) A sanity trial for Jack Ruby, convicted slayer of Lee Harvey Oswald, has been scheduled for Monday, June 13, in this city.

The appointment of James C. Murphy as executive vice president in the new New York headquarters of Chandris Lines has been announced here by Antony J. Chandris, president and board chairman of the Greek-flag steamship concern.
TUCSON, Ariz., May 22 (AP)--Dr. Ursus Victor Portmann, a radiologist, died yesterday at the age of 79.
GREENWICH, Conn., May 22 The opening regatta of the Yacht Racing Association season for fleets based east of Rye in the Connecticut area was completed on Long Island Sound today.

The agonized course of the city's salary negotiations with its hospital and public health nurses has underscored the urgency of establishing orderly machinery for resolving disputes between government agencies and their organized employes. Without a legally defined procedure that protects both workers and community, fact-finding can become a complicating element in the search for peace, rather than an instrument for rational resolution.

The recent decision of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare to continue the operation of United States Public Health Service hospitals in Detroit and Savannah, Ga., was hailed here last week by two maritime labor leaders.

STOCKHOLM, May 22 (AP) Dennis Ralston, the United States' No.1 tennis player, won the men's singles title in the Saltsjoebaden tournament today with a 6-4, 9-7, 8-6 victory over John Newcombe of Australia.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., May 22 Ch. Pinefair Password, a 3year-old black cocker spaniel belonging to Mrs. H. Terrell Van Ingen of Greenwich, Conn., became the best-in-show winner today at the 64th event of the Long Island Kennel Club. The choice by James A. Farrell Jr. of Darien, Conn., ended a show with 1,200 dogs on the horseshow grounds of the Piping Rock Club.
SANTA BARBARA, Calif., May 22 (AP)--A lawyer says he will appeal a municipal judge's order that a 21-year-old mother of two be surgically sterilized if released on probation in a marijuana case.

SPARTA, Tenn., May 22 (AP) The police in Marion, Ind., found a man's dismembered body in the basement of his home today after the victim's wife told the White County (Tenn.) sheriff that she and her three children had escaped from the killer.
SAIGON, May 22 American and South Vietnamese soldiers killed 228 Vietcong guerrillas in two widely separated actions yesterday, military spokesmen said tonight.
The leadership of the largest American student organization has given its 1.3 million members a bleak and discouraging account of political unrest and the prospects of the war in South Vietnam.

For the last five years the annual concerts of the Duke Ellington Jazz Society have been consistently rewarding. This year's concert, presented yesterday afternoon at the Barbizon-Plaza Theater by a septet under the direction of Bob Wilber, maintained what is becoming an increasingly demanding standard.
Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, president of City College, said yesterday that the draft system was unfair and should be replaced with a universal service system that would include nonmilitary service.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 22 Paul Hoffmann's 49-foot cutter, Thunderhead, made a runaway of Larchmont Yacht Club's long-distance race for the Edlu Trophy that ended today.

RYE, N.Y., May 22 Scott Alexander of Kingston, N.Y., won the two final Finn Class races today for a near-perfect record in the area quarter-final series of the North American singlehanded sailing championship. The event was held on Long Island Sound off the American Yacht Club.

VICTOR and Jacqui Mitchell, two of New York's leading bridge experts, captured the master pair title at the Eastern regional championships here Saturday. It is rare that a married couple wins an event of such importance. The Flight B winners.

LA JOLLA, Calif., May, 22 (UPI)--Stan Smith of the University of Southern California and Mrs. Billy Jean Moffitt King of Long Beach, Calif., won the men's and women's national hardcourt championships today.

Mrs. Judith Ann Blaumanis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lester Lengfelder of Kenmore, N.Y., was married here yesterday to Adam August Pinsker, son of Mrs. Dewey Pinsker of New York and Weston, Conn., and the late Mr. Pinsker.

Vessel movements into and out of the Port of New York during the first four months of this year exceeded those of the corresponding period in 1965 by 973, the Maritime Association of the Port of New York reported last week.
The case against the Indonesian freighter Johannes Latuharhary by American Hawaiian Ventures, which created something of an international incident, has been settled in favor of the vessel's owners.

A 19-year-old youth accused of stealing an automobile led the police on a wild car and foot chase through West Side streets and backyards, up a fire escape and twice over a nine-foot fence before being seized.

LONDON, May 22 Britain will begin negotiations here tomorrow with the Government of South Arabia to set the stage, politically, military and economically, for Britain's departure from Aden and its adjoining tribal areas by 1968.
LOS ANGELES, May 22 (AP) The Los Angeles Dodgers informed a fan last night that he is going to become a father.
SYRACUSE, May 22 (AP) Allan Levenson of Indianapolis compiled a total of 4,721 points today to win the Northeastern Snipe championship regatta on Onondaga Lake.
The American subsidized steamship industry is developing plans for presentation to the Department of Defense on how it would finance and build merchant vessels for military use.

TOKYO, May 22 A 45-yearold advocate here of world peace and a "paradise on earth" is expounding his views in a two-page advertisement in this issue of The New York Times because he considers it his duty to terminate the war in Vietnam.

The Ford Foundation announced yesterday its first grants for family-planning action programs in the United States. The move, the foundation said, reflects "increasing concern with domestic population problems."

DANANG, South Vietnam, May 22 Leaders of the Buddhist and military opposition to the Ky regime, whose position is rapidly deteriorating, offered today to negotiate peace with Government commanders here if the United States would sponsor and mediate the talks.

Arthur D. Schwarz, a consultant and former vice president of the S.E. Rains Company, manufacturers of handkerchiefs here, died of a stroke yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 44 Edgewood Road, Summit, N.J.

CHICAGO, May 22 (AP) Tie-breaking hits by Rocky Calavito in the first game and Fred Whitfield in the second lifted the Cleveland Indians to 3-2 and 4-1 victories over the Chicago White Sox today before a crowd of 40,058.

LANCASTER, Pa., May 22 Cap and Gown, owned by Mr. and Mrs. Gene Cunningham of Warrenton, Va., took the regular conformation hunter championship in his first start of the season today in the Lancaster spring horse show.
Three Suffolk County shopping centers have been sold by the A.V.R. Construction Corporation of White Plains for $3,475,000. The buyer was Sydney M. Siegel, a real estate investor.

The American Stock Exchange said yesterday that it had amended its listing, application to include the requirement that companies disclose "the existence of material conflicts of interest between companies and their officers, directors or substantial stockholders."

PARIS, May 22--The end may be approaching for one of the most endearing aspects of the daily scene in France--the long, bare, golden loaf of bread tucked under the arm or peering from the net bag of the housewife, the businessman, the schoolgirl and the boy on the bike.

A big tanker moves in from the Persian Gulf with a cargo of crude oil for an East Coast refinery. She is ready to head back east, but her owner has an opportunity to take an export load of grain in the Federal-aid program, in the same vast compartments filled with muck.
VIENNA, May 20 Dr. R.F Foster of the Batelle Memorial Institute can hardly abide the sight of whitefish, no matter how nicely prepared.
Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of Brooklyn, defended President Johnson's policies in South Vietnam yester day.

YONKERS, May 22 Bob Ashton of New Jersey Spiked Shoe Club, running in the 5,000meter event, and Jim O'Connell of City College, competing at 10,000 meters, won the Olympic Development races today at War Memorial Field.
The appointment of Wilbur A. Levin as president of Martin's, Brooklyn, a fashion-apparel store chain, was announced over the weekend.
Sydney D. Bierman, a partner in the New York law firm of Bierman Damashek, died yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 53 years old and lived at 54 Maple Hill Drive, Larchmont, N.Y.
DANANG, South Vietnam, May 22 Three Western newsman were slightly wounded today when they and nine other newsmen were caught in cross fire between rebel and Government troops.

WASHINGTON, May 22 A compromise version of a bill giving the Government more precise tools with which to prevent unsound practices in banks and savings and loan associations will be worked out behindthe-scenes over the next several weeks.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, May 22 Tanzanian stilt dancers, drummers and demonstrators from South Africa, Rhodesia and the Comoro Islands, a French possession in the Indian Ocean, greeted the members of the United Nations Special Committee on Colonialism who arrived today for a six-week fact-finding tour in Africa.
American Reform Judaism will publish a liberal commen tary of the Torah, the five Books of Moses, "to meet the problems and perplexities the Bible poses to modern man."
RIVERBOAT, Empire State Building, Fifth Avenue and 34th Street. Cab Calloway's Cotton Club Orchestra.

GREAT NECK, L.I., May 22 Miss Mary Judith Munley and Ens., George Arthur Clum, U.S.N., who received master's degrees in psychology from St. John's University, were married here this afternoon in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Aloysius.

BOSTON, May 22 The marriage of Miss Lynne Elaine Barber of Allston, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur M. Barber of Buffalo, to Dr. Alan Burton Retik, of Cambridge, took place here this afternoon in the chapel of Hillel House at Boston University.

BRIDGEHAMPTON, L.I., May 22 Jerry Grant of Santa Ana, Calif., drove a Lola-Ford to an easy victory today in the season's fourth United States road championship 200-mile race. He averaged 98.39 miles an hour for 70 laps over the 2.85-mile course in the dunes overlooking Peconic Bay. I
Jack Hanson has been named vice president of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., effective Aug. 1, Donald B. Smiley, the company announced yesterday.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, May 22 There are two kinds of art festival: those where you invite guest companies and guest artists from abroad and offer an international program, and those where you depend upon the home resources, trying to show the rest of the world your own artistic treasures.
For 10 cents, the Canada Dry Corporation will supply anyone with a box of colored stars to stick to a bottle of Pedro Domecq Fundador, a "fine but starless" Spanish brandy.

Jose Torres went to a victory party in midtown Manhattan Saturday night after he had gained a 15-round unanimous decision over Wayne Thornton to retain his world light-heavyweight title in his first defense.
IN his final year at Harvard in 1937, Rusty Crawford was poring over his anthropology texts when he decided, suddenly, to apply to law school. He was promptly accepted.
HAVANA, May 22 (AP) The Cuban armed forces charged today that a Cuban soldier was killed by gunfire from the United States Naval Base at Guantanamo Bay in southeast Cuba last night.
HOUSTON, May 22 (AP) Jim Bunning scattered eight hits and Clay Dalrymple drove in two runs today to lead the Philadelphia Phillies to a 6-1 victory over the Houston Astros.

WASHINGTON, May, 22 The Administration has quietly passed the word to key House members that it may have to rescind the recent 15 per cent increase in wheat acreage allotments unless some restrictive provisions are modified or removed from the $3.3-billion socalled "Food for Freedom" bill.

Romeo Hanover, the leading 3-year-old pacer in the nation, has drawn the No. 7 post position and has been installed the even-money favorite to win the $25,000 Commodors Pace, opening-night feature Wednesday at Roosevelt Raceway.
Vice President Humphrey appealed to Americans yesterday to prove that a free society could surpass the Soviet Union in the development of amateur athletes.

The Packard Bell Electronics Corporation said over the weekend that the expenses connected with the cash sale of its business and net assets to the Singer Company were not expected to exceed 25 cents a share.

The Sparrows Point, Md., shipyard and the Staten Island foundry and propeller plant were among 31 Bethlehem Steel Corporation operations cited last year by the National Safety Council for safety achievements.

Miss Elizabeth Rose Beilenson, daughter of Mrs. Peter Beilenson of 1035 Fifth Avenue and the late Mr. Beilenson, was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Joseph J. Schildkraut, son of Mr. and Mrs. Simon Schildkraut of Brooklyn. Rabbi David J. Seligson performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's mother.

Few investors need be reminded that stock prices have dropped sharply in recent weeks. Their task now is to decide what to do about it. Aside from short sellers, who strive to make profits in declining stocks by selling borrowed securities and later replacing them with pur-...
The Central Gulf Steamship Corporation of New Orleans has applied to the Maritime Administration for four C-4 vessels from the National Defense Reserve Fleet in a further expansion move.

The Senate Commerce Committee has scheduled additional hearings this week on the difficult problem of drafting legislation to protect the hundreds of thousands of animals used each year for medical research.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (UPI) The Roman Catholic Archbishop of Washington declared today that "blockbusting, panic selling and similar tactics" designed to perpetuate racial discrimination in housing are "immoral and unworthy" of Christians.
Mayor Lindsay, facing tough opposition to his tax package in the Legislature, did a turnabout yesterday and said he would agree to let commuters pay a smaller income tax than city residents.
ATLANTA, May 22 (AP) Byron Browne raced home on Clay Carroll's wild pitch in the ninth inning today, giving the Chicago Cubs a 4-3 victory over Atlanta and a split of their double-header.
RALEIGH, N.C., May 22 North Carolina Democrats and Republicans will pick nominees next Saturday for the House of Representatives and for one United States Senate seat.
WASHINGTON, May 22 Total debt in the American economy rose $93-billion to about $1.3-trillion last year, the Commerce Department reported today.
The projected NATO hearings of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee may illuminate the Atlantic crisis in the way its China hearings focused new light on the Pacific crisis.

LUSAKA, Zambia, May 22 President Kenneth Kaunda said today that Zambia would not adhere to a demand by the Rhodesian Railways Board that Zambian freight traffic be paid for in advance with convertible currency. He said that Zambia was preparing a case to take to the International Court of Justice, if necessary to support her refusal.

Representative Emanuel Celler of Brooklyn, dean of the New York State delegation in Congress, scoffed yesterday at the idea that his fellow Democrats would name their candidate for Governor at an "open convention."

CINCINNATI, May 22 (AP) A throwing error by Leo Cardenas on Orlando Cepeda's run-producing single allowed another run to score in the ninth inning and enabled the St. Louis Cardinals to post a 4-3 victory over the Cincinnati Reds today.

KALAMAZOO, Mich., May 21 (AP) Maj. Gen. Charles K. Gailey Jr., a retired Army officer who was chief of staff of Lucius D. Clay, military governor of Berlin, during the 194849 airlift, died here today at the age of 65.

The inanity of present American legislative obstacles to expanded trade with Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union emerges strongly from the survey of East-West commerce which is published in today's Times.
A man who was killed as he tried to aid three teen-age sisters early Saturday was identified yesterday as David Jeans, 38 years old, of 110-48 Farmers Boulevard, Jamaica, Queens.

Jack Sparrow of Chaminade High School in Mineola, L.I., defeated Phil Krieger of St. Benedics's Prep, Newark, 0-6, 6-2, 6-4, in the singles final and Xavier won the team title with 20 points yesterday in the 18th Fordham interscholastic invitation tennis tournament.
For three hours yesterday afternoon, the 369th Veterans Association held its eighth an nual memorial parade up Fifth Avenue. There were 5,840 marchers and 37,700 spectators, according to the police.
PITTSBURGH, May 22--Another element of uncertainty was injected into the steel-market picture last week.
Two United States-flag airlines have ordered a total of 28 Fairchild Hiller FH-227B turbo-propeller airliners. The purchase price of the twin-engine aircraft was not disclosed.
Miss Georgians O. Miranda will be sworn in today as an assistant United States attorney in Federal Court in Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, May 22 Dr. William Haddon Jr., a New York State physician, is expected to be named to head the new Federal auto safety program now awaiting Congressional approval.
The Rev. Dr. Reinhold Niebuhr returned to the pulpit yesterday after an absence of more than two years.

The Frank G. Shattuck Company announced over the weekend a revised statement for 1965 showing consolidated net income at $91,000. This compared with a previously reported net income for last year of $913,000, or 82 cents a share.
MONTE CARLO, Monaco, May 22 Jackie Stewart, a Scotsman from Dumbarton who is the hot new talent on the international auto racing scene, won the Grand Prix of Monaco today and broke the record.
PIEKARY SLASKIE, Poland May 22 Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski offered the Government a formula for coexistence today, but coupled it with a warning.
A T-shaped dining hall with facilities to serve 2,000 Coast Guardsmen in 90 minutes will be built this year on Governors Island.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., May 22 (UPI) A Federal judge took control over the weekend of a proxy fight involving the Studebaker Corporation, and asked the Securities and Exchange Commission to enter the case.
Three-quarters of the city's public health nurses are scheduled to withdraw en masse today from service in health centers and clinics.
OTTAWA, May 22 (Canadian Press) The Air Transport board has announced that it approved with restrictions the applications of three United States airlines to extend charter services to Canada.
BEAUMONT, Tex., May 21 (UPI) Shirley Englehorn overcame 90-degree temperatures today to post rounds of 68 and 70 and win the Babe Zaharias women's golf tournament with a 209.

The New York Philharmonic concluded its 1965-66 subscription season at Philharmonic Hall Saturday night. The program continued Leonard Bernstein's two-year survey entitled "Symphonic Forms in the Twentieth Century." It offered Harris's Symphony No. 3 and in B flat ("La Reine"), Roy Harris's Symphony No. 3 and Brahma's Symphony No. 2 in D.
PARIS, May 22 (UPI) France will explode three bombs in the air and one under water in its nuclear tests in the Pacific, informed sources said today.

SAIGON, Monday, May 23--South Vietnamese marines and paratroopers moved in around Buddhist headquarters today after one Vietnamese was killed in front of the headquarters and two American vehicles were burned by an angry mob.
FORT WORTH, May 22 Bruce Devlin, an Australian plumber who became a golf professional four years ago, won the $110,000 Colonial National invitation tournament today by one stroke.
PALM BEACH, Fla., May 22 Dr. and Mrs. Robert Boggs of Palm Beach and of Mill Neck, L.I., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Boggs's daughter, Miss Brenda Lee Teagle,to Winfield, Scott Essex Jr.
MIAMI, May 22 The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations is ready to start a fullscale organizing campaign among migrant farm workers on the Atlantic Coast.

THE delineation between children's and adult fashion is getting to be more a matter of size and proportion than of cost and style. That is the opinion of Helen Van Slyke, president of the House of Fragrance and current president of the Fashion Group, an organisation of... women executives in the fashion field.

BALTIMORE, May 22 A thoroughly relaxed and resting Kauai King had to be awakened at 9 o'clock this morning to be put on view for the many fans who came out to Pimlico to get a look at him. The Marylandbred colt who won the Preakness yesterday in record-breaking time was fast asleep, stretched out in his stall, when his owner, Mike Ford, stepped in to awaken him.

Normally on a Sunday afternoon at 99th Street between Amsterdam Avenue and Broadway the sounds are those of Boleros Pachangas and Rhumbas. The Hispanic music is punctuated by the sounds of Puerto Rican youngsters playing in the streets.

Seven thousand persons gathered in the Forest Hills Stadium in Queens yesterday and heard public officials and spiritual leaders of all faiths call on the Soviet Government to restore the spiritual and cultural rights of its Jewish citizens.

PARIS, May 22 Piero Savoretti looks into the Soviet market for his Italian employers Fiat, Olivetti and others from a small suite in Moscow's Sovietskaya Hotel. Britain's giant Imperial Chemical Industries, which sells almost 10 per cent of its exports to the Soviet Union, has a staff of Russianspeaking specialists.
The successful use of an artificial auxiliary heart chamber was reported yesterday by a team of surgeons, physicians and other specialists at Maimonides Hospital of Brooklyn.
David L. Cole, the senior mediator in the New York newspaper strike, reported to Mayor Lindsay yesterday that the 28-day shutdown of the World Journal Tribune, Inc. could end this week.

MONTREAL, May 22 (Canadian Press) Judge Rene Lippe has asked the International Longshoremen's Association to call a meeting of its membership for tomorrow to vote on recommendations that he has made to settle the threeweek-old strike at three St Lawrence River ports.

AUSTIN, Tex., May 22 (AP) Dan Moody, whose meteoric career in Texas politics saw him as the state's Attorney General at 31, Governor at 33, and back in private law practice at 37, died today at his home after a long illness. He was 72 years old.

LEOPOLDVILLE, The Congo, May 22 (Reuters)--Ninety persons were killed and hundreds of homes were destroyed in a violent earth tremor last Wednesday in the northeastern town of Beni, the Congolese news agency reported today.

The election of Lowell Brody as a vice president of Abbott, Merkt Co., architectural firm specializing in shopping centers, department stores and industrial buildings, has been announced by Richard H. Tatlow 3d, the firm's president.
GREENWICH, Conn. May 22 Miss Lynn Solinger was married here this afternoon to Robert A.M. Stern in the garden at Chieftains, the estate of her grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. Bernard F. Gimbel.

ATHENS, May 22 (Reuters) About 10,000 Greeks and foreign visitors walked 27 miles today from the ancient battlefield of Marathon to Athens in a peace march demanding a nuclear-free Europe and an end to the Vietnam War.
SANTA BARBARA, Calif., May 22 (AP) The Tulsa polo team led from the start and defeated Fountain Grove of Santa Rosa, Calif., 10-5, for the national open polo championship today.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., May 22 Marvin Panch, who quit the idle Ford factory team a week ago, drove a year-old Plymouth to the richest victory of his 15year career in the World 600mile stock-car race today.
I ENJOYED the first 10 minutes of "A Time for Singing" very much. I thought I was about to see a good sentimental musical. I was wrong.
ROME, May 22 The Roman Catholic Church "does not and cannot support" the "blindness" of atheistic Marxist ideology; Pope Paul VI reasserted today.

A Roman Catholic Bishop last night defied the CardinalArchbishop of Baltimore, the Vatiean Secretary of State and the Pope's own representative in the United States in a spirited defense of the Rev. Gommar A. De Pauw, founder of the Traditionalist Movement.

Governor Rockefeller rebutted widespread criticism of the state's new medical aid program yesterday, asserting that it would both expand the state's help to the needy and save money for New York City and other local communities.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., May 22 Dr. John T. McSweeney, a dental surgeon and an authority on oral dynamics and maxillofacial prosthetics, died of cancer yesterday in his home at 35 Anpell Drive. He was 50 years old. His office was at 140 East 80th Street, New York.
BONN, May 22 Government sources reiterated today that West Germany remains confident that it would reach agreement with France on the stationing of French troops on West German territory.
Freeport's loss would be the southeast Bronx's gain under a proposal made by a group of seven Bronx Democrats yesterday.
The Ford Motor Company has engaged the Independence for four cruises this summer carrying 1,200 dealers and managers and their wives.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 22 Proposals that ownership of the seas and space be vested in the United Nations have been made by the Commission to Study the Organization of Peace.

SHREVEPORT, La., May 22 (AP) Alfred C. Glassell, an oilman, wild life conservationist and hotel owner, died yesterday at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn. Mr. Glassell was 76 years old and lived here.

CHICAGO, May 22 The University of Chicago Community and Family Center, with further Ford Foundation help, announced today that it would triple its birth control research and training program, primarily for foreign countries.
ST. JAMES, L.I., May 22 Janice Clarke of Amagansett, L.I., scored a triple victory today in the equitation division at the Hollandia Farm Horse Show.

FORT McMURRAY, Alberta In 1719, an intrepid Cree Indian named "The Swan" returned from trading along the Athabasca River to tell Hudson's Bay Company officials of "pitch that flows out of the banks of that river."
The National Teacher Corps has elicited a response comparable to that which originally greeted the Peace Corps. Applications have been flooding in at a rate of well over 600 a day.
For 50 minutes yesterday children asked Mayor Lindsay about taxes on candy bars, the smells in New Jersey, their stolen bicycles and his homework.

WHITE PLAINS, May 23--Edward J. Whitehead, a New York advertising executive, died last night in St. Agnes Hospital here of a heart attack. He had been stricken on the Westchester Hills Golf Club's course. He was 53 years old and lived at 1111 North Street.

A thorough study of maritime freight rates, shipping conference practices and the adequacy, of shipping services will be undertaken this summer under the auspices of the United Nations. The study will also show their relationship to the economies of the developing nations.
PARIS For anyone with the remotest interest in food and the preparation thereof, Paris must be the most stimulating place on earth.

The Food and Drug Administration seized yesterday a quantity of the prescription tranquilizer, Serax, charging that advertising for the product was false and misleading and could lead to dangerous use by elderly and psychotic persons.
ATLANTA, May 23--Herman E. Talmadge announced today that he would remain in the United States Senate and stay out of the Governor's race in Georgia.
LONDON, May 23 Queen Elizabeth proclaimed a state of emergency today in Britain's eight-day maritime strike.

HIS colleagues in the Legislature have considered Perry Belmont Duryea Jr. "a young man in a hurry" ever since he arrived in Albany in his own plane to begin serving in the Assembly in January, 1961. As a 39year-old freshman legislator, he had flown his twin-engine...
HOW real is the sudden resurgence of the New York Yankees? How long will it continue? How serious a pennant contender will they be?

GREENPORT, L.I., May 23 Leighton L. Phelps, a director of the Morewood Realty Corporation, 551 Fifth Avenue, New York City, died of a heart attack yesterday in his home on North Road. He was 71 years old.
GENEVA, May 23 Assistant Surgeon General James Watt of the United States was unanimously elected today to a one-year term as chairman of the World Health Organization's executive board.

BONN, May 23--The lawyer who defended Rudolf Hess, Hitler's Deputy Fuhrer, at the Nuremberg war trials, has appealed to President Johnson, Queen Elizabeth, President de Gaulle and President Nikolai V. Podgorny of the Soviet Union for his immediate release.
Sixty-four of the city's 94 child health stations were closed yesterday because of the mass resignation of public health nurses in a labor dispute with the city.

ALBANY, May 23 Attempts to reach a compromise on New York City's tax program were set back sharply today as Republican legislative leaders reacted angrily to Mayor Lindsay's suggestion of "political cowardice."
Hilliard J. Coan is expected by sources close to the company to resign today as chairman of E. J. Korvette, Inc., at a special board meeting.

BATAVIA, N.Y. There is a factory complex here that simultaneously turns out pool tables, mobile homes, champagne, acid tanks, lamps and pet food. It also turns out girls who know how to apply cosmetics and boys who can repair cars.

Prices of copper futures advanced sharply yesterday despite the action by the Bridgeport Brass Company, which cut prices on certain copper products at a time when prices in London and in New York have been on the rise.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 23 (Reuters) President Sukarno has agreed to peace talks at the foreign ministers' level to end the fight with Malaysia that he began more than three years ago.
The soundtrack album for "A Hard Day's Night," the first feature film starring the Beatles, has so far made a profit estimated at $2-million for United Artists Corporation.
The American Stock Exchange advanced sharply yesterday in slightly stepped up trading.
PARIS, May 23 A Frenchman raised his hand to ask the only question that none of the American Negroes in the auditorium felt able to answer.
Philip J. Levin, the insurgent board member of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc., dropped yesterday the lawsuit through which he had tried to block today's special meeting of the motion-picture company.

Elia Kazan, who has had one of the most distinguished careers in the theater, has no plans to direct another play on, around or off Broadway.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., May 23--A 21-year-old mother of two children, who chose a 90-day jail sentence rather than undergo an operation she feared would make her sterile, was jailed briefly today and then released to await a hearing on May 31.
EPSOM, England, May 23 (UPI) Thousands of bets poured onto the Americanowned outsider, Black Prince II, today, dropping the odds on the colt for Wednesday's Epsom Derby from 33-1 to 25-1.

LONDON, May 23 The First National City Bank of New York announced here today plans to create an international investment instrument expected to add new dimensions to the Eurodollar market and possibly accelerate development of a unified capital market in Europe.
WASHINGTON, May 23 The Georgia-Pacific Corporation agreed today not to engage in any manipulation or deception in connection with purchases of its own stock.
ROME, May 23 Brother Charles Henry of Brighton, Mass., was elected today as superior general of the Brothers of the Christian Schools, Roman Catholic educational order founded in France in 1680.
The London stock market improved yesterday as renewed hopes for an end of the British seamen's strike prompted modest investment demand.

PARIS, May 23 (UPI) Gaetano Di Maso of Italy rallied after losing the first two sets to upset Ron Holmberg of Dallas and formerly of Brooklyn, 2-6, 4-6, 6-4, 6-0, 6-1 today in the opening round of the French tennis championships.
Ran Jackson, the 10th leading scorer among the nation's small-college basketball teams last season; signed a contract yesterday with the New York Knickerbockers.
A Roman Catholic priest suggested at an interfaith meeting here yesterday that Christians drop the term "Old Testament" because "it is an affront to Jews."

TOKYO, May 23 Premier Eisaku Sato called today for a new long-range economic program for Japan in which balanced growth would lead steadily to higher living standards and a more efficient commercial-industrial structure.
Mrs. Charles S. Guggenheimer died yesterday at her home, 174 East 72d Street, after a long illness. She was 83 years old.
Jacques Laperriere, of the Montreal Canadiens, who missed the final 13 games of the National Hockey League season as well as the Stanley Cup...
CHICAGO, May 23 (AP)--Zipperpedium, ridden by Henry Moreno, charged from behind to win the $7,000 Banyan Purse by two lengths today before 11,740 fans at Arlington Park.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (UPI) The Justice Department today approved, under the Law Enforcement Assistance Act, a grant of $281,440 to the District of Columbia for a "detoxification unit" to treat alcoholics.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 23 (UPI) A nationally known authority on rocket and missile research was found shot to death in gangland style today in a room he had planned to use for his writing.
CAIRO, May 23 Reliable sources reported today that the United Arab Republic had refused to permit a visit by ships of the United States Sixth Fleet to the port of Alexandria.

COLUMBIA, S.C., May 23 A group campaigning for "religious freedom" has failed to persuade the South Carolina Legislature, which adjourned last Thursday, to modify the state's "blue laws" to permit Jews and Seventh Day Adventists to operate businesses on Sundays.
SAIGON, Tuesday, May 24 About 2,000 Buddhists left Saigon's besieged central pagoda today when Government troops opened a narrow passage in the barbed wire barricades around it.

PARIS, May 23 A ten-man team of experts from the state-owned Renault automobile works, France's biggest auto producer, left for Moscow today with hopes of land ing a contract with the Soviet Union for the construction of a car plant there.
BOSTON, May 23 A leading Presbyterian educator challenged today the traditional Sunday school pattern of modern Protestantim.

A theater party in behalf of the scholarship fund of the Convent of the Sacred Heart has been arranged for next Tuesday at the Viennese Promenade Concert that Andre Kostelanetz will conduct at Philharmonic Hall of Lincoln Center. The evening will include a champagne dance afterwards at Sherry's in Lincoln Center.

A well-rated ride by an apprentice, Ernest Cardone, en abled Miss Puzzle to win the main event at Aqueduct yesterday. Competing against four other fillies in the six-furlong race, the Jules Michaels color bearer scored by 1 lengths over the favored Indian Sunlite, with Boiseana of the Clearview Stables next.
Long-term Government bonds declined fairly sharply yesterday, some falling as much as 8/32.

THE Reisinger Knockout Team Championship, the blue ribbon event of the Eastern Regional Championships, began at the New York Hilton last night with an entry of 90 teams. The defending champions are Michael Moss, Jim Bennett and Anthony Dionisi, all of New York, Harlow Lewis and Mark Blumenthal of Philadelphia, and John Snelling of Brookline, Mass., as a recruit to the team.
WASHINGTON, May 23 Yields on both the three-month and six-month Treasury bills rose from last week's levels in today's auction, the Treasury announced today.

The Michigan Gas and Electric Company urged its stockholders yesterday to turn down a $100-a-share tender offer for their stock made by the American Electric Power System. The attitude was conveyed in a letter yesterday and followed one sent last Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, May 23 Hypothetical History: Suppose Britain and France had said no to Hitler in 1938 at Munich.
BUFFALO, May 23 (AP) Les Schissler of Denver became a three-time champion today of the 63d American Bowling Congress tournament.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 23 Mrs. Emma Peabody Abbett, widow of Sheldon Abbett, an investment and real estate broker, died Saturday in her home, 744 North Street. She was 66 years old. Her husband died in 1963.

Three productions have been added to next month's list of Off Broadway entries. They are Ronald Ribman's "The Journey of the Fifth Horse"; Arnold Wesker's "The Kitchen," and Myron Levoy's "Bada, as Seen From Gemini Five."

Macy's New York has formed a new merchandising division, which will include women's, misses' and junior "better" 'ready-to-wear, accessories and millinery, to provide more concentrated attention to the growth potential in this area of the business, David L. Yunich, president, announced yesterday. Stanley Abelson, vice president, will relinquish responsibility for children's wear and will assume responsibility for the new division, Mr. Yunich said.
SEVENTH AVENUE'S fall fashion showings, now in their second week, slipped into high gear yesterday as Bill Blass served up a sizzling fashion repast and Chester Weinberg made an auspicious debut.
About $35-million in billings ended up on the block yesterday.
BOMBAY, India, May 23 The ruling Congress party began today to assemble its lineup for next year's general elections. At this stage it appeared slightly weighted to the right.

ALBANY, Calif., May 23 (UPI) Price-seekers hoping to "get well" at the final program of the Golden Gate Fields spring meeting hit a natural today when Tranqalate won the feature by two lengths and returned $34 for $2 straight.
BUFFALO, May 23 (AP) Please Note, owned by Dan Curtin Oldsmobile of Syracuse and ridden by Ginger Burr of Camillus, won two championships yesterday at the Buffalo international horse show.

WASHINGTON, May 23 The saving of "many millions of dollars" in foreign aid funds was credited by Secretary of State Dean Rusk today to the hitherto secret policing activities of the United States Inspector General of Foreign Assistance.
WASHINGTON, May 23 President Johnson said tonight that the time had come to do something about the effects of workers' jobs on their health.
The world chess champion, Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, and his compatriot Boris Spassky drew the 18th game of their title match at Moscow's Variety Theater last night.
BRUSSELS, May 23 Miss Katherine T. Goldschmidt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jean Goldschmidt, was married today to Peter A. Levy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gustave A. Levy of New York.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 23 (UPI) Activity at the Indianapolis Speedway switched from the track to the garage area today as 33 crews began final preparations of the cars that will start the Memorial Day 500-mile race.
Steve Thurlow and Ernie Koy, the two young, robust New York Giant halfbacks, have signed their 1966 contracts, the club announced yesterday.
Mayor Lindsay has shown political courage in his tax program; but, in the handling of that program, he has not demonstrated much diplomacy.
CINCINNATI, May 23 (AP) Joe Torre drove in three runs with a homer and double to power the Atlanta Braves to a 6-4 triumph over the Cincinnati Reds tonight.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 23--Black Africa's call for the use of force in Rhodesia was defeated today in the Security Council.
Two of the nation's largest department-store companies reported gains in sales and earnings yesterday for their first fiscal quarter, ended April 30, of the retailing year.

LONDON, May 23 (UPI)--Cassius Clay showed newsmen a film today of his successful heavyweight title defense against Henry Cooper to prove that a punch opened the bloody gash over the Briton's eye in the sixth round of their bout Saturday night.

BAKERSFIELD, Calif., May 23 (UPI) Racial disorders erupted here for the second consectutive day as Negroes threw fire bombs and smashed the windows on a school bus loaded with Negro youngsters, the police reported tonight.
Clarence H. Linder was elected yesterday to the board of the Western Union Company.
CHICAGO, May 23 Dr. Benjamin C. Willis, the controversial Chicago school superintendent who has been the target of civil rights protests, today announced his resignation effective Aug. 31.

LOS ANGELES, May 23 The recommendations of the McCone report, aimed at alleviating the racial and economic crises of the riot-plagued Watts community, are in the process of being implemented here. The report's authors and civil rights spokesmen differ, however, as to the meaningfulness of the implementation to date.
The appointment of Juan Martinez as executive vice president was announced yesterday by the Government Development Bank for Puerto Rico.
WARSAW, May 23 The Polish Government has expelled three United States military attaches. Two of them were accused of having carried out "intelligence activities."

SCARBOROUGH, Me., May 23--Miss Marilyn McLean and Paul D. Paganucci plan to be married in September. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. McLean, parents of the bride-to-be, whose fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. R. J. Paganucci of Waterville, Me.

LOS ANGELES, May 23 A portly bus driver, who admitted that he was "too frightened" last week to testify at a coroner's inquest into the police shooting of a Negro here, came forward today to give testimony supporting the Police Department's version of the case.
LONDON, May 23 Prime Minister Wilson and Ludwig Erhard, the West German Chancellor, found themselves in broad agreement today on how to approach the crisis in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) An end is in sight to the long feud between the Amateur Athletic Union and National Collegiate Athletic Association, according to Theodore W. Kheel the arbitrator in the dispute.

On the bold assumption that to claim is to take, a band of 55 Jersey City businessmen and officials "took" the 12-acre Liberty Island and the Statue of Liberty in a festive, bloodless invasion yesterday.
LONDON, May 23 The Government is urgently considering tougher measures against racial discrimination in Britain, particularly in employment and housing.
A handful of touring professionals and two former amateur stars were among the 379 golfers who survived local qualifying tests for the United States Open yesterday.

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., May 23 Dr. Eugene M. Katzin, who collaborated in the research that established the role of the Rh factor in a disease that kills many infants, died yesterday at his home here. He was 61 years old and lived at 81 Parker Avenue.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 23 (AP) The president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland said today that moderate monetary restraint was needed in the present economic situation but "higher taxes at the moment are probably not politically feasible."
The National Broadcasting Company will televise a onehour color special on Luci Johnson's wedding at 7:30 P.M. Saturday, Aug. 6.

Mrs. Charles S. Guggenheimer "Minnie" of Lewisohn Stadium made an unforgettable impact on everybody, this stout little woman with the perky hats, the shrewd eyes, and the incredible pronunciations of the common and proper nouns of the English language.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 23 (AP) Montclair State College accepted a bid today to the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics District 8 baseball playoffs Thursday and Friday in Millersville, Pa.

The role the American merchant marine plays in peace and war was underscored here yesterday at National Maritime Day ceremonies in City Hall Plaza with the presentation to Mayor Lindsay of the flag of an American freighter now in Vietnamese waters.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 23 (AP) Acting Police Chief William Cade walked out of headquarters last night when he noticed a young man lounging on the street.
SANTA BARBARA, Calif., May 23 (AP) Favored Tulsa led from the start and defeated Fountain Grove of Santa Rosa, Calif., 10-5, yesterday for the United States national open polo championship.

Spokesmen for the country's chemical, electrical and utility industries went before a gathering of the nation's financial analysts yesterday to present a bright picture of unabated expansion and technological breakthroughs.
The spot rate on the British pound eased yesterday in quiet trading on foreign-exchange markets here. The pound closed at $2.7915, down 5 points from last Friday's level.
DETROIT, May 23 (AP) The automobile industry, paced by the General Motors Corporation, staged a mild production comeback last week.

SAIGON, Tuesday, May 24 The military Government of South Vietnam appeared today to be taking long strides toward restoring its authority throughout the country, but it remained unclear whether it could reconcile important elements of the population to its rule.

Until now, almost everyone has conceded the I.C.4-A outdoor track and field championship to Maryland's defenders. But a wave of Villanova sentiment has beclouded the issue for the 62-college meet Friday and Saturday on Randalls Island.
PLANDOME, L.I., May 23 Hank Brancato and Julie Epstein of Bethpage scored a 62 to win the Metropolitan Professional Golfers' Association pro-amateur tournament at the Plandome Country Club today.
A man collapsed and died in front of 700 persons at a dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night as he was presenting an award.
Nine of the Belgian block stanchions along the path curving past the maintenance house in Franz Sigel Park in the Bronx had been shorn of their crowns when the clean up crew arrived yesterday.

Ohbach's announced yesterday that it would open its first New Jersey suburban store in the Bergen Mall Shopping Center in the fall of 1967. The two-story and basement store will be about 180,000 square feet, about the same size as the Ohrbach's store in Westbury, L.I.

A motion picture televised over the air cannot be intercepted by a community antenna television system without payment of a royalty to the film's producers, according to a decision handed down yesterday in United States District Court here.

A large tank truck from New Jersey pulled up in front of the Lincoln Square Motor Inn, 155 West 66th Street, yesterday and hooked up to 150 feet of hose that had been dropped from the roof of the 10-story building.

Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson strolled under a tree house, stepped over a brick-paved plaza and peered into a concrete "igloo" yesterday afternoon in a tumultuous dedication ceremony for an experimental park and playground on the Lower East Side.

EASTCHESTER, N.Y., May 23 Mickey Homa, a Rolling Hills professional, and Carl Bernstein of Dellwood teamed for 33, 30-63 at Vernon Hills today to win the Metropolitan Professional Golf Association's pro-amateur tournament for Westchester by two strokes.
WOOMERA, Australia, Tuesday, May 24 (Reuters) The Europa 1 rocket, a project of seven nations, was launched from Woomera today, but developed a fault shortly after take-off.

PALM BEACH, Fla., May 23 Mr. and Mrs. W. Stanton Barbour of Palm Beach and East Hampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katharine Stanton Barbour, to Ogden Hillyer Sutro, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ogden Winne Sutro of Hamden, Conn.
The traditional attitude that has doomed new ideas, experiments and necessary change in New York is based on the assumption that this is the city where "it can't be done."
BELGRADE, May 23 While retaining the Communist party as the country's foremost political force, Yugoslavia appears to be headed toward a "one-andone-half" party system.
PARIS, May 23 Marya Freund, mezzo-soprano who helped introduce the works of Mahler, Schoenberg, Satie and Falla, died here Saturday morning. She was 89 years old.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 23 The president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers Union today criticized efforts by "some in high office" to silence those who disagreed with the Government's Vietnam policies.

MANY of the Bergen County, N.J., auxiliary police reserves participate in a sharply contested summer target pistol league. Last Saturday, the Teaneck team shot against the Englewood department and Teaneck won. But it wasn't an ordinary contest for one man.

A program of 20th-century music was played at Carnegie Recital Hall last night by the Festival Brass Quintet, a group of instrumentalists who play in various orchestras here in New York. They are Noble Morrell and James Stubbs, trumpeters; Robert Carlisle, French horn player, and Lawrence Benz and Jay Shanman, trombonists.
The nationwide Arts Councils of America is considering a change of name because, after it moved to New York last summer, it found that its title had been previously registered in New York State.

Nine hundred Roman Catholic women gathered yesterday to honor Cardinal Spellman on the 27th anniversary of the day he became head of the Archdiocese of New York. It was also a belated party for his 77th birthday.

SUMMIT, N.J., May 23--Roy Faber, a professional at nearby Colonia, who did most of his playing as a youngster on Staten Island's public courses, led a field of 73 in the New Jersey section of the United States Open qualifying today.

LAUREL, Md., May 23 (UPI)--The owner of Kauai King, the Kentucky Derby and Preakness winner and the year's outstanding 3-year-old, said today he would consider it "an honor" to represent the United States in the Washington D.C. International Nov. 11, if his horse were chosen by the American Selection Board.

WASHINGTON, May 23 The head of the Food and Drug Administration, predicted today that his agency could stamp out the black market in LSD without seeking new legislation to make use of the drug a criminal offense.
Worldwide operations of the General Foods Corporation in fiscal produced records in sales and earnings for the 14th consecutive year, it was announced yesterday.
Thomas W. Kelly, a senior partner of the law firm of Coudert Brothers, which he joined 50 years ago, died yesterday at his home. He was 74 years old and lived at 17 East 89th Street.
What is happening to the Administration's wageprice guideposts? The new technique of holding private consultations with businessmen is unlikely to prove effective.
The United States automobile industry seems to have turned up from, but not completely pulled out of, the sharp dive in sales it took during the first 10 days of May.
Mrs. Louis Ceraso was reported still improving slowly at Maimonides Hospital in Brooklyn yesterday, five days after an artificial heart pump was implanted in her chest.
Former City Controller Lazarus Joseph died yesterday of a stroke in Beth Israel Hospital. His age was 75. He had become ill Thursday at his home, 240 Central Park West.
TRENTON, May 23 (AP) The State Supreme Court reinstated nine indictments today against former Jersey City Clerk Bernard Rosengard charging fraud and misappropriation of city funds.

WASHINGTON, May 23 The Department of Housing and Urban Development will begin an effort this week to save the President's demonstration cities program, the imaginative but politically vulnerable plan for rehabilitating city slums. The program has run into serious difficulties in Congress.
HOUSTON, May 23 The New York Mets, having survived a "brushback war" in San Francisco, flew to Houston today with the best record in their five years as the doormat of the National League.
TOKYO, May 23 (AP) Cambodia has rejected as a "new slander" a United States protest charging attacks from Cambodian territory on American forces in South Vietnam, Communist China reported today.
ALBANY, May 23 Governor Rockefeller has apparently changed his mind and decided to try to work out a compromise on a bill to aid the City University.
HOUSTON, May 23 (AP) Larry Jackson pitched a threehitter and Doug Clemens hit a three-run homer tonight as the Philadelphia Phillies routed the Houston Astros, 9-0.
YONKERS, May 23 The trotters and pacers will be leaving Yonkers Raceway for a couple of months following tomorrow night's 70th program.
The Southern Nitrogen Company has announced the election of George V. Taylor as executive vice president. He had been senior vice president in charge of sales.

Brandeis High School won the Manhattan team title and DeWitt Clinton took the Bronx crown yesterday in the Public Schools Athletic League borough track and field championships at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.
PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., May 23 (UPI) Doug Sanders retained first place today in the Professional Golfers' Association money-winning list.
The Soviet Union is supplying the world's largest helicopters to North Vietnam.
In matters of urban design, New York has a well-documented record of finishing last. With Riis Plaza, the city finally has produced a winner.
WESTBURY, L.I., May 23 Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Willis Hicks have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janet Wentworth Hicks of Atlanta to Graham Duncan Johnson.
A 3-week-old girl died in the Bellevue Hospital infectious disease ward Saturday night after she had been dropped to the floor by a 5-year-old boy, apparently accidentally, according to the police.
GENEVA, May 23 An eightmember international consortium headed by the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) founded today a Swiss concern to buy and operate the country's illfated first refinery.
WASHINGTON, May 23 The Supreme Court declared unconstitutional today an Alabama law under which a Birmingham editor has been prosecuted for publishing an editorial on an election day.
Richard H. Clayton, a Texas Gulf Sulphur Company geophysicist, testified in Federal Court here yesterday that the second hole drilled into the concern's Timmins, Ont., copper strike...
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 110.8 on Friday from 110.6 on Thursday.

IS anyone seeking relief from the fatiguing efforts of singers who warble discordantly or who coyly vibrate thier vocal cords near a microphone? If there is, the advice is to repair to the Jan Hus Playhouse on East 74th Street, where the American Savoyards opened last night with "The Pirates of Penzances."
WASHINGTON, May 23 Congress approved one budgetary proposal of President Johnson's today but immediately began arguing about another.

MOSCOW, May 23 (Reuters) Comdr. M. Scott Carpenter, American astronaut, has declined an invitation to attend scientific congress here because the Soviet Union banned a simultaneous visit by a United States Naval ship, the American Embassy said today.

TRENTON, May 23 Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange, indicated to state officials here today that the exchange planned to establish an auxiliary trading floor in New Jersey to escape a proposed increase in New York State's stock-transer tax.
ALBANY, May 23 Governor Rockefeller has decided to go before a legislative committee tomorrow in an effort to quell the controversy over the state's new medical care program.

Mayor Lindsay fought hard yesterday for his plan to consolidate the transportation agencies of the city. In a hostile atmosphere at the hearing of the City Council's Committee on Legislation he seemed to be the only one concerned about improving the lot of subway riders as his soundly conceived program was subjected to a barrage of misrepresentations. Again, as in the case of the tax problem, he displayed courage if not diplomacy.

Plans for the RockwellStandard Corporation to acquire the Kearney and Trecker Corporation for $55-million in stock were dropped yesterday.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 23 Fifty soldiers and marines fired warning shots over the heads of 5,000 students who were marching on the Indonesian Parliament building today. One student was bayoneted in the chest as he tried to break through the wall of troops, but he was not seriously hurt.
PARIS, May 23--Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China "might come to Paris two weeks from now," according to L'Aurore, a morning newspaper.
MONTREAL, May 23 (AP) Striking longshoremen in Montreal, Trois Rivieres and Quebec City will vote today and tomorrow on a proposal aimed at getting 4,520 strikers in six union locals back to work.

John F. Wharton, theatrical lawyer, has received the Kelcey Allen Award, given annually to someone who has rendered "unusual service to the theater." The presentation was made yesterday at Mr. Wharton's office ...

The forced liquidation of a large block of stock by a large shareholder set off a chain reaction that caused Rowland products, Inc., to tumble 8 points to 24 yesterday on the American Stock Exchange on a turnover of 43,000 shares.

Three recent amendments to the New York Condominium (Housing) Act of 1964 should have a "substantial effect" on the development of condominium housing in the state, according to State Attorney General Louis J. RICK REICHARDT lounged in a deck chair alongside the pool at the Cali fornia Angels' training base in Palm Springs, Calif., last winter. He looked dreamily around him at the luxurious setting and the big league surroundings. He sighed and flashed a shy smile in the direction of Tommy Egan, the kid catcher.
The Bridgeport Brass Company announced yesterday price reductions on many of its fabricated brass products.

NAIROBI, Kenya, May 23 After a day of widespread rioting and shooting, a state of emergency with a dusk-to-dawn curfew was declared tonight in Buganda, the richest and most powerful of the five kingdoms in Uganda.
MADISON, Wis., May 23 Lieut. Gov. Patrick J. Lucey, 48 years old, a political adviser to President Kennedy, today announced he would seek the Democratic nomination for Governor.
WASHINGTON, May 23 The State Department confirmed today that the Egyptian Government recently declined permission for ships of the Sixth Fleet to pay a courtesy call at Alexandria.

RICHMOND, May 23 The four detectives investigating the slaying of two men here said today that they had been unable to determine if the pacifist activities of one of the victims was connected with the killing.

The National Association of Home Builders, which annually holds one of the country's largest business conventions, will change cities for the first time in 21 years for its 1968 meeting. In that year, the builders will meet at the Astrodome in Houston instead of in Chicago, which had become the association's traditional meeting place. The group's headquarters are in Washington, D.C.
ATLANTA, May 23 The Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee said today that it was withdrawing from the White House Conference on Civil Rights, scheduled for June 1 and 2.

LOS ANGELES, May 23 (AP)--John Roseboro rapped a two-out double in the ninth inning and went all the way home on pinch-hitter Derrell Griffith's infield single, giving the Los Angeles Dodgers a 3-2 victory over Pittsburgh tonight.
Horatio Alger awards were presented yesterday to 12 men whose life stories follow a "rags-to-riches" pattern.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) The Supreme Court permitted today reinstatement of an indictment that charged Ben Blue, Hollywood entertainer, with attempts to evade Federal income taxes.

WASHINGTON, May 23--Secretary of State Dean Rusk gave what was described as a guardedly optimistic report to Congressional leaders today about the prospect of avoiding further major violence between South Vietnam's Government and its Buddhist opponents.
William Siegel, a Yiddish playwright, died yesterday morning at Columbus Hospital. He had suffered a heart attack at his home at 166 Second Avenue. His age was 73.
Governor Rockefeller said last night that Senator Jacob K. Javits should be on the Republican national ticket in 1968 and hinted that Gov. George Romney of Michigan should have the other spot.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) Phil Roof's first major league home run, a two-out, two-run drive in the 12th inning, gave the Kansas City A's a 5-8 victory over the Washington Senators tonight.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 23 (UPI) Weeb Ewbank, coach of the New York Jets, said today that players from the rival National Football League were seeking out American League coaches to offer their services.
ITHACA, N.Y., May 23 (AP) Cornell University said today that a commission would study the university's relation to the draft and military service.

WASHINGTON, May 23 The Florida East Coast Railway received permission from the Supreme Court today to make "reasonably necessary" deviations from its labor contracts to continue operations during a strike by 11 nonoperating unions that started Jan. 23, 1963.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) In response to pleas by Republicans to "dry up this oasis of juvenile drinking," the House voted today to raise the minimum age for buying beer and wine in the District of Columbia from 18 to 21.
NEW BEDFORD, Mass., May 23 (UPI) The city council voted tonight to ask President Johnson to move the Fort Rodman Job Corps center out of here.
THE HAGUE, May 23 Princess Margriet of the Netherlands will marry her countryman Pieter van Vollenhoven next Jan. 10 in The Hague. They became engaged 14 months ago.
ABERNATHY, Tex., May 23 (UPI) Luci Johnson's matron of honor when she marries Patrick J. Nugent on Aug. 6 will be Mrs. James R. Ray, a young Texas housewife.
Gustave G. Rosenberg was re-elected chairman of the Board of Higher Education last night for a two-year term.
Antonio Liziero, 30 years old, a New York tenor, was one of four winners picked from 27 contestants in the finals of the American Opera Auditions yesterday at Hunter College Assembly Hall.
The Department of Justice has asked for a delay in the consummation of the proposed merger of the Mead Corporation and Westab, Inc., according to an announcement yesterday by the two companies.
Stock prices advanced for the second consecutive session yesterday after surviving a midafternoon selling wave prompted by reports of possible reductions in airline fares.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) The Senate Post Office and Civil Service Committee today approved a $622-million annual raise for 1.8 million. Government employes, effective July 1.
ALBANY, May 23 A bill that would provide rigid protection of the constitutional rights of crime suspects in New York was passed today by the Assembly.

David L. Cole, chief mediator in the newspaper strike, pressed yesterday for an agreement between the photoengravers and the World Journal Tribune, Inc.

The Reform Democrats, with support from Senator Robert F. Kennedy, have decided to mount a primary fight against the nomination of State Supreme Court Justice Arthur G. Klein for Manhattan Surrogate.

LOS ALAMOS, N.M., May 23 Visible amounts of the heaviest known element, fermium 257, have been isolated for the first time by scientists of the University of California's Los Alamos scientific laboratory. Evidence suggests that even heavier elements may be present in the sample.

MADISON, Wis., Tuesday, May 24 (UPI) University of Wisconsin students marched across the darkened campus early today and seized Bascom Hall to protest the school's cooperation with the Selective Service System.

MADISON, Wis., May 23 The faculty of the University of Wisconsin asked today for a re-evaluation of the national draft deferment policy. It also asked the university administration to give information on class standing to individual students instead of local draft boards.
WASHINGTON, May 23 "Don't you agree," asked the letter from Ottumwa, Iowa, "it is about time that the civil rights hysteria be brought under control and we return to constitutional government?"
THE linen closet went walking yesterday as Fieldcrest displayed what high-fashion talent can do with sheets, pillowcases, towels, blankets and shower curtains.
Mayor Lindsay told the City Council bluntly and faceto-face yesterday that its failure to support his proposed transportation reorganization would be viewed as "a cynical
ATLANTA, May 23 Julian Bond was denied a seat in the Georgia House of Representatives a second time today.
Measles, the "harmless" childhood disease that can kill, will be nearly eradicated from most areas of the country a year from now, officials of the United States Public Health Service predict.
The Pearl Socolof League for the Rehabilitation of Retarded Children will hold its annual spring luncheon on behalf of the Jewish Hospital of Brooklyn at the St. Regis Hotel Roof today.
The American Indian has gained a new memorial hall at the American Museum of Natural History.
The financial analysts heard some sharp warnings yesterday about the impact that tight money could have on the economy.

The Lindsay administration was putting finishing touches last night on revisions in its $525-million tax package, but none included concessions to commuters that the Mayor said Sunday were in order.

The IBM World Trade Corporation, the overseas arm of the International Business Machines Corporation, has arranged a four-year, $35-million line of credit in Eurodollars, a spokesman for the company said yesterday.

The J. Walter Thompson Company and the Urban League of Greater New York are quietly at work on an experimental training project for Negroes and Puerto Ricans that could have a significant effect on the whole business community.
The 26th running of the Connecticut Cup, a three-mile timber event, heads the program for Saturday's 18th annual Adjacent Hunts race meeting at Purchase, N.Y.
ST. LOUIS, May 24 (AP) Glenn Beckert's two key hits enabled the Chicago Cubs to beat the St. Louis Cardinals, 2-0, tonight.

OKLAHOMA CITY, May 24 (AP) Preston Moore, an Oklahoma City lawyer and former national commander of the American Legion, defeated former Gov. Raymond Gary tonight in their runoff contest for the Democratic nomination for Governor of Oklahoma.
Mayor Lindsay opened the city's water tap just enough yesterday to let gardeners sprinkle their lawns, restart some ornamental fountains and permit swimming parties in back yards.
A New York labor leader offered the local chapter of the League of Women Voters a tongue-in-cheek formula yesterday for overcoming political apathy in the city's slums.

A police detective yesterday accepted a distinguished service award from a veterans' organization for his attempt to sing "God Bless America" at a rally protesting United States policy in Vietnam.
DOVER, Mass., May 24 Miss Marilyn Jean Hall and George Remsen Morgan plan to be married here on Aug. 27.
MONTREAL, May 24 Quebec's school reforms, welcomed by many educators, have become one of the most controversial issues in the campaign to elect a new provincial legislature.

Mrs. John V. Lindsay began a personal survey of the city's hospitals yesterday, with a visit to one in Manhattan and one in Brooklyn. "I'm just looking," Mrs. Lindsay said, as she began a tour of Gouverneur Hospital Ambulatory Clinic at 9:30 A.M.
SAIGON, May 24 (AP) 79 Vietcong dead today in bombers lashed at a major guerrilla concentration, believed to total about 350 men, in the highlands 35 miles west of Quangngai.
WASHINGTON, May 23 Small business in America received an unusual amount of official attention at the White White House today.
A Federal antipoverty official said yesterday that despite repeated prodding from Washington to submit its budget for neighborhood programs, New York City's "only response was delay."
