BOSTON, May 24 (AP) The Boston Red Sox unloaded a 16-hit attack and rolled to their sixth straight victory tonight, crushing the Minnesota Twins, 11-2.
LAUSANNE, Switzerland, May 24 (Reuters) The International Olympics Committee said today that Communist China was free to ask for membership if it wanted to compete in the 1968 Olympic Games.
LONDON, May 24 The ancient British tradition of granting political asylum will soon extend, for the first time, to refugees from Commonwealth countries.
CHICAGO, May 24--Leaders of a striking union of Cook County public aid employes today rejected a county board settlement formula for their 12day-old strike.

At a tearful mass meeting, 300 public health nurses unanimously rejected yesterday a city offer to end a labor dispute that has disrupted health services for 2,500 children daily.
WASHINGTON, May 24 (UPI)--The United States Weather Bureau said today girls' names were still the best way to identify hurricanes. It released a list of 42 ready to be used this year.
The appointment of William T. Lybrand and John C. Mott as vice presidents of the Irving Trust Company, was announced yesterday.
The General Motors Corporation reported yesterday an 18 per cent drop in passenger car sales for the mid-May period.
WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) President Johnson signed today legislation authorizing the sale of pooled participations in mortgages and other financial assets owned by the Federal Government.
Theodore Schlesinger, president of Allied Stores Corporation, was given the Brotherhood Award of the National Conference of Christians and Jews last night.

The Bank of America, the nation's largest bank, announced yesterday plans to license other banks around the country to use its credit card, which it calls the BankAmericard. The hope, a spokesman for the bank said, is to create a national credit card system, since the cards issued by one would be acceptable to merchants enrolled by all other banks in the system.
WASHINGTON, May 24 A Cuban soldier killed at the Guantanamo Naval Base was shot by a United States Marine while the Cuban was Climbing over the fence to get away, reliable sources said today.

WASHINGTON, May 24 Pierre de Lagarde Boal, former Minister to Nicaragua and Ambassador to Bolivia, died today in Paris at the age of 70. He retired from the State Department in 1948, ending a foreign service career that had begun in 1919.

MADRID, May 24 Top-ranking executives of European and American banks aired concern today about inflation on both sides of the Atlantic. There was a consensus that the major industrial countries were not threatened by recessions, and some concern that they might be faced with increased government regulation.

Mayor Lindsay showed common sense in waiting until the reservoirs were almost 85 per cent full before easing the water restrictions that have helped so substantially to build up the city's supplies. A more profligate policy, before the crisis had clearly abated, would have been akin to playing Russian roulette with the city's future.

The Marine Midland Corporation of Buffalo, New York's only statewide bank-holding company, announced plans yesterday for a merger between its Rockland County subsidiary and the Maybrook National Bank, Maybrook, N.Y.
PORTLAND, Ore., May 24 Representative Robert B. Dun can won the Democratic nomination for United States Senator today in a primary election in which Vietnam was the leading issue.

After a long debate, the Bronx Democratic organization led by Charles A. Buckley has decided not to oppose Representatives Jonathan B. Bingham and James H. Scheuer, both Reform Democrats, in the June 28 party primary.
Mediators in the newspaper strike planned to concentrate, starting today, on settling the dispute between the striking Newspaper Guild and the World Journal Tribune, Inc.
WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP)--The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today the nomination of Eugene M. Locke, a friend of President Johnson, to be Ambassador to Pakistan.

BOSTON, May 24--The General Assembly of the 3.3million-member United Presbyterian Church overwhelmingly approved today a proposed updating of the denomina tion's basic doctrine that for the first time would recognize in a creedal statement its obligation to work for social justice.
Whitey Ford made a brief, discouraging but inconclusive appearance for the New York Yankees last night as their five-game winning streak came to an end in a 4-2 loss to the California Angels.

Matthew H. O'Brien, a corporate attorney who represented concerns and trade associations in the artificial and synthetic fibers field, died Saturday after abdominal surgery at New York Hospital. He was 71 years old.

Manuel F. Cohen, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, suggested last night that "conglomerate companies" giant corporations engaged in several distinct lines of business might break down their profit-and-loss statements on a divisional basis.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., May 24 (UPI) The Brotherhood of Railway Trainmen had the approval of a Federal Court today to picket the Jacksonville railway terminal, but a spokesman said it probably would be several days before any action was taken.

MOSCOW, May 24 The battered city of Tashkent was struck by another earthquake today, close in intensity to that of the April 28 tremor, which destroyed thousands of buildings, killed eight persons and left at least 100,000 people homeless.

THE Wilderness Society has alerted the conservationists and national-park supporters in its 35,000-member organization to public hearings set for June 18 and 15 on the future of the Great Smoky Mountains National Park.
CINCINNATI, May 24 (UPI) Don Pavletich's two-run single and a two-run double by John Edwards sparked a sevenrun sixth-inning rally tonight as the Cincinnati Reds defeated the Atlanta Braves, 8-2.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 24 (AP) M.G. Snyder of Jefferson County, a Goldwater conservative, overcame the re sistance of moderates today to win the Republican nomination in the primary in the new Fourth Congressional district.

CLEVELAND, May 24 (AP) The Edward N. Siegler Co., which was suspended yesterday from the Midwest Stock Exchange, asked a United States District Court's permission today to undergo a reorganization in bankruptcy court.

NEW ORLEANS, May 24-- A three-judge panel of the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals began hearing today a petition by the Department of Justice for a uniform decree to speed school desegregation in many Southern school systems.

ANAHEIM, Calif., May 24 An optimistic assessment of the prospects for exploring Mars during the next decade and finding some form of life there was presented here today. The views were offered by scientists attending a symposium sponsored by the American Astronautical Society.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 24 (UPI) The South African Government announced today that no foreign newsmen would be permitted to accompany Senator Robert F. Kennedy on his visit to South Africa next month.

NORFOLK, Conn., May 24 Mr. and Mrs. Richard R. Hasbrouck have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Elizabeth Hasbrouck, to Douglas Ellsworth Duncan, son of Mrs. Ray E. Shockley of San Jose, Calif.
Arnold A. Saltzman, president of the Seagrave Corporation, told shareholders at the annual meeting here yesterday that the company expected to "do better" this year than it did in 1965.

Mrs. Maria Sanner Georgi de Mallerais, wife of William C.H.M. Georgi de Mallerais of 21 East 90th Street, died Monday at Roosevelt Hospital. She had suffered a heart attack believed to have been induced by shock at the death of her sonin-law, Dr. John Worcester, and his son, William, in a plane crash in New Jersey on Sunday.
LONDON, May 24 Prime Minister Wilson, who has consistently stressed the need to accelerate technological progress in Britain, created today the post of Chief Scientific Adviser to the Government.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission said tonight Peck Peck, a chain of 66 stores selling apparel and accessories, has agreed to an order banning it from inducing or receiving discriminatory promotional allowances from suppliers.

OTTAWA, May 24 (Canadian Press) Shipments of Canadian-made motor vehicles continued to rise in March, jumping to 99,709 units from 88,705 in March last year, the Dominion Bureau of statistics reported today.
LUNEBURG, Germany, May 24 (Reuters) A 72-year-old former Nazi police captain was sentenced today to life imprisonment for the wartime murder of Jews.

LOS ANGELES, May 24 Mrs. Barbara Deadwyler, widow of a Negro killed by a policeman May 7 in the Watt District testified today at a coronor's inquest that the officer had reached through the window of their parked car and shot her husband without saying a word.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) The chairman of the Civil Service Commission told Congressmen today that the Johnson Administration had asked Government contractors to review the use of personality tests in employment.

MOBILE, Ala., May 24 (UPI), Federal District Judge Daniel H. Thomas ordered the Dallas County Democratic Executive Committee today to count previously rejected ballots from six predominantly Negro polling districts in a Democratic primary for sheriff.
MELBOURNE, Australia, May 24 (Reuters) With a flourish, Alfred Brendel, the pianist, completed the stirring closing passage of Mozart's Piano Concerto in C major last night and rose to take his bow.

The central object of our foreign policy can be simply stated to "secure the blessings of liberty to ourselves and our posterity." Some may state it in other ways but without significant improvement. One must add, in the modern world, that we must prevent a major war if possible.
Postmaster Robert K. Christenberry has submitted his resignation effective June 17 for "reasons of health," he said last night.

White Plains's mile relay team missed the national scholastic record by three-tenths of a second with a 3:15.2 clocking in a special event yesterday on the all-weather track at St. John's University in Hillcrest, Queens. Gusty winds of almost 20 miles an hour hampered the runners.
WASHINGTON, May 24 State Department officials took issue today with the Polish press agency charge that two United States military attaches had engaged in espionage.

MELBOURNE, Fla., May 24 (AP) Charles Brand, who represented the Seventh District of Ohio in the House of Representatives for 12 years in the twenties and thirties, died here last night. He was 94 years old.
An off-track bet on horse racing was ruled legal yesterday by the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court in Brooklyn.
DORSET, Vt., May 24 T. Wylie Kinney, a retired advertising sales man for Life magazine, died here today in his home. He was 66 years old.
LONDON, May 24 Scotland Yard broke a long silence today over the sensitive issue of colored policemen.

WOOMERA, Australia, May 24 The efforts of six European nations and Australia to carve out a bigger space role faced an uncertain future as a result of the launching of a test rocket at Australia's Woomera rocket range earlier today.
WASHINGTON, May 24 The Senate Finance Committee will hold its long-postponed hearings next month on the alleged dumping of foreign steel in the United States.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) A 10 per cent drop in exports and a 3 per cent rise in imports reduced the favorable United States trade balance to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $4.1-billion during April, the Commerce Department reported today.

OTTAWA, May 24 (AP) Hearings in Canada's sex-andsecurity scandal ended today.

PARIS, May 24 (AP) Marty Riessen collapsed with a badly sprained ankle in the first round of the French tennis championships today and had to forfeit his match to Alan Stone of Australia.

SNOW HILL, Md., May 24 Wilbur Ross Hockersmith, 31year-old former state's attorney for Worcester County, was sentenced today to concurrent three-year sentences for embezzlement and forgery.

HUE, South Vietnam May 24 (UPI) A top general in this dissident northern city said today that efforts to topple Premier Nguyen Cao Ky "will continue" despite the change in Danang and Government promises of elections in September.

Three out of four American drivers believe that safety features rather than style or convenience should be incorporated in new automobiles, a national survey found last night. Two-thirds of the drivers favored Federal regulation of the automobile industry's safety standards.

Station WNJU-TV announced yesterday it would become the first television station here to carry liquor advertising, which is generally barred by the video industry. Filmed commercials for Rum Superior of Puerto Rico will be broadcast in color in prime time over Channel 47 beginning June 6.

THE Reisinger Knockout Championship continues tonight with 32 teams out of 90 surviving the first two sessions of play. There were no major upsets in the first round, and the 19 top-Seeded teams had a bye last night.
The spot rate on the British pound continued to ease in quiet trading on foreign-exchange markets here yesterday. It closed at $2.7911, down 4 points from Monday.
CRESSIER, Switzerland, May 24 The Shell Refining Company of Switzerland opened today the refinery it erected on the flatland here between Lakes Neuchatel and Bienne at a cost of about $42-million.

LOS ANGELES, May 24 (AP) Maury Wills's run-scoring single capped a two-run rally in the seventh inning and Ron Fairly hit a homer in the eighth tonight to lift the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 3-2 victory over the Philadelphia Phils. Fairly's fourth homer in his last five games turned out to be the decisive hit when the Phillies scored a run in the ninth off the Dodger relief ace, Ron Perranoski.

BETHPAGE, L.I., May 24 Thomas A. Kenny, a nephew of the late William F. Kenny, a New York City building contractor, died today in Mid-Island Hospital here after suffering a stroke on May 13. His age was 69 and he lived at 171 Haypath Road.

The New York transit strike of last January gave ample proof of the inadequacy of the Condon-Wadlin Act as a protection against stoppage of vital public services. The evidence was made conclusive by the humiliating necessity, under threat of a second illegal walkout, for a special act of the Legislature to immunize the subway strikers against enforcement of the penalties that their strike had theoretically made mandatory.
The London stock market was quiet and steady yesterday as investors showed a reluctance to sell despite a deadlock in the seamen's strike and consequent declaration of a national emergency.

The Westhampton Bath and Tennis Club, an oceanfront resort at Westhampton Beach, L.I., has been bought for an undisclosed sum by a corporation headed by Walter C. Goldstein and Rene J. Barchilon.

The law of supply and demand worked with a vengeance in the world sugar market yesterday. Second-hand supplies in dealers' hands, still pressing on the market, resulted in a sharp drop in prices yesterday.

Even the scenery is entertaining.

R.H. Macy Co. announced here yesterday that its sales and earnings climbed sharply in the 13 and 39 weeks ended April 30.

Gerald Weales, a 41-year-old author and professor of English, has won the $4,000 George Jean Nathan Award for drama criticism during the 1965-68 season. The award is the richest theater prize.

Mrs. John F. Kennedy, her two children and two of their cousins will fly to Hawaii on June 5 for a month's vacation, it was announced at her office yesterday. It will be Mrs. Kennedy's first trip to the islands, and she plans to rent a house there.
Daniel P. Loomis, chief spokesman for the nation's railroads since 1957, is understood to be planning to resign shortly. His official title is president of the Association of American Railroads.

OTTAWA, May 25 (Canadian Press)--The St. Lawrence Seaway Authority was told today it should concede that it is impossible to pay off the initial capital costs of the $475,000,000 seaway through traffic revenues.

RICHMOND, May 25--A Richmond police detective will leave tomorrow for Washington with 32 small-caliber slugs taken from the bodies of six persons who were shot to death and one victim of a shooting and rape.

Met with Maurice Johnson, UPI, president of the White House News Photographers Association, and officers of the association; met with 16 Cabinet deputy secretaries and under secretaries; lunched with Secretary of State Rusk, Defense Secretary McNamara and special assistants Moyers and Rostow.
A sociologist would have felt right at home if he accidentally wandered into the 74th general meeting of the American Iron and Steel Institute yesterday.
AMERICANS baffle the world by being realists half the day, romantics the other. There's never any telling when we'll bring either trait into play.

BRISTOL, Conn., May 25-- A 33-year-old man was killed in a gun battle with the police here this morning after he had kidnapped a 6-year-old boy and held him captive in the woods for nearly three hours.
MILWAUKEE, May 25--Luci Johnson and her fiance will be honored here Saturday night at a party that is being cloaked with secrecy.

When longer vacations are set, it can be rated a certainty that politicians will set them--for themselves, that is. It can be argued, of course, that the amount of time that legislators or legislatures spend on the job is secondary to their productivity on the occasions when they are on the job. This argument has a double edge. When productivity is poor, the absenteeism becomes hard to justify.

Dartmouth was the consensus choice to repeat as Ivy football champion this year in the opinions voiced by the coaches at the annual Ivy League luncheon of the Touchdown Club of New York yesterday, but the stiffest kind of competition was foreseen for the Hanoverians.
SPRINGFIELD, N. J., May 25--The Philadelphia women's golf team of seven regained the Griscom Cup today by a 9 point margin over rivals firom Massachusetts and New York.

WASHINGTON, May 25-- The American Optical Company and Bausch Lomb, Inc. agreed today to restrictions of their operations in both the wholesaling and retailing of eyeglass lenses for periods of up to 20 years.

CINCINNATI, May 25, (AP) --Cincinnati scored two runs on a pair of sixth inning errors by Woody Woodward, and Milt Pappas recorded his fourth straight complete game victory tonight as the Reds defeated the Atlanta Braves, 6-2.

City Building Commissioner Charles G. Moerdler charged yesterday that a "preliminary inquiry" indicated a "pattern of discrimination" by fire insurance companies against certain areas in the city--Harlem, Bedford-Stuyvesant and South Jamaica.

BOSTON, May 25--The new stated clerk, or chief ex ecutive officer, of the United Presbyterian Church is a handsome, dark-haired lawyer who for the next five years will guide the destinies of the Protestant denomination.
ITHACA, N.Y., May 25--Cornell students took part today in a referendum on United States policy in Vietnam and, in general, found it open to criticism.
NEWARK, May 25--Former Mayor Leo P. Carlin announced tonight that a lack of funds had forced him to abandon his campaign for election as Mayor in the June 14 run-off contest.

THE Aviation/Space Writers Association conference at the New York Hilton Hotel put aside the weightier questions of defense and space flight yesterday for a reception and fashion show sponsored by the Aero Commander Corporation, Flying Magazine and B. Altman Co.

CAPE MAY, N.J., May 25-- Mr. and Mrs. Paul W. Schmidtchen have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss. Kristin Louise Schmidtchen, to Raud Earl Johnson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Earl D. Johnson of Greenwich, Conn.

WASHINGTON, May 25--Following is a table showing the number of immigration visas issued in various countries by the United States since the new immigration law went into effect last Dec. 1, and in a comparable period the year before.

A daughter was born at 12:19 P.M. yesterday to Mrs. Stavros Spiros Niarchos, the former Miss. Charlotte McDonnell Ford and the wife of the Greek shipping magnate, at the New York Hospital. The child, who weighed 7 pounds, 1 ounce, will be named Elena.
LANSING, Mich., May 25-- Gov. George Romney formally opened a campaign for re-election today, a move that most of his supporters hope will lead to the Republican Presidential nomination in 1968.

WASHINGTON, May 25-- Senator Edward M. Kennedy recorded a modest victory today in his battle to liberalize procedures under the new immigration law. But he also found more ammunition for the charge that the Administration is "unduly restrictive" in applying that law.

WASHINGTON, May 25--At what age does a person cease being a youth? Billions of words are written about youth each year, but this fundamental question remains unanswered and, for that matter, unasked. It's as if physicists had set out to solve the riddle of the atom without first deciding what an atom was.

BELRUT, Lebanon, May 25-- King Hussein of Jordan laid the foundation stone today of the Mokheiba Dam, which is part of the unified Arab engineering plan for diversion of the headwaters of the Jordan River.

BONN, May 25--Chancellor Erhard complied today with the French demand that Bonn make an official statement that it wants French forces to remain in West Germany after they leave the NATO command July 1.
MONTREAL, May 25 (Canadian Press)--The Alliance Credit Corporation announced today a net loss of $5,383,310 for the six months ended Feb. 28, 1966.
The London Stock Exchange continued to make limited gains yesterday despite the threat of a prolonged seamen's strike.

The Brooklyn Dodgers of the Continental Football League selected Sonny Gibbs, the 6-foot 7-inch former Texas Christian quarterback, from Philadelphia yesterday as Coach Andy Robustelli stocked his new team.

South Vietnamese marines and paratroopers yesterday broke up a number of small anti-Government and anti-American demonstrations in Saigon staged by about 2,000 Buddhist monks and nuns as well as youths. The troops and riot policemen broke up the gatherings with tear gas almost as soon as they began. A massive demonstration called by leaders of the United Buddhist Church failed to materialize. Sailors Snug Harbor, a home for retired merchant marine seamen on Staten Island's north shore, is preparing to admit sailors' wives and to charge fees for the first time in its 165-year history.

Trans World Airlines, Inc., said yesterday in its quarterly mailing to stockholders that it has tripled its claims in a damage suit against the Hughes Tool Company to more than $300,000,000 after statutory trebling.

LONDON--Elizabeth David is as shy and beguiling as the English sun. She is a soft-voiced woman with a quick wit and a penetrating mind, and she is almost without question the best-known food authority in England.
Native Prince won the $38,100 Juvenile Stakes for Edward R. Scharps at Aqueduct yesterday, which was a notable achievement in itself.

TOKYO, May 25--Japan's Parliament, repeatedly paralyzed by squabbles and walkouts, returned to an outward semblance of normality this week, but the political atmosphere in the resumed sitting appears as stormy as ever.

The United States and the world at large have been given two contrasting views of the meaning of the war in Vietnam in two important speeches delivered the same day. One came from U Thant and the other from Dean Rusk.
SYDNEY, Australia, May 25 --Newspapers throughout Aus tralia today used banner headlines to report the killing of the the first Australian conscription Vietnam.
SAIGON, May 25--A rash of strikes and other labor incidents has led United States officials to expect a major effort by the Vietcong to disrupt the billion-dollar program to construct bases here.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., May 25--The director of a Federal Job Corps center here said tonight that he was taking "immediate steps" to tighten the center's disciplinary system because some youths at the center had been involved in street fights in downtown New Bedford.

As the guest on Radio Moscow remarked when asked if he had anything to say: Help! Help! Help! Channel 13 presented last night Jean Erdman's ballet interpretation of James Joyce's "Finnegans Wake." It was a twohour noncommercial special, one fears, for the Merry Mustard Frothblowers of Humphreytown Associations.
Orders for machine tools, which have been gaining steadily for many months, turned sharply downward in April, an analysis of figures supplied by tool builders indicated yesterday.

ROCHESTER, May 25--Miss. Marguerite Powell Mills and Carlo Chiarenza, graduate students at Cornell University, will be married there on June 11 at the Newman Oratory (Roman Catholic). Their engagement has been made known by Mr. and Mrs. Charles Gardner Mills 3d, parents of the prospective bride.
New Yorkers were invited last night to a "happening" in Central Park, one in which they will be expected only to sniff and listen.

SAG HARBOR, L. I., May 25 --Teams from the United States and Norway will compete in the first International Whaleboat Cup contest to be held here in conjunction with the annual Old Whalers Festival June 17, 18 and 19.

The first action in the House of Representatives on the long-stalemated minimum wage bill has been to whittle it down. A close floor vote shut out more than a million and a half workers in small businesses who were to have been brought under Federal protection--and should have been. Even before their exclusion, the bill was too limited. We hope it will suffer no more attrition before it goes to the Senate.

BARCELONA, Spain, May 25--The Harkness Ballet, the first American dance group to come to Barcelona in several years, received a thunderous farewell early today from one of Western Europe's most knowledgeable audiences.

TOLEDO, Spain, May 25-- Thirty Spaniards dressed in 16th-century armor formed a corridor from Toledo's Zocodover Square to the Museum of Santa Cruz, where Spanish royalty and society came to see the premier of the film "El Greco," starring Mel Ferrer.
Dr. Morton Furman, resident in internal medicine at Francis Delafield Hospital, died of a heart attack Tuesday in his home at 200 East 57th Street. He was 38 years old.

Charles F. Fogarty, executive vice president of the Texas Gulf Sulphur Company, testified in Federal Court here yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission's chief mining engineer told him a press release the concern put out on April 12, 1964, was "accurate."

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, May 25--If the late Errol Flynn, rapier in hand, mustache at the ready, did not make a film of "The Three Musketeers," he should have. But whether that old Dumas novel of braggadocio and panache provides a suitable basis for a ballet is a good deal more debatable.

TRENTON, May 24--Democratic leaders reached tentative agreement today on a reapportionment plan that will shift a Congressman from Essex County to South Jersey to accommodate the southern area's rapidly growing population.
Mayor Lindsay indicated yesterday that the city had no immediate plans to rehire 17 Staten Island ferry engineers who walked out with 122 other employes a year ago in a union jurisdictional dispute.
PHILADELPHIA, May 25-- Edward H. York Jr. of Villanova, an investment banker associated with Drexel Harriman Ripley, Inc., died today at Jefferson Hospital. He was 75 years old.

The 19th game of the 24game title match between world chess champion Tigran Petrosian and Boris Spassky, both of the Soviet Union, was postponed because of Petrosian's illness according to Tass, the Soviet press agency.
The American Stock Exchange reported yesterday the changes carried below in the share holdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.
HOLLYWOOD, May 25 (UPI) --Jack L. Warner announced today that the new Elizabeth Taylor-Richard Burton movie, "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?" would be released for adults only.

PATRICK DE BARENTZEN, the Italian couturi er who is known primarily for his young-looking tailoring, will design half the future dress lines of Dynasty of Hong Kong, according to an announcement made last week by Bud Berman, president of Dynasty.

Interstate Department Stores Inc., one of the nation's largest discount and conventional store chains, is negotiating to acquire the old Seals football stadium property in downtown San Franscisco. Interstate plans to build the largest discount store in its chain on the property.
CHICAGO, May 25 (AP)-- Several hundred Cook County welfare workers voted tonight to accept a County Board settlement and end a 14-day strike. They are to return to work at 8:30 A.M. tomorrow.

Top officials of the Ford Motor Company forecast yesterday "a strong growth trend ahead" for the automobile industry and suggested that "normal levels" for yearly sales would run about 11.5-million units by 1975.
SYOSSET, L.I., May 25-- State Controller Arthur Levitt said today that his department would have to devise new accounting procedures for the state's medical care program.

FARMINGDALE, L.I., May 25--Edward G. Uhl, president of the Fairchild Hiller Corporation, told 150 well-disposed stockholders here today that the company expected to set new records in sales and earnings this year and that 1967 "will be even better."

Last night Sophia Loren, the girl whose first claim to fame was that she had placed second in a 1950 "princess of the sea" contest in Naples, was the guest of honor at a black-tie dinner here at the Museum of Modern Art.
CHIHUAHUA, Mexico, May 21--Across millions of acres of arid northern plains. Hereford and Aberdeen Angus cattle graze placidly, the unknowing objects of one of Mexico's last great agrarian struggles.

PALO ALTO, Calif., May 25 (UPI)--The Pacific Eight Conference has voted to outlaw the television device that enables football coaches to view instant replays on the field to spot offensive alignments quickly and accurately.
MELIPILLA, Chile, May 25 --On 60 acres of flat, irrigated land near here a dozen Chilean peasants carefully measured off individual plots to be sown in winter wheat for their own profit.

CARIO, May 25--Cassius Clay, the world heavyweight champion, arrived in this Moslem capital city early this morning for a four-day visit and said. "My main concern now is to go back to the States and try to beat the draft."

Hans O. Tischer, president of United Forwarders Service, Inc., 51 Beaver Street, shippers of American freight to foreign countries, died Monday of a heart attack in Mexico City en route to New Zealand on a business trip. He was 52 years old and lived in Flushing, Queens.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., May 25 --Harrison Wright, a retired lieutenant colonel who had served in both World Wars, died here today at Lawrence Hospital after a long illness. He was 78 years old and lived at 333 Parkview Avenue.

LONDON, May 25--Chancellor Ludwig Erhard of West Germany seemed unusually happy today as he boarded his plane for the return flight to Bonn after two days of talks with Prime Minister Wilson.
Mr. and Mrs. Jerome J. Feiner of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss. Sally Helene Feiner, to Robert Fuld Winter, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Winter of Brooklyn.

CINCINNATI, May 25-- Dr. and Mrs. Robert Perlman have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss. Virginia Paula Perlman, to Jeremy Zwelling, son of Rabbi and Mrs. Harry Z. Zwelling of New Britain, Conn.
NEW DELHI, May 25--The United States agreed today to lend India $3.5-million for a search that officials here hope will ultimately save India many millions of dollars more.

WASHINGTON, May 25--The New York City Police Department plans to set up a single clearinghouse to process all criminal suspects detained in half of Manhattan.

Sheila MacRae, singer and comedienne, has been selected to portray Jackie Gleason's new wife on 10 one-hour "Honeymooners" shows next season on the Columbia Broadcasting System television network. The role was played for years by Audrey Meadows, who failed to reach agreement with the comedian on a new contract.

LONDON, May 25--The D'Oyly Carte Opera trust and admirers of Gilbert and Sullivan undertook today efforts to keep at least eight of the famous team's original light opera scores in Britain.

Mrs. Tillie Young Vinokur, teacher at Public School 200, 1940 Benson Avenue, Brooklyn, and the wife of Grigory Vinokur, a Russian-born author, died Tuesday in Mount Sinai Hospital. Her age was 54 and she lived at 160 West End Avenue.

A $530-million offering of participation certificates in pooled loans owned by the Federal Government was announced yesterday by the Federal National Mortgage As sociation. WASHINGTON, May 25-- The Treasury auctioned $1-billion in one-year bill today at the highest rate ever paid for this series of bills, it was disclosed tonight.
The Center for Inter-American Affairs completed its organization yesterday and announced a drive to raise $1-million to remodel the Payne Mansion at 680 Park Avenue as its headquarters.

Institutional investors have by no means been standing pat in the stock market in recent years, a survey by the New York Stock Exchange has confirmed. MADISON, Wis., May 25 (UPI)--Three decades of tradition toppled today when the Wisconsin Assembly voted to allow the sale of colored oleomargarine in the dairy state.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., May 25-- A special Federal Court moved today toward implementing a reapportionment plan for Suffolk County in the general election this November.

WASHINGTON, May 25--The International Union of Electrical Workers, in a slashing attack on the labor relations policies of the General Electric Company asserted today that eight unions would not be dissuaded from their plans to coordinate contract negotiations with the concern.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., May 25--The nation's Apollo manned moon-landing program took a giant step toward the launching pad here today.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (UPI)--Lieut. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, director of the Selective Service System, said the present draft system was better for national defense than the universal service training proposed by Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara.

WASHINGTON, May 25--The most comprehensive measure of Government finance, the Federal budget on a national income accounts basis, moved into a small surplus in the first quarter of this year, the Council of Economic Advisers disclosed today.
PARIS, May 25 (UPI)--Dennis Ralston of Bakersfield, Calif., and Cliff Richey of Dallas paced the American contingent in the French tennis championships today.

The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association charged in a brief filed yesterday that the Lindsay administration's plan to revamp the board that reviews complaints against policemen was "fatally defective" because it was unconstitutional.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 25-- Romeo Hanover, "unbettable" in the mutuels, was unbeatable in the $25,000 Commodore Pace that featured the return of harness racing to Roosevelt Raceway tonight following 72 nights of action at Yonkers Raceway.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 25-- Oregon Democrats have entrusted Representative Robert S. Duncan with the job of undermining the political ambitions of Mark O. Hatfield, the state's two-term Republican Governor.

ALBANY, May 25--Despite the upstate furor over the state's new medical care program, leaders of the Legislature indicated today they would make no major changes in the law this year.
The West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company achieved the highest production, sales and earnings in its 78-year-history in the quarter and six-month periods ended April 30.

Dr. Elizabeth P. Stein, for more than 20 years a professor of English at Hunter College, and an authority on Shakespeare, died Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital after a long illness. She was 73 years old and lived at 170 Second Avenue.
WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP)--United States armed strength went over the threemillion-man mark last month for the first time in 11 years, a Pentagon report showed today.

The "common Bible," long desired by ecumenical-minded Protestants and Roman Catholics, and proposed at the Vatican Council, became a reality yesterday.

ALBANY, May 25--Mayor Lindsay's $520-million tax program for New York City was thrown into new uncertainty today as the Speaker of the Democratic controlled Assembly presented his own tax plan. It would cut the Mayor's package by more than $200-million.
A coordinator of W.E.B. DuBois Clubs was convicted yesterday for interfering with the arrest of another club member during a near-riot on a Brooklyn street.

Deutsche Erdol, A.G., a West German oil company, reported yesterday for 1965 a net profit equivalent to $4.2-million, up from $3.9-million in 1964. Revenues were $501-million, a rise of 7.4 per cent from the 1964 level.

WASHINGTON, May 25--In a private memorandum, a high official of the Department of Agriculture has appealed to Federal farm leaders in the 50 states to defend the Administration against political attack.
Luncheon, Municipal Forum of New York, Towers Hotel, Brooklyn, noon, Speaker: Mayor Lindsay.
LOS ANGELES, May 25-- A policeman testified at a coroner's inquest today that his fatal shooting of Leonard Dead wyler, a 25-year-old Negro, had been accidental.

A bipartisan group of lawyers charged yesterday that "both the Democratic and Republican organizations in New York County have compromised the integrity of the Surrogate's Court" by nominating State Supreme Court Justice Arthur G. Klein for Surrogate.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., May 25--Long Jim Barnes, a leading professional golfer in the nineteen-twenties, was found dead of a heart attack today in his apartment at 95 Washington Street here. He was 79 years old.
WASHINGTON, May 25-- The House tentatively agreed today to extend the minimum wage to some agricultural workers but to bar coverage to about 1.6 million workers in relatively small businesses.

WASHINGTON, May 25--Dr. James L. Goddard, the chief of the Food and Drug Administration, charged today that a third of the nation's major manufacturers of prescription drugs had violated Federal rules prohibiting false and misleading advertising last year.
LINCOLNSHIRE, Ill., May 25 --Mr. and Mrs. George Heitz have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss. Pamela Heitz, to Harrison Graham Lowry, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. McNeil Lowry of New York.

WASHINGTON, May 25-- Governor Rockefeller is turning over to Governor George Romney of Michigan "anything he wants" in the way of 1964 campaign material, such as organization contact lists and research papers, a Rockefeller source said today.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 25-- Vice President Humphrey called today for a national drive against "slumism."
WICHITA, Kan., May 25-- Oklahoma City's Board of Education protested today that a Federal District Court school desegregation ruling last August was "shocking" and "drastic."
WASHINGTON, May 25-- "You would think it just wouldn't dare rain on her garden party," said a guest at Mrs. Merriweather Post's party for Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson and the National Symphony Association.
The Reynolds Metals Company announced yesterday in Richmond, Va., the election of C. Byron Richards and Donald B. McCammond as vice presidents.

DETROIT, May 25, (UPI)-- Home runs by Leon Wagner and Del Crandall, plus four singles by Chico Salmon, sparked an 18-hit attack tonight that enabled the Cleveland Indians to rout the Detroit Tigers, 13-2.

CINCINNATI, May 26 (UPI) --Despite a spring plagued by rain and cold weather, the National League has drawn more than 250,000 more customers than at the same stage of the 1965 season through games of last Sunday, the league said today.

BALTIMORE, May 26 (AP) --Navy, Rutgers and Williams placed four men each on the squads named today for the 25th annual North-South college lacrosse game June 10 at the Johns Hopkins University's Homewood Field.

QAKLAND, Calif., May 26 (AP)--The Oakland Raiders of the American Football League said tonight that they had signed Roman Gabriel, a quarterback for the Los Angeles Rams of the rival National Football League, to a 1967 contract.

Tottenham, Hotspur, of London and Glasgow Celtic of Scotland will open the American portion of their North American soccer tour this weekend in Jersey City's Roosevelt Stadium.
Gerhard Schroeder, long a crusader against Nazism, died Wednesday in University Hospital at the age of 58. He resided at 735 West 183d Street.
Earl (Butch) Buchholz of St. Louis became the seventh player yesterday to enter the professional tennis tournament at Forest Hills June 8 to 12.

The Rev. John E. Pallas, a 48-year-old Greek Orthodex priest, collapsed and died early yesterday afternoon in the St. Moritz hotel just after outlining the goals set for a new agency, the United Greek Orthodox Charities. The death was attributed to a heart attack.

Strong gains gave the Campbell Soup Company record sales and earnings in the three and nine months ended May 1, according to a report issued yesterday by W.B. Murphy, president.
BRUSSELS, May 26--Two weeks of bizarre Congo-Belgian financial negotiations end ed today with the initialing of a somewhat vague agreement.

Louis Wallef, chairman, of Union Miniere du HautKatanga, told the annual meeting in Brussels yesterday that the company expected to increase 1966 copper production to 300,000 metric tons from 287,000 metric tons last year.
A suspected pickpocket was shot and killed yesterday by a Transit Authority patrolman on the platform of the IND terminus at 207th Street and Broadway.
ELIZABETH, N.J., May 26 --John Noel Mackessy Sr. of 18 Country Club Lane, a former electrical engineer with the Bell Telephone Laboratories in Whippany, died yesterday at his home at the age of 63.
HACKENSACK, N.J., May 26 --Bergen County police and Federal narcotics agents arrested 14 youths last night in the South Bergen area in a sudden move against heroin distribution.

A new marketing tool has been developed that its creators say will enable industrial marketers to examine more accurately than ever before the sales potential for their products in every sector of the economy.
OKLAHOMA CITY, May 26 (AP)--Johnny Pott toured the Quail Creek Golf and Country Club course with a record-tying eight-under-par 64 for a fourstroke lead today in the $57,000 Oklahoma City open.
NEW DELHI, May 26--The Indian Government announced today that it was lifting the ban on trade with Pakistan.
WASHINGTON, May 26--Because of its silence, the Johnson Administration left open today the possibility that, on occasion, American warplanes had flown over Communist China.
A 4-year-old boy died of diphteria in Broklyn Tuesday, the Department of Health disclosed yesterday. He was the first child to die of the disease here since 1961.

BONN, May 26--The Federal Bank's Central Banking Committee raised the discount rate, on commercial paper today to 5 per cent in a move that was intended to counter the inflation danger. The rate had been at 4 per cent since Aug. 12. Short-term rates also were increased today.

"IF you take up tiddlywinks," Bil Sterett said with a Kentucky drawl, "you're going to find competition. Right? It's no different with unlimited hydroplanes. But we think our new boat is something special."

WETMPKA, Ala., May 26 --The mother of a Negro soldier who was killed in Vietnam postponed his funeral today while she and city officials clashed over a burial site in the segregated municipal cemetery.

John J. Reilly, who retired as a director and corporate secretary of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company in 1963, died yesterday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Yonkers. He was 65 years old and lived in Riverdale, the Bronx.

The prospect of conquering most virus diseases and many of menkind's genetically determined ills "during the next 20 years or so," was suggested here yesterday by an internationally renowned geneticist.

SAIGON, May 26--Foreign Minister Tram Van Do tonight expressed to Dean Rusk, United States Secretary of State, the "consternation and sincere regrets" of the Saigon Government for the sacking and burn ing of the United States library and cultural center in Hue today by Buddhist-led students.

SURBITON, England, May 26 (AP)--Two Americans, Mary Ann Eisel and Tory Ann Fretz, advanced today to the women's semi-finals of the Surrey championships, the first major grass court tournament of the British season.

Benjamin Adelstein, chief mining engineer for the Securities and Exchange Commission, denied in Federal Court here yesterday that he had described a press release issued by the Texas Gulf Sulphur Company on April 12, 1964, as "accurate" or had said that he "would have done the same thing" if he had been in the company's position.

The I.C. 4-A's 90th annual outdoor track and field championships start today with Maryland the team favorite and Villanova the only apparent challenger. Villanova's chances depend largely on how well its three key runners can double.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Friday, May 27 (Reuters)-- Indonesia's first military goodwill mission in three years arrived by air today. It was the first time since 1963 that Indonesian military personnel had set foot on Malaysian soil in friendship.
WESTBURY, L.I., May 26-- Cardigan Bay will face Bret Hanover and three others at Roosevelt Raceway on June 4.

DERBY, N.Y., May 26--Mr. and Mrs. Harold Morton Esty have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Larkin Esty, to William Pierce Franklin Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin of Buffalo.

WASHINGTON, May 26-- President Johnson told a gathering of African ambassadors today that the United States finds repugnant the policies of white supremacy practiced in Rhodesia and other parts of Africa.

MONTPELIER, Vt., May 26 --Virgil C. Kline, a retired corporate patent lawyer, who had headed the patent department of the Johns-Manville Corporation for 20 years, died here Tuesday night at Heaton Hospital. His age was 73.

Nearly 500 musicians, music lovers and just plain fans gathered yesterday at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and 65th Street, to pay their last respects to Minnie--Mrs Charles S. Guggenheimer, who died here Monday at the age of 83.

The word from this country's museums is help wanted. Like the fine old masters and the impressionist paintings, first-rate museum directors and curators are becoming increasingly harder to find. "It's a serious problem," says S. Dillon Ripley, secretary of the Smithsonian Institution.
STOCKHOLM, May 26--A first step toward an open international exchange of all data concerning underground nuclear tests was taken during a fourday conference that ended here today.

GOTENBURG, Sweden, May 26 (Reuters)--The former world heavyweight champion, Sonny Liston, said today he hoped to have a third title bout with Cassius Clay. Clay knocked Liston out in each of their first two meetings.

LOS ANGELES, May 26-- Ron Karenga, the leading Black Nationalist figure in the Watts District of Los Angeles, told an enthusiastic Negro teen-age audience last night they should prepare to defend themselves-- if need be--from whites.

Supreme Court Justice Arthur G. Klein charged yesterday that the only reason that the Reform Democrats mounted a primary fight against him for New York County Surrogate was to revive "the flagging interest in the Reform Movement."
THREE major upsets marked the third round of play in the Reisinger Knockout Championships at the New York Hilton Wednesday night.
The New York Drama Critics Circle yesterday followed the lead of the Pulitzer Prize jury by deciding not to name an American play as the best of the 1965-66 season.
Haryou-Act owes the Federal Government $290,000 in withholding taxes, city antipoverty officials said yesterday.

DETROIT, May 26 (AP)-- Father Coughlin showed a flash of his renowned temper for a brief second today when one newsman asked if the priest had been accused in recent months by some of his own parishioners and some Detroit archdiocesan officials of being anti-Negro.

PARIS, May 26 (AP)--Three American men, Cliff Richey, Clark Graebner and Jim McMagnus, won second-round matches today in the French national tennis championships, but an American woman was eliminated.

The London stock market turned somewhat hesitant yesterday on Imperial Chemical's announcement of a sharp drop in quarterly results, but the over-all trend remained firm and key indexes set new highs.

LOS ANGELES, May 26-- The New York Mets flew from Houston to Los Angeles today, and naturally pitching was on everybody's mind since the Mets will probably have to bat against Sandy Koufax, the Dodgers' ace lefthander, twice in the next two weekends. It was especially on the mind of Harvey Haddix, ...

ONE afternoon recently, Ann Philips, a model, went to Henri Bendel's beauty salon to have her hair done. Fifty minutes later, she emerged washed, set and combed out, and kissed the hairdresser good-by.

New York University's outstanding basketball player, Mal Graham, and its National Collegiate fencing champion, Al Davis, were the principal award winners last night at the annual N.Y.U. varsity awards dinner held on the University Heights campus.
The Bendix Corporation, a Detroit producer of aviation, missile and automotive products, announced yesterday the election of Allen M. Harrelson as a director.

WASHINGTON, May 26-- President Johnson has finally acted to end, or at least to control, the scandal of political fund-raising in the United States. His proposals for raising, disclosing and limiting campaign contributions are not complete--they do not deal with the major problem of free television time, for example--but they are an improvement over the present system.
VERSAILLES, France, May 26--The Grand Trianon, a chateau that Louis XIV envisioned as a retreat, will become next month the official residence of visiting chiefs of state.
The stock market ended in a standoff yesterday as early gains faded in another round of relatively slow trading.

WASHINGTON, May 26-- President Johnson asked Congress today to impose tight new controls on contributions to candidates for Federal office and to encourage more political contributions by small givers.

PARIS, May 26--The Executive Board of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization endorsed today a 29.5 per cent bedget increase after a debate that showed profound changes in traditional line-ups.

What began as an apparently innocent plan for a bicycle race in Central Park on Sunday, June 5, emerged last night as a fight to decide whether Parks Commissioner Thomas P.F. Hoving or Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes controls the park's roads.
William C. Bethke has been named executive assistant to Thomas J. Watson, Jr., chairman of the International Business Machines Corporation.
The New York Giants and the New York Jets signed three holdover players yesterday to 1966 contracts, The two Jets are bigger, but the one Giant is faster.
WEST POINT, N.Y., May 26--Three assistant coaches for the Army football team were named today by Col. Raymond P. Murphy, the director of athletics.

OTTAWA, May 26--A proposal to increase tolls on the St. Lawrence Seaway came under heavy attack in the House of Commons today. Opposition leaders said that higher tolls would hurt Canada's booming economy.
LISBON, May 26--The Portuguese Government announced today new legislation aimed at improving working conditions and thus reducing the flow of workers abroad.
POCONO MANOR, Pa., May 26--The American Book Publishers Council today received reassurances here about the role electronics corporations plan to play in publishing.
Arnold Palmer made a brief visit here yesterday to greet sponsors of the All-American Collegiate Golf Dinner to be held Aug. 9 at the WaldorfAstoria.
SADDLE RIVER, N.J., May 26--Mrs. Frank Barnes looked out of her kitchen window this morning and saw a large black bear strolling across her lawn. Her husband, a policeman, called police headquarters.

DARIEN, Conn., May 26-- A tour of five residences in which special floral arrangements will be on display has been arranged for next Thursday afternoon to raise funds for the Darien Community Association.
Three corporate stock offerings came to market yesterday and all were quickly oversubscribed.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., May 26--Members of the New York Press Photographers Association proved they shoot better with cameras than with woods and irons at their annual tournament today at the Old Westbury Golf and Country Club.

It is easy with hindsight to say that the ingenious Constitution under which Uganda achieved independence in 1962 could not possibly endure. The federal system represented an attempt by Britain to cope with one of the new Africa's most complicated mix tures of regionalism, tribalism and traditionalism.

NORTH SALEM, N.Y., May 26--Mr. and Mrs. Carlo Middaugh Paterno of Meadow Lane Farm have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mina Minton Paterno, to Dr. David Lawrence Cappiello, son of Joseph Lawrence Cappiello of Auburn and the late Mrs. Mary C. Cappiello.
DETROIT, May 26 (AP)-- Chuck Hinton's two-run single sparked a five-run ninth inning tonight that gave the Cleveland Indians an 8-4 victory over the Detroit Tigers.

BOONTON TOWNSHIP, N.J., May 26--James G. Cunningham, former secretary-treasurer of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad, died today at St. Clare's Hospital, Denville. He was 66 years old and lived on Rockaway Valley Road here.
The controversial $125-million Lower Manhattan Expressway proposal is still being studied by the Lindsay administration, which is considering the construction of a road that would not be elevated.

WASHINGTON, May 26-- The Spanish Government has proposed three alternative defense links with Britain provided the latter yields substantial sovereignty to Spain over the disputed colony of Gibraltar.
The American Stock Exchange tried for its seventh straight advance in a row yesterday but could not quite make it.
LONDON, May 26--The Lord Chief Justice, Lord Parker, introduced today his own bill designed to stamp out drug peddling in clubs.
Mario J. Cariello, Borough President of Queens, held a "familiarization tour" yesterday to acquaint city officials with his "burgeoning borough."

MILLERSVILLE, Pa., May 26--Montclair State College was eliminated from the Area 8 competition of the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics baseball tournament today, losing to Salem (W. Va.) College, 4-1.
ST. LOUIS, May 26 (AP)-- Tim McCarver's bases-filled single capped a three-run rally in the ninth inning that gave the St. Louis Cardinals a 3-2 victory over the Chicago Cubs tonight.
Chester Wallace, who retired in 1949 as a rate expert for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, died Wednesday at his home, 124 Effingham Place in Westfield, N.J. He was 82 years old.

The engagement of Miss Gale Emmitt Schippers to Ens. Steven Barrett Sigloch, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Charles Sigloch of Rhinecliff, N.Y., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Jack Montagu Schippers of New York and East Wallingford, Vt.

OLEAN, N.Y., May 26 (AP)--Cazzie Russell, an all-American at Michigan last season, says he is trying to decide whether to play in the National Basketball Association or with the Harlem Globetrotters. Russell was the top draft choice of the New York Knickerbockers.
CHERRY HILL, N.J., May 26 (UPI)--Welshwyn, a speedy filly owned by D.O. Evans, led all the way at Garden State Park today to win the $6,000 Zaca Gray Purse by three lengths.
WASHINGTON, May 26--Following is the text of President Johnson's speech tonight at the White House reception celebrating the third anniversary of the Organization of African Unity:

LUSAKA, Zambia, May 26--Loading of landlocked Zambia's vital copper exports on the railway through Rhodesia to the sea was cut today. The development had broad implications for the world's copper industry.
SAIGON; May, 26--The United States forces in Vietnam sustained last week the heaviest battle casualties of any week of the war, an American military spokesman reported today.
ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., May 26--Joseph C. Copps of this city and Larchmont, N.Y., former president of Steve Hannagan Associates, Inc., a New York publicity company, died here today. His age was 68.
Emile Griffith will stage the first defense of his middleweight boxing title against Joey Archer, at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday, July 13.

STAMFORD, Conn.--Any mother who thinks her ambulatory preschool child combines the action of a whirling dervish with Houdini's ability to disappear should have been on Cummings Park Beach here one morning this week.

"Force Majeure" was the message that moved copper prices upward yesterday. Major Zambian producers invoked the legal clause in their contracts, which permits delayed deliveries. The reason beyond their control was that the Rhodesia, Railways refused permission for Zambian copper to move through the country except on certain terms, such as advance payment.
The Missouri Pacific Railroad and its parent, the Mississippi River Corporation, yesterday confirmed their plans for acquiring control of the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway.

NEWARK, N.Y., May, 26-- Knee-deep in alfalfa and dandelions on a sunny hillside, 19 eighth-grade pupils of this upstate village stretched out in a line, each with a three-foot plywood signboard held blank side out.

Dr. Ernst M. Rosenbaum, an associate professor of clinical dermatology at the Skin and Cancer Unit of the New York University Medical Center, died last Friday of a stroke in Florence, Italy, while on vacation. He was 68 years old and lived at 325 West 86th Street.
KAMPALA, Uganda, May 26 --On the southern edge of town the broad avenue that leads up Mengo Hill to the charred palace of the Kabaka of Buganda is still and empty.
WASHINGTON, May 26--The Senate Foreign Relations Committee dealt a series of body blows today to President Johnson's $4-billion request for foreign aid.

WIESBADEN, Germany, May 26, (AP)--Nelson Pessoa of Brazil rode Cangaceiro to victory today in the opening event of a nine-nation, five-day horse show. Kathy Kusner of Arlington, Va., was second on Untouchable.

Three of the four lights on the pari-mutuel board's orderof-finish section at Aqueduct blinked like caution lights at a dangerous intersection yesterday following the 19th running of the $11,175 Hitchcock Handicap.

CHICAGO, May 26--The faculty Council of the University of Chicago has condemned student draft-protest demonstrations and recommended that expulsion not be excluded as a means of discipline, it was learned today.

BABYLON, L.I., May 26-- The Public Service Commission heard angry telephone customers complain today that they had been overcharged, and made unwilling bookkeepers because of a new computerized billing system.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (UPI)--Senator Edward M. Kennedy today urged creation of a special Federal agency to guarantee full compensation to persons displaced by highway and urban renewal projects.
MOSCOW, May 26--Dmitry Ivanovich Shcherbakov, one of the Soviet Union's leading specialists in geology, geochemistry and geography, died here today after a long illness. He was 73 years old.
BERLIN, May 26--East and West Germans agreed in principle today on the dates and conditions for the first public debates between the East German Communists and the West German Social Democrats.

Keneret, 296 Bleecker Street, OR 5-9587. This is a Syrian restaurant in Greenwich Village, and the food is quite special. It may not appeal to the most fastidious palates, but for those who enjoy fairly robust salads, eggplant dishes and the North African specialty called couscous it is excellent, Keneret is, in fact, one of the few restau- ...
NEWARK, May 26 (AP)-- The Public Service Electric and Gas Company notified the Securities and Exchange Commission today that it will offer $60-million worth of debenture bonds for sale in June.
EPSOM, England, May 26 (AP)--I Say, owned by a London business man, scored in the 1 -mile Coronation Cup today by two lengths over Prominer. Atilla was three more lengths back in third position.

William J. Crockett, Deputy Under Secretary of State for Administration, has reiterated that the State Department makes assignments of its personnel "on the basis of need and merit, without in any way taking into account race or religion."
PORTLAND, Ore., May 26-- A helicopter crashed into a power line in British Columbia today and the vast inter-connecting electrical girid system of the West proved it could handle the emergency.
ROYAL OAK, Mich., May 26 (UPI)--The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, the famed Depression era "radio priest," ended 25 years of church-enforced silence today.
LONDON, May 26--No more nightmares for the Chancellor of the Exchequer, at least on one score. Tax officers have decided to continue processing capital gains forms after all.
MOSCOW, May 26--Shunning flaccid polemics, the Russians are toying with the far more devastating weapons of satire for dealing with the Chinese Communists.
Three mosaic murals depicting Gen. Ulysses S. Grant at Vicksburg, Chattanooga and Appomattox were dedicated yesterday at Grant's Tomb, on Riverside Drive at 122d Street.
WASHINGTON, May 26-- Great Britain is making its first serious effort to sell a military aircraft to the United States armed services.
William D. Eckert, Commissioner of Baseball, issued a statement yesterday clarifying his stand on expansion of the major leagues, declaring that it could come "any time after two years."
BOSTON, May 26 (UPI)-- Richard Cardinal Cushing cele brated his 45th year as a priest today by ordaining 31 students at St. John's Seminary into the priesthood.
The World Trade Center should be built in Harlem, where it would be welcome, rather than on the lower West Side, where some do not want it, the National Urban League said yesterday.

MONTREAL, May 26 (UPI) --Bobby Hull of the Chicago (Black Hawks, who broke the National Hockey League scoring record with 54 goals and 97 points last season, was named today the winner of the Hart Memorial Trophy as the league's most valuable player for the second consecutive year.

WASHINGTON, May 26-- Paul Rand Dixon, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, defended today the decision of the Food and Drug Administration not to order a longacting aspirin off the market even though its advertised pain relieving qualities were allegedly based upon fraudulent research data.

WASHINGTON, May 26-- A plane crash that killed the original Gemini 9 astronauts was blamed today on the pilot's inability to see the runway in rain, snow and fog as he turned for a second try at a landing.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (UPI)--The Pentagon is rejecting an appeal from the A.F.L.C.I.O. Executive Council that could have meant denying defense contracts to the nation's largest supplier of military textiles. J.P. Stevens Co.

BONN, Germany, May 26-- Officials said today that West Germany intends to follow up the visit here of Georghe Ciora, the Rumanian Foreign Trade Minister, and intensify both economic and cultural relations.
The Lindsay administration's chief counsel was reported yesterday to have decided that it is legal for policemen to belong to the John Birch Society.

Senator Robert F. Kennedy, by with many elements upstate, the his intervention in the Manhattan Surrogate race, has spread joy among Reform Democrats, shaken the regulars, embarrassed some Republicans, and sharply recast speculation about the contest for Governor.
The Roslyn Savings Bank, a $150-million Long Island institution, announced yesterday that effective July 1, it intends to increase its dividend rate to 4 per cent from 4 per cent.
SYDNEY; Australia, May 26 --Barrow Island, off the coast of northwest Australia, was today proclaimed a major oil producing area.
The spot rate on the British pound improved substantially in fairly active trading yesterday on foreign-exchange markets here. The rate closed at $2.7927, up 16 points over the preceding day's level.
CHICAGO, May 26 (AP)-- Sam Bowens drove in four runs and collected four hits today in leading the Baltimore Orioles to a 7-1 victory over the Chicago White Sox.

WASHINGTON, May 26-- Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler has proposed that the Congress authorize the Treasury to issue up to $5-billion in long-term bonds in the next 12 months at interest rates higher than the present statutory ceiling of 4 per cent.

HELSINKI, Finland, May 26 (Reuters)--An agreement to form a coalition that would include Communists for the first time since 1948 was approved today by the Central Committee of the Social Democratic party, which is scheduled to head the proposed regime.

The National Broadcasting Company said yesterday that the Soviet Union had suddenly withdrawn permission for it to present live television coverage of the Tchaikovsky International Music Competition in Moscow. Early last week N.B.C. announced it would televise a portion of the event on Sunday, June 26, from 2 to 3 P.M., New York time.

WASHINGTON, May 26-- President Johnson said today that he did not know whether he should recommend a tax increase to combat inflation. But he indicated a belief that the Government might already have done enough to cool off the business boom.
Dr. Stephen Michael Lewandowski, a Brooklyn physician from 1919 until his retirement in 1959, died Wednesday at Methodist Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived at 313 Garfield Place.

PHILADELPHIA, May 26-- To the strains of "Semper Fidelis" and "Hey Look Me Over," the Philadelphia-Baltimore-Washington Stock Exchange, the oldest market in the United States, formally dedicated its new quarters here before the start of trading this morning.
CLEVELAND, May 26 (AP) --The Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers will seek a general increase of 30 to 33 per cent in basic daily and mileage rates for 38,000 locomotive engineers this summer.

GEORGETOWN, Guyana, May 28--Members of the Marxist Opposition party in this new South American nation wore anti-Government placards pinned to their suits today when they attended the ceremonial opening of the Guyanese Parliament.
ROME, May 26--The Communists and their allies lost two rounds today in their effort to cling to power in the autonomous Alpine region of Val d'Aosta in defiance of majority rule.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP)--The Agriculture Department is investigating a complaint that an unauthorized and premature disclosure of President Johnson's plans to increase soybean acreage this year permitted a speculator to make "a pile of money."

A team of top executives from the Citizens and Southern National Bank at Atlanta is on its way to London to sound out British financial leaders on the market potential for a new bank on the island of Jamaica, a former British colony.

LONDON, May 26 (UPI)-- Two of Britain's largest electrical and electronic groups announced today a merger of their domestic appliance interests in a new $44.8-million company to enlarge their scale of operations and to compete more effectively in world markets.

Two research organizations agree that the amount of capital business is planning to put into new plant and equipment is descending from earlier estimates, but have come up with variant readings on the size of the decline.

A court order has been issued directing Harold Prince of Agon Productions, Inc., not to engage in the promotion or sale of any securities for the production of a film or other theatrical enterprises in this state unless he informs investors that he is not Harold S. Prince, the Broadway producer of "Fiddler on the Roof" and "Superman."

The opening of Staten Island as the next big area of retail expansion here was signaled yesterday with the announcement of a new shopping center that will be the largest in the metropolitan New York area. Macy's New York announced its plan to build a major, full-line department store, 230,000 square feet in area, in the new center.

OLYMPIA, Wash., May 23-- The Republican party's most promising pool of manpower may be its 17 state Governors-- and 40-year-old Daniel Jackson Evans, chief executive of the bustling state of Washington, is a good example of the reason why.

Mayor Lindsay appointed Carl Madonick, a real estate man, yesterday as the city's new Commissioner of Real Estate. Mr. Madonick, 48 years old, will be sworn into the $25,000-a-year post at 3 P.M. today by the Mayor at City Hall.

EAST QUOGUE, L.I., May 26--Mr. and Mrs. A. Russell Richards have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marilee Ann Richards, to Timothy Peter Clouser, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger M. Clouser of Geneseo, N.Y. A July wedding iS planned.

ALBANY, May 26--The Republican leaders of the politically split Legislature, in a move toward compromise with labor and the Democrats, have softened the controversial union penalties in Governor. Rockefeller's plan for discouraging strikes by government employes.

Directors of Julius Garfinckel Co., operator of specialty stores in the Washington, D.C., area, and of Brooks Brothers and A. DePinna Co. in New York, raised the quarterly dividend 4 cents a share yesterday and approved an executive committee recommendation for an eventual 100 per cent stock dividend.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (UPI) --President Johnson said today that the United States had never pulled out of a fight in which it believed and would not start with Vietnam.

SUMMIT, N.J., May 26-- Miss Joan Frances Thielbar and John Patrick Sharkey plan to be married in August. Their engagement has been announced by Miss Thielbar's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Henry B. Thielbar. Mr. Sharkey is the son of Mrs. George L. Campbell of Weirton, W. Va., and the late William F. Sharkey.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP)--The Johnson Administration apparently will have substantial Senate backing for any negotiations that might lead to gradual reduction in United States ground forces in Europe.
GENEVA, May 26--The fate of one of the most ambitious scientific programs ever devised probably will be determined in talks that began here today.

DETROIT, May 26--The fundamentalist Southern Baptist Convention rejected today a call for open discussion of current moral and theological questions. Thus it kept the door closed to debate on controversial issues such as desegretation, integration, the war in Vietnam and the United States Government's policy toward Communist China.
The blue-uniformed puplic health nurses picked up their black satchels and returned to work yesterday, after a threeday walkout, enabling the city to open all public health facilities.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 26--Miss Eleanor Betsy Rubin, who has worked as an information officer with the President's Committee on Juvenile Delinquency and Youth Crime, and Martin Allan Charwat, program coordinator and vice president of Sports International and Youth for Development in Washington, plan to be married next month.

State Medical Society leaders said here yesterday that they had assurances from both parties and Governor Rockefeller that the state's new medical care program would be amended at the current session of the Legislature to meet their objections.

HOUSTON, May 26 (UPI)-- Manny Mota's leadoff homer in the third inning proved to be the winning margin tonight as the Pittsburgh Pirates hung on for a 3-2 victory over the Houston Astros behind the relief pitching of Pete Mikkelsen.

Broadway paid tribute to one of its own yesterday. For 50 minutes, seven of the theater's leading writers and artists took turns on the stage of the Broadhurst Theater on West 44th Street recalling the geniality, wit, kindness and talent of Russel Crouse, the producer and playwright who died here on April 3 at the age of 73.

WASHINGTON, May, 26-- "I don't act, I react," is a saying often attributed to President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic. American officials were relieved this week at how little he is reacting.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP)--The State Department denied today a contention by Senator Frank Church, that there was a lack of diplomatic contact between the United States and France.

Carl Gunnard Johnson, the John Woodman Higgins Professor of Engineering at Worcester Polytechnic Institute and the president of the Metal Powder Industries Federation, died Saturday at the Mercy Hospital in Portland, Me., of a heart attack. He was 64 years old and lived in Westborough, Mass.
HONOLULU, May 26 (UPI) --Two Vietnam war protesters were convicted today on charges of desecrating the flag by substituting dollar signs for stars during a rally at the University of Hawaii.
GEORGETOWN, Guyana, May 26--Day and night during this feverish independence week, the glittering yellow Cadillac convertible has plied the narrow streets of the capital.
Contracts for building projects continued to climb last month, setting their third consecutive record for total dollar values involved. But homebuilding plans slipped for the first time this year.
WASHINGTON, May 26-- Estimated rail freight tonmileage and intercity truck tonnage in the latest week ended May 21 were both above the volume in the corresponding week of 1965.

A "modern landmark"--the Seagram Building--and its architects were among buildings, individuals and civic groups honored last night by the Municipal Art Society at its 74th annual meeting at the Friends Meeting House, 144 East 20th Street.
LONDON, May 26--Prime Minister Wilson has now fully committed himself and his Government to seeking a negotiated settlement of the conflict with rebellious Rhodesia.
LONDON, May 26 (AP)--The bloodstock stable of the late Lord Astor of Hever, one of Britain's most successful race horse breeders, was sold to an American today for an undisclosed sum.

HUE, South Vietnam, Friday, May 27--Buddhist students sacked and burned the United States cultural center and library in this city yesterday in the most violent out burst of anti-Americanism since the current political crisis began 10 weeks ago.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 26-- Roy Wilkins, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, praised organized labor today for its policy of supporting civil rights goals. But he chided some unions for failing to carry out that policy.
CINCINNATI, May 26 (UPI) --Marty Keough, a utility outfielder of the Atlanta Braves, underwent surgery today for a lung condition at Christ Hospital.

THE New York Philharmonic put on its spring finery last night for the opening of its fourth season of Promenade concerts in Phil harmonic Hall. Although it was trailing its magenta and green streamers indoors, it was also blessed by the elements outside; a warm night and a half moon square in the middle of a clear sky, ...
The Union Carbide Corporation announced yesterday the election of Adger S. Johnson as a director and of Vernon L. Larson as operations vice president of its plastics division.

The controversy over the Metropolitan Opera House at Broadway and 39th Street is rising to its crescendo. Many arguments have been expressed for and against saving the 83-year-old building with its historic Diamond Horseshoe, which is now facing the wrecking ball.

WASHINGTON, May 26-- Senator Thomas J. Dodd today dropped all but four of the original 14 claims for damages in his three-week-old libel and conspiracy suit against Drew Pearson and Jack Anderson, the Washington columnists.

The City Stores Company, which operates 105 department and specialty stores, has announced Plans to enter the Indiana market through the proposed purchase of the Wolf Dessauer department stores' business and assets, subject to liabilities.

Top negotiators for The World Journal Tribune, Inc., and the striking Newspaper Guild defined the key issues still dividing them yesterday and agreed to work through the holiday weekend to resolve them.

While 200 diners watched and listened on the 17th floor of the Downtown Athletic Club yesterday, Rear Adm. Irvin J. Stephens picked up a telephone and put in a test call to his Coast Guard headquarters for assistance at sea.

The Liggett Myers Tobacco Company has completed arrangements for the acquisition of a controlling interest in the Paddington Corporation and Star Industries, Inc., under its tender offer, which expired May 23, it was announced yesterday.

The Government and Eastern Air Lines were found yesterday to have been guilty of "concurrent carelessness and negligence" in a 1962 crash at Kennedy International Airport in which 26 persons were killed.
LOS ANGELES, May 26-- Additional testimony that the fatal police shooting of a Negro motorist was accidental was presented today as an elaborate coroner's inquest passed its sixth day.
DETROIT, May 26--The American Motors Corporation has revised its operations to enable the company to notify customers directly of any safety defects found in cars.

CAIRO, May 26--The Nasser regime, engaged in a power struggle with what it considers reactionary powers in the Middle East, has embarked on a new campaign against the political influence of the right wing at home.

Six large voluntary and professional health agencies, in a consolidation move, have leased a combined total of about 53,000 square feet in the Mutual of New York Building at 1740 Broadway, for headquarters.
LONDON, May 26--The Government announced today the formation of a court of inquiry into the maritime strike in particular and the British shipping industry in general.
LONDON, May 26--With the bulk of Zambia's copper supplies choked off in a rail dispute with Rhodesia, prices of the metal rose sharply in London today.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (UPI)--The State Department announced today that it was willing to authorize travel to Communist China by members of Congress and any Americans who could show their trip was "in the national interest."

Bond prices declined sharply yesterday, mostly because Treasury Secretary Henry H. Fowler was reported to have suggested the Government be given temporary authority to issue up to $5-billion of bonds of any maturity at rates above the 4 per cent ceiling now in effect.
NEWARK, May 26--The Essex County grand jury today indicted 11 former New Jersey Turnpike toll collectors in the alleged embezzlement of thousands of dollars in turnpike receipts.

The State Legislature, and Governor Rockefeller as well, are showing a callous indifference to the welfare of New York City. With the city living on borrowed money, going deeper into debt every day, its credit downgraded, Mayor Lindsay, despite his pleas, is rebuffed in Albany by the leadership of both political parties.

Roger Maris, carried off the field at Yankee Stadium on a stretcher Wednesday night, felt so well yesterday that he did not even need an additional medical examination for his two bruised kneecaps. Whether he will be able to play against the Chicago White Sox tonight in the opener of a three-game series Won't be known until pregame practice, but he seems to have escaped serious injury.

City, state and Federal Government eanployes, more than 300,000 of them, partici pate in drives each year to help raise money for the 425 hospital, health and welfare agencies of the Greater New York Fund:

The City Council was urged yesterday to ask the State Board of Welfare to change its rules to permit the city's Welfare Department "to carry out a widespread educational and informational program on birth control and family planning."

HONG KONG, May 26-- Clarence C. Adams, American Korean war turncoat who arrived here this morning from Communist China., faces questioning by consular officials before he is readmitted to the United States, but he is not expected to have any difficulties.
