The Federal Reserve kept the credit markets on tight rein during the week ended Wednesday, figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York indicated.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., May 26 (UPI)--Three exceptionally bright high school students were turned over to Juvenile Court today after being accused of stealing chemicals so they could manufacture hallucinatory drugs and sell them to their fellow students.
A gain of 800 million gallons in New York City's water supply was recorded in the 24-hour period that ended at 8 A.M. yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 26--The House passed a bill tonight increasing the minimum, wage and expanding its coverage, but balked at raising the rate to $1.60 before 1969.
ALBANY, May 26 (AP)-- William J. Dawson, former Cohoes Democratic party chairman, was found guilty today on two of three counts of evading $68,415 in income taxes over a three-year period.
Mary Barnette, a young flutist from Quincy, Fla., was heard at Carnegie Recital Hall last night.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 26 (AP)--Bob Barton drove in a run with a pinch-hit sacrifice fly in the 14th inning today to give unbeaten Juan Marichal his ninth victory of the season as San Francisco edged the Philadelphia Phillies, 1-0.
WASHINGTON, May 26-- Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon gave economics a priority over Vietnam as a political issue today.
Sir G. Edward Beharrell, the Chairman, in the course of his speech at the 67th Annual General Meeting of the Dunlop Rubber Company Limited in London on May 23rd, said:--

About 5,000 air passengers to Spain and Portugal this summer will be rerouted because of restrictions placed an two United States carriers by the two countries, according to spokesmen for the airlines.
Parks Commissioner Thomas P.F. Hoving has agreed to stop trapping cats in Central Park, and thereby won postponement of a court suit threatened by the Save a Cat League.
Public confidence in the elective process is the foundation of public confidence in government. There is no higher duty of a democratic government than to insure that confidence.

Dolphins who go to college now get summer vacations. Two bottle-nosed dolphins arrived at the New York Aquarium yesterday for what the aquarium's director, Dr. Ross F. Nigrelli, said would be a "pleasant summer vacation." "We won't force them to do anything they don't want to do," he said, referring to the 7 -foot mammals.
GOVERNOR ROCKEFELLER announced plans yes terday to set up guidance centers in the state to help women who "are seeking a way to a deeper self-fulfillment through usefulness."
David Rockefeller, president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, endorsed last night a "limited and temporary" across-theboard increase in personal and corporate income taxes.

Seatrain Lines, on the heels of receiving a $10,850,000, twoyear contract with the Federal Government for the use of three of its ships in a "multipurpose cargo system" for the movement of military cargoes, announced yesterday a major expansion of its regular commercial services.

THE twin-engined jet plane taxied to a halt at a corner of the Newark airport just before noon yesterday. The plane was sleekly handsome, a white body with blue cowling and a red stripe. Modestly lettered on the red band was the identification, "Arnold Palmer." Grinning behind the glass on the pilot's side of the cockpit was Arnold Palmer.
The National Dairy Products Corporation is entering the meat-products business through the acquisition of Brains Food Products, Ltd., of Bristol, England.

BRASILIA, May 26--General of the Army Artur Costa e Silva accepted the ruling party's presidential nomination today, declaring that he would be a faithful "continuer of the patriotic work" of Brazil's present government. The nomination is tantamount to election.

Directors of the Pennsylvania and the New York Central railroads at meetings yesterday voted to accept the conditions set by the Interstate Commerce Commission for approving the merger of the two roads.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) The Social Security Administration said today that all its district offices would be open regular hours Monday Memorial Day.

Four major lumber associations reported an increase of 6.4 per cent in production for the week ended May 21 compared with the level in the corresponding 1965 week. Output fell 1.3 per cent from the preceding week.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., May 27 Thomas F. McAndrews, former secretary to the late Mayor James J. Walker of New York and a former justice of the Court of Special Sessions in New York, died today at All Souls Hospital. He was 77 years old.

HELSINKI, Finland, May 27 (Reuters) A four-party coalition Government was sworn in here today, bringing in Communists for the first time since 1948 and ending six weeks of indecision about Finland's leadership.
LOS ANGELES, May 27 The New York Mets had one of their outstandingly bad innings of all time tonight as Claude Osteen shut them out for the Los Angeles Dodgers, 4-0, on three singles.

BATON ROUGE, May 27 (UPI) Carol Mann, a Buffalo golfer who has won tournaments this year, shot a recordbreaking five-under-par 67 today to take the first-round lead in the $10,000 Baton Rouge invitation tournament.

The bond market closed out the week by continuing to decline yesterday. The money market wound up tighter than ever, with bankers' acceptance rates going up and Federal funds trading at 5 per cent in the largest volume so far.
Eighteenth-century French and American furniture continues to be in the height of fashion for collectors. Prices for 18th-century works reach new highs regularly.
RAHWAY, N.J., May 27 A Nobel prize-winning biochemist said today that the outpouring of great discoveries in medical and biological research of the last few decades might be coming to an end.

Met with Farris Bryant, director of the Office of Emergency Planning; saw the Rev. Calvin Thielman; conferred with members of the National Security Council; met with Secretary of State Rusk, Defense Secretary McNamara and special assistants Walt Rostow, Robert Komer and Bill D. Moyers; conferred with roving Ambassador W. Averell Harriman; saw Mexican Ambassador Hugo Margain.
The Belding Heminway Company, producer of fabrics, threads and chemicals, announced yesterday the election of Lester Avnet as a director and a member of the executive committee.
LONDON, May 27 A delegation representing the Federation of South Arabia is pressing Britain for a defense guarantee when it becomes independent in 1968.
TWO New York Protestant churches one Presbyterian, the other Methodist have merged to form one congregation.
A new toy, an obsolete World Wax II observation plane, was deposited yesterday in the backyard of Mrs. John F. Kennedy's home in Hyannis Port, Mass.
WASHINGTON, May 27--Secretary of State Dean Rusk chided Congress today for not having supported Administration efforts to promote new agreements with the Communist nations of Europe.
Interest rates at home and abroad continue to attract the close attention of bankers, economists and commentators.
WASHINGTON, May 27 A Presidential emergency board today concluded formal hearings in a major airline labor dispute and began to prepare recommendations for resolving it.

The evacuation of American and other foreign civilians from Hue, following the sacking of the U.S.I.A. library by Buddhist students, marks as ominous turn in the internal political struggle in South Vietnam.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, May 27 Indonesia's undeclared war against Malaysia has unofficially ended, Abdul Razak, Acting Prime Minister of Malaysia, announced today.

Martin J. Travers, the Buffalo banker, will resign as executive vice president of the Marine Midland Trust Company of Western New York, largest in the city, to become president and chief administrative officer of the Liberty National Bank and Trust Company, third largest, E. Perry Spink, president of Liberty, said yesterday.
The Buildings Department moved yesterday to reduce a 13-week backlog of 835 applications for construction on Staten Island.

The Radio Corporation of America and Hoffman-La Roche, Inc., headquartered in Nutley, N.J., announced yesterday an agreement to collaborate in the development, production and marketing of new medical devices.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Section), May 27 A spokesman for Harry S. Truman said today that the former President would come to the groundbreaking for the peace center named for him at Hebrew University if at all possible. The ceremony is set for July 11.
Experts said yesterday that adoption of Assembly Speaker Anthony J. Travia's tax plan for the city without modification would force an increase of at least 5 cents in the transit fare.
The National Maritime Union has won an important demand after long negotiations with seven American ship lines on the size of the unlicensed crews aboard new automated cargo ships.

ELATH, Israel, May 27 (AP) Dr. Bernard E. Donovan, New York City's School Superintendent, has proposed teacher and pupil exchanges between New York and Israel such as the exchanges New York has with Norway, Japan and Britain.
CHICAGO, May 27 The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., disassociated himself today from a "Black Nationalist" stand taken by the new chairman of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee.

FOR the contemporary sculptor, the attractions of Italy are many and hazardous. He is surrounded by monuments of a great past. He lives, virtually, in a museum. Venerable trarditions of craftsmanship in stone carving and foundry work still flourish. Ancient masterpieces abound, and the weight of history exerts an unremitting pressure on the artistic consciousness.

Moccasin, the Claiborne Farm's filly who won all her races last year, was rated at 4-5 against 11 rivals in the Acorn Stakes at Aqueduct today. For 3-year-olds at a mile, the Acorn is the first part of the New York Racing Association's triple crown for fillies, the other sections being the Mother Goose at 1 1/8 miles and the Coaching Club American Oaks at 1 miles.

HUE, South Vietnam, May 27 Lieut. Gen. Nguyen Chanh Thi, whose dismissal as I Army Corps commander March 10 precipitated the current political crisis in South Vietnam, held a conference in Chulai today with Premier Nguyen Cao Ky.

ROCKFORD, Ill., May 27 Adolph Germer, former national secretary of the Socialist party and a vice president of the United Mine Workers of America, died yesterday of cancer in the Swedish American Hospital here. He was 86 years old and lived here at 227 South Highland Avenue.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 26 The Brazilian Federal Telecommunication Commission ordered a major television group today to change its contractual relationship with Time, Inc., to conform with Brazilian laws.
BAKERSFIELD, Calif., May 27 Seven Molotov cocktails were thrown last night in the Negro district here.

Pan American World Airways preliminary statement for April issued yesterday indicated net earnings for the month of $3,908,000, or 25 cents a share. This is contrasted to a net loss of $1,349,000 in April last year, when a strike during the first 10 days of the month halted most of the company's flights.

Villanova made a strong bid for the team title as the I.C.4-A's 90th annual outdoor track and field championships began yesterday on Randalls Island. But Maryland's defenders, despite a slight setback in the javelin throw, remained the team to beat in today's 18 finals.

"T.S. Eliot: The Man and His Work," edited by Allen Tate, will be published by Delacorte in September. The book will be a hardcover edition of the special winter issue of The Sewanee Review devoted to the late poet. Contributors include I.A. Richards, Sir Herbert Read, Stephen Spender and Ezra Pound. There will be sixteen pages of photographs of Mr. Eliot.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 27 Dallas S. Townsend Sr., a New York lawyer and former Assistant United States Attorney General, died today at his home here. He was 77 years old and lived at 10 Crestmont Road.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., May 27 A second attempt to launch the Gemini 9 space mission was delayed 24 hours today, until Wednesday, to give technicians more time to check out the Atlas rocket.

Miss Melba Louise Halleran, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin J. Halleran of Jericho, L.I., was married yesterday afternoon to Richard M. Neville, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice J. Neville of this city. The Rev. Henry J. Bertels performed the ceremony at the Corpus Christi Roman Catholic Church.
OKLAHOMA CITY, May 27 (AP) Johnny Pott retained his four-stroke lead in the $57,000 Oklahoma City open golf tournament today by shooting a 69 for 133.
Savings accounts at savings banks and savings and loan associations declined a total of $1,36,000,000 during April, a spokesman for the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said yesterday.
"BACH AND HIS SONS," a National Educational Television Network hour-long special presented on Channel 13 last night, bore a twopronged subtitle, "The Overwhelming Legacy."
AUSABLE FORKS, N.Y., May 27, (UPI)--Dr. John B. Schwedel, of 230 West 79th Street, New York, drowned in the Saranac River today.

LONDON, May 27 The new Cunarder, better known at this stage as the Q-4, will be launched and completed six months later than originally expected because of labor shortages in the Clyde River shipyard near Glasgow where she is being built.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 27 Premier Levi Eshkol left today for a threeweek tour of Africa, a continent that, he said, shared with Israel the achievement of having "cast off slavery for freedom in the same epoch of mankind's history."

PRINCETON JUNCTION, N.J., May 27 A nun was killed and four persons were injured this afternoon when a metal spring fell from a passing freight train and crashed through a window of a Pennsylvania Railroad passenger train.

When Mrs. H. was married, she was 16 years old. Within a year, she and her husband had their first child. Mr. H., an ambitious but uneducated man, provided a fairly comfortable home for his family by work ing on two unskilled jobs, but he was unable to save money for emergencies.
The police arrested two youths yesterday on charges of stealing mailed contributions intended for the Police Athletic League.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 27 (AP) The Philadelphia Phillies scored six runs in the fifth inning tonight and trounced the San Francisco Giants, 9-2, behind the six-hit pitching of Larry Jackson.

CHICAGO, May 27 Prof. William H. Zachariasen, a physicist at the University of Chicago, suggested today that the 2,400-student undergraduate college at the university be closed if more sit-ins developed.

ALBANY, May 27 A Governor's committee has been asked to study whether railroad tracks could be added to proposed bridges over the Long Island Sound to tie the Long, Island Rail Road into a highspeed Boston-Washington rail operation.
Two firemen interrupted their brass polishing chores in the Engine 2 firehouse at 43rd Street near Tenth Avenue yester day and captured a man who was charged with burglarizing a neighbor's apartment.
Parks Commissioner Thomas P.F. Hoving disclosed yesterday plans for his next pastoral happening.

PHILADELPHIA, May 27 (AP) Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation used a low-flying helicopter and a team of men on foot and in automobiles in an unsuccessful attempt to catch a person who threatened to blow up a Pennsylvania Railroad train unless paid $100,000.
ITT World Communications, Inc., filed yesterday, with the Federal Communications Commission rate cuts of "up to 50 per cent" in monthly rental charges for international leased channel cable service.
WASHINGTON, May 27 President Johnson named 121 youths today as Presidential Scholars of 1966.
LONDON, May 27 (UPI) The Soviet Union says that charges that it discriminates against its Jewish citizens are absurd.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman announced today that an additional $313million worth of food was being made available to India under this country's Food-forPeace program.
THE corner delicatessen of the future or today, in many cases will be situated at the intersection of frozen foods and canned goods in a large supermarket.

OAKLAND, Calif., May 27 (UPI) Cordon (Scotty) Stirling, the general manager of the Oakland Raiders of the American Football League, reasserted today that his club had a "legal and binding" contract for the services of Roman Gabriel, a quarterback for the Los Angeles Rams of the National Football League, after the 1966 season.
MONTICELLO, N.Y., May 27 (UPI) Tony Morales, a sparring partner for Doug Jones, was unconscious and in critical condition today with severe brain damage.

WETUMPKA, Ala., May 27 (UPI) A Negro mother who refused to have her soldier son interred in a pauper's grave said today that she was content that he would be buried in a national cemetery although it is more than 100 miles away.

SANTO DOMINGO, May 27 (UPI) The Vice Presidential candidate of Dr. Rafael F. Bonnelly's National Integration Movement resigned today and announced his support of Dr. Joaquin Balaguer in the general elections June 1.

FIRE ISLAND, L.I., May 27 A proposal made today to add Gardiners Island and part of Shelter Island to the Fire Island National Seashore won quick support from Secretary of the Interior Steward L. Udall.

The Israeli Government has donated land for two housing projects to allow Jewish concentration-camp survivors living in the United States and Canada to be reunited with their families in Israel, it was announced yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, May 27 A threatened walkout of 1,000 of the city's 1,138 firemen was averted at the last minute today when Mayor Alfonso J. Cervantes announced a tentative wage agreement with Local 73 Of the International Firefighter's Association.
GENEVA, May 27 The nations of the world spent more than $130-billion on defense in 1964, according to a United States study.
WASHINGTON, May 27 Organized labor turned its attention to the Senate today in the hope of salvaging two pet bills from an uncooperative Congress.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) New claims for unemployment insurance dropped to a 13-year low of 146,700 last week, the Labor Department said today.

Joel Edward Horlen had an insoluble problem last night. He was supposed to pitch the Chicago White sox to victory over the New York Yankees at Yankee Stadium. Instead, he was the loser in a 4-1 game that enabled the Yankees to take sixth place away from the White Sox.
ST. LOUIS, May 27 (AP) The latest model of the Phantom jet zoomed into the sky today on its first public flight. Its predecessor is reponsible for 11 of the 12 enemy planes shot down in Vietnam.
BRASILIA, May 27 President Humberto Castelo Branco has thwarted three army generals' attempts to take over the governorships of three key states.
FAYETTE, Miss., May 27 (AP) A civil rights leader, speaking from the courthouse steps in the end of a protest march, said tonight that any future racial violence here would be met with violence.
CLEVELAND, May 27 (AP) Rocky Colavito's ninth-inning single brought Max Alvis home with the winning run tonight as the Cleveland Indians edged the Minnesota Twins, 5-4.

Troy Meadows, which lie in Morris County, New Jersey only some twenty miles west of Times Square are regarded by ornithologists as one of the best fresh-water marshes in the Northeast. They are critically important for ducks, bitterns and other marshloving birds. A court case now pending may determine whether this habitat, unique in the metropolitan area, will be seriously damaged.
ALGIERS, May 27 The Algerian Government declared tonight that it would take over the insurance business here starting tomorrow.

MONTREAL, May 27 (Canadian Press) Judge Rend Lippe said today representatives of management and labor had been unable to reach an agreement in the strike of 4,250 longshoremen at three Quebec ports. The walkout, which began May 9, was called to obtain pay raises.
The Congress of Racial Equality expelled its Mount Vernon group yesterday because of dissension growing out of an antiSemitic remark made by a former officer of the group.

For grain traders who live by charts, soybean futures provided a neat entry yesterday at a new high level. The key July contract set a lifetime high of $3.15 cents a bushel, compared with the previous high of $3.13 5/8 reached Thursday.

WASHINGTON, May 27 The Department of Housing and Urban Development announced today a grant of $2.7-million to California to develop new techniques of transportation aimed at "unlocking" the ghettos of Los Angeles.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) The United States and Brit ain agreed today on a broad expansion of the air routes curently operated by the carriers of the two nations.
A series of animated short subjects created by John and Faith Hubley will be presented from June 7 through June 12 at the Gallery of Modern Art at Columbus Circle.
PARIS, May 27 The 15 members of the North Atlantic alliance have been asked to consider the possibility of an East-West conference on European security.
James A. Farley, practicing political sage and soft-drink salesman extraordinary, celebrated his 78th birthday yesterday, three days early, at a breakfast for the press at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
A 59-year-old ulcer patient underwent surgery this week in which he was transfused with three pints of his own blood.

DETROIT, May 27 Gov. Carl E. Sanders of Georgia sought today to lead the members of the Southern Baptist Convention as individuals onto the high road of social action and personal involvement in the nation's social and political problems.
DETROIT, May 27 (AP) The Detroit Lions announced today they had reinstated Gail Cogdill, an end, after a 77-day suspension and fined him $1,000.

Ignorance about conditions in the United States, taxation at home and central planning policies of European governments were cited as reasons this week why there is not more European investment in the United States.
PHILADELPHIA, May 27 Charles Palmer of Ridley Park, a lawyer in Delaware County and oldest alumnus of Swarthmore College, died Wednesday at the age of 102.

HICKSVILLE, L.I., May 27 Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Brindley have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Ellen Brindley, to Frederick Francis Pfeiffer Jr., son of Mrs. Pfeiffer of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Dr. Pfeiffer.
HOME decorators who want to use fashionable crewel embroidered textiles from Kashmir must reckon with special hazards. Their plans may be sent awry by war, famine or weather.
SAIGON, May 27 A group of Buddhist leaders voted today to continue to press for the end of rule by South Vietnam's military junta, informed sources said.
David L. Cole, chief mediator in the newspaper strike, reported a "major breakthrough" yesterday in the negotiations between the striking Newspaper Guild and the World Journal Tribune, Inc.
PITTSBURGH, May 27 (UPI) Two high school students took a break from classes yesterday to rob a bank and then went back to school, the police said today.

MOBILE, Ala., May 27 (AP) A Federal judge ordered officials of three rural Alabama counties today to permit Federal observers to watch while illiterates are assisted in voting, provided the voter requests it.

Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes was readmitted to St. Vincent's Hospital yesterday after suffering chest pains at his home at 79-33 215th Street, Bayside, Queens. The Commissioner had left the hospital only 16 days ago after suffering his second heart attack in 30 months.
The New York City Center of Music and Drama ended its fiscal year April 30 with an operating loss of $1,663,364, it was announced yesterday by Morton Baum, the civic group's chairman of the board.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., May 27 Mrs. Kathleen Aston Casey was married today to Orlan Johnson in her home here. The Rev. Martin Duffy of the Mount Vernon Congregational Church performed the ceremony.
The American Motors Corporation announced yesterday it would resume car production at its Wisconsin plants next Wednesday.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 27 A chancery judge struck down today an Arkansas law that prohibits the teaching of evolution in the public schools. He found it to be an unconstitutional restriction on inquiry. Chancellor Murray O. Reed ruled that the law, adopted in a statewide vote in 1928, "tends to hinder the quest for knowledge, restrict the freedom to learn and restrain the freedom to teach."
WASHINGTON, May 27 The first of an initial print order of 2 million copies of the first United States international airmail postal card went on sale here today.
The London stock market scored further gains yesterday despite a late flurry of profittaking before the Whit Monday weekend.
The Bell System believes that "the zone of reasonableness" for earnings on its net investment "would be a range of 7 to 8 per cent."
LONDON, May 27 (AP) The lure of higher pay, quicker advancement and better working conditions in the United States reached into the ranks of British airline pilots today.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 27 A senior Yugoslav Communist has outlined the Government's plans for permitting Western businessmen to set up profit-sharing ventures here.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 27 (AP) The last practice session for the 50th 500-mile race on Monday at the Indianapolis Speedway followed a monthlong script today. Mario Andretti again ran faster than anybody else.
Mari Tsumura, a 19-year-old violinist, won first prize in the 1966 Merriweather Post Contest. The finals were held in Washington on Thursday night.

A FRESH orange cake, crunchy with oats and nuts, may be the quick answer to weekend breakfast or brunch appetites. Equally good as an after-school snack or to serve with coffee for adults, the orange-oatmeal cake given below may be served warm or cold.

"M. Jullien," according to the ad in this newspaper, "has the honor to announce that his first series of GRAND CONCERTS VOCAL AND INSTRUMENTAL in the United States of America will commence on Monday, August 29, and be continued EVERY EVENING for ONE MONTH ONLY." So New York and the United States of America were introduced to their first Prom concerts--113 years ago this summer at Castle Garden on the Battery.

Washington, May 27 The index of primary market prices edged down 0.1 per cent to 105.2 (1957-59 equals 100) during the week ended May 24, the Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Prices moved lower for farm products and processed foods but averaged unchanged for industrial commodities.

Stockholders of the Ogden Corporation elected Mrs. Tillie Lewis yesterday as the company's first woman director. She is president and founder of Tillie Lewis Foods, Inc., a California fruit and vegetable canner acquired by Ogden last January.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) Luci Johnson will have all that the old adage requires: something old, something new, something borrowed, something blue and a sixpence for her shoe.
The Coast Guard Cutter Campbell, of the Third Coast Guard District, will be the scene of ceremonies marking two changes of command within a three-day period and 430 miles apart.
EPSOM, England, May 27 The Oaks Stakes, a classic race for 3-year-old fillies after which the American counterpart was named, went to the 11-10 favorite, Valoris, here today.

ROME, May 27 Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton opened their studio Wednesday for diplomatic representatives of Britain and the United States to visit the set where they are filming Shakespeare's "The Taming of the Shrew."

MADRID, May 27 Roman Catholic lay organizations in Spain and 30 leading Catalonian intellectuals have protested the "tendentious" treatment by Spanish information media of the police beatings of Barcelona priests on May 11.

CHICAGO, May 27--Friends of 50 veterans at the Great Lakes Naval Hospital charged today that the Conrad Hilton Hotel had refused to let the veterans attend an ice show because their presence would depress other guests.

GUATEMALA, May 27 Guerrillas last night kidnapped the Vice President of the Congress, Hector Menendez de la Riva, only few blocks from his residence as he was driving home from a downtown theater. Mr. Menendez, 54 years old, is chairman of the Institutional Democratic party which came out second best in Guatemala's general elections on March 6.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) The Senate confirmed today the nomination of Eugene M. Locke, Texas friend of President Johnson, to be Ambassador to Pakistan.

The American Medical Association has informed its member medical societies and associations that physicians may separate their treatment of welfare clients from that of their private patients without violating the Civil Rights Act of 1964.
The $1,000-a-year raise won by the city's nurses ended a series of improbable events that has altered the image of nursing, and may well affect the quality of nursing care throughout the country.

Thirty-two sand hogs working in a tunnel under Staten Island chose 6 hours of overtime yesterday afternoon to climbing a 945-foot ladder. This would be the equivalent to walking up to the 87th floor of the Empire State Building.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 27--Strong positive action to build a dozen or more regional sub-centers for offices, stores, universities and other major activities is being proposed as part of a second New York metropolitan regional plan.

HONG KONG, May 27 Clarence C. Adams, the 37-year-old Korean war defector from Memphis, said here today that he had acted voluntarily and on his own in making two tape recordings in Peking that called on United States soldiers to get out of Vietnam.
Mayor Lindsay swore in four officials yesterday, including Carl Madonick, former Assistant State Attorney General, who became Commissioner of Real Estate at $25,000 a year.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, May 27 The problem fac ing Flemming Flindt in his appointment as chief of the Royal Danish Ballet is enlarging the company's international repertory.
KIEV, U.S.S.R., May 24 "Why don't you come to spend your vacation with us in Kiev?" a man here wrote to his cousins in Moscow.

Now that the analysts attending the yearly Financial Analysts Federation convention here have packed away their ideas on favorite stocks, their pet jokes and their clothes and gone home, the question arises as to just what they think the outlook is for the stock market. Their convention here couldn't have been more timely.
WASHINGTON, May 27The familiar telephone PBX, or private branch ex change, with its tangle of cords and plugs, is disappearing from modern offices.

MOSCOW, May 27 The Defense Ministers of the Eastern Europe military alliance, the Warsaw Pact, opened a planning session here today preparatory to a summit meeting of the European Communist Governments, informed sources said.

CHANTILLY, France, May 27 (AP) Bob Falkenburg of Los Angeles, a former Wimbledon tennis champion, and Tom Draper of Detroit led five Americans into the second round of the French amateur golf championship today. Seven Americans were beaten.
The marriage of Miss Louise Lombard Stillman to Lewis Edward Lehrman took place yesterday afternoon at the River Club. Judge Pelham St. George Bissell of the Civil Court performed the ceremony.

Anyone who has ever dreamed of being President of the United States has a hard time convincing the doubters that there is any real recovery, ever, from Potomac fever. But Governor Rockefeller has tried it again. At a political rally this week he said: "I speak as one who has taken himself out of national con tention, completely and forever, without reservation."

LOS ANGELES, May 27 The reliability of Mrs. Leonard Deadwyler's testimony that her husband was shot without provocation by a policeman in the Watts Negro district on May 7 was both supported and questioned today as a score of witnesses appeared at the seventh day's session of a county coroner's inquest.
MOSCOW, May 27 Tass, the Soviet press agency, warned today that Israel was activating "aggressive and extremist forces" against "neighboring Arab states."

LONDON, May 27 Britain has begun wielding the big stick in antitrust enforcement, and is hearing some of the same kind of criticism that has been fired at the Department of Justice in the United States.

Deering Milliken, Inc., one of the country's leading textiles producers, will announce on Tuesday a new chemical treatment that will eliminate the stain-retention characteristic of durable-press fabrics.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) Senator Wayne Morse, of Oregon said today that he will vote in November for Gov. Mark O. Hatfield, a Republican, if the Governor "continues to stand for the foreign policy he has enunciated."
Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary declared yesterday that he opposed police membership in the John Birch Society, "but legally I can't do anything about it."
A deaf mute who sued the city for injuries allegedly caused by police brutality was awarded $90,000 by a Brooklyn jury in State Supreme Court yesterday.
Dr. Thomas G. Davis, a surgeon specializing in eye, ear and nose operations, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 98 Bay Street, City Island, the Bronx. He was 83 years old.
KAMPALA, Uganda, May 27 President Milton Obote said today that there was no trace of the Kabaka of Buganda when Uganda Army troops overran his palace.

Faulty bookkeeping and financial practices are no novelty at Haryou-Act, the Harlem antipoverty agency. The latest example is the revelation that the agency owes the Federal Government $290,000 in withholding taxes, money it apparently failed to set aside or that it somehow lost track of.

LONDON, May 27 (UPI) Britain is considering the monopoly aspects of a $7-million bid by Litton Industries, Inc., to buy this country's last major typewriter concern, the Imperial Typewriter Company, a Treasury spokesman said today.
Water restrictions were lifted temporarily yesterday in Stamford, Conn., and the relaxation of restrictions in effect in northern New Jersey since April were extended until at least July 15.
CINCINNATI, May 27 Jerome Swartsberg, president of Shillito's Department Store since March 30, 1965, died of an aneurism after surgery at the Holmes Hospital here today. He was 54 years old.

Mr. and Mrs. David H. Rosenberg of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss. Elissa Rosenberg, to Leon Levine of East Orange, N.J., son of Mrs. Sylvia Levine of Brooklyn. The wedding will take place in September.
WASHINGTON, May 27--Secretary of State Dean Rusk tried today to deflate a quiet Pentagon campaign by stating that he had no evidence of a build-up of North Vietnamese troops in Cambodia.

MONTREAL, May 27 Secretary General Thant unfurled the United Nations flag here today in ceremonies marking the beginning of construction of the United Nations pavilion at the Expo 67 world exhibition, sociations.
WASHINGTON, May 27--Rates for three-month and six-month bills showed small movements in opposite directions at today's auction, compared with the sale last Monday, the Treasury disclosed tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, May 27 The Federal Bureau of Investigation's practice of viewing suspects without their knowledge by means of a two-way mirror was upheld today by the United States Court of Appeals, here.
ARTHUR GEORGE KLEIN'S first Govern ment job was as a Securities and Exchange Commission lawyer under Joseph P. Kennedy.
The Avco Corporation has received two Army contracts totaling $40.9-million to product helicopter jet engines.

A unit of the National Council of Churches made public yesterday the English text of a letter of protest from two Russain Orthodox priests in Moscow to the President of the Supreme Soviet, Nikolai V. Podgorny.

HAVANA, May 27 (AP) Premier Fidel Castro ordered a state of alert tonight for the Cuban armed forces "and all the Cuban people" as a result of what he called provocations by the United States against his country.

The Outlet Company, which owns and operates a department store in Providence, R.I., and two branch stores in that state, announced yesterday it would acquire the Cherry Webb Company, a major retailing complex, involving a chain of seven stores throughout southern New England.

Mrs. Elinor Gates Clendenin, a well-known amateur golfer of the nineteen-twenties under the name of Mrs. Norman K. Toerge, died Thursday at the Le Roy Hospital, 40 East 61st Street. She was 70 years old and lived at 3 East 77th Street.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., May 27 A Suffolk lawyer was found guilty last night of stealing $25,700 from a Rockville Centre church.

MILWAUKEE, May 27 The Milwaukee Repertory Theater today hired a Turkish-born actor, playwright and director as its new artistic director. He is Tunc Yalman, who signed a three-year contract and succeeds John A. McQuiggan, new co-director of the Trinity Square Playhouse, Providence, R.I.
DETROIT, May 27 (AP) The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, the radio priest of the nineteenthirties, will retire next month as pastor of the Shrine of the Little Flower in Royal Oak.

GRANADA, Spain, May 27 Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler told European bankers and financial officials today that a quick rebalancing of United States international payments would seriously hurt "the economies, the aspirations and, indeed, the safety of all the nations of the free world."
Otto Preminger, who has been known to be icy with critics of his films, will appear next winter in two half-hour episodes of "Batman" as the evil Mr. Freeze.

HOCKESSIN, Del., May 27 Miss Ann Jackson Loftin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Earl Loftin of Charlotte, N.C., was married this afternoon to Peter Samuel Robinson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Apel Robinson of Avondale, Pa. The Rev. Anthony DiMichele performed the ceremony at St. Mary's of the Assumption Roman Catholic Church.
Horace L. Santford, whose career with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York took him from page to vice president, will retire July 1, the bank announced yesterday.

The film version of Edward Albee's "Who's Afraid of Virgiina Wolf?" is presenting Jack J. Valenti, former Presidential assistant, with his first major problem since he became president of the Motion Picture Association of America several weeks ago.

WASHINGTON, May 27 A former administrative assistant of Senator Thomas J. Dodd testified today that the Senator "had frequent contacts" in 1961 with Michael Struelens, then a registered lobbyist in Washington for the rebel Congolese province of Katanga and its president, Moise Tshombe.

MILAN, Italy Milan is a city of more than a million and a half people in the north of Italy that is just ugly enough to have encouraged a number of architects and designers to try to chance it inside and out.

LANSING, Mich., May 27 (UPI) Fire forced 118 persons, including 16 Michigan legislators, from a hotel near the State Capitol early today. A State Senator collapsed and died after staggering through smoke-filled hallways to awaken residents.
DETROIT, May 27 (AP) Willie Smith drove in two runs and scored another tonight as the California Angels edged Detroit, 3-2.

DEVON, Pa., May 27 Highfield's Town and Country, owned and ridden by Debbie Wolfe of Elkins Park, Pa., won a pony hunter class at the Devon Horse Show today and in the process whipped the national champion.

THEY do not say that the pen is mightier than the sword. They loathe both. But the hapless British "Virgin Soldiers" of this wildly black-humored novel serve in what one of their protest songs calls "the filing cabinet cavalry."

The most important thing about President Johnson's major speech to African ambassadors this week was that it was made at all. It was his first speech on African policy since he became President and the first by as American Chief Executive on the subject since John F. Kennedy spoke briefly on "Africa Day" in 1961.
LONDON, May 27 Billy Graham has come to London, bent on saving this city from its excesses with his own brand of hellfire and damnation.
TOKYO, May 27 Indonesia's new Government will adopt a balanced foreign policy as part of its national recovery program, the island republic's top economic authority declared today.

ITHACA, N.Y., May. 27--The last of the big cup races of the season preparatory to the championships of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association and the Yale-Harvard regatta on June 18 will be held here tomorrow.
Two chartered jet planes will carry the Metropolitan Opera Company from Detroit to Paris early tomorrow morning. The company will end its six-week United States tour in Detroit tonight.

The 19th game of the title match between the world chess champion, Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, and his compatriot, Boris Spassky, was adjourned last night at Moscow's Variety Theatre after White's sealed 41st move.
MOSCOW, May 27--A worldwide organization promoting tourism urged today that visas, customs formalities and other hindrances to travel be abolished during International Tourist Year in 1967.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 27 Yugoslav and other Eastern European diplomats are reading a note of conciliation toward the Soviet Union into the latest series of speeches by Nicolae Ceausescu, the Rumanian Communist leader.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (UPI)--A House Information subcommittee today rejected Selective Service arguments for withholding the names of draftees. It called on Lieut. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, the draft director, to halt "arbitrary and unauthorized censorship."

Despite a sudden shower that brought umbrellas up and paintings down for a brief period, the 69th annual spring show of the Washington Square Outdoor Art Exhibit was opened officially yesterday afternoon. Mrs. John Lindsay, wife of the Mayor, accompanied by her 5-yearold son, John Jr., did the honors, falling slightly behind schedule as a result of the rain.
LONDON, May 27 The Consolidated Foods Corporation of Chicago has been negotiating to acquire one of the biggest and most successful restaurant chains in Britain.
LONDON, May 27 Billy Graham has come to London, bent on saving this city from its excesses with his own brand of hellfire and damnation.

Miss Dorothy West Platt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clemens L. Platt of Bayville, L.I., and Gerard Scott Frederick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter G. Frederick of Bayside, Queens, were married here yesterday. The Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken performed the ceremony at the Riverside Church.

HUELVA, Spain, May 27 (AP) Lost in clouds and low on fuel, six French pilots parachuted safely from their Mystere IV jet fighter planes today within reach of well-equipped Spanish-American military airports.

James D. Forrester, dean of the Arizona College of Mines, testified in Federal Court here yesterday that the Texas Gulf Sulphur Company did not have enough information by the evening of April 10, 1964, to establish that its Timmins, Ont., copper strike had commercial potential.

PARIS, May 27 The Defense Ministry said in a communique tonight that the six Mystere IV jet planes that crashed in Southern Spain today were unable to land at Seville, probably because of weather conditions.
The United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday an increase of $2 a ton on cold-finished steel bars.

More than 300 poor people and antipoverty workers picketed the Madison Avenue headquarters of the Office of Economic Opportunity yesterday, demanding more money for city programs, but they received only a pelting by water bombs apparently thrown by irate office workers.

PARIS, May 27 (AP) Dennis Ralston and Clark Graebner, members of the United States Davis Cup squad, battled their way today into the fourth round, but leg cramps felled their teammate, Cliff Richey, in the French national tennis championships.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 27 (AP) Sixteen railroads were forced today to resume operations in Indiana with full crews following refusal by United States Supreme Court Justice Tom C. Clark to stay a mandate by the Indiana Supreme Court.
HOLMDEL, N.J., May 27 Frederick Frelinghuysen, a member of Pitney, Hardin Kipp, a Newark law firm, died yesterday in his home here of a coronary occlusion. He was 62 years old.
SURBRITON, England, May 27 (AP) Mary Ann Eisel of St. Louis gained the women's singles final of the Surrey tennis championships today with a 6-4, 4-6, 6-4 victory over Virginia Wade of Britain.

The police announced yesterday a round-the-clock patrol of West 15 Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues beginning today to cut down on excessive noise; jumping of curbs and other abuses by big trucks.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) Vice President Humphrey received presents and good wishes today from President Johnson on his 55th birthday.

SAIGON, May 27 (AP) South Vietnamese Army reports of a series of brisk fights put the Mekong delta back in the war's spotlight today. A spokesman said troops and planes killed 94 Vietcong in that region yesterday and 50 were reported captured.

EAST NORWALK, Conn., May 27 Mrs. Alice Verrycken Peterson, widow of John M. Peterson, a former publisher and advertising executive, died Wednesday after a long illness. She was 76 years old and lived on Cavray Road.
A late upswing carried the stock market to its sixth consecutive advance yesterday as volume sank to the lowest level since late last summer.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) The Defense Department said today it had cut its special draft call for doctors to 1,713 a reduction of nearly one-third.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 27 More yachts were sailing to the eastward in light airs at nightfall today than ever had participated in an East Coast distance race before.

BRUSSELS, May 27 Col. Francisco Caamano Deno, former leader of the constitutional, or rebel, forces in the Dominican Republic, declared today that the outcome of the June 1 Presidential election must be "respected by all political parties and by the armed forces."

WASHINGTON, May 27 Fred B. Black Jr. linked today the electronic eavesdropping on his hotel suite by the Federal Bureau of Investigation to the Government's investigation of Robert G. Baker and Las Vegas gambling activities.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP)--The United States proposed to Russia today that talks be held about Soviet fishing off United States waters and its impact on valuable fish stocks.

PARIS, May 27 In the window of a small bookstore on Rue Castellane are seven new books on Marshal Henri-Philippe Petain. He is on the cover of at least four national magazines this week, and L'Humanite devoted its entire second page to him today.
George Whitmore Jr., a 21year-old drifter, was sentenced in Brooklyn Supreme Court yesterday to five to ten years in prison for the attempted rape and assault of a 23-year-old Brooklyn mother.
Showers late in the day dampened the holiday optimism of thousands of New Yorkers who were leaving the city yesterday for the first long weekend of the beaching, boating and burning season.
HOUSTON, May 27 (AP) Willie Stargell and Bill Mazeroski each drove in two runs tonight to lead the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 6-0 victory over the Houston Astros.

The Gerber Products Company, Fremont, Mich., maker of various foods for babies, young children and adults, achieved record sales in the fiscal year ended March 31, but, it reported yesterday that earnings fell for the first time since fiscal 1959.
Confusion about bus signs in mid-Manhattan persists more than four months after Fifth and Madison Avenues were made one-way.
The eighth annual International House Ball will be held Friday in the residence at 500 Riverside Drive. Entertainment by foreign students will follow a feast-of-the-nations buffet.
A one-day decline on the American Stock Exchange ended yesterday as the market rose on small volume.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 27--The next morning being a Sunday, perhaps not too many people will mind being asked to stay for the ninth race at Roosevelt Raceway tomorrow night. The opportunity to sleep later the following day is likely to keep most of the fans at the track for Bret Hanover's "nonbetting" appearance in the Realization Pace.

Victor F. Zahodiakin, a Russian-born engineer and inventor who manufactured machinegun synchronizing controls for American military aircraft during World War II, died yesterday in his home at River Road and Morris Turnpike, Summit, N.J. He was 64 years old.

DENVER, May 27 (AP) An official of the American Newspaper Publishers Association said today that the newspaper business was healthier than ever, with a 39 per cent increase in employment since 1947.

A noisy dispute erupted at the Board of Elections office yesterday when supporters of Supreme Court Justice Samuel J. Silverman dashed in with his primary designating petitions either before, or after, the 5 P.M. deadline.
TOKYO, (Reuters)--Japan will increase car production by nearly 20 per cent to meet greater domestic and export needs during 1966, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry reports.

WINDSOR, Ont., May 28 (AP)--The future of United Nations peace-keeping efforts is being "seriously jeopardized" by the failure of governments to agree on financial and administrative aspects of the operations, Secretary General Thant said today.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 28--The Pell family wants another "fatt calfe" from New Rochelle in payment of a 1689 debt.
A man who impresses Mayor Lindsay by his "dynamism" has been chosen to direct the city's health services.
WASHINGTON, May 28-- The Soviet Union is developing a weather satellite capability and may soon release pictures to the world to prove it, space officials said this week.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., May 28 --Four skippers scored two victories each today as 60 boats in 10 classes competed in the first two races of the Tri Club's annual Memorial weekend regatta on Huntington Bay. The event is being conducted by the Huntington Yacht Club.

The Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations of America, in cooperation with similar international groups, will hold a special conference in Jerusalem next year to take up Jewish religious and cultural problems and to deal with such issues as poverty, hunger and civil rights.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 28--In 1965 the value of world exports soared to a new peak of $186-billion, exceeding the previous year's mark by 8 per cent.
TORREON, Mexico, May 24 --Cotton built this clean, modera city, one of the youngest in Mexico, but cotton will not provide for its future.

Questions of literary interest should be addressed to the Queries Editor, New York Times Book Review, Times Square, New York, N.Y. 10036. WASHINGTON, May 28-- Ever since the sun finally set on the British Empire the news out of London has gone from bad to worse. Gone are the stiff upper lip and the thin red line, gone with the empire. And what do we have in their place?

James Meredith, whose entry into the University of Mississippi touched off rioting in 1962, said yesterday that the Harlem Democrats for Action had withdrawn its designation of him as a delegate to the state Constitutional Convention, but he said that he might run as an independent.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 28 --In its continuing effort to put this sprawling prairie city of more than a million souls on America's cultural map, the Performing Arts Foundation of Kansas City has again rounded up a three-day international festival, which began last night.

MADISON, Wis., May 28-- David Carley, Democratic National Committeeman from Wisconsin who is seeking his party's nomination for Governor in the primary Sept. 13, plans to make his opposition to President Johnson's policies in Vietnam a campaign issue.

WICHITA, Kan., May 27-- Civil rights workers believe that an Oklahoma City school desegregation case argued here this week may produce a method for achieving comprehensive integration of classrooms across the country.
LONDON, May 28 (AP)-- Lynn Davies, Britain's longjump gold medalist at the 1964 Tokyo Olympic Games, won the long jump and the 100-yard dash in the British Games today.
PARIS, May 28--France and the Soviet Union have agreed on cooperation that may put them temporarily ahead of the United States in high-energy physics.

ANAHEIM, Calif., May 27-- Scientists seemed convinced this week of intelligent life in space, with a good chance of establishing contact with it in the next few decades. But there was an undercurrent of concern about the impact such life might have upon the earth.

AUSTIN, Tex., May 28--An Austin contributor to the Republican party has attacked the University of Texas Board of Regents' plan to use university funds for a library to house President Johnson's papers.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., May 28 --Paul Hermann, former Municipal manager of Madison Township in Middlesex County, took over duties as City Manager here this week. He is the third person to hold the post since last May when the present administration took office.

HOUSTON, May 28 (AP)-- Willie Stargell and Bob Bailey backed Woody Fryman's eighthit pitching with homers as the Pittsburgh Pirates beat Houston, 5-2, tonight for a split of their day-night program. The Astors won the afternoon game, 2-1.
SEABROOK, N.H. May 28 (AP)--Eight children and seven adults were injured tonight when a swing ride at a carnival tipped over.

BELGRADE, MAY 28--In the northern Yugoslav city of Ljubljana the other day a student attending a political meeting asked a high Communist party official, a woman, if he could pose a few questions without danger of reprisal. BRATTLEBORO, Vt., May 28 --In St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church today, Miss Dianne Louise Estabrook, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Udell Estabrook, was married to Peter Reynolds Cooke, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Negley Cooke of Armonk, N.Y.

THERE was a mighty roar from the gallery as Ben Hogan sank his final putt at the Olympic Club in San Francisco on that June day in 1955. They had just been witnesses to the making of history--or so they thought. This extraordinary little man had apparently won his fifth United States Open golf championship, a feat that had eluded Bobby Jones and Willie Anderson, hitherto tied with him at four. Hogan thought that, too.

A WEEK ago Friday a party was given for Philip Lieson Miller, who has just left the music division of the New York Public Library. He served there as chief since 1959, but had been there since 1906, and that is odd considering that he is only 60 years old, All--right, Say he came there in 1910.

MADISON, N.J., May 28-- Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Kohlschreiber have announced the engagement of their daughters, the Misses Barbara Ann and Carole Kohlschreiber.

BONN, May 28--In the test of wills between General de Gaulle and Chancellor Ludwig Erhard on the issue of French troops in West Germany, the general this week won the first round. At French insistence, Dr. Erhard made a "clear and unequivocal" statement to the Bundestag Wednesday night that the Federal Republic wants the French troops to remain here after they leave the NATO command. His statement cleared the way for negotiations.

SANTO DOMINGO, May 28 --Dr. Balaguer's decision to withdraw unless the election law was changed was reached after a week-long campaign swing through the Cibao region in the northwest part of the country.

THE New York Passport Agency at 630 Fifth Avenue, (Rockefeller Center) always plays to standing-room-only crowds at this time of year, but recently the enthusiasm for overseas travel--and the need for new and renewed pass- ports--has led to long lines outside that office long before the 9 A.M. opening.
CLEVELAND, May 28--The Cleveland Indians, held hitless for sit innings by Dave Boswell today, rode Pedro Gonzalez's two-run single in the seventh inning to a 2-1 victory over Minnesota.

ALBANY, May 28--Prominent physicists from at least five nations will attend a summer symposium on theoretical physics at the State University at Stony Brook, L.I. The symposium will be held from June 1 to Sept. 1.

Kauai King breezed half a mile over the sloppy Aqueduct track yesterday morning under the direction of his owner, Michael Ford. The Kentucky Derby and Preakness winner went easily, clicking off fractions of 12 seconds, 24, 36 3/5 and 49 4/5.

THE history of Paul Gauguin in the South Pacific has idealized suffering. Gauguin's exile on a remote island is another version of "Boheme" against a backcloth more exotic than the gray Parisian winter. Out of bitter frustration, neglect, poverty and disease, blossoms genius. Writers on Gauguin have perpetuated the romantic image of an intrepid outcast, students have accepted the master's self-portrait at face value.

LONDON--About 1,000 British coal miners a week are leaving the pits and the exodus is bound to swell when natural gas from the North Sea and the Yorkshire moorlands begins flowing into homes and factories over the next few years.

VICENZA, Italy--"The streets of Vicenza are a real museum, open to everybody," Gilbert Faure, a French writer, once remarked after he had visited here. Vicentinos like to quote his comment and point out that, while other Italian cities are noted for their art, this one is famous for its architecture.
SAIGON, May 23 (UPI)-- The United States Army is dropping aspirin on the Vietcong in the swamplands southeast of Saigon, it was disclosed today.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 28--A political crisis affecting the Dominican presidential elections Wednesday appeared to have been resolved tonight with the reinstatement of the Reformist party, one of the major contenders.

A FAIRLY towering new wave of English film culture is being churned up by Film ways. Executives of that energetic independent production company, who make no bones about the fact that they also are stepping up their distribution activities, last week revealed that they were "in serious negotiations with the Royal Shakespeare Company to finance and distribute movie versions of many of the classic and contemporary plays in their repertory."
A long-awaited report on a new jetport site by the Port of New York Authority will be issued "within the next month," John R. Wiley, the agency's director of aviation, said last week.

WE have all long since acknowledged Joseph Stalin as the empire builder of Soviet Communism. It may now be appropriate to say that Nicolae Ceausescu is the man who has taken charge of breaking up the Soviet Empire.

The retailing shift from Middle West cities to suburbs may be slowed somewhat in the coming years by efforts to revitalize downtown and neighborhood shopping centers, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago.

Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union, the challenger of the world chess title, defeated his compatriot, Tigran Petrosian, the world champion, in their adjourned 19th game in Moscow last night. The victory ties the 24-game match at 9 points each, with five games to go.

Dave Hemery, the mophaired Englishman from Boston University, has a full summer of competition confronting him. A COLLECTION of letters can make baffling reading. Letters tend to be allusive, with overtones and topical references that become enigmatic as the circumstances to which they refer recede into the past. To a certain extent this is true of the Gide-Valery correspondence even though it is copiously annotated. The title "Self-Portraits;" however, appropriately points up the interest of this particular volume, which has the charm of certain memoirs.

Golf has become the "in" sport. More and more people are playing golf or talking about it. Shares of Chas. Pfizer Co., Inc., an international pharmaceutical company, will make their first appearance today on the Paris Stock Exchange.

Dancing to big-name bands, a pastime that was revived just a year ago when the Riverboat brought in the Les and Larry Elgart orchestra in place of the Dixieland group that had been playing there, is continuing to lure popular leaders of the past back to the bandstand. The latest recruit is Cab Calloway, the "hi-de-ho" singer, who moved into the Riverboat with a big band this week.

The General Motors Corporation announced over the weekend the appointment, effective July 1, of Thomas O. Mathues as general manager of the Inland Manufacturing division to succeed Leslie C. Wolcott, who is retiring.

LUSAKA, Zambia, May 30-- A dispute between Zambia and Rhodesian Railways, which serves both Zambia and Rhodesia, is expected to come to an issue when a trainload of Zambian copper arrives at the border tomorrow afternoon.
PRAGUE, May 30--President Antonin Novotny will open the 13th Congress of the ruling Czechoslovak Communist party here tomorrow in a distinctively low key.

The 20th game of the title chess match between the world champion, Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, and his compatriot, Boris Spassky, was adjourned last night at Moscow's Variety Theater. Petrosian sealed his 41st move while a rook ahead and clear victory in sight.
The International Business Machines Corporation's $400-million stock offering gets under way today in the biggest Wall Street happening of the week.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., May 30 --The first Lloyd's Trophy race, conducted by the new Lloyd Harbor Yacht Club, ran into flukey winds today and an unofficial finish in Class A. William Rich's Spindrift had its victory threatened by a protest that will be heard during the week. A 0-10-knot wind ranged the compass.
WASHINGTON, May 30--In the view of United States experts, Communist China has been remarkably restrained, almost defensive, about its development of an atomic bomb.

DEVON, Pa., May 30--Last fall when Lawrence Golding, the owner of Laureling Farms of Millbrook, N.Y., was trying to buy a top jumper, he scouted all around the metropolitan area with no success. So he sent George Morris, his son's instructor, to Europe, to look. But Morris came home empty handed.
DETROIT, May 30 (AP)-- The long Memorial Day weekend was one of several factors that cut heavily into auto production plans in the United States this week.
ATLANTA, May 30 (AP)-- Don Drysdale scattered eight hits and contributed a double and a single to a 16-hit Los Angeles attack tonight as the Dodgers downed the Atlanta Braves, 10-6.

HANOVER, N.H., May 30-- Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Russell Stearns have announced the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Marjorie Elisabeth Stearns, to Peter Cosby Lent, son of Mr. and Mrs. Deane Lent of Cohasset, Mass.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 30-- Following one of the most accident-plagued races in 500 history, many drivers were confused and others protested the start and finish of today's autoracing classic.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 30 (AP)--Bernie Allen smashed a tie-breaking two-run homer and Harmon Killebrew drove in three runs with two homers as the Minnesota Twins defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 7-4, tonight and gained a split of a day-night program.
WASHINGTON -- The talk and the food may still be French along Washington's Embassy Row, but the furnishings are going native.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 30 (AP) -- Aqua Vite, trained by Johnny Longden, the former jockey, and Ri Tux captured the two sections of the Will Rogers stakes for 3-year-olds today before a crowd of 67,167 at Hollywood Park.

SOMERVILLE, N.J., May 30 --John Aschen, a 20-year-old bookkeeper from the Bronx, set an American bicycling record today when he won the 23d annual 50-mile Kugler-Anderson Memorial Tour of Somerville. Aschen was timed in 1 hour 59 minutes 29.4 seconds, beating the previous mark of 1:59:43.9, set by Hans Wolf of Ozone Park, Queens, in this race two years ago.

Mrs. Louise Ceraso, the 63year-old widow who underwent a heart pump implantation on May 18, died yesterday morning at Maimonides Hospital in Brooklyn. Mrs. Ceraso, who lived at 3718 Flatlands Avenue, Brooklyn, suffered a stroke Saturday.
GENEVA, May 25--An alliance of international organizations has begun a campaign to put the male fruit flies of Central America out of business.

Nineteen young women draped in white sheets from their heads to their sandals and wearing ashy "death masks" filed slowly along Central Park South and down Fifth Avenue yesterday afternoon to protest the war in Vietnam.
JACKSON, Miss., May 30 (AP)--A bill to relocate lowincome Mississippi Negroes in other parts of the nation at state expense was put aside today by the state Senate.
BALTIMORE, May 30 (AP) --A policeman was hit on the head with a rock today as he escorted Ku Klux Klansmen from a Negro neighborhood, where they had been picketing.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 30 --Ray (Rusty) Crothers of West Mystic, Conn., a 125pound, red-haired senior at Central Connecticut State College, won the second annual Greenwich five-mile road run today in 25 minutes 16.8 seconds. There were 94 starters.

LONDON, May 30 (AP)-- Jack Brabham of Australia won the London Trophy race for Formula Two cars today, making it five victories in a row for his Japanese Honda-powered racer in international competition this year.
FOREST PARK, Pa., May 30 --An international labor conference on problems of racial and religious bias was proposed here today at the end of an American-Jewish labor conference on civil rights.
The Federation of American Hospitals yesterday urged Congress or the Department of Health, Education and Welfare to increase the schedule of payments to private hospitals under the Medicare program.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 30-- Arnie Knepper was up to 130 miles an hour when he first saw trouble--only flashes of color at first, then cars spinning and tires flying through the air. He ground down on the brakes of his blue and white Ford, but the car just wasn't stopping.
PATCHOGUE, L.I., May 30 (UPI)--A 19-year-old baby sitter was held on a rape charge today after a land and air search by 350 men had flushed him from woods in the town of Brookhaven.
ANDERSONVILLE, Ga., May 30 (UPI)--Pfc. Jimmy Williams was buried today in Andersonville National Cemetery here with full military honors.

PARIS, May 30--Ambassador Charles E. Bohlen defended American idealism as a moving force in foreign policy as he spoke at Memorial Day services for Americans who died in France in the two World Wars. In paying homage to the war dead of the past he also spoke of new graves now being dug in Vietnam.
More than 100 policemen searched the subway tracks below Rockefeller Plaza for an hour last night for a patrolman who was said to have chased two men there, but who was, in fact, out to lunch.
TOKYO--Japan's hard-pressed cotton textile industry has tentatively adopted plans to scrap one-fourth of its 12 million spindles in a drastic reorganization and modernization program.
SAIGON, Tuesday, May 31-- The toll of Buddhist suicides by fire in the drive against the Ky regime rose to five today as two young girls burned themselves to death.

CHICAGO, May 30--Dr. and Mrs. Philip Morris Hauser have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Martha Ann Hauser, to David Victor Berkowitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abe Berkowitz of Lambertville, N.J. A wedding in August is planned.
TULSA, Okla., May 30 (AP) --Vic Seixas won the Tulsa, tennis championship today by defeating John Pickens of Tuscaloosa, Ala., 6-3, 6-4, in the final.

Miss Carolyn Maria Abad, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Abad of Astoria, Queens, and Mexico City, was married yesterday afternoon to Caesar A. Arredondo, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cesar Arredondo of New York.

RYE, N.Y., May 30--William E. John Jr. of Larchmont Yacht Club won his first International Class race of the season on Long Island Sound with Foxtrot today as the American Yacht Club concluded its holiday weekend regatta for Yacht Racing Association fleets.
CORNWALL, N.Y., May 30 -- The World War I veterans rode in convertibles, the World War II veterans marched and little boys waved flags while their fathers saluted and their mothers sighed.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 30 --The 21st annual Block Island yacht race of the Storm Trysail Club ended this morning, but with such unanswered questions as who would win the main prize and what had become of nine yachts that neither crossed the finish line nor reported themselves withdrawn.

AKRON, Ohio, May 30 (AP)--Dave Marr, the Professionai Golfers' Association champion, took a four-stroke lead on the front nine today and finished with a 33, 37--70 to beat the United States Open champion, Gary Player, by one stroke in National Golf Day's round of champions.
WASHINGTON, May 30--The automobile industry's adoption of revised procedures for notifying owners of safety defects in their cars has apparently failed to satisfy Senate critics.

The Mets at least have a better double-header record than they have over all. Once again they split a twin bill, beating the Phils, 3-1, after losing to a home run barrage and Jim Bunning, 7-2, at Shea Stadium yesterday.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 30 (AP)--Graham Hill's winning car in today's 500-mile auto race had a type-90 Lola chassis from England, powered by a special Ford V-8 racing engine.

ANAHEIM, Calif., May 30 (AP)--Home runs by Jim Fregosi and Bobby Knoop carried the California Angels to 4-3 and 5-1 victories over the Cleveland Indians today. The double defeat extended the league-leading Indians' losing streak to four games.

COLORADO SPRINGS, May 30--William Jovanovich, president of the publishing concern of Harcourt, Brace World, today attacked what he called the contemporary myth "that affluence is eroding public taste and morality."
GLYNDEBOURNE, England, May, 30 -- The 1966 Glyndebourne Opera Festival opened yesterday evening with a twin bill of Purcell's "Dido and Aeneas" and Ravel's "L'Heure Espagnol."

KANSAS CITY, May 30 (UPI)--Denny McLain, the Detroit Tigers' right-hander, pitchhis second one-hitter of the season tonight and Norm Cash drove in three runs with his eighth homer and two singles as the Tigers scored a 5-2 victory over the Kansas City Athletics.
Sixty-four nominees in 16 categories were named yesterday as the Tony Award contenders for Broadway's 1965-66 season. The awards are comparable to Hollywood's Oscars and television's Emmys.

What does the creative artist think of the new Government presence in the arts and humanities? He is exhilirated and worried, hopeful and dubious, wondering whether to shout with joy or cry out in admonition. These were the impressions one gathered last week during an all-day conference at ...

ST. LOUIS, May 30 (AP)-- Orlando Cepeda hit his eighth home run, two doubles and a single and drove in two runs as the St. Louis Cardinals beat the Houston Astros tonight, 3-1. Bob Gibson held Houston to three hits.
WESTPORT, Wash., May 30 (AP)--The commander of a Soviet fishing fleet operating off the Washington coast has asserted that his flotilla has not been netting salmon.
NEWPORT, R.I., May 30-- Austin Ledyard Sands, an early aviator and a veteran of both World Wars, died here today at his home, "Castle Hill." He was 79 years old.

As Mayor Lindsay approaches the climax of his battle with the State Legislature to get the taxing power to govern New York City he labors under one insuperable handicap. He cannot authentically fulfill the role of the prudent man, of the Mayor who demands fiscal responsibility in city management, while he keeps the transit fare at 15 cents.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., May 30 -- Nevada and California today became the first states to enact controls over the hallucinogenic drug LSD.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Tuesday, May 31--An unmanned Surveyor spacecraft, making the nation's first attempt at a soft landing on the moon, streaked toward its target today with bullseye accuracy. It carried a camera that will send thousands of pictures of the moon's surface back to earth, if all does well.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., May 30 (UPI) -- The Coast Guard said today it had refused to permit an Italian luxury liner to sail on a Memorial Day weekend cruise to the Bahamas because the vessel did not meet United States safety standards.
PARIS--Kristina Antander, 23 years old, makes some of the prettiest, most colorful crocheted dresses in Europe, but if people ask her opinion about fashion, she just groans.
CINCINNATI, May 30 (AP) --Ray Sadecki pitched a fivehitter tonight as the San Francisco Giants unleashed a 12-hit attack and routed the Cincinnati Reds, 8-4.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 30 --The defending champion, Mountain Lakes, upset thirdseeded Columbia, 2-1, to qualify for the quarter-finals of the 20th annual New Jersey interscholastic tennis tournament today.

CHICAGO, May 30 (UPI)-- Jack Lamabe, a Boston castoff making his first start in two years, shut out the Red Sox today on one hit--an eighth-inning single by Joe Foy -- in pitching the Chicago White Sox to an 11-0 victory after John Buzhardt had won the opener, 1-0.
Eighteen has long been the age when one can be drafted, drink, get an operator's license for a car in New York State and, until yesterday, be eligible for work at a city amusement area.

The Harvard Lampoon, which has successfully parodied the syntax of Time, the derring-do of James Bond, the fashion advice of Esquire and the gushiness of Mademoiselle, is about to tackle perhaps its most potent target to date.
Mrs. M. had a congenital heart condition for which she had been receiving treatment for many years. Eventually, following her marriage and the birth of her four children, a team of doctors ...
Stock prices moved ahead yesterday on the Montreal and Canadian stock exchanges, extending the current uptrend into its fifth session in a row. Trading, however, was moderate.
MOSCOW, May 30 -- Nearly 2,000 experts from 60 nations convened at Moscow University today for a 10-day conference on oceanography.

WHEN a historian takes a nostalgic backward look at the ancient ball park in St. Louis, originally known as Sportsman's Park, he can't help but get involved with recollections of the St. Louis Cardinals, the dominant team for 40 years. But there once was another team in town, the St. Louis Browns. They not only shared the field with the Cards, but they also owned it.
MOSCOW, May 30 (Reuters) --Nikita S. Khrushchev, former Soviet Premier, is fit and well, enjoys walking in the countryside for relaxation, and reads a lot, his wife said today.

AUSTIN, Tex., May 30 -- A "water for Texas plan" described by a nationally knows expert as the most comprehensive ever developed was unveiled today by Gov. John B. Connally Jr. and the Texas Water Development Board.

TOKYO, May 30 -- Japan's political division is epitomized in the anti-American demonstrations and pro - American countermoves attending the arrival of the United States Navy's nuclear-powered submarine Snook at the nearby port of Yokosuka today.

JERUSALEM (Israeli sector), May 30--One year after its opening, the Israel Museum has proved an artistic and educational success while remaining a financial stepchild of the Government and $350,000 in debt.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 30 -- At 5 A.M., when the bomb exploded, America, streamed into the Indianapolis Speedway: Black-jacketed motorcyclists with iron crosses on their chests, college kids in fuming cars, and red-eyed families who had spent the night in their trailers by a giant billboard that implored them to save their country by impeaching Earl Warren.

OTTAWA, May 30 (Canadian Press)--Minister of Labor John R. Nicholson said today he was hopeful that the longshoremen's strike in Montreal, Quebec City and Trois Rivieres could be settled "in a reasonable time" as a result of weekend discussions. A "fantastic" wage offer had been made to the 4,250 strikers, he said.
CHERRY HILL, N.J., May 30 --As expected, Creme dela Creme demonstrated speed, courage and dangerous curiosity in today's $137,900 Jersey Derby at Garden State Park.

HIGH LEVEL, Alberta--It was 6:30 A.M., and the waitress, dazed, shoved Korean-made flatware across the tables of Terry's Restaurant to the morose mob of railroad foremen, sawmill bosses, farmers, helicopter pilots and oil field hands.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 30--Textile union leaders and management representatives of Johnson Johnson met with a Federal mediator at company headquarters here this afternoon in an effort to end a strike that began last night.
WASHINGTON, May 30 -- The Government is issuing rules for Medicare that it says preserve the traditional doctor-patient relationship.
BRIGHTWATERS, L.I., May 30--A 15-year-old boy accidentally shot and killed a 21-yearold brother in their home here last night while simulating a shooting they had seen in a television program.
The insurgent candidacy of Supreme Court Justice Samuel J. Silverman for Surrogate of New York County assumed new stature yesterday when the Liberal candidate withdrew in his favor.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, May 30 (AP)--The death penalty was demanded today for a Hungarian official accused of spying for the Central Intelligence Agency.
VALLEY FORGE, Pa., May 30 (UPI)--Capt. Roger H.C. Donlon, winner of the first Congressional Medal of Honor awarded in Vietnam, received the Freedom Leadership Medal of the Freedoms Foundation today.
Four thousand unruly youths roamed through the concession area of Coney Island last night, throwing bottles at civilians and the police and forcing rides and booths to close early.

HOUSTON, May 30--Lieut. Col. Thomas P. Stafford and Lieut. Cmdr. Eugene A. Cernan, the Gemini 9 astronauts, practiced space rendezvous procedures at Cape Kennedy today in preparation for their space flight Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, May 30--A highly encouraging performance by Jim Bouton took some, but only some, of the sting out of splitting a double-header for the New York Yankees today.
Commercial banks may soon be sharply limited in their ability to compete for savings accounts, informed sources in baking and Government said yesterday.
North Vietnam has moved to start peace talks through Rumanian intermediaries, Newsweek magazine reported yesterday.
BURLINGTON, Vt., May 30-- Dr. Donald Belcher, a research specialist in physical chemistry, died at his home in Charlotte Saturday morning. He was 73 years old.
Ship repair yards here fear that the declining industry may be eliminated if the State Legislature does not exempt them from the sales tax laws.

TORONTO, May 30 (Canadian Press) -- The Victoria and Grey Trust Company says it has recovered more than $1.7million from an asset given no value at the time of last year's merger with British Mortgage and Trust.
The Richard Burton Fund of the National Hemophilia Foundation and the American Musical and Dramatic Academy will share the proceeds of a theater party and supper dance the evening of June 23.
ALBANY, May 30--Governor Rockefeller said today that New York City would turn over to the City University $5-million in state funds that he has contended the city has been withholding.
Eight Philadelphia schools will start programs of "exceptional excellence" next fall with the aid of a $350,000 grant from the Carnegie Foundation.

The Valley Metallurgical Processing Company, Inc., has elected George H. Connerat as vice president, it was announced over the holiday weekend by Percy W. Hudson, president of the producer of metal powders.
Assemblyman Leonard P. Stavisky has called for a fullscale investigation of the methods of administering the provisions of the Condon-Wadlin Law in New York City.

WASHINGTON, May 30-- The Justice Department announced tonight that Federal observers would serve as poll watchers tomorrow in six Alabama counties in which Negroes are seeking local office in tomorrow's run-off elections.
During his 53 years of continuous service as a member of the Board of Higher Education, Charles H. Tuttle gave unstinting devotion to this vital, unsalaried public office.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- One of the most difficult tasks facing the Republican party is that of regaining Negro support, and no one is more aware of this than the man who has been put in charge of the job.
Seven civil rights leaders yesterday described the White House Conference on Civil Rights, to be held in Washington tomorrow and Thursday, as "a frivolous exercise which will accomplish nothing."
