NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., May 30 -- The 1,000-foot-wide thundering wall of water at Niagara called the American Falls may not be in as much danger as has been feared.
THE recent fashion for trinkets of papier-mache has inspired the extension of the technique to home furnishings accessories.

CARSON CITY, Nev., May 30 (AP)--The Nevada law signed by Governor Sawyer today prohibits the possession or use of LSD except under direct administration by a physician, osteopath or qualified research scientist, who must remain with the patient until all effects wear off.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 30 --Mrs. Thomas Fleming Tunick of Indian Harbor House died yesterday at Memorial Hospital in New York. She was the wife of Judge Archibald H. Tunick of the Connecticut Circuit Court.
SAIGON, May 30--Memorial Day passed in Vietnam with American soldiers doing relatively little fighting.
The First National City Bank will open its third travel service center this morning, in its branch at 640 Fifth Avenue, the bank announced yesterday.

KIEV, U.S.S.R., May 24-- An Estonian emigre in the United States is identified as an employe of the Central Intelligence Agency. Another Estonian is named in gossip deliberately spread as an agent of the Soviet State Security agency.
LAGOS, Nigeria, May 30--A semblance of order appeared to return to northern Nigeria today after anti-Government violence over the weekend took more than 64 lives.
CHANTILLY, France, May 30 (AP)--Gaetan Mourgue d'Algue won his second straight French amateur golf championship today, defeating Patrick Cros, 6 and 5, in the 36-hole final.
Two Brooklyn brothers were held without bail yesterday on charges of homicide in the death of a father and son during a neighborhood fight Sunday night.

EASTHAM, Mass., May 30-- The first land the Pilgrims sighted before landing at Plymouth 346 years ago was dedicated today as the Cape Cod National Seashore. It embraces an area of nearly 40,000 acres in six towns on the Cape.

NASHVILLE, May 30--Gov. Frank G. Clement has called a news conference tomorrow at 10 A.M. to announce that he will seek again the Democratic nomination to the United States Senate, thereby assuring a rematch with Senator Ross Bass.
CHICAGO, May 30 (AP)-- Warren W. Brown, retired president of the Monon Railroad, died Saturday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 66 years old.

TEANECK, N.J., May 30-- Robert Henderson, a newspaper man and advertising executive who was serving his second term as a member of the Township Counnil, died today in Holy Name Hospital. He had been stricken with a cardiac seizure while visiting police headquarters. He was 61 years old and lived at 821 Red Road.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 30--The Dominican Republic celebrated a national holiday today known as the Day of the Goat.
WANTAGH, L.I., May 30-- An 18-year-old high school senior was accused today of running down and killing a 16year-old boy with his automobile after a fight between 25 teenagers.

ALGIERS, Algeria, May 30-- Syria's Vice Premier and Foreign Minister, Ibrahim Makhos, has proposed to Algeria a meeting of "progressive" Arab states to counter the plan of King Faisal of Saudi Arabia to create an "Islamic alliance," the official press disclosed today.

CHICAGO, May 30 (AP)--A visiting Buddhist, who says the self-immolation of monks in South Vietnam is not suicide but an act of 'self-sacrifice for the good of others," joined with prominent Chicago clergy today in a Memorial Day "service for peace."

WESTBURY, L.I., May 30-- Too young to be followers of form, but just at the age to enjoy a barn area and two of its distinguished citizens, hundreds of youngsters appeared for Roosevelt Raceway's "open house" this morning -- to visit with Cardigan Bay and Bret Hanover.
WIESBADEN, Germany, May 30 (AP)--Frank Chapot of Wallpack, N.J., won the 2,500mark ($625) Grand Prix of the Wiesbaden equestrian jumping tournament today.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 30 (AP)--The Cornell University faculty of arts and sciences voted today, in a move "to defeat the use of class rank for draft deferments," not to compute an all-male class-rank list as requested by Selective Service officials. Class rank is one factor considered by draft boards in determining student deferments.

PURCHASE, N.Y., May 30 --Mother Eleanor M. O'Byrne, the retiring president of Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart, received what she called the biggest surprise of her academic life today when a $42,000 purse was given to her for Manhattanville improvements.

Simon and Schuster have published travel guides to the United States in collaboration with Mobil Oil Company since 1958. Eugene Fodor, known for European travel guides, has produced his first American guide this year for the David McKay Company, and Shell Oil Company is selling the work, along with bookstores.

John J. O'Brien, a retail advertising salesman for The New York Times, died yesterday in his sleep while visiting friends in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 58 years old and lived at 1420 Parkchester Road, the Bronx.
GARDEN CITY, Kan., May 30 --Drought is robbing this year's wheat harvest of millions of bushels of grain counted on to meet mounting export demands.
HAVANA, May 30 (AP)-- Cuban armed forces shot and killed two infiltrators landed from a launch west of Havana last night, then pursued the craft and sank it, a communique said today.
SYDNEY, Australia, May 30 --The Government's confidence in its policy of participating in the war in Vietnam has been strengthened by the results of the weekend state elections in Queensland.

Jack Richardson, playwright; Leon Kirchner, composer, and Agnes De Mille and John Butler, choreographers, have been commissioned by the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts to create major works for television. Each has freedom to prepare a program of his or her choice for presentation by the National Educational Television network.
ATHENS, May 30--Greek shipowners are working on an ambitious $600-million plan to renovate Greece's merchant fleet.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 30 --One of the largest hoards of ancient Greek gold coins ever reported discovered has been unearthed by a team of Princeton University archeologists outside the ancient city of Morgantina in the central hill country of Sicily.
ARLINGTON, Va., May 30-- President Johnson said today that the protest suicides of Buddhists in South Vietnam were tragic and unnecessary.

WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) --The national commander of the American Veterans of World War II and Korea expressed shock today at the "business as usual" operation of many concerns on Memorial Day this year.

BAY ST. LOUIS, Miss., May 30 (UPI)--Failure to reconnect a pressure sensing line following a test--apparently a human error--was blamed in a preliminary report today for Saturday's explosion of a secand stage for the Saturn moon rocket.

James G. Murray, former president of the Junior High School Principals Association, died yesterday in the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 61 years old and lived at 160 Newtown Lane, East Hampton, L.I.
BUENOS AIRES, May 30-- Argentina awoke this gray autumn morning to find the peso reduced in value from 188.50 to 205 to the dollar, a decline of about 8 per cent.
The New York Rangers of the National Hockey League anpounced a shift yesterday of their Central Hockey League club from Minneapolis-St. Paul to Omaha.

Woodbrook Gardens, a twostory development of garden apartments on an eight-acre plot in Irvington, N.J., has been sold by Friedman Liebler to an investing client of Dreyer Traub, lawyers, for cash over mortgages totaling $1.25-million.
The American Machine and Foundry Company announced over the weekend the appointment of Richard W. Kazmaier as vice president and general manager of its Wen-Mac division.

EAST MEADOW, L.I., May 30--Col. Charles B. Frazer U.S. A.F., retired, a staff publicinformation officer, died Saturday at the Meadowbrook Hospital here. He was 61 years old and lived at 40 Arrow Lane in Hicksville.
WASHINGTON, May 30--The United States lost $70-million of gold in April following a $73-million loss in March, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

CAIRO, May 30--The Government has arrested more than 1,500 people in a sweeping campaign against narcotics smugglers following a dramatic desert chase in which four policemen were machine-gunned to death by Bedouin tribesmen allegedly engaged in smuggling.

JIDDAH, Saudi Arabia, May 25--In the rest of the Arab and Islamic worlds, women are relatively emancipated. Here, except for a few young Saudi couples educated abroad, women are unveiled only by the men of their immediate families. Even brothers-in-law are likely to be excluded.
BUENOS AIRES, May 30 (Reuters)--Supporters of Argentina's former dictator, Juan D. Peron, won control of the Catamarca Province legislatures in elections yesterday, incomplete returns showed today.

ROSLYN, L.I., May 30--Miss Nancy Allison, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton F. Allison of Manhasset, was married today to Ens. Theodore A. Ulrich, U.S.C.G., son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert R. Ulrich of Boulder, Colo. The Rev. Thomas P. Stewart performed the ceremony in the Roslyn Presbyterian Church.
The Economic Club of New York has elected Norman H. Strouse, chairman of the J. Walter Thompson Company, its new president for a oneyear term beginning tomorrow.

PITTSBURGH, May 30 (AP) --Roberto Clemente's second home run of the day helped the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 5-3 victory in the second game and a sweep of a double-header against the Chicago Cubs today. The Pirates took the opener, 3-2.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, May 30 -- The expected visit of Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China to Tirana next month and related events in the last three months have led observers in Eastern Europe to conclude that Albania is fully recommitted to ideological and economic dependence on the Peking regime.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, May 30 --The Ceylonese government expressed concern today over the strife in South Vietnam where several Buddhists have burned themselves to death in the last two days.
Registration of persons over 65 for medical insurance coverage under the Federal Medicare program was reported as fairly light yesterday at district offices of the Social Security Administration.

ACTON, Mass., May 30--Mr. and Mrs. John W. Putnam of Acton have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor Thwing Putnam, to John Langdon Marsh, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman J. Marsh of Mount Kisco, N.Y.
Mayor Lindsay joined in a Transit Authority warning yesterday that state legislative action was needed to avert an increase in the city's 15-cent transit fare July 1.

Under a sunny Memorial Day sky yesterday, New York became a city of marchers and strollers, moviegoers and window shoppers, speechmakers and gawkers and just plain lazy loafers in the parks and on the beaches.

ATLANTA, May 30 (AP)-- It was one of the most unusual bits of exam cramming ever seen on a college campus. Emory University students called it an "aggression rally," and even the dean of men and the dean of women participated.

ALBANY, May 30--The Federal Government was asked today to investigate a reported drive on welfare violations in Niagara County where a welfare official was quoted yesterday as having said he had ordered a "nigger" out of his office.

Mrs. Lloyd O.V. Mann of 80 East End Avenue has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Sheridan Cogan, to Macdonald Eaton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Eaton Jr. of Plainfield, N.J. An early June wedding is planned.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, May 30 -- Government troops arrested three former Cabinet ministers and former Premier Evariste Kimba today on a charge of plotting to kill the President, Lieut. Gen. Joseph D. Mobutu, and to seize power. A spokesman said many members of Parliament were involved and would be seized.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., May 30 (AP) -- James Woolf of London, British film producer of "Room at the Top" and many other hits, died last night apparently of a heart attack, at the Beverly Hills Hotel. He was 46 years old. With his brother, John, he headed Romulus Films, Ltd.
UNION, N.J., May 30--Mr. and Mrs. Paul Komroff have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lynn Komroff, to David Lee Pearle, son of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley C. Pearle of Dallas.

Senator Robert F. Kennedy declined yesterday to pledge his support for Supreme Court Justice Samuel J. Silverman on the Liberal party ticket if Mr. Silverman is defeated in his bid for the Democratic nomination.
Montgomery Ward Co. reported yesterday its best firstquarter earnings since 1959. Sales for the period set a record.

Mr. and Mrs. William F. Hurrell of the Bronx have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Therese Hurrell, to Joseph William Ford, son of John T. Ford of Pelham, N.Y., and the late Mrs. Josephine Corkill Ford.

Miss Katherine A. Kamen and Dr. Andrew S. Dalsimer were married yesterday afternoon by Rabbi Eugene Sack in the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Dalsimer, at 20 Sutton Place South. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. Elizabeth Kamen and Dr. Samuel Kamen, both of Brooklyn.

LONDON Although London is not often linked with Lucullus, there is a food shop here that, it can reason ably be said, is without peer or parallel. It is the formidable and wholly admirable half-acre of tantalizing things for the table on the ground floor of Harrod's.
The Lindsay administration put forward a compromise proposal on Neighborhood City Halls yesterday in effort to prevent $200,000 to initiate the program from being slashed from the 1966-67 budget.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, May 31 Leonid I. Brezhnev, Soviet Communist party chief, called today for a strengthening of the Warsaw Pact.

GLEN COVE, L.I., May 31 Mr. and Mrs. Thomas McKenzie of Glen Cove, formerly of London, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nina Margaret McKenzie, to Cadet Terry Allen Richardson of the United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point. He is the son of Mr. and. Mrs. Gilbert P. Richardson of Bowling Green, Ky.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) has approved a $25-million loan to Colombia's central bank, Banco de la Republica, to provide five Colombian finance companies with funds for industrial investment.
WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) Representative Thomas B. Curtis reported to Congress today an encouraging if belated speed-up in the 68-nation tariffcutting negotiations at Geneva.

A three-year grant of $197,500, of which $65,000 is to be matched, has been made by the Rockefeller Foundation to Albarwild Theater Arts, Inc., to discover talented dramatists and to revive meritorious American plays. The plan announced yesterday, to get under way Sept. 6, will apply to Off Broadway production.
Alex Rose, chief tactician of the Liberal party, openly broke political relations with Deputy Mayor Robert Price yesterday.
CHICAGO, May 31 (AP) A total of 542 persons died in traffic accidents during the holiday weekend, a record for any Memorial Day period. The deaths were counted from 6 P.M. Friday to last midnight.

The world chess champion, Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, recaptured the lead in his title match with his compatriot, Boris Spassky, last night in Moscow, when Spassky resigned the adjourned 20th game without further play, after observing the sealed move of his opponent. It was 41 Q-K6.

Robert J. Mangum, the regional director of the Federal Office of Economic Opportunity, said yesterday that the city had submitted its summer antipoverty program "in a lamentable shape" and that he had set up a "command post" to revise the proposals.
HUE, May 31 Anti-Government student leaders agreed tonight to close indefinitely the Hue radio station, which they have held for more than two months.

VETERANS of pop concerts filled with Viennese music may think that these events are stereotyped in content and presentation, but the New York Philharmonic proved last night that this is not necessarily so.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 31 A Government official charged with protecting Nassau County's 1.4-million residents against "inefficiency, maladministration, arrogance and abuse on the part of government" was proposed today by County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson.

SAIGON, May 31--The United States sent the greatest number of attacking planes into North Vietnam yesterday since regular bombing there began Feb. 7, 1965, an American military spokesman said tonight.

Salvage operations for a section of tower legs that will serve as the underpinning for an important new navigation light off the North Carolina coast are to get under way this week off the North Carolina coast.

HUE, South Vietnam, Wednesday, June 1--A screaming mob of about 1,000 students sacked and burned the United States Consulate building today. Yelling and blow... ing whistles, the students ripped down portraits of President Johnson and carried off two American flags while the building burned and other students threw rocks at the windows.
Bids will be opened on June 17 for work on extensive improvement of piers at Buttermilk Channel, Governors Island, later this year.

JOSIAH WEDGWOOD SONS, LTD., the 200 year-old English company best known for its traditional china and neo-classical designs, has sent a representative of the 20th century here in the person of David Puxley.

THE Mixed Team Championship, which ended the 1966 Eastern Regional Championships for all except the four teams surviving in the Reisinger Knockout event, was won by Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Feld of Brookline, Mass., Ed Lazarus and Diane Aiken of Baltimore.

WASHINGTON, May 31 The House Banking Committee took steps today to develop a consensus among top Government officials on what to do about high bank interest rates and their effects on the savingsand-loan and home-building industries.

THE next man to lead the official seminary of the Episcopal Church, the Rev. Samuel Joseph Wylie, is a high churchman with a record of deliberate and thoughtful innovation, a traditionalist eager to engage in a "dialogue with tomorrow." The baldish Boston rector is a quiet man.
The four leading contenders for the Democratic nomination for Governor outlined last night varying ways in which they would try to better the lot of New Yorkers.

TOKYO, May 31 Fifty Socialist legislators marched to the United States Embassy today to protest against the visit of the nuclear submarine Snook to the Yokosuka naval base. The visit, they contend, threatens to drag Japan into the war in Vietnam.

TOKYO, May 31 Peking has requested the Japanese Communist party to begin preparing for armed struggle in case war breaks out between Communist China and the United States, according to a report by Japanese police experts on Communism in Japan.
PALM BEACH, Fla., May 31 James McMillan Gibson of Palm Beach, Washington and York, Me., a financier, died yesterday in his home. His age was 56.

Exhibition, "Graphics From Hunter College" by advanced graphic arts students. Donnell Library Center of the New York Public Library, 20 West 53d Street. Exhibition opens at 9 A.M., continues through June 30.

WASHINGTON, May 31 The hot streak is over for the New York Yankees and the first slump since Ralph Houk took over as manager 24 days ago gathered momentum tonight as the Yankees lost to the Washington Senators, 5-1.

GENEVA, May 31 -- The faster-than-sound airliners due in the early ninteen-seventies will carry detection instruments to warn the pilot when the plane has penetrated zones of health-endangering radiation.
CRANFORD, N.J., May 31 (AP) A five-and-a-halffoot-long boa constrictor is on the loose here, the police said today.

The appointment of Vern C. Richards as president of the Bankamerica Service Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Bank of America, was announced yesterday by Louis B. Lundborg, chairman of the board.
MONTREAL (Canadian Press), May 31 Some violence erupted along Montreal's strike-bound waterfront today after discontented longshoremen walked out of a union meeting.
LONDON, May 31 Britain's merchant seamen are talking tough but are nevertheless hoping their three-week-old strike for a shorter work week and better working conditions will be over quickly.

George Chuvalo of Toronto and Oscar Bonavena of Buenos Aires, who will meet in a heavyweight bout at Madison Square Garden June 23, said yesterday they would ask the New York State Athletic Commission to permit them to "fight to the finish."

LOS ANGELES, May 31 The Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors called on the Federal Government today to clarify its contemplated role, in relation to state governments, in controlling air pollution.
HELSINKI, May 31 (UPI) Secretary of State Dean Rusk arrived here today from Washington for an official two-day visit as demonstrators staged peaceful protests against United States policy in Vietnam.
Gains by gold and copper shares were features in an otherwise quiet London stock market yesterday.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 31 Mohamed Hatta, former Indonesian Vice President, indicated today he wanted to succeed President Sukarno.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company declared yesterday that certain special services it offered were not carrying their full share of the operating load.
Mike Ford, whose Kauai King has taken home $369,027 worth of race track checks this season, reversed that procedure yesterday. He delivered a check for $5,000 to the New York Racing Association.

McCONNELLSBURG, Pa., May 31 (AP) Smiling and cheerful, Peggy Ann Bradnick went home today from the Fulton County Medical Center, where she had spent 13 days recovering from a week-long ordeal as the captive of a kidnap-killer.
WASHINGTON, May 31 Despite the current internal crisis in South Vietnam, the Johnson Administration says it feels that steady progress is being made to arrange elections for a constituent assembly.
WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) An international conference on copper under the auspices of the United Nations is being planned for December, Senate Democratic leader Mike Mansfield announced today.
WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) Governors and Congressional committee chairmen will meet here at the White House's invitation Friday to discuss auto safety legislation.

Combine the sheer speed of Frank Budd, the straightaway strength of Henry Carr and the furious lift of Bob Hayes. Bandage one tender hamstring muscle, stir well and turn loose in all races up to and including 440 yards.

It took the Mets and Phillies 3 hours 13 minutes last night to play a nine-inning game on a chilly evening at Shea Stadium. The seven pitchers who took part in the game, though hired to throw the baseball, didn't seem to want to let go of it.

Negotiations in the 36-day-old newspaper strike slowed almost to a standstill yesterday after seven New York newspapermen announced that they planned to organize a rival union to supplant the striking Newspaper Guild as bargaining agent for editorial employes.

CINCINNATI, May 31, (AP) Unbeaten Juan Marichal pitched out of trouble in the late innings tonight and preserved his 10th victory as the San Francisco Giants posted a 5-3 triumph over the Cincinnati Reds.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 31 Chile's copper reform program expected to make this country the world's major copper producer by 1971 with an annual output of 1.2 million tons, will be completed in about six weeks.

MANCHESTER, England, May 31, (AP) Cliff Richey of Dallas overcame a slight heat stroke and defeated Terry Addison of Australia, 7-5, 6-4, in the second round of the North of England tennis championship today.
DUBLIN, May 31 Ireland will vote for a President tomorrow, with Thomas F. O'Higgins, 49 years old, challenging the incumbent, Eamon de Valera, 83.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., May 31 Lafayette College, a District, 2 playoff entry, defeated the Seton Hall University baseball team, 8-2, today. It was only the sixth loss in 25 games for the Pirates, who had been overlooked by the playoff selection committee.
WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) At the State Department Robert J. McCloskey, press officer, made the following statement:

The Duchess of Windsor, who is planning to sail with her husband tomorrow for their homes in France, says she has decided to take on no more honorary chairmanships for charity balls and other worthy causes.
NOT everyone hates the crow. In an age of cyni- cism one finds comfort in the organization that calls itself simply. The Society for the Preservation of the Crow (25 East 73d Street).
Corporate bond prices declined fairly sharply yesterday while Government bonds rose slightly and Treasury bills also gained a little.

The men who run the refrigeration and air-conditioning plants in Manhattan's major commercial buildings, including Rockefeller Center, voted last night to strike, disregarding the advice of their local and international union.

Ten days after Parks Commissioner Thomas P.F. Hoving announced plans for a renaissance for Coney Island, a concessionaire named Chic stood in the amusement area yesterday and shouted, "Twenty-five years I'm here, but this is the last."
WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) Pauper prisoners in New Jersey who are unsuccessful in appeals will no longer have to pay cost of transcripts for their trials out of their prison earnings.

Four East Coast educational television stations-including Channel 13 here--have formed a live network for the summer months, which will allow them to present simultaneous live news and public affairs programs five nights a week.

The train that got through was the most dramatic news influencing commodity futures and spot prices yesterday. As a result of the news, copper futures dropped about 2 cents a pound for most contracts, and the spot price for copper scrap here declined about a cent a pound. Prices dropped even more sharply in London, where a bigger rise had taken place recently.
LONDON, May 30 A global campaign is being opened to wipe smallpox from the face of the earth, eliminating for all time the need for vaccination against the disease.

MOSCOW, May 31 The workers of the Aksai state farm near Alma-Ata, in a fertile irrigated area at the foot of the Trans-Ili Ala-Tau mountains, had just completed spring plowing of a 200-acre field and were preparing to plant vegetables, a profitable cash crop in the Soviet Union.
LONDON, May 31 An influential economic research group said today Britain was well on the road to balance in her external accounts, barring the effects of a prolonged seamen's strike.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 31 Graham Hill, the English driver with the quiet voice and a closeclipped moustache, became the richest "rookie" in auto racing history today.
The Raytheon Company has received five Army contracts totaling $12,656,140 for work on various missile systems.

It used to be said of a famous French Premier: "Leon Blum knows where he is going but he doesn't know how to get there." The reverse is true of Venerable Tri Quang, the politically obsessed leader of South Vietnam's militant Buddhists. He shows talent for acquiring power but his goal has yet to be disclosed. Masked by contradictions he advances.
The Earl of Avon suggested last night that the creation of a neutral belt composed of Laos, Cambodia and Vietnam might be a way of bringing peace in Vietnam.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 31 Following is the text of a letter sent by Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet Foreign Minister, to U. Thant, Secretary General, and released today by the Soviet mission:
The Columbia College valedictorian said yesterday that protests and demonstrations against social injustice were as important to a student's overall education as class work.
WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) Steve Lewis Watts, an authority on ancient and modern printing face types, died of a heart attack today at Walter Reed General Hospital. He was 70 years old.
PASADENA, Calif., May 31 Surveyor 1 passed a major test on its way to the moon today, making scientists "very hopeful" that it would land there and send television pictures back to earth.

James H. Meredith, whose enrollment at the University of Mississippi touched off riots in 1962, will set out on a 220-mile voter registration march into Jackson, Miss., Sunday to encourage fellow Negroes to vote.
TORONTO, May 31 (Canadian Press) Shareholders of the British American Oil Company, Ltd., approved the sale today a wholly owned United States subsidiary for $182,544,000.
Alfred J. Gagnon was elected yesterday as a director of Booz, Allen Hamilton, Inc., the management consultant concern. He is vice president in charge of the company's western region.

MEXICO CITY, May 31 (UPI) The United States should cut tariffs on manufactured and semimanufactured goods from Latin America to encourage industrial development of the region, George Moore, President of the First National City Bank of New York, said today.

DEVON, Pa., May 31 Not Always, an aged bay gelding who hasn't finished worse than reserve champion in eight shows this year, won the Fred Pinch Memorial Trophy and moved into a solid lead for the working hunter title today at the Devon Horse Show.
IT'S what's happening. Orange circles on a purple suit. Red stripes blazing alongside navy. Color as savage as the rhythmic blasts from a transistor radio.
CHICAGO, May 31 Six persons were found guilty today and 43 were released after an early morning rampage in which three youths were beaten up on a bus and the bus was heavily damaged.

The nation's businessmen appear to be paying relatively little heed to President Johnson's pleas for restraint or to signs of a slowing down in the rate of economic activity. From all indications, they are continuing to spend too heavily on new plant and equipment.

Mrs. John F. Kennedy, the widow of the President, has declared herself in favor of saving the 83-year-old Metropolitan Opera House. The house is scheduled to be razed and a 40story office building erected on its site.

The New York State Council on the Arts, in its first move to encourage the art of motion pictures, will sponsor an experiment in five upstate communities to see if it is possible to develop audiences for quality films in areas where popular movies predominate.

Charles F. Park Jr., a professor of geology at Stanford University's School of Earth Sciences, testified in Federal Court here yesterday that he knew of at least two other mines in which the ore values found in initial drill holes compared favorably with the first hole spudded into the Texas Gulf Sulphur Company's Timmins, Ont., property.
PARIS, May 31 (AP) Francois Jauffret of France, upset Roy Emerson of Australia, 1-6, 6-3, 6-4, 4-6, 6-4, today in the quarter-finals of the French international tennis tournament.
The formation of Northeast Utilities comprising three electric operating utilities as subsidiaries will become effective June 30, according to executives of the three utilities.

Whitney Hart Shepardson, an expert on United States foreign policy and the former president of the group that operates Radio Free Europe, died Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital of a heart attack. He was 75 years old.

THE HAGUE, May 31 An Amsterdam court granted today permission for the 114-year-old bank, the Brothers Teixeira de Mattos, to suspend payments. It was the first time since the war that a bank in the Netherlands has had to file a petition for a moratorium.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) Farm product prices declined three-fourths of one per cent in the month ended May 15. Reporting on farm products today, the Agriculture Department said seasonally lower prices for eggs and wholesale milk, together with a decline in cattle prices, were mainly responsible for the decrease. Partly offsetting the declines were higher prices for oranges, apples and wheat.

The Monmouth Park Jockey Club has announced the names of box holders for the 1966 season at the Monmouth Race Track in Oceanport, N.J. Philip H. Iselin is the club's president and chairman of the board. The 21st year of racing will begin on Friday.
Leonard Stone, an industrialist, died Monday at his home, 880 Fifth Avenue, after a brief illness. He was 67 years old.

BRZEG, Poland, May 31 Squads of helmeted policemen used tear gas and night sticks here last Thursday to break up an angry crowd of about 2,000 Roman Catholics seeking to prevent the eviction of five priests from their house.
The American Home Products Corporation, a producer of drugs, cosmetics and food, announced here yesterday the election of Lawrence J. Sauers as a vice president.

Seven members of the City Council called yesterday for an official explanation of circumstances surrounding the enlistment in the National Guard of Sidney L. Gardner, executive secretary of the City Council Against Poverty.
Sam DeLuca and Dave Herman, offensive guards, signed their 1966 contracts yesterday with the New York Jets of the American Football League.

CHICAGO, May 31 (UPI) A Federal judge freed Sam (Momo) Giancana today from a year-long imprisonment for contempt of a grand jury. The judge criticized the Government for not charging the reputed crime syndicate chief with obstruction of justice and criminal contempt.

In calling for establishment of a New Jersey Board of Higher Education, Governor Hughes has taken an essential step toward long overdue reform in his state's public college and university system. The need for substantial and rapid expansion of educational opportunity in New Jersey is critical. Over 10,000 qualified applicants had to be turned away this year, and a disproportionate number of Jerseyites must annually rely on the generosity of colleges in other states.
The sound and fury coming out of Cuba, Guantanamo Bay, Washington and Moscow do not signify an emergency situation at the moment.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., May 31 Space technicians moved ahead with final preparations here tonight to launch the Gemini 9 manned mission tomorrow, despite an electrical problem in an Atlas rocket that was quickly corrected.
WASHINGTON, May 31 The Consolidated Edison Company changed its plans for the controversial Cornwall power plant today and will put the entire hydroelectric facility underground.

Members of the Rockefeller family have pledged an additional $300,000 to the Saratoga Performing Arts Center. The latest gift comes from Mrs. John D. Rockefeller Jr. and Laurance S. Rockefeller. It is on a one-to-one matching basis, with Sept. 30 as the deadline. Gene Robb, president of the center, announced the gift.

The engagement of Miss Wendy Whitman Hohenstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Adolph Van Kirk Hohenstein of the Bronx, to Alan D. Borisoff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel M. Borisoff of Rochester, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents.
Stock prices fell sharply yesterday, losing a large part of the gains registered in last week's slow-paced recovery.
ALGIERS, May 31 Syria and Algeria have called for a united front of "progressive socialist forces" to oppose the "attacks of colonialism and imperialism" in Africa, Asia and Latin America.

WASHINGTON, May 31 A group of Republican Congressmen, who have been pressing for a Congressional review of the draft, charged today, that the way in which the Selective Service System chose draftees was capricious and arbitrary.

KINGSPORT, Tenn., May 31 Mr. and Mrs. John Russell Sherrill have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katherine Blount Sherrill, to John Edward Powell. He is the son of John Eris Powell of Chevy Chase, Md., and the late Mrs. Powell.
An 18-year-old high school student was charged last night with having planted three bombs that exploded in lower Manhattan in the last week.

WASHINGTON, May 31, (AP) Gen. William Hugh Blanchard, Air Force Vice Chief of Staff, suffered a heart attack at a Pentagon meeting today and died a short time later. He was 50 years old and was the second-ranking officer in the Air Force.
WASHINGTON, May 31 The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
RICHMOND, May 31 An earthquake rattled windows and upset dishes in Richmond and the surrounding counties early today, but caused no injuries or extensive property damage.
New York City rainfall in May totaled 4.26 inches, more than half an inch above the normal of 3.67 inches. It also was the heaviest rainfall for the month since 1953.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) California's Attorney General, Thomas C. Lynch, appealed to the Supreme Court today to review and overturn a decision that the state's ban on pay television for homes is unconstitutional.

BONN, May 31 An official of the State Art Collection of Weimar in East Germany said today that two portraits by Albrecht Durer of Hans and Felicitas Tucher of have been missing from the museum's collection since the end of World War II. The museum was known before the war as the Grand Ducal Museum.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, May 31 The United Nations Special Committee on Colonialism adopted a resolution today urging Britain to take all necessary measures, including force to oust the white minority regime in Rhodesia. The resolution supported mainly by African and Asian countires, was adopted by a vote of 18 to 1, with the United States, Denmark and Italy abstaining.
Go home the day after operation for cataracts or hernias?
SAIGON, Wednesday, June 1 An important Buddhist monk was wounded in a terrorist attack this morning.
LAGOS, Nigeria, May 31--All is reported quiet in Northern Nigeria after demonstrations in the last three days.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, May 31 A military court today condemned to death former Premier Evariste Kimba and three former Cabinet members who were accused of plotting to kill the President, Lieut. Gen. Joseph D. Mobutu. The trial, held outdoors under a blazing sun, lasted 90 minutes.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) A hearing examiner has recommended dismissal of Federal Trade Commission charges that two manufacturers of Portland cement violated antitrust laws by acquiring ready-mixed concrete companies in New York.

It was a year ago today that William McChesney Martin Jr., chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, delivered a speech before the Alumni Federation of Columbia University that startled Wall and Main Streets.
WARSAW, May 31 About 30 students, most of them believed to be Cubans, smashed 10 windows at the American Embassy here today with rocks and ink bottles.

THE early-morning chill at Aqueduct yesterday went unnoticed by three men. They were warmed by the final smash ing workout of Kauai King, his last sharp tune-up before he takes aim at the Belmont Stakes on Saturday and a hoped-for sweep of the Triple Crown. The three were Mike Ford, the owner; Henry Forrest, the trainer, and Don Brumfield, the jockey.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) Drew Pearson and Jack Anderson, defendants in a $2million libel suit by Senator Thomas J. Dodd, were accused by the Senator's lawyer today of trying the case in the press rather than in court.
PARIS, May 31 The Renault automobile company and Air France have negotiated two unusual deals with the Soviet Union and Communist China.

A week-long Festival From India, offering full-length color film by director Satyajit Ray and recitals on the 25-string sarode by Ali Akbar Khan, will begin July 25 at Philharmonic Hall in the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, it was announced yesterday.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., May 31--The Suffolk Board of Supervisors approved today two contrasting reapportionment proposals for consideration by a Federal court that had ordered the county to change its system.

WASHINGTON, May 31 The Supreme Court gave the Government broad authority yesterday to bar mergers between competing companies in industries experiencing rapid concentration, even if no adverse affect upon competition could be proved.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 31 (AP) Gov. Frank Clement announced today he would seek the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate opposing the man who defeated him two years ago, Senator Ross Bass.
LIVINGSTONE, Zambia, May 31 (Reuters) A Rhodesian Railways train carrying copper and zinc exports from Zambia crossed the border into Rhodesia today without hindrance.
GENEVA Members of the Swiss watch industry are beginning to wonder whether they may have somehow developed a self-winding sales boom.
WASHINGTON, May 31 Europe is acting these days like a jealous wife. Every time Uncle Sam looks at another woman the cry goes up that Old Sugar Daddy is thinking about divorce.
The International Business Machines Corporation announced a subscription price of $285 a share for its proposed offering to stockholders of 1,324,136 shares of capital stock.

Three former convicts were indicted yesterday on charges of conspiring to extort millions of dollars from homosexuals. One of the accused is a reputed leader of a nationwide ring that preyed on the victims.
WILHELMSHAVEN, West Germany, May 31 (Reuters) British and West German sailors cast wreaths into the North Sea today to commemorate the Battle of Jutland of World War I.
Kidder, Peabody Co., Inc., a 100-year-old diversified investment banking firm, will take over today the business of B.J. Van Ingen Co., Inc., a 50-year-old tax-exempt bondhouse.
Miss Josephine L. Wright, author and educator, died of a heart attack Friday in her home at 82 Washington Place.
WASHINGTON, May 31 The Administration narrowly won an initial round today in a surprisingly sharp fight over easing penalties on narcotics addict, who are also pushers, charged with Federal crimes.
Tung-Sol Electric, Inc., which held merger talks with the Wagner Electric Corporation, is now courting Wagner's stockholders.
Baseball will hold its second annual summer freeagent draft at the Hotel Roosevelt next Tuesday and Wednesday, Commissioner William D. Eckert announced yesterday.

Effective enforcement of the housing code is essential to correct the worst evils of New York's slum dwellings, but a chronic shortage of inspection funds has traditionally handicapped the city in its enforcement efforts.

WASHINGTON, May 31 The White House Conference on Civil Rights, which opens here tomorrow, was dealt a blow today when the national director of the Congress of Racial Equality announced he would move to throw out the prepared agenda and start from scratch.

ROME, May 31 A centerleft coalition government took over control of the autonomous Alpine region of Val d'Aosta today, ousting a Communistfront regime that had resisted the change with a legislative strike.

PARIS, May 31 A distinguished, lively and expect ant audience turned up tonight at the Odeon to attend the Metropolitan Opera's first performance in Europe in 56 years. The opera was Rossini's "Il Barbiere di Siviglia," with a cast familiar to New York operagoers but, of course, largely unknown here.

TOKYO, May 31 Masahiko (Fighting) Harada of Japan, living up to his nickname, convincingly, beat Eder Jofre of Brazil tonight to retain the bantamweight boxing championship of the world on a unanimous decision.

The Kinney Service Corporation and National Cleaning Contractors, Inc., announced yesterday that the Government had withdrawn its motion for a preliminary injunction to restrain the merger of National into Kinney.

WASHINGTON, May 31 The State Department announced today that, under new regulations, some Cuban refugees in Spain, Mexico and other countries would have no difficulty in joining relatives in the United States.
KANSAS CITY, May 31 (AP) Danny Cater and Mike Hershberger drove in two runs apiece as the Kansas City Athletics got 12 hits to trounce the Detroit Tigers 7-1, tonight.
WASHINGTON, May 31 (UPI) Adm. Willard J. Smith became the 13th commandant of the Coast Guard today.
CHICAGO, May 31--An increase of $42-billion in the Federal budget to liquidate poverty by 1975 was urged today by Leon H. Keyserling, a Washington economic consultant.

RECENT Indian history, ancient folkways and conflicting paths to the good life are united in this modest and satis fying novel. The major figures, whose destinies cross and clash, embody ideas and values in a kind of reverse Platonism, as if the general notion had taken local form in the people in the book. The place of the novel is a steel mill.
WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) The Missouri Pacific Railroad asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today, for authority to acquire control of the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway.
WASHINGTON, May 31--The United States Navy has disclosed that an American sailor recently tried, apparently without success, to sell top-secret information to the Soviet Union.
LOS ANGELES, May 31 Jerold M. Bova, a white policeman, was exonerated today by a coroner's jury looking into his killing of a Negro motorist, Leonard Deadwyler, three weeks ago.

SAN DIEGO, May 30 Chuck Connors, the baseball player turned actor, closed a recent introduction of Ronald Reagan, the actor turned politician, by declaring that one could search every state "from the coasts of Maine to the coasts of California" and not find another man like Mr. Reagan.

The policy commission of the National Education Association recommended yesterday that free public schooling be made available to all children at the age of 4. It called "obsolete" the now generally accepted school starting age of 6.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) The Supreme Court denied today a hearing to school officials of Jackson, Miss., who contended that innate differences between races in their aptitude justified segregation of white and Negro pupils.

Former President and Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower will celebrate their 50th wedding anniversary on July 1 the first Presidential couple to have a golden wedding day since the John Quincy Adamses in 1847.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 111.2 on Friday from 111.1 on Thursday.

GLEN RIDGE, N.J., May 31 Charles J. Gavan, a founder and president of the GavanGraham Electrical Product Corporation, Elizabeth, died Sunday in Clara Maass Memorial Hospital. His home was at 188 Forest Avenue.
ALBANY, May 31 Upstate Republicans planned new moves today to try to force New York City to raise its 15-cent transit fare.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) The White House announced today that the wedding ceremony of Luci Baines Johnson and Patrick J. Nugent in the Shrine of the Immaculate Conception on Aug. 6, would not be televised or broadcast.
PITTSBURGH, May 31 (AP) The Chicago Cubs took advantage of a wild streak by Bob Veale, a Pittsburgh southpaw, in the fifth inning tonight and scored two runs for a 2-1 victory over the Pirates.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 31 (AP) Rodger Ward, one of the outstanding drivers in auto racing history, quit the sport tonight.

HURON, S.D., May 31 Huron College, a Presbyterian institution with 600 students, conferred honorary degrees tonight on Vice President and Mrs. Humphrey. His degree was Doctor of Civil Law. Hers was Doctor of Fine Arts.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 31 (AP) Dave Johnson, a hothitting rookie second baseman, smacked a three-run triple in the first inning today and Andy Etchebarren also drove in three runs on a double and homer as Baltimore routed Minnesota, 14-5.
ALBANY, May 31 Governor Rockefeller tonight signed a bill continuing for one more year the arrangement under which the Surrogates and Family Courts share jurisdiction over adoptions.
SAN JOSE, Calif., May 31 (AP) -- The police said today that a teen-age robbery gang had admitted bludgeoning to death a priest and a warehouseman from whom they got $50 in loot.
The spot rate on the British pound eased yesterday in active trading on foreign exchange markets here. The rate closed at $2.7911, down 4 points from last Friday's level.
Tonight at 10:10 o'clock, Olympic Airways begins transAtlantic service from New York to Rome. Soaring with the Boeing 707 Super Fan Jet are the hopes of a small advertising agency.
The Union Carbide Corporation announced yesterday it had formed an electronics division, which will be headed by Robert A. Charpie as president.

BRUSSELS, May 31--The foreign ministers of Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg failed today to make progress toward a common position on the question of sites for the principal institutions of the North Atlantic alliance.

Irving Hochberg, a former clothing executive and associate treasurer of the Brookdale Hospital Center in Brooklyn, died yesterday in New York University Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived at 945 Fifth Avenue.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., May 31 The State Commissioner of Social Welfare has asked for a complete report on the drive on welfare violators in Niagara County and the reported designation of a welfare applicant as a "nigger" by the county's welfare director.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 31 George Regan, a 29-year-old Canadian-born reinsman, has been guiding standardbreds for five seasons, half of those in this area and all in the role of provisional driver. Each time Regan's name has appeared on a Doc Robins program, it has been accompanied by a parenthesized (P) notation, which informs the betting public that the man does not hold a fullfledged driver's license in this state.
Spartans Industries, Inc., will emerge as the surviving company in a merger with E.J. Korvette, Inc., it was disclosed last night after the boards of both companies approved the merger in principle.

Events today: New York Philharmonic "Promenade," Philharmonic Hall, 8:30 P.M.; Choral Arts Society of the Japan Missionary College, Town Hall, 5:30; concert of popular music under the auspices of the National Hay Fever Relief Association, Town Hall, 8:15.
SAN JUAN, P.R., May 31 (AP) Pablo Casals will be unable to conduct the opening concert of the annual Casals Festival tomorrow at the University of Puerto Rico.

LUDINGTONVILLE, N.Y., May 31 Edward J. Weiner, a former New York exporter was disconsolate as he walked under the tall pines, flowering crab apple trees and weeping willows near the little log house he had built for retirement in this quiet farm country of Putnam County.

Two Manhattan lawyers, one prominent in youth work and the other active in Catholic affairs, are among a dozen persons Mayor Lindsay is considering for the board that reviews complaints about policemen.

A military tribunal in the Congo has taken the alleged plot to overthrow President Mobutu seriously enough to sentence four former Government ministers to prompt death by public hanging in a Leopoldville square. The verdict had been anticipated by the Government's Information Commissioner immediately after the arrests Monday and is doubtless intended as a warning to any other plotters against the sixmonth-old military-led regime.
A prominent West German business economist acknowledged yesterday that Texaco's takeover of Deutsche Erdol, A. G., had caused apprehension among segments of the country's industry.
Amzy B. Steed, general counsel of Texaco, Inc., since 1964, has been appointed to the additional post of vice president, it was announced here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (UPI) The Supreme Court ordered today that a report be submitted on the mental competence of Melvin David Rees Jr., a Hyattsville, Md., jazz musician who has said he is giving up his legal fight to avoid execution in Virginia's electric chair.

Illegal parking in crosstown streets in the 40's and 50's has been made a risky rarity by a sustained police drive. But in the East 60's, 70's and 80's a sort of bumper-to-bumper sanctuary has developed.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 31--A former postal employe today became the first Negro since Reconstruction to win a Democratic nomination for sheriff in Alabama.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 31 The Soviet Union called today for action by the next General Assembly to restrict celestial bodies to peaceful exploration and scientific study for the benefit of all mankind.
ROME, May 31 (Reuters) The governor of the Bank of Italy, Dr. Guido Carli, urged today the formation of an internationally run reserve currency unit.

ROCHESTER, May 31 (UPI) Two-ply automobile tires are safe and superior tires, George R. Vila, chairman of the United States Rubber Company, insisted today in a speech before the Rochester Rotary Club.

RANCHO SANTA FE, Calif., May 31 Mr. and Mrs. Richard Keeline Wilcox have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sarah Lucinda Wilcox, to Tyler Dann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Dann of Quaker Hill in Pawling, N.Y.

BANGKOK, Thailand, May 31 (Reuters) Smiles and handshakes, in evidence when talks began two days ago, were absent today as Indonesian and Malaysian officials struggled to negotiate an end to hostilities between their two countries.
Norman Kruchkow of McKeeBerger-Mansueto has been elected president of the metropolitan New York chapter of the Construction Specifications Institute.
HOUSTON, May 31 Most of the experiments of the Gemini 9 space flight are scheduled to be performed around a $900,000 space platform built mainly from spare parts of old rockets and space ships.
GLYNDEBOURNE, England, May 31 Sir Michael Redgrave made his debut as a producer here tonight with Massenet's "Werther."

SANTO DOMINGO, May 31 Provisional President Hector Garcia Godoy declared today that he would press for removal of the Inter-American Peace Force before the republic's new president is inaugurated on July 1.
LONDON, May 31 (Reuters) Nine thousand people packed a stadium tonight at a dedication service on the eve of Billy Graham's second religious crusade in Britain.

ALBANY, May 31 What began as a "warm welcome" to about 30 would-be City University freshmen sitting in the Senate gallery today ended as a hot debate between Democratic and Republican Senators over the future of financial aid for the overburdened university.
CHICAGO, May 31 Andrew Nicholas Rebori, an architect who designed many of this city's buildings, died at his home today. He was 80 years old.

Honeywell, Inc., announced the formation yesterday of a new company group to handle all major computer activities. The reorganization of the company's efforts in the data processing field follows last week's acquisition of the Computer Control Company,

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 31 James H. Anderson of 151 Centre Avenue here, retired secretary of the United Verde Copper Company of New York, died today at Strong Memorial Hospital in Rochester. He was 88-years old.
The Rev. Samuel Joseph Wylie, a 47-year-old Boston rector whose religious background is as ecumenical as his persuasion, has been elected dean of the General Theological Seminary, here.
LONDON, May 31 (AP) A young Labor party member of the House of Commons is crusading for better working conditions in the centuries-old Houses of Parliament.
ROME, May 31 Most of Italy's 160,000 postal, telegraph and telephone workers went on a 48-hour strike early today and nearly paralyzed domestic and international communications.

ST. LOUIS, May 31 (AP) The St. Louis Cardinals scored all their runs after two were out in the fifth inning tonight and beat the Houston Astros, 3-0, as Ray Washburn and Hal Woodeshick combined to pitch a five-hitter.
SYDNEY, Australia, May 31 Reports that Britain is considering a military withdrawal from Southeast Asia continued to cause concern in Canberra today.
WASHINGTON, May 31--The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether state courts must give defendants a speedy trial, as required by the Sixth Amendment to the Federal Constitution.
WE'RE really in the dress business today," Vin cent Monte-Sano remarked yesterday in the course of his commentary on the MonteSano Pruzan fall coat and suit collection.
NEW YORK theatergoers can relax this morning: Ethel Merman and Irving Berlin are collaborating again.
A plan that might have resolved the dispute over the safe width of trans-Atlantic jet airlanes has been blocked by the British and Canadian Governments, according to the Air Line Pilots Association.

MEXICO CITY, May 31 A gala audience, led by Mexico's first lady, Mrs. Gustavo Diaz Ordaz, gave the Metropolitan Opera National Company a warm though restrained reception at the start of its first visit here last night.

SILVERMINE, Conn., May 31 Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Thomas have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carol Culbertson Thomas, to Barnum Beach Burrall, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry D. Burrall of Saratoga Springs, N.Y., formerly of Litchfield.

Jacques Wullschleyer of Hofstra, seeded first, led the field into the quarter-final round of the metropolitan intercollegiate tennis championships yesterday at the West Side Club in Forest Hills, Queens.
The 13th annual production of the Milliken Breakfast Show opens today at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel and will be seen at 8 A.M. every weekday morning through June 171.
A program designed to convert New York into a film producer's haven free of red tape, nuisance fees and arbitrary censorship was implemented yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.
Steel production eased eighttenths of 1 per cent last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

Mrs. Florence E. Gelfand, mother-in-law of William J. Diamond, deputy commissioner of buildings, was fined $40 in Criminal Court yesterday for violations on a building she owns at 76 East 79th Street.
The entire second floor of the Loew's State Building at 1540 Broadway, the northeast corner of 45th Street, has been leased by Sartorius Co., stock brokerage concern.

LAGOS, Nigeria, May 30 The wave of anti-Government violence that has swept Nigeria's vast Northern Region has plunged this nation into its most serious crisis since it achieved independence from Britain in 1960.
After a fairly strong start, most issues on the American Stock Exchange started to weaken around the noon hour and closed at their lows for the day.
TRENTON, May 31 The Hughes administration's controversial gun control bill won final approval in the Legislature tonight when the Senate passed it, 16-12, with the entire Republican minority opposed.
Laws enacted in California and Nevada on control of the hallucinogenic drug LSD are similar to a law that took effect in New York State in July, 1965.
WASHINGTON, May 31,--The United States denied today that it was preparing to attack Cuba.

WASHINGTON, May 31 The Chief of Naval Operations has taken private issue with Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara by warning that the continued construction of conventionally powered warships poses "grave implications for national security."
An increase in the transit fare is imminent, highly placed officials in the Lindsay administration said yesterday.

HAVANA, May 31, (UPI) The Cuban Government charged today that six men whose "pirate launch" was sunk offshore late Sunday had been sent to Cuba by the United States Central Intelligence agency to kill Premier Castro.

ALBANY, May 31 After weeks of haggling, a compromise bill increasing state aid to public schools by $102.3-million received unanimous approval in both houses of the politically divided Legislature today.

WASHINGTON, May 31 As the first Surveyor spacecraft streaked toward the moon today, the "watchdog of Congress" said that as much as $2.5-million could have been saved on the project if space program management had been more effective.

DUBLIN, June 1--The Irish Republic's electorate of 1.7 million peacefully made its choice for President today between 83year-old Eamon de Valera, the representative of the Fianna Fail party, and 49-year-old Thomas F. O'Higgins, the representative of Fine Gael.
WASHINGTON, June 1-- The Government will probably take in more money than it spends during this calendar year, President Johnson said today.

Bolero, the 73-foot yawl belonging to Mrs. Charles M. White of Huntington, L.I., that had the best corrected time in the 200-mile Storm Trysail Club's Block Island race last weekend, lost a protest hearing yesterday and with it a successful defense of the Harvey Conover Memorial Trophy that was the main prize.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, June 1--The Dominican people voted in an atmosphere of tranquility today in the country's third free election of this century.
Reginald I. McKenzie was appointed yesterday as president of the Aerojet-General Corporation, an 84 per cent owned subsidiary of the General Tire and Rubber Company.

KINGS POINT, L.I., June 1 --Commencement assumed immediate significance today for all 196 cadets in the graduating class of the United States Merchant Marine Academy. They all have officer berths aboard many of the nation's undermanned merchant ships.
PHILADELPHIA, June 1-- An 18-year-old Haverford College freshman who refused to register for the draft was sentenced today to work two years in Friends Hospital, a Quaker mental institution here.

ST.LOUIS, Mo., June 1 (UPI) --International Association of Machinists Local 837, which represents some 18,000 McDonnell Aircraft Company employes, has been taken over by the international union, it was announced Wednesday.

MOSCOW, June 1--Speaking in Khabarovsk, a large industrial city near the Chinese border, President Nikolai V. Podgorny warned today that the Soviet people were alert and determined to protect their Far Eastern territories against any invaders.

NORFOLK, Va., June 1 (AP) --Bids will be opened here June 9 for construction of an airconditioned, humidity-controlled building to house the personal and official papers of the late General of the Army Douglas MacArthur.
A change in senior management was announced here yesterday by the ABC Consolidated Corporation, which operates the Nedick's snack bars and provides refreshment services.

NEW HAVEN, June 1--The bankrupt New Haven Railroad disclosed today that it did not expect the completion of its life-saving merger with two solvent railroads--the Pennsylvania and the New York Central--before Jan. 1, 1968.
About 4,000 city employes picketed City Hall during their lunch hour yesterday to oppose Mayor Lindsay's plan for a "tripartite" labor relations committee.
ALBANY, June 1--Upstate legislators moved tonight to force New York City to raise its 15-cent transit fare.

Mrs.John V. Lindsay appealed yesterday for volunteers --men and women of all ages and from all backgrounds--to join forces with the city's teachers to help raise the educational level of disadvantaged children.
WASHINGTON, June 1--The House passed today a bill offering narcotics addicts charged with Federal crimes the chance for cure instead of prison.

KANSAS CITY, June 1 (UPI) --Ken Harrelson hit a homer and drove in three runs and Joe Nossek batted in a pair of runs tonight as the Kansas City Athletics handed the slumping Cleveland Indians their fifth defeat in their last six games, 8-3.

A Bell System debenture issue that may not be called for redemption for five years was offered publicly yesterday priced to yield 5.45 per cent--the most favorable terms on record for investors in any such issue.

WASHINGTON, June 1(AP) --The Social Security Administration reported today that more than 17 million Americans--90 per cent of those eligible--had signed up for extra Medicare benefits. The deadline for enrolling was last midnight.

Of the four Musick brothers who played football at the University of Southern California, Jim (Sweet) Musick stood out as the most famous. He was the fullback on the 1931 team that worked one of the game's legendary miracles in inflicting Notre Dame's first defeat in three years, after trailing by 14-0 in the final quarter.

Senator Robert F. Kennedy was challenged yesterday by a campaign manager for State Supreme Court Justice Arthur G. Klein to produce facts to back up his charge that Mr. Klein's candidacy for Manhattan surrogate was "tainted by the suspicion of corruption of a deal."
The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday that the total volume of outstanding commercial paper during April rose 5 per cent, or $546-million, to a record of $11.56-billion.

Dominique Lattinelli, an 18year-old high school student accused of planting three bombs that exploded in lower Manhattan in the last week, was committed to Bellevue Hospital yesterday for observation by Criminal Court Judge Richard F. Daly.

Seven hundred and fifty persons, including stable owners and racing fans, attended the annual Belmont Ball last night, in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The dinnerdance heralded Saturday's running of the Belmont Stakes at Aqueduct and saluted the fourth century of thoroughbred racing in the United States. (The sport was introduced in 1665 in what is now Garden City, L.I., by Richard Nicolls, a Colonial Governor).
Stock market slumps such as that of recent weeks are having less and less of an adverse impact on retail sales of luxury goods, a leading retailer asserted here yesterday.
THE excitement of remote places and rivers makes for interesting reading in four new books for children. The age range of the books is from 6 through 17 years old.
BETHESDA, Md., June 1 (AP)--Vice Adm. William Ward Smith, former chairman of the United States Maritime Commission, died Monday at Bethesda Naval Hospital. He was 78 years old.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (UPI) --Senator Robert F. Kennedy left tonight on the first leg of a tour of four nations of Africa.

ALBANY, June 1--Mayor Lindsay and Governor Rockefeller today sent the Legislature a bill that would make available to New York City the hundreds of millions of dollars it needs to catch up with its long-postponed public school construction.

Net railway operating income of Canadian National Railways in April rose to $2,623,000 from $1,677,000 in the corresponding month last year. Operating revenues were $75,796,000 and $68,154,000 in the respective months.

The New York Civil Liberties Union has joined Dr.Timothy Leary, the experimenter with psychedelic drugs, in challenging the legality of a police raid on April 17 at Dr.Leary's Castalia Foundation in Millbrook, N.Y.
TEAMS led by Alvin Roth of New York and Mark Berger of Great Neck clashed in the 56-board final of the Reisinger Knockout Team Championship which began yesterday afternoon.

ANAHEIM, Calif., June 1, (AP)--Jerry Adair's pinch-hit single and a sacrifice fly by Luis Aparicio gave the Baltimore Orioles two runs in the 10th inning tonight and a 9-7 victory over the California Angels.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 1-- The Minnesota Theater Company has begun its new season at the Tyrone Guthrie Theater with a crackling production of Thornton Wilder's "The Skin of Our Teeth." Douglas Campbell, who directed, has an estimable company and a beautifully usable stage; and he devours theatrical opportunities the way Joan Sutherland devours coloratura passages.

Mrs. Mary T. O'Neill, mother of Louis F. O'Neill, sports editor of The Long Island StarJournal, and widow of Patrick O'Neill. died yesterday in his home, at 88-12 62d Drive, Rego Park, Queens. She was 95 years old.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 1--The leadership of the Czechoslovak Communist party is apparently counting on the achievements of science to bolster its lagging cause.
LAKE SUCCESS, L.I., June 1--Six children were injured slightly and a bus driver was hospitalized after an accident involving two school buses on the Long Island Expressway this morning.
NEEDHAM, Mass., June 1-- Miss Mary Eleanor Howland and David Brooks Smoyer were married this afternoon by the Rev. Francis Garrity at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church.

The 21st game of the world title chess match between the champion, Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, and his compatriot, Boris Spassky, ended in a draw after the 39th move at Moscow's Variety Theater last night. Petrosian needs one more point to retain the title.
The Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago has found that inflation is catching up with efforts to take advantage of technological price reductions.
WEST POINT, N.Y., June 1--Seton Hall rallied for eight runs in the sixth inning to hand Army a 10-5 baseball defeat today.

TETERBORO, N.J., June 1-- The New Jersey Legislature was asked yesterday to abolish this community of about 50 Industries, 8 homes and 22 residents. The angry citizenry vowed here today to fight for their municipal identity.
The American Stock Exchange continued to fall back yesterday as volume fell to its lowest level in almost eight months.
The American Stock Exchange reported yesterday the changes carried below in the share holdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.

WHEN Eddie Dooley was an allAmerica performer for Dartmouth in the distant past, he was a strong armed young man who could throw a football as far as anyone ever threw it. He also could absorb a battering without complaint. The second attribute will be a lot more important than the first in the new assignment he formally took over yesterday.

George F. Salman, retired controller of Minerals Chemicals Philipp Corporation and a former volunteer in the International Service Corps, died on Monday in Europe. Mr. Salman, who died while on an airplane flight between Hamburg, Germany, and Amsterdam, the Netherlands, was 58 years old.
PARIS, June 1.--Nancy Richey, the durable 23-year-old Dallas star, played her way into the semi-finals of the French international tennis tournament today, but not without trial.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) --The Interstate Commerce Commission today ordered an investigation to determine whether seat belts should be required in passenger buses.
After a session of soaring prices on Tuesday, soybean and wheat futures declined yesterday morning under the impact of profit taking.

Disowned by an extremist minority and initially divided over procedure, the White House Conference on Civil Rights accurately reflects the turmoil and diffuse striving of the civil rights movement itself. These tensions might have paralyzed the conference if Ben W. Heineman, the chairman, had not made a tactical retreat and acceded to the request that delegates be permitted to take roll-call votes on specific resolutions. Decision by consensus obviously has its limits.

Is Mayor Lindsay going down to defeat or ruinous compromise on his tax program without putting up a real fight for it? This is the indicated outlook at the moment, and it can only be viewed with acute distress.
LONDON, June 1--The Oxford Union, the university's debating society, is angry at the English-Speaking Union, a body formed to promote friendship in the English-speaking world.
TARRYTOWN, N.Y., June 1--Two fathers and a mother shared honors with their daughters at Marymount College's commencement today. An audience of 1,000 attended in the Spellman auditorium.

WASHINGTON--In the nation's capital where dinners at home for 2 or 200 are part of a casual way of life there is probably no table in the city more elaborately prepared than that of the Korean Embassy.
MEXICO CITY, June 1--Latin American business leaders were urged today to modernize their methods and accelerate economic integration.
"Thank you" was the most cutting remark yesterday as some 50 actors showed their stuff in auditions for directors of 20 resident professional theaters all over the country.

Harold G. Clark, formerly sales manager for the New York metropolitan area of Rootes Motors, Inc., died yesterday in North District Hospital, Pompano Beach, Fla. He was 70 years old and lived in Pompano Beach.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., June 1--Charles M. Huenlich, who assisted Thomas A. Edison in his laboratories here, died yesterday at Dunedin, Fla., where he moved four years ago. He was 77 years old and a former resident of Bloomfield.
FORT ORD, Calif. (UPI)-- The brief but vigorous campaign of a World War II veteran to get his son out of the armed services ended today when the Army agreed to give the youth a medical discharge.
School bells are being rung steadily by a growing number of major United States corporations interested in taking part in the burgeoning education business.
PORT LOUIS, Mauritius, June 1--The leader of the pro-independence Labor party in Mauritius has criticized a report issued yesterday on electoral reforms here.
The election of William R. Thomas as president of the Financial Executives Institute was announced yesterday in White Sulphur Springs, W. Va. The appointment becomes effective Sept. 1.
LEOPOLDVILLE, The Congo June 1 (Reuters)--Four former Cabinet Ministers were sentinced today to be hanged in public tomorrow following their conviction for plotting against the Congolese Government.
"Magic Needle," the current needle arts exhibition of the New Hope Historical Society, includes work by groups from around the country and by celebrities such as Joan Crawford and Mary Martin.
RIGHT on all the big things, wrong on all the little ones," the late Sam Rayburn said about President Harry S. Truman. That's how he emerges in today's blazingly controversial portrait.
CHICAGO, June 1--The New York Yankees came apart in all directions tonight, reverted to their saddest early-season form and lost to the Chicago White Sox, 6-2, for their third straight defeat.
LONDON, June 1--The British and United States Governments are acting on the belief that, in the end, President de Gaulle of France is likely to pull French troops out of West Germany.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 1--The Soviet Union's request for General Assembly action to neutralize celestial bodies is believed by some Western diplomats here to be more likely to delay than expedite the adoption of such a treaty.
Glamour stocks bounced upward in active trading yesterday but the rest of the market was a quiet, dull affair, with prices falling slightly.

LIVERPOOL, England, June 1 (AP)--An international competition for hopeful orchestra conductors got under way today. It was an ordeal for Stephen Anthony Simon--the 28year-old New Yorker drew last place and had to listen to the other contestants for 4 hours.

WITH ice shows you have no choice between types. The format remains inviolable. Don't expect drama, profundity or sociological significance. Last night the 26th edition of "Ice Capades" opened at Madison Square Garden and the news this morning is that tradition was upheld for the umpteenth time.
The Franklin D. Roosevelt (East River) Drive between 20th and 63d streets will be closed to all traffic on seven consecutive weekends, starting Saturday, to erect steel for a new viaduct.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 1--United States Air Force fighter-bombers have reduced much of North Vietnam's extensive Yenbay arsenal and munitions storage area to flaming rubble in the largest single raid of the war, Air Force officers said today.

MOSCOW, June 1--The mutation and extinction of species in the evolution of life on earth may be attributable in part to periodic disappearances and reversals of earth's magnetic field, a scientist from Columbia University said here today.

BANGKOK, Thailand, June 1 --The Foreign Ministers of Indonesia and Malaysia ended their four-day peace talks here today with champagne toasts and an agreement to submit to their Governments "the principles" for practical steps to restore friendly relations.

WASHINGTON, June 1-- Leaders of the White House Conference on Civil Rights yielded today to militant delegates and reluctantly agreed to permit a vote on resolutions that could embarrass the Administration.
BRUSSELS, June 1 (Reuters) --The Belgian bank rate will be raised tomorrow by per cent to 5 per cent, the Belgian National Bank announced today.

ST. PAUL June 1 (AP)-- President Kennedy told an executive of The New York Times that if the paper had printed all it knew about preparations for the Bay of Pigs invasion the nation would have been saved from a "colossal mistake," a Times editor disclosed today.
Mrs.Lyndon B. Johnson and her daughter Lynda Bird arrived here yesterday with shopping and the theater among their plans. Luci Johnson is scheduled to come here today.
The appointment of John F. Moriarty as sales vice president was anounced yesterday by the Warner Brothers Company, a Bridgeport, Conn., apparel producer.

There were no castanets clicking in the dim, candlelit Mexican restaurant where the James H. Van Alens gave an informal dinner party last night. But the sonorous twang of guitars more than made up for it.

TAIF, Saudi Arabia, May 30 --Mohamed al-Badr, the deposed Imam of Yemen, and today his enemy, President General Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic, "appears to be carrying out the cease-fire of last August" by withdrawing his troops from Yemen.

REIDSVILLE, N.C., June 1 --In the First Baptist Church of Reidsville today, Miss Alice Lee Boatwright, daughter of Edgar Vaughn Boatwright and the late Mrs. Boatwright, was married to Terence John Baker, son of Mrs. Francis Pearson Baker of London and the late Mr. Baker.

From 41st Street uptown along Eighth Avenue to Madison Square Garden, Greek souvenir-shopkeepers and restaurant owners appeared bewildered when confronted yesterday with a few Greek lines in a cartoon of a banker astride a tiger.
WASHINGTON, June 1-- President Johnson said today that he was "very concerned" about the status of the Administration's foreign aid request in Congress.
DAYTON, Ohio, June 1 (AP) --Three college students set a record by wearing fully pressurized space suits continuously for five days in a research test at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base near here.
The Westec Corporation, formerly known as Western Equities, Inc., is making a bid for the biggest acquisition in its 22-year growth in the natural-resource area.
MANCHESTER England, June 1 (AP)--Ron Holmberg and Cliff Richey of Dallas won third-round singles matches today in the North of England tennis tournament.
The Syntex Corporation reported yesterday record earnings for the quarter and nine months ended April 30.
DETROIT, June 1 (UPI)-- Strikes and school boycotts tomorrow by up to 2,500 Detroit area teachers were called today in defiance of a Michigan antistrike law.
LONDON, Thursday, June 2 (Reuters)--Lord King-Hall, one of Britain's top political and foreign affairs commentators, died here early today after a long illness. He was 73 years old.
The nation's universities were warned yesterday to take a clos er look at Government projects overseas to avoid compromising the traditional role of schools in education and public service.

EAST Side, West Side, all around the town they swing on arms fat and thin, old and young, rich and poor. The paper shopping bag and its more elegant cousin, the tote bag, have become fashion's most versatile accessory.
Problems and criticism are plainly round-the-clock companions of President Johnson. If it isn't Vietnam or inflation, it's the clatter of a metal spoon in the quiet hours of the night.

Mrs. Mary E. Brown Delehanty, a leader among organized industrial nurses and other professional groups, died yesterday in St. Clare's Hospital after a short illness. She was 63 years old and lived at 240 First Avenue. She was the widow of Harold Delehanty.
LONDON--Distinctive little stickers are starting to pop up on plate-glass windows all over the country.
The McCrory Corporation announced here yesterday the appointment of Edwin O. Wack as president of McCrory-McLellan-Green, its 556-variety store division.
One man gave the shoes he was wearing 40 years ago when he first stepped onto American soil.
The month of June was declared yesterday by the Police Department as the official amnesty period for the surrender of unauthorized weapons.

Surrogate Joseph A. Cox said yesterday that he had decided to designate the son of the other Manhattan surrogate, S. Samuel DiFalco, as special guardian of 35 minors involved in an estate estimated at $5million.
The photoengravers reached a settlement here early today with the World Journal Tribune, Inc., to become the sixth craft union to come to terms with the new merged newspaper enterprise.
