Graham Walkey, a mining engineer, testified in Federal Court here yesterday that preliminary exploration of the Texas Gulf Sulphur Company's property near Timmins, Ont., might have indicated only that the concern was drilling into "plugs" of mineralization rather than into a commercial ore body.
The New York Mets went camp yesterday when Ken Boyer's family arrived from St. Louis and moved into an apartment on Park Avenue at Eighty-Sixth Street for the summer.

Consolidated Edison's new proposal to build its Storm King hydroelectric plant underground is a vast improvement over the original plan to cut a huge gash in the mountainside. But while the utility deserves credit for a substantial concession in the long controversy, the proposal by no means disposes of all the valid objections that have been raised by lovers of the natural beauty of the Hudson Valley.
The television broadcast of "The Many Worlds of Mike Nichols" has been postponed indefinitely, the American Broadcasting Company announced yesterday.
Most people are more concerned with being able to hire competent baby sitters, handymen and part-time or fulltime domestics than they are with the liability they must assume as employers.
Reuben Warner, an insurance executive, died Tuesday of a heart attack in his home at 4601 Henry Hudson Parkway in Riverdale, the Bronx. His age was 68.

WASHINGTON, June 1-- Vice President Hubert Humphrey denounced today virtually every segment of American society for maintaining a "gap between promise and performance" in civil rights. And the audience, which was supposed to represent a cross-section of Americans, loved it.
PARIS, June 1 (Reuters) --The Government proposed far-reaching road safety measures today, including a speed limit for young people and new drivers.

WASHINGTON, June 1--The Justice Department, which has been criticized for letting Sam Giancana out of jail yesterday, said today it would have been legally impossible to keep the crime. figure behind bars.
Two period dramas have been booked for reserve-seat, two-aday stands in midtown first-run movie houses. Both are United Artists releases.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (UPI) --The United States Bureau of Mines said today it had erred in failing to check with the American Petroleum Institute before releasing an announcement about a program to develop an antipollution gasoline formula.

WASHINGTON, June 1-- The Governor of North Dakota has vetoed two proposed antipoverty projects for free legal aid to the poor because private lawyers feared it would harm their business, it was disclosed today.

COPENHAGEN, June 1-- The Seventeenth Royal Danish Ballet Festival ended here last night with a repeat performance of Flemming Flindt's full-length ballet, "The Three Musketeers." This festival was the first to be arranged by the Royal Danish Ballet's new chief, Mr. Flindt, and already he has succeeded in putting his mark on it in no uncertain way.

SPRING VALLEY, N.Y., June 1--Construction of Rockland County's first trunk-line sewer system got under way here today with Clarkstown Supervisor Paul F. Mundt, chairman of the county sewer commission, digging the first shovel of earth.
VIENNA, June 1--The Interior Ministry today invited the Habsburg pretender to the throne of former imperial Austria to return from exile.
WASHINGTON, June 1-- Manufacturers' inventories increased by $625-million in April to a total of nearly $70.3-billion, the Commerce Department reported today.

Franklin R. Weissberg, Mayor Lindsay's newly appointed consultant on the Broadway thea ter, television and movies, said yesterday that the $1.50 premium charged on tickets by brokers was "unrealistic" and should be increased.

GENEVA, June 1--Leading business and banking figures from both sides of the Atlantic said today that the successful conclusion of the Kennedy round of trade negotiations was the "most important and immediate task in the field of economic cooperation."
WASHINGTON, June 1--(AP) --Senator John J. Williams told the Senate today that the total of delinquent Federal taxes increased to nearly $1.3-billion last year, up 7.9 per cent from the 1964 figure.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) --Senator Frank J. Lausche, Democrat of Ohio, said today he was opposed to an increase in St.Lawrence Seaway tolls.
Upward of $20-million is believed lost yearly in the United States through the illegal use of credit cards.
This morning I am going to tell you a story--one that has never been told before-- the inside story of The New York Times and the Bay of Pigs, something of a mystery story.

The Ford Motor Company is negotiating with one of Israel's principal automotive dealers to set up a truck and tractor assembly plant there. If as expected, agreement is reached, the company said yesterday, Ford will be the first major American automobile manufacturer to have a commercial vehicle assembly line in Israel.

PHILADELPHIA, June 1 (UPI)--The Philadelphia Phillies rallied twice tonight to win a double-header from the Chicago Cubs with Richie Allen's three-run homer paving the way to a 7-4 victory in the second game after the Phils won the opener, 4-3.

MISS LISA LANE. who shared first place with a fellow New Yorker, Mrs. Gisela Gresser. in the recent United States Women's Chess Championship, produced a positional gem in her triumph over Miss Nona Karff, also of New York, a six-time winner of this women's classic.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) --About one million fewer persons were receiving Government-donated surplus foods this spring than a year earlier--a decline of about 17 per cent.
Two vanloads of sculpture were moved yesterday from the Whitney Museum of American Art at 22 West 54th Street to its new home at Madison Avenue and 75th Street.
CHICAGO, June 1--Miss Karin Ann Erickson and John E. Deitrick Jr. will be married on June 19 in the North Park Covenant Church.
HUE, South Vietnam, June 1 --Premier Nguyen Cao Ky ordered the Mayor of Hue today to use force to quell Buddhistled anti-Government forces here.

LONDON, June 1 (UPI)-- Two American pilots captured in North Vietnam, in a filmed appearance on British television last night, defended themselves against Communist charges that they are war criminals and subject to the death penalty.
The crew of a foundering Cypriote freighter Aktor was rescued by two American cargo ships in the Pacific yesterday.

ALBANY, June 1--A bill to increase the hourly minimum wage to $1.50 easily passed the Senate this evening after an agreement by legislative leaders that is expected to lead to similar approval in the Assembly tomorrow.

PHILADELPHIA, June 1-- An unwed 24-year-old mother, convicted of killing her fourday old son by dropping him into an incinerator in the apartment building where she lived, has agreed to submit to sterilization.

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., June 1 --Mrs. Margaret Foureman Heironimus, a civic leader in the Oranges and Maplewood, died yesterday at Orange Memorial Hospital. She was the wife of Walter W. Heironimus and lived at 18 Kensington Terrace here.

Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Droste Sanders of New York and New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Sanders's daughter, Miss Barbara Ridder McCoun, to Donald A. Herman of New York. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Clemens W. Herman of Indianapolis.

Paperboard production rose 19.7 per cent with 471,500 tons in the week ended May 28, from 393,898 in the corresponding 1965 week, the Paperboard "Group of the American Paper Institute reported yesterday.

JERICHO, L.I., June 1-- Mr. and Mrs. Charles Morgenstern have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ellyn Joyce Morgenstern, to Barry Charles Broden, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Broden of Ossining, N.Y.

As Angelo Presenzano underwent an operation in University Hospital Tuesday night, a nurse went through the routine of preparing his private room. She was startled to find a loaded .38caliber revolver in a drawer in a night table beside the bed, the police reported yesterday.

Dr. T. Duane Price, assistant professor of biochemistry at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons, died Sunday of a heart attack. He was 48 years old and lived at 438 West 116th Street.
The Government was urged yesterday to provide a "rating of essentiality" for the machinetool industry to make sure that defense production obtained the necessary equipment.
WASHINGTON, June 1--A dramatization of authentic tales and dances of American Indians, interwoven with modern dance and performed entirely by Indians, opened here tonight.

Congoleum-Nairn, Inc., the floor-covering concern, told stockholders at their annual meeting here yesterday that an increase in the quarterly cash dividend, a stock dividend and a stock split were all under consideration.
GENEVA, June, 1--A candidate from the Soviet bloc was elected today president of the International Labor Organization's annual conference for the first time since World War II.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., June 1--Once again, the hard-luck astronauts of Gemini 9 sat in their spacecraft on the launching pad here today, waited through most of the countdown --and went nowhere.

A more flexible use of tax policy to influence the economy in the short run has been recommended by a bipartisan subcommittee of Congress' Joint Economic Committee. It proposes greater reliance on rapid tax changes for stabilization purposes, through a rise in rates to counter inflation and a lowering to counter recession.
ALBANY, June 1--Governor Rockefeller will fly to Washington tomorrow to try to settle the controversy over the state's new medical assistance program.

Thomas P.F. Hoving, the city's 34-year-old Park Commissioner, swung enthusiastically from the bars of the new "geodesic dome" in Carl Schurz Park yesterday at the dedication of the first improvements in the playground's 32 years.
The reassignment of more than $41-million in billings was made known yesterday.
DEVON, Pa., June 1--Cap and Gown, some horsemen say, could be at his worst and still be the class of the conformation hunter division.

Brooklyn will hold a 100th birthday party for Prospect Park today with 7,000 pieces of cake, a parade of horse-drawn carriages and cosumed marchers reminiscent of the last century and congratulations from President Johnson.
WASHINGTON, June 1--A nationwide strike by 20,000 members of the Commercial Telegraphers Union disrupted operations today of the Western Union Telegraph Company for four hours.
TUSKEGEE, Ala., June 1-- Lucius Davenport Amer son's ambition did not sound unreasonable. He wanted to be a policeman.

Three common stock offerings reached the market yesterday and two of them sold out quickly. Morgan Stanley Co. and Prescott Co. managed the sale of 282,934 shares of Lubrizol Corporation stock priced at $37 a share. The shares are those outstanding after a threefor-two stock split May 16. The issue was oversubscribed.
Bernard Ettinger, co-sponsor of five state and city-aided Mitchell-Lama Housing projects in the Bronx, refused yesterday to waive immunity to testify before a Bronx grand jury.
Cassius Clay, in New York yesterday on his way from Cairo to Chicago, accused the Egyptian press of having misquoted him.
HELSINKI, Finland, June 1 --Secretary of State Dean Rusk conferred here today with Finnish leaders as minor demonstrations were held to protest United States policy in Vietnam.

BERLIN, June 1--The East German Communists claimed ownership today of two paintings a New York lawyer bought in 1946 for $500. They are believed to be the work of Albrecht Durer, and their value has been put at $1-million.

Mr. and Mrs.George Griswold Jr. of 1148 Fifth Avenue and Litchfield, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Tracy Griswold, to David Fratt Cunningham, son of Mrs. David Cunningham of New York and Washington, Conn., and the late Mr. Cunningham.

ROME, June 1--President Giuseppe Saragat said today that in the last 20 years Italy had been able for the first time to overcome the "social and political depression that seemed to bind it forever to a destiny of squalor and desolation."
MOSCOW, June 1--The sights and sounds of a city in ruins have moved a 32-year-old poet, Andrei Voznesensky, to lay his art at the service of the earthquake victims of Tashkent.
Constance Baker Motley, Borough President of Manhattan, said yesterday that the Federal Government should provide a free college education for every qualified student who desires it.

AUSTIN, Tex., June 1--Texas oil exploration received another stimulus today when the Texas Railroad Commission increased from five to 10 the number of oil wells in a new offshore field that get bonus production allowable rates.

KADUNA, Nigeria, June 1 (Reuters)--Ninety-two people died, 506 were wounded and 300 were arrested in last weekend's intertribal violence in the Northern Region of Nigeria, it was officially announced tonight.
LONDON, June 1--Prime Minister Wilson gave his assurance to Australia today that Britain was not about to abandon her defense role east of Suez.
WASHINGTON, June 1-- Contending Senate leaders in the quarrel over supervision of the Central Intelligence Agency postponed a showdown today in the hope of reaching a compromise.

Thirty pilots and crew members of the Belgian airline, Sabena, have found themselves homeless and without money in New York in the wake of a three-day strike. What is more, they have no means of getting home.
TUSKEGEE, Ala., June 1-- Macon County's white minority was dismayed today over the Democratic primary victory of a Negro candidate for sheriff.
ATLANTA, June 1 (UPI)-- Home runs by Willie Mays, Willie McCovey and Jim Davenport gave Ron Herbel of the San Francisco Giants his first victory of the year tonight, 4-3, over the Atlanta Braves.
WASHINGTON, June 1-- President Johnson expressed confidence today that representative government would be achieved in South Vietnam.

Marine Contracting, Inc., of Southport, Conn., has been awarded what is described as "the biggest commercial job ever attempted" with equipment developed by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation's under seas division.

Twenty-four striking members of the faculty of St. John's University have filed suit in State Supreme Court seeking $2.4-million in damages on grounds that the university has fraudulently listed their names in its catalogue for the 1966-67 college year.

Marion Sadler, president of American Airlines, Inc., was elected yesterday as a trustee of the Atlantic Mutual Insurance Company. He was also named a director of the Centennial Insurance Company, an Atlantic Mutual affiliate.

CAIRO, June 1--A new diplomatic tiff between the United Arab Republic and Saudi Arabia appeared to be in the making tonight following reports that six Egyptian citizens had been arrested by Saudi Arabian authorities.

WASHINGTON, June 1--One of the trials of American life is the struggle to stay abreast of the things that are ruining us. As a service to those who for one reason or another have been unable to keep in touch, the following directory has been compiled to bring all students of American ruin up to date.

ST. LOUIS, June 1 (AP)-- Willie Davis's triple in the seventh and an error by Bob Tolan produced a run that lifted Sandy Koufax and the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 1-0 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals tonight.
WASHINGTON, June 1--The Port of New York Authority is studying the possibility of building a new bridge across the Hudson River about 1975 or thereafter.
The Interstate Department Stores, Inc., which operates a chain of general merchandise department stores, announced here yesterday the election of Myron Schmittlinger as vice president and a director.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 1--South Vietnam's ruling junta, which consists of 10 generals, agreed today to add 10 civilian members, but the accord failed to stop Buddhist violence in Saigon.

TOKYO, June 1--Bookmen from 20 Asian countries, ending a week-long meeting here, have urged rapid expansion of publishing programs with aid from the World Bank to speed educational advances and end illiteracy in the developing countries.

Governor Rockefeller announced yesterday that the State Insurance Department had recovered two union welfare funds totaling $4.2-million that an employe trustee had placed in foundations he controlled in Liberia and Puerto Rico.

A syndicate headed by Smith, Barney Co., Inc., and Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., lost out in competition for $24,485,000 of New York State Dormitory Authority bonds yesterday when it submitted the wrong kind of check.

HONG KONG, June 1--Asian and Western diplomatic observers view the friendship accord between Indonesia and Malaysia as the first step toward a new era of cooperation in Southeast Asia that could strengthen much of the region's resistance to Communist penetration.

PASADENA, Calif., June 1-- The Surveyor 1 spacecraft made a triumphant soft-landing on the moon late today and was hailed as the first man-made vehicle ever to settle gently onto another celestial body.

TOKYO, Thursday, June 2-- Heavy rain last night curtailed mass protest rallies that leftwing political parties had planned for Yokosuka as the climax of their opposition to the visit there of the United States nuclear submarine Snook.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 1-- New Jersey is urgently preparing to acquire for park use a historic, million dollar, sevenacre tract atop the Palisades where construction of a motel is threatened.
WASHINGTON, June 1--Following is the White House transcript of Pres ident Johnson's news conference in the Cabinet Room at the White House today:

WASHINGTON, June 1-- The director of the Selective Service System sharply criticized today proposals advanced in recent weeks for abandoning the present draft method and substituting some other system, but conceded that changes could be made to make the draft more useful to the nation.

The two leading Democrats at City Hall declared yesterday that Mayor Lindsay, Governor Rockefeller and upstate Republican legislators must assume full blame if there was an increase in the city's transit fare.
A block-square plant in Newark, containing 125,000 square feet of floor space, has been sold by the Broadgrant Corporation to Emanuel and Stanley Yeskell and Al Miller.

The Atlantic Research Corporation said yesterday it had set May 20 as the date of record for stock to be voted at the annual meeting July 1 in Alexandria, Va. Proxy material will be mailed soon and will list five management nominees for the slate of seven directors.

LOS ANGELES, June 1-- An amalgamation of Negro organizations that included civil rights, church and Black Nationalist groups failed today to get a commitment for action from the Los Angeles Police Commission on proposals that the group said would relieve racial tension in the Negro community here.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 1-- When Cardigan Bay and Bret Hanover met for the first time recently in the Pace of the Century at Yonkers Raceway, Cardigan Bay started from the No. 3 post. Bret Hanover started from No. 5 and the result was a clear-cut, one-length victory for Cardigan Bay.
LONDON, June 1--Striking seamen today "blacked," or tied up, a tanker of the Standard Oil Company, ushering in a new phase of their strike for shorter hours and better working conditions.
Johnny Rotz was named early yesterday to ride Fast Count in the Belmont Stakes Saturday then he guided two other C. V. Whitney horses to the winner's circle at Aqueduct.

EVEN the mannequins were enthusiastic about Rudi Gernreich's fall showing yesterday--and it wasn't just over the strip tease. "Rudi's just doing the same thing he's always done, but suddenly it jells," said Judy Hinman, who modeled at the Gernreich opening and also turns up at many of the leading houses on Seventh Avenue.

Opponents of Mayor Lindsay's plan to build public housing in middle-class neighborhoods jammed a hearing of the City Planing Commission yesterday, jeering the chairman's rulings and cheering loudly for their spokesmen.
DR. WOLFGANG A. CASPER, a Staten Island dermatologist, dog fancier and amateur photographer, thinks dogs that are obediencetrained show better in the ring that those without such instruction.
The spot rate on the British pound showed little change yesterday in moderate trading on foreign-exchange markets here.
The United States Freight Company disclosed yesterday that it had purchased a 50 per cent stock interest in the Waterman Steamship Corporation.

Tyrone Cunningham, a sophomore from Samuel Gompers High in the Bronx, took the spotlight away from such better known performers as Julio Meade of Jackson and Jose L' Official of Washington yesterday as the sixty-second annual Public Schools Athletic-League track and field championships began a two-day stand at Downing Stadium.

A waste-paper company in which Michael Genovese is a principal stockholder charged yesterday that a Department of Licenses court action blocking the concern's use of trucks was for "the purpose of harassment, which is highly improper and illegal."

Today, 20 years later, Teterboro still has only 22 residents, no schools, no fire department, no libraries, no parks and its effective tax rate is about 73 cents per $100 of assessed valuation, the lowest by far in northern New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) --The White House was asked today to amplify a complaint by President Johnson that the American press has failed to provide adequate coverage of South Vietnamese political developments.

PARIS, May 1--France and Communist China today granted each other the right to fly commercially between Paris and Shanghai. Air France plans to start a once-a-week service in September, using Boeing 707's. Communist China does not have the necessary equipment.

Charles G. Moerdler, New York City Buildings Commissioner, will speak at the monthly luncheon of the Young Men's Real Estate Association of New York at noon on Tuesday, June 14, at the 60 East Club, 60 East 42d Street.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 1--Rutgers University awarded a record total of 4,300 degrees tonight to the graduates of 15 colleges and schools of the state university.

READING, Pa., June 1-- Melvin Mann Waterbor, president of M.M. Waterbor Co., an agency of the Hertz UDrive-It Corporation, died yesterday at Reading Hospital after a brief illness. He was 70 years old.
HAVANA, June 1 (Reuters) --The Government accused the United States today of having landed a heavily armed saboteur in Cuba. It was the second time in two days Cuba had made such an accusation.

When the New York Giants signed Pete Gogolak two weeks ago, they shook up people not only in the American Football League but also in their own National Football League. George Halas of the Chicago Bears confirmed this yesterday and called the signing a mistake.
MOUNT STERLING, Ohio, June 1 (AP)--Lowell Hollingshead, who played a big role in the drama of the Lost Battalion of World War I, died Monday at the age of 66.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., June 2 Threats to boycott the state's medical assistance program are being voiced among Suffolk physicians.

OSLO, Norway, June 2--Hundreds of Norwegians marched tonight through Oslo's main streets to protest against the visit of Secretary of State Dean Rusk and American policy in Vietnam. Mr. Rusk arrived here today from an official visit to Finland.

BELLAGIO, Italy, June 2 (AP) Duke Tommaso Gallarati-Scotti, an author, playwright and former Ambassador to Madrid and London, died yesterday in his villa on the shores of Lake Como. He was 88 years old.

Met with assistant secretaries of defense; met with Budget Director Shultze and deputy director Hughes to discuss the 1968 budget; saw U.N. Ambassador Goldberg; saw A.F.L.-C.I.O. president Meany; issued statement on landing of Surveyor 1 on moon; approved appointment of three officials in Bureau of Indian Affairs.

The suddenly revived move in Albany to give second legislative endorsement to the proposed constitutional amendment to permit New York City to increase its real estate tax rate, while in itself constructive, must be viewed under the circumstances with the deepest mistrust.

Mrs. Hollis Hughes has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Patricia Hughes, to Glenn S. Myers, son of Mr. and Mrs. Glen S. Myers of Everett, Wash. A July 30 wedding is planned at the Roman Catholic Church of the Guardian Angel.

President Eamon de Valera, the grand old man of Ireland, was returned to office for another sevenyear term by a surprisingly narrow margin. His re-election was clearly a personal rather than a party tribute.

ALBANY, June 2 Henry T. Heald, chairman of the commission to prepare for a State Constitutional Convention next April, has told Governor Rockefeller he is ready to resign in the face of what he charges is a lack of cooperation from the Legislature.
The Phelps Dodge Corporation, the copper producer, announced here yesterday the election as directors of William H. Chisholm, Warren E. Fenzi and George B. Munroe.

ALBANY, June 2 A bill to raise the hourly minimum wage to $1.50 quickly won final legislative approval today in the Assembly and was sent to Governor Rockefeller, who is expected to sign it within a few days.
CHICAGO, June 2 United States Attorney Edward V. Hanrahan vowed today to keep fighting the Chicago crime syndicate.

PEKING Newspaper editors and their political supervisors, continuing a campaign against "bourgeois" intellectuals, have attacked two Shanghai opera producers and the deputy director in the Propaganda Department of China's Central Committee of the Communist party.
ALBANY, June 2--The Republican-controlled Senate, seeking to kill any personal income tax for New York City, squeezed through late today a proposal to allow the city to raise its real estate tax.

CHICAGO, June 2 Another remarkable performance by Steve Hamilton the 6-foot-7inch resurrected relief pitcher, and a three-run double by his roommate, Bobby Richardson, gave the New York Yankees a 5-3 victory over the Chicago White Sox tonight.
Corporate and Government bond prices climbed yesterday, bolstered by the successful sale of the $50-million Mountain States Telephone and Telegraph Company debenture issue.
COLORADO SPRINGS, June 2 (AP) The International Typographical Union said today that members of the Progressive party of the union won all top offices in recent balloting.
The spot rate on the British pound improved slightly yesterday in moderate trading on foreign-exchange markets here.
HUE, South Vietnam, June 2 --Vietnamese tanks clattered into this, rebellious university city today, ostensibly to help rout anti-Government forces.
WESTBURY, L.I., June 2 A wholly improbable question was asked of Charlie King, Carmine Abbatiello and Bud Gilmour at Roosevelt Raceway tonight:
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) Counsel for Jack Ruby filed a request in the Supreme Court today for a stay of a sanity hearing scheduled June 13 in the Dallas criminal court.
Francis I. duPont Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, announced here yesterday the appointment of Llewellyn P. Young as a special partner, effective July 1.
BETHESDA, Md., June 2 Dr. and Mrs. Charles A. Rosenberg have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carol Anne Rosenberg, to Leonard A. Wien Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Wein of Miami Beach.
OCEANPORT, N.J., June 2 The word must be out among thoroughbred trainers that Monmouth Park, which opens its 56-day meeting tomorrow, is a land of plenty.
The nation's electric power production rose 6.9 per cent in the week ended May 28, from the level in the corresponding 1965 week, it was reported by the Edison Electric Institute yesterday.
ARMONK, N.Y., June 2 By the margin of a half-point Westchester's 10-woman team won the Golf Illustrated Trophy today over the Bel-Aire Golf and Country Club course.
The city broke a trend of four years yesterday when the water supply showed, for the 24-hour period ended at 8 A.M., an increase for the 111th consecutive day.

WASHINGTON, June 2 The Johnson Administration is moving into a climactic month of maneuvers in the Western alliance in doubt that even President de Gaulle of France knows how he will play out the crisis that he has provoked.

Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that the Albany battle over his tax program had reached "an obvious impasse" and he offered to meet with the Governor and legislative leaders "immediately, around-the-clock, it necessary, in New York, Albany anywhere."

New-car sales by the Chrysler Corporation rose in the last 10 days of May from the yearearlier level but still showed a decline for the month from the comparable 1965 figure, the company reported yesterday.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 2 Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Jesse D. Wolff of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann-Elizabeth Wolff, to Anthony Palen Nicholas of New York and Malvern, Pa., son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Snow Nicholas of Malvern.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 2 (AP) Harmon Killebrew's throw on an attempted forceout at home plate was wild and let in the tie-breaking run today as Detroit rallied for three runs in the seventh inning to beat the Minnesota Twins, 7-6.
Eagle's Top contributed the uncommon performance of staying in front all through the 2 1-16 miles of the Bushwick Hurdle Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 111.6 on Wednesday from 111.5 on Tuesday.
Olympic Airways, the Greek airline founded in 1957 by the shipowner, Aristotle S. Onassis, became the 21st air carrier to enter the trans-Atlantic service with its first flight Wednesday night.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, June 3 A 26-year-old Buddhist nun committed suicide by fire today in the sixth such protest against the Government of Premier Nguyen Cao Ky.
The Royal National Bank of New York announced yesterday the appointment of Joseph H. Kanter as a director.

The chairman of the labor committee of the panel that drew up the proposal for Mayor Lindsay's Office of Collective Bargaining charged yesterday that critics were "deathlessly afraid of collective bargaining."
THE Reisinger Knockout championship tournament ended Wednesday night in an exciting victory for Alvin Roth's New York team, which ...
MEMPHIS, June 2 (AP) Bert Yancey of Philadelphia shot a seven-under-par 63 today to take the first-round lead in the $100,000 Memphis open golf tournament.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) The authority for Government war risk insurance would be extended to 1970 for United States commercial aircraft under a bill passed today by the Senate and sent to the House.
It's been about a year since Tatham-Laird and the Kudner Agency became one, and the occasion was marked yesterday over a luncheon of pot roast and potato pancakes at Luchow's.

BOSTON, June 2 (UPI) The surging Washington Senators backed up the pitching of Phil Ortega and Ronnie Kline with a 13-hit attack today for a 12-2 victory over the Boston Red Sox. It was the Senators' 12th victory in their last 18 games.

BOSTON, June 2 Mr. and Mrs. William H. Gulliver have announced the engagement of Mr. Gulliver's daughter, Miss Ann Derby Gulliver, to David Gordon Hanes, son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Hanes of New York. A September wedding in Hyannisport is planned.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., June 2 James Tingley, Nassau, and Mrs. F.K. Thayer, Piping Rock, posted a gross score of 37, 38 75 over the par-72 North Shore Country Club course today to win the Long Island Golf Association mixed Pinehurst championship. The North Shore course measures 6,631 yards.
YEOVIL, England, June 2 (Reuters) A man waving a banner protesting the Vietnam war sat in the road halt ing Queen Elizabeth's car as she drove from a railroad station here today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 2 Leaders of the moderate faction of the Unified Buddhist Church announced today that they had decided to suspend the campaign against the ruling military junta to give it time to initiate a compromise agreement reached yesterday.
OSSINING, N.Y., June 2 Robert Fellows Gowen, a pioneer radio engineer, died here today in a nursing home. He was 82 years old and lived on Overton Road.
The television pictures of the Surveyor 1 spacecraft's soft landing on the moon represented electronics at its most sophisticated.

NEW DELHI, June 2 Leading Indian and American scholars will meet here tomorrow in a conference that may affect India's nuclear and defense policies.
The American Stock Exchange underwent its third straight loss yesterday. Volume continued to fall.
HARRISBURG, Pa., June 2 Gov. William W. Scranton, in a surprise declaration today, flatly removed himself as a candidate for any future elective office including the Presidency.

A meat broker, who went into the business on profits as a bookmaker and loan shark, went to jail yesterday for selling horsemeat for human consumption to the defunct Merkel, Inc., a Queens meat-processing plant.

Dr. Willard Lacy, head of the department of mining and geological engineering at the University of Arizona, testified in Federal Court here yesterday that preliminary drilling gave the Texas Gulf Sulphur Company "no basis on which to make an evaluation" that it had discovered a commercial ore body near Timmins, Ont.
The Board of Education and the Economic Opportunity Committee announced yesterday a drive to enroll 36,036 disadvantaged children in this year's summer preschool course.
OWNERS of pleasure cruisers are being invited to "enter" their boats in the Around Long Island Marathon.
OTTAWA, June 2--A rising tide of labor unrest across Canada has precipitated a new and possibly critical attack on the minority Liberal Government.
IN the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.
ALBANY, June 2 (UPI) The Court of Appeals today upheld the constitutionality of New York City's Health Code outlawing tattooing.

The Board of Education has directed that the city's afterschool centers for disadvantaged children "must be open to all pupils." It acted after receiving complaints that many of the Federally financed centers were admitting only parochial-school pupils.
MADRID, June 2--Generalissimo Francisco Franco is expected to call a national referendum in July to approve a constitutional charter if major political problems can be resolved in time.
Each day they descend from summer-bright Staten Island to a spooky, wet, mucky, shadowy world filled with the stench of cordite.
Research by the Highways Department has found a Manhattan Street that has not been resurfaced since 1894 when Grover Cleveland was President and the nearly-forgotten Thomas F. Gilroy was Mayor.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., June 2--Surveyor's landing on the moon went a long way toward confirming what the nation's space experts had hoped and assumed for years--that man could land safely on the lunar surface.
Bert Rose, a Long Island musician, was fined $5,000 yesterday by Federal Judge Charles H. Tenney for criminally infringing on copyrighted popular songs.

WESTERLY, R.I., June 2 Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Munro have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Bonnie Ralston Munro, to Michael G. Crissan, son of Mrs. George Crissan of Larchmont, N.Y., and the late Mr. Crissan.

ATLANTA, June 2 (UPI) Bob Bolin pitched a three-hit shutout and four runs scored on Cap Peterson's sixth-inning bases-loaded single when Felipe Alou booted the ball tonight as the San Francisco Giants scored a 5-0 victory over the Atlanta Braves.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (UPI) President Johnson praised the successful landing of Surveyor 1 on the moon and said "we can be as proud of the openness of our space program as we are of its successes."
DETROIT, June 2 (UPI) Teachers boycotted 100 schools today in four Detroit suburbs and nearby Flint, Mich., defying a state antistrike law in a militant bid for pay rises. Most of the schools closed.
Dancer-Fitzgerald-Sample, Inc., has expanded its executive team "to provide the agency's clients and prospects with an even greater depth of management."
SAN FRANCISCO, June 2 Gov. Edmund G. Brown had just crawled under the lion's head, Chinatown's version of the Indian headdress, when someone threw a lighted package of firecrackers at his feet.

THIS is a mild surprise, mildly pleasant. A two character comedy called "Undercover Man," about a fellow who won't get out of bed, produced at the beginning of the summer "silly season?" It sounds grim. But it proves to be generally painless and moderately entertaining.

The New School for Social Research announced yesterday the election of August Heckscher as chairman of its board of trustees for an indefinite term. Mr. Heckscher succeeded Jacob H. Kaplan, financier and philanthropist.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 2 Adelphi University awarded 905 degrees to graduates today at its 70th commencement exercise.

Inspectors of the Federal Food and Drug Administration raided a Japanese cult diet store on the Lower East Side late Wednesday night and seized a quantity of "misbranded" foodstuffs allegedly used in "Zen macrobiotic" diets.
The Federal Reserve pursued its tight money policy vigororously during the week ended Wednesday.
HOLLYWOOD, June 2 The Writers Guild of America voted overwhelmingly late last night to authorize a strike against television producing concerns that could disrupt the new TV season next fall.

Sylvia Plath Poems "Ariel," a volume of poetry by the late Sylvia Plath, will come from Harper Row on June 8. The author was an American who was married to the British poet, Ted Hughes. After the birth of a son in 1962, she took to rising at 4 A.M. and writing poems until her baby awoke.
PASADENA, Calif., June 2--The Surveyor 1 spacecraft, after settling gently on the moon, began a massive outpouring of photographs today.

The conquest of space, advanced most recently by the magnificent achievement of Surveyor 1, is man's greatest adventure; and the immediacy of television has given the nation as a whole and much of the world a sense of participation in every successive feat.
Surveyor l, which descended gently to the moon's surface yesterday, is larger and more complex than its Soviet counterpart, Luna 9, which landed there last Feb. 3.

The Los Angeles Dodgers come to town tonight with all those good pitchers, which is bad enough for the Mets. But, what's worse, they will find the Mets in the throes of a batting slump a slump that steepened last night when the Pittsburgh Pirates shut them out, 5-0.
CAIRO, June 2--Reports in the Egyptian press asserted today that American arms were "pouring into Saudi Arabia" and that some were being urgently sent to Yemeni royalist mercenaries.

WASHINGTON, June 2 In a rare display of bipartisan unity, the House passed a bill by a 336-to-2 vote today authorizing $700-million in Federal aid to public libraries in the next five years. The bill now goes to the Senate.
MOSCOW June 2 Soviet space scientists were highly impressed by the success of the United States in maneuvering Surveyor 1 to a soft landing on the moon, the Soviet press agency Tass reported today.

ALBANY, June 2 Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz called on the Republican-controlled State Senate today to "reconsider" its defeat yesterday of a bill to permit New York City to transfer $69-million to the Transit Authority.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange continued to decline yesterday on a combination of persistent selling and a lack of buying interest.
Gulf Western Industries, Inc., which has greatly broadened its activities through acquisitions, reached an agreement in principle yesterday to acquire the Gulf Sulphur Company of Houston.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 2 (UPI) St. John's and Lafayette breezed to first-round victories today in the National Collegiate District 2 baseball playoffs.
WASHINGTON, June 2 Three Administration witnesses generally opposed today a special study of the steel import problem as proposed by Senator Vance Hartke, Democrat of Indiana.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) Just because you've got a tax refund this year it doesn't mean you're off the hook with the United States.

LOS ANGELES, June 2 Like the child who once observed that the emperor was somewhat shy of clothing, California officials have pointed a blunt finger at what may be a pesky problem in giving the nation's cities clean air.
NEW DELHI, June 2--Prime Minister Indira Gandhi hailed today the soft landing of Surveyor 1 on the moon.
VERO BEACH, Fla., June 2 Don Herold, cartoonist and writer, died here yesterday of a heart attack at the age of 76.

ROME, June 2 Photographs of the moon's surface sent by Surveyor 1 captured front page space in almost all Italian afternoon newspapers. The American space feat was generally hailed as "another enormous step toward the conquest of the moon."
FARGO, N.D., June 2 Gov. William L. Guy of North Dakota is standing firmly behind his vetoes of two proposals of the Office of Economic Opportunity for legal aid to the poor in his state.

WASHINGTON, June 2 Intercity truck tonnage in the latest week ended May 28 was 4.0 per cent ahead of the corresponding 1965 volume. The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported that a survey of 34 metropolitan areas showed increased tonnage at 27 localities from the corresponding 1965 level.

Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands dispelled the notion at the Captain's Gala V aboard the Rotterdam Wednesday night that royalty is always formal, unapproachable or stuffy. He dealt with affluent New Yorkers who didn't seem to know whether to shake his hand or speak to him, and every now and then he gave some of them a friendly wink.

VERONA, N.J., June 2 Dr. Herman Shlionsky, a psychiatrist and first president of the New Jersey Psychoanalytic Society, died yesterday at Mountainside Hospital, Montclair. He was 62 years old and lived at 27 Wayland Drive here.

SPOKANE, Wash., June 2 (AP) A 60-year-old Oregon contractor kidnapped by three young desperadoes after their escape from a county jail yesterday was found safe and unharmed in his parked car here today.
WASHINGTON, June 2 The Ford Foundation has agreed to award $1.1-million for a five-year New York City study of police handling of confessions, alcoholics and the early release of arrested persons.

PARIS, June 2 Carrying a large straw tote bag that had a damp tennis dress in it, Julie Heldman of 88th Street and East End Avenue, Manhattan, headed back to her hotel in downtown Paris from the Roland Garros Stadium, scene of the French national tournament.

WASHINGTON, June 2 The Senate Rules Committee announced today that it would begin closed hearings on June 20 into allegations of official misconduct by Senator Thomas J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut.

LAGOS, Nigeria, June 2 The death toll in communal rioting in northern Nigeria has reached 115. The rioting broke out last weekend after the central government announced drastic administrative reforms.

PHILADELPHIA, June 2 (AP) Rich Allen smashed a 430-foot drive against the leftcenter-field wall for a two-run inside-the-park homer in the seventh inning tonight, leading the Philadelphia Phils to a 5-4 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

James Walsh, vice president and treasurer of May Department Stores, Inc., said yesterday that he expected a "long period of consideration" by the Federal Trade Commission in its investigation of the retail chain's merger with both G. Fox Co., of Hartford, and the Meier Frank Company, Inc., Portland, Ore.
DUBLIN, June 2 The reign of 83-year-old President Eamon de Valera as Ireland's greatest political force has been extended.

Jessica Tandy has agreed to star in Edward Albee's next play, "A Delicate Balance," but contracts have not been signed. The premiere has been scheduled for Sept. 22 at the Martin Beck; previews begin Sept. 12.

TOKYO, June 2 (Reuters) The Japanese Government's Foreign Investment Council has approved the establishment of a joint Japanese-American airconditioner manufacturing concern in Japan, the Nihon Dennetsu Company Ltd., said today.

Eugene Ferkauf, who has just arranged a merger between his company, E.J. Korvette, Inc., and Spartans Industries, Inc., which will be the surviving company, has an idea for a new retailing concept "that can repeat the Korvette success story over again."

WASHINGTON Americans have no experience in human engineering, whereas the Chinese concept of "revolutionary warfare," as improved by Hanoi, has shown marked success in this difficult psychological realm.

WASHINGTON, June 2 Raoul E. Desvernine, a lawyer and former industrialist who fought President Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal, died yesterday of a heart attack in his home at 3636 16th Street N.W. He was 74 years old.
The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company announced yesterday a sharp rise in sales and earnings in the second fiscal quarter and first six months ended April 30.

The engagement of Miss Claire Montgomery to James T. MacGregor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell MacGregor of Mendham, N.J., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Eglinton Montgomery of New York.

ALBANY, June 2 Governor Rockefeller is preparing a bill to create a regional mass transit agency for the New York City metropolitan area. The agency would encompass, among other operations, the Transit Authority, the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority and the Long Island Rail Road.
It was a stirring speech, the kind guaranteed to evoke soul-searching at the Saratoga Yearling Sales.
Dore Schary, the playwright and producer, announced yesterday the formation of a committee, of which he is chairman, to support City Council President Frank D. O'Connor for Governor.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) The Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee approved today a bill to allow use of nonnutritive additives in the manufacture of candy.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 2 Leonid I. Brezhnev, chief of the Soviet Communist party, delivered an unusually strong speech today that Western diplomats interpreted as an indirect warning to Rumania and Communist China against the dangers of division in the world Communist movement and demanding new unity.
An electronic type-composition system was introduced yesterday by the Radio Corporation of America.
ST. LOUIS, June 2 (AP) Don Sutton and Ron Perranoski teamed up tonight and pitched the Los Angeles Dodgers to their fourth straight victory, a 2-0 triumph over the St. Louis Cardinals.

EVANSTON, Ill., June 2 Miss Mary Christina Merrill, a reporter on The Journal News, Rockland County, N.Y., and Alan G. Bradford of New York, a security analyst for Standard Poor's Corporation, plan to marry in September.

WASHINGTON, June 2 George Meany, apparently anxious to prevent a low election turnout this fall that could hurt organized labor, has called a special meeting of labor's political arm to spur a high popular vote.

Surveyor 1 has landed in a region of the moon that appears definitely smoother than that in which Luna 9 was dropped, according to a preliminary examination of the pictures sent so far by the United States spacecraft.
In an expansion move, Air Canada has leased the entire fourth floor of the 12-story office building at 600 Madison Avenue, on the southwest corner of 58th Street, for a 10-year term.
CHICAGO, June 2 (UPI) Sixty-seven wounded Vietnam war veterans got a heroes' welcome at the Drake Hotel tonight. It came just a week after the Conrad Hilton Hotel turned them down.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 2 The Unitarian Church of Montclair has donated $1,000 to the town treasury as a protest against "the long-standing tax exemption of church property" and "in recognition of Montclair's municipal services to the church."
Stock prices closed mixed yesterday as trading continued at a languid pace.
LONDON, June 2 Storm clouds of a new economic crisis are beginning to gather over Britain.

The General Board of the National Council of Churches lined up solidly behind its Mississippi Delta Ministry yesterday on the condition that the project overhaul its financial and administrative procedures.

One hundred and fifty delegates from ballet and modern dance companies from coast to coast, met at the Warwick Hotel yesterday to try to set up a permanent service organization to meet the problems re sulting from the burgeoning interest in dance in the United States.
KEN SCOTT is gilding the lily, the rose and many unreal horticultural species in his clothes for next winter's resort season.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 2 As the second offering in its three-play summer repertory, the Tyrone Guthrie Theater is giving the first professional American production in its entirety of a towering modern drama.

LUSAKA, Zambia, June 2 Trainloads of copper from Zambia are being allowed to roll into Rhodesia on the railway that serves both countries but the Zambians now fear that the Rhodesians will confiscate the copper against cash payments for the freight.
Physicians of Columbia University described yesterday the first evidence that a virus might cause cancer of the prostate gland, a leading killer in men over 60.
Profit taking occupied grain traders' minds yesterday after two consecutive days of new lifetime highs for many soybean and wheat contracts.

Mark Ferrell of Andrew Jackson, who has been running in the shadow of Jim Jackson of Boys all year, broke out into the sunlight shining on the backstretch of Downing Stadium yesterday and won the 880-yard Public Schools Athletic League title in the meet record time of 1 minute 52 seconds.

THREE years ago Thomas Pynchon published his first novel, "V." Highly praised in many quarters and recipient of the Faulkner First Novel Award, it was a structure of such complexity that its true shape could only be seen from a distance where its emotional impact was lost.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) Two witnesses supported today a proposal that the maximum interest rate be cut on long-term bank deposits of less than a specified amount.
PASADENA, Calif., June 2 (UPI)--Unknown to most of those who worked on the project, Surveyor 1 carried an American flag to the moon.

KANSAS CITY, June 2 (AP) The Kansas City Athletics moved out of the American League cellar tonight by belting the first-place Cleveland Indians and their newly acquired relief pitcher, Dick Radatz, en route to a 11-4 victory.

WAYNESBORO, Pa., June 2 (UPI) A report by a pathologist shows that William D. Hollenbaugh kidnapper and killer, was slain by a .38 caliber pistol fired by a state policeman, Coroner Russell McLucas of Fulton County said today.
TUNIS, June 2 Tunisia is celebrating this week her first decade of independence.

JOHN-JOHN KENNEDY walked into the barber shop at the Carlyle Hotel yesterday to get a quiet haircut. He glanced at a comic book and appeared to be ready for the ordeal, but it was the wrong day. The 5-year-old son of Mrs. John F. Kennedy was hastily escorted out by a Secret Service man and his nurse when they spotted a throng of reporters and photographers.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) President Johnson announced today the retirement of Gen. John K. Waters as commander in chief, United States Army, Pacific, on Sept. 1, and the selection of Gen. Dwight E. Beach to replace him.

J. Raymond Jones, Democratic chairman in New York County, charged yesterday that Senator Robert F. Kennedy had intervened in the Surrogate race in a personal vendetta to seize control of the party organization from him.

LEOPOLDVILLE, The Congo, June 2 (AP)--Former Premier Evariste Kimba and three other former Cabinet ministers walked unfalteringly to the gallows in the main square today and were hanged on a charge that they had plotted to kill President Joseph D. Mobutu.
AREA A Outside of Barnegat Bay a few striped bass, seabass and blackfish have been taken. Bluefish, averaging 5-6 pounds, by trolling also were reported caught.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given every Friday on this page. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost of dining in any particular establishment.

WASHINGTON, June 2 The United States charge d'affaires, Robert O. Blake, made several visits to General Mobutu yesterday in an effort to persuade him that the alleged plotters should be spared "for reasons, of humanity and the international standing of the Congo," an official said today.
BUFFALO, June 2 Twentysix Negroes, many with records of juvenile delinquency and all poor credit risks, have been enlisted by the Xerox Corporation in Rochester into a job training program.
WASHINGTON, June 2 President Johnson's latest effort to open up a conversation with the Chinese leaders on disarmament and Vietnam is not likely to get anywhere, but it is significant just the same.

Stockholders of Fanny Farmer Candy Shops, Inc., at a special meeting yesterday in Rochester, approved the previously proposed acquisition of the company by W.R. Grace Co. The closing is scheduled for June 14.

The United Fruit Company said yesterday that the Federal District Court in New Orleans had extended the deadline by which the concern is supposed to file an antitrust divestiture plan from June 30 to Dec. 31.

Strong Jr. of New York, was married this afternoon to Foxhall Parker Jones, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Russell Jones of Far Hills, N.J. The Rev. Lawrence M. Stone performed the ceremony in the Salisbury Congregational Church.
The city submitted its overdue schedule of requests for Federal antipoverty funds yesterday, seeking $52,321,987--about $16-million more than Washington says New York can have.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, June 2 Joaquin Balaguer, a resilient politician who served for 26 years under the Trujillo dictatorship and then spent four years in exile in the United States, emerged as the victor tonight in the Dominican Republic's presidential election.

WASHINGTON, June 2 The Italian Government has denounced its air agreement with the United States, officials reported today.

PARIS, June 21 The Metropolitan opera is not ex actly making a success of its week in Paris. As a matter of fact, its first two performances have come close to being fiascoes and the Paris critics to a man have been expressing disappointment.

SAN JUAN, P.R., June 2 (Reuters) Pablo Casals was absent from the podium last night at the opening concert of the 10th Annual Casals Festival held at the University of Puerto Rico Theater here. Alexander Schneider conducted instead.

ANAHEIM, Calif., June 2 (AP) Boog Powell's basesloaded single was the highlight of a four-run Baltimore burst in the 10th inning that lifted the Orioles to a 9-6 victory over the California Angels today.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) The Defense Department announced today that it had placed a draft call for 32,600 men in August.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., June 2 John J. Buckley, who retired recently as cashier and assistant treasurer of The Yale Towne Manufacturing Company (now Eaton Yale Towne, Inc.), died apparently of a heart attack yesterday ...
WASHINGTON, June 2 The National Endowment for the Arts today announced grants to 16 resident repertory theaters across the country totaling $660,000.
WASHINGTON, June 2 President Johnson today sent to the Senate for ratification a declaration pledging the United States to policies to promote full and freely chosen employment.

LOS ANGELES, June 2 Stockholders of Teledyne, Inc., producer of electronics systems and components, overwhelmingly approved today the acquisition of the Vasco Metals Corporation of Latrobe, Pa., at a special meeting here.
Perry Robinson, a jazz clarinetist with a fresh and provocative approach, played last night at the Astor Place Playhouse with the Uni Trio.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) Imports from Iron Curtain countries reached a record $137.5-million last year while United States exports to the same area dropped almost twothirds below 1964 figures to their lowest level in three years, the Commerce Department reported today.
The First National City Bank thinks Congress should not impose restrictions on the ability of commercial banks to compete for small-denomination savings certificates.
PARIS, June 2 A dissent from President de Gaulle's hard line on gold and international monetary reform has been ratified by an advisory group to the French Government, it was reported today.
DEVON, Pa., June 2 Just three years ago Rod Jenkins, a 20-year-old redhead from Orange, Va., would not have dared dream he would be the busiest professional in the East some day.
Sherman Hazeltine, chairman of the First National Bank of Arizona, was elected yesterday as a director of the Sperry Rand Corporation.

David L. Cole, chief mediator in the newspaper strike, said last night that the dispute between the pressmen's union and The World Journal Tribune, Inc., was now a major obstacle blocking an over-all settlement.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) The Senate Labor Committee approved today a bill to provide $1,600 toward purchase of a car for veterans disabled as a result of armed conflict or extra-hazardous duty since the Korean War.

A conference sponsored by the Committee for the Beautification of the City of New York recommended yesterday that the city grant some form of tax "forgiveness" to owners who embellish their buildings with art works.

To Dr. Lawrence L. Jarvie, president of the Fashion Institute of Technology, education for retailing requires a special orientation on the part of the institution, the faculty and the students.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 2--South Vietnam asked the United Nations today to provide observers at the September elections for a constituent assembly.
WASHINGTON, June 2 Eight states are going to forfeit millions of dollars in antipoverty funds unless they submit acceptable community action projects quickly.
WASHINGTON June 2 (UPI) The Navy is installing floodlights on all of its aircraft carriers, it was learned today.

Silver and vermeil tableware by Puiforcat, French silversmiths, have just been introduced at Cartier. This is the first time wares of the 145-year-old silver company have been carried in this country, according to a spokesman for the store.

Dr. William Howard Steiner, professor emeritus and retired chairman of the department of economics at Brooklyn College, died of a heart attack yesterday. He was 71 years old and lived at 2 Tudor City Place.

The A.C. Nielson Company yesterday added the names of two more defendants in the $1.5-million suit filed in March against Rex Sparger. The suit charged Mr. Sparger, a former Congressional investigator, with attempts to rig Nielson television ratings.
The port's traditional harbor welcome was extended yesterday to the new freighter Oriental Queen, the latest addition to the Orient Overseas Line's fleet.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 2 Mrs. Thomas J. Hory of the home club won the Women's Westchester-and-Fairfield Golf Association one-day tournament by five strokes at Winged Foot Golf Club today.

The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association announced last night the start of an "all-out campaign" to get New York voters to strike down Mayor Lindsay's plan for civilians to review complaints of police misbehavior.
Donald R. Gant a partner in the New York investment banking firm of Goldman, Sachs Co., was elected yesterday to the board of the Sperry Hutchinson Company, a trading stamp plan concern.

WASHINGTON, June 2 The head of the Justice Department's Antitrust Division proposed today that the Government subsidize research on the effectiveness and safety of consumer products and publicize the results.

PARIS, June 2 (AP) Istvan Gulyas, a 34-year-old Hungarian, and Tony Roche, a 21-yearold Australian, advanced to the singles final today in the French tennis tournament.

Brooklyn celebrated the 100th anniversary of Prospect Park yesterday with a procession, speeches and cake. The procession consisted of equestrians, high-wheeled bicycles, antique cars, bagpipers, Boy Scouts, Girl Scouts, an Indian troupe and bands at Grand Army Plaza.

LONDON, June, 2 Peter George, who wrote the novel that was the basis for the film "Dr. Strangelove," was found dead of shotgun wounds, apparently self-inflicted, at his Sussex home last night. He was 41 years old.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 2 (AP) The Maryland Court of Appeals ruled today in a landmark case that three state grants to church-affiliated colleges were invalid.

Sales in New York City department stores during May had an average gain of 2 per cent above May, 1965. Merchants said the gain would have been greater except for the adverse effect of cool, unseasonal weather on sales in most fashion apparel categories.

The Fifth Avenue steps of St. Patrick's Cathedral again will sprout flowers that will be sold Tuesday and Wednesday for the benefit of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association.

YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N.Y., June 3--Deep in the woodlands of northern Westchester County, a $4.2-million training school is being developed for the conversion of bad boys from New York slums into responsible gentlemen.

Oscar Mayer Co. reported yesterday a 21 per cent increase in earnings and 15 per cent in sales for the six months ended April 30. The company specializes in sausage and smoked meats, and has plants in Madison, Wis.; Chicago; Los Angeles; Philadelphia, and Perry and Davenport, Iowa.

Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union retained his world chess championship last night by defeating Boris Spassky, also of the Soviet Union, in the crucial 22d game of their 24-game match at Moscow's Variety Theater.

Gemini 9's 11-foot-long docking target, known unofficially as "the Glob," "the Blob," and "the Fireplug," had been waiting since Wednesday in an orbit about 185 miles high for rendezvous with the Gemini 9 manned spacecraft.

CHICAGO, June 3 (UPI)-- The American Medical Association said today it would handle Project Vietnam, the State Department's program for sending volunteer doctors to South Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) --President Johnson reiterated to a group of elderly persons today his intention to seek a broad increase in Social Security benefits during the next Congress.

The London stock market continued yesterday along the downward trend begun earlier in the week, with prices again generally dropping in sluggish trading.

The Continental Can Company is expanding its table glassware line through the purchase of the Tiffin Art Glass Corporation of Tiffin, Ohio. The transaction, reported yesterday, involves $4,135,680.

The American Stock Exchange managed to end in the plus column yesterday for the first time this week as trading continued at a very slow pace. Advances barely outnumbered declines--288 to 264. The market opened slightly stronger and crept ahead slowly during the session.

A 46-year-old woman whose forebears held the settlements of Virginia's Blue Ridge Mountains against the Indians, the British and the Yankees yesterday routed a cable crew in a battle with the New York Telephone Company upstate.

CHICAGO, June 4--Mr. and Mrs. Elmer Ashton Stewart have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Ann Stewart of New York, to Stanford Augustus Roman Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Roman of New York and Kingston, Jamaica.
Mr. and Mrs. Irving H. Schnapp have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jacqueline Louise Schnapp, to Scott Andrew Neumann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mannis Neumann.

WESTON, Conn., June 4-- Miss Sandra Lade, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Lade, was married here today to Dr. Maynard Boynton Wheeler in the Norfield Congregational Church. The Rev. Robert B. Reeves performed the ceremony.

A number of man's deadliest enemies--viruses, bacteria and parasites--live a sufficiently precarious life so that it should be possable to drive them into extinction. The World Health Organization (W.H.O.) has undertaken global campaigns to eradicate three such diseases: smallpox, malaria and cholera. If successful, they would be relegated to medical history books and the costly wars against them, by vaccination and other means, could be suspended.

WASHINGTON, June 4--Miss Donna Erickson, who will be married to Robert Humphrey, son of Vice President and Mrs. Hubert Humphrey, in St. Olaf's Roman Catholic Church in Minneapolis on July 9, has selected her bridal attendants.
GREENWICH, Conn., June 4 --The annual long distance sail of the Luders-16 Class became a match race today when only two boats entered the race for the Grundoon Trophy at Indian Harbor Yacht Club.

FARIBAULT, Minn., June 4 (AP)--People throughout the world want a decent standard of living and human dignity and also want their children to grow up strong, healthy and free, Vice President Humphrey today told a graduating class that included his youngest son.
QUEBEC, June 4--Voters Quebec refer to tomorrow as Premier Jean Lesage's day of reckoning.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., June 4-- Boat owners have been advised that, with an extra store of food and canvas, a pleasure craft could serve as an efficient nuclear fallout shelter.
SCRANTON, Pa., June 4-- Miss Patricia Grace Brady and Ens. George Vincent Lynett, U.S.N.R., co-publisher of The Scranton Times, were married here today in St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) --The greatest flood of college graduates in the nation's history will pour from classrooms this month, and the Labor Department says their prospects for jobs at high pay have never been brighter.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) --Despite criticism from some sources, the antipoverty agency insists that its program to train school dropouts in residential centers is receiving strong support from businessmen, civic leaders and educators.

MOSCOW, June 4--The Soviet Union named a delegation of six writers today to defend the sinyavsky-Daniel trial at a congress of the International Society of Poets, Essayists and Novelists opening next Saturday in New York.
Don Schollander, the winner of four gold medals in the 1964 Olympics, was named yesterday to the United States swimming team that will compete in a 10-nation meet in Moscow, July 16 and 17.

The Eastern clay tournament circuit is picking up steam, but two standout players are missing. Herb Fitz Gibbon of Garden City, L.I., ranked No. 3, and Bailey Brown of Bronxville, No. 4, are on military duty. Fitz Gibbon, formerly of Princeton, had a grand overseas tennis tour before going into service.
The over-the-counter market made a small advance last week in desultory trading.

LAS PALMAS, Gran Canary, Canary Islands --Americans visiting these Spanish islands in the Atlantic Ocean are invariably surprised to discover a tourist boom with which their fellow countrymen have had very little to do.

PHILADELPHIA, June 4 (UPI)--Jim Tuppeny, assistant to the Villanova coach, Jim Elliott, for the last 12 years, has been named track and cross-country coach at the University of Pennsylvania, it was announced today by the Penn director of athletics, Jerry Ford.

MIAMI, June 4--The Cuban Government began today what it called "the year of combative preventiveness," an intensive nationwide program of military training for reservists and membera of parliamentary organizations.

At about 3 P.M. on June 13, public-school principals throughout the city will close shop, pick up racquets and sneakers and hustle out to the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens, where, presto! they'll turn into eager, querying pupils.

OCEANPORT, N.J., June 4 --On an afternoon in which the day's leading race, the Belmont was being held across the bay at Aqueduct, Chuck Baltazar, America's leading rider, was doing business as usual at Monmouth Park.
WASHINGTON, June 4-- New York City will not need a major new source of water for 10 to 20 years if the drought ends this year, a special committee told President Johnson today.

ST. LOUIS--The Missouri Botanical Garden here is a 70-acre blend of glorious color and sooth ing shade, an ideal stopping point for cross-country motorists who may have had Httle of either on the superhighway grind.
A two-story house of Colonial design, priced at $49,000, has been added to the selection of models at the Woodland Manor development at River Vale, N.J.

HANOVER, N.H., June 4-- Miss Mary Catherine Wheelock, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. FredBrick Albert Wheelock of Urford, was married today to Edward Joseph McCormick of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Charles McCormick of Montclair, N.J. The Rev. Arnold De Rosa performed the ceremony at St. Denis Roman Catholic Church.

CHICAGO, June 4--The Building Officials Conference of America, Inc., has announced that it has conferred its top award on Arthur J. Benline, New York Commissioner of Air Pollution Control. Mr. Benline will yield his post to Austin N. Heller on July 1.

LIBBY, Mont.--Damming up the Kootenai River in the Great Northwest called not only for an Act of Congress but also for one by the Canadian Parliament. And, although the two Governments were able to coordinate a vast dam project, they never got together on how to spell Kootenai. So it is still the Kootenay in Canada, the Kootenai when tains from Alaska to Mexico and is sometimes known as the "Park Highway."
NEW YORK society presents a lighthearted facade, but behind that fa cade is a philanthropic attitude whose roots go back to the 19th century and to men like Peter Cooper.

WELLESLEY, Mass., June 4 --Eugene R. Black, a special Presidential adviser on financial matters, proposed today the establishment of an American council for education and industrial arts to manage some of the nation's overseas programs.
Ten-year-old Henry says he "hates it" at school, but even on those days when he plays hookey he shows up for afterschool tutoring sessions with his teacher.

RALEIGH, N.C., June 4--A drive by East Carolina College to achieve independent university status threatens to undermine North Carolina's concept of a consolidated university system. It also appears to be setting the stage for a major legislative battle in next year's session of the General Assembly.

MANCHESTER, England, June 4--Mrs. Billie Jean Moffitt King of Long Beach, Calif., won the women's singles title in the North of England tennis championships today with a crushing 6-2, 6-1 triumph over Winnie Shaw, Britain's 19-year-old sensation.

MILWAUKEE, June 4--Representative Henry S. Reuss, a Milwaukee Democrat, has attacked a $25,000 Federal education grant to a wealthy Milwaukee suburb and has threatened a Congressional investigation to have it canceled.
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 4-- Former President Juscelino Kubitschek, who has been under investigation by hard-line military officers, returned to Brazil today for his sister's funeral.

ISLIP, L.I., June 4-- St. Mark's Episcopal Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Suzanne Spear, daughter of Mrs. Robert E. Thornhill of New York and Islip and John Spear of East Hampton, to George H. C. Lawrence. He is the son of Mrs. John G. Jackson Jr. of Locust Valley and the late Christopher Lawrence of Bronxville, N.Y.
ABILENE, Kan., June 4 (UPI)--Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower returned to his boyhood home town yesterday to rebury the body of his first-born son, Doud, who died at the age of 3 in 1921.

LONDON, June 4--Quietly, almost imperceptibly, the struggle over Rhodesia has slipped into a new phase--an earnest attempt by Britain and the rebel Rhodesians to see whether they can settle their differences peacefully.

DJANET, Algeria--In the Tassili N'Ajjer Mountains, which tower above this ancient caravan oasis 50 miles west of the Libyan border, evidences of a Stone Age civilization are so abundant that a tourist can find them almost as tasily as an archeologist.

MARIO ANDRETTI of Nazareth Pa., who was he fastest qualifier but only a 15th-place finisher in the 500-mile race at Indianapolis, heads the field of drivers for the 100-mile national championship race at Langhorne, Pa., next Sunday afternoon.

He is a son of Mrs. Richard Roelofs Jr. of 115 East 67 Street and Greenwich, Conn, and the late Ernest O'Malley of Dublin, author and onetime Irish Republican Army general.

In All Souls Unitarian Church here yesterday afternoon, Miss Judith Jeanne Rich, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul J. Rich Jr. of Buffalo, was married to Winston Lauder of New York. He is the son of Mrs. S. Worrall Hyde of Greenwich, Conn., and Edwin S. Dewing of Hartford, Conn.

The 11th National Plastics Exposition, a kind of giant supermarket for professionals, will open its gates at the New York Coliseum tomorrow to demonstrate its belief that the dynamic growth rate of the plastic industry is far from over.

A DOUBLE-DECKER hotel on wheels, the Rotel --it looks like a bus, but is equipped with 24 sleeping couchettes, a lounge, bar, kitchen, rest rooms and showers--left New York last month on its maiden trip across the United States and into Canada and Mexico. The Rotel is carrying 20 passengers from Europe on a twomonth, $725 tour; the price includes round-trip air transportation from Luxembourg.

HUNTINGDON VALLEY, Pa., June 4--Ch. Makhayl of Tam-Boer, a 3-year-old borzoi owned and bred by Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Tamboer of Mahwah, N.J., took best-in-show honors in a field of 822 at the 40th annual Huntingdon Valley Kennel Club event.

AMSTERDAM, N. Y., June 4--Mayor Marcus I. Breier and Mrs. Breier have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joan Beth Breier, to William Jay Brodsky. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Irwin A. Brodsky of West Hempstead, L. I.

OJAI, Calif. NEXT to the big guns of, say, the Berkshire Festival at Tanglewood, the Ojai (OH-hi) Music Festival does not make much of a bang. It runs for only one long weekend in May. It is performed by fine but not always famous musicians. It is managed by upper-class amateurs who, in a larger town, would probably be running the Junior League Worn-a-Bit Shop.

WASHINGTON, June 4--This year's graduates from the colleges and universities of the United States are particularly interesting. They were born of parents greatly influenced by the economic depression and the Second World War.

WASHINGTON, June 4-- Secretary of Defense and Mrs. Robert S. McNamara have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Elizabeth McNamara, to Barry Edward Carter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Byron B. Carter of Los Angeles.

CHICAGO, June 4--Sam Giancana was reported to have played golf this week while the Justice Department and the United States Attorney here disagreed publicly about his future, the department's wisdom and the attorney's skill.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 4 --Mr. and Mrs. Bernhard M. Auer have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan M. Auer, to Stephen M. Parks. He is the son of the Rev. and Mrs. Ralph Waldo Parks Jr. of Detroit.

WHAT can this summer's overseas traveler do for guidebooks? The best bet continues to be the Michelin Guides. They have long been published in the friendly, familiar and comforting red books in French, German, Italian and English. Now there is also a GREEN ENGLISH MICHELIN GUIDE (Michelin Tire Corp., Box 217, Woodside, N.Y.) at $3.50 per book.

TACOMA, Wash--Timberland holdings of the Weyerhaeuser Company average one acre for every square mile of the United States. The 3.6-million-acre total is 1/640th of the country's area. It is larger than Connecticut and nearly five times the size of Rhode Island.

Cuban veterans of the unsuccessful operation against the regime of Premier Fidel Castro in April, 1961, issued a call to exile organizations yesterday to join in a new armed effort to invade Cuba.
ROME, June 5 Pope Paul VI praised today the space feat of the American astronauts Lieut. Comdr. Eugene A. Cernan and Lieut. Col. Thomas P. Stafford and offered a prayer for them.

CANTHO, South Vietnam, June 5 In a civilian hospital in this country are to be found the unreported casualties of this war the Vietnamese men, women and children who get in the way of bombs, mines and bullets unleashed by both sides.
PURCHASE, N.Y., June 5 Greenwich and New Haven played to a 6-6 tie today in the first match of the season at the Blind Brook Polo Club.
MEXICO CITY, June 4 The biggest private-enterprise group in the Western Hemisphere is now under commitment to accelerate lagging efforts to integrate Latin America's economy.

TOKYO, June 5 (UPI) Communist China accused the United States today of a "new conspiracy," trying to get United Nations intervention in the Vietnamese question because of "extraordinary difficulties" in South Vietnam.

ONE of those rare television occurrences a full length original play marked the closing last night of the first season of "Sunday Showcase" on Channel 13. The work, entitled "The Good Lieutenant," was written by Robert Murray of the Yale School of Drama. His bitter commentary on misplaced idealism and compassion often had an engrossing and controversial power.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 5 The civilians drawing up a South Vietnamese election law have recommended that a constitution-drafting assembly to be elected in September be given legislative functions and be allowed to transform itself into a national assembly.
LONDON, June 5 (AP) The Rev. Billy Graham was challenged by an atheist on a British television program tonight about the existence of God.

The Federal Maritime Commission has appealed to 1,600 shipping operators, freight forwarders, port authorities and terminal operators to support President Johnson's 1966 Youth Opportunity Campaign by providing summer jobs for young Americans.

WASHINGTON, June 5 The New York State Education Department and three colleges in the state have been awarded grants totaling $426,000 to train education researchers, the United States Office of Education announced today.

AUSTIN, Tex., June 5 Gov. John B. Connally Jr. put his brand on another major agency of state government early today when State Senator Franklin Spears conceded defeat in the Democratic run-off primary for Attorney General to Crawford Martin, the Governor's choice for the post.
The New York Newspaper Guild submitted to the World Journal Tribune, Inc., yesterday the names of 325 employes who wish to end their jobs with the publishers.

BALTIMORE, June 5 (AP) The Baltimore Orioles won a suspended game, 6-5, today on Russ Snyder's 12th-inning single and then lost their regularly scheduled contest to the Kansas City Athletics, 9-4, after taking a three-run lead.
The New York Mets and Los Angeles Dodgers fought each other for 18 innings to a draw yesterday before 56,382 persons in Shea Stadium.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 5 Adhemar de Barros, Governor of Sao Paulo state, was removed from office today by the Federal Government. The state is Brazil's most populous and richest.

BOSTON, June 5 Jim Bouton, the Yankees' right-hander whose hat often flies off as he pitches, had reason to toss his hat with joy today as New York beat the Red Sox, 5-3. The victory was his first since June 30.
PITTSBURGH, June 5 Reports from steel mills last week indicated continuing general strength in demand and a further weakening of the automotive sector.

Plans to bring to the floor of the State Legislature today a measure granting specific exemption from the provisions of the Condon-Wadlin Law to 17 unemployed licensed ferryboat officers were revealed over the weekend by State Senator Thomas J. Mackell and Assemblyman Leonard P. Stavisky.

CHESS by mail, also known as correspondence chess and postal chess, is a boon to all chess buffs who live in spots far removed from active centers. With a usual time limit of 72 hours a move, games may last from a week to a number of years. Chessby-mail players are generally a fanatical lot, and often play many games simultaneously with opponents all over the globe.
HONG KONG, June 5 Victims of Communist China's current purge were accused today of having used Peking University as a base for attempting to win over the younger generation.
