More than 500 flags were flown at half-staff from windows, doorways and porches in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn yesterday in tribute to a 20-year-old Marine from the area who was killed in South Vietnam.
ST. LOUIS, June 5 (UPI) Kathy Whitworth shot a one-under par 68 today to win the $12,500 Clayton Federal women's open golf tournament by four strokes with a 54-hole total of 208.
JOHNSON CITY, Tex., June 5 President Johnson received today a report that the Administration hopes will avert a major airlines strike.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., June 5 Jakob Isbrandtsen's revitalized 64-foot-yawl Good News looked more than ever a yacht to watch in ocean racing after today's final regatta of the New York Yacht Club's two-day event.

PHOENIX, Ariz. They say it will be the most beautiful shopping center in the Southwest if it is ever finished. And indeed, the most striking features of the Biltmore Fashion Park are its physical properties and the remarkably relaxed pace at which it is being built.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 5 (AP) Harmon Killebrew's fifth home run in six games broke a 4-4 tie in the sixth inning and Minnesota went on today to score a 9-4 victory over Cleveland that snapped the Twins' five-game losing streak.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) The president of the Commercial Telegraphers Union said today "very little progress" had been made in negotiations with Western Union.

PARIS, June 5 It was like hitting a ball against the wall. It almost always came back. For Nancy Richey, the 23-year old imp from Dallas, the "wall" was Mrs. Ann Haydon Jones of Britain, who defeated the Amer ican girl, 6-3, 6-1, here today and thereby won the French women's singles championship.
Two office buildings in the Times Square area, have been, purchased and extensive renovation projects are planned by each of the new owners.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) Sargent Shriven, the director of the Federal anti poverty drive, defended the program against Republican critics today by citing figures from the home states of the two top Republican Congressional leaders.

An auto crash on the Governor Dewey Thruway, which took the lives of a man and his mother-in-law early Saturday claimed a third victim yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 5 Two Government lawyers proposed today that management fees charged by mutual funds be limited by law to a level that is "fair and reasonable." At present, such fees are "inflexibly high," they said.

MANHATTAN, Kan., June 5 (AP) Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower told graduates at Kansas State University today, "This is the finest generation this country has produced. In spite of all the kooks and beatniks that receive a lot of space, I believe my statement is correct."

It will be cooler in northern New England, the upper Mississippi Valley and the Central and Southern Plains States.

Unencumbered by horses that only get in the way, Cardigan Bay and Bret Hanover will meet in a $35,000 match race next Saturday night in what should be the first true test between the country's best pacers.

VINELAND, N.J., June 5 Bob Bucher of Binghamton, N.Y., and Ed Hugus of Pittsburgh finished one, two today in the Inver House Cup race on Vineland's 1.3-mile road course. Bucher drove a new all-white Class C Lola-Ford and finished 4 seconds in front of Hugus's Class E strawberry pink Porsche Carrera 6.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., June 5 Miss Christine Annette Caruso, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Caruso, was married today to Aldwin H. Zim, son of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert S. Zim of Tavernier, Fla.
TORONTO, June 5 (UPI) Mounted policemen drove back Canadians who tried to attack John William Beattie, selfstyled Nazi leader, as he spoke in a park today.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 5 (AP) The Right Rev. James A. Pike, Episcopal Bishop of California, broke tradition today to install two laymen without theological training as canons of San Francisco's Grace Cathedral. Heretofore, the honor has been limited to the clergy.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 5 (AP) Dr. Arthur Clay Cope, Camille Dreyfus Professor of Chemistry at Massachusetts Institute of Technology and chairman of the board of the American Chemical Society, died last night, apparently of a heart attack, while dining with friends in a restaurant in Washington. He was 56 years old.

Television station WPIX, which barred a taped discussion about Communist China after it was initially scheduled on "Open End" last March, will permit the program to go on unchanged next Sunday. But the station, still concerned that the program lacked balance in points of view, will present other panelists on the following Sunday, June 19, with opinions in opposition to those expressed on the first program.
WASHINGTON, June 5 Some Army scientists are anxious to dispatch battalions of bedbugs to Vietnam to help in the fight against the elusive Vietcong.
The election of Felix A. Kalinski as vice president for planning was announced over the weekend by the Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc.

WHITE PLAINS, June 5 The marriage of Miss Linda Rose Goldstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold M. Goldstein of Scarsdale, to Melvin Loins Heineman, took place here today. The bridegroom is the son of Mrs. Myron Heineman of New York and the late Mr. Heineman. Rabbi Richard Sternberger performed the ceremony at the Jewish Community Center of White Plains.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) Strikes were averted by only hours tonight at two Bell Aircraft Company plants where helicopters are manufactured for the Vietnam war, the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service said.
WASHINGTON, June 5 The only major new education program proposed this year by President Johnson is expected to win speedy House approval tomorrow.

Miss Linda Maria Halperin, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Barnet Halperin of Forest Hilis, Queens, was married yesterday to James W. Matthews of Brooklyn He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. R. Willard Mattews of Clarks Green, Pa.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, June 5 Premier Suleyman Demirel's conservative Justice party appears to have won a significant victory in today's sensational elections.

LUBLIN, Poland, June 5 (Reuters) Two huge crowds gathered in this southeastern Polish city today, one to listen to an open-air sermon by Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski and the other to attend public entertainment arranged by the city government.

BRUSSELS, June 5 The foreign ministers of 14 of the 15 members of the North Atlantic alliance have arrived here to discuss the consequences of President de Gaulle's decision to withdraw France from the integrated defense system of the alliance.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., June 5 Richard Eberhart, the Pulitzer Prize-winning poet, and Ada Louise Huxtable, architecture critic of The New York Times, were awarded honorary doctorates at the graduation exercises of Skidmore College today.

Glen Ray Bedenkapp, Republican state chairman in the late nineteen-forties, and a retired member of the Public Service Commission, died Saturday in Houston, where he had lived for several years. He was 76 years old.

PHILADELPHIA, June 5 (AP) Hal Lanier's two-out home run off Bo Belinsky in the 10th inning gave the San Francisco Giants a 7-6 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies today, ending a six-game Phillie winning streak.
Mayor Lindsay pedaled a bicycle into Central Park yesterday and said he would try to close the park to vehicular traffic every Sunday "from early in the morning till 3 P.M."
Mayor Lindsay asserted yesterday that a tax compromise under which city residents would pay an income tax but commuters only a payroll tax would be a "sellout of the city's future."
NORTON, Mass., June 5 (AP) Prof. Walter Cleveland Shipley, who retired last week from the Wheaton College psychology department, died today at his home. He was 62 years old.

The American West African Freight Conference headquarters in New York has warned its shipline members that cargoes shipped to the port of Lobito, Angola, bound for the Republic of the Congo, might have to be turned back because of difficulty at the Congo-Angola border.
WASHINGTON, June 5 The following is a list of loans and other aid extended last week by United States and other international lending agencies here:
WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) A Navy Hercules plane left Christchurch, New Zealand, tonight on an eight-hour flight to Antactica to pick up a seriously ill United States serviceman, the Navy reported.
SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., June 5 (AP) Dr. Ann Haden Morgan, a retired professor of zoology at Mount Holyoke College, died today in her home at the age of 84.

Four maritime unions said yesterday they would take "all legal means" to halt chartering of foreign-flag ships by American operators whose own cargo vessels are busy on military service to South Vietnam.

Morris W. Berns, an exporter of electronic equipment, who was active in Republican affairs in New York, died of a heart attack at St. Luke's Hospital in San Francisco on Saturday. Mr. Berns was attending a convention. He was 57 years old and lived at 885 Park Avenue.

Joseph Bartha, the old man of the woodland hiking trails, stood in the wind yesterday at the top of Bear Mountain high above the Hudson River. On a rock near him were his children, his grandchildren, his great-grandchildren, his greatgreat-grandchildren and his inlaws 12 in all. They were there to celebrate Mr. Bartha's 95th birthday.

WEST NEWTON, Mass., June 5 Mr. and Mrs. Elbert Payson Little of West Newton and Woods Hole have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Thomson Little, to David Haslam Walsh. He is the son of Richard J. Walsh Jr. of New York and Mrs. Margaret Whedon Walsh of Scarsdale, N.Y.
Fairleigh Dickinson University placed three cyclists among the top 10 finishers and cap tured the Intercollegiate Bicycle Road Racing Championship yesterday at Central Park.

The fate of Grand Canyon is at stake in the complex and little-noticed Colorado River Bill now under consideration in the House Interior Committee. As the bill stands, it would authorize dams at Marble Gorge, north of Grand Canyon National Park, and at Bridge Canyon, to the south of it, that would substantially alter, the ecology of one of the world's great geologic and scenic wonders.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., June 5 A cool-nerved 32-yearold astronaut soared around the world today on a recordsetting jaunt as a human satellite, working, floating and doing handstands outside the orbiting Gemini 9.
The State Investigation Commission has recommended that laws be enacted to broaden the right of the police to fingerprint arrested persons and to provide better control over firearms.
ROME, June 5 (Reuters) Hundreds of prisoners were released from Italian jails today under an amnesty law that came into force yesterday.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., June 5 Miss Evelyn Thacher Bossange, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edouard R. Bossange of Dallas, was married this afternoon to Mohamed Saleh Younes of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Saleh Younes of Cairo.
QUEBEC, June 5 Quebec voters delivered a severe setback today to the Liberal Government responsible for reforms that are often referred to as the quiet revolution.

BONN, June 5 The Deutsche Bank announced yesterday that Texaco had acquired a controlling interest in Deutsche Erdol, A.G., which has 5,000 service stations and 6 per cent of West Germany's oilrefinery capacity.

NEWTOWN SQUARE, Pa., June 5 Five-year-old ChKham of Norbulingka, a lioncolored Lhasa Apso owned by Mrs. Michael Pym of Oakton, Va., won her third best-in-show title in three weeks today at the 858-entry Delaware County Kennel Club fixture.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., June 5 Howard Crusey, sailing Dodger III, was declared the winner in the 17-boat Ensign Class race today after Howard Hansen's Windigo, leading the fleet, hit the finish marker of the ninemile course set up for the Tri Club's opening of its championship series competition.

LOS ANGELES, June 5 Jim Ryun, the Kansas superfrosh, ran the second fastest mile on record 3 minutes 53.7 seconds in another amazing effort last night at the Los Angeles Coliseum. Minutes later the gangling, 19-year-old Wichita boy said, "I could have run faster, but I'm not too disappointed."

A fountain in memory of Oscar Hammerstein 2d, librettist and lyricist, is to be erected next spring at the southern end of Central Park's Mall between the statues of Columbus and Shakespeare. Mrs. Hammerstein is contributing the cost, estimated at $75,000.
LAGOS, Nigeria, June 5 Fresh rioting and killing have broken out for the second consecutive weekend in northern Nigeria.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 5 Charles J. Maguire, a producer of television commercials and former advertising executive, died yesterday of a cerebral hemorrhage in Greenwich Hospital. He was 44 years old and lived at 7 Greenwich Cove Drive, Old Greenwich.

ROCHESTER, Minn., June 5 (AP) Wellington D. Rankin, a Montana lawyer and political leader and one of the largest landholders in the nation, died yesterday at Methodist Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived in Helena.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., June 5 This rural village, tucked into a wooden hill in the center of northern Westchester County, is preparing for a future that some of its 6,941 residents welcome and others regard with alarm.
PASADENA, Calif., June 5 Surveyor 1 added pictures of the brightest star in the sky and an errie view of a mountain range to its lunar snapshot album today.
The regulation of paid lobbyists who seek to influence the course of city legislation was proposed yesterday by Councilman Robert A. Low, Democrat of Manhattan.
Doris Pines, a pianist who gave her first New York recital in 1950 and waited 15 years before playing her second last year, came to Town Hall on Saturday night for her third.
The State University of New York is drafting plans that will pledge some form of higher education to every high school graduate in the state by 1974.
NORTH HAVEN, Conn., June 5 (UPI) Pratt Whitney Aircraft workers voted today to accept a new contract offer, ending a three-week-old strike threat.

ALMOST all rules have to be broken eventually, and this applies to bridge columnists as well as players. This column does not normally quote verbatim from material submitted by readers; nor publish freak deals; nor pay any attention to correspondents using fictitious names and addresses. The following, however, represents an exception to all three rules. It is a letter headed 666 East 66th Street, New York, 66, and it is signed 'Looey the Rat.'

Alex Rose said yesterday that the Liberal party shied away from nominating Supreme Court Justice Arthur G. Klein for Surrogate because the Republicans had given one man the power to choose their party's candidate.

Now that the Dominican elections are over and President Balaguer is to take office July 1, the InterAmerican Peace Force can be expected to melt away as soon as he decides he can maintain internal peace without foreign help.
NUERBURGRING, West Germany, June 5 (Reuters) An automatic transmission Chaparral outlasted the Italian Ferraris today and won the Nuerburgring 1,000-kilometer (621 miles) sports car race.
MADRID The Spanish economy is still flying high but has been hitting some uncomfortable areas of turbulence.
Jose Feliciano's musical talents are varied, to say the least, and he displayed several of them generously at Town Hall last night in his first New York concert appearance.
LONDON, June 5 London taxi drivers are planning a "coordinated day of rest" on June 14 to protest what they call the minicab menace, Londoners have never before faced a cabbie walkout.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 5 Two hundred fifty-six American planes have been lost over North Vietnam since regular bombing began there Feb. 7, 1965, a United States military, spokesman said tonight.
About 50 prints by contemporary American artists will be exhibited by the Awixa Pond Center in Bay Shore, L.I., from next Sunday to July 17.
MEMPHIS, June 5 James H. Meredith, pith-helmeted and a little apprehensive, stepped off today on the beginning of a 220-mile march to the heart of his native Mississippi.
ALTHOUGH Hans Gal's readable collection covers some 380 years in time and 50 composers, the pattern is established almost at the very beginning with Claudio Monteverdi (1567-1643).
The key ingredient in one of the most famous advertising battle cries of World War II is being rehabilitated.
PARIS, June 5 Prince Rainier III moved today to break his deadlock with Aristotle Onassis over control of the Monte Carlo casino.
RYE, N.Y., June 5 Herman F. Whiton sailed Small Hotel to an International Class victory today for the third time in six Yacht Racing Association championship races since the new season began.

BADEN-BADEN, West Germany, June 3 Last spring, when Gen. Jacques Massu took over command of the French forces in West Germany, one of his first actions was to order all his staff officers to take two German lessons a week.

DETROIT, June 5 (UPI) Striking teachers in three Michigan school districts tentatively agreed on new contracts today to end two-day walkouts. But three other districts were still on strike and another was threatened with a walkout.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 5 Miss Trudy L. York, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward York, was married here today to Iraj Afnan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ruhi Afnan, of Beirut, Lebanon. Judge Milton Freiman, of the Municipal Court of Millburn, N.J., performed the ceremony. Miss Charolotta Rabinovitz was maid of honor and Dr. Ibrahim Abu-Shumays was best man.
EAST ORANGE, N.J., June 5 William K. Flanagan of 209 Prospect Street, a lawyer in Newark for 50 years, died yesterday at the Hartwick West Nursing Home in Cedar Grove. He was 83 years old.
FRAMINGHAM, Mass., June 5 (AP) William J. Elkins, chief of the Justice Department's antitrust division in New England, died today in his home at the age of 55.

STOCKHOLM, June 5 Among the first aspects that must strike someone looking at the Royal Swedish Ballet is its range. The repertory includes 19th-century classics indeed, at the 200year-old Court Theater at Drottingholm it offers reconstructions of l8th-century ballets together with modern works by classic choreographers, as well as in the European modern dance idiom.

HUE, South Vietnam, June 5 (AP) Mayor Phan Van Khoa today dismissed Hue's police chief, whose men failed to do anything to resist the student mobs that burned the United States Information Service and consulate buildings in raids a week apart.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., June 5 Miss Helen Rita Kessler, daughter of Lawrence Victor Kessler and the late Mrs. Kessler, was married here this afternoon to Victor George DiFate Jr. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. DiFate. Msgr. Charles O'Connor Sloane performed the ceremony at a nuptial mass in SS. Peter and Paul's Roman Catholic Church.

PRAGUE, June 5 Czechoslovakia's filmmakers, who have accomplished within the last few years a stunning output of bold and adult movies in the modest confines of their Communist state, are now looking with candid skepticism upon the co-production deal their government is planning to enter into with Italy within the next few weeks.

In the Bellerose (Queens) Jewish Center yesterday, Miss Barbara Helene Frieser, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Frieser of Jamaica, Queens, became the bride of Allan Bomze, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Bomze of Philadelphia.
MILWAUKEE, June 5 (AP) Mario Andretti of Nazareth, Pa., drove his rear-engine Ford around the Wisconsin State Fair Park today at a speed of 95.65 miles an hour and won the 100-mile Rex Mays Classic.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., June 5 Philip C. Johnson, the architect who designed the New York State Theater at Lincoln Center, pleaded today with graduating seniors at Mount Holyoke College to persuade their generation that beauty, "that much neglected, abused, perjorative word, is worth money."
LONDON, June 5 (AP) Jean-Paul Crisinel, a Swiss rider, was disqualified from the Tour of Britain motorcycle race today on charges of taking a drug.

ATLANTA, June 5 (AP) The Atlanta Braves scored seven runs in the fifth inning today before the St. Louis Cardinals retired a batter and went on to post a 14-4 victory. The triumph was the third straight for Atlanta after seven consecutive losses.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, June 5 President-elect Joaquin Balaguer said today that he believed foreign troops might have to remain in the country after the installation of his Government July 1.
The National Jewish Hospital at Denver will receive the proceeds of a cocktail party to be held on Thursday aboard the Grace Lines's Santa Rosa at Pier 57 on the Hudson River.
NEW DELHI, June 5 The Indian Goverment announced a devaluation of the rupee tonight.

The Alliance experimental C Class catamaran sailed by Dave and Jerry Hubbard of Stamford, Conn., won the open-division honors yesterday as the Bayside Yacht Club concluded its seventh multihull invitation regatta.
BERLIN, June 5 The steamer's loudspeaker blared out "When the Saints Come Marching In," but the jazz tune appeared to arouse only a handful of youngsters.

Miss Edna Marion Weinstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Weinstein of the Bronx, was married there yesterday evening to Dr. Joel Jacknow, son of City Marshal William S. Jacknow and Mrs. Jacknow of New York.

CORTLAND, N.Y., June 5 (AP) Philip H. Stevens, who served with the United States Weather Bureau in New York State for 26 years and who was state climatologist at his retirement in 1956, died here yesterday. He was 72 years old.
MOSCOW, June 5 A fourth violent earthquake early today rocked the Central Asian city of Tashkent, which is already one-fifth in ruins.
BAYEUX, France, June 5 (UPI) American veterans of the invasion of Normandy returned to the beaches and the bridgeheads today to honor their comrades who died in the D-Day landings 22 years ago.
WASHINGTON, June 5 Henry F. Haviland, a former electrical engineer in New York died here yesterday. He was 88 years old.

Dr. and Mrs. Hylan A. Bickerman of Bayside, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Pamela Marian Bickerman, to David J. Volkman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Volkman of Brooklyn.
CINCINNATI Experts in the field say that New York's new smog-control ordinances fall considerably short of being the "toughest in the country" as its supporters have said.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 5 Senator Robert F. Kennedy discussed racial problems today with South African editors, one of whom handed him a book on apartheid to help him "understand South Africa better."

NYACK, N.Y., June 5 The first upset occurred today in the annual Nyack invitation tennis tournament at the Nyack Field Club when Ken Abere, the seventh-seeded player, lost to Steve Gottlieb, 6-4, 6-2.

Morton Sobell, serving a 30year sentence for conspiracy to commit wartime espionage, has been brought here for conferences with his lawyers, and possibly scientists, on impounded evidence recently furnished to his defense.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) Arthur J. Goldberg called today for a "mutual cessation of all types of hostilities" in Vietnam and a new Geneva conference to reaffirm the 1954 and 1962 Geneva agreements for peace in Southeast Asia.
GREENWICH, Conn., June 5 Benjamin H. Bryon Jr., sailed his Ensign-class Clyte IV to a third straight East-of-Rye Yacht Racing Association victory on Long Island Sound today.
PITTSBURGH, June 5 (AP) Willie Stargell cracked five straight hits, including two homers, and drove in four runs today as the Pittsburgh Pirates routed the Houston Astros, 10-5.
Jesus Christ had a bit of "what the world calls madness" in Him, according to the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken.

JACKSON, Miss., June 5 (UPI) The Justice Department is expected to dispatch poll watchers to areas of high Negro population in Mississippi tomorrow to observe Tuesday's primaries for a United States Senate post and five Congressional seats.
MOSCOW, June 5 (AP) Six Americans were among the firstround winners today in the Tchaikovsky International Competition for Young Musicians.

SANTA ANA, Calif., June 5 Ronald Reagan came back to the conservative heartland of Orange County today for the last major rally of the campaign that has made him a strong favorite for the Republican nomination for Governor of California and an increasingly good prospect for election.
WASHINGTON, June 5 Following are the votes of delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-call in Congress during the week ended yesterday.
CINCINNATI, June 5 (AP) Leo Cardenas of Cincinnati walloped four homers and drove in eight runs today as the Reds split a double-header with the Chicago Cubs. The Reds won 8-3, before bowing, 9-5.

CHICAGO, June 5 (UPI) Gary Peters pitched a twohitter in the finale and Tommy Agee had a hand in eight runs during the double-header today as the Chicago White Sox downed the Washington Senators, 4-1 and 12-0. Chicago has now scored eight victories in its last 10 games.

FALL RIVER, Mass., June 5 Miss Louise Ellen Cohen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Justin Cohen, was married today to David Wechsler, son of Lawrence Wechsler of Wyncote, Pa., and the late Mrs. Tobeleah Wechsler.
ROME Everything seemed to be looking up in Italy, economically speaking, in late spring except the things that need improvement most the building industry, general investment and employment.

TEHERAN, Iran, June 5 (AP) Arthur Godfrey and his four fellow pilots took off today for Bombay, India, after a 16hour 25-minute flight from New York. They are trying to break various round-the-world records.
JOHNSON CITY, Tex., June 5 President Johnson announced today his intention to nominate Dr. Robert Alan Frosch as Assistant Secretary of the Navy for Research and Development.

A nationwide television audience "saw" the space maneuvers by Lieut. Comdr. Eugene A. Cernan yesterday. The three networks televised mockups of the maneuver using everything from the Bil Baird puppets to engineers on wires playing astronaut roles.

LYNBROOK, L.I., June 5 Miss Harriet Jane Rosenthal, daughter of Mrs. Herbert W. Rosenthal and the late Mr. Rosenthal, was married today to Stanley David Rosenberg. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton I. Rosenberg of Laurelton, Queens. Rabbi Harold I. Saperstein performed the ceremony at Temple Emanu-El here.

CAIRO, June 5 A team of Japanese transportation experts today recommended early construction of a subway system and use of river buses on the Nile to relieve the "horrible traffic congestion" that chokes the heart of this city.
DENVER, June 5 (AP) Don Hardy, publisher of The Canon City (Colo.) Daily Record, died yesterday in Colorado General Hospital. He was 54 years old.

Gov. William W. Scranton of Pennsylvania suggested yesterday that the United States bomb North Vietnamese oil depots and steel mills. He said they were far enough from cities that they do not involve concentrations of civilian population.

ANAHEIM, Calif., June 5 (AP) Don Wert drove in six runs today as Detroit took a double-header from the California Angels, 8-4 and 4-1. The Detroit third baseman knocked in four runs in the opener. The Tigers frittered away an early 4-0 lead, but broke an eighth-inning tie with a four-run rally against Dean Chance, who suffered his fifth straight defeat and seventh in 10 decisions.

The things that needed saying about the "shocking irresponsibility" Governor Rockefeller and legislative leaders of both parties are showing toward the necessity for an adequate city income tax have now been said by the expext best qualified to appraise New York's fiscal requirements with authority and detachment.
RUNNYMEDE, England, June 5 (AP) Park attendants have scoured all traces of vandalism from the Runnymede memorial to President John F. Kennedy.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., June 5 (AP) America's third Orbiting Geophysical Observatory, an insect-shaped satellite carrying more scientific instruments than any previous United States spacecraft, will be launched into orbit around the earth at 10:48 P.M. tomorrow.

Blood will be donated for the New York-New Jersey Red Cross blood program at the New York Red Cross Chapter House, 150 Amsterdam Avenue, today and Thursday from 2 P.M. to 8 P.M. and tomorrow, Wednesday and Friday from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 5 Two smooth riding teen-agers Frederika Leet and Kip Rosenthal dominated the horsemanship and junior hunter classes today at the 24th annual Fairfield-Wetchester Professional Horsemen's Association horse show.
A $530-million sale of Government loan participation certificates Thursday will be the main event this week in the capital market's stiff competition for investors' dollars.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 5 Miss Corinna Finley and Lincoin Davis Hammond were married here this afternoon at Christ Episcopal Church. The Rev. Gardiner M. Day performed the ceremony.

ASHLAND, Ore., June 5 Red, gold and green banners floated from lamp posts in this mad-for-Shakespeare community today as Duke Ellington and his band arrived to help launch a $500,000 expansion program for America's first Elizabethan theater.

The mail-order business may look like the ideal vehicle for making profitable use of spare time to hardpressed families with small incomes or perhaps the fixed allotments of retirement. And some promoters strive to take advantage of that illusion.

VIENNA, June 5 (Reuters) The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (O.P.E.C.) announced today it would give full support to some member countries where it said oil companies were manipulating production against the national interest.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., June 5 The National Aeronautics and Space Administration will have to wait until the flight of Gemini 12 to test a back pack designed to extend man's ability to work and move about in space.

PHILADELPHIA, June 5 (UPI) The Philadelphia Ukrainian Nationals won the soccer championship of the United States today when they defeated the Orange County team of Los Angeles, 3-0, in the National Open Cup competition.
Harlem community leaders heatedly detailed their grievances on housing yesterday. One declared that only "black ownership and control" would cure the explosive problems in Negro ghettos.
A former Open champion, Jack Fleck, was one of 53 players who qualified yesterday for next week's United States Open golf championship at San Francisco's Olympic Country Club.
NEWCASTLE, England, June 6 (UPI)--The British lightweight champion, Maurice Cullen, retained his title tonight with a fifth-round technical knockout of Terry Edwards.

ALBANY, June 6--With tempers in the Legislature at the breaking point over New York City's tax problems and legislators chafing to get home for some political fencemending, Governor Rockefeller issued the following proclamation today:
Negotiations in the monthlong strike that has stopped Carey bus service to and from major metropolitan airports will be resumed today, Abraham A. Desser, a Federal mediator, said last night.

The countryside beat the city in Quebec Province, putting Jean Lesage's Liberal party out of office. Barring switches in the many areas where the vote was so close that recounts are being demanded, Daniel Johnson and his National Union will form a new government.
SAN ANTONIO, June 6-- President Johnson ordered today that the full resources of the Federal Government be put to work to bring to justice the person or persons who shot James Meredith.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 6 (Reuters)--Saigon plans to transfer its prostitutes from the city's streets to a suburban colony in an effort to alleviate the vice problem, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, June 6--The Federal Trade Commission was given broad power today by the Supreme Court to ban manufacturers' franchise programs that threaten to restrain trade, even without proof that the plans have reduced competition.

MOSCOW, June 6--The foreign ministers of the Eastern European Communist countries assembled today to coordinate, according to reliable sources, a joint bargaining stand for an attempt to loosen the stalemate in political relations between Eastern and Western Europe.
WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) --The Supreme Court refused judgment that the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People could be held liable for picketing ordered by its Savannah branch.
QUEBEC, June 6--Daniel Johnson, leader of the Conservative National Union, insisted tonight that he should be asked to form a new Government for Quebec Province with the least possible delay.
Jack Cole, choreographer of "Man of La Mancha," will be a triple-threat man in his next assignment, the new musical, "Chu Chem."
SEOUL, South Korea, June 6 --South Korea rejected today a request by South Vietnam for an air force unit in addition to ground troops.
The British pound registered some improvement in trading here after the close of the London market yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 6-- The Treasury bill rate dropped sharply at today's auction by comparison with results a week ago, the Treasury disclosed tonight.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 6-- A settlement was signed in Federal Court today to end formally the long and bitter legal battle over portable videotape recorders between the Ampex Corporation and the MVR Corporation.

Negotiators for the striking Newspaper Guild and the World Journal Tribune, Inc., worked yesterday to develop a list of future employes for the new corporation following the resignations of 398 persons who had worked for the predecessor newspapers.
WASHINGTON, June 6--A $140-million Administration bill to upgrade international studies in American colleges squeaked through the House today.
RICHMOND, June 6 (AP) --A Federal appeals court today ordered the re-employment of 16 Negro teachers who lost their jobs after school integration in Hendersonville, N.C.

With each return to earth of a manned spacecraft we become more acccustomed to the excitement of those searing minutes as the vehicle first plows into the atmosphere. We become more convinced that the retro rockets will fire and the parachutes open. Yet there are always doubts--a suspicion that it cannot always be so.
New managers and assistant managers of several of the Saks Fifth Avenue stores have been announced by Allan Johnson, vice president.

With workmen still hammering exhibition stands into shape, the National Plastics Exposition opened its gates at the Coliseum here yesterday to offer manufacturers and consumers an orientation course in new products and machinery.

Thomas S. Gates, who was a Secretary of Defense in the Defense in the Eisenhower Administration, criticized the military draft system yesterday and called for "some kind of program to involve all our young men in government service for a period."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 6 --Miss Elizabeth Virginia Glover was married today to Jose Enrique Trias, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jose Trias Monge of San Juan, P.R. The bride is a daughter of Prof. John Desmond Glover of the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration and Mrs. Glover of Weston.
LONDON, June 6 (AP)--The Broadway musical "Funny Girl" will end its run here July 16 when its star, Barbra Streisand, bows out.

BECKENHAM, England, June 6 (UPI)--Arthur Ashe of Richmond, Va., playing in his first tournament in months and fac ing a two-year hitch in the Army, won his first test in the Kent tennis championships today, scoring a 6-2, 6-4 victory over Geoff Bluett of England.

CHICAGO, June 6--George W. Mitchell, a member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, predicted today that increased automation would enable banks to give more attention to individual depositors, small businessmen and, in general, "the men in the street."
Jacob M. Budish, a labor economist and writer, died Saturday. He lived at 51 West 86th Street and was 80 years old.

WASHINGTON, June 6-- Arthur J. Goldberg said today that the United States would be willing to have the International Control Commission observe the planned September elections for a constituent assembly in South Vietnam.
BERLIN, June 6--Forty elderly West Berlin Jews received permits from East Germany to cross the Berlin wall and visited the graves of their relatives in East Berlin yesterday.

NEWARK, June 6--The president of the state A.F.L.C.I.O., in a reference to the Genovese case, called today for a Congressional investigation of Rutgers to see whether the state university was carrying on "an active program of subversion."

GREENWICH, Conn., June 6 --Mr. and Mrs. Carl E. Holch have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Claire Holch, to Clyde Walker Gordon Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon of Burlington, N.C.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (UPI) The Washington Senators, held to one run in their last four games, ended their scoring drought tonight on homers by Frank Howard and Ed Brinkman that carried them to a 5-3 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.

"It was a crusher of a day," a sugar dealer commented yesterday, as he described the sharp drop in prices. What pushed down further the already low prices for world sugar was news of a huge sale by Brazil over the weekend.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 5--Outside the Governor's house in Svayrieng, red, blue and green light bulbs turned the mango grove into a fairyland. Inside, wine glasses tinkled gently on the flower-strewn dinner table.

Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union, who was unable to wrest the world chess crown from his compatriot Tigran Petrosian, defeated Petrosian in the 23d game of their match last night at Moscow's Variety Theatre.

THE natives are getting restless--even in the Soviet Union. Just the other day Yuri Vlasov, the one-time Olympic weight-lifting champion, let drop some observations that landed with the shattering clatter of a barbell dropping to the deck.

SINGAPORE, June 6 (UPI) --The Singapore Government disclosed today that it had agreed to recognize Indonesia, but was delaying the exchange of diplomatic representatives for fear of antagonizing Malaysia.
WASHINGTON, June 6--The Supreme Court took away today the power of Federal judges to hand down, without a jury trial, prison sentences of more than six months for criminal contempt.
LONDON, June 6--The pound fell to its lowest level in 18 months today in selling approaching the heavy proportions of late 1964.
The purchase of options for two supersonic Concorde aircraft to strengthen the capabilities of Eastern Air Lines for Pacific service has been announced by the carrier's president, Floyd D. Hall.

City Controller Mario A. Procaccino walked into the upper West Side headquarters of a new Puerto Rican antipoverty agency financed by the city yesterday, and exclaimed: "Hey, this is lush!"

TEL AVIV, June 6--All of Israel's music critics declined to review a performance of a cantata by the German composer, Carl Orff, pending clarification of allegations that he had been a Nazi collaborator.

Syracuse will play Baylor, Sept. 10, at Waco, Tex., in the first nationally televised college football game of the season and each institution will receive about $165,000. This is the first college TV game of the season in a 14-program schedule that will televise college football 13 Saturday afternoons and Thanksgiving Day.

MILLBROOK, N.Y., June 6 --Frederick Keiley Gaston Jr., president of the insurance company bearing his name at 100 East 42d Street, New York, died today at the Sharon (Conn.) Hospital. He was 68 years old.
In a major management realignment, Continental Airlines, Inc., announced yesterday the appointment of Orville E. Melby, 44 years old, as senior vice president-finance ...

The chapel of the Brick Presbyterian Church was the setting here yesterday morning for the marriage of Princess Martha Crawford Auersperg of New York to Claus von Bulow of London. The Rev. Dr. D. Reginald Thomas performed the ceremony.
Shareholders of the Cold Lake Pipe Line Company, Inc., have fully subscribed to a recent offer of Consolidated Oil and Gas, Inc., to exchange one share of its stock for five shares of Cold Lake.

Voter apathy threatens the efforts of progressive and moderate elements in the Democratic party in the Bronx to break the steadily weakening control of party machinery still held by the aging boss, Charles A. Buckley.

Peter Pellicani, a newly graduated city building inspector, faced his first adversary yesterday, a growling, nipping dog. He dodged the attack artfully.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (UPI) --The House, ignoring President Johnson's plea against tax reductions while the Vietnam war continues, approved unanimously today a tax break that the Treasury would go primarily to "high-paid doctors, dentists and lawyers."

The Department of Justice has called on a group raising funds to aid South African prisoners to register as "agent of a foreign principal." The group has defied the order, and reports it has backing from major civil liberties organizations.
The negotiations between the city and the Port of New York Authority over the controversial World Trade Center enter a crucial and perhaps climatic stage this week.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., June 6 (AP)--Big Broad Jumper, a 32-foot aluminum maritime, captured the two-day Gateway Powerboat Marathon today by darting over the turbulent Atlantic Ocean between Grand Bahama and West Palm Beach in 5 hours 10 minutes 52 seconds.

Earl Leonard Griffith, a senior vice president of the Consolidated Edison Company, died of a heart attack Sunday while playing golf with his son at the Canoe Brook Country Club, Short Hills, N.J. He was 66 years old and lived at 18 Roland Drive, Short Hills.

PITTSBURGH, June 6 (AP) --Civil rights pickets began a series of demonstrations today against the United States Steel Corporation, protesting what they contend are discriminatory employment practices against Negroes.

WASHINGTON, June 6--The effect of the free election in the Dominican Republic was a sweeping popular endorsement of President Johnson's determination there shall be "no more Cubas."

The New York Stock Exchange began yesterday the transmission of stock prices by computer from the floor of the exchange to the Big Board's international ticker network.

The Ford Motor Company said yesterday that five of its 17 automobile assembly plants in the United States would be on short work schedules this week. This is Ford's first such production cutback since the furor over auto safety began earlier this year.

Jack R. Howard, president of the Inter American Press Association, said yesterday that freedom of the press did not exist in Paraguay, Haiti or of the press.

PATTEN, Me., June 6-- Most people think of big-game hunting as coming late in the fall when snow is on the brink of falling and the ground is cold and dead. Emile Francis, who said he never had any doubt he could handle both jobs, was rehired yesterday as coach and general manager of the New York Rangers.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (UPI) --The Commerce Department announced today that 73,700 tons of the 200,000 short tons of refined copper released from the Government stockpile last March were allocated for domestic hardship consumption in May and June.
WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) --The new United States Ambassador to Pakistan, Eugene Murphy Locke, will establish the American Embassy in Rawalpindi rather than Karachi, the State Department said today.

ALBANY, June 6--Upstate Republican Assemblymen, jumpy over the grass roots furor caused by the passage of the state's new medical aid program, led a rebellion today against several of the Governor Rockefeller's bills, including his major one to combat air pollution.

The election of Leslie N. Landes as director and chairman of the executive committee of the Anglo Norness Shipping Company, Limited, one of the world's major operators of tanker and dry bulk-cargo tonnage, was announced here yesterday by the Naess Shipping Company, Inc., a subsidiary of the British concern.

Cool music for hot-weather listening was played by the Kent State University Faculty Trio in Carnegie Recital Hall last night. The members of this capable ensemble from Ohio are Frederic Cohen, clarinetist, John Dempsey, violinist, and Frederic Schoettler, pianist.

LIVINGSTON, N.Y., June 6 --Frederick Young, the 38-yearold Kings Park, L.I., grade school teacher sought on charges of molesting a dozen of his boy pupils in the last three years, ccommitted suicide here yesterday, the police reported.
HARTFORD, Conn., June 6 --The State of Connecticut is spending $4.6-million on threefoot-high steel median dividers to make its highways safer.
Pan American World Airways announced here yesterday it had urged the Civil Aeronautics Board to include the award of routes to Moscow in its investigation of new transPacific runs.
TRENTON, June 6--Despite a last-minute drive for votes by Gov. Richard J. Hughes, the Assembly defeated late today part of the Governor's program to curb drunken driving in New Jersey.
WASHINGTON, June 6-- Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision invalidating the conviction of Dr. Samuel Sheppard in the murder of his wife:
WASHINGTON, June 6 (UPI) --The Civil Aeronautics Board blamed pilot error today for the crash of a Boeing 727 jetliner at Salt Lake City, Utah, last Nov. 11. The crash killed 43 of the 85 passengers.
WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) A program to provide burial insurance for wrecked and junked automobiles was suggested today by Senator Paul H. Douglas.

South Africa's restrictive racial policies drive that Government steadily into greater isolation from the community of nations. There is danger in such isolation. For the long run, a major danger is that South Africa will miscalculate the state of United States sentiment.

HOBOKEN, N.J., June 7 Stockholders of the United States Lines Company approved here today a change in corporate structure to allow diversification into fields other than cargo and passenger-vessel operations.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 7 The leadership of the Unified Buddhist Church appeared tonight to have adopted a policy of passive resistance to the regime of Premier Nguyen Cao Ky.
BOSTON, June 7 Thirteen newspapermen were announced by Harvard University today as winners of Nieman fellowships for 1966-67.
ALBANY, June 7 Governor Rockefeller signed into law tonight a bill providing "seed money" to encourage the construction of housing developments for low-income families.
BRISTOL, England, June 7 (AP) Two American Stars, Ron Holmberg and Cliff Richey, scored victories today in the West of England tennis championships.
The police opened a drive yesterday against illegal parking in the East 60s, 70s and 80s, an area that has enjoyed considerable immunity from parking laws.

STOCKHOLM, June 7 One of the most interesting as pects of the Swedish dance world is the presence of a modern-dance element. In many places in Europe, particularly Germany, there developed between the wars a very definite school of expressive dancing. Subsequently this declined. Not, however, in Sweden, where it has even played some part in the development of the Royal Swedish Ballet.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., June 7 (AP) OGO 3, a satellite scheduled to perform more experiments than any previous United States scientific spacecraft, orbited the earth "in perfect condition" today in its first day in space. The satellite is attempting to unravel mysteries of the sun's relations to this planet.

ROSELLE, N.J., June 7 Harrison W. Gardiner of 612 Chestnut Street, a pioneer in the field of electricity and the last veteran of the Spanish-American War here, died last night at the Elizabeth General Hospital. He was 87 years old.
Sue Halpern, public relations director for the city's Department of Hospitals, died yesterday at New York University Hospital of a heart attack. She was 56 years old.

Amid the brave talk about the "vastly improved" New York Mets earlier this spring, hard-headed spoilsports kept muttering, "It's pretty risky to depend on a pitching staff with so many youngsters on it, even if they're pretty good."
Andrew Goodman, president of the Bergdorf Goodman Company, was elected yesterday as chairman of the Better Business Bureau of Metropolitan New York.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., June 7 Thomas W. Hays, general superintendent of construction of the Uris Buildings Corporation, 850 Third Avenue, New York, died yesterday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville. He was 62 years old and lived on Hayward Avenue here.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 7--President Tito declared today "it is an illusion" to think that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization "can be preserved."

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, June 7 (AP) The President-Elect Joaquin Balaguer, and the candidate he defeated, Juan Bosch, met secretly last night to discuss national problems, an authoritative source said today.
WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) The International Monetary Fund said today 83 of its 103 member nations had agreed to increases in their quotas as recommended last year by the fund's board of governors.

RUMSON, N.J., June 7 Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Spring Woodman have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kittie Spring Woodman, to Edward Thomas Richards, son of Mr. and Mrs. Earl Thomas Richards Jr. of Indianapolis.
The College of Mount St. Vincent today conferred an honorary degree of doctor of laws on Sir Etienne Depuch, editor and publisher of the Nassau Daily Tribune in the Bahamas.
A Silverman-for-Surrogate supporter took new legal action yesterday in an attempt to avoid the candidacy of State Supreme Court Justice Arthur G. Klein.

Andrew Jackson High of Queens and White Plains High set national interscholastic records for the two-mile relay and the 880-yard relay yesterday in special events on the all-weather track of St. John's University in Hillcrest, Queens.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 7 So many members of the graduating class of the United States Military Academy have volunteered for combat in the jungles of Vietnam that the Army has used a quota system to cut their number.
MEXICO CITY, June 7 Every day Mexicans in the aggregate get more opportunities to live better. But the improvement, while obvious to the most casual observer, is slow and uneven.
The Chock Full o' Nuts Corporation said yesterday that Gaylord M. LaMond had been elected president of the company. He is the fourth man to hold that post since 1963.

Huntington Hartford, grandson and namesake of the founder of the Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company, has arranged to sell about $22-million worth of the big grocery-store chain's stock. A. P. filed a registration statement yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission, covering a public offering of 760,000 shares of stock, or about 3 per cent of the 24.5 million shares outstanding.

JO HUGHES, the brown-eyed, copper-haired saleswoman who has served as a marriage broker between the worlds of fashion and society, is moving to Bergdorf Goodman. On June 24, she will leave DePinna, where for the last 12 years she has commanded an empire of grateful, obedient, blue-blooded and rich customers from a tiny, unmarked salon carved out of three fitting rooms.

THE outstanding events of the coming weekend are the Area One championship races of the Sports Car Club of American at Lime Rock, Conn., on Saturday and the 30th running of the 100-mile championship race for Indianapolis cars at Langhorne, Pa., on Sunday.

WASHINGTON, June 7 The Under Secretary of the Treasury urged Congress today not to put an interest rate ceiling as low as 4 per cent on what commercial banks can pay on smaller-denomination time deposits.
EDGEWATER, N.J. June 7 A team of Federal officials and shipping men stood behind a 40-foot overland trailer bearing export cargo for the trailership terminal of Seatrain Lines.
The City University is considering the establishment of a medical school that would "pioneer new health-career educational programs."

The Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation began yesterday a rights offering to holders to subscribe to 258,503 additional shares at $112.50. Goldman, Sachs Co. is the manager of an underwriting group that will buy unsubscribed shares.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (UPI) Four Negroes sought today to force their way into the office of Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach to demand more Federal protection for civil rights workers like James H. Meredith.

The vista of sizable rate savings Governor Rockefeller has dangled before Blue Cross subscribers is obviously a maneuver to mute complaints about the high potential cost to taxpayers of the state's new program for free care to the medically needy. The worst part of the performance is that the Blue Cross cuts the Governor holds forth are even more speculative than the projections he has made of the probable cost of the new medical program.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., June 7 Mr. and Mrs. Walter Arthur Bastedo have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Julia Gilbert Bastedo, to Richard Robinson Vietor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Orr Vietor of New Haven and Edgartown, Mass.

The name of the oil millionaire John W. Mecom disappeared yesterday from the masthead of The Houston Chronicle, apparently signaling the collapse of an $85-million deal that was thought to have given him ownership of the Texas paper six months ago.

FLANDERS, N.J., June 7 Frank D. Farnsworth, a former director of outside plant development of the Bell Telephone Laboratories, Inc., died yesterday in Dover General Hospital after a heart attack at his home on North Road. He was 74 years old.

PASADENA, Calif., June 7 (UPI) Natacha Rambova, second wife of the late screen idol Rudolph Valentino and the adopted daughter of Richard Hudnut, the perfume manufacturer, died Sunday in a hospital here.

The executive director of the Port of New York Authority charged yesterday that the city administration was making "preposterous" demands on his agency as condi tions for permission to proceed with the proposed World Trade Center.

The 103-man graduating class of New York Maritime College the second largst class to complete four years of shipofficer training at the State University school heard an emotional appeal yesterday from an old salt to keep American ships sailing.

WASHINGTON, June 7 The United States has refused permission for the Cuban delegation to the forthcoming Central American and Caribbean Games to travel directly from Cuba to Puerto Rico, a State Department spokesman said today.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) The Senate passed by voice vote today a bank holding company bill that would require the multimillion-dollar Alfred I. du Pont estate in Florida to be split up within five years.
Deputy Postmaster General Frederick C. Belen said yesterday that the nation was facing "a mail explosion of unprecedented proportions" but that the Zip code program would be able to cope with it.

Confusion is endemic to battlefields and revolutions. In South Vietnam, with a political revolution in progress within a civil war, the chaos of both are combined. Disaster may be at hand. But it is also just possible that a hopeful evolution is beginning. For important steps are being taken toward representative government in Saigon that could alter the whole context of the revolution and the war.
MEMPHIS, June 7 James H. Meredith said today from his hospital room that he would never again walk through Mississippi unarmed.

Directors of the First National City Bank announced yesterday an increase in the quarterly dividend rate to 45 cents a capital share from 40 cents in previous quarters. The dividend is payable Aug. 1 to holders of record July 5.

HERNANDO, Miss., June 7--The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and three other civil rights leaders took up James H. Meredith's march to Jackson today and almost immediately were shoved from the pavement to the shoulder of the highway by Mississippi state troopers.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., June 7 Ground crews were baffled by what to do with four small wire devices and that, it was disclosed today, caused the nose shroud failure that left the Gemini 9 target vehicle looking like an "angry alligator."
CLEVELAND, June 7 The New York Yankees started their second month under Manager Ralph Houk tonight by defeating the Cleveland Indians, 7-2, and dispersing a whole platoon of demons, to wit:

"BOY, they sure look different from the way they did this morning," a father from Michigan said Monday night as he shook his head in wonder at members of the just-graduated class of The Masters School for girls at Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

The Pollyannas of the Western world now comfort themselves by claiming NATO has actually benefited from the crisis forced upon it by de Gaulle because this provokes needed reforms. That is patent nonsense. No alliance benefits by removal of its keystone. And General Lemnitzer, allied commander, remarks: "One more benefit of this sort and we'll be out of business."

PASADENA, Calif., June 7--Pictures taken by Surveyor 1 show a lunar surface with the consistency of a "freshly turned field" in which an astronaut would leave footprints and scuff marks but would not "sink up to his kneecaps," a space scientist, said today.

New York University will hold commencement exercises for 6,770 students today at its University Heights campus in the Bronx, Arthur J. Goldberg, United States Representative to the United Nations, will be the principal speaker.

The Canada Dry Corporation reported yesterday that sales for the fourth fiscal quarter ended March 31 rose to $36,836,300 from $31,471,694 a year ago. Net earnings stood at $989,515, or 40 cents a share, excluding a special item of $202,937, or 9 cents a share. In the 1965 period, the company earned $761,235, or 30 cents a share.
ALBANY, June 7 The Democratic-controlled Assembly defeated today a proposed increase in New York City's real estate tax and dug in for a long siege in the tax battle.
Dr. Arthur M. Cahn, who retired recently as an epidemiologist for the Department of Health, died yesterday in his home at 11 Riverside Drive. He was 66 years old.

PALO ALTO, Calif., June 7 Mr. and Mrs. Han Liang Huang have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Helen S.M. Huang, to Dr. Yang Wang, son of Mrs. Yu-Shen Wang of the Republic of China and the late Mr. Wang.
The Sperry Hutchinson Company, distributor of S Green Stamps, has named Frederick A. Collins Jr. as executive vice president, in charge of the marketing, merchandise and control divisions.

Thirteen of the world's foremost professional tennis players from Australia, Europe, South America and the United States have gathered for the roundrobin tournament starting at 6:30 this evening on the turf courts in the stadium of the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens.
BUENOS AIRES, June 7 A major effort by organized labor to topple the Government of President Arturo Illia through a general strike, appeared to have failed today.
QUEBEC, June 7 (Premier Jean Lesage has kept silent about his plans two days after his upset defeat in a close election for Quebec's parliament.

Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., former special assistant to President Kennedy, warned last night against basing the nation's policy in Southeast Asia on comparisons with what happened in Europe before World War II.

SPEYER, Germany, June 3 Lieut. Col. Jean Louis Guillot, commanding officer of the First Spahi Regiment welcomed the Second Squadron, First German Armored Car Regiment, to Speyer last week as "comrades in arms."

THEY were amused last night at the Jan Hus Play house on East 74th Street, where the "H.M.S. Pinafore" anchored. Which is more than Queen Victoria was back in 1878 when the arrival of the saucy ship of sober men prompted her to deliver her famous dictum: "We are not amused."

WASHINGTON, June 7 The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said today that it must earn at least an 8 per cent profit on its investment a bit more than it is earning now from the part of its businesses that is regulated by the Federal Government.

An exhibition and sale of needlework at the Brooklyn Museum Gallery Shop includes examples of work from all over the world. Among these are Hungarian pillow covers, Portuguese motherand-daughter aprons, Indian crewelwork and Central American applique.
"John F. Kennedy: Years of Lightning, Days of Drums" at the Lincoln Arts Theater and Cinema I.

The Zayre Corporation expects to achieve record sales and earnings in fiscal 1967, Stanley H. Feldberg, president of the discount department stores chain, said yesterday at its annual meeting in Boston. Sales in the year ending Jan. 28 are expected to exceed $300-million, with a proportionate gain in profits, he said.

AFTER four decades of service with the Ameri can Telephone and Telegraph Company, Ben Screws Gilmer still likes to answer his own phone. A muted ring, a sweep of the hand, then "Gilmer" in a courteous Southern tone.
HONOLULU, June 7 (AP) Mrs. John F. Kennedy has rented a three-bedroom house for her month-long visit to Honolulu.

BECKENHAM, England, June 7 (AP) Arthur Ashe and two United States Davis Cup teammates, Marty Riessen and Clark Graebner, won secondround matches today in the Beckenham tennis tournament. The event is a tune-up for the Wimbledon championship, which starts June 20.
CAIRO, June 7 "Well," a fashionable young Egyptian in a brilliant red sheath and pony tail whispered to her date, "if it gets hot, we'll just leave." Hot it got, but leave they did not.
A sudden electrical storm drenched a considerable part of the metropolitan area yesterday, causing power failures and some flooding before it stopped abruptly after an hour.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, June 8--American paratroopers turned back an attack on an artillery position in the Central Highlands yesterday, killing 136 North Vietnamese soldiers.
Governor Rockefeller came under sharp attack yesterday for the support he has given the city tax program of Senate Majority Leader Earl W. Brydges and for not supporting the program of Mayor Lindsay.

The Lower East Side antipoverty election appeared yesterday to have resulted in a major victory for the area's Puerto Rican community and for parishes of the Roman Catholic church that helped them organize.
LOS ANGELES, June 7 With the assistance of a 74year-old steel heiress from Pittsburgh, Richard M. Nixon is helping to ease the financial pangs of selected Republican Congressional candidates.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 7 (AP) The Minnesota Vikings announced today that they had traded a defensive tackle, Jim Prestel, and a defensive back, Larry Vargo, to the New York Giants, also of the National Football League, for a rookie defensive end, Bill Briggs, and a future draft choice.
MANHASSET, L.I. June 7 Miss Susan Rittenhouse and Jeffrey Law Simmons plan to marry this summer.

Paperboard production rose 9.4 per cent with 441,900 tons in the week ended June 4 from 403,179 tons in the corresponding 1965 week, the Paperboard Group of the American Paper Institute reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 7--The Senate Foreign Relations Committee has accepted an invitation to visit Cambodia.
LONDON, June 7 The British pound came under heavy selling pressure again today, falling 1/8-cent to a new 18month low of $2.78-27-32.
LONDON, June 7 The pound trembles, the gold runs out, Britain's ships stand in the docks but at Annabel's they come and go, talking of how short the skirts can go.

Charges of felonious possession of marijuana against the four young men who make up the Lost Souls rock 'n' roll singing group were dismissed yesterday by Criminal Court Judge Daniel S. Weiss because of lack of evidence.
WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) Legislation intended to assure the humane treatment of cats, dogs and other animals used for research was sent to the Senate floor today by its Commerce Committee.

E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., announced yesterday immediate reductions ranging from 4 to 14 per cent in the price of Dacron polyester textile filament yarns, affecting 24 items in the company's product line.

WASHINGTON, June 7 The more President Johnson declines in the popularity polls and the nearer we come to the November elections, the more political considerations seem to influence the President's activities in the field of foreign policy.

A spokesman for the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants said yesterday that the resignation from practice before the Securities and Exchange Commission by Hurdman Co. "will automatically be docketed for investigation" by the trade group's ethics committee.
Awards for the Broadway season of 1965-66 were announced yesterday by the Outer Circle, an association of writers covering the New York theater for out-of-town newspapers and other media.

Ronald M. Killie, manager of mutual fund business for Bache Co., testified in Federal Court here yesterday that he had heard of the Texas Gulf Sulphur Company's copper strike near Timmins, Ont., almost an hour before the concern announced it had made a "major discovery."

Record sales and earnings were reported yesterday by J. Ray McDermott Co. in its annual statement for the fiscal year ended March 31. The Louisiana-based company provides engineering and other services for the production and transportation of oil and gas in offshore and marshland areas.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., June 7 Miss Barbara Ann Lytton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert E. Lytton of Middletown and New York, was married at noon today to Frederic Ormond Glover Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Glover of Stanford, Calif.

WASHINGTON, June 7 Rebellious members of the House Banking Committee succeeded today in forcing a full committee meeting to consider the validity of subpoenas issued to a number of banks in connection with an investigation being conducted by Chairman Wright Patman, Democrat of Texas.

Sam Snead, who at 54 figures he does not have too many chances to win the elusive United States Open Golf championship, failed to qualify for the 1966 title round yesterday when he shot a 76, 75 151 at Detroit.
NEWPORT, R.I. June 7 Although there will be no America's Cup races this year, the prospects for a full summer social season at this resort are bright.
BALTIMORE, June 7 (AP) Frank Robinson singled across a run with the bases loaded to cap a three-run 12th inning that gave the Baltimore Orioles a 6-5 victory over the Washington Senators tonight.
WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) The Post Office Department asked today for a stronger law to prevent the use of the mails for sending false and misleading material.
Heat, high humidity and a strike by 700 air-conditioning operators yesterday caused secretaries to look limp and executives to lose their dignity in many Manhattan office buildings.
When Ernest Cardone was born 22 years ago, he weighed 4 pounds 5 ounces. They had to put him into an incubator to try to fatten him up.

STRATFORD, Ont., June 7 The Stratford Shake spearean Festival opened its 14th season last night with Michael Langham's production of "Henry V." The capacity festive audience saw a performance by an ensemble whose best quality is that it is a true Shakespearean company.

OCEANPORT, N.J., June 7 (AP)--Rigorous, racing in the colors of Mrs. Milton Erlanger's Woodside Stud Farm won the feature race at Monmouth Park today. The victory was the fourth of the four-day old meeting for Mrs. Erlanger, a New Jersey sportswoman. One of her horses has won a race each day since opening day last Friday.
MIAMI, June 7 (UPI) A hurricane, pushing slowly out of the Caribbean with 95-mile-anhour winds, spun gales across western Cuba today and kept south Florida on the alert.
Harding F. Bancroft, executive vice president of The New York Times, has been elected a trustee of the Carnegie Corporation of New York, it was announced yesterday by the educational foundation.
A Negro chauffeur for John D. Rockefeller 3d filed suit yesterday in Federal Court under the Civil Rights Act to gain membership in the Volunteer Fire Department in Tarrytown, N.Y.
CHICAGO, June 7 (AP) Jim Lefebvre's 12th home run and an inside-the-park homer by Al Ferrara in the 10th inning lifted the Los Angeles Dodgers to an 8-6 victory over the Chicago Cubs today.
WASHINGTON, June 7 A railroad labor organization, charging the industry with failure to bargain with workers in good faith, warned today of possible strikes unless the carriers changed their ways.
LONDON, June 7 Britain's striking merchant seamen called today for a world-wide labor union embargo against British ships.
HUNTINGDON VALLEY, Pa., June 7 Mrs. Charles Wilson of the Philadelphia Country Club took a fourstroke lead as the 60th annual women's Eastern 54-hole medalplay championship got under way today.
ROSLYN, L.I., June 7 Miss Nora S. Kanton and Leonard J. Shukovsky were married this evening in the Sanctuary of the Temple Beth Sholom by Rabbi Ario S. Hyams.
Although the looks in the eyes of her friends and neighbors led her to believe that her husband was dead, Mrs. James H. Meredith said yesterday, "I never gave up."
BRUSSELS, June 7 The principal members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization took a united stand today against an early East-West conference on European security.
WASHINGTON, June 7 The House approved sweeping bail reforms today, allowing poor defendants awaiting trial in Federal courts to be released without bond. The vote was 318 to 14.

HERNANDO, Miss., June 7 Aubrey James Norvell, a 40year-old former hardware dealer, was placed under a $25,000 bond today and arraigned on charges of "assault with a deadly weapon with intent to murder and kill James Meredith."

PEKING, June 7--The Chinese Communist authorities have stepped up both the scope and the intensity of street demonstrations that have been staged daily since last Friday's purge at Peking University and in the city's Communist party branch.
Buyers returned to the London stock market yesterday and pushed up prices.
GENEVA, June 7--The International Red Cross said today it was forwarding an average of 50 letters a week to United States prisoners in North Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, June 7 Mayor Lindsay of New York was derided today by William F. Buckley Jr., his unsuccessful Conservative party opponent, for adopting policies that Mr. Buckley had proposed in last year's campaign.

Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Washington of the Bronx have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Washington, a concert soprano, to Benjamin Grant of High Point, N.C., who teaches at the Lexington School for the Deaf here.
Grey Advertising, Inc., held its first annual meeting yesterday since going public--and the whole thing was apparently beginner's luck.
The growth of nuclear power in the United States in outstripping even optimistic predictions, Glen T. Seaborg, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, said yesterday.

Lester O. Naylor, president of Arlan's Department Stores since October, 1964, has resigned after a policy dispute with Herbert Palestine, chairman of Arlan's, it was announced by Mr. Palestine at the discount chain's annual meeting yesterday.

THE least of Bobby Bragan's problems during spring training was his line-up. It was set. Unlike most managers who had one or two positions in doubt, the virtually peerless leader of the Braves had his batting order firmly fixed in his mind even before he took his carpetbaggers to Atlanta to open the new store.

LONDON, June 7 Norman Baillie-Stewart, who served two prison terms for twice betraying his country to Germany, died today in Ireland at the age of 57. He collapsed in the street in the village of Artane, near Dublin, and died without regaining consciousness.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 7 Edward G. Dowling, executive vice president of the Venus Pen and Pencil Corporation, died today of a heart attack in St. Francis Hospital here. He was 51 years old and lived at 76 Sherry Lane, Manhasset.

PANAMA, June 7 Students and sympathizers, numbering 500 to 1,000, remained in Panama University today surrounded by a cordon of National Guardsmen in the wake of yesterday's burning and looting of public buildings and private property here and in Colon.
LONDON, June 7 Three comic one-act plays by Saul Bellow have received a generally enthusiastic critical reception here.

The American Electric Power Company announced yesterday that it was extending its $100a-share tender offer for the stock of Michigan Gas and Electric Company to June 20. The offer was originally scheduled to expire June 6.

Directors of the Western Bancorporation approved yesterday a plan under which the holding company would acquire the 1,067,576 shares, or 18 per cent, of the stock in the United California Bank that it does not already own.

LOS ANGELES, June 7 Kenneth Donahue has been appointed director of the Los Angles County Museum of Art, the museum's trustees announced today. The position had been vacant since the resignation last November of Dr.Richard F. Brown.
PARIS, June 7 The United States is being accused of trying to break up Western Europe's space rocketry program with tantalizing offers for joint United States-European exploration of the planets.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 7 The director of the Bureau of the Budget told leaders of the nation's electric-utility industry here today that the Government must be ready both to seize opportunities and to cut losses both to innovate and to amputate."
Prices of world sugar futures rose yesterday after a slow start in fairly heavy trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange and then eased to close mixed.
Bob Thompson, a surrealist artist from New York, died on Saturday in Rome of a lung hemorrhage at the age of 29.

CLEVELAND, June 7 (UPI) Prosecutor John T. Corrigan said today he would not decide until tomorrow whether to bring Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard to trial again for the 1954 murder of his pregnant wife, Marilyn.

MANY readers like to test their skills on the deals shown in this column, and they can do so with today's by covering the East-West hands and planning the play in six hearts against the opening lead of the spade queen. There is only one procedure for the declarer that offers any real hope of success.
CHAPINGO, Mexico, June 7--The United States has assured Mexico it does not intend to dump cotton surpluses in world markets.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 7 Vice President Humphrey had "a wide-ranging discussion" with Secretary General Thant at luncheon today and expressed the Administration's support of the United Nations and its confidence in the Secretary General.

WASHINGTON, June 7 The nation's air pollution problems continue to grow faster than all efforts to cope with them, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare John w. gardner, told a Senate subcommittee hearing today.
PITTSBURGH, June 7 (AP)--Roberto Clemente's three-run homer was the big blow in an eight-run eighth inning that gave the Pittsburgh Pirates a 9-1 triumph over the St. Louis Cards tonight.
The Metropolitan Opera received one of a pair of its backstage curtains yesterday morning, creating a small traffic jam.

TOKYO, June 7 A top officer of the Tokyo Stock Exchange expressed confidence today that the market could successfully absorb 363 billion yen (about $1 billion) worth of frozen securities soon to be sold back by two big stock-pooling syndicates.
DURBAN, South Africa, June 7 Senator Robert F. Kennedy said here tonight that he had been invited back to South Africa next year. He said he would be delighted to return.

WASHINGTON, June 7 President Johnson said today that recommendations of a Presidential emergency board "form the framework for a just and prompt settlement" of the labor dispute between the International Association of Machinists and five major airlines.

Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that the city is planning to set up at least one additional industrial park in Brooklyn to attract new industry, provide badly needed jobs and reduce industrial slums in the boroughs.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 7 The Armstrong Brothers' favored Armbro Flight will be on the pole when the 160th anniversary of harness racing's birth is observed next Friday at Roosevelt Raceway with the staging of the $25,000 Yankey Trot.

Since concerts exert the educational influence they do in our society, it is fervently hoped that last night's "American" Promenade by the New York Philharmonic at Philharmonic Hall did not leave its audience with the idea that what it had heard was the heart and soul of American music.
PARIS, June 7 (UPI)--Students celebrating the end of the rigorous "baccalaurcat" examinations clashed frequently with police tonight in the Paris streets.
The major leagues offered rich lures to 20 high school and college baseball players yesterday when they staged their annual spring free-agent at the Roosevelt Hotel.
DACCA, Pakistan, June 7 (Reuters) Ten people were killed when the police opened fire today to quell bloody rioting in this East Pakistan capital and the nearby industrial town of Naryanganj.
The election of Walter L. Lingle as a director of Federated Department Stores, Inc., was announced yesterday at the annual meeting in Cincinnati.
NEWARK, June 7 A compromise settlement was reached here today on a suit brought by the N.A.A.C.P. charging that Negroes had been discriminated against in the selection of juries.
For the first time in five years, the Communist party of the United States proposes to identify at least its general secretary and national chairman publicly despite risk of Federal prosecution.
ATLANTA, June 7 More than 500 of Atlanta's 728 firemen walked off their jobs tonight in a dispute over wages and hours and refused a plea by Mayor Ivan Allen Jr. to return to work.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (UPI) The Senate Public Works Committee approved today a three-year, $375-million program of grants to states and localities to sponsor driver education, auto inspection, traffic control and other safety projects.

DETROIT, June 7 (UPI) Teachers' strikes called in defiance of a Michigan anti-strike law spread to another suburb today, Gov. George W. Romney met with leaders of both sides as picketing teachers chanted outside his Capitol window.
WASHINGTON, June 7 The Job Corps announced today it was abandoning its women's training center in St. Petersburg, Fla., because of "local hostility."
STERN BROTHERS showed its corduroy fashions for fall yesterday.

Catharine K. Miller, former supervising librarian of the old Music Library of the 58th Street Branch of the New York Public Library, died at Trafalgar Hospital Monday after a long illness. She was the wife of Philip L. Miller, who retired last month as chief of the Music Division of the New York Public Library.

The spot rate on the British pound declined again yesterday in moderate trading on foreignexchange markets here. The rate reached a low for the day of $2.788, but later improved somewhat to close at $2.7886, down by 10 points from Monday's final quotation.
Music lovers in the Metropolitan area will be singing the praises of the Federal Communications Commission on Jan. 1.

Miss Kendra Delos Blodgett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Delos A. Blodgett 2d of 66 East 79th Street, will be married in Cambridge, Mass., on Saturday to Sabin Head, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Maurice Head of Yale, Mich.
WASHINGTON, June 7--A serious fight appeared to be developing today within the International Brotherhood of Teamsters over James R. Hoffa's plan to pick a successor if he goes to jail.
TORONTO, June 7 (AP) The general assembly of the Presbyterian Church in Canada voted today to allow women to be ordained into the full ministry of the church. The vote was 133 to 72.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 7 (AP) Garuda International Airlines, Indonesia's airline, will suspend flights to Paris and Frankfurt, Germany, beginning June 17.
STELLENBOSCH, South Africa, June 7 (UPI)--Senator Robert F. Kennedy, Democract of New York, said today he was shocked and saddened by the Meredith shooting.
