The Burroughs Corporation announced yesterday plans to market a new medium-to-largescale electronic data processing system called the B6500.
The Edward R. Lewis Company has appointed Harold K. Wolfson as vice president to head its brokerage division for motels, retirement hotels and nursing homes.
ALBANY, June 7 Citing drastic increases in motorcycle accidents, the State Commissioner of Motor Vehicles called on the Legislature today to enact a series of safety laws.
BASEL, Switzerland, June 7 Jean Arp, the French abstract sculptor and painter and one of the founders of the Dada movement in art, died of a heart attack here today. He was 78 years old.

Continental Shopping Centers, an investment syndicate formed by Zilkha Sons, Inc., of New York City, has purchased two regional shopping centers from the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance for $15-million.
Tax-exempt bond yields continued to rise yesterday, and corporations continued to disclose plans to make big bond sales.
PATTEN, Me., June 7 The accepted and standard method of hunting black bear here at this time of year is by baiting, a procedure that, at first glance, may strike some as not quite sporting.
PIERRE, S.D., June 7 (UPI) Senator Karl E. Mundt easily defeated Richard Murphy, a former member of the John Birch Society, in the South Dakota Republican primary election today.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 7 Ronald Reagan won the Republican nomination for the governorship of California today by rolling to an easy victory over George Christopher, a former Mayor of San Francisco, and three other rivals in the state's primary election.

HONG KONG, June 7 (Reuters)--Bertrand Russell, the British philosopher, has told the Vietnamese people that he is preparing a war crimes tribunal to try President Johnson and other United States leaders for "brutal treatment of the people of Vietnam for 12 years."

The American Tobacco Company has elected as a director W. Elliot Brownlee, chief executive office of Sunshine Biscuits, Inc., which was acquired by the tobacco company May 31. This brings the board membership to 17, it was announced yesterday by Robert B. Walker, president and chairman of American Tobacco.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 7 Miss Diana Lynn Krainin, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Krainin of Bedford, N.Y., was married this afternoon to Stephen Arthur Goldberg. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel Goldberg of Washington.

ALBANY, June 7 Signaling their failure to reach a compromise on legislation to discourage strikes by Government employes, the Republican Senate and the Democratic Assembly rammed through conflicting bills tonight.
WASHINGTON, June 7 (UPI) A Senate Agriculture subcommittee, rejecting Administration opposition, modified and approved today a bill to make permanent the Federal school milk subsidy program.
ROME, June 7--Pope Paul VI will receive at the end of the month the report on an exhaustive study of the birth-control issue from his three-year-old commission of secular and clerical experts.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 7 (UPI) Alabama's Attorney General Richmond M. Flowers said today the ambush shooting of James H. Meredith yesterday was "barbaric" and declared: "Discrimination has got to stop."
WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) A Senate-passed bill authorizing preservation of the Indiana dunes area as a national lakeshore won House subcommittee approval today with extensive amendments.

RYE, N.Y., June 7 John W. Roberts of Honolulu weathered a brief, but fierce midafternoon downpour to take a one-stroke lead today after the opening round of the United States Senior Golf Association championship.
WASHINGTON, June 7 The United States has decided to send emergency food assistance to areas of Yemen controlled by the republican Government and those controlled by the Government's royalist foes.
ALBANY, June 7--Governor Rockefelller announced today that some Blue Cross-Blue Shield rates would be reduced soon as a result of Federal and state medical assistance programs.

Robert Moses, still looking deep into the future, disclosed plans yesterday for a 1,640-car garage adjacent to the East Side Airlines terminal, First Avenue and 39th Street, and expansion of Fordham University over the New York Central Railroad freight yard west of Lincoln Center.

Roy Wilkins, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, called on the organization's local branches throughout the country yesterday to hold rallies and marches this Sunday to protest the shooting of James H. Meredith and to observe the third anniversary of the assassination of Medgar Evers.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 7 The Rev. John C. Bennett, president of the Union Theological Seminary in New York City, warned Christians today against too much involvement with the secular world. Dr. Bennett spoke on "The Church and the Secular" at the commencement exercises of Princeton Theological Seminary today.
WASHINGTON, June 7 A nationwide strike against Western Union was called tonight by the Commercial Telegraphers Union as negotiations broke off just before midnight.
DETROIT, June 7 Robert B. Evans, newly appointed board chairman of the American Motors Corporation, promised today "a different philosophy and approach" in the company's affairs.

The Paramount Pictures Corporation was cast in the biggest dramatic role of its career last year in the battle for control of the company. This year, it is starred in a mystery with a new supporting actor Gulf Western Industries, Inc.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, June 7 (AP) President Joseph D. Mobutu today canceled concessions held by oil, mining and forestry companies in the Congo in a move to bring the country's resources under governmental control.
Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, president of City College, has called on Congress to "inquire into the advisability of revising the Selective Service Act."
An explosion and fire in an underground power transformer on Madison Avenue near 48th Street yesterday shut off all the current in two office buildings at 400 Madison Avenue and 18 East 48th Street.

HOUSTON, June 7 (AP) Sonny Jackson, Dave Nicholson and John Bateman got three hits apiece tonight to lift the Houston Astros to a 10-9 victory over the Giants. The loss was the fourth in their last five games for the Giants.
DARIEN, Conn., June 7 Billy Farrell and Bob Watson shared the lead at 142 today in the Metropolitan District's qualifying tests for the United States Open golf championship.

OTTAWA, June 7 (AP) A Canadian Longshoremen's strike has held up wheat shipments to the Soviet Union and is seriously damaging the grain export trade, W.C. McNamara, chairman of the Canadian Wheat Board, said today.

Robert Moses, still looking deep into the future, disclosed plans yesterday for a 1,640-car garage adjacent to the East Side Airlines terminal, First Avenue and 39th Street, and expansion of Fordham University over the New York Central Railroad freight yard west of Lincoln Center.

Roy Wilkins, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, called on the organization's local branches throughout the country yesterday to hold rallies and marches this Sunday to protest the shooting of James H. Meredith and to observe the third anniversary of the assassination of Medgar Evers.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 7 The Rev. John C. Bennett, president of the Union Theological Seminary in New York City, warned Christians today against too much involvement with the secular world. Dr. Bennett spoke on "The Church and the Secular" at the commencement exercises of Princeton Theological Seminary today.
The Celanese Corporation of America announced yesterday that it would enter the expanding market for nylon plastics, a material with many applications.

MALCOLM BROWN arrived in New York with two suitcases and a welding torch. When he returned to Arroyo Seco, N.M., carrying the same equipment two months later, Manhattan was richer by a one-ton fireplace sculpture.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 7 (UPI) Jim Kaat stopped the Kansas City Athletics on eight hits and contributed a bases-loaded single in the fourth inning tonight to pace the Minnesota Twins to a 6-1 victory.
WASHINGTON, June 7 Republicans and friends dined and danced tonight to replenish the party's Congressional campaign fund. For the privilege they paid, all told, about $300,000.

WASHINGTON, June 7 The shooting of James H. Meredith on a Mississippi highway stirred angry reaction among Washington officials today and increased the pressure for enactment of the Administration's civil rights bill.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 111.4 on Monday from 111.8 on Friday.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, June 7 The Ceylon Government decided today not to devalue the Ceylon rupee, which is pegged at 4.76 to the American dollar.

The slowdown in the pace of business activity experienced in the current quarter has lessened the threat of a serious inflationary wage-price spiral. But the threat has not been eliminated. In fact, economists say that inflation is already here.
Mr. and Mrs. William L. Shirer of 27 Beekman Place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Shirer, to Noel Rae, son of Mrs. Alexander Rae of London and the late Mr. Rae.
A three-man committee was named yesterday to coordinate the operations of the Police Department with the police forces of the Transit and Housing Authorities.
The Household Finance Corporation is negotiating to acquire White Stores, Inc., of Wichita Falls, Tex., it was made known yesterday in Chicago.
WASHINGTON, June 7 (UPI) The Administration asked Congress today for authority to pay servicemen overseas up to 10 per cent interest on the savings they deposit with the Government.
VERSAILLES, Ky., June 7 (UPI) A.B. (Happy) Chandler announced that he would begin a campaign for the Democratic nomination for Governor immediately after the November election for Senate this year.

A CATCH-ALL review of the American image abroad was unreeled last night over the television network of the Columbia Broadcasting System. The hourlong film touched on what could have been several absorbing stories on the overseas influence of the United States. But in trying to compress a global issue into a handy TV package the presentation ended up saying nothing, whatsoever.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., June 7 (AP) Coaches completed the selection today of the eightmember free-style wrestling team that will represent the United States in the world amateur wrestling championships June 16 through 22 at Toledo, Ohio.
The towering public housing projects that forest the ghettos and are seen by some poor people as symbols of second-class citizenship will no longer be built by the city.
The American Stock Exchange continued to retreat yesterday as trading activity increased slightly.

WASHINGTON, June 7 The Maritime Administration reported today that three groups of subsidized American ship lines, consisting of eight companies, had proposed to coordinate their building programs by building new tonnage en bloc and from a standardized design.
WASHINGTON, June 7 President Johnson today defended the right to dissent, but also urged that those who do so know why they protest.
NEW DELHI, June 7 A Finance Ministry spokesman said today that the Government was taking urgent measures to check a rise in prices of several consumer goods following devaluation of the Indian rupee.

HOBART, N.Y., June 7 Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Gould have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nola Andrews Gould, to Richard H. Miller, son of Mrs. Harry J. Miller of Buffalo and the late Mr. Miller. An August wedding is planned.
Stocks declined again yesterday as light selling pressure continued to prevail.
Salvador Dali, the surrealist painter, was ordered yesterday in Supreme Court to pay $71,724 for failing to keep a promise to paint a picture of the Statue of Liberty on a television program.
A controversial plan to reroute the Number 5 bus from Riverside Drive in the evenings will be considered by the Board of Estimate today.

A seldom-invoked provision of state law has raised a question as to the validity of the appointment of a dozen or so persons to policy-making jobs in the Lindsay administration. Those appointed lived elsewhere than New York at the time they were selected.

JACKSON, Miss., June 7 Candidates of the Mississippi Freedom Democratic party were defeated today in primary elections in which Mississippi Negroes voted in sizable numbers for the first time since Reconstruction days.
A girl who scored A in every subject during four years of undergraduate study was graduated summa cum laude yesterday at Long Island University's Brooklyn Center.
The American Stock Exchange continued to retreat yesterday as trading activity increased slightly.

WASHINGTON, June 7 The Maritime Administration reported today that three groups of subsidized American ship lines, consisting of eight companies, had proposed to coordinate their building programs by building new tonnage en bloc and from a standardized design.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 8 Senator Robert F. Kennedy described Chief Albert Luthuli today as "one of the most impressive men I have met in my travels around the world" after a quiet call on the Nobel Peace Prize winner whose activities have been restricted by the South African Government.

MOSCOW, June 8 (AP) The Soviet Union has taken a step toward making the ruble a world currency by giving in to pressure from its East European trading partners. In the past, trade has been conducted in Communist East Europe in rubles that had only regional value. They were not backed by gold and therefore were not freely convertible into other currencies for worldwide use.

OTTAWA, June 8--An important Federal-provincial conference to discuss tax sharing, federal aid to education and other questions has been postponed, partly because of the prospect of a "hard-line" government in Quebec.
COLDWATER, Miss., June 8 Five civil rights organizations patched up their differences today over what they hoped to accomplish by continuing James H. Meredith's march into Mississippi.

PARIS, June 8--The judicial investigation of the Ben Barka kidnaping case was officially closed today and trials were ordered for 13 persons. Seven of the 13 will be tried in absentia, including Gen. Mohammed Oufkir, the Moroccan Interior Minister, who the French say organized the affair.
Dr. Louis W. Scalettar, a dentist at the Brownsville Center, 259 Bristol Street, Brooklyn, died Tuesday of a heart attack in his home at 415 Argyle Road, Brooklyn. He was 67 years old.
CHICAGO, June 8 A proposed increase in St. Lawrence Seaway freight tolls was supported today by spokesmen for Eastern ports and opposed by Midwestern shipping interests.
BONN, Germany, June 8 Two West German bank clerks accused of having stolen $300,000 from their bank are back in Germany from South America and awaiting trial.
BRUSSELS, June 8 The foreign ministers of the 15 North Atlantic Treaty nations narrowly avoided today a final break between France and the other members of the alliance.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) The Warsaw Pact, the East European defense alliance, is suffering from strains of nationalism that may further reduce Soviet authority over its allies, a Senate subcommittee said tonight. The alliance is "in a state of flux and ferment," the report asserted.

GRAND BLANC, Mich., June 8 Sam Snead's failure yesterday to qualify for the United States Open championship brought an appeal from Arnold Palmer today. The game's leading money winner said some formula should be devised to get Snead into the tournament that begins June 16 at the Olympic Country Club course in San Francisco.

Prices of copper futures rose to new highs yesterday on the New York Commodity Exchange following news that Zambia copper mining companies had suspended shipments by rail through Rhodesia to Moz ambique. The companies involved were the Roan Selection Trust and the Anglo-American Corporation.

ALBANY, June 8--A City University aid bill was introduced in the Legislature today, with provisions that would guarantee the admission next fall of 2,278 qualified students who had been barred for lack of facilities.

MENDHAM, N.J. Forgetting to pack the mus tard for a picnic or camping trip need not be a catastrophe the yellow flower head of the wild mustard plant tucked into a sandwich or placed atop a frankfurter is an excellent substitute. No need for soggy lettuce in sandwiches either, as long as oval-shaped plantain leaves are near the picnic site to add a distinctive flavor and crunchy texture.
The Internal Revenue Service recently issued a ruling that further reduced the income-tax advantage to employes of "split-dollar" life insurance plans, which the agency long ...
The outsider in the field of eight, Norman Bates' Triple Brook, raced in front all the way to win the $27,900 Liberty Belle Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 8 President Johnson foresaw today a world in which routine factory and clerical jobs would be performed by machines, and he told the younger generation that it would have to "think seriously about the proper function of human beings, when our old ideas of work are no longer useful."

GENEVA, June 8 Rudolph Faupl of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations has been nominated for re-election to the International Labor Organization's executive committee, despite his boycott of the current session of the United Nations agency.

TUSCALOOSA, Ala., June 8 (AP) Joe Namath, the New York Jets' quarterback who was the subject of a fierce bidding war when he graduated from the University of Alabama in 1965, said he was surprised by the merger.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., June 8--Hurricane Alma struck St. Petersburg tonight with slashing rains and winds gusting to 93 miles an hour.

The St. Regis Paper Company is entering the newsprint business through its acquisition yesterday of a 28 per cent interest in the Southland Paper Mills, Inc. The transaction involves nearly $25-million, based on the present market value of Southland stock.
Leon Kipnis, a certified public accountant and a lawyer, died yesterday in his home at 20 West 77th Street. He was 78 years old.
WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) Edward B. Carney, property custodian of the House of Representatives, died Monday. He was 60 years old.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 8 The Federal Government and the nation's investor-owned utilities appear to have embarked on an era of mutual cooperation, it was indicated here today.

"Forget about image," Jack J. Valenti, the new president of the Motion Picture Association of America said here yesterday. "Image is an illusive word. DuPont's greatest public relations instrument is nylon. What we've got to do is make excellent movies."
SEVERAL picaresque lifetimes seem to crowd John Gale's searchingly candid memoir. At the age of 40 he looks back on a rather full part in our thunderous era.
Macy's has the first Fiberglas tablecloths, made by Timely Linens of OwensCorning Fiberglas Corporation's Beta glass thread.

ROSTOV-ON-DON, U.S.S.R. June 7 Mikhail Sholokhov, the Cossack novelist who has been an unchallenged candidate in elections to the Supreme Soviet (Parliament) since 1937, has met with his constituents in this Don River city to deliver a confident campaign speech.

ATLANTA, June 8 (AP) Mayor Ivan Allen Jr. warned the city's striking firemen tonight that he would ask a court to begin contempt proceedings tomorrow unless more than 500 who walked out in a dispute over wages and hours returned to their stations.

A three-judge Federal court in Florida, which in May, 1965, stopped a merger of the Atlantic Coast Line and the Seaboard Air Line Railroads, ruled yesterday that the two wealthy carriers could go ahead.

WARSAW, June 8 Polish authorities called on the Roman Catholic clergy today to withdraw their allegiance from Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski and follow churchmen who stood for coexistence between Communism and Catholicism.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 7 Does the "Sihanouk Trail" exist?

Retirement benefits for two former city officials, and one who will leave office on July 1, are scheduled to be approved tomorrow by the Board of Estimate. Their length of public service totals 92 years.

Morris Feinberg, a retired Cloakmakers' Union official, died yesterday in St. Joseph's Hospital, Far Rockaway, Queens. He was 80 years old and lived with a daughter, Mrs. Lillian Gulker, at 440 Neptune Avenue, Brooklyn.
Prices of lumber and plywood have dropped sharply on the West Coast in the wake of a labor settlement that has averted a strike, it was reported yesterday.

A merger between the Rexall Drug and Chemical Company and the Thatcher Glass Manufacturing Company, first proposed in 1964 was approved yesterday by stockholders of both companies. Rexall holders met in Los Angeles and Thatcher shareowners convened here.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 8 Max Loewenstein, industrialist and art patron, and his wife, Lili, residents of Sao Paulo, were found dead Monday in their vacation home on the beach in Guaruja. The police said a bottle of barbiturates was nearby.

Professional football's heated money war has ended. The 47year-old National Football League and seven-year-old American Football League announced yesterday plans to merge into a single league of at least 26 teams in 25 cities.

TRENTON, June 8 In a dramatic reversal late today, the Assembly bowed to intense pressure by Gov. Richard J. Hughes and approved a bill requiring every suspected drunken driver to take a drunkometer test or face the automatic loss of a driver's license.
The Park Association of New York City presented its annual award yesterday to George T. Delacorte Jr., for his efforts in preserving and beautifying Central Park.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 8 Indonesia's highest-ranking leaders failed tonight to approve the peace proposals agreed upon last week between Indonesia and Malaysia.

PATTEN, Me., June 8 when the bear hunting season opened the other day, all 23 hunters here were firmly convinced from the evidence that each and every one would drop a bear of considerable ferocity and size. A large percentage of the baits were being visited regularly by bears and each hunter knew he was going to yell "bingo" by day's end.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 8 Thich Tri Quang, the militant Buddhist leader, began a hunger strike in Hue today to protest President Johnson's support of continued military rule and he accused the President of attempting to impose a colonial system on South Vietnam.
Three secondary offerings of common stock were marketed yesterday and all met good receptions.
Bentley Kassal, state chairman of Americans for Democratic Action, announced yesterday his personal support for City Council President Frank D. O'Connor for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

LOS ANGELES, June 8 Army friends recall him devouring and then spewing forth in complete detail articles from the Reader's Digest. Colleagues in the Screen Actors Guild kiddingly refer to him as "the boy on the burning deck." so fond was he of declaiming at their meetings.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 8 President Rene Schick Gutierrez of Nicaragua said today that he would allow his country's territory to be used again as a base for an invasion of Premier Fidel Castro's Cuba "at any time, in any circumstances."

LOS ANGELES, June 8 Ronald Reagan's sweeping victory in the California gubernatorial primary has given the national Republican party its sharpest tug to the right in two years and placed continued Democratic control of the state in clear jeopardy.

TOKYO, June 8 (UPI) Communist China declared today it would never permit United Nations "meddling" in Vietnam and would not accept the results of any elections in South Vietnam while United States troops were there.
MOSCOW, June 8 (UPI) Two Russian Orthodox priests who accused the Soviet Government of suppressing religion have been suspended from the priesthood, a high Church official said today.
LONDON, June 8 Sterling came under pressure again this morning in the London foreignexchange market, but improved in the afternoon and closed with a net gain on the day of 4 points at $2.7890.

COLORADO SPRINGS, June 8 Only those cadets who learn that "education is a neverending process of integrating continually changing factual information, understanding its meaning and applying it purposefully" are prepared for the world that lies ahead of them, Air Force Secretary Harold Brown told 469 graduating cadets of the Air Force Academy today.

THE "Peanuts" gang of the Charles Schulz comic strip made an appearance last night in a cartoon account of Charlie Brown's misfortunes in trying to put together a successful baseball team. The intrepid leader was downed again, but not before winning appreciation for his loyalty to the girls and the dog on his erratic nine.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 8 The United States armed forces got 853 new officers today as graduation exercises were held at the Naval Academy here.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 8 Vice President Humphrey pledged today that the United States would continue to try to widen its contacts with Communist China despite the "denunciation and hostility" provoked by such efforts.
DETROIT, June 8 (AP) Reliever Don McMahon walked Don Wert with the bases filled in the 11th inning tonight, enabling the Detroit Tigers to defeat the Boston Red Sox, 5-4.
WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) Princess Cantacuzene awoke. Suddenly, she saw the canopy on her bed. She sat up, unbelieving, and reached out to touch the fabric.

ORANGE, N.J., June 8 Dr. Matthew Chalmers Pearce, a retired exodontist and a former All-America basketball player, died Monday at Redwood Nursing Home, West Orange. He was 75 years old and lived at 82 High Street here.

Directors of North American Sugar Industries, Inc., voted here yesterday to reduce the quarterly dividend to 10 cents a common share from 15 cents in previous quarters. The new dividend is payable July 1 to holders of record June 20.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., June 8 (UPI)--Edward G. Robinson, 72-year-old actor who played gangsters in a score of Hollywood movies, suffered head, chest and abdominal injuries today when he lost control of his car and it hit a tree, the police reported.
BANGKOK, Thailand, June 8 Deputy Premier Prahas Charusathien has urged the Thais to go slow on a plan to put 20,000 United States servicemen here under Thai justice.
MEXICO CITY, June 3 A journey through the Mexican provinces consists mainly of a visit to the country's peasantry. Mexico remains predominantly rural despite the striking growth of industry.

Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Schrank of 500 East 77th Street have announced the engagement at their daughter, Miss Andrea Heather Schrank, to Harvey Neil Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph A. Brown of Woodbury, L.I.

France's agreement with its fourteen NATO partners to start negotiations next week on the retention of French forces in Germany an agreement reached with difficulty moves the alliance forward on its most critical problem.

WASHINGTON, June 8 The Senate Foreign Relations Committee responded to Administration pressure today and substantially modified a series of restrictions voted earlier in the $3.4-billion foreign aid authorization.

PURCHASE, N.Y., June 8 "What you want to do," a president told a vice president on the first tee today at the Century Country Club, "is swing easy real easy, almost slow motion. Don't try to kill it."

CLEVELAND, June 8 Sam McDowell returned to the baseball wars tonight and overpowered the New York Yankees in one critical inning of relief pitching as the Cleveland Indians squeezed out a 2-1 victory.

BALTIMORE, June 8 (AP) Arnold (Red) Auerbach, who retired as coach of the Boston Celtics after his club won its seventh straight championship last season, will return to coach the East team in the National Basketball Association's AllStar game.

LOS ANGELES, June 8 Ronald Reagan, the 55-year-old actor who would be Governor, was piling up a formidable bid for victory in November as the tallying of California's primary ballots neared completion tonight.

ANAHEIM, Calif., June 8 (AP) The California Angels snapped Jack Lamabe's scoreless inning streak at 25 tonight with a run in the seventh and defeated the Chicago White Sox, 1-0, behind the two-hit pitching of George Brunet.

PHILADELPHIA, June 8--Cardigan Bay's match race with Bret Hanover, scheduled for Saturday night at Liberty Bell Park here, was canceled today because of an injury to the 10-year-old New Zealand pacer's left front leg.
DACCA, Pakistan, June 8 (Reuters) The police patrolled the streets of Dacca today as this provincial capital recovered from the effects of a violent general strike yesterday.

Americans have rejected the dual standard that provides excellent medical care for persons who can afford it, but less adequate care for those who cannot, Dr. James M. Hester, president of New York University, said yesterday.

Edward J. Logue, who has been studying the city's housing and redevelopment programs for more than four months, is expected to recommend the abolition of the City Planning Commission and the Department of City Planning as independent agencies.
The National Broadcasting Company is expected to televise Shakespeare's "Othello" next season as a two-hour program starring Sidney Poltier.

WASHINGTON, June 8 "It would be distressing," said Attorney General Katzenbach on a television program today, "if Congress and the American people needed another shooting to get another needed civil rights bill." It would be equally distressing if the vicious crime in Mississippi, to which he referred, should foreclose due consideration by Congress and the American people of the serious questions of constitutional and individual rights raised by this pending bill.

The 24th and final game of the title match between the world chess champion, Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, and his compatriot, Boris Spassky, was adjourned last night at Moscow's Variety Theater after Petrosian sealed his 41st move.

The City Commission on Human Rights will hold extensive hearings this summer into hiring and union-membership practices in the construction industry, Commission Chairman William H. Booth disclosed yesterday.

CAIRO, June 8 Western oil interests here have been dealt important setbacks in recent months by what Western diplomatic circles regard as political pressures from pro-Moscow elements within the Nasser regime.

A DEAD heat for top honors in match points was shared by the First National City and Chase Manhattan banks in the recent Bankers Athletic League tournament. The front-runners scored 9 -2 each, but First National, with game points of 40 19 against Chase Manhattan's 37 22 , got the final nod.
"Yankee Come Home," the first play written by Woody Allen, 30-year-old monologist scenarist and television writer, will be introduced here in October.

CHICAGO, June 8 (AP) Randy Hundley, the Cubs' rookie catcher, hit his first majorleague grand-slam home run in the fourth inning today to pin a sixth defeat on the Los Angeles Dodger pitching ace, Don Drydale, and lead Chicago to an 8-1 victory.

OLD SAYBROOK, Conn., June 8 St. Mary's-by-the-Sea in Fenwick was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Cynthia Escher, daughter of Mrs. John Gleason Escher of Fenwick and the late Mr. Escher, to DeWitte Rickels Hendon, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Estel Hendon of Wichita Falls, Tex.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 8 The enemy's death toll was raised to 191 as heavy fighting with American paratroopers continued today in the central highlands 195 miles northeast of Saigon.

Francis W.H. Adams, the former Police Commissioner who has long been active in the Democratic Reform movement, charged yesterday that Senator Robert F. Kennedy was "no more interested in reform of the Democratic party than was William Marcy Tweed."

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) A Federal Trade Commission examiner recommended today dismissal of a complaint charging false claims and attempts to mislead the public in the sale of the book "Calories Don't Count."
TOPEKA, Kan., June 8 A tornado sliced through Topeka tonight, including the business district. Hospital authorities reported at least 10 persons had died in its wake.

The Greater New York Fund is now seeking to raise $73 million for its 425 affiliated voluntary hospital, health and welfare agencies. This is the twentyeighth annual citywide campaign of the Fund, which includes among its beneficiaries the Catholic, Jewish and Protestant federations and the United Hospital Fund with its 69 member hospitals.
Mayor Lindsay advised 32 new graduates of the Collegiate School yesterday to follow whatever roads they chose "with determination, some guts and some style."
SANTA BARBARA, Calif., June 8 A court order requiring a young mother on welfare to undergo sterilization or go to jail was reversed here today.
A hope that furs may be coming back as an American status symbol is spreading through New York's steamy and crowded fur market.

The Texas Gulf Sulphur Company's copper discovery near Timmins, Ont., was an "open secret" before the discovery was publicly announced, according to Stuart Rafkind, a floor trader on the New York Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, June 8 William McChesney Martin Jr., the Federal Reserve Board chairman, supported today a "direct injection of funds into the mortgage market" to ease the shortage of funds for homebuilding loans.

CHICAGO, June 8 (UPI)--Arthur Morse, a lawyer who has represented several National Football League players, said today any merger or common draft by the two pro football leagues would violate United States antitrust laws.

THE prices came from another day and age. The food came from all the lands that have contributed to the collection of nationalities on New York's Upper West Side. And the appetites (550 of them) came from all directions the other evening to Public School 9 at 84th Street and Columbus Avenue.

A collection of 11,000 78 r.p.m. records has been donated by radio station WQXR to the Library and Museum of the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center. They will be housed in the Rodgers and Hammerstein Archives of Recorded Sound.
Yesterday might well have been called account day, on account so many were moving.
PARIS, June 8 Four of France's leading private banking houses commanding resources approaching $2-billion announced agreement today on a close affiliation.

A catalogue of commencement themes that included the terms "nostalgiabration," "antinostalgiabration" and "nostra culpa" was outlined yesterday at Fordham University's graduation ceremonies in an address by the Rev. Vincent T. O'Keefe, a former president of Fordham.

Withdrawals increased faster than new deposits at New York State's 126 mutual savings banks in May, causing a sharp reduction in the net increase in funds available for mortgage lending and other investment.

YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N.Y., June 8 Mr. and Mrs. Henry R. Gunther of Yorktown Heights and Dennisport, Mass. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathleen Mary Ann Gunther, to Cadet Michael Chenoweth Wimert, son of Col. Paul M. Wimert Jr. U.S.A., military attache at the United States Embassay in Santiago, Chile, and Mrs. Wimert of Santiago and Westminster, Md.

ACCRA, Ghana, June 8 (UPI)--Ghana's military Government announced tonight that work had been abandoned on the Soviet-financed $90-million hydroelectric dam project on the Black Volta River because it was "unfeasible."

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 8 Miss Cynthia Frances Yenkin, daughter of Fred Yenkin and the late Mrs. Lillian Levin Yenkin, was married this afternoon to Sanford Victor Levinson, son of Mrs. Meyer Levinson of Hendersonville, N.C., and the late Mr. Levinson.
LONDON, June 8 A compromise report aimed at settling the 24-day maritime stop page was rejected today by Britain's striking merchant seamen.
The nation's electric power production rose 7.1 per cent in the week ended June 4, from the level in the corresponding 1965 week, it was reported by the Edison Electric Institute yesterday.
A second housing sponsor refused yesterday to waive immunity to testify before a grand fury investigating the administration of Mitchell-Lama housing projects in the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, June 8 The Senate Commerce Committee moved today toward approval of a stiffened version of the Administration's auto safety bill.

An increase of 743,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend, total supplies were 207,060,000 barrels, compared with 206,317,000 a week earlier and 210,879,000 a year ago.
A man in a tricorne, generally mistaken for Paul Revere, rode a reddish-brown horse with white hoofs through the narrow streets of the downtown financial district yesterday.

Met with Democratic Congressional leaders; met with high school students visiting here under sponsorship of the National Rural Electric Cooperative Association; saw Preston Moore, Democratic nominee for governor of Oklahoma; saw Angier Biddle Duke, U.S. Ambassador to Spain.

Seven churches and two other buildings in Harlem are among 30 structures in upper Manhattan that will be considered for designation as landmarks next Tuesday at a public hearing before the Landmarks Preservation Commission at City Hall.

LIKE all wars, this one was wasteful and costly. As it mounted in intensity in recent weeks, it began to look as if it eventually would reach a dismal end, with no winners and an awful lot of losers. So the National Football League finally bowed to the inevitable yesterday and agreed to make peace with the American Football League, a group it had tried to ignore as a pretentious upstart.
Henry J. Gucker Jr., former owner of a tenement at 328 East 15th Street, was fined $300 yesterday for 31 building violations in it.
The election of Samuel S. Greeley to the new post of executive vice president was announced yesterday in Chicago by the Masonite Corporation, manufacturer of hardboard.

Mr. and Mrs. Stephane Groueff of New York have announced the marriage of Mrs. Groueff's daughter, Miss Tina Marguerite Isles, to John Joseph Barnet, son of Mrs. Harold B. Barney of Watch Hill, R.I., and the late Mr. Barney.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., June 8 Mr. and Mrs. Claiborn McDowell Carr Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Sandra Carr, to Thomas Grant 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Grant Jr. of Charlotte, N. C.

COLORADO long has been known for its gold and silver. The Central City district alone once produced $85-million in gold. And when President Grant stepped from his stagecoach at the Teller House in Central City, a walk of silver bullion had been laid for him.
RYE, N.Y., June 8 George Haggarty, a white-haired corporation lawyer from Detroit, rallied from five strokes off the pace today to capture the 62d United States Seniors Golf Association championship.
Petrea Hoving built herself a hideaway yesterday in the Tavern on the Green in Central Park and did what any sensible 8-year-old would have done at a champagne breakfast. She disappeared.
CHICAGO, June 8 (AP) A list of civil rights demands, including $2-an-hour minimum wage, was made public by aides of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. today.

IF a poll were taken to establish a ranking of the 30 best bridge players in New York, the list would no doubt correspond very closely to the experts who will assemble next Monday evening for a special event at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
WASHINGTON, June 8 (UPI) Demanding a break for the nation's housewives, Administration forces in the Senate defeated an attempt today to seriously weaken the "truth-inpackaging" bill.

The architect for the on-again off-again Franklin Delano Roosevelt memorial planned for the nation's capital will be Marcel Breuer, it was announced by the Franklin Delano Roosevelt Memorial Commission in Washington yesterday.
Emily Marx, a lawyer with an office at 27 William Street, died Tuesday in St. Clare's Hospital after an illness. She was 63 years old and lived at 4621 Waldo Avenue, Riverdale, the Bronx.
BRUSSELS, June 8 The European Economic Community, or Common Market, said today attempts to maintain price stability in 1965 in the six member countries "can not be qualified as satisfactory."
The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation announced here yesterday the election of Theodore S. Gary to the new post of vice chairman.

Prices on the London stock market were firm yesterday, with investors encouraged by overoptimistic hopes for an early end to the seamen's strike. After the close of trading, it was reported that the seamen's union had rejected a compromise plan to end the 24-day maritime stoppage.

KARACHI, Pakistan, June 8--Rumors that Pakistan's Foreign Minister, Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, is to be named as Ambassador to the Soviet Union are just that--and no more--according to information available here.

DETROIT, June 8 (UPI) The Chevrolet Motor division of the General Motors Corporation, which last month dropped behind Ford in sales for the first time in seven years, will shut down three of its 13 assembly plants a month ahead of time to retool.

JEAN DALRYMPLE, director of the New York City Center Light Opera Company, hasn't been around the theater all these years without learning that one must build to the boff climax. This may be a final line that suddenly and unexpectedly illuminates a comedy routine, or even a production, such as "Guys and Dolls," which brings to a close the City Center's four-show Frank Loesser retrospective.

The decision that 1970 would be the date for the two professional football leagues to merge into a single league schedule obviously was dictated by current television contracts. The American Football League has a contract with the National Broadcasting Company that runs through 1969. For the next two seasons, National Football League games are committed to the Columbia Broadcasting System and C.B.S. also holds an option for 1968.
HOUSTON, June 8 (UPI) The Houston Astros staged a four-run sixth inning against Juan Marichal tonight and went on to whip the San Francisco Giants, 6-1, behind Mike Cuellar's six-hitter.

BECKENHAM, England, June 8 (AP) Marty Riessen of Evanston, Ill., tuning up for the Wimbledon championship, was ousted from the Kent grasscourt tournament today. He lost, 7-5, 8-6, to John Newcombe of Australia, who has won the title the last two years.
The American Machine and Foundry Company and the Borg-Warner Corporation each have announced the election of new officers in their Australian affiliates.
WASHINGTON, June 8 The House voted today to raise the national debt limit from $328billion to $330-billion, $2-billion short of the ceiling sought by President Johnson. The vote was 199 to 165.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., June 8 (AP) Two Greco-Roman wrestlers nailed down the final spots on the United States team today by winning the final training matches.

LONDON, June 8 "Qui vient?" calls a minor character early in the first act of Donizetti's "La Fille du Regiment." At that point a roar of laughter went around Covent Garden this evening. The first-night audience knew who was coming: Joan Sutherland in her first major comic role.
WASHINGTON, June 8 President Johnson was described today as "very satisfied with the outcome of yesterday's primaries.
METUCHEN, N.J., June 8 (AP) Theodore B. Hunt, a former professor of English at Lafayette College, died yesterday in the Cranford Hall Nursing Home. He was 69 years old.

A new device curtailed false alarms so sharply in Brooklyn during a one-month experiment that Fire Commissioner Robert O. Lowery announced yesterday that he intended to have the gadget installed on many of the city's 14,000 fire boxes.
WASHINGTON, June 8 (UPI) Negotiations were deadlocked today in a Western Union strike that left New York the only city in the country with telegraph service.
NEW LONDON, Conn., June 8 The first Negro to be graduated from the Coast Guard Academy received his ensign's commission here today from his father, a colonel in the Regular Army.
The spot rate on the British pound improved yesterday after a weak opening in heavy trading on foreign-exchange merkets here.
MONTREAL, June 8 (Canadian Press) The announced merger of the two American football leagues brought mixed comments tonight from spokesmen of the Canadian Football League.
The Radio Corporation of America announced here yesterday a change in the title of Dr. Carroll V. Newsom to vice president in charge of education from educational consultant.
HAMILTON, N.Y., June 8 (AP) Florida State continued to dominate the annual Eastern Intercollegiate tennis tournament today by placing two players in the semi-finals.
PAULINE TRIGERE, a concealed microphone around her neck recording her comments on tape, advised her assistants where to place the jewels just before her fall show yesterday.
LONDON, June 8 John Osborne declared "open and frontal war" today on London's theater critics for having failed to grasp the merits of his new play, which opened here this week.

CARNOUSTIE, Scotland, June 8 (AP) Bill Hyndman of Philadelphia, a former Walker Cup player, sank a 30-foot putt on the last green today and joined four other Americans in the last 32 of the British amateur golf championship.
The general feeling among National Football League and American Football League owners was that yesterday's merger would strengthen the structure and standards of professional football.
WASHINGTON, June 8 Limits may have to be imposed on the amount of lead that auto exhausts spew into the atmosphere, a Public Health Service official said today.

EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., June 8 An XB70A research bomber and an F-104 chase plane flown by Joseph A. Walker, the X-15 test pilot, collided today over the Mojave Desert, killing Mr. Walker and the bomber's copilot.

WASHINGTON, June 8--The Tariff Commission reported to President Johnson today that it found no current collusive or unfair practices in the watch import field that would require restriction of imports under a special section of the tariff laws.
WASHINGTON, June 8--A considerably revised bill to preserve the wetlands along the South Shore of Long Island appeared on the way to ultimate Congressional approval today.

PHANRANG, South Vietnam, June 8 (AP) About 1,100 South Vietnamese construction workers defied Vietcong threats and voted today in an election that the South Vietnamese Government considers to be a test case for the feasibility of holding nationwide elections.

The merger of the two major professional football leagues in the United States that was announced yesterday was the second in which the National League had been the dominant party. In 1950 the senior league absorbed the All-America Conference, which operated from 1946 through 1949.
UNION, N.J., June 8 Dr. Karl Schumpelt of 1090 Overlook Terrace, chief metallurgist for the Sel-Rex Corporation, Summit, died Sunday at Overlook Hospital, Summit, at the age of 79.

California marketed yesterday $100-million of tax-exempt bonds that were offered publicly at yields higher than last week's, and by early evening the underwriters reported the big issue was 60 per cent sold.
"Believe it or not," the Capital Gains Research Bureau told its subscribers yesterday, "some of the big funds are buying the steels."
ALBANY, June 8 Governor Rockefeller, deluged with mail, has postponed action on a bill to increase state funds for supplying textbooks to students in private and parochial schools.
The 47-year-old National League and the seven-year-old American League, which have been bitter rivals, announced plans yesterday to merge into a single professional football league of 26 teams.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., June 8 Mr. and Mrs. Chester Bayard Hansen have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Randi Leigh Hansen, to David Carter Abercrombie, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abbott Abercrombie of Darien and Northport, Me.

WASHINGTON, June 8 The Senate gave the first broad Congressional approval today to President Johnson's sweeping plan to make Pennsylvania Avenue between the Capitol and the White House a "national boulevard."

The sustained tempo of the Police Department's latest drive against illegal parking in midtown is a refreshing indication or so we hope that this will be more than the usual "crackdown" that blows over like a summer storm.

Mrs. Stephanie Ehrlich Schwerin, a daughter of the late Dr. Paul Ehrlich, who developed a cure for syphilis, fell or jumped to her death on Tuesday from her 10th-floor apartment at 12 East 86th Street, the police reported yesterday.

Tennis different from anything previously on view in the Forest Hills Stadium was seen last night as the world's foremost professionals started play under faltering lights in a $30,500 round-robin tournament.

HUNTINGTON VALLEY, Pa., June 8 Mrs. Paul Klinefelter Jr. of the Philadelphia Cricket Club jumped into a three-stroke lead today after 36 holes had been completed in the 60th annual Women's Eastern golf championship.
The strike of 700 air-conditioning engineers against more than 100 large Manhattan office buildings went through its second day yesterday with no settlement in sight.

WASHINGTON, June 8 A Presidential emergency board recommended a major labor settlement based on broader factors than the productivity figures used for the Administration's guideposts, it was disclosed today.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., June 8 James H. Meredith left the cityowned William B. Bowld Hospital and flew home to New York today. His departure was almost as dramatic as his arrival.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (UPI) Senator Philip A. Hart, Democrat of Michigan, the chairman of the Senate anti-monopoly subcommittee, said he believed the merger of the professional football leagues conformed with objectives of the sports bill passed by the Senate last year. He said he hoped the House would approve the bill.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 8 Dick Siderowf continued his good play of recent weeks by taking the one-day 36-hole William Rice Hochster Memorial golf tournament today at the Quaker Ridge Golf Club.

Henry Aaron drove in six runs at Shea Stadium last night, and so did the New York Mets. So a home run by Mack Jones off Larry Bearnarth with two out in the seventh inning proved to be the margin of victory for the Atlanta Braves.

Governor Rockefeller brought the rift between himself and Mayor Lindsay into the open yesterday when he accused the Mayor of reneging on a deal that would have assured passage of a $407-million tax package for the city.

WASHINGTON, June 8 A maritime union leader told Congress today that the shipping policies of Robert S. McNamara, the Secretary of Defense, and Nicholas Johnson, the Maritime Administrator, were helping the Russians in their plans to dominate world shipping.
JERSEY CITY, June 8 Theodore A. Austin, now director of the Cambridge (Mass.) City Hospital, has been appointed director of the Jersey City Medical Center. He will be paid more than the Mayor.
MOSCOW, June 8 Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin held out hope today for a change in the United States' present Vietnam policy, which he said had turned into an "inevitable failure."

In the face of a deadlock with the pressmen, representatives of the World Journal Tribune, Inc., concentrated their efforts yesterday on negotiations aimed at achieving settlements with the Newspaper Guild, the mailers and the drivers.

WASHINGTON, June 8 There is a growing belief in Congress that a compromise must be reached on the open housing section of the Administration's civil rights bill if the measure is to be enacted this year.

California voters of both parties very nearly brought off a double disaster in Tuesday's primaries. The Republicans, against all counsels of common sense and political prudence, insisted upon nominating actor Ronald Reagan for Governor instead of his experienced opponent, former Mayor George Christopher of San Francisco.

Forty-two former first classmen, all members of yesterday's graduating classes at the three major service academies (Army, Navy and Air Force) made an orderly transition yesterday from military marches and brass bands to wedding marches and gold bands.

The bankruptcy of the State Legislature has never been more appallingly demonstrated than in its deadlock over a new law to ban civil service strikes. The Democratic Assembly and the Republican Senate have passed bills so incompatible that the state seems doomed to another year with no better shield against government strikes than the almost-useless CondonWadlin Act.

Francis C. Coppicus, former manager of Enrico Caruso, Feodor Chaliapin, Maria Jeritza and other famous opera stars, died yesterday morning at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Adolf Badner, in Mill Valley, Calif. He was 86 years old.
WASHINGTON, June 8 Bill and Marge are packing their drugcase for a long trip. Let's cavesdrop.

The Brown Shoe Company said yesterday that it believed it could continue to offer a lawful dealer-assistance plan, despite a Supreme Court decision on Monday that ruled its franchise system was illegal.

Jack I. Straus, founder of the Jesse Isidor Straus Awards to Cooperative Education students, will receive a resolution of appreciation from the city school system tomorrow at a ceremony in the Board of Education headquarters, 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn.
A two-day decline on the American Stock Exchange ended yesterday as the market managed to edge higher in quiet trading.

BALTIMORE, June 8 (UPI) Camilo Carreon's 14th-inning double gave the Baltimore Orioles a 6-5 victory tonight over the Washington Senators. A curfew halted play after five innings in the second game of the double-header with the Senators leading by 5-4.

The Jerrold Corporation reported yesterday in Philadelphia that its annual meeting had been postponed from June 28 to Sept. 19. The postponement came amid rumors that insiders were trying to buy control of the company, from Milton J. Shapp.

Sales of the United States Plywood Corporation exceeded the half-billion-dollar mark for the first time in its 47-yearhistory while earnings rose 15 per cent to a new nigh, Gene C. Brewer, president, reported yesterday.

More than 130 graduating students and faculty members walked out during New York University's commencement exercises yesterday in silent protest against an honorary degree for Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara.
Stock prices edged upward yesterday as trading activity continued near the lowest levels of the year.

WASHINGTON, June 8 "Next steps in China policy" was the announced subject of Vice President Humphrey's speech at West Point today, yet all it offered was a mixture of metaphor that careful readers had met before.
WASHINGTON, June 8--A cost-effectiveness study of American education will be carried out by the Office of Education starting in the fall of 1968.

Hoofbeats pounding behind them, losing ground to a patrolman on horseback and a detective on foot, two robbery suspects tried to escape down the IRT Times Square station yesterday but were headed off at the turnstile by a lack of tokens.
ALBANY, June 8 The deteriorating relationship between Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Lindsay is viewed by many politicians as an inevitable conflict.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 8--Susan Montgomery Wood, who retired in 1946 as executive secretary of the New York City Cancer Committee (now the New York City division of the American Cancer Society), died yesterday at the Community Hospital here. She was 89 years old and lived at 225 West 12th Street in New York.
ROME, June 8 (AP) Julie Andrews and Richard Burton tonight were named the best foreign actress and actor of the 1965-66 season by leaders of the Italian film industry.
WARSAW, June 8 (UPI) Two more military members of the United States Embassy staff here were ordered expelled today, making a total of five ousted by Poland in the last two months.
Ground will be broken today in the Rutherford Industrial Park, Rutherford, N.J., for a 375-000-square-foot distribution center for B. Altman Co., the New York department store.
Six psychology teachers at City College conducted a protest yesterday against the college's cooperation with Selective Service regulations by filing a final grade of A for each of their 200 students.

Ninety cadets of this year's 103-man graduating class at the New York Maritime College, Fort Schuyler, are planning to enter the merchant marine as licensed officers, spokesmen for the Bronx school said yesterday. Five others are taking maritime jobs ashore.
A New York County grand jury recommended yesterday that corporations be barred by law from taking advertisements in political journals.
The New York and the American Stock Exchanges reported yesterday the changes carried below in the share holdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (UPI) Lawyers for Senator Thomas J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, filed two motions today in United States District Court in his tangled $2-million conspiracy and libel suit against two columnists, Drew Pearson and Jack Anderson.
PEREGRINE POLLEN was terribly tempted to bid on a Victorian mirror wreathed in painted roses that went under the hammer last night at his own auction house.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 8 (AP) The California Supreme Court ruled today that the owner of a single-family dwelling was free to refuse to sell or lease it to a Negro. In doing so, the court reversed itself in a North Sacramento case.
CHICAGO, June 8 (AP) The American Bankers Association announced today the formation of a 21-member task force to seek ways of handling securities certificates through automated processing.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, June 8 A mood of confidence in a secure future is making inroads into the habitual fear and instability of this volatile republic.
A Pre-Summer Soiree sponsored by the Young Leadership Division of the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York will be held on Wednesday at the Sheraton-East.

AT West Point, where he ranked 191st in a class of 551, Bill Carpenter was the guy who never complained. Not that the big (6 feet 2 inches, 205 pounds), softspoken cadet didn't earn other distinctions. He did, by the bushel: football captain, 1959 All-American in his second ...

Grace Line received a special citation yesterday from the United States Public Health Service for operation of its fleet operations in accordance witeh the highest standards of sanitation laid down by the Federal service.
IT is often asked, Why can't they forget? when the ques tion might better be, Why should they forget?
June may be the traditional month for brides, but it belongs to debutantes, too.

The Government's $530-million offering of participation certificates was placed on the market formally yesterday. Late in the afternoon, dealers estimated that the Government securities were 80 per cent sold.
The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire a parking company.
BONN, June 9 Chancellor Ludwig Erhard will again visit President Johnson this summer. The plan was tentatively approved today by the Chancellor with Secretary of State Dean Rusk.
CHICAGO, June 9 (AP) Eight players were eliminated today in the 1966 United States open pocket billiards championship.

WASHINGTON, June 9 A Federal-state committee laid down an 80-page inventory of opportunities today to preserve scenic, historic and recreation values in the Potomac River Valley from the estuary at the mouth of the river to the Mason-Dixon line.
Another beer Falstaff has entered the highly competitive but lucrative New York market.

The election of Archie R. McCardell as group president for corporate services was announced yesterday in Rochester by the Xerox Corporation. Mr. McCardell, 39 years old, has served since 1949 with the Ford Motor Company, most recently as director of finance.
WASHINGTON, June 9 Leaded gasoline was defended today before a Senate subcommittee hearing on air pollution.

WASHINGTON, June 9--A slight shift of emphasis in Soviet comments on Vietnam has inspired a search here for other signs that Moscow may be trying to reactivate its diplomatic dealings with the United States.
An apparent impasse was reached yesterday in a strike by 700 operators of air-conditioning against more than 100 of Manhattan's biggest office buildings.
ALBANY, June 9 An art dealer may not use his family name on a gallery he set up next door to one his brother had been operating for more than 25 years, the State's highest court ruled today.
Dr. Paulo G. Hasslocher, Brazilian Ambassador to the Dominican Republic from 1951 until 1956, died May 29 in his home in Rio de Janeiro, after a long illness. He was 76 years old.
A major expansion of container shipping facilities at Elizabeth, N.J., was announced yesterday by the Port of New York Authority.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) The House Banking Committee resolved an internal row over its chairman's subpoena power today by invalidating the subpoenas issued in connection with a pending investigation but affirming the chairman's author ity to issue new subpoenas.

AREA A Chumming for bluefish off the shores of Barnegat Bay was reported yesterday. Sea bass were being taken off the wrecks and a few striped bass were being caught off the jetties and rocks near Barnegat Light Inlet. Just north of Long Branch Pier, there was good fishing for fluke, kingfish and blackfish with worms, clams and live killies as bait.

Mrs. Catherine Hannon Kelly of New York was married yesterday afternoon to Peter Alexander Larkin of Kingsville, Tex. State Supreme Court Justice William B. Groat performed the ceremony in the library of the St. Regis-Sheraton, where Mrs. William S. Paley and H. Virgil Sherrill attended the couple.
ATLANTA, June 9 (AP) Atlanta's striking firemen agreed tonight, after a conference with Mayor Ivan Allen Jr. at City Hall, to return to work immediately.

WASHINGTON, June 9 Rail freight ton-mileage in the Memorial Day holiday week ended June 4 was an estimated 13.5 billion ton-miles. The total was 8.6 per cent above the comparable 1965 week which also included the holiday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. There is every indication that Indonesia will be permitted to resume membership in the United Nations by administrative action between now and September, when the General Assembly meets, provided Jakarta wholly ends its "crush Malaysia" campaign and makes token payment on assessments owed. The Secretary General's office has analyzed prevailing opinion and finds a consensus favoring this solution.
STAMFORD, Conn., June 9 Myron Frankel, merchant and civic leader here, died today in New York City. He was 66 years old and lived at 1425 Bedford Street.
Deputy Mayor Timothy W. Costello told union leaders yesterday that the city would no longer permit its employes to leave their desks an hour early in the hot summer months.

WASHINGTON, June 9 Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen accused the President and his Administration today of being neither "caidid" nor "consistently credible" in their statements of United States policies and "our position" in Vietnam.
The summer table settings now on display on the second and third floors at Tiffany's are called "Cool as a Cucumber."
Good evening, My purpose in appearing here tonight is to set the record straight on New York City's tax program.

QUEBEC, June 9, (Canadian Press)--Jean Lesage announced today that he would resign as Premier of Quebec and said that he would meet with Daniel Johnson next week to fix a date for the National Union to take over the government.

HAY RIVER, Northwest Territories The "No Loitering" sign is almost hidden by the Indians loitering on the long front porch of the onestory hotel. Inside the logcabin beer parlor, a burly waiter scuffles with a drunk.
COMO, Miss., June 9 The civil rights march begun by James H. Meredith continued to gain momentum today as it pressed deeper into Mississippi.
An independent national committee, including experts on Asia as members, was formed here yesterday to sponsor widespread public discussion of United States policy toward Communist China.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fal., June 9 (AP) Seventeen of 21 experiments aboard the orbiting Geophysical Observatory 3 were successfully turned en today and began radioing to earth data of the sun's relations to earth.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (UPI) A Federal district judge fined the fireman's union today for ignoring his back-to-work order while on strike against eight railroads in April.

LONDON, June 9 The lovers die, the tragedy ends, the curtains close. Then whitefaced, hair lank, eyes dulled, they start the ritual. Scarcely moving, drained of feeling, they stare with a kind of pained puzzlement at the spotlight, while the audience, similarly numbed, cheers them desultorily. The curtain falls again and this hushed and shocked prelude over, this tribute to purple tragedy completed, the ritual moves into its next phase.

The first international congress of its kind in this country was opened here yesterday by the Federation Internationale des Societes Aerophilateliques, a world group of organizations of air-mail stamp collectors.

The famous nineteenth century American painter Frederick Edwin Church, who thought nothing of tackling the Aurora Borealis or the full sweep of Niagara Falls in nature's most dramatically technicolored moods, built a Persian-Victorian castle for himself high above the Hudson in the river landscape that he immortalized. He then filled it with treasures of the East and named it Olana, "our place on high."
The American National Theater and Academy, on the eve of its seventh annual national assembly, is undertaking a major program of expansion.

The real deadline for New York City in its great fiscal crisis is not June 30, the end of the fiscal year, but rather a week from today, by which time the City Council and Board of Estimate must act on a budget whether new tax revenue has been approved or not.

Governor Rockefeller yesterday invited Mayor Lindsay, the legislative leaders and the leaders of the City Council to a meeting in the Executive Chamber in Albany on Monday and asked them to be "prepared for continuous sessions until this [tax] matter is successfully resolved."
FAYETTE, Miss., June 9 (AP) This tiny southwest Mississippi town appears to have surmounted its many racial problems.

Abercrombie Fitch has entered into a joint venture with University Microfilms, Inc., to publish books. The new imprint will be called the Abercrombie Fitch Library of Sporting Books, Americana, Travel and Exploration.
STANTON, Del., June 9 (UPI) Carl Hanford, the trainer of Kelso, announced his resignation today from the Bohemia Stable of Mrs. Richard C. du Pont, effective July 31.
The American Stock Exchange registered a moderate advance yesterday as trading continued at a slow pace.

WASHINGTON, June 9 President Johnson is being told that his diminishing popularity in the public-opinion polls can be attributed to an increase in the number of Americans who think he should step up the war in Vietnam to win a quick victory.
CARBONDALE, Ill., June 9 (AP) The expulsion of 21 students arrested last night and early today was ordered today by the president of Southern Illinois University.

CAIRO, June 9 The Palestine Liberation Army, set up by Arab heads of state to oppose Israel, will send members to Vietnam to "fight alongside the Vietcong in their struggle against American imperialism," its spokesman said today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 9 President Johnson today invited Secretary General U Thant and the heads of 112 diplomatic missions and their wives to a White House reception next Tuesday.
BOSTON, June 9 Dr. Max Rinkel, a medical researcher who pioneered in studies of the effects of the controversial drug LSD, died of a heart attack last night in his office here. He was 71 years old.

MOSCOW, June 9 The Soviet Union withdrew today from participation in the world congress of P.E.N., a writers' organization, apparently to avoid being challenged about the conviction of the two writers, Andrel D. Sinyavsky and Yuli M. Daniel.
The Pakistani delegate to the United Nations recited Omar Khayyam.
THE imposing Etoile restaurant that opened recently in the Sherry-Netherland Hotel will be stanchly praised for its sleek, modern look or regarded askance for its cold, sterile aspect.

SCARBOROUGH, N.Y., June 9 Theodore L. Crockett, a general partner of Shields Co., stockbrokers at 44 Wall Street, died today, on his 62d birthday, at Phelps Memorial Hospital in North Tarrytown. He lived at 777 Sleepy Hollow Road.
The Theater World, the annual pictorial and statistical compilation, announced yesterday its selection of "Promising Personalities" from Broadway and Off Broadway.
Mayor Lindsay yesterday approved proposals of the City Planning Commission for revisions in the plans for the $200-million downtown civic center and ordered a go-ahead on the project.
CLEVELAND, June 9 The New York Yankees filled Whitey Ford's place on the roster tonight at least temporarily by recalling Bill Stafford from Toledo.
William F.R. Ballard, chairman of the City Planning Commission, declared yesterday that he would oppose any reorganization that would destroy the independence of his agency.
Industrial shares maintained a firm trend on the London Stock Exchange yesterday, although trading was light pending new developments in the British seamen's strike.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 9 (AP) The Minnesota Twins smashed five home runs in the seventh inning today and scored a 9-4 victory over the Kansas City Athletics. The homer outburst tied a major league record. The Twins just missed breaking the major league record for most home runs in an inning when Jimmie Hall came within two feet of clearing the fence after Harmon Killebrew had crashed the fifth homer of the inning.

The New York City Opera, in response to an unusual demand for subscriptions, is adding three new series to the seven already announced. Each new series will consist of three concerts: either three Saturday evenings, or two Sunday matinees and one Friday evening, or three Sunday evenings. The price range is from $7.50 to $16.50.
ALBANY, June 9 The Court of Appeals upheld today an order directing fraternities and sororities at the State University to sever their national affiliations.
It's SUPERMAN" will give four matinees a week Wednesday, Thursday, Saturday and Sunday starting on June 29.
The deep crevices that had seemed to divide New York's Republican party in recent weeks closed yesterday, at least for the day, as Governor Rockefeller formally opened his reelection campaign.
GROSSINGER, N.Y., June 9 Car manufacturers have only themselves to blame for stirring a furor over vehicle safety, the president of the State Automobile Association said today.

WASHINGTON, June 9 Dr. William H. Stewart, Surgeon General of the Public Health Service, and 360 service officers were in the South today trying to persuade hospitals to desegregate in time to make them available for Medicare patients July 1.

NASHVILLE, June 9 (AP)--Maj. Gen. Ben Sternberg, commander of the 101st Airborne Division, said tonight that "500,000 more troops would be required" to seal off the borders of South Vietnam to infiltrators.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) The State Department suggested today that a Cuban delegation to the Caribbean Games starting in Puerto Rico Saturday "could arrange for charter flights via nearby third countries."

New York City is issuing more parking summonses this year but is collecting less money in parking fines. In the first five months summonses increased by more than 300,000 over the comparable period of 1965, but payment dropped by nearly $1-million.
Max Druckman, a founder of the New York Furniture Exchange at 200 Lexington Avenue, died Wednesday night at his home, 96-11 65th Road, Forest Hills, Queens. He was 81 years old.

WASHINGTON, June 9 Recent Administration estimates of the minimum amount of American merchant shipping required to meet national needs came under bitter attack today from a leading spokesman for the American shipbuilding industry.

Technical excellence and mu sical sophistication have become common aspects of college and university choirs in this country, but it is still very rare to find high school ensembles with these qualities. Last night in Carnegie Recital Hall some teen-agers demonstrated than they can make as good music as just about any vocal group around.
JACKSON, Miss., June 8 Mississippi's Legislature, reacting to heavy Negro voting in some counties in Tuesday's primary election, has approved a constitutional amendment for consolidation of counties.

Army's baseball team; Tom Skenderian, Brown's sophomore outfielder, and Gene Ryzewicz, Dartmouth sophomore infielder, won top awards in the 1966 championship race of the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League.

The New York Central Railroad's directors voted yesterday an extra dividend of 30 cents a share in addition to the regular quarterly dividend of 52 cents a share. Both payments will be made June 30, to holders of record June 20.
TOKYO, June 9 (UPI)--Yoshiaki Numata of Japan, 21-year-old Orient junior lightweight champion, won the Orient lightweight title tonight by scoring a unanimous 12-round decision over Flash Elorde.
The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court ruled against Hunt Foods and Industries, Inc., yesterday in its bid to obtain control of the Eastern Can Company.

WASHINGTON, June 9 House Republicans strongly criticized today the sale of participations in Governmentowned loans by the Federal National Mortgage Association at an interest cost of up to 5.75 per cent.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 9 National leaders of the conservative wing of the Republican party said today that they were astonished to hear that a man they regarded as a conservative had associated himself with liberal Republicans in a primary fight in Nassau County.
EAST LANSING, Mich., June 9 (UPI) More than 1,000 Michigan State University students went on a rampage today, throwing rocks and bottles at the police and milling through campus streets.

Eighteen Negro Democratic legislators and district leaders in Harlem charged yesterday that the effort to nominate Supreme Court Justice Samuel J. Silverman as Manhattan Surrogate was "aimed solely at J. Raymond Jones because he is a Negro."

PITTSBURGH, June 9 (AP) Jerry Buchek and Phil Gagliano cracked two-run homers tonight as the St. Louis Cardinals defeated Pittsburgh, 4-2, and tagged the Pirates' rookie southpaw, Woody Fryman, with his first defeat.
PHILADELPHIA, June 9 (AP) Joey Jay pitched a fivehitter and Leo Cardenas drove in the only run with an eighthinning single as the Cincinnati Reds beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 1-0, tonight.
PARIS, June 9 The Elysee Palace published tonight the schedule of President de Gaulle's forthcoming 12-day state visit to the Soviet Union, which begins June 20.

Miss. Tomi Maida Deutsch and Stuart Emanuel Berney were married here last evening at the Sheraton-East by Rabbis Judah Nadich and Nathan A.

LANSING, Mich., June 9 (AP) The Roman Catholic Church in Michigan said today it would use its millions of purchasing dollars to try to influence supplier companies to hire more Negroes and members of other minority groups.

STOCKHOLM, June 9 (Reuters) Sweden announced today she would raise its bank rate tomorrow to the highest level in more than 30 years in a move "designed to control inflationary pressures in the nation's economy."
WASHINGTON, June 9--The Senate passed today a truth-in-packaging bill designed to save the housewife time and money when she goes to the supermarket. The vote was 72 to 9.

LAKE FOREST, Ill., June 9 Mr. and Mrs. Hermon Dunlap Smith have announced the engagement of their daughter Miss. Adele Dunlap Smith, to John Leroy Simmons, son of Mr. and Mrs. Elwyn Leroy Simmons of Decatur.
WASHINGTON, June 9 The United States apparently had to pay nearly $20-million of gold in the first quarter of this year as its share of the cost of keeping the price stable in the London market.

ROME, June 9 Vittorio Ivella, who went to the United States as cultural attache when the Italian Embassy in Washington was reopened after World War II, died here early today. He was 49 years old.
WASHINGTON, June 9 President Johnson conferred tonight at the White House with the chairmen of 15 Senate committees.
Two-hour television adaptations of Arthur Miller's "The Crucible" and Tennessee Williams's "The Glass Menagerie" will be presented in color next season by the Columbia Broadcasting System.

LONDON, June 9 The Boy Scouts Association of Britain said today that it had outgrown short pants, that it was considering dropping the word "boy" from its name and that it hoped to start planning joint programs with Girl Scouts.

In 1946, Rabbi Joshua Loth Liebman published "Peace of Mind," which was greatly praised by people in many fields, from philosophers to laymen.
