WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) Sections of the Administration's civil rights bill designed to prevent discrimination in jury selection were tentatively approved today by a House judiciary subcommittee.

WASHINGTON, June 9 The General Electric Company has charged eight labor unions with breaking the law by banding together to present a united front against the company in this year's biggest set of contract negotiations.

WASHINGTON, June 9 President Johnson asked Congress today to approve a compact among Maryland, Virginia and the District of Columbia that would make possible a long-planned metropolitan rapid transit system.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 9 (AP) The United States Auto Club reported today that no one driver could be blamed for the 16-car pile-up at the start of the 500-mile race at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway on May 30.
HOUSTON, June 9 (AP) Jim Davenport's 11th-inning double drove in two runs and gave San Francisco a 3-1 victory tonight over the Houston Astros.

Richard Rosenthal, chairman of the Michigan Gas and Electric Company, said yesterday that his company had filed an antitrust suit against the American Electric Power Company, Inc., in the New York Federal Court.
PARIS, June 9 "The French Government feels that things follow their normal course and that France's partners in the alliance are adapting themselves to the decisions that France has taken."

Patrolman Robert Dziedzic, temporarily assigned to Coney Island, was treated last night for scalp lacerations after having been beaten with a softdrink bottle during a beach disturbance. Four youths were arrested.
A modification of the terms of the proposed merger of the Warren Brothers Company into the Ashland Oil and Refining Company was announced jointly by the two companies yesterday.

Supreme Court Justice Charles G. Tierney denied yesterday a plea by 24 striking teachers at St. John's University that distribution of the school's Undergraduate Bulletin 1966-67 be halted since its listings were false and erroneous in recording their names as members of the faculty. WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) The Western Union Telegraph Company announced today a two-year contract agreement ending a strike that had shut down telegraph service to the public throughout the country.

Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, chess champion of the world, drew the 24th and final game of his match with his compatriot, the challenger, 28-year-old Boris Spassky, after 77 moves at Moscow's Variety Theater last night.

The head of one of the nation's major barge companies disclosed yesterday that his concern was shifting its headquarters from New York to St. Louis "because the waterways of the east, including the New York State Barge Canal, are not being developed for low-cost water transportation."
PLAINFIELD, N.J., June 9 Harry Keith White, a retired New York architect who designed many public buildings, died today at Muhlenberg Hospital. He was 89 years old and lived at 815 Carlton Avenue.

The American Stock Exchange apparently is going to nose out the New York Stock Exchange in the race to issue its own stock-price index.
Ninety-five persons were arrested in Harlem last night in what was described as the city's biggest roundup of heroin sellers in many years.

HOUSTON, June 9 (UPI) A rookie astronaut, Maj. Michael Collins of the Air Force, is expected to open his hatch for at least two excursions into space during the orbital flight of Gemini 10 next month.

ALBANY, June 9 Governor Rockefeller prodded the Democratic-controlled Assembly today to pass his "enlightened" bill to discourage strikes by government employes.

THE death of Walter Malowan last month at the age of 83 deprived New York of one of its most distinguished bridge veterans. He won the American Whist League Open Team Championship in 1933, was twice second in the Vanderbilt and won ten regional titles. He was also an active administrator and writer.

BRUSSELS, June 9--The negotiations in the Kennedy Round of trade talks in Geneva echoed in Brussels today. The European Common Market let it be known that it considered the United States' offer to change the "American selling price" system inadequate.

ROME, June 9 (UPI) Sergia Tacchini and Nicola Pietrangeli of Italy scored upset victories over Cliff Drysdale and Keith Diepraam of South Africa today to give Italy a 2-0 lead in the semi-final round of the European Zone Davis Cup competition.
BECKENHAM, England, June 9 (AP) Ray Ruffels, 20 years old, an unranked Australian upset Arthur Ashe today, 20-18 6-2, in a day of surprises at the Kent tennis tournament.

Fawcett Publications, Inc., announced yesterday the appointment of George H. Allen as vice president, magazine division, a new position and one that makes him, in effect, the publisher of all the company's magazines.

WASHINGTON, June 9 An economic foreign aid program totaling $2,352-billion was approved today by a 17to-1 vote of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. Senator Wayne Morse, Democrat of Oregon, cast the single dissent.

President Tito has again demonstrated a short memory and a tendency to bend Yugoslavia's "nonaligned" stance toward Soviet policy in major EastWest issues.

Jurisdictional warfare broke out again in track and field last night. HAVANA, June 9 (AP) Hurricane Alma claimed 12 lives and caused extensive damage to property and crops in its sweep across Cuba, news reports said today. There was no estimate as yet in dollar loss.
Three large United States aluminum producers have been negotiating with the Jamaican Government in recent months on plans to build a jointly owned installation to produce alumina in Jamaica.

The Industrial Real Estate Brokers Association has elected Irving T. Wallach president. The group has a membership of 300 industrial brokers in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and Pennsylvania.
India's devaluation of her currency earlier this week should help to stimulate an inflow of foreign investment, G.L. Mehta, a leading Indian businessman said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 9 The United States Government is rapidly overcoming the political objections to its population control programs. In fact, the contrast now with the last days of the Eisenhower Administration is startling.

STRATFORD, Ont., June 9 A paradox. On Tuesday the Stratford Festival presented "Henry VI," a weak play, which the company gave life through their theatrical strengths. Last night they presented "Twelfth Night," a gem of romance, which they fumbled.

The Federal Government stepped up its campaign yesterday to prosecute those responsible for polluting the Hudson River and its tributaries. The water supply in the city's reservoirs yesterday at 8 A.M. stood at 413.6 billion gallons, 86.8 per cent of capacity. This represents an increase of 700 million gallons over the day before.

The New York Society of Security Analysts announced yesterday the election of Raymond W. Hammell, 53 years old, as president for a oneyear term.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 111.1 on Wednesday from 111.2 on Tuesday.
NEW DELHI, June 9 Chandigarh, the Punjab state capital famed for its Corbusier architecture, will become a federally administered territory the Government announced tonight.

Copper futures gained almost a cent a pound for some deliveries yesterday under the impact of further bad news.

The Appellate Division voided a $280,000 malpractice award against Doctors Hospital yesterday and ordered a new trial of Mrs. Marjorie Deutch's charge that her son, Christopher, had suffered permanent brain damage when he was delivered at the hospital nine years ago.

Landlords who charge illegal rents and refuse to repair hazardous conditions in rent-controlled buildings face heavy fines and possible imprisonment under an unused law that the city is planning to invoke for the first time.

Far from smashing the Administration's wageprice guideposts, the recommendations a Presidential emergency board has made in the airlines pay dispute may have given the much-battered anti-inflation standards the kind of flexibility they need for survival.

The St. Louis-San Francisco Railway and the Southern Railway jointly announced yesterday that they had been unable to reach agreement on a merger and that no further merger talks between the roads were now planned.

Mayor Lindsay and his top antipoverty aides will visit Washington today to appeal for increased Federal aid to New York City's poor.

In a surprise move yesterday, R.H. Macy Co., Inc., announced that its president, Wheelock H. Bingham, was retiring on the advice of his physician, after 40 years with the Macy organization.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., June 9 (UPI) Hurricane Alma rammed ashore on the Florida panhandle today, sending floodtides rushing through the streets and dying down to a tropical storm as it surged into Georgia. The storm struck inland near Apalachicola. The Weather Bureau in Miami said it had moved northeast at about 12 miles an hour to near Valdosta, Ga., by midnight.

The $11,050 Annapolis hurdle, the final stakes event for jumpers in New York until the thoroughbred circus moves to Saratoga in August, was concluded in a manner to delight chalk players at Aqueduct yesterday.

In a ruling filled with musical references by Keats, Spinoza, Nietzsche and Longfellow, Justice J. Irwin Shapiro handed down a decision yesterday declaring that it was unreasonable to limit music-playing in an apartment house during "reasonable" hours.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan and State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz are investigating the operation of Franklin Plaza, a 1632-apartment Mitchell-Lama cooperative in East Harlem.
LONDON, June 9 The Trades Union Congress, representative body of Britain's trade union movement, told striking merchant seamen tonight that they could expect no assistance from other unions.
The Distillers CorporationSeagrams, Ltd., reported yesterday sharp increases in sales and earnings for the threemonth and-nine month periods ended April 30.
WESTBURY, L.I., June 9 Frank Mollica doesn't care much for trotters.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) Congress approved sweeping reforms today in the 175-yearold Federal bail system. The legislation is designed to permit poor people awaiting trial in Federal courts to be released without bond.

The city school system, which has been under sharp criticism by Charles G. Moerdler, Commissioner of Buildings, announced plans yesterday to put a rejected group of school buildings "reasonably first-class condition."
ALBANY, June 9 (AP) The State Court of Appeals ruled today that Roosevelt Raceway at Westbury, L.I., must pay Nassau County a 30 per cent admission tax.
Escalation of the war in Vietnam and a series of natural disasters have all but depleted the $20-million reserve of the American National Red Cross.
The main Post Office on Eighth Avenue between 31st and 33d Streets was one of seven buildings in Manhattan designated as landmarks yesterday by the Landmarks Preservation Commission.
MOSCOW, June 9 (AP) President Nikolai V. Podgorny said today that the Soviet aid ... to the Communists in Vietnam would be increased "if necessary."

Bache Co. has had its fling uptown and is going back home to the financial district.

Alonzo (Willie) Wilkins, a New York watchmaker who is one of two men who have been in all the nine previous meets, was determined yesterday that his team would regain the championship of the National Wheelchair Games, which will open for three days today in Queens.
BUENOS AIRES, June 9--President Arturo Illia has called an extraordinary meeting of his Cabinet and all the top aides of his belabored Government for tomorrow morning.

CARNOUSTIE, Scotland, June 9 (AP) Charles McCallum, Richard Anthony and Hunter McDonald, a Scot living in Michigan, carried the hopes of the United States into the fifth round of the British Amateur golf championship after today's play.
ATLANTA, June 9 Mayor Ivan Allen Jr. said earlier today that striking firemen who did not return to work by 8 A.M. Saturday would be dismissed from their jobs.

IN THE aftermath of the surprise peace settlement of the undeclared war between the National Football League and the American Football League the same questions were being asked yesterday: Who won and who lost? The longer a grandstand quarterback thinks about the merger of the embattled factions into a unified whole the more convinced he becomes that everyone presently involved will benefit owners, coaches, team members and fans.
A Department of Health inspector, two more housing inspectors and another landlord's agent were indicted yesterday in the investigation of corruption in the city Buildings Department.
WASHINGTON, June 9 The United States Government was reported to be divided today over West German proposals to shift funds committed for arms purchases to buying "space for peace" items.

GENEVA, June 9 Western anti-Communist labor leaders suffered a defeat today with the election of a Soviet trade unionist, for the first time, to the executive board of the International Labor Organization, a United Nations specialized agency.

The 50th annual commencement of the Professional Children's School was held yesterday afternoon at the New York State Theater in Lincoln Center. Among the 67 graduates of the 8th and 12th grade were the sons of Soupy Sales and Gabriel Dell and students of George Balanchine.

Goddard Lieberson, one of the more prominent figures in the phonograph recording industry, has been named president of the C.B.S./Columbia Group, a new unit of the Columbia Broadcasting System for expanded activities in education and music. HARRISBURG, Pa., June 9 (AP) The terms of a proposed interstate-Federal compact to coordinate development, management and use of the 27,500square-mile Susquehanna River Basin watershed were announced today.

TOPEKA, Kan., June 9 Emergency workers searched wreckage today for more victims of last night's devastating tornado, which left 14 known dead in this city of 120,000.

Owens-Illinois, Inc., glass products manufacturer, announced yesterday that it planned to go into the sugarproducing business. It will convert some of its timber lands on Great Abaco Island in the Bahamas into sugar producing acreage by 1969 through an investment of more than $15million.

The "key issue" in the dispute between the striking Newspaper Guild of New York and The World Journal Tribune, Inc., was settled last night, according to the guild's chief negotiator.

A Town Hall audience of 1,200 people joined with two Pulitzers, Prize winners last night in a tribute to a Vietnamese monk. Arthur Miller, the playwright, and Robert Lowell, the poet, drew applause as they denounced the United States presence in Vietnam. Mr. Wilier was applauded in particular when he said; "No sane person any longer believes that Premier Ky is any more than an American creation."

The peace agreement between the National and American Football Leagues on Wednesday supposedly ended an era during which professional teams paid dazzling six-figure bonuses to untried collegiate hotshots.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, June 9 The Dutch Government today freed Willy P. F. Lages, a 64-year-old German war criminal, who is said to be dying. Lages was taken to the West German frontier this morning and handed over to West German authorities.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., June 10 (UPI)--Ten members of the Springfield chapter of the Congress of Racial Equality picketed on Main Street last night against the Springfield Police Commission.
The Department of the Interior and the National Park Service disclosed this week that they were missing two statues --one nonexistent and the other valued at $5,000.
ALBANY, June 10--A slight drop in attendance and the amount of money bet during the spring race meetings at Aqueduct and Yonkers was reported today by the State Tax Commissioner.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., June 10--Stewart L. Udall, the Secretary of the Interior, told the chemical industry here tonight that the Federal Government would step in if the industry did not hasten to clean up waters it was polluting.
Edison Brothers Stores, Inc., has announced in St. Louis the appointment of Elmer L. Jeffryes as sales manager of its new northeastern division.
GENEVA, June 10--The recent Moscow trial of two Soviet authors. Andrei D. Sinyavsky and Yuli M. Daniel, today was called a "blundering travesty of justice" by the International Commission of Jurists.
The Federal Home Loan Banks plan to make an offering of $750-million of bonds and notes on Tuesday.
TURIN, Italy, June 10 (Reuters--A Communist Chinese economic mission arrived here today and met for an hour with Italian aircraft officials and officials of the Fiant Motor Company.

DETROIT, June 10--The New York Yankees negotiated a fiveplayer trade with the Kansas City Athletics today in which they acquired a pitcher and a catcher, Fred Talbot and Bill Bryan, in exchange for Gil Blanco, Bill Stafford and Roger Repoz.

A defeated candidate for a major office in the National Maritime Union announced last night that he planned to protest the election on grounds of alleged irregularities, and that he would take his protest to the Secretary of Labor if necessary.

ATLANTA, June 10 (AP)-- Striking firemen have returned to their jobs after an agreement with city officials that their grievances will be considered by a mediator and that court action against union leaders will be dropped.

A layman in the United Church of Christ has attacked the bulk of hymns in popular use today as meaningless vestiges of the 19th century and urged churches to delegate the task of revising Protestant hymnody to recognized poets and composers.
Yankee Stadium, which usually rings to the shouts of baseball fans, last night shook, rattled and rolled to the din of bigsound bands and squealing teenagers.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., June 10 (UPI)--Jim Ryun, Kansas' 19-year-old freshman sensation, smashed the 880-yard world record tonight, covering the distance in 1 minute 44.9 seconds in the United States Track and Field Federation championships.

TO win three events in one tournament is a very rare experience, as memorable for the player concerned as a hole in one is for a golfer. Mrs. Augusta Cantor of New York, a member of the Greater New York Bridge Association's board of directors and a fine and consistent player, achieved this distinction recently in a tournament in Port Chester, with triumphs in the Mixed Pairs, the Master Pairs and the Team-ofFour.
PACIFIC PALISADES, Calif., June 10--Frederic A. Gimbel, former president of Gimbels department store in New York, died at his home here early tonight. He was 73 years old.

The Chelsea Hotel at 222 West 23d Street, the Board of Estimate ruled yesterday, is not the "shabby institution" described by some members of the Local Community Planning Board, but a distinguished hostelry where famous writers have lived.

LONDON, June 10--The Oxford Union, the university's debating society, set off a tempest last night by voting to reject the English-Speaking Union's choice of two debaters for an American tour in the fall.
J.C. Penney Company announced yesterday that it would open its second catalogue distribution center on a 270acre tract 11 miles south of Atlanta.
CHICAGO, June 10 (AP)-- Dave Boswell pitched a fourhitter and collected two hits as the Minnesota Twins defeated the Chicago White Sox, 6-2, tonight.
An 11-year-old Korean girl has won the attention and affection of patients and the nursing staff in the intensivecare unit of University Hospital by just smiling from inside her oxygen tent.
BALTIMORE, June 10 (AP ) --Baltimore's Wally Bunker pitched no-hit ball for six innings and wound up with a four-hitter tonight as the Orioles crushed the Boston Red Sox, 9-2.
TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., June 10--A benefit will be held next Saturday in the Peacock Patio of Sterling Forest Gardens for the Tuxedo Memorial Hospital.
CINCINNATI, June 10 (AP) --The body of a 56-year-old widow, strangled with a necktie and raped, was found today in a city park, the third Victim of a rapist-strangler in Cincinnati in six months.

WASHINGTON, June 10-- The chairman of a Congressional investigating panel reported today that a collision in which two test pilots were killed Wednesday had occurred on a flight staged for publicity photographers.
The Affiliated Fund and American Business Shares, open-end investment companies, announced the election here yesterday of Paul Windels Jr. as a director.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 10 --Avery Brundage placed San Francisco "in the Big League" today in the world of art.

WASHINGTON, June 10--An 11 per cent decline in the winter wheat crop during the last month was estimated today by the Department of Agriculture. Frost and drought in the Great Plains wheat belt caused the major damage.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 10 --A bequest by George W. Oakes, journalist and author, will be used to purchase books in American history for the Princeton University library, William S. Dix, the librarian, announced today. The amount of the bequest was not made public.

JOHNSTOWN, Pa., June 10 (AP)--Dr. Ed Updegraff of Tucson, Ariz., battled winds gusting up to 25 miles an hour and fired a par 70 to take a one-stroke lead in the first round of the Sunnehanna golf tournament for amateur champions at the Sunnehanna Country Club today.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 10--The state constitutional convention snapped a protracted deadlock here tonight and approved a reapportionment plan for the New Jersey Legislature.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, June 10 (AP)--A Mexican Olympic Committee official said tonight that 364 Cubans would land here in private barges tomorrow morning to take part in the 10th Central American and Caribbean Games.
The Lindsay administration's abrupt about-face on summer siesta time for municipal employer is an object lesson in how not to conduct civil service labor relations.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., June 10--Mrs. C.K. Finch of New Canaan posted a 38, 42--80, for low-gross prize during the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day tournament today over the Huntington Country Club course. Par for the women is 36, 37--73, for 5,845 yards.
MOSCOW, June 10 (Reuters) --Three young American musicians will go into the final round of the cellists' section in the Tchaikovsky Music Competition here next week.
DALLAS, June 10 (UPI)-- District Judge Louis Holland today ordered a sanity trial for Jack L. Ruby to proceed on schedule Monday.
The World Bank has approved two loans totaling the equivalent of $30-million for the expansion of electric power in Portugal.

PHILADELPHIA, June 10-- Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson, a noted campaigner for national beautification, paid a four-anda-half-hour visit to this city today to inspect Philadelphia's progress in urban renewal.
Two Chilean freighters are still held up at Brooklyn piers because of a union dispute among crew members.

Fewer than half the parking summonses served in New York City in the first five months of this year have been answered. Such intolerable disregard for law requires a thorough overhaul of defective enforcement machinery.

KEILGHLEY; England, June 10 (AP)--Twenty members of a group of Amateur Tour of Britain cyclists were injured today when they overshot a sharp bend and plunged down a slope just below the summit of a 2,000-foot peak in the Pennines.

HONK KONG, June 10-- Communist China is in the grip of a nationwide political purge in the aftermath of the fall of Peng Chen, the Mayor of Peking and a member of the Politburo, and his chief subordinates.
BARTON-ON-HUMBER, England, June 10 (AP)--Henry Treece, British poet and historical novelist, died at his home here today. He was 55 years old.

WASHINGTON, June 10-- George Meany's decision to have American labor boycott the current International Labor Organization conference has deeply strained his recently improved relations with Walter P. Reuther.
WASHINGTON June 10-- President Johnson's campaign to sell United States savings bonds to Federal employes is reaching the high pressure stage, a few employes complained today.

Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes left St. Vincent's Hospital for his Bayside, Queens, home yesterday with a warning from his physician that he cannot go back for a while to his normal 15-hour working day.
The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court has thrown a roadblock in the may of the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines effort to keep the New York Stock Exchange from delisting its stock.

ARLINGTON, Va., June 10-- Mr. and Mrs. Armistead M. Lee of Arlington and Westford, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanore Ruggles Lee, to Robert Pack Browning, son of Mr. and Mrs. Archibald Robert Browning of Salt Lake City. The wedding is planned for Sept. 11.
Senator Jacob K. Javits gave his oldest daughter's highschool graduating class an elementary lesson yesterday in world problems and urged it to help solve them.

WASHINGTON, June 10-- Regular periodic treatments with artificial kidney machines not only can keep doomed patients alive but also can restore a high percentage of them to an active life, a nationwide survey indicates.
Louis de Kermaingant, secretary general of the magazines Paris Match and Marie-Claire, died on May 31 in Paris, it was learned here yesterday. He was 85 Years old.

GUILDFORD, Conn., June 10 --Miss Phoebe C. Ellsworth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Ellsworth Jr., was married here today at her parents' home to A. Richard Diebold Jr. of Cambridge, Mass., and Roxbury. The ceremony was performed by Justice of the Peace Henry S. Noble of New Canaan.

Four major lumber associations reported a decrease of 14.4 per cent in production for the week ended June 4 compared with the level in the corresponding 1965 week. Output fell 12.2 per cent from the preceding week.

HOUSTON, June 10 (UPI)-- The Gemini 9 astronauts, Lieut. Col. Thomas. P. Stafford of the Air Force, and Comdr. Eugene A. Cernan of the Navy, who just completed a three-day flight in space, came home today.
Robert W. Galvin, chairman of Motorola, Inc., has been elected president of the Electronic Industries Association, which has concluded its 42d annual convention in Chicago.
PARIS, June 10--Negotiations to save Europe's spacerocket program were suspended again today.
CHICAGO, June 10 (UPI)-- Four more players were eliminated today in the national open pocket billiards tournament. The finals in the week-long event are scheduled for tomorrow.

Charles Parkhurst, director of the Baltimore Museum of Art, has been named president of the American Association of Museums: The announcement was made Thursday by the association's executive council at the organization's 61st annual convention in Chicago.

An official of National Educational Television has charged that stations within the network have refused to televise controversial N.E.T. programs out of fear of offending the state legislatures that help to support them.

ACCRA, Ghanna, June 10-- The United States Government has reacted favorably to an urgent appeal from the new Ghanaian Government to provide Peace Corps volunteers to replace about 100 Russian teachers who left Ghana shortly after the Feb. 24 coup that toppled the regime of Kwame Nkrumah.

Another triple crown, this one for 3-year-old fillies will be in the building process at Aqueduct today with the running of the $75,000 added Mother Goose stakes. With Ogden Phipps's Marking Time heading the list, a field of nine will compete in the 1 1/8-mile test, which is the second part of a triad sponsored by the New York Racing Association.
NEW DELHI, June 9--India is facing her worst cholera epidemic in a decade.

GROSSINGER N.Y., June 10--Mayor Lindsay was accused here today of "hampering the economy he had promised to vitalize by delaying action on more than 600-million of vitally needed highway projects in New York City."
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 110.8 on Thursday from 111.1 on Wednesday.

ROME, June 10--Italy's governing coalition of the centerleft is fighting hard to turn back the Communists' determined bid to become the biggest party in Rome and to make gains elsewhere in the municipal and provincial elections Sunday and Monday.

SARDIS, Miss., June 10--The civil rights march to Jackson encountered sharp criticism today from a Mississippi Negro leader, who says he wants assurances that it will not be used to "exploit the state for money and publicity."
The House has passed a generally good bill to launch President Johnson's "Food for Freedom" program, but with some crippling restrictions that require removal by the Senate.

FALMOUTH, Me. (AP)-- Science teachers at the Plummer School are hoping to have a skeleton in their closet some day soon.

CHECKERBOARD rabbit is fun, bead-fringed mink is amusing and a monkey-fur dress is a barrel of giggles. Although the classic mink coat is still bread and butter to furriers, far-out ideas should have them laughing all the way to the bank.
West Germany took a 1-0 lead over England yesterday in their Davis Cup European zone semi-final tennis competition, and was leading in the second singles match when play was halted.

The Rev. Dr. Laurence MacColl Horton performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Noroton Presbyterian Church.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 10 (Reuters)--Three brothers were sentenced today to prison terms ranging from 5 to 16 years for kidnapping Mrs. Betty Glazer, the wife of a millionaire property owner.

WASHINGTON, June 10-- The index of primary market prices remained unchanged at 105.3 during the week ended June 7, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Farm products declined in price, while, processed foods increased. Industrial commodities averaged unchanged.

Plaster ceilings, concrete roads and blackboard chalk have one thing in common-- they all originated nearly 500 million years ago as shellfish.
GRAND BLANC, Mich., June 10--A three-way tie for the lead and some surprising golf marked the first round of the $100,000 Buick open tournament today.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP)--Harry P. Snyder, associate director of public relations for the American Textile Manufacturers Institute here, died of hepatitis today. He was 57 years old and lived in Bethesda, Md.
LINCROFT, N.J., June 10-- Joseph Daniel Cronan, a former advertising representative for The New York Times, died today at his home here, 257 Riverbrook Avenue. He was 54 years old.

BUENOS AIRES, June 10-- President Arturo U. Illia de fended his Administration today by refusing, to dismiss any of his cabinet ministers or other top aides to satisfy mounting criticism by the military and others. The critics charge that there is inefficiency in Government and deterioration in Argentina's economic and social life.
CHERRY HILL, N.J., June 10--Mike Goebig, a tall 15year-old from Philadelphia, won one class and took a second in another today in the West Jersey horse show at Garden State Park.
LONDON, June 10 (Reuters) --The Rootes Motor Group, one of Britain's biggest car manufacturers, today announced a 2-million- ($5.6million) loss for the half year ended Jan. 31.
LOS ANGELES, June 10-- The executive director of the California Arts Commission resigned today, expressing disappointment over the state budget allotment to the commission for the coming year.

BUFFALO, June 10--Miss Ann Curtis Walker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Wriggins Walker, was married today to David Arthur Rich, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Edward Rich of Buffalo and Palm Beach, Fla. The ceremony was performed in Trinity Episcopal Church by the Very Rev. Harold B. Robinson, Dean of St. Paul's, Cathedral, and the Rev. Peter M. Sturtevant.
Cecil Thomas has been designated executive secretary of the newly formed National Committee on United States-China Relations.

LUSAKA, Zambia, June 10-- Zambia's $98-million transitional development plan, which was to extend over an 18-month period, achieved it main goals in 17 months, Finance Minister Arthur Wina said here tonight. He had told the Cabinet it would be safe to exceed the original target in the last month of the plan.
MONTREAL, June 10 (Canadian Press)--Alcan Aluminium, Ltd., announced today a $28million expansion program of its bauxite and alumina producing facilities in Jamaica.

The talents of one of the nation's leading architects and a planning firm that masterminded the building of a new type of city at Reston, Va., are expected to be used in developing the Ruppert Brewery site as a high school, housing and park complex.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, June 11--Capt. William S. Carpenter Jr., the former West Point football hero, and his company of paratroopers fought their way through North Vietnamese machine-gun fire to safety today, bringing their dead and wounded with them.

Dr. Richard H. Heindel, president of Pratt Institute, told graduating students at a commencement ceremony yesterday not to become so interested in national and local affairs that they forget world affairs.

For a better understanding of English furniture, New Yorkers have only to visit the Metropolitan Museum. There, besides the fine permanent collection, an unusually good group of 18th-century English furniture is on view until July 4 in the New Accessions gallery.
ALBANY, June 10--New York City could get along comfortably without any new taxes at all, according to the Commerce and Industry Association of New York.
The recent firm trend on the London stock market continued yesterday, undeterred by the British seamen's strike.

CHARLESTON, S.C., June 10 (UPI)--A tropical storm that once was a hurricane churned out to sea today and pulled gradually away from land, raking the Eastern sea board as far north as Virginia with its gales.

Bob Shaw, a pitcher who has had distinguished records in both major leagues, was purchased by the New York Mets yesterday from the San Francisco Giants for an undisclosed sum. Met officials said it was "considerably over" the waiver price, which is $20,000.
TOKYO, June 10--Cherry blossoms, geisha, rickshas and Mount Fuji are inadequate symbols for a rapidly modernizing Japan, the Government believes.

Even as scientists, space officials, corporate executives and armchair astronauts are basking in the success of the Surveyor 1 lunar mission, the companies that built the spacecraft are sharpening their products, procedures and personnel for future Surveyor missions.

CAIRO, June 10--The newspaper Al Ahram reported today that the Soviet Union had agreed to extend to the United Arab Republic a $165-million credit to finance projects in the second Egyptian development plan.
BAY HEAD, N.J., June 10-- Dr. Levering Tyson, former president of Muhlenberg College, died today at the Sunnyside Farms Nursing Home in Brielle. He was 77 years old and lived at 212 East Avenue.

Cecil Taylor, a pioneer in the jazz avant-garde, gave his second annual concert at Town Hall last night with his septet, the Cecil Taylor Unit. The concert was a benefit for the New York University chapter of the Congress of Racial Equality.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 10 (AP)--Sandy Koufax won his 11th game, the most in the majors, and pitched the Los Angeles Dodgers into first place in the National League tonight by beating San Francisco, 6-1, on four hits.
The American Stock Exchange turned in its strongest performance yesterday in more than two weeks.
Interest rates paid on individual savings accounts are continuing to rise.
A new pedestrian signal went to work at noon yesterday in the middle of the long block of 34th Street between Herald Square and Seventh Avenue.

Fred Campbell, an accountant who was a founder and the first president of the Allied Federal Savings and Loan Association in Jamaica, Queens, died Wednesday in Hillcrest General Hospital in Flushing after a brief illness. He was 62 years old and lived at 17817 132d Avenue, Springfield Gardens, Queens.
NEWARK, June 10--A middle-aged school teacher correcting term papers in an elementary school here was raped today while other teachers taught classes nearby.

The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company announced yesterday it would begin marketing radial-ply passenger car tires in the Kansas City area next week to evaluate public acceptance before starting national distribution.

Miss Clay Dowdney Deering, daughter of William R. Deering of New York and Laurel Hollow, L.I., and Mrs. William L. Pollok of New York and East Hampton, L.I., was married yesterday to Joseph Richardson Dilworth Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Richardson Dilworth of Princeton, N.J.
The 86 men and 10 women arrested throughout Harlem in one of the biggest narcotics rains in recent years were arraigned in Criminal Court yesterday.
CHICAGO, June 10 (AP)-- Although Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne have officially retired from their dominant positions in the American theater, they strode to center stage once again today.

ALDEBURGH, England, June 10--A strange and compelling new religious work by Benjamin Britten, "The Burning Fiery Furnace," is the centerpiece of the annual festival in and around this fishing village of East Anglia-Britten country.
LONDON, June 10 (AP)-- Donald E. Farr, president of H.B. Maynard Co., Inc., of Pittsburgh, management consultants, died while visiting the firm's London office today. He was 56 years old.

HOUSTON, June 10 (AP)-- Jim Wynn, the first Houston runner to reach second base against Ken Holtzman tonight, scored on Bob Aspromonte's single in the 10th inning, giving the Astros a 1-0 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 10--The Electoral Law Commission has proposed that seats in the constituent Assembly that is to be elected on Sept. 11 be allotted so that anti-Government Buddhists are not discriminated against. An analysis of the apportionment plan submitted by the commission shows ...
The Midland-Ross Corporation, a Cleveland manufacturer of automotive and railroad equipment, announced the election yesterday of William T. Marston as a vice president.

HAMILTON, N.Y., June 10 (AP)--Ron Goldman of Georgetown defeated Paul Dezeeuw of Florida State, 6-2, 12-10, today to retain the singles title in the Eastern intercollegiate tennis tournament. Rain forced officials to limit the final to twoof-three sets.
Gamble-Skogmo, Inc., one of the nation's leading merchandisers, is making a move to get back into the grocery business and expand its Eastern market.
WASHINGTON, June 10-- Intercity truck tonnage in the Memorial Day holiday week ended June 4 was 6 per cent ahead of the corresponding period last year.
JIDDA, Saudi Arabia--Westerners usually suffer a sharp cultural shock when they arrive in Saudi Arabia; and many who live here seem to recover very slowly.

The Bureau of Customs will open an inspection and appraisal office at Port Newark on Sept. 1. Announcement of the decision to establish the facility was made yesterday by the Port of New York Authority.
WASHINGTON, June 10-- Mayor Lindsay came away from a conference with Federal antipoverty officials today without an extra penny for the New York City program.

SYRACUSE, June 10 (UPI) --The State Social Welfare Board was ordered today to show cause why it should not be enjoined from implementing New York's plan for aiding the medically indigent. It was the first court action brought against the new controversial law.
The Blackstone Cigar Company gave housewives as well as its stockholders what it hoped would be good news yesterday.
NEWPORT, R.I., June 11 (AP) George F. Johnson's 64foot sloop Challenge was the first to finish the 220-mile Corinthian Cup race from Cape May. N.J., to Newport today.

SHORT HILL, N.J., June 11 The engagement of Miss Susan Roberts, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Richard H. Roberts, to Robert Miller Crosby, son of Mrs. Kenneth H. Crosby of Wayland, Mass., and the late Mr. Crosby, has been announced by the future bride's parents.

PHILADELPHIA, June 11-- Miss Charlotte Edna Horner was married today to Dr. William Henry Adler 3d in the Roman Catholic Church of Our Mother of Consolation. The Rev. John F. Casey performed the ceremony.

A valet, maid, butler, laundress and dog walker will be among the staff of 54 persons who will serve the 334 tenant-owners in the twin 38-story towers of the cooperative nearing completion at 860-90 United Nations Plaza, near the headquarters of the United Nations.

Now that the National and American Football Leagues have joined forces, in a way that is supposed to guarantee prosperity for all concerned except greedy bonus-seekers, it is time to call attention to the next logical step.
Arthur Ashe of Richmond, the nation's second-ranking tennis star, said last night he would be called into military service June 23.
The Continental Football League postponed the stocking of its new Brooklyn franchise yesterday, then named a threeman expansion committee to investigate applications from five cities.
Bob Lacey, a flanker and Glen Condren, a defensive tackle, have signed their 1966 contracts with the New York Giants of the National Football League.
THE leisurely two- or three-month cruise around the world is as popular today as it was in the 1920's and 1930's.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, June 11 Just after dawn the helicopters of the InterAmerican Peace Force begin thundering up from the polo field on the outskirts of the city for supply or observation missions along the verdant coast or into the mountainous interior.

GREENVILLE, Del., June 11 Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Ridgely du Pont have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Genevieve Livingston du Pont, to William Howell Taylor Gilmour of Wilmington. He is the son of Matthew Pollock Cailmour of New York and Mrs. Frances H. Gilmour of Wilmington.

New England job prosperity and manpower shortage went hand in hand during the first quarter. These were part of a belated but sharp rise in the economy compared with a year ago, when inflationary strains were just beginning to appear.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., June 11 Jacqui Zuccaro, a dark-haired teen-ager from Oradell, N.J., rode her 9-yearold chestnut gelding, The Delegate, to the regular working hunter championship today at the Helping Hand horse show.

SUZANNE SZASZ uses a Rolleiflex, available light and ingenuity, her subject is children and her results are enviable. What she has learned in years of experience is now within reach of anyone with a camera, especially parents, and the readiness to follow her simple instructions and counsel.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 11 Miss Adele Katte Merrill, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Dudley Merrill, was married today to Wilford Hitchcock Welch, son of Mr. and Mrs. G. Harold Welch of Mount Carmel, Conn.
What may be the longest and most controversial route case in its history will be opened by the Civil Aeronautics Board in Washington on June 15.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), June 11 "Every time we went to Washington to talk about arms," an Israeli Government official said this week, "the Americans had a stock answer: 'Don't worry, there is always the Sixth Fleet.'"

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 11 Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson of Canada urged here tonight that the United States lead the way in establishing a new, revitalized Atlantic alliance to replace what he described as the outdated North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

IN "Two Under the Indian Sun, Jon and Rumer Godden, the wellknown British novelists who are sisters, have fused their very different talents and temperaments to write together, with one pen, a memoir of the childhood years they spent more than half a century ago in India. Time has not dulled the sheen of their memories. "We were lucky," they say.
LLOYD HABOR, L.I., June 11 The police headquarters for this village's nine-man department was destroyed early today by a fire apparently caused by a bottle of gasoline that was thrown against it.
WASHINGTON, June 11 The poor pay more for food than consumers in higher income areas, the Government reported today.

Allain Onuska made his vacation plans early because this year it would be special. His family was coming to New York from his native France for a long-delayed reunion. But the Vietnam war changed that.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y.--The mementos of the most massive invasion this state has ever known still exist throughout a 12,000-square-mile area in these northern parts. By conservative estimate, they will be there forever.
WASHINGTON, June 11 Recapitalization of the financial structure of the American merchant marine was urged here today by the head of one of the nation's largest passenger and cargo shipping lines.

FAIRFIELD, Iowa, June 11 (AP) The House Republican Leader, Gerald R. Ford of Michigan, said today that the Administration was not doing all it could to hold down casualities in Vietnam and end the war.

DENVER My nostalgic fondness for train travel is not archaic. Bargain-hunting was the disease that prompted me to take a delightful 5,669mile trip Colorado to Florida and New York, and return but a strong aversion to sitting up all night led me into finding ways of sleeping comfortably at the least expense.

PHOTOGRAPHY has discovered a new kind of sponsor, the banking institution. For some years, banks have been giving space to photographic exhibitions in their street winddows and lobbies, and the trend has been growing. Last week, their patronage of the medium took a new and substantial turn.

WASHINGTON, June 11-- The supply situation in Vietnam is "so bad," a marine corporal recently wrote his Congressman, "that some of the guys are writing Sears and asking for a tent, as the troops can't get them."

KANSAS CITY, June 11 (AP) The president of the American Academy of General Practice today urged physicians to bill their Medicare patients "in the usual and customary manner" and let patients collect from the Social Security Administration.

ALL the officers and all but two of the directors have resigned from the Skye Terrier Club of America because of the failure of the American Kennel Club to include in the breed standard a stipulation that parti-colored coats be a disqualifying fault.

THE traditional crowned eagle of Poland, in white lights a red shield, high lights a design by Edmund D. Lewandowski for the American postal tribute to the Polish Millennium. The millennium, which Poland is observing this year, marks the 1,000th anniversary of the adoption of Chirstianity there.

Elston Howard and Joe Pepitone hit home runs as the New York Yankees beat the Tigers, 6-3, yesterday at Detroit. The New York Mets shut out the Cincinnati Reds, 4-0, in the opener of a double-header, then lost the second, 5-2, in 10 innings after being within one out of a 2-0 victory.

SAIGON, Sunday, June 12 (AP) The United States First Infantry Division virtually wiped out a company of Vietcong troops in heavy fighting yesterday in plantation country about 75 miles northwest of Saigon, a United States military spokesman said today.
MADISON, Wis., June 11 (AP) Navy withstood a stretch drive by Wisconsin today to beat the Badgers in a 1 -mile crew race on windtossed Lake Mendota.
A mugging suspect who was killed by a Brooklyn policeman shortly before midnight on Friday was identified yesterday as William Moultrie, 21 years old, of 560 Greene Avenue, Brooklyn.

LOS ANGELES, June 6 It is called the Doctors Building. It is a new, ultramodern, three-story professional offices building overlooking a riotravaged commercial strip along 103d Street of Watts that still has the appearance of a bombedout European city of World War II.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 11 Miss Toni Marie Bornemann, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alfred Bornemann of Montclair and Nantucket, Mass., was married this afternoon to Martin McKerrow, son of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent S. McKerrow of Park Ridge, Ill.
NEW HAVEN, June 11 Miss Carol Adele Schaaf was married this morning in the Dwight Chapel of Yale University to Richard Lee Heppner.
A waterfront colony with its own private yacht club and beach club is now under development on Northport Bay, on Long Island's north shore.

SCOTLAND NECK, N.C., June 11 Mr. and Mrs. Eric Winfred Rodgers have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Suzanne Croft Rodgers, to John Sampson Bush Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bush of St. Louis.

CHICAGO, June 11 (AP) San Diego State accounted for two of seven meet records in amassing 67 points today to repeat as team champion in the National Collegiate college division track and field tests at Stagg Field.

When Michael W. Leisure became the newest Assistant United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York the other day he stepped into a slot that had been held by his father and his two older brothers. Sworn in last Monday, Mr. Leisure, who is, 31 years old, will work in the Criminal Division.

THIS novel by the Argentinean writer Beatriz Guido, her second to be published in this country, is set in Buenos Aires, during the later days of Juan Peron's rule. Its protagonists, the wealthy and aristocratic Pradere family, and the revolutionary student Pablo Alcobendas, have in common only their hatred of the peronista regime.

CLIMBING hydrangea (H. petiolaris) is per haps the most distinguished clinging woody ornamental vine. There is an old specimen growing over the north end of the stone house where I live. Every summer the vine is covered with spectacular bloom that always arouses appreciative comment, but visitors invariably look askance when told the vine is a climbing hydrangea.
LIME ROCK, Conn., June 11 Bob Sharp of Wilton, Conn., and Bob Akroyd of Warwick, R.I., set class records for the course in Area One championship races at Lime Rock Park today.

CLEVELAND, June 11 (AP) Sam McDowell of Cleveland gained his first victory today since May 1, but needed relief help from Bob Allen and Dick Radatz in the Indians' 6-4 victory over the Washington Senators.

The Commerce and Industry Association of New York warned yesterday that there might be strikes by public employes in the near future if the Legislature failed to pass an effective substitute for the Condon-Wadlin Law.
EAST ORANGE, N.J., June 11 John Mangan of Pelham, N.Y., swept into the fourth round of the New Jersey state tennis championship at the East Orange Club today.

AFTER visiting Tokyo in 1956, Benjamin Britten was haunted by the memory of a 15th-cen tury Japanese No play that he had seen. Called "Sumidagawa," it told in slow-moving style a simple tale of a madwoman in search of her lost child. It was played by an all-male cast, which chanted, spoke and sang to the accompaniment of three instruments. Chorus and musicians sat onstage; there was no scenery nor special lighting.
The marriage of Miss Robin Gorham to David Auchincloss of New York took place in St. John's Anglican Church in Pembroke, Bermuda, yesterday afternoon. The Rev. Jack Peale performed the ceremony.
CHICAGO, June 11 (UPI) Irving Crane of Rochester ran a string of 150 tonight to win the national open pocket billiards championship.

THIS Portuguese novel introduces to American readers for the first time the work of one of Brazil's outstanding novelists, Jose Lins do Rego, who died in 1957. Lins do Rego wrote mainly about the Northeast a region of Brazil analogous in many ways to the North American South. Like our South, it was once the scene of a plantation economy manned by slaves imported from Africa.
CATANIA, Italy, June 11 (UPI) A loud rumbling from the Etna volcano today rattled window panes in suburbs of this Sicilian city of 360,000 and sent hundreds fleeing to the streets.

WILMINGTON, N.C. One can follow either bank of the Cape Fear River south from here to the Atlantic Ocean. Until a few months ago, however, it was not possible to make a circular tour from Wilmington down the Cape and return without retracing one's steps.

WARREN, Conn., June 11 The marriage of Miss Patricia Gould, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton S. Gould of Warren and New York, to Francis Booth took place here this afternoon. The bridegroom is a son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Edwin P. Booth of Islington, Mass.

MENDOZA, Argentina--Just east of the Chilean border, along the highest ridge of the Andes, snow-covered peaks drop off to steep, grassy slopes, terminating in a dry plateau on the edge of the vast Argentine pampas.

HARTFORD, June 11 The Union Boat Club of Boston won its first team trophy in history today by capturing the eightoared and four-oared shell events in the first annual junior championship regatta of the New England Amateur Rowing Association on the Connecticut River.

VALHALLA, N.Y., June 11 Blythedale, a children's hospital on Bradhursst Avenue here has announced a $3.5-million expansion program. The institution is a member of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York.

MORE than a half million visitors are ex pected to attend the 35th annual Rose Festival sponsored by the Jackson Perkins Company which begins Friday. In full bloom in the 17-acre gardens in Newark, N.Y., will be 36,000 roses of all types. Highlights of the nine-day event are the introduction of the Bob Hope hybrid tea and the 1966 Rose of the Year, Mexicana, on opening day, a Sunrise Service at 8:30 A.M.
MOSCOW, June 11 (AP) Two Americans were among 14 musicians chosen by a Moscow jury today to take part in the final round of the Tehaikovsky International Competition for violinists.

The eldest son of an eldest son of an eldest son stood on the sweeping lawn of an olds manor house on a high hilltop in the Monmouth County, N.J., horse and fox-hunting country and spoke of a way of life that is gradually vanishing.
Temperatures here dipped to 53 degrees yesterday and rose to only the average low for a June 11.
BATESVILLE, Miss., June 11 The civil rights march through Mississippi sparked new political interest today among Negroes in Panola County.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 11 Secretary General Thant told the Security Council today that tension in Cyprus was growing rather than diminishing and might erupt into general violence.

GENEVA, June 11 Washington is preparing new arms control proposals that it hopes to present at the session of the Disarmament Conference that opens here Tuesday, William C. Foster, the United States delegate, said today.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 11 Frederick H. Ungerer, chairman of the board of Ungerer Company, New York, manufacturers of fragrances and flavors, died today in his home at 160 Park Street. He was 88 years old.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 11 Tradition, a yawl owned by Robert Rullon Miller of Bristol, R.I., took first place in Class A-1 today after two days of racing in the spring event of the Off Soundings Club.

ST. LOUIS, June 11 (UPI) The St. Louis Cardinals have received requests for more than 100,000 tickets for the major league All-Star game to be played in the new 50,000 seat Busch Memorial Stadium in downtown St. Louis.
The City Planning Commission made even more remote last week the already faint possibility that a new Stock Exchange might some day rise on the Battery.

CHICAGO, June 11 Maj. Gen. George William Hickman Jr., U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Hickman have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Anne Hickman, to Richard, Stanley Wirtz, son of W. Willard Wirtz, the Secretary of Labor, and Mrs. Wirtz.
Miss Deborah Louise Bertsch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick C. Bertsch Jr. of Brooklyn Heights, was married yesterday afternoon to Ellis Mane Jones Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Jones of Bethesda, Md.

Dennis Ribant pitched a strong five-hit shutout against the Cincinnati Reds to give the, Mets a 4-0 victory last night in the first of two games. Rob Gardner continued the shutout pitching for the Mets for eight innings against the Reds before the dam broke and, despite the establishment of a club pitching record, the Mets lost the second game, 5-2, in 10 innings before 43,967 persons at Shea Stadium.

COPENHAGEN. WHY do people run ballet companies? Why don't they settle for something simple like training man-eating tigers? Thoughts such as these are possibly scudding desultorily around the mind of Flemming Flindt, who has just completed his first session as head of the Royal Danish Ballet. This is not an easy job. The Royal Danish Ballet will be in Copenhagen as long as the green copper domes, and so will the Royal Danish Ballet's problems.

WHEN Johann Sebastian Bach died 1750, he did not die alone. The golden age of organ music died with him, never apparently to be revived. It would have vanished sooner had Bach not been an anachronistic composer in his own time. The classical esthetic was aborning long before his death, and its emphasis was on melody and accompaniment rather than contrapuntal structure, which was one of the glories of Baroque musical art.

Miss Susan Day Jones, daughter of Mrs. MacDonald Jones of New York and Hingham, Mass., and William Alden Jones of Chestnut Hill, Mass., was married yesterday to Thomas Foster Beech. He is the son of Mrs. Raymond H. Beech of St. Paul and the late Dr. Beech.

JAPANESE stone lanterns are not new in American gardens. But, until recent years they have been displayed only in gardens of Japanese design together with pagodas, arched bridges and stepping stones typical of the oriental plan. Lately, however, American gardeners have become aware of the decorative possibilities afforded by stone lanterns and more and more of them are being seen as features in both public and private gardens.

WASHINGTON, June 11 Postmaster General Lawrence F.O'Brien, who is admired for his knack of making friends, sent his 650,000 employes a message the other day that began: "Shoddy postal service will not be tolerated."
LONDON, June 11 (Reuters) Graham Taylor, a 21-year-old Briton running his first marathon, today won the annual Windsor to Chiswick race with an incredible last-lap sprint.

It might seem strange to associate the production of soda ash with the state of the American economy, but the president of the Diamond Alkali Company, Arthur B. Tillman, says there is a definite connection.

HOLLYWOOD, June 11 (AP) Wallace Ford, the craggyfaced character actor who appeared in Broadway plays and in more than 200 motion pictures, died today of heart disease at the Motion Picture Country House and Hospital in suburban Woodland Hills. He was 68 years old.
The City Planning Commission will start the long process this week of mapping the permanent boundaries of the community planning boards.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Jnue 11 The Larchmont Avenue Presbyterian. Church was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Susan Logan Stirling, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S. Logan Stirling, to Jonathan Edwards Clark, son of Mrs. Charles R. Hook of Oyster Bay, L. I., and Raymond S. Clark of Havre de Grace, Md.

Representatives Jonathan B. Bingham and James H. Scheuer, Bronx Reform Democrats, have been accused of trying to get their names on the June 28 primary ballot even though they are unopposed for renomination.

DEDHAM, Mass., June 11 Miss Teresa Reece, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin A. Reece Jr., was married today to Ian S. Michie of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. James K. Michie of London and Aldeburgh, Suffolk, England.

GROSSE POINTE, Mich., Tune 11 Miss Janet Anna Hobbs and David Alan Norton were married here today in the Barbour Chapel of the Grosse Pointe Memorial Church. The Rev. Gary Gurber performed the Presbyterian ceremony.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 11 A former Secretary of the Army and an Illinois judge have been elected to four-year terms as alumni trustees of Princeton University officials of the Princeton National Alumni Association reported at the association's annual reunion weekend meeting today.
MONTREAL, June 11 The effects of the longshoremen's strike, which has paralyzed three principal St. Lawrence River ports since May 9, are seriously being felt here.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 11 Dr. John Kenneth Galbraith, a former Ambassador to India, criticized Administration policy in Vietnam and urged reduction of military action there in a commencement address at Rhode Island College here today.

While the American book world has been droning quietly through the late spring, its British counterpart has been acting as though beset by the furies. Life has been wild over there, one acrimonious discussion following another.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla. Camping in Florida is becoming so popular that it is almost impos sible for the Florida Park Service to keep up with the demand for campgrounds in state parks. In the last 12 years, there has been a 2,000 per cent increase in camping in the state.

JERSEY CITY, June 11 Paying their own transportation and living costs, nine St. Peter's College students will work 10 weeks this summer with the poor of Martin County, Ky., the heart of the Appalachian poverty belt.

Twenty-eight per cent of the nonwhite children living in families in New York City are in homes with only one parent, according to a report to be issued tomorrow by the Community Council of Greater New York. The report says that 8 per cent of the white children are in similar homes.
BANGKOK, Thailand, June 11 Is Southeast Asia outside war-torn Vietnam and its neighbors really moving toward harmony and regional cooperation?
LONDON, June 11 The United States has told Britain that it would like her to remain in the European space program.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., June 11 (UPI) Four robed members Of the Ku Klux Klan left here today on a 90-mile march to Washington to "force the Justice Department to deal out justice equally."

Time and prices will be rolled back in Central Park June 22 for the opening of the 49th season of Guggenheim Memorial concerts by the Goldman Band. Everyone, both the public and civic dignitaries, includ ing Mayor Lindsay, is invited to c me in clothing typical of 1917, the year of the first Guggenheim Central Park concerts.

BALTIMORE, June 11 The Congress of Racial Equality, groping here for a new role and a new avenue to "direct confrontation" with a "racist" community, is finding its national "target city" of 1966 a segregated but conciliatory and elusive quarry.

When Edgar Tafel, a Greenwith Village architect, set out to design a new church for a growing Lutheran congregation in Deer Park, L.I., he was faced with a problem inherent in the times; a site ringed with the crowding commercialism of suburbia.

NORTHFIELD, Ill., June 11 Mr. and Mrs. Charles Arthur Huebner have anounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Elizabeth Huebner of Cambridge, Mass., to L. Webb Jenckes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marcien Jenckes of Brookline, Mass.
WESTBURY, L.I., June 11 "He's coming back, Chappie's coming back." Jimmy Michaels screamed from the paddock at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 11 Miss Margaret Iona Silliman was married this evening to Ens. William Harry Hawley 3d, U.S.C.G., in the Memorial Chapel of the Coast Guard Academy. Donald Allmann's 45-foot ketch Lovely Lady from the Sea Cliff Yacht Club was the scratch boat yesterday as 37 boats entered the 13th edition of the Bayside Yacht Club's point-to-point 65-mile overnight race.

PARIS General de Gaulle is the most imaginative and methodical statesman now practicing although his ruthless methods inspire fury. Another big name has been wiped off the Brazilian political slate Adhemar de Barros, Governor of the State of Sao Paulo the New York State of Brazil. Along with them have gone hundreds of politicians, professors, economists, writers and lesser figures.

The Sheppard case has long been one of the scandals of American jurisprudence and journalism. A complaisant judge, irresponsible police officials and a sensationalist press combined to turn the trial of Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard, accused of murdering his wife in 1954, into a latter-day Roman circus. The Supreme Court has rectified that injustice by ordering the trial verdict set aside.

ALBANY, June 11 (AP) New York State's controversial plan to provide financial assistance to pay medical bills of families unable to pay such expenses has attracted more than 40,000 applications in its brief existence, the Social Welfare Department has reported.

JERSEY CITY, June 11 Jersey City scrapped its 15year-old Comprehensive Master Plan this week and started work on a new series of reports that will candidly assess the city's character and problems.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 11 Ground fighting in the Central Highlands, where American paratroops fought their way out of a trap this morning, was sporadic throughout the day, a military spokesman said here. VENICE, Italy One of the most spectacular automobile routes in Europe stretches from this city of canals to Innsbruck, Austria. It is a 210mile road on which the Alps and the Dolomites are never out of sight.

Discount retailing, after two decades in which it has transformed the ancient art of selling, is still a troubled industry. In 1966, discounters will transact about $14-billion in sales.
