JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 12--Indonesia's leaders are laying the groundwork for legally removing President Sukarno from office without precipitating a government crisis or civil war.

The band played "Yankee Doodle," 12 men dressed in Civil War Blues fired rounds of blanks from Springfield rifles and 17 descendants of Brig. Gen. James S. Wadsworth of the Union Army gathered on Staten Island yesterday to help open Fort Wadsworth's first military museum.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 12 (AP)--Juan Marichal of the San Francisco Giants stopped the Los Angeles Dodgers, 3-2, today on a four-hitter.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 12 --An Irish setter, Ch. Webline Rio Hondo, who was bought by Mrs. Cheever Porter of New York at the International Show in Chicago two months ago, was named best of the 1,512 dogs today at the 34th annual Longshore-Southport Kennel Club show on the spacious grounds of the Fairfield County Hunt Club.
American companies are hiring more Negroes but strides in Negro employment are still slow, the National Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday.
CAIRO, June 12--Senator Edward M. Kennedy has started an investigation into the distribution of United Nations rations to members of the Palestine Liberation Army, diplomatic sources disclosed today.

A curious and significant economic tug-of-war is taking place in Canada. While the Federal Government in Ottawa is trying to achieve a greater measure of economic independence from the United States, it is losing control over domestic economic policy to Canada's ten provincial administrations.
David Brower, executive director, of the Sierra Club of San Francisco, left here for Washington last night to fight to retain the conservationist group's tax privileges as a nonprofit organization.

TOKYO, June 12--Socialist opponents of Japan's mutual security treaty with the United States concede, in a party document published this weekend, that they have "started late" in planning to block an extension of the treaty when its 10year term expires in 1970.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 12 --Miss Marion Shelley Lancaster and Charles Michael Hampden-Turner were married at Christ Episcopal Church this evening by the Rev. John C. Snow.
MOSCOW, June 12--Nikita S. Khrushchev emerged fleetingly from the political shadows today to vote for the two unopposed candidates to the Supreme Soviet (Parliament) from his electoral districts.

ROSLYN HEIGHTS, L.I., June 12--Miss Kathryn Margules, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Seymour Margules, was married here this afternoon to Mark Leonard Winer, son of Dr. and Mrs. Harold Winer of Dallas. Rabbi Alvan Rubin performed the ceremony at Temple Sinai.

Jack I. Straus, chairman of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., announced over the weekend that James M. Lundy has been elected president of Macy's California. Mr. Lundy has been vice president and general merchandise manager of Macy's California division since 1961.
UPPER MARLBORO, Md., June 12--Mrs. Alfred A. LePine chose a brown toy poodle, Ch. Loramar's I'm a Dandee, best today of a field of 839 at the Upper Marlboro Kennel Club dog show and obedience trials.
The $2,000 Faculty Prize of the Harvard University Press for 1965-66 has been awarded to Don K. Price, dean of Harvard's Graduate School of Public Administration, for "The Scientific Estate."

GREENBELT, Md., June 12 --An unusual bid by civil rights and antipoverty partisians to take control of the country's largest consumer cooperative was overwhelmingly defeated today in this suburb of Washington.
HARTSDALE, N.Y., June 12 --J. William Reilly, vice president and secretary of the Canada Dry Corporation, died of a heart attack today at his home on Paret Lane here. He was 52 years old.
A 30-year-old woman and a 17-year-old girl were raped early yesterday on Riverside Drive and in Tudor City, the police reported. The assailants escaped.
Gert Keller, president of Schimmel Co., Inc., of Newburgh, N.Y., manufacturers of fragances and flavors, died Friday in Mexico, where he was on a business trip. He was 61 years old.

Anglo Fabrics, Inc., New York, a 27-year-old producer of high-fashion wool and woolblend fabrics, has elected a new president and is diversifying its operations to provide quality fabrics in various price lines.

WASHINGTON, June 12--A series of "hard-nosed" recommendations for solving the United States balance-of-payments problem emerged today from a major study by the International Economic Policy Association.

WASHINGTON, June 12--In Temple Sinai this afternoon, Miss Helene Schiff, daughter of Mrs. Philip Schiff of Bethesda, Md., and the late Mr. Schiff, was married to Eugene B. Granof, son of Mr. and Mrs. David H. Granof of New York.

DETROIT, June 12--The New York Yankees and Detroit Tigers split a double-header today that was marked by 10 home runs, 50 hits, 34 runs and, somewhere lost in the shuffle, the Yankee debut of Fred Talbot.
LONDON, June 12--Barbra Streisand topped the bill tonight in an extraordinary onenight stand at the United States Embassy in Grosvenor Square.

The National Conference for New Politics, composed of liberals and radical activists, announced yesterday that it would start an early search for a 1968 "Presidential candidate committed to peace in Vietnam."

CHICAGO, June 12 (AP)-- The Santa Fe Railway has asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to dismiss an application by the Missouri Pacific Railroad and the Mississippi River Corporation for permission to gain stock control of the Santa Fe.
HONG KONG, June 12--More than 50 people were dead or missing today following the worst flood in Hong Kong's history.

TANCANH, South Vietnam, June 12--First Sgt. Warren S. Eichelberger, his chin covered with dirty whiskers and his boots covered with mud, had just spent 48 hours on a hill in Kontum Province helping to fight off North Vietnamese assaults. "Believe me," he said today, "this thing is far from over. The worst is...

EAST ORANGE, N.J., June 12--Peter Fishbach of Great Neck, L.I., the defender, and Bob Barker of Port Washington, L.I., a former winner, opened play with two victories each today in the New Jersey State men's singles tennis championships at the East Orange Tennis Club.

TWENTY-FOUR-YEAROLD Thomas Lux of Cali- fornia, sweeping all opposition by 7-0, won the recent annual United States Amateur Chess Championship, an event that drew 215 players from every part of the nation. The seven-round Swiss-system tournament was played at the Henry Hudson Hotel here.

SAMUEL JACKSON SNEAD, the millionaire hillbilly, will be adding to his bankroll with exhibitions and other money-making activities this week. But he will not be competing in the United States Open at San Francisco. The Slammer struck out in the qualifying trials, thereby varying his procedure in much more abrupt fashion than normal.
TENAFLY, N.J., June 12-- Miss Barbara Ann Neuman and Samuel Masket were married here this afternoon in Temple Sinai by Rabbi Irwin M. Blank.
BOQUILLAS, Tex., June 12 (AP)--Fifteen New Mexico boy scouts and their leader were found safe on a ranch in Mexico today after having been missing since Friday on a raft trip down the Rio Grande.
NEW DELHI, June 12 (AP) --Prime Minister Indira Gandhi declared today that a crippling economic crisis had thrust India into her most crucial period since independence 19 years ago.

JACKSON, Miss., June 12 (AP)--Medgar Evers, slain three years ago today in the heat of civil rights struggles, was commemorated today in a city where Negroes no longer are barred from white schools, movies and the front of the bus.
PITTSBURGH, June 12 (AP) --The Pittsburgh Pirates scored five runs in the first inning and four in the third as they set back the Atlanta Braves today, 11-8.

Three of five teen-agers involved in a paint-throwing incident in front of the Soviet Mission to the United Nations were paroled yesterday in Manhattan Weekend Court for a hearing on July 11 on charges of disorderly conduct.
The creation of a coordinator's office and a development corporation to bring order to the rapid, unplanned growth of Staten Island has been proposed by the City Planning Commission.
ALAN BURKE, the bearded baiter of Channel 5, must have had an off-night on Saturday evening. The quality of his insults was distinctly disappointing.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 12--Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, Foreign Minister of Pakistan, hinted today that Pakistan would consider resuming diplomatic relations with Malaysia after Indonesia and Malaysia settled their dispute.
HOUSTON, June 11 (AP)-- Home runs by John Bateman, Rusty Staub and Dave Nicholson powered the Houston Astros to an 8-4 victory over the Chicago Cubs today.

BOSTON, June 12--At 3:07 o'clock yesterday morning, sandwiches and soft drinks were broken out in Room 201 of the War Memorial Auditorium and something that was unmistakably a smile crossed the normally inscrutable countenance of Kenneth P. O'Donnell.
The necessity for an airline pilot to possess, in addition to technical skill, the qualities of "prudence, judgment and care" was stressed by the Civil Aeronautics Board last week.
PITTSBURGH, June 12--To steel men last week, 1966 was starting to shape up as an almost perfect market year.

Miss Elizabeth Page Welsh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Winfield Welsh Jr. of Forest Hills, Queens, was married yesterday to Second Lieut. Charles Paul Ahnell Jr., U.S.A.R. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ahnell of Huntington, L.I.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 12 --Juscelino Kubitschek, former President, whose ambitions were thwarted by the present revolutionary government, made a thinly disguised bid today for liberal United States opinion to come to his political aid.
COLUMBUS, Ga.--Army wives would like to see more of two things--money and their husbands.
Dr. Max Spiegel, a general practitioner for 57 years, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived at 255 West 98th Street, where he maintained his office.
CHICAGO, June 12--A crowd rioted against the police for five hours in a predominantly Puerto Rican neighborhood here tonight after a policeman had shot a Puerto Rican youth.
KINGSTON, R.I., June 12 --For the first time in the memory of its president, the University of Rhode Island had no major speaker at its commencement exercises, which were held here today.

Deputy Mayor Timothy W. Costello, a former professor of psychology at N.Y.U., is recruiting an unpaid Council of Psychologists to concentrate on such major city problems as crime, addiction and alcoholism. Dr. Costello also wants some of them to observe meetings of city officials, including Mayor Lindsay's cabinet, in order to "contribute to increased rationalization of decision-making in municipal government."
GRAND BLANC, Mich., June 12--Phil Rodgers, who was uncertain whether he would be able to play here, won the $100,000 Buick open golf tournament today.

LONDON, June 12--The 300,000 to 400,000 American stockholders in British companies will be paying less taxes soon to the British Government. There is to be a reduction in the withholding tax rate on dividends paid by British companies to Americans from the present 41 per cent to 15 per cent.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 12--"If we are to master our current problems we must develop an ever closer relationship between the scientific tradition, on the one hand, and the humanistic tradition on the other," Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson of Canada said today.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 12 (UPI)--Mickey Wright shot her third consecutive subpar round over the Hunting Creek Country Club course today and won the $10,000 Bluegrass open golf tournament with a sixunder-par 210.

FLORENCE, Italy, June 12 (AP)--The German conductor Hermann Scherchen died today in a Florence clinic at the age of 74. He suffered a heart attack Tuesday night while conducting the Gianfrancesco Malipiero opera "Orpheus" at the Pergola Theater.
CHICAGO, June 12--Maurice H. Needham, a long-time advertising man and the founder of Needham, Louis Brorby, Inc., died yesterday at his home in Woodstock of a heart ailment. He was 77 years old.

EAST LANSING, Mich., June 12 (UPI)--Vice President Humphrey, speaking at Michigan State University's graduation ceremonies today was greeted by a small group of 70 peace demonstrators carrying placards reading, "Hubert Humphrey master of war."

BALTIMORE, June 12 (AP) --Brooks Robinson knocked in two runs and set up another score with alert base running today as the Baltimore Orioles defeated the Boston Red Sox, 8-1, behind Steve Barber's fivehit pitching.

Physicians face an unrelenting barrage of advertising by drug companies urging them to prescribe their brands, but the effect on patient care is not nearly so important as a high Federal official has charged.

POZNAN, Poland, June 12 (UPI)----Gov. Edward T. Breathitt of Kentucky defeated Premier Jozef Cyrankiewicz of of Poland today in a brief bowling engagement at the American pavilion at the Poznan trade fair.

A monthly series of two-hour television versions of Broadway plays will be presented in color by the American Broadcasting Company, beginning in the fall of 1967. The production budget for each show will be $625,000, an unusually high cost for drama on a regular basis.

PHILADELPHIA, June 12-- Mr. and Mrs. George Morris Piersol Jr. of Chestnut Hill have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jean McKenzie Piersol, to William Harlowe Miller Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Miller of Lloyd Harbor, Huntington, L.I.
YUMA, Ariz., June 12 (UPI) --Six persons were killed early today in a head-on collision 34 miles east of here on U.S. 80.
BALTIMORE, June 12 (AP)--The Baltimore Orioles acquired Eddie Fisher, a relief pitcher, from the Chicago White Sox today in a trade for the Baltimore second baseman, Jerry Adair.

London, June 12--South Arabia's Foreign Minister, Mohammed Farid, said here today that he would ask the United States to underwrite the security of South Arabia when it becomes independent of Britain in 1968.

BATESVILLE, Miss., June 12--Leaders of the Mississippi civil rights march began shaping plans today for a sweeping detour that would lengthen their march by a week and carry them deep into the state's plantation region.
Plans for the largest summer program of study and recreational activities in the city school system's history--nearly double the size of last year's-- were announced yesterday.

DALLAS, June 12--Mayor Lindsay, calling for a "fresh assault" on unemployment in New York, announced today that the city would make a door-to-door survey of the jobless and establish neighborhood employment centers covering "every part of the city that needs them."

SPA, Belgium, June 12--John Surtees, a roly-poly Englishman who has a way with fast motorcycles and cars, won today the Grand Prix of Belgium, an auto race that lost more than half of its competitors before it had hardly begun.
Mayor Lindsay is a free agent in only one respect in the city's financial crisis, which grows worse by the minute. For the imposition of new taxes he has to depend on Albany.
CHICAGO, June 12 (AP)-- Ceasar Tovar raced home in the eighth inning today while Floyd Robinson, the Chicago right fielder, held the ball and Tovar's ...

CAIRO, June 12--Iraq's Foreign Minister expressed hope today for improving his country's relations with Syria but he said it was "premature" to speak now of a conference of five radical Arab states, which the Syrians are promoting.
Rodney Laver is the champion VASSS tennis player of the world.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 12 --Patty Heuckeroth, daughter of the Ox Ridge Hunt Club manager, Otto Heuckeroth, captured the green working hunter championship and was reserve in the regular section today in the Greenwich horse show.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., June 12 --Senator Jacob K. Javits proposed today that the United States agree to stop sending additional troops into South Vietnam in return for a pledge by North Vietnam to halt the infiltration of its soldiers into South Vietnam.
CHICAGO, June 12 (AP)-- A drop in earnings despite record sales was reported today by Swift Co., the meat packers and producer of feeds and chemicals, for the six months ended April 30.
Richardson-Merrell, Inc., announced over the weekend that its house agency for Vick products would be dissolved and its $8-million in billings reassigned.

London, June 12 (AP)-- Union leaders persuaded shortvoyage seamen in Dover today to continue their support of Britain's maritime strike. But the split between these coastal seamen and deep-sea men appeared to be widening.

Despite a strong plea for restraint by Stanley S. Surrey, the Treasury's tax expert, the House has voted a big tax concession to self-employed persons setting up retirement plans. Under present law self-employed persons can place up to $2,500 a year in pension plans and deduct half of that amount from taxable income.
LANGHORNE, Pa., June 12-- Mario Andretti continued his spectacular record-setting pace today in winning the 100-mile United States Auto Club championship race on the Langhorne Speedway.
Seven new members of the board of directors of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau have been elected, including the first woman ever to serve.
The Bulova Watchmakers upset the University of Illinois Gizz Kids, 126 -71, to win the team title in the annual national Wheelchair Games here yesterday.

The shooting last week of James H. Meredith in Mississippi provided the major theme yesterday for several outdoor rallies throughout the city as civil rights leaders called for intensified Negro voting registration.
GLADSTONE, N.J., June 12 --Kevin Freeman of Portland, Ore., captured the national open three-day equestrian championship today on Royal Imp. But he refused to take full credit for the triumph.
PARIS, June 12 (Reuters)-- A Vietnamese Buddhist monk, fasting to protest United States policy in his country, called it off the hunger strike tonight on orders from superiors in Vietnam.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 12 --The marriage of Miss Anne Chi-fang Wang to James Reeve Pusey, son of Nathan M. Pusey, president of Harvard University, and Mrs. Pusey, took place this afternoon. The Rev. Charles P. Price, an Episcopal minister and preacher to the university, performed the ceremony in the Appleton Chapel of Harvard's Memorial Church.

NEW HAVEN, June 12-- Kingman Brewster Jr., the president of Yale University, sharply criticized the Administration today for its "persistent refusal to take the lead" in designing a fairer system of military draft.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 12--Former Gov. Robert B. Meyner said flatly today that he would not accept the Democratic nomination to run in November against United States Senator Clifford P. Case. Mr. Case, a liberal Republican, is seeking a third term.
WASHINGTON, June 12-- Medicare is leading more than 7,000 hospitals in the nation into vast changes in their operations.

WALTHAM, Mass., June 12 --About 165 graduating students and 65 faculty members pinned white ribbons to their black academic robes today in protest against an honorary degree for Arthur J. Goldberg, chief United States Representative at the United Nations, at Brandeis University's 15th commencement.

Hundreds of riders carrying dogs, children and lunch boxes in baskets yesterday wheeled bicycles through Central Park's east and west drives as a ban on Sunday morning vehicular traffic in the park went into effect. The Sunday auto ban will be maintained until colder weather in the fall.
The leasehold of 40 Wall Street, the 71-story office building between Nassau and William Streets, has been sold to Carl M. Loeb, Rhoades Co., a tenant in the building, and a group of associates.
BETHPAGE, L.I., June 12-- Bethpage and Westbury resumed their polo rivalry at Bethpage State Park today and Bethpage scored a 6-4 victory.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 12--A comparison of recent Soviet and Rumanian statements on military blocs indicates that a compromise has been reached on this issue.

CLEVELAND, June 12 (AP) --Chico Salmon's third hit of the game, a run-producing single, capped a three-run seventh inning uprising today that carried the league-leading Cleveland Indians to a 6-3 victory over the Washington Senators.

The resignation of Albert A. Lawrence as Dean of the State University Maritime College, Fort Schuyler, the Bronx, was announced yesterday by Vice Admiral Harold C. Moore (Coast Guard ret.), president of the college.

SAN ONOFRE, Calif.-- "Those swallows that come back to Capistrano every spring have a new place to nest," Bill Shu, an engineer for the Bechtel Corporation, said, pointing to the turbine crane that looms above the outdoor generator being assembled here on the shores of the Pacific Ocean.
HELSINKI, Finland, June 12 --President Urho K. Kekkonen, who pursues a policy of neutrality and friendship with the Soviet Union, plays host tomorrow to Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin.

PASADENA, Calif., June 12 (UPI)--Surveyor 1, America's Lunar robot, sent back to earth today 1,362 more pictures of the moon, raising its total to 8,494. The photographs were received at the Goldstone Tracking Station in the Mojave Desert about 100 miles east of here.

The Metropolitan Opera has set a $250 top for the opening night of its new house at Lincoln Center. That price will apply in rows A through M of the orchestra for the world premiere of Samuel Barber's "Antony and Cleopatra" on Sept. 16.

ROBERT FROST was nature's gift to newspaper and magazine editors, reporters, photographers and radio people. For one, he was very photogenic. As Milton Bracker wrote in this newspaper, he looked like a sage.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 11-- "Detail men" in the pharmaceutical trade are salesmen who are generally paid commissions for persuading physicians to write prescriptions using the drugs produced by their employers.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP)--The Government plans to begin testing cigarettes for tar and nicotine content at a new laboratory within 60 days, Senator Warren G. Magnuson, Democrat of Washington, said tonight.

Dr. Shepard Shapiro, a diagnostician and a specialist in diseases of the blood, died of a heart attack yesterday in his home at 19 East 88th Street. He was 69 years old and had retired five years ago.
BASEL, Switzerland, June 12 --Central bankers of the major industrial powers have agreed on a new arrangement to support Britain's ailing pound once again, informed sources said today.
TORONTO, June 12--A year after the collapse of the Atlantic Acceptance Corporation, repercussions are still being felt in the Canadian economy.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 12--Premier Nguyen Cao Ky abruptly canceled tonight his plans to travel to South Korea for a conference of Asian foreign ministers this week.
The Fugs, a rock 'n' roll sextet quite unlike any other, brought its outrageous songs of sex and satire to Town Hall last night.

Mayor Lindsay, City Council officials and leaders of the Legislature will converge on Albany today, in an air of uncertainty and some distrust, to make a crucial effort at breaking the impasse over a tax program for New York City.

SAN JUAN, P.R., June 12 (AP)--Mexico took two gold medals in swimming, but Puerto Rico gained the lead in the unofficial team scoring as the 10th Central American and Caribbean Games began in sunny weather today.

Bill's Rough Riders, a lunch spot facing Newark's West Side High School, looks like an ordinary hash and coffee place. It has eight stools at a counter and a few tables. A jukebox throbs with wild, atonal rhythms. The menu majors in french-fried potatoes and other items that plead for catsup.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., June 12--Miss Mary Edith Sabatini, daughter of Judge Robert V. Sabatini of the New York Civil Court and Mrs. Sabatini of New York and Long Beach, was married this afternoon to Joseph F. Carlino Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Carlino of Long Beach.
Tommy Smith set a world record and a Hungarian produced a fantastic hammerthrow series Saturday night at a Sacramento, Calif., invitation meet.
France, West Germany and Brazil completed the field yesterday for the semi-final round of the European Zone Davis Cup tennis competition.
PLAZA 9, Plaza Hotel, Fifth Avenue and 59th Street. Julius Monk, host performer; Charlotte Rae, comedian; Hendra and Ullett, comedians; Bruce Scott, singer.
MADRID, June 12--Two Czechoslovak delegates to an international movie festival at San Sebastian were reported to have been accidentally beaten by the Spanish police today during a student riot.

JERSEY CITY, June 12-- Gacinto Jaoa's goal with six minutes to play today gave Vitoria Setubal of Portugal a 1-1 tie with Bologna of Italy in an exhibition soccer game before 6,134 at Roosevelt Stadium.
LONDON, June 12--Nominally Britain's Royal Bal let consists of 139 dancers, but like the 247 dancers of Moscow's Bolshoi Ballet, they would never appear on stage together.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 12.--The Episcopal Cathedral of the Incarnation was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Lorelle Elizabeth Hurst, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Russell Hurst, to Second Lieut. Harry Edward Wise, U.S.A. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Wise of Andalusia, Ala.

About $1-billion of notes are scheduled for sale this week, a week in which corporations will have just finished making large dividend payments and will be heading into the task of settling their tax payments to the Federal Government.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 12 (Reuters)--The Johannesburg Afrikaans-language newspaper Die Beeld said today that the South African Government will not allow Senator Robert F. Kennedy to return to the republic for another visit.
The theatrical road is thriving in most places from coast to coast. Musicals, comedies and dramas are generating record grosses, moving into new cities and reviving ailing downtown areas.
WASHINGTON, June 12-- Following are the votes of delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the week ended yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP)--Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusett, urged Congress today to consider a lottery to determine who will be drafted into the military service.
BROOKLINE, Mass., June 12 (AP)--A youthful Eastern States team upset New England, 5-4, yesterday and won the Sears Cup tennis tournament for the first time in a decade at Longwood.
SAIGON, June 12--American infantrymen killed 93 Vietcong yesterday in the rolling, dense jungles 50 miles northwest of Saigon, a United States military spokesman said tonight.
SANTA BARBARA, Calif., June 12 (UPI)--A swiftly spreading brush and timber firetouched off by a plane crash in which two men were killedburned out of control today in Los Padres National Forest.
WASHINGTON, June 12-- The presidents of three railroad operating unions announced today that they would recommend a merger to their 92,000 members.
Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within 12 months amount to $97,196,952,825. They consist of Treasury securities as follows:
PHILADELPHIA, June 12-- Mrs. Mary Meer has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Catherine Meer, to John D. Mazza, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Mazza of New York.

WASHINGTON, June 12-- Job Corps education innovators, who believe they have found methods of teaching "teacher-proof" youths, have found a way to introduce these methods into public school systems on a small scale.

CLIFTON, N.J., June 12 (AP)--Six of 18 meet records fell today as the Seth Weekly Track Club of Cranford dethroned the Central Jersey Track and Field Club of Madison as team champions in the New Jersey Amateur Athletic Union track and field championships.

PHILADELPHIA, June 12 (AP)--Chris Short, with the help of a two-run homer by Bill White, defeated the St. Louis Cards for the sixth straight time today as he hurled the Philadelphia Phillies to a 5-3 victory.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 12 --"One mark of an educated man is his capacity to change his mind when the evidence warrants it," Dr. Robert F. Goheen told Princeton University's graduating class today in his baccalaureate address.
NANNA DITZEL, a Scandinavian furniture designer who once tried to get businessmen to recline at their conferences, thinks it would be a good idea for social gatherings too.

The dramatic struggle between the old, authoritarian Spain of Generalissimo Franco and the new, enlightened world of Popes John XXIII and Paul VI is convulsing the Spanish Roman Catholic Church. The conflict is still unequal, but history moves inexorably from old to new and the only question is when the younger, progressive-minded clergy are going to win out over the older members of the hierarchy.

TUCKAHOE, N.Y., June 12 --The marriage of Miss Barbara Caplin to Joshua Eliran took place here this afternoon in the Genesis Hebrew Center of Westhchester. Rabbi Ludwig Nadelmann perfomed the ceremony.

ST. LOUIS, June 12 (AP)-- Eugene L. Raymond, president and executive director of the Cigar Institute of America, was stricken and died, apparently of a heart attack, aboard an airliner en route from Kansas City today. He was 54 years old and lived at 33 Morewood Oaks, Port Washington, L.I.

HANOVER, N.H., June 12 (AP)--John W. Macy Jr., chairman of the United States Civil Service Commission, said today that a public administrator's most urgent task was to mobilize talent and imagination to meet the growing needs of urbanization.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., June 13 (UPI) More than 2,000 fire fighters battled from the ground and air today to contain a brush and timber fire that had already charred 28,000 acres in the Los Padres National Forest.

Prices of various borax products will be increased July 1 by the American Potash, and Chemical Company, the concern announced yesterday. It said it also would increase the present differentials for bagged materials over bulk borax.
EAST ORANGE, N.J., June 13 Top-seeded Frank Froehling of East Orange made an auspicious debut in the New Jersey State men's singles tennis championship today at the East Orange Tennis Club.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 13 Lieutenant General Suharto, Deputy Premier for Defense, said today he was still "discussing ways to reach an understanding" with Gazhali Safei, Malaysia's Foreign Secretary.

The Association of Russian War Invalids of the First World War will receive the proceeds of a showing on June 28 of the film documentary "Emperor Nicholas II." The screening by Alexandre Tarsaidze at the St. Regis-Sheraton Maisonette will be followed by a dinner party at the St. Regis-Sheraton Roof.

The Bulova Watch Company, Inc., increased its earnings for the fourth consecutive year, with sales the highest in its 99-year-history, the annual statement for the fiscal year ended March 31 disclosed yesterday.

EUGENE, Ore., June 13--A Circuit Court judge ruled today that the managing editor of The Oregon Daily Emerald, University of Oregon newspaper, must tell the grand jury the names of seven students she interviewed for a story about marijuana smoking on the campus.
James Farmer, the Negro leader, sharply rejected yesterday the contention that a racial issue was involved in the contest for Manhattan surrogate.
GENEVA, June 13 Lord Chalfont, British Disarmament Minister, warned today that the arms talks here could fail to survive the new round opening tomorrow unless some progress was made.
The Police Department's Tactical Patrol Force, the elite corps of judo-trained men, is being increased 50 per cent.

WASHINGTON, June 13 The Administration is expected to propose at the Geneva disarmament negotiations an international ban on larger underground nuclear tests. The negotiations resume tomorrow after a six-week recess.

THAT narrow, winding London street called Carnaby keeps getting closer to New York. Early in August, another branch of it will move into Arnold Constable's second floor with a Tom and Moll's Place shop (for Tom Jomes and Moll Flanders). The shop will carry pants suits for her as well as him, flowered shirts, wide ties and Mod sweaters. To clinch it, the clothes will be tagged with Beatles labels.

TAMERLANE, A Tragedy, by Nicholas Rowe, edited by Landon C. Burns Jr.; THE CHANGELING, by Thomas Middleton and William Rowley, edited by Matthew W. Black (University of Pennsylvania, $4 each). Volumes in "The Mathew Carey Library of English and American Literature."
News of continuing support for sterling by international banks had a favorable effect on the London Stock Exchange and prices recorded modest advances along a broad front.
Steel production fell 2.4 per cent last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 13 The crash of as XB-70A research aircraft last Wednesday has forced the Administration to conclude that it must buy more than two test models of a proposed supersonic airliner, informed sources said today.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (UPI) A spokesman for Postmaster General Lawrence F. O'Brien denied today that Federal employes were being coerced into buying savings bonds to make President Johnson's campaign a success.
WASHINGTON, June 13 George Meany has scheduled a showdown this week with Walter P. Reuther over the A.F.L.C.I.O. boycott of the current International Labor Organization conference.
Lecture, Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and 82d Street, 10:30 A.M. "Etruscan Art," Elaine P. Loeffler.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 13 John B. Rhodes, chairman of the board of the Elastic Stop Nut Corporation of America, died last night of a heart attack while attending his 45th reunion at Princeton University. He was 66 years old and lived at 9 Barberry Lane, Short Hills.

EAST LANSING, Mich., June 13 (AP) The editor of The Michigan Democrat, party publication, has asked President Johnson to remove the Michigan State University president, John A. Hannah, from chairmanship of the United States Civil Rights Commission.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) The Supreme Court ordered today reinstatement of a Justice Department complaint that the acquisition of the Blatz Brewing Company by the Pabst Brewing Company violated antitrust law.

Lea of Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia, and the late Mr. Lea.

Resnik of South Orange and Bolton Landing, N.Y., was married this afternoon to Robert Slater, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Slater of East Orange. Rabbi Isador Breslau of Washington, uncle of the bride, and Rabbi Theodore Friedman performed the ceremony at Temple Beth El.

License Commissioner Joel J. Tyler announced yesterday that the cabaret bureau, now at 300 West 43d Street, will be moved back to the license department's central headquarters at 80 Lafayette Street for economy reasons.

"Dear Comrades," a biographical play about Jack London, is headed for a Broadway premiere in mid-October to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the author's death on Nov. 22. Wilbert (Bert) Mulholland possesses the perfect record at Aqueduct. The 82-year-old trainer of a division of Mr. and Mrs. George D. Widener's stock sent Belle de Nuit into the sixth race on the card yesterday. The filly won as a favorite, paid $5.20 for $2, and extended Mulholland's record for the Belmont-at-Aqueduct season to five victories in five attempts. The Belmont season started on June 1.

The protest by Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, against American labor's walkout from the annual conference of the International Labor Organization is important and valuable for reasons that transcend the immediate issue. It presages more open debate inside the A.F.L.-C.I.O. on the wisdom of the adamant stand its president, George Meany, has taken against any East-West rapprochement in the labor field.

SYDNEY, Australia, Tuesday, June 14 students from Malaysia and Singapore who attend schools here were called last night to join in a hunt for Lim Yew Hock, the Malaysian High Commissioner in Australia who is missing.

CHICAGO, June 13 (AP) Frank Malzone hit a fifth-inning homer and scored a run in the ninth to lead the California Angels to a 2-1 victory over the Chicago White Sox and a split of their twilight-night doubleheader tonight.

The dollar value of Manhattan real estate sales in the first quarter of 1966, according to the Real Estate Board of New York, was 43.2 per cent less than the total value in the same period last year, although there were only five fewer properties sold in the quarter.

KANSAS CITY, June 13 (AP) Rich Rollins's three doubles and a single paced the Minnesota Twins to a 6-1 victory over the Kansas City Athletics tonight after the A's had taken the opener of a double-header, 5-2.

TOKYO, June 13 Japan National Railways announced today that its New Tokaido Line the world's fastest railroad, had carried more than 50 million passengers in the 20 months and 12 days since it began service. The total is equivalent to more than half the country's population.

The Consolidated Foods Corporation plans to enter the convenience-food field through its proposed acquisition of Idaho Frozen Foods, Inc., a processor of frozen potato products. The transaction would involve about $3.4-million worth of common stock.

STOCKHOLM, June 13 (UPI) Pilots of the Scandinavian Airlines System went on strike today and paralyzed the company's worldwide operations.

Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. has challenged the assertion that he was mistaken in reporting that The New York Times suppressed a dispatch about the build-up for the Bay of Pigs invasion of Cuba in 1961.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 13 Britain's team of three yachts slugged its way into high headwinds in the race from Oyster Bay, L.I., that began yesterday to become the leader today for the Onion Patch Trophy, an international competition involving four other countries.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., June 13 Pete Burke, Indian Hills, and Bernie Grill of Cold Spring, scored 32, 30 62 today, to win the Metropolitan Professional Golfers' Association pro-amateur event at the Cold Spring Country Club. Par for the 6,508-yard course is 37, 34 71.

John Joseph Phelan Sr., a stockbroker and member of the New York Stock Exchange since 1930, died Sunday night at the Harkness Pavilion, Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, after a long illness. He was 61 years old.

The election of Paul S. Smith as a vice president of the General Motors Acceptance Corporation in charge of sales was announced yesterday. He succeeds W. Gerow Schick, who is retiring after nearly 40 years with the company.
It was a tough tour, but worth it all the way. This is the sentiment of the managers of the Metropolitan Opera National Company, which ended its first season Sunday night in Guadalajara, Mexico.

A news conference in which scientists will tell what they have learned from Surveyor I's mission to the moon will be televised live at 2 P.M. Thursday by the American Broadcasting Company and the National Broadcasting Company.
CINCINNATI, June 13 (UPI) Cincinnati's ordinance outlawing the sale or distribution of hate literature was ruled unconstitutional today by the Court of Appeals for the First District.

FLORIDA CITY, Fla., June 13 Alfred Nilson, a retired audio engineer for station WOR in New York, who lived with his family on a Chinese junk in New Rochelle and the Bronx for 38 years, died of a heart attack here Friday. He was 70 years old. He retired in 1960 and came to live here.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (UPI) The Supreme Court asked the Gavernment today for more information on how the Federal Bureau of Investigation placed an eavesdropping device in the hotel suite of Fred B. Black Jr., an associate of Robert G. Baker, former secretary to the Democratic majority in the Senate.

Maurice Northrop Quade, a structural designer who specialized in designing bridges, highways and tunnels, died Sunday of a heart attack while on a business trip to Sea Island, Ga. He was 65 years old and lived in West Orange N.J.

"An Evening in Egypt," a benefit for the American Committee to Preserve Abu Simbel, will be held at the Gallery of Modern Art on Thursday at 8 P.M. The Abu Simbel temples are on the site to be flooded by the waters of the Aswan High Dam.
BASEL, Switzerland, June 13 Eleven countries and an international bank anounced today an exceptionally long-term arrangement to protect the British pound sterling.

DETROIT, June 13 (AP) Eighth-inning singles by Jim Northrup and Bill Freehan, and Gates Brown's sacrifice fly gave the Detroit Tigers a 4-3 victory, over the Washington Senators tonight. The loss was the eighth straight for the Senators.
NEW DELHI, June 13 Prime Minister Indira Gandhi will go to Moscow next month in an effort to reassure Soviet leaders of India's dedication to nonalignment.
Judge Edward Weinfeld of the Federal District Court ruled yesterday that judges in state courts could not promise lenient prison terms to defendants to induce them to plead guilty.
SAN JUAN, June 13 (AP) Guillermo Echevarria of Mexico set a record of 17 minutes 15.3 seconds in winning the 1,500meter free-style swimming race at the Central American and Caribbean Games today.
A Federal judge here refused yesterday to quash a grand jury subpoena that requires the administrators of a Teamsters union-employer pension fund to provide certain records of loan transactions.

BRUSSELS, June 13 France reaffirmed today her opposition to making Dr. Walter Hallstein head of a single executive commission for the European Common Market and two sister organizations, the European Atomic Energy Community and the European Coal and Steel Community.
BAY SHORE, L.I., June 13 (AP) A teacher who was shot April 27 when he tried to intercept a youth with a shotgun stalking the halls of Bay Shore High School died today.

WASHINGTON, June 13--The six-month Treasury bill rate declined at today's auction, but the three-month rate was almost unchanged, the Treasury disclosed tonight.

DETROIT, June 13 (UPI)--Teachers in suburban Ecorse voted today to continue a strike that has left almost 200 school-children without classes.

HARRISON, N.Y., June 13 Jim Cassia and Philip Ragonetti of Putnam County Club posted a best-ball card of 29, 34 63 at Willow Ridge Country Club today to win the Westchester County Golf Association oneday pro-amateur tournament-by one stroke.
DALLAS, June 13 A State court jury ruled today that Jack Ruby, slayer of Lee Harvey Oswald, who killed President Kennedy, was same.
Representatives of the newspaper Guild and the World Journal Tribune, Inc., met yesterday and adjourned last night on an optimistic note.
OAKLAND, Miss., June 13 The civil rights march through Mississippi today encountered heavy rains, segregationist warning signs, and apathy and fear from unregistered Negroes.

BERLIN, June 13 The recent flurry of diplomatic activity in the Soviet bloc reflects Soviet expectations that President de Gaulle's forthcoming trip to Moscow may pave the way for a gradual European relaxation of tension, in the view of Western observers here.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 13 (AP) Ronald J. Landeck, a football tailback and baseball shortstop and captain, received today the William Winston Roper Trophy, Princeton University's highest athletic award.

SEOUL, South Korea, Tuesday, June 14 United States circles are hopeful that the Asian and Pacific conference that opened here today will include "some kind" of endorsement of the American position on Vietnam in the final communique Thursday. OTTAWA, Tuesday, June 14 (AP) Representatives of the striking Quebec longshoremen agreed early today to accept a compromise proposal by Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson to settle the strike.

PIKESVILLE, Md., June 13--Dr. and Mrs. Irvin B. Golboro have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss F. Sally Golboro, to Joel Peter Harrison, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick M. Harrison of Wilkes-Barre, Pa. A fall wedding is planned.

A library of 5,000 volumes covering Jewish learning and thought, including rare and ancient items, was presented to the Jewish Theological Seminary of America yesterday to help replace 70,000 books destroyed by a fire this spring.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (UPI) President Johnson was an uninvited guest today for graduation ceremonies at Gallaudet College, the nation's only college for the deaf. He pledged greater determination to help the handicapped people of the nation.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (UPI) The Supreme Court granted Ohio permission today to sue Kentucky directly in the high court over their boundary dispute on the Ohio River. The Court gave Kentucky 60 days to answer the complaint.

CHICAGO, June 13 Violence flared again tonight in Chicago's principal Puerto Rican neighborhood. Rock-tossing youths ran through the community on the Northwest Side, smashing car and store windows and traffic lights, tipping over mailboxes, stealing merchandise and harassing police cars.

BONN, June 13 France informed West Germany today that she intended to move some or all of her aviation units out of this country after French ground and air units are withdrawn from the Atlantic alliance's command on July 1.
CHICAGO, June 13 (UPI) The board of directors of Field Enterprises, Inc., elected today George B. Young and Bailey K. Howard to the corporation's two top posts, effective Oct. 1.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, June 13 Juan Bosch grudgingly conceded today his overwhelming defeat by Dr. Joaquin Balaguer in the general elections June 1.
BALTIMORE, June 13 The Baltimore Orioles subdued the New York Yankees, 8-0, tonight with a frightening display of power and pitching.

LONDON, June 14 British ballet is 40 years old tomorrow for it was on June 15, 1926, that Marie Rambert, with Frederick Ashton as choreographer, produced the first British ballet. That was the historic "A Tragedy of Fashion," and it formed part of a revue, "Riverside Nights."

ROME, June 14 The Roman Catholic Church's "index" of forbidden books and related sanctions have no juridical effect upon Catholics, but it is still a sin to read them and other publications "contrary to faith and morals."
PARIS, June 14 What was largest collection of works of believed to be the world's Honore Daumier, who died a pauper, was sold in a transAtlantic auction today for $617,000.
BALTIMORE, June 14 Jim Bouton, whose comeback attempts for the New York Yankees bear some resemblance to Russian roulette, gave it another whirl tonight and lost.
CHICAGO, June 14 More than 500 policemen in white helmets patrolled a Puerto Rican neighborhood tonight, ending anti-police rioting that swept the area Sunday and last night.

TOKYO, June 14 Proceedings in the Japanese Diet came to a halt again today as the opposition Socialists, angry over the Government's issuance of a labor ordinance, carried out a party decision to obstruct the passage of legislation.

WASHINGTON, June 14 James R. Hoffa made it clear today that if he was sent to jail he expected to resume the presidency of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters when he was freed.

Marshall McLuhan yesterday expounded at the International P.E.N. Congress on the alterations wrought in the writer's environment by the development of "electrical circuitry." The reaction of his audience of writers was generally both skeptical and scared.

In intervening in the interest rate war between banks and other savings institutions, the Treasury is supporting a proposal to ban commercial banks from paying more than 5 per cent on deposits of up to $100,000 and is reportedly considering legislation to keep them from paying more than 4 per cent on small accounts.

KLM Royal Dutch Airlines reported yesterday it had made its first fiscal-year profit in six years. For the three months ended March 31, however, the line operated at an indicated net loss of $1.9-million.
Prices of stocks on the London Stock Exchange eased yesterday after a steady opening but then managed to close with a small over-all gain.

WASHINGTON, June 14 Dean Rusk, the Secretary of State, cautioned the Western alliance today against a repetition of "the tragic errors of the past" through one-sided defense cuts inspired by a reduced fear of war.

Lawrence Alloway, a key figure in a recent controversey over the United States exhibit at the forthcoming Venice Biennale, has resigned as curator of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum.

Corbett, president of the two-millionmember organization, said today.

DALLAS, June 14 Discussion among the nation's mayors narrowed today to two basic issues: The effect of the Vietnam war on municipal spending and the explosive question of racial integration in the suburbs.

WASHINGTON, June 14 The nation's schools are spending hundreds of millions of Federal dollars for electronic educational equipment, but lack sufficient high-quality educational programs to feed into the machinery, United States Commissioner of Education Harold Howe 2d declared today.

Joan Bennett, a Hollywood star for more than three decades, has been signed to a feature role in "Dark Shadows," the American Broadcasting Company's new gothic-style soap opera.

City College will confer a record number of degrees at its 120th commencement exercises tonight in an outdoor ceremony at Lewisohn Stadium, 138th Street and Convent Avenue. A total of 4,216 students will receive degrees.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., June 14 The Rev. Matthew A. Schumacher of the Congregation of the Holy Cross, former president of St. Edward's University at Austin, Tex., died today in Holy Cross House on the campus of the University of Notre Dame. He was 87 years old.

WASHINGTON, June 14 There was nobody at President Johnson's party tonight that he did not recognize. But there were some he does recognize who stayed away.

Franklin K. Lane High School won the first Public Schools Athletic League baseball championship in its history by routing Lafayette High, 12-1, at Pratt Institute's field in Brooklyn yesterday.

PARIS, June 14 Georges Villiers was replaced today as head of the National Employers Council by a close associate, Paul Huvelin.

PASADENA, Calif., June 14 (AP) Surveyor 1 televised eerie, almost surrealistic panoramas of a sunset on the moon today and then shut down halting perhaps forever a historic flow of photos to the earth.

Mrs. Cordelia Wood Kelly, a former hospital superintendent, author and a former editor of Professional nursing magazines, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital after a long ill ness. The wife of Thomas S. Kelly, she was 59 years old and lived at 19 West 12th Street.

Fourteen hundred persons are expected at the Grand Ballroom of the New York Hilton next Saturday, when Governor Rockefeller will receive the annual Humanitarian Award of the Nassau County Chapter of the Association for the Help of Retarded Children.

HONG KONG, June 11 (Reuters) Thousands of people walked to work through mud and rubble today after 15 inches of rain over the weekend took more than 60 lives and made 6,000 homeless.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Wednesday, June 15 Bands of anarchist youths joined striking construction workers in the streets today, giving Amsterdam the appearance of a beleaguered city.
VIENTIANE, Laos, June 14 Brig. Gen. Phao Ma, flamboyant chief of the Laotian air force, who has led air strikes against Communists, has been recalled from his post in a quarrel with politicians.

WASHINGTON, June 14 The House of Representatives issued a constitutional challenge to the executive branch today by ordering the Defense Department to construct two nuclear-powered frigates for the Navy.

The Norfolk Western Railway's petition to the Interstate Commerce Commission asking it to stall the Pennsylvania and New York Central railroad's merger plans took the steam out of the two stocks yesterday.
WINCHESTER, Mass., June 14 Miss Deborah Ellen Nichols, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen George Nichols, was married today to John William Losse 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Losse 3d of St. Louis.
CLEVELAND, June 14 (AP) George Thomas and George Scot hit ninth-inning home runs that gave the Boston Red Sox an 11-7 victory and a split of a double-header with the Cleveland Indians tonight.
WASHINGTON, June 14 Republican party leaders, from former President Dwight D. Eisenhower down, will roll out the red carpet tomorrow for their party's new star, Ronald Reagan.

Paperboard production rose 4.7 per cent with 450,000 tons in the week ended June 11, from 429,985 tons in the corresponding 1965 week, the Paperboard Group of the American Paper institute reported yesterday.
A RECORD entry list that includes most of the point leaders is assured for the Northeast Division national championship sports car races at Bridgehampton, L.I., on Saturday and Sunday.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 14 Britain's team of three yachts again was the fleetest on the handicap scale today. It established a firm hold on the point lead for the Onion Patch sailing trophy that will be settled next week after the Newport-Bermuda race, which will begin Saturday.

The United Artists Corporation plans to return to a cash-dividend basis after having paid stock dividends since mid-1963.
CHICAGO, June 14 (AP) Two candidates backed by Mayor Richard J. Daley Representatives William L. Dawson and Barrett O'Hara won renomination tonight in the Illinois Democratic primary.

THE Council of Fashion Designers of America will be involved in three major fashion events in coming months, Norman Norell announced yesterday.

The striking Newspaper Guild reported last night that it had reached agreement with the World Journal Tribune, Inc. on the employment lists for seven of the eight departments in which the union has jurisdiction.

MIAMI BEACH, June 14 The executive vice president of the International Longshoremen's Association warned steamship operators yesterday that the 60,000-member dockworkers union may "refuse to negotiate" a work contract to replace the four-year contract that expires Sept. 30, 1968, unless there is industrywide bargaining.

OTTAWA, June 14 E. Davie Fulton, former Minister of Justice today spurned an invitation from a Commission of Inquiry to defend himself against allegations of having mishandled the Gerda Munsinger case six years ago.

Another important economic indicator has turned down. American consumers, according to a widely respected survey, are definitely less optimistic about both the business outlook and their own spending intentions than they were earlier this year.

COLUMBIA, S.C., June 14 Former Gov. Ernest F. Hollings, one of the South's most energetic political campaigners, unseated Senator Donald S. Russell in the South Carolina Democratic primary today.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) The chairman of the House Committee on Un-American Activities has been subpoenaed to appear at the trial of Robert M. Shelton, the Ku Klux Klan leader, for contempt of Congress.
BUENOS AIRES, June 14 (AP) President Arturo U. Illia's Government, apparently striving to head off a military coup, has promised stronger action to control Communism and labor unrest.

MIAMI, June 13 (AP) Top-seeded Charles Pasarell of the University of California, Los Angeles, used smashing serves and power strokes to advance to the third round of the National Collegiate tennis championship today with a 6-2, 6-1 triumph over Steve Stockton, a Tennessee student from Garden City, L.I.

TRENTON, June 14 Democratic party leaders have asked State Senator Ned J. Parsekian, independent Democrat from Bergen County, to oppose United States Senator Clifford P. Case, the liberal Republican who will seek election to a third term in November.
Ostensibly, the whole thing was to talk about an advertising campaign for a beer and it's a beer that isn't even widely distributed in the New York City area.
MOSCOW, June 14 Oskar Rabin, a Soviet nonconformist artist, was criticized today in the controlled press for having permitted last year an exhibition in London of his "neurotic" paintings.
The spot rate on the British pound continued to improve yesterday in moderate trading on foreign-exchange markets here.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), June 14 A year after the death of Martin Buber, a small but devoted staff working in the Hebrew University library is beginning to see some progress in sorting out the massive correspondence of the influential Jewish philsopher.

ALBANY, June 14 Governor Rockefeller charged tonight that Federal authorities were "trying to create a three-man supergovernment for the Hudson River shoreline that would intrude on the lives of many hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers."

Mrs. Edith E. Cook Edwards, the widow of James A. Edwards, a New York lawyer, died Monday in her home at 930 Park Avenue after a short illness. She was 80 years old and also had homes in East Hampton, L.I., and Vero Beach, Fla.
HOBOKEN, N.J., June 14 Leo P. Kiely, the deputy chief of the Hoboken Fire Department, died today in St. Mary's Hospital here. He was 63 years old and lived at 1235 Park Avenue.
A drive opened in the City Council yesterday to prevent Mayor Lindsay from abolishing the city's 22-year-old Division of Veterans Affairs at the end of this month.

Three weeks after Mayor Lindsay took office he drove to the southern Bronx one Saturday morning to swing a shovel and help clear refuse from a vacant lot that was to become the first of "hundreds" of vest-pocket parks.
MADRID, June 14 One of Spain's Socialist leaders voiced support today for the restoration of the monarchy under the 53-year-old exiled pretender, Don Juan de Bourbon y Battenberg.
American Export Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., a holding company, and the Equity Corporation, a registered investment company, are planning to hold merger talks.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall signed leases today under which the International Nickel Company, Inc., plans to develop a big copper and nickel mining operation in the Superior National Forest near Ely, Minn.
COLONIA, N.J., June 14 Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood virtually clinched her eighth championship today in the 13th annual Elizabeth Goss round-robin golf tournament at the Colonia Country Club.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 14 (AP) Willie McCovey's tworun homer in the seventh inning snapped a 7-7 tie and sent the San Francisco Giants on the way to an 11-7 victory over the Chicago Cubs today.

PARIS The United States, which worships at the altar of a civilian republic, likes to imagine it has a prejudice against naming Presidents from among military heroes. This is of course a legend. We have had 35 chief executives and eleven almost a third were generals before they reached the White House.
MONTREAL, June 14 (AP) The New York Rangers acquired Red Berenson, a leftwing, from the Montreal Canadiens today in exchange for Ted Taylor, also a left-wing, and a player to be named later.

In terms of percentages, the changes brought about in the Italian municipal and provincial elections were slight; in terms of political importance, they were great. The Communists made a strong bid to get control of the Rome municipal council and failed.
Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts will present its first international festival beginning in mid-June of next year, with performances by more than a dozen groups.

George Whitmore Jr. and Richard Robles the former indicted and the latter convicted in the 1963 murder of Janice Wylie and Emily Hoffert are expected to win new trials or go free as a result of Monday's ruling by the United States Supreme Court.

OBERLIN, Ohio, June 14 Miss Linda Beth Sarasohn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Homer M. Sarasohn of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married today to Arthur McAfee Kingdon, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Robert W. Kingdon of Wisconsin Rapids, Wis.
The vice president of the Horsemen's Service Corporation was supposed to have ridden a horse at Monmouth yesterday. But the race didn't fill.
LONDON, June 14 (Reuters) Bold Lad, the Irish-trained British horse owned by an American, Beatrice Lady Granard, won the Coventry Stakes as the four-day Royal Ascol meeting opened today.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., June 14 (AP) Jacques Alexandria Samossoud, composer and conductor, whose late wife was the last surviving child of Mark Twain, died today, at the age of 71.
MIAMI, June 14 The Cuban Government ordered yesterday what it called a general mobilization for work in agriculture.

BOSTON, June 14 Dr. George Gerard, an authority in the field of structural design and analysis, died here this morning in the Tufts-New England Medical Center after a longs illness. He was 44 years old.

WASHINGTON, June 14 A former Marine helicopter crew chief told a Senate subcommittee today that he had taken four "goof balls," had drunk a glass of beer, had gotten "high" and then shot and wounded two South Viet

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., June 14 The space agency said today it planned to rocket a picture-taking satellite into orbit around the moon, possibly to photograph Surveyor 1 on the Lunar surface, during a sixday period starting July 12.
LONDON, June 14 It was strangely quiet in London today. Motorists were relaxed. Traffic flowed without major tieups. Even the mammoth doubledecker buses were able to make good time.
CORNWALL, Conn., June 14 Mrs. Elizabeth Rogers Mc Conaughy, widow of Dr. James L. McConaughy, a former Governor of Connecticut, died last night at her home here. She was 78 years old.
CAIRO, June 14 Western diplomats reported today that several thousand Arab refugees from Palestine had undergone military training in the Gaza Strip while on the United Nations payroll.
Otto Ernst Meyer, the founder and first president of Varig Airlines, the South American carrier, died Sunday at his home in Porto Alegre, Brazil. He was 68 years old.

WASHINGTON, June 14 The Department of Commerce released new figures today indicating that there might be significant savings this year, after all, in the direct foreign investment sector or the balance of payments.

LOS ANGELES, June 14 Mort Sahl, that inveterate rebel against the status quo, unveiled his new nightclub here last night. The club stands in the midst of a bizarre new establishment that styles itself "the nation's first toutique."
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 14 Cuba accused the United States today of "trying to condition United States public opinion psychologically for armed aggression against Cuba." No action was called for.
BOSTON, June 14 The Hovey Players of Waltham were voted the winners in the Festival Theater Showcase for members of the New England Theater Conference.

CAIRO, June 14 The United States and the United Arab Republic agreed today to undertake the world's largest "X-ray" job searching the interior of one of the great stone Pyramids of Giza for hidden passageways and chambers.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 14 The thirsty course commanded attention today as Gary Player, the titleholder, and other golfers made preparations for the United States Open championship.
New-car sales in the United States in the first 10 days of June fell 5.1 per cent from last year's level, according to report received yesterday from Detroit.
NEWARK, June 14, (AP) The Newark Teachers Association was certified today as the winner of an election to choose a bargaining agent for the city's 3,200 public school teachers.
WASHINGTON, June 14 Vice President Humphrey told 116 young Negro executives today to redouble their efforts to find "that rich deposit of human talent" among America's poor and frustrated students.

WASHINGTON, June 14 Five major airlines have told President Johnson that they believe his emergency board's recommendations "form the framework" for settling a labor dispute with the International Association of Machinists.

NEWARK, June 14 The National Bowl-O-Mat Corporation of Paterson N.J., and its 10 operating subsidiaries filed suit in Federal District Court today, charging the Brunswick Corporation with violation of antitrust laws.
NEWARK, June 14 Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio was overwhelmingly re-elected to a second term today in a runoff contest with former Mayor Leo P. Carlin.

For the 10th successive year United States Lines has been awarded a United States Public Health Service citation for excellent sanitation of the passenger liner United States and the company's fleet of 46 cargo ships during 1965.

By its 5-to-4 decision limiting the power of the police to obtain confessions in criminal cases, the Supreme Court has demonstrated again the high importance it accords to the protection of individual rights.

LONDON, June 14 Mr. Rabin's works aroused a good deal of interest here a year ago when they were shown at the Grosvenor Gallery. The monthlong exhibition was extended a few days because of the public response.
Eastern Air Lines has temporarily canceled about 5 per cent of its flights in its 102city system because of delayed delivery of new jet aircraft.

REHOBOTH BEACH, Del., June 14 Mrs. Mary Elizabeth Nuttle Marine of 18 Baltimore Avenue died yesterday at her home at the age of 78. She was the wife of Dr. David Marine, a New York City pathologist who retired 20 years ago to Rehoboth Beach.
Bond dealers began talking yesterday as though they expected something of a rise in prices fairly soon.

The HOUSING AUTHORITY OF THE CITY OF NEWARK will receive separate sealed bids for each of the following subdivisions of work to be done in connection with Housing Project NJ 2-21. Sites A. E.F. situated in Newark, New Jersey.
Luncheon in honor of Philip Rosenblum under the auspices of the taxicab industry in support of the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York, Essex House, 12:15 P.M.
The Navy has awarded the Sperry Rand Corporation a $17,891,530 contract to fabricate and test prototype models of an aircraft electronics systems called ILAAS.
MOSCOW, June 14 If any Soviet candidates were wating nervously for the returns from Sunday's voting, they can relax. It's official all 1,517 were victorious.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 14 United States Navy jet fighters attacked two unidentified aircraft over the North Vietnamese coast just before dawn today and apparently shot one down, an American military spokesman said.
JAKARTA, June 14 Lieutenant General Suharto, Indonesia's Deputy Premier for defense, said today that there were "no principal differences" between Indonesia and Malaysia.
The proposed acquisition of Fanny Farmer Candy Shops, Inc., by W.R. Grace Co. has been delayed by unresolved legal issues.

The election of Jacques Ernest Solvay of Brussels as a director of the Allied Chemical Corporation was announced yesterday. He has been managing director of the Belgium chemical firm of Solvay Cie since 1955.
A resident theater management-training program has been formed by the American National Theater and Academy to fill the need for administrative personnel in nonprofit professional groups.
The Japanese Mission to the United Nations has leased 16,000 square feet of space at 866 United Nations Plaza in a move to larger quarters. The mission is now at 237 East 42d Street.

WASHINGTON, June 14 A Federal judge declared today that a former aide of Senator Thomas J. Dodd had "no ethical duty" to "abstract documents" from the Senator's files and turn them over to the columnists Drew Pearson and Jack Anderson.
Six common stock offerings were brought to market yesterday and all met enthusiastic receptions. Three issues were reported oversubscribed, while the other three were reported to be near sellouts.
Members of the Social Service Employes Union of the Department of Welfare voted last night to submit to arbitration their dispute with the city over summer hours.

A ruling by California authorities that savings and loan associations are permitted to advertise high-rate-bonus plans is threatening to ignite a new savings-rate war, industry leaders said yesterday.

Taking a backward look, some soybean traders estimated that the crush in May probably totaled 47 million to 48 million bushels of soybeans, compared with a crush of 45.09million in April. That news probably helped push old-crop soybean contracts forward in price, as did reports of higherthan-expected bean exports last week.
WASHINGTON, June 14 A bill that would reclaim at least temporarily for the United States the position of having the world's largest water power plant was signed today by President Johnson.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, June 15 The Government announced today it would limit the power of the coming constituent assembly to writing a constitution.
PARIS, June 14 The threepower Standing Group, the highest military council of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, is due to be abolished by July 1, according to informed sources.
LONDON, June 14 Britain went deeper into the red last month as her trade gap, the excess of imports over exports, widened by 10-million ($28,widened by 81-million ($226.8million).
Intellectual leadership in the United States has not followed the melting pot theory. This is the contention of Nathaniel Weyl, social scientist and historian, in "The Creative Elite ...
RIVERHEAD, L.I., June 14 Six Negroes accused the Deer Park volunteer fire department of racial discrimination today and sought a court order to cut off the department's municipal tax funds.
WASHINGTON, June 14 One hundred student lawyers have been added to the staff of the Office of Education this summer to investigate complaints about compliance with school integration.
The General Electric Com- pany abandoned yesterday the "turnkey" method of selling commercial nuclear power plants in the United States.

PATTEN, Me., June 14 There is such a thing as luck. There has to be or we couldn't explain some experiences. It's nothing tangible. One cannot reach out and grasp the phenomenon of luck, but when its golden touch rests on one, the recipient knows it's there.
Beekman.-Downtown Hospital elected Howard S. Cullman yesterday to succeed Frederick H. Brandi as chairman of the board. Mr. Cullman had been president 45 years.

WASHINGTON, June 14 Miss Nancy Marshall Brereton Robinson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hamilton Robinson, was married today to George Mifflin Dallas Peltz of Sloatsburg, N.Y. He is the son of Mrs. W. Leslie Sully of Cambridge, Md., and the late G.M.D. Peltz.
The election of Harry E. Figgie Jr. of Cleveland as a director of the Western Union Telegraph Company was announced yesterday by Russell W. McFah, president.

PITTSBURGH, June 14 Mr. Hodnette a former resident of Mount Lebanon, a Pittsburgh suburb, had retired in 1964 as executive vice president and vice chairman of the board of directors of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, but he remained a board member. An engineer, he was internationally recognized for developing power distribution transformers that were completely self-protected against lightning and electrical overloads.
RICHMOND, June 14 Three Negroes were elected today to the nine-member Richmond City Council.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) A nervous private detective told Senate investigators today about a 10-day "blitz kit" do-it-yourself devices that keep an automatic ear and eye on an indiscreet husband or wife.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 14 Mrs. Florence Belford Carrabine, widow of Dr. Oscar Carrabine, a New York orthodontist, died today in her home at 668 Forest Avenue here at the age of 77.
ALBANY, June 14 Two days of negotiations by top state and city officials failed tonight to break the deadlock over a tax program for New York City.

Some Christian churches risk repudiation by colored peoples unless the "grievous sins of racism" are acknowledged and remedial steps are taken, Thomas P. Melady, president of the Africa Service Institute, declared yesterday at the annual commencement exercises of Manhattan College.

NOROTON, Conn., June 14 Donald Cameron McMillan of Salem Straits has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Katherine Douglas McMillan, to Duncan Gregory Burke. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gregory Thomas Burke of Salem Straits.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass, June 14 (UPI) Nathan M. Pusey, president of Harvard, said today that Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara's proposal for mandatory two-year universal service "could only lead to a colossal waste of time" for the nation's youth.

BRUSSELS, June 14 (Reuters)?The European Common Market's ruling Council of Ministers reached agreement here today on major industrial and farm issues, thus en... abling the Kennedy round of tariff-cutting talks in Geneva to proceed.
WASHINGTON, June 15 The House passed without opposition or controversy today the eomplex bill revising the tax treatment of foreigners.
A massive construction program to expand the City University was proposed yesterday for next year by the committee on finance and facilities of the Board of Higher Education.
WASHINGTON, June 15 A young Greenwich Village user of LSD suggested today that senate investigators "take a trip" with the drug before making laws to control it.
EDISON, N.J., June 15 Seven youths have been ousted from the Camp Kilmer Job Corps here as a result of the stoning of automobiles on a highway last Saturday night.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (UPI)--Andy Etchebarren and Boog Powell hit homers tonight to give the Baltimore Orioles a 6-4 victory over the Washington Senators.

TED YATES, the adventurous producer for the Na tional Broadcasting Company, took his cameras into the remote jungles of Guatemala and up to the cold Andean plateau of Peru for the unusual documentary film shown last night on the N.B.C. television network.

WASHINGTON, June 15 New Jersey civil rights officials are investigating a report that a summer nudist camp invited a Brooklyn woman to share its recreation facilities and then turned her away because she was a Negro.

BRYSON CITY, N.C., June 15 The plan to establish six wilderness areas in the Great smoky Mountain National Park and to build a transmountain road from here to Townsend, Tenn., was endorsed today by Gov. Dan K. Moore of North Carolina.
SCRANTON, Pa., June 15 Edwin R. Colvin, manager of the Scranton office of Bache Co. for the last 10 years, died last night at Community Medical Center. He was 61 years old.
WASHINGTON, June 15 Senator Jacob K. Javits, breaking a lifelong rule of neutrality in Republican primaries, sent a strong telegram of support today to William J. Casey.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, June 15 Senator Robert F. Kennedy blamed the world powers tonight for the deadlock on nuclear arms control and called on Africa to take the lead with Asia and Latin America to break it.
DARIEN, Conn., June 15 The Ox Ridge Hunt Club's Horse Show Ball will be held on Saturday to raise funds for the building fund of the Darien Young Men's Christian Association.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, June 15 (Reuters) Dantes Bellegarde, a former Haitian Minister to the United States and United Nations representative, died here last night at the age of 89.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 15 A mistake in computing Illusion's time allowance for yesterday's third race of the International Ocean Racing team competition for the Onion Patch Trophy was corrected today by the Ida Lewis Yacht Club Race Committee.

HARRISVILLE, N.H., June 15--An August wedding is planned by Miss Izola Page Colony and Thomas Warner Porter 3d. Their engagement has been announced by Miss Colony's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Joslin Colony Jr. of Harrisville and Chesham. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Porter Jr. of Fort Worth.

Max A. Berger, a former president of Allied Yarns Corporation, textile converters, died yesterday at the Astor Hotel, where he had been attending a benefit luncheon for the Home and Hospital of the Daughters of Israel. He was 75 years old and lived at 63-24 Boelsen Crescent, Rego Park, Queens.

WASHINGTON, June 15 The suddenly vigorous competition among West German leaders for new ideas to promote the reunification of Germany has brought a prominent Bonn politician across the Atlantic with proposals for long-term military, economic and political inducements to the Soviet Union.

PURCELLVILLE, Va., June 15 For the first time since Franklin D. Roosevelt tried to purge him and other Congressional conservatives in 1938, Representative Howard W. Smith, the 83-year-old chairman of the House Rules Committee, is running scared.
The United States will not progress unless it invests as much in people as it does in machines, Commerce Secretary John T. Connor declared yesterday.
The Police and Correction Departments announced last night a plan to bar the overnight detention in precinct houses of prisoners who do not speak English.
A new, wholly Asian and Pacific organization devoted to regional cooperation in economic and cultural fields has promising possibilities.

The Corn Products Company, a major manufacturer of grocery products and products for industry, announced yesterday that it would close its executive offices in New York and build a headquarters building in Englewood Cliffs, N.J.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) A Senate-House compromise opened the way today for action on a long-stalled bill to tighten controls on lobbyists for foreign interests.
WASHINGTON, June 15 A high-ranking naval officer suggested here today that the nation come out of the clouds of space and start paying more attention to ships.
The present situation of the American merchant marine has become a national disgrace, stockholders attending the annual meeting of the Todd Shipyards Corporation were told here yesterday.
The number of "de facto Negro and Puerto Rican segregated schools" has risen sharply in recent years, a Board of Education report said yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, June 15 (AP) Misericordia Hospital has opened a family planning clinic and will use birth control pills. It is the first such clinic at a Roman Catholic-operated hospital in the Philadelphia area.
In the midst of the din of traffic and the shopping hubbub of Fulton Street, Brooklyn's dominant shopping lane, one store stands out as an oasis of calm, even understatement.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 15 A Chilean psychiatrist described today the use of LSD, along with other hallucinogens; in facilitating the mental transitions he desires for patients undergoing analysis.
KARACHI, Pakistan, June 15--Foreign Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto will be taking a long leave in West Germany beginning July 1, The Karachi Daily News reported today.

PARAMUS, N.J., June 15 John Corte of Weequahic Park eliminated the defending champion, Paul McGowan of Plainfield West, in the second round of the 65th annual New Jersey State golf championship today. The score was 1-up.
BRISTOL, R.I., June 15 Miss Carol Lumb, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Haigh Lumb 2d, was married today to William Anderson Barnes, son of Dr. and Mrs. Frederick Walter Barnes Jr. of Providence.
Two major New York banks named new vice presidents yesterday.

WEEHAWKEN, N.J., June 15 (AP ) Dr. Herman B. Kaplan, president of the Weehawken Board of Education, died tonight, apparently of a heart attack, while delivering a baby at North Hudson Hospital. He lived at 103 Columbia Terrace.
TOKYO, July 15 Finance Minister Takeo Fukuda indicated today that Japan would soon gradually liberalize her policy on foreign capital investment.
BOISE, Idaho, June 15 (AP) A merger with Rust Craft Greeting Cards of Dedham, Mass., through an exchange of shares valued at about $37.8million was announced today by the Boise Cascade Corporation.
WASHINGTON, June 15 A three-month series of sonic boom flights related to the proposed supersonic airliner has begun in the California desert.
ATLANTA, June 16 Two ununearned runs in the ninth inning gave the Mets a 5-4 victory over the Atlanta Braves early this morning and ended an eventful day for the New York club.
PARIS, June 15 A German general will be named soon to succeed a Frenchman, Gen. Jean Crepin, as commander of allied forces in Central Europe, authoritative sources said tonight.

ISLIP, L.I., June 15 Mr. and Mrs. Howard W. Nugent have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Marie Nugent to A. Stephen Patten, son of Alexander S. Patten of Franklin, Mich., and the late Mrs. Margaretta Patten.
