A life-sized sculpture of James Joyce will be placed and unveiled on the writer's grave at Fluntern Cemetery in Zurich, Switzerland, today, a date known to the literary world as Bloomsday. It was on June 16 that Joyce's spiraling story of "Ulysses" and Leopold Bloom occurs.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., June 15 (UPI) Bombers dumped thousands of gallons of chemicals today on a fire in the Los Padres National Forest, and 2,500 fire fighters battled on the ground to save 31 ranches about four miles from the fire line.

WASHINGTON, June 15 The new villains of American education are Dick and Jane. "Run, Dick, run!" and "Look, Jane, look!" are not doing the job of interesting children in reading, according to a spate of complaints reported in the Bulletin of the Council for Basic Education.

CINCINNATI, June 15 (AP) The Cincinnati Reds took a double-header from the Philadelphia Phillies tonight, winning the opener, 7-6, on Vada Pinson's triple in the ninth and taking the second game, 9-6, with a three-run eighth inning rally.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 15 When the Scots first set styles in golf, they favored seaside courses that were grass-covered in spots and wind-swept sand dunes elsewhere. They were so treeless that they regarded trees as "obstructions" and even had local rules to remove the difficulties presented by such unnatural hazards.
More than 30 graduating seniors at Brooklyn Technical High School, including many student leaders, have accused the school of perpetuating an "outmoded and obsolete" academic program.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) The Senate is giving its members a week off for the 4th of July holiday so they can return "refreshed and replenished," the Democratic leader, Mike Mansfield, said today.
HONG KONG, June 15 (Reuters) Another storm today set off new landslides and floods in this battered British colony where last weekend's rains were already feared to have taken more than 80 victims.

A decline of 1,442,000 barrels of the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend, total suppliers were 205,618,000 barrels, compared with 207,060,000 a week earlier and 205,984,000 a year ago.
Carmen Cavallaro, the latest onetime dance band leader recruited for the current revival of pre-twist dancing, is less than enthusiastic about this turn of events.
Soybeans and wheat rose to new life-of-contract highs yesterday, continuing their strong recent trends.
CHICAGO, June 15 One of the nation's most powerful city political machines emerged from another primary today with renewed strength.

GARDEN CITY, L.L. June I5 The Roosevelt Field Shopping Center, an amalgam of clothing and retail stores, delicatessens, supermarkets, restaurants and other business concerns, will become a center for knowledge, too.
WASHINGTON, June 15 President Johnson's beagle Him was killed on the White House grounds tonight by a White House limousine.

Criminal Court Judge Thomas E. Rohan declared yesterday that if he was elected Surrogate of New York County he would "look into all phases of the present practices and procedures" of the Surrogate's Court.

IF it weren't for the fact that "Paradise, Hawaiian style" is in glowing, brighterthan-life Technicolor, one might reasonably expect the late Bob Burns and his bazooka to turn up in the supporting cast.
WASHINGTON, June 15--Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara announced today that virtually all American combat units in France would be evacuated in orderly stages in the next few months.

FRANKFURT, Germany, June 15 (AP) Karl Mildenberger of West Germany used a steady jabbing attack to score a 15round decision over Yugoslavia's Ivan Prebeg tonight and successfully defend his European heavyweight championship.

HOLLYWOOD, June 15 A threatened strike by television writers was averted tonight by an 11th-hour settlement between the Writers Guild of America West and TV production companies. The strike had been called for midnight.
The round of June coming-out parties continued yesterday as young women were presented to society in Old Chatham, N.Y., and in New York.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 15 (AP) Two fresh North Vietnamese regiments have crossed into South Vietnam from staging areas in Laos even as United States paratroops hunted down remnants of another, the decimated 24th Regiment, intelligence sources said today.

Oscar Kantor, the assistant New York branch manager for Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., died Tuesday morning of a heart attack at New York Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 201 East 28th Street.
The New York and the American Stock Exchanges reported yesterday changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., June 15 Curtis Person of Memphis, the first-round leader with a 72, added a 36, 37-73 at-the Siwanoy Country Club today and won the sixth annual Eastern Seniors Golf Association championship by nine strokes.
David P. Bicks, a Securities and Exchange Commission attorney, said yesterday that the government agency was investigating the Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation.
The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court upheld yesterday a lower court dismissal of two suits against the American Express Company Both cases were an outgrowth of the food oil swindle.
WASHINGTON, June 15--The Boeing Company unveiled today a design for a 300-passenger, 300-foot-long supersonic airliner with a tail as large as the wings on today's intercontinental jets.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 15 (AP) Willie Mays blasted the 520th home run of his career as the San Francisco Giants defeated the Houston Astros,4-0, today. It was the fourth straight victory for the league leaders.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 15 Diane Matzner, a 17-yearold West Hempstead, L.I., high school senior, scored a surprise victory in the New York State women's tennis championship to reach the semi-finals today.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., June 15 Miss Lois Ann Larkey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Barney Larkey of East Orange and Deal, was married this evening to Ronald Edward Wiss, son of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Wiss of South Orange.
Frank Stanley Herring, an artist and art teacher, formerly of this city, died on Sunday at Burnsville, N.C., where he had lived recently. His age was 72.
Five grants totaling $330,000 have been made by a music educators' organization to strengthen the teaching of music at universities, colleges and public schools across the country.

BOSTON, June 15 (AP) Al Kaline, who earlier collected his 2,000th hit, blasted a two-run homer that capped a four-run Detroit rally in the ninth and gave the Tigers an 11-7 victory tonight over the Boston Red Sox.

Radische Anlin und Soda Fabrik, a mayor West German chemical producer, announced yesterday it would invest about $142-million up to the beginning of 1969 in new chemical facilities in Antwerp, Belgium.
LONDON, June 15 (UPI) Prime Minister Wilson intervened today in the deadlocked seamen's dispute in an effort to end Britain's 31-day maritime strike.

MANHATTAN'S newest bridge club, the Gotham, celebrated the opening of its well-appointed quarters in the Olcott Hotel last Saturday evening with one of the biggest parties in bridge history. At 2 A.M. Arnold Mishkin, the manager, looking surprisingly fresh at the end of a strenuous evening, estimated that more than 750 persons had attended.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (UPI) Representative L. Mendel Rivers, Democrat of South Carolina, announced today that the House Armed Services Committee would begin public hearings on the draft June 22.
"IF I hadn't tripped over an undertaker in 1937 my whole career might have been differnt," Alfred Joseph Scotti mused yesterday.

West Point-Pepperell, Inc., the textile producer, reported yesterday that net profits for the third fiscal quarter ended May 28 rose to $5,471,000 or $1.15 a share, from $5,246,000, or $1.10 a share, a year earlier. Net sales rose to $88,571,000 from $78,877,000.

WASHINGTON, June 15 President Johnson called on health leaders and hospitals today to avoid racial discrimination, prevent excessive fees and other abuses and get Medicare off to a good start 16 days from now.

WASHINGTON, June 15 Russell B. Long of Louisiana, one of the Senate's most influential Democrats, gave the automobile industry a helping hand today in its fight with the Johnson Administration over a proposed antitrust provision of the auto safety bill.
A United States Weather Bureau forecast issued yester day indicates that above normal precipitation in the next 30 days may help to alleviate fur ther the Northeast's five-yearold drought.
Solid progress was reported yesterday toward resolving the dispute between the World Journal Tribune, Inc., and two of the newspaper unions.

CHICAGO, June 15 (AP) Lew Krausse, making his first start of the season, limited the Chicago White Sox to five hits in a seven-inning stint tonight and pitched the Kansas City Athletics to a 5-4 victory. The scheduled second game of the double-header was postponed because of rain.
LONDON, June 15 With its renewed international backing, the pound continued its recovery today, rising 3/32-cent, to $2.79 5/32.
Whether they realize it or not, prudent individuals and families are effectively applying basic economic principles in their personal financial planning.

DALLAS, June 15 A group of mayors asked the Federal Government today to use its powers to force all-white suburbs to bear part of the burden of housing and schooling low-income citizens of large cities.

SEOUL, South Korea, June 1 A new association of noncommunist Asian and Pacific states was formed today but was unable to agree on the wording of a joint statement on the conflict in South Vietnam, one of the nine member nations.
LONDON, June 15 The House of Lords voted 56 to 31 today in favor of televising "some of the proceedings for an experimental period."
WASHINGTON, June 15 The United States is resuming full-scale economic aid to India and Pakistan, the State Department announced this evening.

Haryou-Act, the beleaguered antipoverty agency, announced yesterday that it was undertaking extensive reforms in its operating methods as a result of a six month investigation by members of its board of directors.

L. Judson Morhouse, former chairman of the State Republican Committee, was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to serve two to three years in prison after hearing himself described as a man who misused the vast power of his political position to satisfy his greed for money."

The Long Wharf Theater in New Haven, will use part of its recent grant of $50,000 from the National council on the Arts to introduce four new shows during the summer. Three are by American playwrights who have not had professional production before, according to Harlan P. Kleiman, the Long Wharf's executive director.
LOS ANGELES, June 15 (UPI) Wes Parker's three-run homer capped a five-run fifth inning tonight that gave the Los Angeles Dodgers a 6-5 victory over the Chicago Cubs.
The new 1967 America's Cup defense candidate will be named Intrepid, but her owners are tempering confidence with caution.
Stock prices wobbled indecisively in active trading yesterday. Moderate selling pressure developed late in the session, and declines outnumbered advances by a small margin at the close.
The Alumni Federation of Columbia University has elected Robert D. Lilley, president and director of the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company, as its president.
ALBANY, Thursday, June 16 Top state and city officials were reported to have agreed yesterday on how much money was to be raised by a new broad-based tax for New York City.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) New promise was held out today that a painful facial ailment frequently may be treatable by a drug rather than surgery.

CHERRY HILL, N.J., June 15 (UPI) Paul Kallai moved Steel Pike into the early lead, then beat back a determined stretch drive by Our Michael and scored a nose victory today in the $15,000 added Select Handicap at Monmouth Park.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., June 15 This week, Indiana University has played host to Boys State, a national police pistol tournament, an economics planning seminar, the annual meeting of the Indiana Conference of Methodist Churches and an annual convention of Indianan Elks.
HOW good is Bent Larsen of Denmark, one of the eight grand masters scheduled to compete in the Piatigorsky Cup Tournament in Los Angeles next month?
DETROIT, June 15 (AP)--Teacher walkouts that closed 100 schools in southeastern Michigan have been narrowed to one, but more trouble is brewing.

A combination offering of 110,000 shares in Thalhimer Brothers, Inc., was made yesterday at $21.50 a share through an underwriting group led by Kidder, Peabody Co., Inc., F. W. Craigie Co., Inc., and Wheat Co., Inc.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 15 Billy Haughton drove Romulus Hanover, a 2-year-old chestnut son of Dancer Hanover and Romola Hanover, to a sevenlength victory in a one-mile nonbetting race for pacing colts at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. The mile of 2:04 2/5 was the season's fastest by a juvenile sidewheeler over a half-mile oval anywhere in the world.
New Yorkers will pay higher finance charges on automobiles, home improvements and most other installment loans at New York City's largest bank.
The Vietnam war is causing some of the country's major airlines to cut back or defer new commercial passenger services this summer.
The nations electric power production rose 7.8 per cent in the week ended June 11, from the level in the corresponding 1965 week, it was reported by the Edison Electric Institute yesterday.
Late profit taking depressed the majority of stocks on the American Stock Exchange yesterday. Earlier gains melted away in the last half hour of trading.

It is still too early to burn the featherbeds mandated by New York's archaic railroad Full-Crew Law. For more than half a century the law has compelled trains in this state to carry crews larger than safety or efficiency requires.

MIAMI BEACH, June 15 The safety director of the International Longshoremen's Association complained today that after eight years of trying, "I have found it almost impossible with the dozens of Federal agencies having jurisdiction in longshore safety, to get action on new legislation or strong enforcement of present safety laws."
OTTAWA, June 15 Chester Ronning, special Canadian Ambassador, has returned to North Vietnam in a new effort to establish a basis for peace talks.
Steel shares advanced on the London market yesterday on reports that a bill for steel renationalization favorable to the in dustry would be introduced in Parliament within a month.

LINCOLN, Neb., June 15 (UPI) Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson contributed an elm seedling to Nebraska's tree-planting program, visited the state's two largest cities and accepted citizenship is Boys Town today.
MADRID, June 15 (AP)--Vicente Rojo, chief of the Republican Army staff during the Spanish Civil War from 1936 to 1939, died today of a heart ailment. He was 71 years old.

How do you sell something you can't advertise? That's the dilemma the First National City Bank finds itself in now that the Securities and Exchange Commission has cleared the way for National City's controversial entry into the mutual-fund business.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., June 15 Winston H. Hagen, a director and a former treasurer of Cox Co., Inc., manufacturers in New York of military electronic equipment and temperature-control devices, died of a heart attack yesterday in his home on Bayville Road here. He was 59 years old.
TRENTON, June 15 In a dramatic rebuff to the New York Stock Exchange, the Senate decisively rejected tonight a move to bar the future imposition of a stock transfer tax in New Jersey.
WHILE the rest of the fashion world may be camping in tent coats, Leo Ritter of Ritter Brothers shapes furs as narrowly as dresses.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 15 Eastern European diplomats reported today that the question of Germany had become a subject of heated disagreement between Rumania, on one hand, and East Germany and Hungary, on the other, at the Moscow meeting of Warsaw Pact foreign ministers last week.
Two convicts who tried to escape from Rikers Island Prison were back behind bars yesterday because they ignored a major rule of military concealment.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 15 Ghanaian ministries have been abolished, diplomatic missions cut and grandiose economic plans junked as the National Liberation Council has guided the country out of the Nkrumah era.
Julius Rothkopf, a Yugoslav economics expert and a former member of the staff of Radio Free Europe, died Tuesday at his home, 156-08 Riverside Drive West. He was 69 years old.
BLEECKER STREET was a streamer-strewn, balloon dotted, antiques-cluttered, people-walking summer festival yesterday and will be again today, if the summer sun holds.

VENICE, Italy, June 15 Those who look to the Venice Bieanale for a large admixture of controversy, politics and sheer gossip to go with the unending exhibitions of painting and sculpture have not been disappointed by this Year's proceedings.

FALLS CHURCH, Va., June 15 Miss Beverley McNeil Grow, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Aubrey Patterson Grow of North Arlington, was married today to Second Lieut. Henry Brenner Jr., Medical Service Corps, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Brenner.
BRUSSELS, June l5 Union Miniere du Haut-Katanga, the Belgian-owned mining company that is the colosus of the Congo economy, is locked in an ambiguous embrace with the Congolese Government.

A plea for more stability in the agency-client relationship was made yesterday by a Chicago ad executive. At the same time, he laid down a list of guidelines for both advertisers and agencies to help stop the "painful, expensive and totally unnecessary rash of partner switching."

EUGENE, Ore., June 15 A defense fund was established today for a student editor who has refused to identify her sources for an article she wrote about marijuana smoking on the University of Oregon campus.
The marriage of Mrs. Frances Conant Balsam of 20 East 74th Street, widow of Aldo Balsam, to Cooper Schieffelin of Laurel Hollow, Syosset, L.I., took place yesterday afternoon.

Vornado, Inc., operator of the Two Guys discount stores, has elected Bernard Marcus, who heads the toiletries, cosmetics and stationery departments, and Horace R. Zimmerman, who heads the jewelry, luggage and giftware departments, as vice presidents.
The appointment of Dr. George Kozmetsky, 48 years old, as dean of the College of Business Administration at the University of Texas, Austin, was announced yesterday.

OTTAWA, June 15 W. Averell Harriman, special representative of President Johnson, and Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson discussed means of improving East-West contacts today. They conferred for 90 minutes at a luncheon meeting here.
LAWRENCE, L.I., June 15 Miss Dorothy Packer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Packer of Great Neck, was married this evening to Raymond Frommer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Frommer of Cedarhurst.

MONTREAL, June 15 (Canadian Press) A compromise agreement on wage increases was reached between Air Canada and 1,453 of its sales employes late tonight, only minutes before the midnight deadline for a strike.

Mr. and Mrs. Allan Younger of Flushing, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nan Younger, to Dr. Robert C. Stalnaker, son of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Stalnaker of Northfield, Ill.

William Baur had a gift to give his most productive years and he gave them to India. He was a very young man in 1926 when he left his home at Webster Groves, Mo., and traveled 10,000 miles to Madaya Pradesh, taking his bride of one week.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) The Internal Revenue Service will begin Monday to examine the activities of the Sierra Club of San Francisco, a major conservation organization with 20 chapters, to determine whether it still qualifies as a tax-exempt group eligible to receive deductible contributions.
WASHINGTON, June 15--President Johnson and Senator J.W. Fulbright gave a public indication today that relations between them had grown less hostile.

TRENTON, Thursday, June 16 Bowing to intense pressure by Gov. Richard J. Hughes, the Senate early this morning rammed through a Democratic Congressional reapportionment plan for New Jersey's 15 districts.

ROME, June 15 The Italian Communists' setback in the weekend municipal and provincial elections not so great as the anti-Communist zealots claim, greater than the Communists will concede raises the possibility that the biggest Communist party in the West may be on the way to a decline.

TOLEDO, Ohio, June 15 The world wrestling championships, once the exclusive property of the Middle East and Europe, open tomorrow in this Northwest Ohio shipping and industrial city for the second time in five years. More than 250 athletes from 28 countries are quartered here in three large University of Toledo dormitories.
WASHINGTON, June 15 The Federal Government hopes to put scientists to work on police problems on a massive, organized basis.

Jim Ryun, who broke the world record for the 880-yard run last Friday, will be permitted to compete in the Amateur Athletic Union national outdoor championships at Randalls Island, June 24 and 25, as a result of a ruling yesterday by Vice President Humphrey's sports arbitration board.

THE inevitable has happened. Two designers on opposite sides of the Atlantic have come up with the do-ityourself dress. It requires of the wearer no talent and less energy than five minutes of frugging.
COLONIA, N.J., June 15 Mrs. Merge Mason of RidgeWood Won the annual Elizabeth Goss round-robin tournament today with 20 points at the Colonia Golf Club.

CENTERPORT, L.I., June 15 Mr. and Mrs. John C. Gorman have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rosemary Therese Gorman, to James Kirby Guerin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph K. Guerin of New York.
WASHINGTON, June 15 Administration proposals to create a Redwoods National Park on the northern coast of California a national sys tem of wild rivers have been shelved until next year.
PHILADELPHIA, June 15 The first direct dialed telephone call between the United States and the continent of Europe was made today.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 15 Prof. Frank Ahern Heacock, a member of Princeton University's faculty for 38 years until his retirement in 1961, and a well-known engineer, died in Princeton Hospital this morning after an illness of several weeks. He was 73 years old and lived at 202 Prospect Ave.

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, June 15 (Reuters) The police used tear gas tonight against more than 1,000 rioters who surged through the streets of the Dutch capital for the third successive night, smashing property indiscriminately.
Cowles Communications, Inc., is making its second acquisition in the education market.
DENVER, June 15 (UPI) The Denver Broncos' season ticket sales were over the 19,000 mark.

FORT SMITH, Ark., June 15 (AP) Mrs. Nancy Roth Syms, the favorite, and Mrs. Lew Gilliam, the medal winner, led the field today into the quarterfinals of the 36th annual transMississippi women's amateur golf tournament.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 15 The 66th United States Open golf championship starts tomorrow at the Olympic Country Club course under new rules but with the old favorites.
About 700 Queens residents angrily entered City Hall yesterday and voiced loud objections to the city's plan to put up public housing in largely white middle-class neighborhoods.

LONDON, June 15 Dennis Ralston and Many Riessen reached the quarter-finals of the London grass-court tennis championship, the time-honored warm-up for the Wimbledon tournament, at the Queen's Club today.

Permitting his most formidable rival to set the pace until the final phase of the 1 1/8-mile race, Bobby Ussery guided Pluck to a seven-length triumph in the $27,150 Nassau County Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday.

Charles H. Tuttle told the students at the 120th commencement exercises of City College last night that history had never before offered moments "more exciting and fateful" than now, "none more fraught with universal destiny."

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) For the first time in 20 years the American Automobile Association removed the state of Georgia entirely today from its lists warning of "speed traps" and unusually strict traffic enforcement.

ATLANTA, June 15 (AP) Julian Bond, 26-year-old Atlanta Negro civil rights worker who was not permitted to take his seat in the Georgia House, qualified with the Democratic party today to seek the seat again.
The Eastern Federal Savings and Loan Association, Sayville, L.I., said yesterday it would begin July 1 to pay dividends at the rate of 4.65 per cent. The rate Eastern Federal now pays is 4 per cent.

LE MANS, France, June 15 Mario Andretti of Nazareth, Pa., a 26-year-old racing car driver, worked his skills at Reading, Pa. last Saturday night on a half-mile dirt track in an event of no consequence. Next Saturday night he will be driving a Ford at 225 miles an hour on a French black-top highway in an event of consequence, the Le Mans 24-hour race.
Dr. Harry D. Gideonse received a standing ovation yesterday from 3,238 graduating students of Brooklyn College at the last commencement at which he will preside.
Writers at the International P.E.N. Congress in New-York yesterday devoted thousands of words to modern forces inimical to their craft. This stirred a publisher who is participating to admonish them:

ALBANY, June 15 Most of the New York City officials who have been closeted in the Executive Mansion for three days wrangling over city taxes with Governor Rockefeller have run out of clean shirts and underwear.
WASHINGTON, June 15 Personal income rose by $2.4billion in May to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $565.5billion, the Commerce Department reported today.

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., June 15 John W. Glendening, who retired in 1947 as general auditor of the now defunct Commonwealth Southern Corporation of New York, died today at Orange Memorial Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived at 29 Kendall Avenue here.

SAN JOSE, Calif., June 15 (AP) Robert G. Fowler, an aviator who flew a biplane from California to Florida in 1911, collapsed and died, apparently of a heart attack, at his home today. He was 81 years old.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., June 15 Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower endorsed today Ronald Reagan's bid to become Governor of California. General Eisenhower said that if Mr. Reagan won, "you can bet" he would become a Republican Presidential possibility.

WASHINGTON, June 15 In sustaining the legality of Section 4(e) of the 1965. Civil Rights Act that was particularly designed to extend the right to vote to New York citizens who are literate only in the Spanish language, the Supreme Court left no room for doubt that, in this legislative area, Congress need fear no judicial curb on assertions of the power granted to it in the Fourteenth Amendment.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 15 John D. Holby, former president of University Society, Inc., educational publishers, died yesterday of a heart attack in his home at 40 Vine Lane. His age was 80.
DAKAR, Senegal, June 15 (Reuters) President Leopold Senghor has shuffled his Cabinet, bringing in three members of the Opposition.

Harry Eisenberg, a partner in the maritime law firm of Eisenberg Dembo, 305 Broadway, specializing in negligence cases, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived at 112-36 68th Avenue Forest Hills, Queens.

HELSINKI, Finland, June 15 If she does any extensive traveling abroad, Mrs. Aleksei N. Kosygin stands a better chance to make an impact as a popular world celebrity than does her husband, the Soviet premier.

WASHINGTON, June 15 In sustaining the legality of Section 4(e) of the 1965. Civil Rights Act that was particularly designed to extend the right to vote to New York citizens who are literate only in the Spanish language, the Supreme Court left no room for doubt that, in this legislative area, Congress need fear no judicial curb on assertions of the power granted to it in the Fourteenth Amendment.

WASHINGTON, June 15 Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen told Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach today that he did not believe the Senate would pass the open houshousing section of the Administration's civil rights bill.
HONG KONG, June 15 The purge of political figures in Peking has extended to the Communist Youth League.
HUE, South Vietnam, Thursday, June 16 The governing junta moved a batallion of loyal paratroopers into this rebellious city at dawn today.

Mrs. Dorothy Michelson Stevens, widow of William Dixon Stevens, was married yesterday to Goodhue Livingston. The Rev. Dr. Donald Walter Kring performed the ceremony in the Unitarian Church of All Souls.
GRENADA, Miss. June 15--A new mood among white Mississippians was dramatized today as civil rights marchers ended their visit here and struck west toward the state's cotton country.

WASHINGTON, June 15 In an effort to bring about adequate supervision of the border between Cambodia and South Vietnam, the United States has offered to pay for expanding the International Control Commission assigned there under the 1954 Geneva agreements.

Mrs. A. Ralph Wexler of Jackson Heights, Queens, and Livingston Manor, N.Y., has made known the engagement of her daughter, Miss Isadora Wexler, to Dr. Robert J. Quinlan of Guilford, Conn. He is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Joseph B. Quinlan.
Mayor Lindsay's City Hall "night owls" will celebrate six months of existence late next month.
The right of a union local to leave its parent international and retain all its funds and property was unanimously affirmed yesterday by the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court.

PARIS, June 15 Now at the end of its second European tour the Harkness Ballet has linked up temporarily with the Alvin Ailey Dance Company to appear in the Festival du Marais. This open-air festival takes place in the courtyards and grounds of some of Paris's noblest buildings, and the Harkness Ballet is dancing at the Hotel de Rohan, a beautiful 17th-century mansion.

The nonstop talks in Albany that have gone on since Monday to seek agreement on a tax program for New York City should have one by-product not on the agenda. They should prove beyond doubt the desirability of giving the city its independence, its home rule, its right to make its own decisions, even its own mistakes.

HAMILTON, N.Y., June 15 Dr. Marc R. Gutwirth, visiting associate professor of classical languages at Colgate University, was killed yesterday when the automobile he was driving was in a head-on collision with another car on Route 12 near here. The driver of the other car was injured.

Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, said last night that men who serve in the Palestine Liberation Army must be stricken from United Nations refugee relief rosters. The army, made up of Arab refugees, is dedicated to the restoration of Arab control in what is now Israel.
CHICAGO, June 15 Stringent police control has brought at least temporary peace to Chicago's Puerto Rican community on the Northwest Side.
RENNES, France, June 15 (Reuters)--Michel Jazy of France clocked 3 minutes 36.3 seconds tonight to better the European 1,500-meter record by one-tenth of a second.
The Public Housing Administration administered a $109.54million bond sale in the midst of a rising bond market yesterday, and investors quickly purchased an estimated 90 per cent of the bonds.

KINGS POINT, L.I., June 15 The United States Coast Guard Academy at New London, Conn., led after 10 races today in the Intercollegiate Yacht Racing Association's national dinghy championship for the Henry A. Morse Trophy. The races were held on Long Island Sound.

CAIRO, June 15 President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic declared tonight that further cooperation with right-wing Arab governments against Israel was futile and indicated his opposition to a top-level conference of Arab leaders scheduled to be held in Algiers next September.
The independent United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America announced yesterday that it had filed charges of unfair labor practices against the General Electric Company.
Mrs. Lillian Bostwick Davis, wife of Dr. E. William Davis of 770 Park Avenue and Old Westbury, L.I., died yesterday in New York Hospital after a brief illness. She was 31 years old.

In an effort to break the Albany deadlock over a law to prevent strikes by public employes, Senate Majority Leader Earl W. Brydges is now reported ready to accept the toothless bill passed by the Assembly if that is the only way to replace the CondonWadlin Act.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 15 President Sukarno assailed today "Parliamentary and liberal democracy" as practiced in Western countries.

BUFFALO, June 15 A joint United States-Canadian study on controlling levels of the Great Lakes by internal regulation of their waters is underway. But critics at a water symposium today suggested it might be better not to try.

MIAMI, June 15 (AP) Charles Pasarell, minus some of his sharpness, reached the quarter-finals of the National Collegiate tennis championship today with a 7-5, 6-4 victory over Jack Jackson of Tennessee.
BRASILIA, June 15 The Supreme Court granted today the Hanna Mining Company's request for an injunction against the former government's cancellation of its concessions for immense iron-ore deposits.
WALKER PERCY won the 1962 National Book Award for fiction with a first novel, "The Moyiegoer," Now, in "The Last Gentleman," he has written an even better book.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., June 15 James H. Meredith, the Negro shot while leading a voter registration march in Mississippi, said here today that "as an old military man" he believed in a good chain of command, which he believed was lacking in the Mississippi demonstrations. He served in the Air Force from 1951 to 1960.
ALBANY, June 15 Governor Rockefeller announced today his approval of a series of highway safety bills.

Cotton is the nation's biggest cash crop. It also is the biggest and most expensive crop problem. Unlike wheat and other grains, which are benefiting from rising world demand, cotton is in oversupply because of Government price supports, near stagnant demand and intense competition from man-made fibers. Cotton has cost the taxpayers over $3 billion during the past ten years and their bill will rise still further unless ways are found to increase consumption.
Ten Harlem parents staged a talk-in at a microphone for the last half hour of a Board of Education meeting last night, alternately haranguing the board and singing verses of "We Shall Overcome."

MOSCOW, June 15 The Soviet and United States flags hung side by side tonight in Moscow's Operetta Theater at the opening performance of the American Ballet Theater's sixweek cultural exchange tour of the Soviet Union. Russians and Americans in the audience stood at attention during the playing of the Soviet and United States national anthems.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 15 (UPI) Joe Adcock's threerun eighth-inning pinch homer gave the California Angels a 6-3 victory over the Minnesota Twins tonight and a doubleheader sweep after Clyde Wright won his major league debut with a four-hitter in the opener, 8-1.
A three-judge Federal Court yesterday ordered the Suffolk County Board of Supervisors to operate on a weighted vote basis until it could work out a solution to reapportionment.
Three members of a nationwide ring preying on homo sexuals pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal Court to conspiring to use interstate facilities to extort money.

In a lucid and practical report the City Planning Commission proposes basic policy and sound procedures that could halt the senseless and tragic destruction of the city's last open land on Staten Island.
LONDON, June 15--Prime Minister Wilson stamped out with ease today a Labor party revolt against his Government's policy of keeping a military presence east of Suez.

Richard S. Salant, president of news for the Columbia Broadcasting System, said yesterday he had "goofed" in permitting a staff correspondent to appear on a documentary produced by an outside company and televised by C.B.S. on Tuesday evening.

THE telephone book notes that McSorley's Old Ale House is at 15 East Seventh Street, but people who believe in leprechauns know better. It's at Ale Place and East Seventh Street, and there's a sign there to prove it.
COLUMBIA, S.C., June 15 Former Gov. Ernest F. (Fritz) Hollings defeated Senator Donald S. Russell in yesterday's Democratic primary with a combination of campaign skill and a fortuitous issue.
The stock market continued to trace an uncertain pattern yesterday as the pace of trading slowed.
The Glen Alden Corporation which acquired 28 per cent of Philip Carey Manufacturing Company stock through a tender offer last February, is now planning a merger.

CINCINNATI, June 16 (AP) A Federal court ordered the Federal Trade Commission today to hold new hearings in a case in which the agency had held that five drug companies combined to fix and maintain prices on tetracycline, an antibiotic.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) A Massachusetts State Senator said today that the New England Telephone and Telegraph Company was running a monitoring system that listens in on every telephone line in Boston over a period of 14 to 15 months.

WASHINGTON, June 16 Great American Industries Inc., its president, Walter S. Mack, and seven other individuals were accused by the Securities and Exchange Commission today of fraudulent acts aimed at running up the price of the company's stock on the American Stock Exchange.

ALBANY, June 16 At about 7 P.M. Wednesday, on the third day of bone-tiring tax negotiations inside the Executive Mansion, Governor Rockefeller's press secretary came out on the lawn and told newsmen to be ready for "something" within the next few hours.
The Women Stockbrokers Association, Inc., has elected new officers for the coming year.
They proved last night that it is no easier for a camel to pass through the eye of a needle than it is for a camel to go through a revolving door.

FORT SMITH, Ark., June 16 (AP) Roberta Albers sank a five-foot birdie putt on the 19th hole today for an upset victory over Mrs. Nancy Roth Syms in the quarter-finals of the TransMississippi women's amateur tournament.
A shroud of smoke hung over the busy industrial town of Bayonne, N.J., yesterday afternoon after the crash of the two oil tankers in the Kill Van Kull.
A new Childs Restaurant will soon occupy part of the ground floor and basement in the 25story building at 43 Exchange Place, between Broad and William Streets.

ALBANY, June 16 The following table summarizes the estimated returns from tax plans proposed for New York City by Mayor Lindsay, Senate Majority Leader Earl W. Brydges and Assembly Speaker Anthony J. Travia, and the final compromise package agreed upon early this morning:

TOKYO, June 16 The governing Liberal-Democratic party has decided not to submit to the current session of the Diet (Parliament) a bill that would restrict the spread of automatic coin-operatad laundries.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, June 17 Vietcong terrorists threw a grenade and detonated a mine near an American military bus stop here this morning, wounding 10 United States servicemen, an American spokesman said.
A tugboat captain who played a key role after two tankers collided yesterday in the Kill Van Kull described how he maneuvered his tug through flames to pull the burning vessels apart.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 16 President Johnson tonight pledged his Administration "to strive unremittingly" to strengthen the United Nations in its role of maintaining and restoring global peace.

St. John's Episcopal Church, in Pembroke, Bermuda, was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Anne Lindsay Gibson to Clive Davis Conley. Canon Jack Peel performed the ceremony, and the Rev. David Woodhouse assisted.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (UPI) The Justice Department accused Leflore County officials of having failed to protect Negro voting rights in the state's primary June 7.

Bayard Rustin, the Negro civil rights leader, said yesterday that he could not "see a racial issue involved" in the contest for Manhattan Surrogate and he intended to vote for Supreme Court Justice Samuel J. Silverman.

WOR-FM will become the first frequency modulation radio station here to broadcast rock 'n' roll music on a regular basis. The station now duplicates shows of WOR-AM, but will present separate programing from 9 A.M. to midnight, Mondays through Fridays, and from 5 P.M. to midnight on Saturdays and Sundays, beginning July 30.
HOOK OF HOLLAND, the Netherlands, June 16 (Reuters) The white whale of the Rhine, dubbed "Moby Dick," returned to the North Sea today after swimming in the polluted river for more than three weeks.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (UPI) Pete Richert and Ron Kline who went in with one out in the ninth stopped the Baltimore Orioles on one hit, Brooks Robinson's second-inning single, tonight as the Washington Senators scored a 2-1 victory.
DETROIT, June 16 (AP) Detroit's 10,000 public school teachers voted overwhelmingly today to strike, if necessary, a spokesman for the Detroit Federation of Teachers said.

Mrs. Christine Stewart Magera, local news editor of WPIXTV, died yesterday of pneumonia at Bellevue Hospital. Mrs. Magera, who was 34 years old and lived at 344 East 51st Street, was the wife of Roman Magera, an editor for The Canadian Press in New York.
AUSTIN, Tex., June 16 Gloomy testimony and statistics led the Texas Railroad Commission to reduce Texas oil production for the second month in a row, at its statewide proration hearing today.
Two tankers collided in bright sunlight in the waters between Bayonne and Staten Island yesterday and at least 21 men were killed and 40 were hospitalized in a thunderous explosion and fire.
PHILADELPHIA, June 16--Vice President Humphrey urged American universities today to abandon the concept that they must be isolated from life "by acres and acres of well tended lawn."
Bernardo DePace, an Italianborn mandolin player who performed widely in Europe and in the United States, died Wednesday in his home at 579 East 28th Street, Brooklyn. He was 85 years old.

LONDON, June 16 What could be the American Davis Cup team against what is certain to be Australia's defending team if they meet Down Under will clash is the semifinals of the London grasscourt championships tomorrow.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., June 16 (UPI) Rising humidity and falling temperatures enabled firefighters to gain the upper hand today in their battle to contain the fire in the Los Padres National Forest that has charred more than 90,000 acres of brush and timber.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) The ration of packaged liquor for American military and civilian personnel in Vietnam has been cut by more than half.

Five Tonys, emblematic of the best of the Broadway season of 1965-66, were awarded yesterday to the musical "Man of La Mancha" and its creators. Four went to "Marat/Sade," a drama. A posthumous award was made to Helen Menken, president of the American Theater Wing since 1956, who had supervised arrangements for the prizes until last year.
WASHINGTON, June 16 Ronald Reagan stood up today two blocks from the White House and set forth his blueprint for a "constructive alternative" to the Great Society.
Rainer Barzel has broken some dramatic new ground with proposed concessions that might be offered to the Soviet Union as part of an agreement for the reunification of Germany in freedom.

In 1867, an overpass was opened on Broadway at Fulton Street to protect pedestrians against death from surging horse-drawn traffic. Two years later it was torn down. New Yorkers refused to use it; let the horses climb the two flights of overpass steps, they said, not us.

WASHINGTON, June 16--The current discussions on future American merchant marine policy have created too much heat and have not been conducive of the productive atmosphere "in which the seeds of long-range solutions must be sown and harvested," a leading maritime industry spokesman said here today.

ATLANTA, June 16 Tony Cloninger of the Atlanta Braves personally demolished the New York Mets tonight, but he also got a lot of unnecessary help from a gang of accomplices. Cloninger hit a three-run homer in an eight-run third inning, added a single and a two-run homer subsequently, and pitched a five-hitter for a 17-1 victory.

DARIEN, Conn., June 16 Miss Stephanie Loe Wold, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Antheney Wold, became the bride today of Peter Terrell Maxwell of Bloomfield Hills, Mich. The Rev. Lawrence McColl Horton performed the ceremony in the Noroton Presbyterian Church.
Following is a partial list of the dead and missing in the Kill Van Kull tanker collision:
Three gunmen robbed the owner of a jewelry concern in midtown yesterday of $50,000 worth of diamond pieces and $2,000 in cash, according to the police.

A plan to publish an opposition magazine in Yugoslavia was described yesterday by the sister of Mihajlo Mihajlov, who would be the publisher. It would be the first such publication to appear behind the Iron Curtain.
John M. Gaver, the trainer of the Greentree Stable horses, has been elected to membership in the Hall of Fame of the National Museum of Racing at Saratoga Springs, N.Y.
WASHINGTON, June 16--Organized labor's high command backed George Meany today in a stormy showdown with Walter P. Reuther over labor's boycott of an International Labor Organization meeting.

ST. LOUIS, June 16 (AP)--The Pittsburgh Pirates ended a 20-inning scoreless streak tonight with Willie Stargell's second-inning home run and added a run on Roberto Clemente's single in the ninth to de feat St. Louis, 2-1.
PARAMUS, N.J., June 16 Two former champions were defeated today in the New Jersey State amateur golf championship over the West and Center nines of the Ridgewood Country Club.
The facade of the New York Shakespeare Festival's Delacorte Theater in Central Park has been embellished by 20 black-andwhite silhouette studies of prominent Shakespearean characters.

SEOUL, South Korea, June 16 The nine non-Communist states that have formed the new Asian and Pacific Council affirmed their solidarity with South Vietnam today in its fight against "external aggression and subversion" and deplored North Vietnam's rejection of peace overtures.

The New York Stock Exchange, bowing to pressure from the Securities and Exchange Commission, announced yesterday that it planned to reduce the extra charge levied on investors who buy and sell fewer than 100 shares at a time.
A jury of 10 was named yesterday by the National Endowment for the Arts to appraise 20 plays and select seven for production at resident professional, university and Off Broadway theaters.
LONDON, June 16--The House of Lords gave its final approval today to a bill repealing criminal penalties for homosexual conduct by consenting adults in private. The vote was 78 to 60.
TOKYO, June 16 (AP) Another university chief, the rector in Nanking, has been dropped as part of the continuing political purge in Commu nist China, the Peking radio announced today.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 16 Al Mengert, who couldn't find a playing partner for a practice round here Monday, led the United States Open golf championship today with a 67.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., June 16 The reaction of Suffolk County's 10 town supervisors, the legislative arm of the county government, varied today on yesterday's order by a three-member Federal court that the Board of Supervisors adopt immediately an interim weighted voting system.

Deputy Mayor Timothy W. Costello promised representatives of two entertainment unions and a leading nightclub owner yesterday that he would cooperate in efforts to abolish the city's 26-year-old requirement that cabaret performers and employes be fingerprinted and licensed.

SYDNEY, Australia, June 16 Huge reserves of natural gas, found 500 miles north of Adelaide, were believed here today to have made it certain that the South Australian capital will be the first major Australian city supplied with natural gas.
ALBANY, June 16 (AP)--A newspaper reporter and a radio station news director have been named winners of the New York State Bar Association's 1966 press awards.
The city's reported plans to reorganize welfare and antipoverty operations were attacked yesterday as an attempt to destroy community-run programs.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., June 16 Gerry Lindgren stopped coughing long enough today to win the six-mile run, the first final of the National Collegiate outdoor track and field championships. But he had to share the glory with the omnipresent Tommie Smith, Charlie Greene and Randy Matson, all of whom dented meet records.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., June 16 Miss Georgia Ann Santangelo and Peter Michael Derrico plan to be married Aug. 27 at the Waldorf-Astoria in New York.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 16 The Security Council voted unanimously today to extend the term of the peacekeeping force in Cyprus for another six months, until Dec. 26.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 16 When memories are joggled even slightly, the conversation starts to flow. Such was the case today before the United States Open began on the exacting Olympic Club course, where the trees crowd the fairways in junglelike profusion and grab greedily at wayward shots.

HUE, South Vietnam, June 16 Government troops seized control of about a quarter of Hue today after a series of minor skirmishes with Buddhist-led dissidents. Some soldiers were supporting the dissident forces.
MILWAUKEE, June 16 (AP)--Kathy Whitworth carded a sizzling 68 today to take a two-stroke lead in the opening-round of the $13,000 Jaycee open women's golf tournament.

RUMSON, N.J., June 16 Mrs. Virginia Barrett Melniker of Asbury Park was married here today to Thomas F. Daly of Rumson. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Joseph Sullivan at the Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church.
MOSCOW, June 16 (AP) Five Americans stand a good chance of winning prize money in the violin and cello divisions of the Third International Tchaikovsky Competition.

BALBOA, C.Z., June 16 With a half month's ship traffic yet to be handled before the fiscal year 1968 closes June 30, the Panama Canal is already setting new records on its three major statistical indicators transits, tolls and cargo.
WASHINGTON, June 16 Secretary of State Dean Rusk told a Senate subcommittee today that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization had just passed "with confidence" a critical test of its vitality.

"I didn't think it was so bad at first, not as bad as some of the torpedos I caught in the war," said Jesse R. Vick, a fireman on the Texaco Massachusetts, one of the two tankers involved in a fiery crash in the Kill Van Kull yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, June 16 Miss Wendy Ann Cowperthwaite and Charles A. Fritz 3d, son of Professor and Mrs. Fritz Jr. of Storrs; Conn., were married here this afternoon. The bride's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Morgan Cowperthwaite of Ottsville.

PARIS General de Gaulle is now in the process of accomplishing the unusual diplomatic feat of having his cake while eating it. He has ruthlessly booted NATO out of France, lock, stock but not yet barrel; lock and stock meaning NATO military headquarters and American bases which must be evacuated by next April. But barrel, referring to the alliance's political headquarters, remains to be evicted.

New York is being explored, along with the problems of literature, by the 450 foreign writers attending the International P.E.N. Congress. The verdict, in words heard around the corridors of the Loeb Student Center of New York University, is "electric," "dynamic" and "a wonderful cosmopolis."

The Consolidated Edison Company is discussing with the Pennsylvania Railroad a plan to generate power in Trenton for New York City as a means of replacing antiquated Con Edison plants that are among major contributors to New York's air pollution.
The Chase Manhattan Bank announced yesterday the appointment of James W. North as a senior vice president. Mr. North is group executive of the personal trust group of the bank's trust department.

Lincoln Gordon, Assistant Secretary of State for InterAmerican Affairs, said last night that a "peaceful revolution," encouraged by the Alliance for Progress, was under way in many parts of Latin America.

THE HAGUE, June 16 The Provos and others blame the Amsterdam police for this week's riots in Amsterdam, charging excessive use of force. The police blame the Provos youthful, self-styled "Provocateurs" and lenient judges. The conservatives blame the welfare state. And everyone blames this week's heat wave.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 16 An American recently met a Vietnamese he had known for several years as a middleranking civil servant.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 16 (AP) Juan Marichal of the San Francisco Giants scored his 12th victory today, beating the Houston Astros, 2-1 on four hits. The triumph was the Giants' fifth straight.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) The American Institute of Architects awarded a $15,000 grand prize today to a Houston architectural firm for designing a community educational and recreation center that can serve also as a fallout shelter.
THE PRESIDENT Saw William Porter, Deputy Ambassador to South Vietnam; saw Ralph Hall, national commander of Amvets; spoke to state legislative meeting; met with Cabinet.

LOS ANGELES, June 16 (AP) Bob Hendley doubled home two runs in a four-run rally in the second inning tonight as the Chicago Cubs trimmed Los Angeles, 5-3, handing Don Drysdale his fourth straight loss.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 16--A reception for the crews of the foreign vessels at the Newport Casino, a captains' meeting for the trans-Atlantic contestants, a bit of paper work in connection with the Newport Bermuda race and a lot of manual toil constituted the business of the yachting fraternity here today.

Miss Leslie Gordon was married yesterday to Oliver Walston, son of Lord Walston, Under Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs in the British Government, and Lady Walston of Cambridge, England. Algernon D. Black of the Ethical Culture Society performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Milton A. Gordon, at 740 Park Avenue.

Alfred John O. Speak, who helped establish the Boys Clubs of Newark and the Junior Chamber of Commerce branch there, died of a heart attack Wednesday in St. Barnabas Hospital in Livingston, N.J. He was 65 years old and lived at 14 Rutgers Street in Maplewood, N.J.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange weakened yesterday for the third day in a row.
WASHINGTON, June 16 The House voted overwhelmingly today against giving President Johnson stand-by power to control consumer installment credit as an anti-inflation measure.

Dr. Paul T. Connolly, who retired in the fall as an ophthalmologist here and in Bronxville, N.Y., died yesterday in the Veterans Administration Hospital. His age was 72 and he lived at 38 Hornbeam Road in South Duxbury, Mass.
Mediators in the 53-day-old newspaper strike pushed yesterday for settlements by this weekend between the World Journal Tribune, Inc., and the drivers and the New York Newspaper Guild.

Mayor Lindsay and his Democratic allies returned from the long talks in Albany with a negotiated agreement on a tax program for New York City that can be regarded as a half-victory. On revenue, it is far short. It ignores the long-demonstrated need for fiscal reform. It lays nothing aside for replenishment of exhausted reserves. It assumes that no unforeseen expenditure increases will require budget modifications upward during the year, though they always do.
The Trade Bank and Trust Company has appointed A. Bundy Cole vice presidenttrust officer, it was announced yesterday by Henry L. Schenk, president.
BALTIMORE, June 16 (AP) A $2,520,000 syndicate, the largest in the history of American racing, was formed today to purchase Kauai King, the 1966 winner of the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., June 16 The International Longshoremen's Association made a final payment of $60,000 to the United Mine Workers this week, clearing up a debt of $473,000, Thomas W. Gleason, president of the 60,000-member pier union, told 350 delegates at the closing session of their four-day regional convention here.

New Jersey's Senate deserves credit for rejecting a proposed constitutional amendment to prohibit a stock transfer tax in the state. This lure to the New York Stock Exchange was based on the theory that it would materially encourage the New York exchange to leave Wall Street and open a trading floor in New Jersey.
IN a large living-and-working loft on Seventh Avenue Betty Thomson is making take-apart, put-togethr structures for children.

A 20-year-old girl who majored in mathematics became yesterday the first student in the history of Hunter College to graduate with a 4.0 index, or perfect average, for a full fouryear course of study at the college.

BONN, June 16 The governing body of the ruling Christian Democratic party dissociated itself today from statements in Washington by Dr. Rainer Barzel in which he raised the possibility that Soviet troops might be allowed to remain in a reunited Germany "in the framework of a European security system."
The city's transit fare will go up to 20 cents within the next two weeks, and perhaps to 25 cents in the near future, authoritative sources said yesterday.

New Yorkers who have been ignoring their traffic summonses and getting away with it for up to a year and a half will soon be tracked down by the Criminal Court within five weeks with the aid of a new computer system.

RICHMOND, Va., June 15 When William B. Spong Jr., a candidate for the United States Senate, is in Richmond he frequently makes hand-shaking forays into the financial district on Main Street, where the bank buildings are high and shiny.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, June 16 (AP) A helicopter missing for a week in the Yukon with three persons aboard was found 120 miles north of Dawson City last night by a United States Air Force C-130 Hercules.
With almost persistent reguclarity, wheat and soybeans have been making life-of-contract highs recently. Yesterday, they did it once again.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., June 16 (UPI)--Harold Worst, the world's three-cushion billiards champion, died early today in Blodgett Memorial Memorial Hospital of cancer. He was 37 years old and had lived here.

Dr. J. Lewis Blass, professor of periodontia and oral medicine at New York University's College of Dentistry, died Wednesday night at the New York Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived at 4108 Ocean Avenue in Brooklyn and had an office at 4 East 41st Street.

The Internal Revenue Service has introduced a new procedure for tax-exempt organizations that raises serious questions of fairness and administrative due process. The Sierra Club, a society of energetic and outspoken conservationists, is the first organization to run afoul of this regulation; but its implications are significant and ominous for many other nonprofit educational, scientific and conservationist groups throughout the nation.

As a result of the new city income tax, the resident New York city taxpayer can look forward to an additional deduction from his paycheck and a third income tax form to fill out and return by April 15. In all probability, there will be a new small box on the stub of each paycheck labeled "city income tax" that will indicate the amount withheld.
GENEVA, June 16 Britain's delegate at the disarmament conference deplored today the Soviet Union's "unhealthy and myopic obsession" with German and European affairs.

Price trends in the bond market diverged yesterday. Corporate bonds rose sharply and municipal bonds sold actively but Government bonds closed with declines at the end of a series of price swings that left traders confused.

Business loans surged upward by $784-million at major banks in New York and Chicago during the week ended Wednesday, as corporations borrowed to make tax and dividend payments, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
N.Y. STOCK EXCHANGE Stocks declined, although final prices for many issues were above the lows of the day, as trading slowed; volume, 6.87 million shares.

WASHINGTON, June 16 House and Senate foreign policy committees completed their work today on the Administration's $3.4-billion foreign aid authorization request. The Senate version cut $142.2-million from the measure and attached a score of administrative restrictions while the House committee gave the Administration a clear-cut victory.
VIENTIANE, Laos, June 15 The military, leadership crisis in Laos had eased with the agreement by Brig. Gen. Phao Ma, air force chief, to move his base of operations from Sa"annakhet to Vientiane.

MIAMI, June 16 (AP) Top-seeded Charles Pasarell of the University of California, Los Angeles, twice rallied from the brink of defeat to lead three other Coast representatives into the semi-finals of the National Collegiate tennis championship today.

RENO, June 16 Civil Defense rockets misfired at three sites during a practice alert last night and, in the worst of the mishaps, rocked the new City Hall, shattered windows four blocks away, felled power lines, pulverized a truck, injured one man and stampeded hundreds of residents.

Charles Seidenman, national sales manager of the Vermont Furniture Company and former president of the Home Furnishings Club of Greater New York, died Wednesday night of a heart attack while attending a sales meeting at the company's showroom, .200 Lexington Avenue. He was 76 years old and lived at 115 Pomona Avenue, Newark.

JOSEPH PAPP presses on. Under his administrative direction, the New York Shakespeare Festival opened its 12th season on Wednesday night, and the open-air Delacorte Theater in Central Park was packed to welcome it. Under his artistic direction, the company played "All's Well That Ends Well," giving this play its New York professional premiere.

OULU, Finland, June 16 The industrial engineer who became Premier of the Soviet Union was in his element today touring three factories in central Finland and escaping all but the bare minimum of protocol.
Daniel J. Donovan has beer elected a vice president for Government securities by the First Boston Corporation, it was announced yesterday.

Senator Mike Mansfield called yesterday for a meeting between Secretary of State Dean Rusk and Communist China's Foreign Minister, Chen Yi, to seek "a curb on the expansion of the war" in Vietnam "and a prompt and durable termination of the tragic bloodletting."
WASHINGTON, June 16 Industrial production rose strongly in May despite the decline in automobile manufacturing, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
The president of Yonkers Raceway, Martin Tananbaum, said yesterday he thought the track would suffer a loss in business if night harness racing were permitted "across the river."

GREENWOOD, Miss., June 16 Gov. Paul B. Johnson Jr. reversed today his policy of providing heavy protection for the civil rights march through Mississippi, and resistance to the march stiffened immediately.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 16--About 20 United States marines held a barren, rocky hill for almost six hours today against repeated attacks by a Vietcong force estimated at 400.
John W. Suling, a lawyer here for 48 years, died yesterday morning at Mountainside Hospital in Glen Ridge, N.J. He was 86 years old and lived at 37 Oakwood Avenue in Upper Montclair, N.J.

WASHINGTON, June 16 Freight traffic on United States railroads in the week ended June 1 was the highest since the October 1944 wartime total. Intercity truck tonnage in the same period registered a sizeable year-to-year increase.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 16 St. Luke's Episcopal Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Sara Noyes Hall, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Marcus Brown Hall of Stowe, Vt., to Alvin Watkinson Fargo 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fargo Jr. of South Plainfieid. The Rev. George M. Bean, rector of the church, performed the ceremony. A reception was held at the Montclair Golf Club.
THE dynamic German politician Dr. Rainer Barzel comes from a 700-year-old East Prussian village, now Polish-controlled, that has seen one conqueror after another in its long history.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 16 In Trinity Episcopal Church here this afternoon, Miss Leslie Dudley du Pont, daughter of Mrs. Bernard Peyton, became the bride of Cuthbert Latta Myrin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lars B.C. Myrin of Ivy, Va. The Rev. Dr. Robert R. Spears Jr. performed the ceremony.
NORFOLK, Va., June 16 (UPI) Two Puerto Rican crewmen who survived the sinking of a barge in the Caribbean Sea were rescued from a raft today by the guided missile frigate Luce.
The New York Yankees' "revival," which has been badly in need of a revival of its own lately, got one last night when the Yankees routed Sam McDowell and defeated the Cleveland Indians, 7-6.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 16 A favorable response rate of about 50 per cent has been shown by alcoholics treated with LSD, a Canadian psychiatrist said here today.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 16--Steven B. Derounian sharply criticized Senator Jacob K. Javits today for breaking his role of neutrality and favoring William J. Casey, Mr. Derounian's Republican primary opponent in Nassau County's Third Congressional District.
BOSTON, June 16 (AP) Denny McLain gained his 10th victory today as the Detroit Tigers routed the Boston Red Sox, 16-4.

A Harvard Medical School professor has charged that some medical experiments in humans are ethically unsound performed without the patients' full knowledge and consent and without promise of benefit to them or to other patients.

"THEY treat you like an addlepated princess you don't have to make any decisions," Nancy Kelly, the actress, said last weekend. Miss Kelly, dressed in a loose, yellow terry cloth robe, was soaking in the sun on the terrace of the Hambletonian Spa in Goshen, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, June 16 The outlook now is for a hot and bloody summer of fighting in Vietnam, followed by another effort to arrange a cease-fire before the constitutional assembly elections in September.

WASHINGTON, June 16 The New Jersey Republican Congressional delegation threatened tonight to take its state's new reapportionment plan to court if it is given final approval by the Legislature and signed by Gov. Richard J. Hughes.

LONDON, June 18 (UPI) The executive board of Britain's striking seamen's union will decide tomorrow whether to call off the walkout, now in its fifth week, or continue it, presumably with new, tougher action.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) A warning to all Federal agencies and officials against rolling back or freezing farm prices below parity levels was passed by the Senate today by unanimous voice vote.

ALMOST immediately following the ousting of Nikita Sergeyevich Khrushchev from his position of supreme power in the Soviet Union in October, 1964, it occurred to several New York publishers to commission biographies of the round man from Kursk Province. For Khrushchev was a personality supreme ironically, considering the ...
ALBANY, June 16 The three-month deadlock over new taxes for New York City ended early today with bipartisan agreement on a personal income tax on city residents and an earnings levy on commuters.

United Shoe Machinery Corporation reported yesterday consolidated net income of $3,851,962, equal to $1.68 a share, for the quarter ended May 31. This compares with $3,570,033, or $1.55 a share, for the corresponding three months a year ago. Gross operating income increased to $69,620,714 from $59,968,468.

CHICAGO, June 16 (AP) Mr. and Mrs. Chester Fronczak are planning to adopt a child from a New Jersey orphanage who they think might be the infant who was kidnapped from Mrs. Fronczak's arms in a hospital two years ago, it was learned tonight.
The first tentative reaction of politicians to the Albany tax agreement yesterday was that Governor Rockefeller might have helped his chances of reelection, and had at least held his ground.

QUEBEC, June 16 (AP) Daniel oJhnson, 51 years old, was sworn in as the 20th Premier of Quebec Province in the legislative chamber tonight in a ceremony that was interrupted constantly by the untraditional cheering of a crowd of 600.
THE brownstone at 111 East 35th Street that was opened to the public last year by Celanese Fibers has just been redecorated for an imaginary family.
OMAHA, June 16 St. John's University was eliminated from the college world series tonight, losing to Oklahoma, State University by 6-1.

A hearing on efforts to settle suits by a group of stockholders against several officers and directors of the Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation was adjourned yesterday in the New York Supreme Court until June 22.

WASHINGTON, June 16 David Sarnoff, chairman of the Radio Corporation of America, called tonight for the establishment of a world patent office. Modern communications, Mr. Sarnoff asserted, have made feasible a universal system, operated from a single center.
Robert Gordon resigned as president and chief executive officer of the DWG Cigar Corporation at a directors meeting yesterday.

Letters commending L. Judson Morhouse for "integrity, honesty and devotion to good government" were sent to a State Supreme Court justice by Senator Jacob K. Javits, former Gov. Thomas E. Dewey and a secretary to Governor Rockefeller before the former Republican state chairman was sentenced on Wednesday.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday obtained an order in Supreme Court, New York County, barring a Brooklyn college student from raising $2.5-million for the production of a television series of historical documentaries.
TRENTON, June 16 Nighttime horse racing in New Jersey, which could siphon off much of the betting money from New York's lucrative race tracks, seemed assured today after years of vain efforts.
WASHINGTON, June 16 The State Department was noncommittal today about the proposals for Germany's reunification made here by Dr. Barzel.

THE annual United Jewish Appeal event held Monday night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel once again broke all records for a single local charity bridge event. Sixtynine tables were in play, and 44 experts were in attendance at the instance of tournament co-chairman Mrs. Samuel Stayman. Almost $13,000 was raised for the scholarship fund.
WASHINGTON, June 16 The House Banking Committee voted today to limit the interest rate commercial banks can pay on time deposits to 5 per cent for all depositors other than corporations.

Harvey Goodman, national director of the American Zionist Fund, the fund-raising arm of the Zionist Organization of America, died Wednesday night while addressing a meeting of his organization here. He was 54 years old and lived at 3935 Blackstone Avenue in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

Robert E. Maher of 57 Dekoven Court in Brooklyn, sports make-up editor of The Sun from 1915 until its merger with The New York World-Telegram in 1950, died yesterday at Holy Family Hospital in Brooklyn. His age was 71.

WINSTON SALEM, N.C., June 16 This year Win ston-Salem is observing the 200th anniversary of its founding. Unlike most American cities as old or older, it is able to celebrate the event by reviving music that was a part of the early community's way of life.
An 86-year-old painting by the French artist Claude Monet, valued at $250,000, had a hole the size of a pencil stub punched in it yesterday as it hung in a gallery at the Metropolitan Mu seum of Art.
OYSTER BAY, L.I., June 16 Ann Meinertz of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club won the ninth annual competition for the Henry S. Morgan Cup yesterday on Long Island Sound.

The City Record has disclosed the creation of some new city jobs and reshuffles of old ones. Some of the changes were described as part of the Lindsay administration's continuing reorganization of city government.

ORANGE, N.J., June 16 Charles Borinsky, chairman of the board of Tuscan Dairy, Union, a milk distributing concern founded by his father, died yesterday at Orange Memorial Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived at 177 Elmwynd Drive.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, June 16 Mrs. Nelson A. Rockefeller was named chairman of the board of the new Saratoga Performing Arts Center, and her husband, Governor Rockefeller, played the role of proud husband during a ceremony dedicating the $4.1-million center here today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 16 The placing of Vietnamese family altars in the streets of Saigon as a symbol of protest against the military Government continued today, but it did not reach large proportions.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (UPI)--Premier Nguyen Cao Ky of South Vietnam has ordered disciplinary action against Government policemen who roughed up American newsmen, Saigon's Ambassador to the United States said today.

WASHINGTON, June 16 Legislation authorizing the Secretary of the Interior to make a two-year feasibility study of a national recreation area in the Connecticut Valley was introduced in Congress today.
WASHINGTON, June 16 A bill authorizing Federal outlays of $260-million for a three-year highway safety program was approved today by the House Public Works Committee.

TOLEDO, Ohio, June 16 The 19th world wrestling championships opened today amid a burst of political frenzy as the East German team withdrew in protest over conditions governing its participation here.
WASHINGTON, June 16 Adamant foes of Medicare are pushing a nationwide campaign to convince doctors that they should shun a short-cut system of collecting fees for treating elderly patients.

LONDON, June 16 David M. Koetser, an art dealer, has presented a painting by Titian, which he values at nearly half a million dollars to Britain to repay a debt he believes he has incurred to British art.
RICHARD S. SALANT'S prompt and candid expression of displeasure over the presentation of the documentary on Wall Street is a constiuctive forward step for television journalism.
Leading industrials advanced along a broad front on the London Stock Exchange yesterday.
Neither Manufacturers Hanover Trust nor Mr. McNeill would comment yesterday on the letter asking stockholders to thank Senator Robertson. The text of the letter, dated Feb. 24, 1966, follows:
WASHINGTON, June 16 The State Department raised to day the question whether Premier Fidel Castro is still in full command in Cuba.
Indian Head, Inc., reported yesterday its highest quarterly earnings in history and announced election of a new chairman and a board member.
Rode J. Elving, an actress for many years on the Yiddish stage in the Newark area, died Tuesday in Florida after a long illness. The widow of Bernard Elving, she was 72 years old.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 110.9 on Wednesday from 110.5 on Tuesday.

CHICAGO, June 16 (AP) Tom McCraw hit two home runs, one a grand-slam, as he powered the Chicago White Sox to a 5-2 victory over the Kansas City Athletics and a sweep of their double-header tonight. The White Sox had snapped a three-game losing streak by taking the opener, 6.4, scoring twice in the seventh inning on a wild pitch and a passed ball to break a 4-4 deadlock.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 16 W. Averell Harriman, United States Ambassador at Large, counseled today against any retreat from the spirit of the Marshall Plan toward "neo-isolationism" in foreign aid.

WASHINGTON, June 16 A former Communist party member need not inform on his Communist associates to qualify as a Communist "defector" and avoid deportation, the Board of Immigration Appeals announced today.

VIETIANE, Laos, June 15 North Vietnamese troops infiltrating South Vietnam through Laos have transformed sections of the Ho Chi Minh Trail into all-weather routes to keep truck traffic moving during the rainy season.

WFSTPORT, Conn., June 16 Miss Sandra Elaine Marceau, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. LeRoy Marceau of Fairfield, was married here at noon today to Peter Miner Briggs. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Briggs of Plymouth, Mass.

Despite an obvious bumping incident with the runner-up in the stretch, Seima Udko's Hoist Bar won the main event at Aqueduct yesterday. Hoist Bar, ridden by Manuel Ycaza, collided with Winnie, guided by Bobby Ussery, just before moving into the lead, and went on to a three-quarters-of-a-length advantage at the finish of the six-furlong sprint.
ATHENS, June 16 (UPI) Senator Robert F. Kennedy stole the stage from the Acropolis today.
WASHINGTON, June 16 The moon is a "very gritty, bouldery, pebbly, silt-like" place, apparently "a sort of a neutral gray," scientists said today in reporting the Surveyor 1 spacecraft's findings.

ATLANTA, June 16 Eight civil rights groups charged today that Atlanta hospitals were about to be certified for Medicare and other Federal funds without having met desegregation requirements under the law.
POTTERSVILLE, N.J., June 16 (AP) A farmer who killed a 230-pound black bear last week as it climbed a tree in a dairy farm received a summons yesterday for shooting it out of season.
People, not raindrops, are responsible for most of the improvement in this year's water supply, the city's Acting Water Commissioner, Robert D. Clark, said yesterday.

William G. Hart, a make-up man in the composing room of The New York Times for the last 11 years, died yesterday, apparently of a stroke, in Jackson, Mich. He was 59 years old and lived in Kew Gardens, Queens.
WASHINGTON, June 16 Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler strongly criticized today some types of state and municipal tax-exempt bond is sues and hinted that action might be taken to curb them.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) Postmaster General Lawrence F. O'Brien moved today to dampen overzealousness by some Government officials in the campaign to get Federal employes to buy United States savings bonds.

The marriage of Miss Lynn Touchstone Weaver, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Douden Weaver of Paget West, Bermuda, to Second Lieut. James Mason Dwinell, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bancroft Dwinell of Montpelier Vt., took place yesterday afternoon in Paget.
COLUMBIA CITY, Ind., June 16 (AP) Deodat Clejan, who developed a specialized type of piggy-back automobile, and two other men were killed today when two planes collided.

Reports that city and state officials had agreed on a 25 per cent increase in the stock transfer tax rather than the 50 per cent originally proposed by Mayor Lindsay produced a decided shift of emphasis on Wall Street yesterday.
ATHENS, June 16 (UPI) Senator Robert F. Kennedy stole the stage from the Acropolis today.
The spot rate on the British pound continued to recover yesterday in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here.
WASHINGTON, June 16 A national conference of state legislative leaders today endorsed President Johnson's policy in Vietnam.
MANILA, June 16 (UPI) An American couple who circled the world in the record time of 126 hours aboard a twin-engine plane last week are up and flying again.

Charles H. Mayer, former publisher of The San Francisco Examiner and president of the William Randolph Hearst Foundation, died, apparently of a heart attack, yesterday while attending a board meeting at the office of the Hearst Corporation, 959 Eighth Avenue.
The American Can Company announced yesterday that it would build a new headquarters building within the next three years in the New York metropolitan area.
WASHINGTON, June 16 A House Judiciary subcommittee avoided a vote today on the open housing section of the Administration's civil rights bill and left the decision to the full committee.
