LONDON, June 16--The Government-owned Cable and Wireless, Ltd., the biggest cable company in the world, announced today that it would build three new ground stations for satellite communications.
Thinking of writing for tickets for opening night of the new Metropolitan Opera House? Forget it.

Secrecy enveloped a United States District Court proceeding yesterday involving a man who admits having smuggled millions of dollars worth of heroin into this country. Federal agents expressed fear that he might be murdered.
Reaction to the city tax program ranged yesterday from relief that it wasn't worse to commuter mumblings about "taxation without representation." But there was no ferment for revolution.

What is prompt disclosure? That is a question that has long perplexed corporate executives and there could hardly be a more crusial one. Some time ago, the Securities and Exchange Commission charged that officials at Texas Gulf Sulphur bought company stock before informing stockholders fully about a promising mineral discovery.

Miss. Laura Beth Hagler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Bruce Hagler of 150 East 69th Street, was married last evening to A. Richard Benedek, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin H. Benedek of 900 Fifth Avenue. The ceremony was performed in the Terrace Room of the Plaza by Rabbi Harry Halperin.
CAPE KENNEDY, June 16 (UPI) A Titan 3-C rocket put eight satellites into orbits high above the Equator today.

John Tchicai, an alto saxophonist who is often one of the more lucid and communicative members of the jazz avantgarde, gave a Carnegie Recital Hall concert last night that failed to show him in either a lucid or communicative light.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 16--The United States and the Soviet Union, the leading rivals in the race to put a man on the moon, are competing for the honor of being first in defining the rules for human behavior in space.

WASHINGTON, June 16 Proposed changes in the Federal medical care law designed to permit New York State to reduce the scope and cost of its companion program were introduced today by Senator Jacob K. Javits.
The Appellate Division, in a strongly worded opinion, has severely criticized the State Supreme Court practice of appointing special guardians for incompetent veterans who have small estates.
WASHINGTON, June 16--The Equal Opportunity Commission said today it was not religious discrimination for an employer to require all of his employes to work on Saturday.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, June 16 Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China arrived today for an eight-day official visit.

LONDON, June 16 (Reuters) The West Indies cricketers, already one up in the series, batted brightly in adverse conditions today to reach 155 runs for four wickets by the close of play on the first day of the second test against England at Lord's.
MOSCOW, June 17 The Soviet Union announced tonight that the members of the Warsaw Pact would hold a highlevel meeting in Bucharest early next month.

Mayor Lindsay presented the Police Department's Medal of Honor at a noon ceremony yesterday at City Hall to Mrs. Lillian Mercer, whose husband, Patrolman Maitland Mercer, earned it at the sacrifice of his life.
MEMPHIS, June 17 (AP) The Memphis Beer Board has stopped the music for hundreds of teen-aged musicians, and they are going to sing shout and stomp in protest.
Two large paintings about 400 years old, one by Raphael and one by Veronese, have been lent to the Metropolitan Museum of Art by J. Paul Getty, the oilman.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) France and the United States announced plans today for joint research in long-range weather forecasting through the use of balloons sending data to a satellite.

Miss Carol Leslie Bayne was married yesterday in Naples, Italy, to Theodore W. Price, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore H. Price of Woodbury, L.I. The bride is the daughter of Capt. Marmaduke Gresham Bayne, U.S.N., and Mrs. Bayne, formerly of Norfolk, Va. Captain Bayne is commander of Submarine Flotilla 8 and is stationed in Naples.
Mike Ford, who said he was always a crapshooter, took a gamble, lost, and yesterday wound up $1.8-million richer.

Miss Lu Ann Smith, daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Eugene L. Smith of Closter, N.J., was married last evening to William Mecklenburg Polk, son of Mrs. John C. Wilmerding of Old Westbury, L.I., and the late Frank Lyon Polk of New York.
The following books of a religious and inspirational nature have been published recently:

Two youths were convicted yesterday in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn for the murder last year of Arthur Abrams, a teacher who also worked as a cab driver. Justice John R. Starkey sentenced them to life imprisonment.

A 200,000-share combination offering of Methode Electronics, Inc., common stock was made yesterday by an underwriting group led by A.G. Becker Co., Inc., at $12.75 a share. The issue was oversubscribed and late in the day was quoted at 14 3/8-14 .

Joseph Dean Edwards, a lawyer of 120 Cabrini Boulevard, was indicted here yesterday on charges of stealing $495,758 in escrow funds from four clients who had intended to use the money to build hotels and motels.

MIAMI, June 17 (AP) Topseeded Charles Pasarell of the University of California, Los Angeles, trailing, 2-1, after three sets, surged back today to defeat Tom Edlefsen of Southern California in the semi-finals of the National Collegiate tennis championship.
HUE, South Vietnam, June 17 South Vietnamese Government troops, advancing slowly but remorselessly, forced Buddhist-led dissidents back into three defensive positions today.
STOCKHOLM, June 17 (AP) John E. du Pont of Atherton, Calif., and a student at Stanford University, finished 21st today in the modern International pentathlon meet.

KANSAS CITY, June 17 (UPI) Willie Smith's two-out, two-run seventh-inning triple and superb relief pitching by Jack Sanford carried the California Angels to their sixth consecutive victory tonight a 4-2 triumph over the Kansas City Athletics.
A navigation beacon that has guarded that spit of land in the Bronx known as Throgs Neck since 1827 will be discontinued if the Coast Guard has its way.
WASHINGTON, June 17 The Justice Department filed a new bank merger suit today and at the same time announced that it was dropping an old antitrust case against Anheuser-Busch, Inc.
A new battle of Washington Square over New York University's plans to put up a 12story library building on the south side promises to be the hardest fought yet.
WASHINGTON, June 17 Stringent new regulations concerning dietetic foods and supplements, including strict labeling requirements, were announced today by the Food and Drug Administration.

HOUSTON, June 17 The frustrations, malfunctions and failures that plagued the Gemini 9 flight earlier this month have brought an admonition to the space program's scientists, engineers and technicians: try harder.
Charles A. Gordon of 1085 Park Avenue, retired executive vice president and director of the Oxford Paper Company, died yesterday in Delray Beach, Fla., after a brief illness. He was 90 years old.

WASHINGTON, June 17--A commission created by Congress decided today to proceed with the extension of the west front of the Capitol, which looks out on the Mall, the Washington Monument and, beyond, to the Lincoln Memorial.
AUGUSTA, Me., June 17 (UPI) Gov. John H. Reed ordered today that all telephone companies in Maine "discontinue all telephone monitoring at once."

WASHINGTON, June 17 Alabama has served notice on the Federal Government that it will go to court in an attempt to avoid a cutoff of more than $90-million a year in welfare funds for failure to comply with the Civil Rights Act of 1964.

GREENWOOD, Miss., June 17 Mississippi civil rights marchers led 800 Greenwood Negroes on a protest march to the Leflore County courthouse today and for the second consecutive day had a close brush with violence.

LONDON, June 17 Despite his best performance of the year, Dennis Ralston, America's top-ranking tennis player, was outlasted and outlucked today by Roy Emerson in a sporadically brilliant semi-final of the London grass court championships. The Australian won, 6-4, 6-8, 6-4, after a storming finish by Ralston had given him two chances for a service break in the very last game.
The annual meeting of the Studebaker Corporation and a showdown between dissidents and management will be further postponed because of a court ruling yesterday.
The Tennessee Valley Authority entered the nuclear power field yesterday. It awarded a contract for the world's largest nuclear-powered generating station to the General Electric Company.

LONDON, June 17 (Reuters) Tom Graveney, a 39-year-old Worcestershire batsman who returned to the test team after a three year absence, helped England dominate the second day's play today in the second test against the West Indies at Lord's.

EDISON, N.J., June 17 (AP) Four youths were arrested by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation today at the Kilmer Job Corps Center in connection with the burning of several deserted buildings on the campus earlier in the week.

For his final pair of Promenade concerts with the New York Philharmonic, Andre Kostelanetz, who began the popular series three years ago, put together his typical successful program. In last night's International Promenade, Mr. Kostelanetz mixed new and old, known and obscure, with a master's hand.
PARIS, June 17 French officials still flatly assert that "no formal political agreement" will come out of President de Gaulle's visit to the Soviet Union, which begins Monday.
Three sweating workmen put the finishing touches yesterday on a 7-foot-high pine stockade fence that effectively hides Gracie Mansion from public view.

CHICAGO, June 17 (UPI) Two full-grown circus elephants, frightened by a jet plane, escaped from handlers today and rampaged for four hours through the lawns, gardens and rush-hour traffic of four western suburbs.
The future of the nation's international communications systems is now in the hands of Congress.
The Republic Steel Corporation confirmed yesterday that it "was considering" construction of a new strip mill.

Mr. and Mrs. Rene Aubale of Paris have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Christine Aubale, to Patrick Gerschel, son of Mrs. Michel de Camaret and of Marc Gerschel, also of Paris, and grandson of Mr. and Mrs. Andre Meyer of New York.
TOLEDO, Ohio, June 17 Bobby Douglas leaned heavily against the water cooler, the top of his blue United States jersey hanging, and arduously peeled off the thick bandage taped around his chest.
NEW DELHI, June 17 India is impatient with what she regards as "foot dragging" by West Germany on aid for her fourth five-year plan.

E.J. Korvette, Inc., the nation's largest discount department-store chain, reported yesterday a reduced net income for the 39-week period, and a substantially greater loss for the third quarter ended May 1. Sales, however, increased in both periods.

MIAMI, June 17 (UPI) Cargo handlers of Pan American World Airways walked off their jobs today to protest working conditions, including what they called dirty toilets, sweltering warehouses, dim lights and swarming mosquitoes.
A new top management and board of directors have taken command of the financially ailing Wagner Baking Company.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 17 "McBee, who's McBee?" That was the question asked most frequently this morning at the Olympic Country Club course. His name was on the scoreboard, he was out in 32, he had nine birdies and scored a 32 coming back for a 64 that tied the 18-hole record in the championship.
The German measles virus may damage unborn babies by slowing the division of cells in vital organs, studies by two Texas researchers indicate.

ENFIELD, N.H., June 17 Mrs. Lona Tillman Moore, a daughter of the late United States Senator Benjamin R. Tillman, Democrat of South Carolina, died yesterday at a nursing home here at the age of 86. She was the widow of Charles S. Moore, Atlantic City lawyer, who died in 1964.

ST. LOUIS, June 17 (AP) Tony Taylor, who raced home from second on a wild pitch for the tying run in the eighth, singled across the winning run in the ninth tonight as the Philadelphia Phils edged the St. Louis Cardinals, 6-5.

LOS ANGELES, June 17 (AP) Willie McCovey broke a seventh-inning tie with a threerun homer tonight as the San Francisco Giants ran their winning streak to six games with a 4-1 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

Since 1953 there have been 26 accidents at the narrow dog-leg meeting of the Kill Van Kull and Newark Bay where on Thursday two tankers collided and burned, leaving 20 known dead and 12 seamen missing.
The Americsn Stock Exchange ended its three-day losing streak yesterday with advances outnumbering declines by a narrow margin.
DES MOINES, Iowa, June 17 (AP) Arthur I. Boreman, a former trade publisher and a leading supporter of air travel, died today of cancer in a hospital here. He was 80 years old.

KING POINTS, L.I., June 7 The United States Coast Guard team won the Intercollegiate Yacht Racing Association's national dinghy championship today as the three-day competition in a 22-race series wound up on Long Island Sound.
Teen-age members of the drama group of Mobilization for Youth will make their debuts at a noted Off Broadway theater.

MUNICH, Germany June 17 (AP) Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, the primate of Poland, has told German Catholic leaders he hopes that a "gigantic bridge" will link Poland and Germany "over everything which separated us in the past."
The increase in interest charges on consumer-type installment loans initiated by the Chase Manhattan Bank on Wednesday started to spread yesterday.

South Vietnamese riot policemen moved in to take over the Buddhist Institute in Saigon today after a policeman was attacked by rioters and killed with his own gun. Another was dragged into the institute compound. [Page 1, Columns 2-3.]

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 17 Seven members of the 1956 Yale shell, which brought an Olympic title back to New Haven after having beaten Harvard here by five lengths, will be on hand tomorrow when the Elis match oars with the unbeaten Crimson in America's oldest intercollegiate event.
The Right Rev. Jonathan Goodhue Sherman will be instituted as the fifth Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Long Island at 11 A.M. today in the Cathedral of the Incarnation, Garden, City.

OTTAWA, June 17 A strike that would have shut down the St. Lawrence Seaway at noon today was called off after the Federal Cabinet approved a 30 per cent pay increase for 1,200 Canadian Seaway employes.
HOUSTON, June 17 (AP) Jim Gentile, assigned to the minors last Monday by the Houston Astros for disciplinary reasons, has decided to report to Oklahoma City.
The Home Lines luxury liner Oceanic will resume today her regular weekly cruises from here to Nassau, the Bahamas. The 39,241-ton liner arrived here yesterday with 460 passengers from Italian ports.
A four-company merger, with the United Whelan Corporation as the dominant concern, was cleared yesterday as shareholders of two of the companies being acquired voted their approval.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) Patrick J. Nugent, the 22-year-old fiance of President Johnson's daughter Luci, has taken a job as a member of a new Washington higher education consulting concern.
ALBANY, June 17 Officials who fashioned the New York City tax package complained today that their "earnings tax" on commuters has been widely referred to as a "payroll" tax.

The United States Court of Appeals yesterday held that a union has a right to send representatives into an employer's place of business to check the fairness of the rate of pay to piece goods workers.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) The Director of the Central Intelligence has informed the Senate Foreign Relations Committee that he is willing to give it "substantive intelligence information" but will not disclose "sources and methods," which he reveals to another Senate committee.

Two claims, one for $1.7-million and one of so far unspecified amount, have been filed in connection with a Grace Line legal proceeding to limit the steamship line's possible liability arising from the ramming of the Raritan River drawbridge by the cargo-passenger liner Santa Isabel last March 3.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP)--Bob Saverine led off the 11th inning with a pinch-hit double and scored on an error by Pedro Gonzalez, giving the Washington Senators 5-4 victory tonight over the Cleveland Indians.

NORTH TAARYTOWN, N.Y., June 17 The Internal Revenue Service was accused by Representative Richard L. Ottinger tonight of a "reprehensible and undemocratic" act in trying to end the tax exemption of the Sierra Club's San Francisco chapter.
PARAMUS, N.J., June 17 Walt Zembriski of Northwood and Andrew Kunsaw of Forsgate gained the final of the 65th annual New Jersey golf championship today.

Four major lumber associations reported a decrease of 17.1 per cent in production for the week ended June 11 compared with the level in the corresponding 1965 week. Output fell 3.1 per cent from the preceding week.

DARIEN, Conn., June 17 Australis, the defending national high-point champion, won two classes one a bonus point test and gained the lead for the open jumper championship today at the Ox Ridge horse show.
An executive of one of the nation's largest retail advertisers advised newspapers yesterday to improve their products to make them more desirable as an advertising medium.

Ignazio Silone, the Italian novelist of Socialist sympathies, and Pablo Neruda, the Chilean poet and Communist, clashed yesterday at the International P.E.N. Congress over whether mention of the term "totalitarian" constituted a cold war act.
Prices on the London stock market declined by fractions yesterday across a broad front.
NEW DELHI, June 17 President Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan promulgated today an ordinance aimed at prosecution in cases of subversion and sedition.
EXETER, N.H., June 17 Miss Susan Hammond Niebling was married today to Donald Franz Hendrie Jr. by the Rev. Roswell Moore of Christ Episcopal Church here.
Henry Milberg, a partner in the Jersey City law firm of Milberg and Milberg, died Thursday at his home here, 1 University Place. He was 64 years old.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., June 17 Mrs. Buelah Trewin Rand of 603 Madison Avenue, a teacher of English in the Middlesex schools for 39 years, died yesterday at Muhlenberg Hospital. She was 64 years old and the widow of Ellsworth Rand.

Ever since the convulsions of 1956 brought both men out of prison and back into power, stability in Poland has rested partially on a tacit, shifting but enduring agreement to coexist between Wladyslaw Gomulka, First Secretary of the Communist party, and Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski.

Mr. and Mrs. Harry Bejosa of 21 East 90th Street and Bantam, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Diane Francine Bejosa, to Charles Frankel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Frankel of Chicago.
DETROIT, June 17 (AP) A 55-year-old missionary was elected today the new world president of the Seventh-Day Adventist Church.

WASHINGTON, June 17 Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler said today an anti-inflation tax increase "remains very much an open question" and would depend largely on whether Congress significantly raises Federal spending beyond President Johnson's requests.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 17 Delvin Miller, driving Hugh A Grant's Tarport Countess in the $29,074.25 Belle Acton Pace at Roosevelt Raceway tonight, thought he "had the money" one-sixteenth of a mile before the finish of the mile race for 2-year-olds. He had the fleet daughter of Adios-Countess Vivian a couple of lengths ahead of the other 11 fillies in the field, suddenly, something happened.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 17 The administrative work attached to the Newport-to-Bermuda yacht race established today Robert F. Johnson's 73-foot ketch Ticonderoga from Portland, Ore., as the boat to beat as far as the time allowances were concerned.
MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., June 17 (AP) Eight Navy air men and four passengers were killed last night as a C-130 Hercules Naval Air Transport plane plunged into the South China Sea near South Vietnam.
Dresser Industries, Inc., with total assets of $260,866,000, is discussing a possible merger with the Chicago Pneumatic Tool Company whose assets exceed $127.3-million.
DEER PARK, L.I., June 17 (UPI) A straw-hatted gunman embraced two armloads of small-denomination bills in a Long Island branch bank yesterday, and the police said he got away with $11,600.
Brakes that failed on a northbound express as it entered the Wall Street station caused a 35minute delay yesterday afternoon on the Seventh Avenue IRT subway line.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, June 17 (Reuters) Former Foreign Minister Cleophas Kamitatu will be tried here publicly tomorrow morning for alleged complicity in a recent plot to overthrow and kill President Joseph Mobutu.
TRENTON, June 17--Richard J. Hughes showed today that a Governor can be all things to all men. He did that when big business and organized labor walked out of his office here singing his praises.

CINCINNATI, June 17 The New York Mets, breathing hotly on the necks of the Cincinnati Reds and Atlanta Braves, set their sights on nothing less than seventh place by sweeping a double-header from the Reds tonight, 6-5 and 2-1.

Announcement has been made here of the marriage of Miss Karen Blanc, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Blanc of Paris, to Joel Blocker, chief of the Paris bureau of Newsweek magazine. A civil ceremony was performed May 20.
DUBROVNIK, Yugoslavia A peaceful American invasion on an unprecedented scale is taking place here now as American tourists flock to this historic playground on Socialist Yugoslavia's Dalmatian coast.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 17 Homes Bannard, a retired vice president of the New York Central Railroad, died of a stroke today in his home at 10 Wayside Lane. He was 60 years old.

CHICAGO, June 17 (AP) More than 40 persons arrested this week in three nights of disturbances in a Puerto Rican neighborhood on the Northwest Side were sentenced today to punishment ranging from $100 fines to six months under court supervision.
James H. Meredith announced yesterday that he was supporting Supreme Court Justice Samuel J. Silverman for Manhattan Surrogate.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 17 Arnold Palmer charged in with a 66 today and shared the 36hole lead in the United States Open golf championship with Billy Casper. It was the lowest score in an Open for the general of Arnie's Army since a closing 65 brought him the title in 1960.
Dr. Rosemary Park will leave the presidency of Barnard College to become vice chancellor for educational planning and programs at the University of California at Los Angeles.
Four public bathing beach areas in New York City have been found to have polluted water that is unsafe for swimming, the Health Department said yesterday.
LONDON. June 17 (UPI)--The Soviet Union held a 55-38 lead over Britain in the men's competition and a 38-28 advantage in the women's events today in a dual track and field meet.

Thirty-seven Roman Catholic clergymen attending a workshop at Washington's Catholic University are getting a rare opportunity to sit squirming in a pew among their colleagues and watch themselves preach on television.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) The Federal Communications Commission, shunning the role of censor, renewed today the license of a radio station it said had carried defamatory, anti-Semitic programs.

Political dinners usually produce money for the candidate's campaign, a news story for the reporters, and a mild hangover for the guests. The first is soon spent and the others soon forgotten. But it looks as if the dinner last Oct. 26 for Abraham D. Beame, then the Democratic mayoralty candidate, may have had more lasting and beneficial results.

Mr. and Mrs. William Ernest Donovan of 2 Beekman Place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sarah Anne Donovan, to Donald P. Madden, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis P. Madden of Winthrop, Mass. The wedding is planned for Aug. 12.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 1 Lieutenant General Suharto, Deputy Defense Premier, tried today to set the mood for the People's Consultative Congress, which convenes here Monday.
Dr. Simon C. Kramer, president of the Hebrew Theological College at Chicago, announced yesterday the appointment of Rabbi Aaron Soloveitchik as dean of the faculty.
HOLLYWOOD, June 17 (UPI) Lynda Bird Johnson flew here today from Texas to attend a costumers ball with George Hamilton, the actor.
MOSCOW, Saturday, June 18 (AP) Americans took second and fourth prizes in the Tchaikovsky International Cello Competition, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported today.
CHICKASHA, Okla., June 17 (AP) A dwindling band of rain-soaked, foot-sore rights demonstrators switched to cars today to complete their 100-mile march from Oklahoma City to Lawton, Okla.
The shipping industry yesterday was studying the Defense Department's controversial decision to inaugurate a system of competitive bidding for its military cargoes.

BANGKOK, Thailand, June 17 In the conference halls and hotels of Bangkok the hubbub of half a dozen languages rises from throngs of Government Ministers, engineers and economists who are speaking with new zest about the trend toward unity in Southeast Asia.
Following is a partial list of identified dead and missing in Thursday's tanker collision in the Kill van Kull:

WASHINGTON, June 17 Dr. James Lee Goddard has credentials that the severest critics of the Food and Drug Administration may consider appropriate: he is a qual fied hot-air balloon pilot. Dr. Goddard, 42 years old, a handsome 6-footer with closecropped, prematurely gray
The excitement of becoming part of society was felt last evening by young women who handshook their way through parties in New York and suburban areas.

The opening skirmish between residents of a Park Avenue apartment house and the horde of motorcycle and scooter drivers who park along the curb between 36th and 37th Streets ended yesterday in a standoff. Battle lines have been drawn, however, and another confrontation appears likely after the cyclists return from their surburban homes on Monday. Most of them are businessmen who work in the immediate vicinity and use the cycles to commute.

Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange, said yesterday that the financial community "should be able" to live with most of the elements in the city's compromise tax package, but he took exception to a proposed increase in the stock transfer levy.

School officials and laymen from across the country were told yesterday that education for Negroes is "one long disaster area" that must be radically improved for the sake of whites as well as Negroes.

BONN, June 17 The Mobil Oil Company and Gelsenkirchner Bergwerks, A.G. have reached basic agreement on an arrangement under which Mobil will increase its holdings in Aral, A.G. West Germany's largest service-station operator, in return for renegotiation of the contract for the sale of crude oil to Gelsenkirchner, it was announced today.
Fifteen hundred Health Department doctors, dentists and veterinarians threatened yesterday to stop work next Friday unless the city gives them a contract to replace the one that expired Jan. 1.
Paul Resnick, one of the city's leading apartment house architects, died of a heart ailment yesterday at Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals. He was 59 years old and lived at 201 East 62d Street.

So starts a brightly colored, well-traveled flyer, which has circulated throughout the Lower East Side since December, when the Cooperative Mothers Club (Cooperativa de Madres) opened at the University Settlement House, 184 Eldridge Street.
BOSTON, June 17 (AP) Baltimore's two Robinsons, Frank and Brooks, accounted for five runs with homers to lead the first-place Orioles to a 5-3 victory over Boston tonight.

Miss Adrienne Gray, daughter of Mrs. Ann Gray of 161 East 75th Street and Stewart Sill Gray of Kansas City, Mo., was married here yesterday afternoon to R. Spencer Hines Jr. of New York, son of Raymond Spencer Hines of Rocky Mount, N.C., and the late Mrs. Hines.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., June 17 Randy Matson, who is modest, and Charlie Greene, who has never been accused of modesty, won titles with record performances today in the National Collegiate outdoor track and field championships.
WASHINGTON, June 17 The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) uses a special computer in placing warehouses to the best advantage.
LEBANON, June 17 Lebanon and Kuwait are expected to undertake mediation with other Arab states to insure that all Arab heads of state attend a meeting scheduled to be held in Algiers next September.
LONDON, June 17 Efforts by the Prime Minister, the Minister of Labor and the Trades Union Congress to end the fiveweek-old shipping strike ended today in failure.

ELIZABETH, N.J., June 17 The Rev. Francis J. Szeszol, assistant pastor of St. Hedwig's Roman Catholic Church since 1949, died of a heart attack today at St. Peter's Hospital in New Brunswick. His age was 65.

NATCHEZ, Miss., June 17 (UPI)--A man who said he could not live with his conscience told authorities today that he watched two Ku Klux Klansmen shoot an aged Negro to death on a lonely road last week.
Government and corporate bond prices advanced yesterday, ending the week with substantial gains on both fronts.
No beer, not even Rheingold, will be available at the concessions stands during the Rheingold Central Park Music Festival, Ron Delsener, the festival's executive producer, said here yesterday.
BUCHAREST, June 17 Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China spent the first complete day of his state visit to Rumania today in private discussions with the leaders of this country.
MILWAUKEE, June 17 (AP) Kathy Whitworth withstood a rally by Donna Caponi and built her lead to three strokes today at the midway mark in the Milwaukee Jaycee open golf tournament.
The last of the elected officers of Local 32-E of the Building Service Employes International Union was convicted yesterday in Federal court of labor racketeering.
Mayor Lindsay took a little time off from taxes and budgets yesterday to urge New Yorkers to join him in a major drive to keep the city clean.
BASEL, Switzerland The Bank for International Settlements has arrived.

DETROIT, June 17 (UPI) Ward's Automotive Reports pre dicted today that the automobile industry would raise production of 1966-model cars to 8.6 million before complete shutdown for model changeover next month. This would be 2.8 per cent below the record turnout of 8.84 million 1965 models.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 17 Miss Betty Marie Wismer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis K. Wismer of Bethlehem, Pa., was married here this evening to Richard Henry Pells, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvan J. Pells of Kansas City, Mo. The ceremony was performed in the Faculty Club of Harvard University by the Rev. Ralph N. Helverson of the Unitarian Church of Cambridge.
SYDNEY, Australia, June 17 Prince Abdul Rahman, Prime Minister of Malaysia, appealed from Kuala Lumpur today for his missing envoy to Australia, Lim Yew Hocke.
The "labor holiday" threatened by nearly 200,000 construction workers for next Wednesday has been indefinitely postponed.

Beset by the city and rejected by New Jersey legislators who won't promise to ban local taxes, the New York Stock Exchange is apparently stuck with an increase in the stock transfer tax and its antiquated quarters at 11 Wall Street.
The lively and fascinating results of a 12-year adventure in collecting by a husband-andwife team from Long Island is being exhibited at the Brooklyn Museum until Oct. 2.

BRIDGE-PLAYING ability and the insurance profes sion often go hand in hand, so it was not surprising that two insurance teams figured in the five-way tie in the Eastern Regionals Commercial and Industrial Team event. The actuarial ability of some of the players became significant, because the method of determining the ultimate prizewinners required prolonged calculation.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (UPI) The Senate Republican leader, Everett McKinley Dirksen of Illinois, took all the responsibility today for a Republican meeting with Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach to discuss changes in the new civil rights bill.

STRABANE, Northern Ireland, June 17 (Reuters) Woodrow Wilson's ancestral home, from which his grandfather emigrated to Ohio, was dedicated as a national monument here today by the grandson of the late President.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 17 United States Air Force jets, evading Soviet-made surface-to-air missiles, knocked out the radar trucks guiding the missiles in a raid over North Vietnam yesterday.
Three men convicted of violating the Federal narcotics laws were sentenced to prison yesterday by Federal Judge Edward Weinfeld.
LOS ANGELES, June 17 (UPI) Johnny St. Cyr, the jazz banjoist, died of leukemia today at the Los Angeles County General Hospital. He was 76 years old.
BUFFALO, June 17 Atomic projects that would distill fresh water from the sea, as well as extract valuable minerals, were pictured today as a way to meet increasing water needs.

Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary, applying principles recently set forth by the Supreme Court, ordered his 28,000 men yesterday to advise prisoners of their right to stay silent and to have a lawyer.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), June 17 The political and diplomatic officials who see Israel's leaders in and out of the country put in a strenuous day today at Lydda Airport.
WASHINGTON, June 17 The vice president of the United Rubber Workers today challenged the president to a fight for control of the 180,000-member labor union.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 17 (AP) The Department of Justice asked Clark County District Court today to halt further litigation in a $5-million wiretapping suit pending further developments in the Robert G. Baker case.

Two major Los Angeles savings and loan associations--the $830-million Great Western Savings and Loan Association and the $420-million Gibraltar Savings and Loan Association--announced rate increases yesterday on special long-term "bonus" savings accounts.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 17 Delegates to the Minnesota Democratic-Farmer-Labor party convention gathered here today amid increasing indications that they will deny a secondterm endorsement to Gov. Karl F. Rolvaag.

The extraordinary sight of $2.8-million worth of pure heroin, piled in six suitcases atop a courtroom table, virtually mesmerized the principals and participants in a narcotics trial yesterday in Federal Court.

VENICE, Italy, June 17 The 33d Venice Biennale is one of the most dismal surveys of contemporary visual art ever assembled. In this mammoth art carnival, with very few exceptions, one looks in vain for anything one would ever want to look at again.
STANTON, Del., June 17 Buckpasser will race for big money for the first time in more than three months in the $41,420 Leonard Richard Stakes at Delaware Park.
WASHINGTON, June 17 A code of ethics instituted a year ago has led 10 key Government officials to adjust their financial holdings to avoid potential conflicts of interest.
HUGO, Okla., June 17 (UPI) A Hugo businessman was charged with murder today in the shooting of Todd Whatley, a former world champion rodeo performer and southeastern Oklahoma rancher.

David L. Cole, chief mediator in the newspaper strike, reported last night that differences between the Newspaper Guild and the World Journal Tribune, Inc., had been narrowed and that he was encouraged by the day's progress.

PHILADELPHIA, June 17 Miss Mary Bean Dall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Curtis Bean Dall of Chestnut Hill, was married this afternoon to C. Dary Dunham Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Dunham of Mount Kisco, N.Y. The Rev. Philemon F. Sturges performed the ceremony in the Episcopal Church of St. Martin-in-the-Fields, and a reception was held at the Philadelphia Cricket Club.

After a dozen futile attempts this season, Gee Judge of the Pine Tree Stable made her way to the winner's circle yesterday, capturing the feature race at Aqueduct. With Braulio Baeza guiding her competently between horses in the six-furlong sprint, Gee Judge enjoyed the margin of three-quarters of a length over Terrentia, who had three lengths over Ameri Belle, in the field of seven fillies and mares.
JERUSALEM, Israel, June 13--The "temporary recession" that has caused increasing concern in Israel for the last few months may last for a year or two, according to the Labor Minister, Yigal Allon.
RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, June 17 Reports that Zulfikar Ali Bhutto will resign as Foreign Minister were confirmed today.

BONN, June 17--Chancellor Ludwig Erhard commemorated the 13th anniversary of the uprising in Communist East Germany today with a statement reiterating West Germany's long-standing request for unification through free all-German elections.

Governor Rockefeller's press secretary, Leslie Slote, who denied on Thursday that any secretary to the Governor had written or sent a letter to a Supreme Court justice concerning L. Judson Morhouse, the former Republican state chairman, withdrew the denial yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 17 New orders received by manufacturers of durable goods a key indicator of the direction of the economy declined slightly in May, the Census Bureau reported today.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., June 17 After presenting chamber music on the first three evenings of its week-long series here, the Early American Moravian Music Festival turned to vocal music last night for its fourth concert in the Ralph P. Hanes Auditorium of Salem College. Vocal music finds the 18th-century Moravian composers at their best, and it was a rewarding program, given distinction by the first "modern" performance of Christian Latrobe's "Dies Irae."

Mexico had one of the most successful revolutions of modern times and yet most of her population are still uneducated peasants and still very poor, as Times correspondent Henry Giniger has been report ing on a long tour through northern rural Mexico.

SYRACUSE, June 17 The University of Washington is the choice to win the varsity championship for the first time since 1950 in tomorrow's regatta of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association but Navy, Cornell, Brown or Pennsylvania could confound the consensus.

OXFORD, Ohio, June 17 Robert H. Wieche, who played on Ohio State University's Big 10 football championship teams in 1917 and 1920, died here today of a heart attack. He was 69 years old. Mr. Wieche played guard on the 1917 team that featured Chic Harley, an AllAmerica fullback, and on the 1920 team with Gaylord (Pete) Stinchcomb, an All America halfback.
AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, June 17 The Defense Ministry has canceled furloughs for 3,500 soldiers, who will be kept available if needed to reinforce 2,000 policemen in the event of new riots.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 17 (AP) Tommy John pitched Chicago to a 3-1 victory over Minnesota tonight, giving the White Sox their first triumph of the season over the Twins after eight straight losses.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 17 Stephen Rutledge, the 25year-old Peace Corps volunteer of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., who had been missing for over a week, was found ill today in a small town in the interior of northeastern Brazil.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 17 The Soviet Union made public today its formula for preserving the universe for peaceful exploration and research in the interest of all mankind.
HERNANDO, Miss., June 17 (AP) Aubrey James Norvell, the man charged with assault in the shooting of James H. Meredith on his march through Mississippi, posted $25,000 bond and left jail here today.
WASHINGTON, June 17 Defense officials today hailed as a "remarkable achievement" the creation of the first military space communications network with one rocket flight yesterday.
KARACHI, Pakistan, June 17 East Pakistan's largest opposition daily newspaper, Ittefaq, ceased publication today when its printing press in Dacca was confiscated by the Government.

The Board of Estimate and the City Council last night adopted an expense budget of $4,553,875,982 for the fiscal year beginning July 1, trimming $134.5-million from Mayor Lindsay's budgetary recommendations.

ASCOT, England, June 17, (AP) Hill Rise, running his first race in England, scored the upset of the day at the Royal Ascot meet today by win ning at odds of 20-1 and beating the British champion miler, Silly Season.

SYDNEY, Australia, June 13 All mention of the name of its Danish designer, Jorn Utzon, has been removed from the site of the still unfinished but already famous Sydney opera house.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, June 6 A farmer's wife in New Zealand has been raised to royal status. Her title as queen is Kuini Te Ata-i-rangi-kaahu (the Soaring Bird of Dawn). She rules a kingdom within a kingdom. Like all New Zealanders, she acknowledges allegiance to Queen Elizabeth II.

Hurley Jr. of Taunton and North Falmouth have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Mary Hurley, to Elon Huntington Hooker Marquand of Cambridge and Newburyport. He is the son of the late John P. Marquand, novelist, and the late Mrs. Adelaide Hooker Marquand.

MOSCOW, June 19--President de Gaulle arrives in the Soviet Union tomorrow for a spectacular state visit to dramatize the search for new understanding between East and West Europe, divided and hostile since the end of World War II.

ST. LOUIS, June 19 (UPI) Bob Gibson pitched a threehitter and Tim McCarver hit a two-run homer to lead the St. Louis Cardinals to a 5-1 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies today and a sweep of their double-header.

PALMYRA, N.J., June 19 A 3-year-old pointer, Ch. Silver Ridge Crackerjack, owned by William Metz of New City, N.Y., led a field of 688 today to take best in show at the 19th annual Burlington County Kennel Club event.

CHICAGO, June 19 (AP) The last-place Chicago Cubs went on a power-hitting spree today and whipped the Houston Astros, 9-8 and 8-2. The double victory marked the first time this season that the Cubs had won a double-header.

The Central Intelligence Agency needed a change of leadership, and President Johnson has picked the best available man in Deputy Director Richard Helms. Admiral Raborn, the retiring director, was chosen in 1965 because he had done an outstanding job in developing the Polaris missile and, in the process, had established excellent relations with Congress. It did not hurt that he was a Texan who campaigned for Mr. Johnson.

SENGOKUHARA, Japan, June 19 Japanese and American diplomatic planning staffs conferred here again today and were reported to have discussed Japan's intricately developing relations with Communist China.

Jazz moved onto firm new ground last night at Philharmonic Hall. Ornette Coleman, the alto saxophonist, giving his first New York concert in four years, revealed that he had refined what had once been an exploratory, avant-garde approach to make it a strong and individualistic part of the main flow of jazz development.

Yet an obscure rule that covered a oncein-a-lifetime incident victimized Gary Player on one occasion. The defending champion was so far out of the running in this Open that he had regained his normal cheerfulness. So he could discuss the incident with considerable gusto.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., June 19 Ed Wynn, "The Perfect Fool" of stage, radio and television for more than 60 years who later won success as a dramatic actor, died at his apartment here today. He was 79 years old.
Normally, Coney Island isn't the same place to an adult as it is to a child. But it was yesterday.
Abe Birnbaum, an artist and illustrator who painted nearly 200 covers for The New Yorker magazine in the last 39 years, died yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital. His age was 67.

GRAND MASTER ROBERT BYRNE of Indianapolis, scoring 5-1, won the recent Chicago "2000" Tournament at the Edgewater Beach Hotel. Nine masters, seventeen experts and six Class A players participated in this six-round Swiss system.
WESTBURY, L.I., June 19 (AP) The owner of Pluvier III of Sweden accepted today an invitation to defend his laurels in the $100,000 International Trot at Roosevelt Raceway.

Dr. Kenneth B. Clark, a leading Negro educator and psychologist, asserted yesterday that Senator Robert F. Kennedy had "injured his vote-getting power in New York City, among Negroes and Puerto Ricans" by his stand in the Democratic primary fight for Surrogate.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP)--Fred Valentine hit a home run in the first inning and Ken Hamlin hit one in the sixth, giving the Washington Senators a 2-1 victory today over the Cleveland Indians.
SAIGON, June 19 The governing South Vietnamese junta does not plan to relinquish power to a civilian government at least until the autumn of 1967, informed sources said today.
LANDSCAPE IN CONCRETE. By Jakov Lind. Translated by Ralph Manheim from the German, "Landschaft in Beton." 190 pp. New York: Grove Press. $4.50.
The National Council of Jewish Women has appealed to rabbinical authorities to lessen hardship for women in divorce, remarriage and inheritance.

RANGOON, Burma, June 19 Burma's Cromwellian military chief of state, Gen. Ne Win, makes no secret of the fact he finds Burma's peacetime problems far tougher than those he faced in war and the struggle for independence.
Three military vessels are on their way to the ice-choked waters around Greenland for the annual task of repairing and opening up ports in the Arctic.
PITTSBURGH, June 19 Steel officials were already talking about an upturn last week.

PURCHASE, N. Y., June 19 Miss Elizabeth Mary Affelder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul B. Affelder of New York, was married here this evening to Gordon Darnell Newby, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon L. Newby of Salt Lake City.

SAIGON, June 19--American B-52 bombers from Guam stepped up their bombardment of targets in South Vietnam for the second straight day today, pounding a Communist propaganda radio station and other enemy positions.

The owner of a Venetian blind factory, which will be razed to make way for an urban renewal project, has received an unexpected loan from the Federal Government after his business was declared a "disaster" to qualify for the funds.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), June 19 The Israel Philharmonic has decided to lift a 28-year-old ban on the playing of works by Richard Wagner and Richard Strauss but the move, it seems, was hardly unanimous.
PARIS, June 19 The French Government is trying to bring about a big business merger with considerably more strategic than commercial significance.

KATONAH, N.Y., June 19 Caramoor does not need a magic mirror to know it is the most beautiful festival of all. With its broad lawns, tall trees, and huge rhododendrons exploding in fuschia and white blossoms, the Caramoor Festival, named for the estate of Walter and Lucie Rosen here, has eye appeal to spare.

A veteran furniture industry salesman has charged that department stores, in blasting furniture makers about quality, are simply setting up a smokescreen to avoid paying servicing costs on pre-delivery inspection.

This week the New YorkNew Jersey Red Cross Blood Program will collect blood from the public today at the Grand Central Branah, Young Men's Christian Association, 224 East 47th Street, from 10 A.M. to 3:30 P.M.
A proposal to set up a permanent center at which high level thinking will be applied to the problems of the maritime industry is receiving favorable response.

PORT CHESTER, N. Y., June 19 In Congregation Kneses Tifereth Israel here today, Miss Joan Ellen Granowitz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Granowitz of Port Chester, became the bride of Howard N. Charlson. Mis parents are Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Charlson of Pittsburgh. Rabbis Joseph Speiser and Jacob Shragowitz officiated.

The bond market will be called on this week to shoulder its heaviest load of corporate financing since June, 1965, as $400-million of debentures is scheduled for sale. The total is one of the highest on record.
Arnold Palmer's five-stroke lead with only four holes to go was overcome by Billy Casper yesterday, forcing the United States Open golf championship into an 18-hole playoff today.
From dawn to after nightfall yesterday Randalls Island was taken over by 60,000 fiestahappy people from another, larger island Puerto Rico.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., June 19 Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Anderson Parrish have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cecelia Jo Parrish of Washington, to Adlai S. Hardin Jr. of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hardin of Lyme, Conn. The couple plan to marry Sept. 24.

DAYTON, Ohio, June 19 Mr. and Mrs. Jefferson H. Heeter of Dayton and Sea Island, Ga., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Ann Heater of New York, to William Langstaff Crow 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Crow of Rye, N. Y. A September wedding in Sea Island is planned.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 19 Mr. and Mrs. John F. Wardle Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Ellen Wardle, to John Wellington Hope Simpson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wellington H. Simpson.
WASHINGTON, June 19 President Johnson seemed in the last week to be not so much trying to court public approval as to take it by storm.

FOR quite a few years now Julann Griffin has been trying to convince practically everyone that she is not a kook. "I don't mind for myself," she said as the Griffin chauffeur hovered in the background of the Griffin apartment on Central Park West waiting for a list of errands. "But I don't want people to think that my husband married a nut."

SAN FRANCISCO, June 19 Arnold Palmer suddenly lost the tiger in his tank late this afternoon during the closing stages of the United States Open golf championship. He had been behaving in ravenous fashion on the Olympic Club course, tearing it apart until he had a seven-stroke lead on Billy Casper. Then high drama unexpectedly descended on the show and Arnie lost his fangs.
SAN JUAN, P.R., June 19 (AP) Mexico won most of the medals in the tennis competition today and took a commanding lead at the Central American and Caribbean Games.
BRIDGEHAMPTON, L.I., June 19 Bob Brown of Huntington, L.I, averaged 94.98 miles an hour today for an easy victory in one of the two featured races on the 2.85-mile Bridgehampton road course.

BERLIN, June 19 The Soviet Union has intervened to block the planned East-West German public debates, sources close to Mayor Willy Brandt said today. They said the Russians had acted out of fear that the confrontations could endanger the status quo in divided Germany.
MINNEAPOLIS, June 19 Lieut, Gov. A.M. Keith won a 20th-ballot victory late tonight in the battle for the Democratic-Farmer-Labor party's endorsement for Governor.

The most serious problem facing both airlines and airport authorities here and abroad is expanding the world's airport facilities to meet the needs of the coming era of the jumbo jet aircraft carrying up to 900 passengers, according to a survey by Interavia, the international aviation magazine published in four languages in Geneva.
WASHINGTON, June 19 Luci Baines Johnson is getting a coast-to-coast wedding shower from hundreds of Americans who want to make sure that she gets a good start in married life.

Litton Industries announced at the weekend the election of Ellis B. Gardner as vice-president. Mr. Gardner was also appointed general manager of Litton's Ingalls Ship-building Division, Roy L. Ash, president of Litton, announced.
MORRISTOWN, N. J., June 19 Miss Pamela Spring Newton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anson P. Newton, was married this afternoon to Francis Seott Renna, son of Dr. and Mrs. Francis S. Renna.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 19 Roy Emerson will be gunning for his third straight Wimbledon title a feat last accomplished by Fred Perry of Britain from 1934 to 1936 when the 80th All-England lawn tennis championships begin tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, June 19 The crucial immediate question in world monetary reform is how to proceed with negotiations rather than the substance of the reform.

ROCHESTER, June 19 "We're celebrating the first anniversary of black power in Rochester," the stocky Negro at the podium shouted. "The first anniversary of our declaration of manhood and independence."

"He's been here 34 years, he could have left and gone to another parish or post," a woman at the Church of the holy Cross on West 42d Street said of her pastor yesterday. "This is not an easy neighborhood for a church."
Directors of the American Sugar Company have elected Robert O. Nagle as vice president of the Spreckels Sugar Company, a division, the parent company announced over the weekend.
ALBANY, June 19 Several snags developed today between Mayor Lindsay and the top Republican in the Legislature over the compromise tax package for New York City that was worked out here last week.

EFORIE NORD, Rumania, June 19 The conversations between Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China and Nicolae Ceausescu, Secretary General of the Rumanian Communist party, went into an unscheduled third day today in a new locale.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (UPI) James H. Meredith said today that agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation had watched as he was shot in ambush on a Mississippi highway June 6.

LOS ANGELES, June 19 (AP) Willie Davis hit a tiebreaking single in the eighth inning today and the Los Angeles Dodgers captured the third and deciding game of their series with the San Francisco Giants, 2-1, before 53,527.
MONTREAL, June 19--The Expo '67 here is upset about what it considers an unfavorable reference to its World Festival by William Schuman, president of the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., June 19 "That cardinal, if he left my yard, I'd leave this town," a man said to his neighbor on the 8:28 morning train from New Canaan, Conn. The two had been talking about the final days of spring and the near arrival of summer. It had not been a silent spring this year.
LONDON, June 19 (AP) An unidentified woman hit the jackpot at the Ascot race meet yesterday, winning $176,719 on a 70-cent bet.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (UPI) Members of the United World Federation, calling for a speedy end to the Vietnam War, clashed among themselves today over an award honoring Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara.

Eugene Gilbert, who probably did more than anyone else to convince the American businessman that teen-agers are one of the biggest buying forces in the United States, died Saturday night at Beth Israel Hospital.

Building walls instead of bridges seems to be the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s idea of how to arrive at One World. Its executive council has lined up behind its president, George Meany, in endorsing the federation's self-defeating boycott of the annual conference of the International Labor Organization.

PATERSON, N.J., June 19 Harry I. Knecht, a consulting mechanical engineer for Consolidated Edison, died last night in Paterson General Hospital. Mr. Knecht, who lived at 320 South Harrison Street, East Orange, was 67 years old.

BONN, June 19 Dr. Rainer Barzel, deputy leader of the governing Christian Democratic Union, returned to Bonn today and declared he would discuss his controversial proposals for German reunification with his party's Executive Committee, including Chancellor Ludwig Erhard, tomorrow.
Msgr. Thomas A. Barry, pastor of Holy Innocents Roman Catholic Church for 15 years, died yesterday at the church rectory, 128 West 37th Street, where he lived. His age was 68.

Miss Sandra Karen Gold, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Gold of Plainfield, N.J., was married yesterday evening to Daniel Seishi Watanabe, son of Michiro Watanabe, former Attorney. General of Hawaii, and Mrs. Watanabe of Honolulu.

The chairman of the City Commission on Human Rights said yesterday that he would try to determine whether he police discriminate against Harlem and the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn by failing to provide adequate police protection.
The appointment of Sheldon D. Smith as vice president for construction of Walter Kidde Constructors, Inc., has been announced by the company.

Television viewers will find something new when they dial the "Bell Telephone Hour" next season. The series, which has been limited to music performed in studios or concert halls for 26 years, will have most of its programs filmed on location, and will also present other arts than music.
WASHINGTON, June 19--The automobile industry is apparently fighting a losing cause in the Senate Commerce Committee over amendments that it wants Congress to write into the auto safety bill.

The legal protections afforded suspects during the interrogation stage of a case appear to be markedly greater in the United States than in other countries, a survey of seven major capitals by The New York Times has shown.

An arbitrator ruled yesterday that the Lindsay administration must honor the nine-year-old tradition that permits city employes to leave work an hour early in June and September. The ruling takes effect today.

The City Commission on Human Rights has built up a roster of 45 to 50 vacant apartments whose landlords have promised to rent on a nondiscriminatory basis, but civil rights agencies question the value of the list.

MILWAUKEE, June 19 (AP) Kathy Whitworth shot a 65 today for a total of 273, which set a Ladies Professional Golf Association record for a 72-hole tournament, as she captured the Milwaukee Jaycee Open.

General de Gaulle's visit to Russia this week recalls his last trip there, in 1944, when he urged Marshal Stalin to join France in a "direct entente" in order to "establish a [European] settlement which they would propose in common" to the Anglo-Americans.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (UPI) Gen. Harold K. Johnson, Army Chief of Staff, has disclosed that he recommended three times within a year that the Army call up its reserves for the Vietnam war. He says he is glad he was overruled.
WASHINGTON, June 19--Three of speedboat racing's most famous drivers were killed on the Potomac River today the blackest day in unlimited hydroplane competition.
AUSTIN, Tex., June 19 The Texas Liberal Democrats gave up today on getting a third candidate on the ballot for United States Senator in November.
KANSAS CITY, June, 19 (AP) Bert Campaneris scored the winning runs in both games today as the Kansas City Athletics swept a double-header from the California Angels 1-0, and 3-2, in 10 innings.

It is not unusual, in this age when show business is so much oil for the vast machinery of mass communications, for good pop singers to try acting and for good actors to have a fling at singing. Even poor singers try acting.
Miss Micheline Jeannette Blum, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel P. Blum, was married yesterday to Donald Brand Liberman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Saul B. Liberman of Englewood, N. J.
WHITE PLAINS, June 19 Miss. Judith Ann Swallow and Jonathan Frederick Wechsler were married today in the White Plains Community Church. The Rev. Peter H. Samson performed the Unitarian ceremony.

WASHINGTON, June 19--Representative Gerald R. Ford of Michigan, Republican leader of the House, described today the mood of the American voter as one demanding an early resolution of the war in Vietnam.
Four policemen responded yesterday to a radio call to "investigate a disorderly parrot" on West 24th Street.
ESTORIL, Portugal, June 19 A white-walled villa on a hillside at this Portuguese sea side resort is gradually becoming an important center of Spanish politics.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (UPI) The Senate Republican leader, Everett McKinley Dirksen, said today his proposed constitutional amendment to override the Supreme Court's ban on prayers in public schools "is probably the biggest think in my life."
CAIRO, June 19 King Hussein of Jordan is coming under increasing propaganda pressure from radical Arab states for having refused to permit the Arab refugee army to form military units in his country.

The Legislature reconvenes today with the compelling necessity to enact the minimal revenue program for New York City agreed upon by all state and city leaders at last week's conferences in Albany. That the Legislature could give the Lindsay administration less in new taxing power than was agreed is inconceivable. It ought to do more.

The election of Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. as a director of Baker Industries, Inc., with offices at 277 Park Avenue, was announced over the weekend by the manufacturer of nuclear fire detection and fire alarm systems.

DETROIT, June 19 (UPI) The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. temporarily left the march through Mississippi today and traveled north to tell a rally that the "powerlessness of the Mississippi Negro must be transformed into economic and political power."

Light breezes yesterday eliminated all chances for a record trip in the Newport-to-Bermuda yacht-racing classic, which for its start, a day earlier established a record for size, tonnage quality and international flavor.

BELZONI, Miss., June 19 Hundreds of singing and shouting plantation workers joined the civil rights march through Mississippi today and formed the longest marching column yet in the 13-day-old journey to Jackson.
The United States and 19 Latin-American countries have reached a compromise resolution of differences over economic and social policies.
An employe of a growing company that grants stock options may have the opportunity to build a relatively substantial estate, provided the stock-option plan was properly drawn.
DARIEN, Conn., June 19 Jim Paxson decided at the last minute to enter his aged brown gelding, Ilion, in the open jumper division at the Ox Ridge horse show. It turned out to be a wise move.

The top golfers not only know how to play the game better than anyone else, but they also know the rules down to every misplaced comma. This was demonstrated Saturday by Jack Nicklaus, who saved himself a penalty stroke that could have cost him thousands of dollars in the final distribution of prize money.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 19 The Prime Minister of Basutoland, Chief Leabua Jonathan, and the Prime Minister of South Africa, Dr. Hendrik F. Verwoerd,, are expected to meet soon for talks on future relations.

She couldn't see the stars, and the sky was only a thin strip locked between overhanging buildings, but when Lana Ralbag was married last night in the middle of Vanderbilt Avenue, she felt the presence of both.
NEW DELHI, June 19 The departure of Zulfikar Ali Bhutto from Pakistan's Cabinet may help to ease Indian-Pakistani relations, according to observers here.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 19 A sailor sleeping on the deck of a United States aircraft carrier rolled off into the South China Sea yesterday and spent nine hours treading water before he was rescued.

Mrs. Sadie Van Praag Marks, widow of Louis B. Marks, founder and first president of the Illuminating Engineering Society and inventor of the enclosed are lamp, used before Edison's invention of the incandescent lamp, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 92 years old and lived at the Lombardy Hotel on East 56th Street.

Spectacular orders by the Soviet Union for 97 new dry-cargo ships in the 15,000-ton class have moved that country from fifth to third place in world standing in the amount of new tonnage on order. British shipping sources report.

In a major expansion move the Green White Construction Company, general contractors, has leased the ninth floor with 34,000 square feet of space at 331 East 38th Street for 10 years. The 11-story and penthouse office building is at the northwest corner of First Avenue and 38th Street.

WASHINGTON, June 19 Law enforcement officials of many major cities are agreed that they will have to forgo the interrogation of indigent suspects rather than press for round-the-clock free legal counsel at the police station.

WASHINGTON, June 18 The National Commission on Food Marketing, which will recommend sweeping regulations of the food industry, has been accused of reaching a verdict without having developed supporting evidence.

LUCERNE, Switzerland, June 19 (Reuters) Pairs of women riders from Italy and the United States finished with faultless rounds today to win a team event against male competition at the Lucerne international horse show.

Robert Preston will be Mary Martin's leading man in the unconventional two-character musical, "I Do, I Do." The premiere has been scheduled for Nov. 15 at the 46th Street Theater. Trial engagements in Boston and Washington will start Sept. 26 and Oct. 18.

PARIS, June 19 One of the most spectacular presen tations of France's National Ballet Company is Tchaikovsky's "Casse-Noisette" seen Friday at the Opera Comique. The old Petipa ballet has been adapted by Michel Rayne and Pierre Rhallys and, music apart, the work bears little or no relationship with the Russian original.

ROME, June 19 A pontifical commission assigned by Pope Paul VI to study the problems of population, family and birth began a series of final discussions today on the Roman Catholic Church's stand on birth control.
WASHINGTON, June 19 The Senate Internal Security subcommittee charged tonight that Communists had played a key role in organizing campus demonstrations against the war in Vietnam.

Howard J. Samuels, who is seeking the Democratic nomination for Governor, accused Governor Rockefeller yesterday of "political opportunism and cowardice" in negotiations for a New York City tax program.

LONDON, June 19 Ravi Shankar, the virtuoso musician who introduced the sitar, an Indian stringed instrument, to Western concert audiences, is finding to his amazement that he has become a pop hero to the shaggy-haired youths who dote on the Beatles and the Rolling Stones.
BLOOMINGTON, Ind., June 19 Today, Bloomington. Tomorrow, the world. After that, Jim Ryun.

LE MANS, France, June 19 A quarter of a million Frenchmen watched the Fords go by today as the acquisitive, promotional Ford Motor Company won the Le Mans 24-hour sports car race. In pursuit of that goal, Ford had spent $9million in the last three years.
CHICAGO, June 19 (AP) A drive to gain control of Wilson Brothers, Inc., fell short yesterday as stockholders voted in support of the company's present management.

"I may be from west of the Hudson," Howard R. Leary mused the other day, "but that doesn't mean I'm a cowboy or an Indian." Nonetheless, when Mr. Leary forsook his home town of Philadelphia to become New York's Police ...

Dick McAuliffe hit two home runs one of which even he was joking about after the game to give the Detroit Tigers a 2-1 victory over the New York Yankees yesterday and disappoint most of the fans who made up the largest majorleague crowd of the season.
BANGKOK, Thailand, June 19 The non-Communist na tions of Asia are beginning to lay the foundation of a regional security system.

MASSENA, N.Y., June 19 (UPI) A 39-year-old man drove his four children to a field near his home here today, killed them with a 12-gauge shotgun and then turned the weapon on himself, the state police reported.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 19 Arnold Palmer saw a sevenstroke lead vanish and with it an immediate chance to win the United States Open golf championship today. As he dropped stroke by strike over the closing nine of the Olympic Country Club course for a 71, Bill Casper caught him with a 68 to duplicate Arnie's 72-hole total of 278.

The marriage of Miss Amy Lore Hoffmann, daughter of Mrs. Hugo Hoffmann of Riverdale, the Bronx, and the late Mr. Hoffmann, to Sylvain Edward Cappell, took place here last evening. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Cappell of the Bronx.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia The Bulgarian regime of Todor Zhivkov has demonstrated a new spirit of confidence and enterprise in the last six months.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., June 19 Mrs. Betty Hart MacIntyre, widow of Ezra MacIntyre and public relations director for the American Red Cross in White Plains, died yesterday at United Hospital. She was 61 years old and lived at 11 Oneida Street, Rye.

DETROIT, June 19--A new 38-gallery, wing of the Detroit Institute of Arts, doubling its exhibition space for 40 centuries of art, will be opened tomorrow night with a dinner for patrons and benefactors as the first event in a week-long celebration.
WASHINGTON, June 19 Coal vs. the atom a slowly developing battle that has suddenly intensified will draw the attention of the coal industry's top strategists here this week.

STRATFORD, Conn., June 19 In its past 11 seasons the artistic fortunes of the American Shakespeare Theater have fluctuated, but not very widely. To judge by productions I have seen, the movement has been more often down than up. The theater opened its 12th season last night, and the first play is somewhat low on the scale.
Miss Floris Flam, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Flam of New York, was married here yesterday to Joel B. Bergen, son of Mr. and Mrs. M. Marvin Berger of Jamaica Estates, Queens.

Trans World Airlines announced yesterday that it would continue to offer a special weekend excursion fare this summer aboard its jetliners between New York and the Hartford-Springfield area of Connecticut

VAGRANTS from the Bowery drink their dubious wine hard by the re mains of Peter Stuyvesant, and jazz played at the second oldest church in New York sometimes disturbs the residents. But the people who own houses in the Renwick Triangle think it a fine place to live.
SYDNEY, Australia, June 19 Lim Yew Hock, Malaysian High Commissioner (ambassador) to Australia, who had been missing for nine days, was returned to his home in Canberra today.

DOVER, N. J., June 19 The marriage of Miss Claudia Jan Schwarz to Eliot D. Feldman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lucian T. Feldman of Bernardsville, took place here today. Rabbi Z. David Levy performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney M. Schwarz, parents of the bride.

CINCINNATI, June 19 Faced with a chance to go as high as seventh place in the National League, the New York Mets went in the opposite direction today by losing a doubleheader to the Cincinnati Reds, 5-0 and 4-2.

When Nicholas Johnson was named Maritime Administrator two years ago, the young professor of administrative law announced that his chief qualification was a "fresh viewpoint." It quickly developed that he also had plenty of courage and a dynamic determination to scrape away the barnacles that have made the American merchant marine a steadily shrinking force in world commerce.

Livingstone L. Wingate, executive director of Haryou-Act, said yesterday that his beleaguered Harlem antipoverty organization was owed more money by the city than it owed the Federal Government in withholding taxes.

PITTSBURGH, June 19 (AP) Carlos Ortiz, the champion, meets Johnny Bizarro in a 15round lightweight championship fight at Civic Arena tonight. The bout, starting at 10 P.M., will be televised, with Channel 5 the outlet in New York.
The Liggett Myers TobacCo. Company has a new entry in the filter-cigarette derby Chesterfield Filter.
TEL AVIV, June 19 There young Israeli Jews were imprisoned today after being convicted of having spied for the United Arab Republic.
